title: Southern Governors Weigh New Primary System
Wetzel Leaves Suns
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Aug. 31 (AP) John Wetzel, 31 years old is leaving the Phoenix Suns of the National Basketball Association after a sevenyear career. I made the final decision about two days ago, he said today.

title: 21 Plants Told to Limit Heat
Low Nuclear Power Cost Cuts Public Service Rate
description: NEWARK, Aug. 31Electricity customers of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company will get lower bills in September because of the increased output of power from the Peach Bottom Nuclear Generating Station, the first reversal of the upward trend of electric rates since the oil embargo in 1974.

title: Seaport Museum Forced to Reduce Staff
description: The South Street Seaport Museum, beset by shortterm financial problems, is laying off nearly a third of its fulltime staff and virtually all of its parttime staff and is considering closing one day a week.

title: Picture Tube Imports Lose DutyFree Status
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI)Frederick B. Dent said today that dutyfree status for television picture tubes over 16 inches had been ended for Taiwan, South Korea, Brazil and Mexico.

title: Excerpts From Speech by Irish Leader Seeking Curbs on Terrorism
Frank Reece, 51, an Editor Of The Dallas Morning News
description: DALLAS, Aug. 31 (UPI)Frank D. Reece, assistant managing editor of The Dallas Morning News, died yesterday. He wa'S 51 years old.

title: Mexico to Float Peso
description: Mexico in effect devalued the peso by abandoning its 22yearold fixed parity with the United States dollar and allowing it to float in currency markets, a move that could have wide impact on American businesses in Mexico as well as on individuals who maintain savings accounts there. Page 49.

title: United Airlines Defends Chicago Security Service
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (UPI)United Airlines today defended its use of Andy Frain Security Services personnel to screen passengers boarding planes at O'Hare International Airport.

title: SENATE UNIT SEEKS EARLY GULF DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) The chairman of the Senate Ethics Committee said today he hoped the panel could issue a report before Congress adjourned on the Gulf Oil Company's contributions to members of the Senate.

title: Watershed Sale Rejected
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug, 31 (AP)A plan by the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company to sell 65 acres of its watershed land to Fairfield County was denied today by the State Health Department. The plan submitted to the State Public Heath Council called for using the land for open space and to expand Fairfield's golf course. We do not feel that's an appropriate use of the land, the acting deputy health commissioner, Dennis Kerrigan, said.

title: YiddishHebrew Strain Eased at Parley
Judge Says Cleveland's Schools Are Deliberately Segregated
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 31  A Federal district judge ruled today that this city's school system was deliberately segregated, and he left open the possibility that a solution could be integration with suburban schools.

title: Hays Reported on Verge Of Submitting Resignation
Regulatory Staff Report Backs Use of Plutonium
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 31The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has concluded that stoking the nation's atomic reactors with the controversial fuel plutonium would pose no special health problems and would be economically sound.

title: SeaLaw Conferees Hoping Kissinger Will Break Impasse
description: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 31Third  world negotiators are looking to Secretary Henry A. Kissinger to salvage some small gains from the stalemated Law of the Sea Conference.

title: Ray Barretto Leads First Latin Group At the Bottom Line
Homer By Nettles Helps Yanks Win
Medicaid, cont.
description: It is disappointing that Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare David Mathews reacted to the disclosures about widespread Medicaid abuses with the standard brand of bureaucratic defensiveness.

title: Radio
Question of Crowding
description: But the most troubling cluster of issues by far is raised by overcrowding. Attica is just about as crowded as it was in the summer of 1971, and the population in the system as a whole has risen from 14,500 in March 1975 to a projected 18,500 this fall. That kind of overcrowding virtually precludes humane control. Inmate proposals to deal with this and other problems are to put a fiveyear limit on most prison terms and an outside limit of ten years on all. They also propose improvements in parole, workrelease and furlough programs.

title: Kissinger Bids Africans Remain Confident in U.S.
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger appealed to black African leaders today not to give up hope that the United States and Britain could negotiate a formula that would end control by, the white minorities in Rhodesia and Southwest Africa without causing warfare.

title: Ford Park Proposal Perplexes Conservationists
Books of The Times
description: . . . blind, loose, untameable, superstitious, religious, execrable, whiskyswilling, frivolous, frank, amorous, ireful and gloating in war. This is how an early Welsh historian, Silvester Giraldus Cambrensus, saw the Irish. But while, in Mother Ireland, Edna O'Brien finds Cambrensus close enough to the truth to quote, she prefers concrete detail. And when she is in good form, nobody is better at choosing and rendering the concrete details, the defining gestures or speech, of men and women anywhere.

title: Notes on People
Israel Takes Military Steps
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 31Israel took military steps along its border with Lebanon today amid reports that friendly Lebanese had requested Israeli help in organizing the defense of their villages against Palestinian attacks. Censorship bars any detailing of the Israeli moves.

title: New Factory Orders Off 0.5% As Defense Bookings Decline
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) New factory orders fell 0.5 percent in July as a record decline in new defense bookings overshadowed a record increase in orders for nondefense capital goods, the Commerce Department said today.

title: No Further Penalty for Weiskopf
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 31 (AP)No disciplinary action is contemplated against Tom Weiskopf for his disqualification hr the American Golf Classic, Deane Beman, commissioner of the Professonal Golfers Association tour, said today.

title: BOYCOTT PENALTY OPPOSED BY FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31The Ford Administration adamantly refused today any compromise in its opposition to use the tax laws to penalize United States companies that comply with the Arab boycott of Israel.

title: Medicaid Mills Are Generally Cloaked in Anonymity
description: Despite the scandals that have swirled for years about socalled Medicaid mills in New York City, authorities do not know how many there are or who owns them, and are enjoined by a court from finding out.

title: Above the Rabble
description: BOSTONNo principle is more fundamental to democracy than that everyone has a right to his own opinion, and that everyone has a right to express it. Anyone has these rights no matter how wrong, how ignorant, how stupid he may be. Because we ought to be willing to die to defend this principle, we ought to take great care not to confuse it with a counterfeit version that maintains that anyone's opinion is as great as any other's.

title: MANY AT CITY U. ARE SEEKING AID
Pele and Cosmos to Begin Postseason Tour Tonight
description: The North American Soccer League season is over, but the New York Cosmos will be making money for another month or so. Pel and his teammates left for a tour of North America and Asia yesterday.

title: NORTHEAST BLOC URGED BY LABOR
Chicken and Mushroom Mayonnaise
description: 1. When the chicken is cool, remove it from the kettle. Take the meat from the bones. Remove the skin from the meat. Return the bones and skin to the kettle and continue cooking to reduce the broth to any desired strength.

title: U.S. Fears Halt in Service With Britain in Air Dispute
U.S. and Canada Reach Tennis Final
Reuss Shuts Out Padres on 4Hitter
description: Jerry Reuss, who has not won 20 games in his seven years in the major leagues and doesn't appear to be headed for that number this year, outdueled the major leagues first 20game winner last night.

title: Nose Knows Where Odors Are Coming From in Jersey
description: WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Aug, 31 (AP)Pollution inspectors let their noses lead them to the source of an odor that residents here have been complaining about for nearly a month.

title: Open Interest
Joan Copeland Set for New Comedy
description: Joan Copeland, who recently won critical praise as Vera Simpson in the Circle in the Square's revival of Pal Joey, will be a costar with Allen Swift in a new comedy, Checking Out. It will open Sept. 14 at the Longacre Theater.

title: TavernonGreen Reopens After $2.5 Million in Work
description: Bands, balloons, bikinied models and other assorted ballyhoo were served up in Central Park yesterday as the newly refurbished $2.5 million TavernontheGreen opened for business.

title: Mrs. Abzug Urged to Retract Repudiation of Moynihan
Ford Switches Nominations For Two F.C.C. Vacancies
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) President Ford said in a statement today that he was transposing the nominations of a Republican and a Democrat to the Federal Communications Commission.

title: UNDERCOVER DRIVE ON FRAUD IS URGED
description: TRENTON, Aug. 31Gerald J. Reilly, director of the state Medicaid program, said today, that while New Jersey had been praised for aggressively attacking Medicaid fraud, it might be a good idea to hire undercover agents to check for unscrupulous physicians within the program.

title: Flood Toll at 130
description: LOVELAND, Colo., Aug. 31 (AP)The number of known dead in the July 31 flood in Big Thompson Canyon has risen to 130 with the discovery of a woman's body by debris removal crews, the authorities reported. A data coordinator at the Loveland Disaster Center, said the death toll was expected to reach 156.

title: Upstate Utility Gives Cuts In Rates for OffPeak Use
description: ALBANY, Aug. 31Starting tomorrow, Gloria Arco is going to do her laundry before 10 o'clock in the morning and her dishes after 10 at night in an effort to save money by using electricity when the rates are at their lowest.

title: Soviet Union Buying More U.S. Wheat
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) The Soviet Union has bought an additional 275,000 metric tons of United States wheat valued at $34.6 million for delivery under a longterm agreement that takes effect this fall, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Beirut's Envoy Rebuffs Moscow On Interpretation of Civil War
Caution and Anxiety in Economic Lull
Soviet Won't Play Chile in Davis Cup
ABORTION STAND BY CARTER VEXES CATHOLIC BISHOPS
MEXICO ABANDONS FIXED PESO PARITY; Allows Currency to Float Against U.S. DollarTiming Is a Surprise; MEXICO ABANDONS FIXED PESO PARITY
Fateful Meeting
description: Aides say Secretary of State Kissinger will try to impress on South Africa's Prime Minister in Zurich this weekend that time is running out for nonviolent solutions in Rhodesia and Namibia (SouthWest Africa); and so it is. But the bell is also tolling for racial apartheid in South Africa itself, as Mr. Kissinger underscored yesterday when he promised a mostly black audience in Philadelphia that, in the meetings with John Vorster, we will use all our influence to bring about peaceful change, equality of opportunity and basic human rights in South Africa.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: Since last November, prospective buyers of individual retirement accounts marketed by banks, insurance companies and other financial institutions have been entitled to receive detailed information about the accounts before they purchase them, or, at the latest, on the day of purchase.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 31 (UPI)The price of gold fell to its lowest level in almost three years on the London bullion market today, but later recovered most of the loss. The dollar advanced against most continental currencies, but fell against the British pound, which firmed up substantially.

title: The Choice That Confronts France
Codd and Store Aides Discuss Arson
description: Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd met with 75 New York Cityarea departmentstore executives yesterday to explore ways of halting the rash of firebombings in the last month. The Commissioner said he would assign additional police officers to the case.

title: STOCKS RISE 4.82 AS TRADING GAINS
description: Stock prices posted their third advance in a row yesterday with gains showing in computer, defense, savings  andloan, retail, electronic and oilrelated issues.

title: FARM PRICES FELL 4% IN MIDMONTH
CableTV Journalism Offers a Taste of Gonzo Eric Shawn Focuses on Manhattan News
description: In the always percolating pot of television news, the lategt ingredient promising consumer satisfaction is being called Gonzo broadcast journalism. The label has been chosen, with not even a nod of attribution to its creator, Hunter Thompson, the. Rolling Stone magazine writer, by Eric Shawn, the 19yearold producer of Newswatch, a half hour that made its debut on Manhattan Cable's Channel 10 at 8 P.M. Monday. Or, this being cable, make that 8:05.

title: ContinuingEducation Schools Thrive
description: Schools of continuing education in the New York City area are establishing new courses in health services and paralegal and gerontological studies, among others, as the manpower needs of the economy and the age composition of the population change.

title: U.S. Aide Accuses Soviet on New Missile
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31The Ford Administration's top arms control official accused the Soviet Union today of attempting to alter the strategic nuclear weapons balance with the United States by introducing a new missile in Eastern Europe.

title: Yanks Sought Carty
CONFEREES ON TAX ASSAILED BY FORD
Corporation Affairs
description: Citing increased demand for aluminum, the Aluminum Company of America announced yesterday that it had scheduled reactivation of idle capacity at three plants in the next two months.

title: Forest Surrender
description: Although the Forest Service in the United States Department of Agriculture gives lip service to the multiple use concept in its management of the national forests, it has in recent decades put commercial logging first and relegated the other useswildlife habitat, outdoor recreation, wildernessto the sidelines. The ultimate expression of this contempt for the broader public interest is the increasing reliance on clear cutting instead of selective cutting in the management of forests.

title: Women's Bank President Expected to Resign Post
description: The First Women's Bank, which opened last October and has already replaced two of its four top officers, is preparing to announce that Madeline McWhinney, its president, is leaving, a spokesman for the bank said last night.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 1, 1976

title: DUBLIN PREPARES SWEEPING CURBS AGAINST THE I.R.A.
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 31The Irish Government moved today to increase drastically prison sentences for members of the Irish Republican Army and to impose emergency legislation to quell suspected terrorists. The proposed legislation was the most sweeping aimed at the I.R.A. in 50 years.

title: Carter And Labor
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31It hasn't been easy, but Jimmy Carter and George Meany have finally agreed on a strategy for winning the Presidential election of 1976: Mr. Carter will hold the South, and Mr. Meany will use the power of the labor unions of the A.F.L.C.I.O. to deliver the electoral votes of most of the big industrial states from Massachusetts, New York and New Jersey to Pennsylvania, Ohio and Illinois.

title: Vietnamese Who Fled by Boat Cite Grim Economic Situation
description: SINGAPORE, Aug. 31 (Reuters)Refugees from Vietnam said today that there were sewere shortages of food and of consumer and industrial products in the territory of former South Vietnam, which fell to Communist troops from North Vietnam in April 1975 and has since been merged with the North.

title: Amtrak and AutoTrain Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI)Amtrak signed an agreement today with the AutoTrain Corporation to combine its Floridian, a train now losing $6 million a year, with autoferry service between Louisville, Ky., and Sanford, Fla., for a sixmonth trial period. If the experiment, beginning daily service Oct. 31. is successful, Amtrak and AutoTrain will conChicago similar joint routes from Chicago to Denver and along the West Coast.

title: SOUTH AFRICA POLICE BREAK UP PROTESTS
description: CAPE TOWN, Aug. 31 (Reuters)The police used. tear gas to disperse demonstrators in two incidents today, but the black townships were reported quiet.

title: Amex Prices Rise In 3d Straight Day
description: Prices rose yesterday for the third consecutive session on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market.

title: Berle Plants State's Flag On L.I. Strip
Dr. Paul Lazarsfeld Dies
description: Dr. Paul Lazarsfeld, a Columbia University sociologist whose studies of American voting patterns and the influences of the printed and electronic press on society are classics in his field, died of cancer at New York Hospital on Monday, He was 75 years old.

title: BANK GUIDELINES WIDENED BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31The Securities and Exchange Commission, adopting guidelines for financial disclosure by bank holding companies, said today the banks would be expected to provide data on questionable loans for a fiveyear period instead of two years as it originally proposed last October.

title: 3 WIN NOMINATION IN GEORGIA RUNOFF
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 31 (AP)A banker, a former Congressional aide aind a State Representative won Democratic nominations for Congressional posts in Georgia runoff elections today.

title: Dole Predicts Carter Losses in the South
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 31 Senator Robert Dole, the Republican VicePresidential nominee, predicted here tonight, that Jimmy Carter would lose much of his Southern support as his liberal philosophy becomes more apparent.

title: White, a Rookie, Is Key to Vikings' Chances
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 31How can the destiny of an entire football team, as to its success or failure in the coming season, depend upon the ability of one 22yearold rookie player from Ruston, La., named Sammy White? This would be a fine football team of Super Bowl potential  the Minnesota Vikings.

title: Harrises Get Indeterminate Sentences
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31William and Emily Harris were given sentences today that could mean life imprisonment for their conviction of armed robbery, kidnapping and auto theft charges stemming from twoday trip here with Patricia Hearst in 1974.

title: Greek Dig Shows Anew That Myths Aren't All Mythical
description: NEMEA, GreeceAccording to Greek legend, the hero Hercules was given 10 dangerous tasks to perform by the goddess Hera. The first was to slay the lion of Nemea, a ferocious heast with an impregnable hide.

title: Attica: Some Questions
description: Attica is quiet now after a weeklong strike accompanied by tense negotiations, first between inmates and correctional authorities and then between groups of disagreeing inmates. Violence was averted partially because of the willingness of high state officials to come from Albany to deal with inmate girevances and partially, we suspect, because inmate memories run back five years to the bloody outcome of the first rebellion. Along with relief, the ruptured crisis has left a potful of troubling questions abOut future policies in corrections in this state.

title: Bridge:
description: A cowboy out of the old Wild West has been whooping it up along the country's bridge trails for the last nine months. He is Don Oakie, and he comes from San Jose, Calif., which is certainly West if not very wild. And he used to be a lumbermill operator, a tough rural occupation, even it not actually a bovine one.

title: Challenge of Jersey Trotters To Yonkers Starts Tonight
They're Off! Tonight at Meadowlands Race Track
N.F.L. Players Reject New Pact Offer
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP)Player representatives of the 28 National Football League teams rejected the owners latest contract offer tonight by tabling it.

title: Jimmy Cliff And Reggae In the Park
description: Jimmy Cliff's concert at the Schaefer Music Festival Monday night had its considerable virtues, but first a word about the weather: Outdoor concerts in New York are generally afflicted with mugginess or thunderstorms. Monday's clear, clean, cool night air would probably have made a quartet of singing critics sound good.

title: Wheat Futures Up Nearly 5c a Bushel On Deal by Russia
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) Wheat futures on the Chicago Board of Trade gained nearly 5 cents a bushel today.

title: Giants Hurt By Rumors Of Trade
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 31Almost every day now, Pat Hughes reacts or hears he has been traded to a team to he named later.

title: DUBLIN PREPARES SWEEPING CURBS AGAINST THE I.R.A.
Sarkis Flies to Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 31President  elect Elias Sarkis flew to Damascus today for discussions with the Syrian President, Iiafez alAssad, on future LebaneseSyrian relations and on ways for ending the 17 month Lebanese civil war.

title: ABITIBI TO LIFT PRICE OF PRINT $20 A TON
description: The Abitibl Paper Company announced yesterday that it would raise its price for newsprint sold in Canada and the United States by $20 a ton, effective Dec. 1.

title: College President Named
description: BRIDGEPORT. Conn., Aug. 31 (AP)Dr. Thomas P. Melady has been chosen as president of Sacred Heart University here, the school announced today. Dr. Melady, a former United States Ambassador to Burundi and Uganda, is now executive vice president and professor of politics at St. Joseph's College in Philadelphia. He will succeed Charles E. Ford, actig president, in late October.

title: McRae Holds Lead As a dh With .354
description: Kansas City's Hal McRae continues to lead American League designated hitters with a .354 average, according to figures released yesterday.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: About 2,000 members of the United Auto Workers Union in the state voted to strike a Ford Motor Company plant in Edison on Sept. 14 unless a contract settlement is reached, union officials said. Stephen Aniskevitch, president of Local 980, said the rank and file had voted, 1,35889 in favor of walking out to demand a better contract and to protecst layoffs at the assembly plant on Route 1.

title: Redskins Sign Grant, Receiver
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI)The Washington Redskins signed Frank Grant, a wide receiver, to a oneyear contract today, removing a thorn from the side of Coach George Allen.

title: DIRECTOR OF F.B.I. TARGET OF INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31Clarence M. Kelley, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, acknowledged today that he had been questioned by Justice Department investigators about possible misuse by him of Government services and property in his home.

title: Tenants in Luxury Apartments Protest Services
description: Disgruntled tenants in one of the city's most luxurious highrise buildings, the Sovereign, on Manhattan's East Side, met in their marblefloored lobby last night in an effort to organize a rent strike. Monthly rents in the building range from $1,700 to $2,700 an apartment.

title: Libya Curbs Egypt's Planes
description: CAIRO, Aug. 31 (UPI)The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar lelQaddafi, has ordered a ban on the refueling of Egyptian aircraft in Libyan cities, the newspaper Al Akhbar said today. Egyptair planes stop at Tripoli. the Libyan capital, the port of Benghazi and the town of Sebha, 400 miles south of Tripoli.

title: 3d Labor Pact Reached
description: The musicians' union last night joined the Radio City Music Hall's Rockettes and stagehands in agreeing to a oneyear costsaving contract, thus averting a threatened shutdown of the theater.

title: SOUTHERN AIR TIE TO EUROPE BACKED
description: WILLIAMSBURG. Va. Aug.31 Ten Southern Governors sent a strongly worded telegram to President Ford today urging him to grant direct airline routes between London and five Southern cities.

title: Housing Authority Acts To Cut Overtime Abuses
description: The New York City Housing Authoriy, damaged by an overtimefraud scandal in its elevatorrepair division, is instituting major changes in an effort to avoid such abuses in the future.

title: Aid for Miners' Widows
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI)The Senate Labor subcommittee approved today legislation providing automatic eligibility for black lung disease benefits for widows of men who worked in coal mines for 25 or more years.

title: About New York
description: Monday morningthe glorious day before yesterday, when New York decided to be perfect for a whilethe newspapers were full of President Ford's promises on parks. One and a half billion dollars is a lot of park promises.

title: Police Accused of Having Helped Provoke Bloody London Riot
Mr. Ford's Agenda
description: PHILADELPHIAThe Presidential debates of 1976 will have a large influence on the November election, and on the future of America.

title: Two Guilty of Fraud Say Medicaid Fosters Cheating
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 31Two New York City chiropractors who will soon begin serving fiveyear prison sentences for Medicaid fraud told a Senate subcommittee today how they built their Medicaid empire and why they had felt encouraged to cheat the Government.

title: American Party Candidates Designated for Ohio Ballot
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 31 (UPI)Ohio Secretary of State Ted Brown said today that he had authorized the names of Lester G. Maddox and William Dyke as official American Party candidates for President and Vice President on the state's Nov. 2 ballot.

title: Market Place
NYE PHARR, ARTIST AND ART DIRECTOR
description: Nye Pharr, an artist and former advertising art director, died of cancer on Monday in Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 1 Strawberry Hill in Stamford.

title: U.S. Six Bows to Soviet
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 31The creases were transformed into boxing rings, and center ice became a battlefield for spearing and elbowing tonight as Team USA and the Soviet Union's national team played an exhibition match here that had little to do with hockey.

title: Harrises Get Indeterminate Sentences
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31William and Emily Harris were given sentences today that could mean life imprisonment for their conviction of armed robbery, kidnapping and auto theft charges stemming from a twoday trip here with Patricia Hearst in 1974.

title: State Hearings Set On Sunday Stores
SENATE BREAKS ALLEN FILIBUSTER ON ANTITRUST BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31.The Senate broke a filibuster today against a major antitrust bill and apparently cleared the way for the measure's enactment before Congress adjourns.

title: Seewagen Wins
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 31 (UPI)Butch Seewagen, Columbia University coach, beat Eric Friedler of Evanston, Ill., 46, 60, 60, today and earned the right to represent the East in the American Express Challengers championship match. He will meet Dick Bohrnstedt, the West champion from Redlands, Calif., on Thursday at Forest Hills, with the winner getting $5,000.

title: Africans Ask U.N. Council to Impose Sanctions on South Africa
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Aug. 31The group of African countries today asked the Security Council to impose sanctions on South Africa to force it to relinquish its control of Namibia, r SouthWest Africa.

title: Advertising
description: When the Consolidated Cigar Corporation instituted its Miss Muriel election a year ago, there was a definite marketing reason: sales of the Muriel brand had flattened out.

title: A Nobel Biologist Supports Research In Genetic Synthesis
description: Dr. George Wald, the Nobel Prize  winning biologist who has been an active critic of genetics research using recombinant DNA, which he views as posing grave hazards, said he saw no such dangers in research on synthesized genes.

title: How the I.R.A. Evolved
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 31  The Irish Republican Army, the target of new antiterrorist moves by the Irish Government, grew out of the Irish volunteers who rebelled against British rule in 1916.

title: Goldin Warns City It Faces Penalties On Welfare Plans
Richards to Sue U.S.T.A. on Test
description: Dr. Renee Richards said yesterday she would sue the United States Tennis Association unless the association waived its sex chromosome test and admitted her to the United States Open championships as an alternate.

title: Wartime Mayor of Warsaw, Julian Kulski, Is Dead at 83
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Julian S. Kulski, former Presi, dent, or Mayor, of Warsaw during the Nazi occupation from 1939 to 1944, died in the Polish capital Aug. 18, his son said here today. He was 83 years old.

title: People and Business
description: A New York State Supreme Court Justice, George Postel, reserved decision yesterday on an effort by two minority stockholders of the MerrittChapman & Scott Corporation to force Louis E. Wolfson to show cause why he should not be ordered to repay $1.3 million in expenses he allegedly drew illegally from the company.

title: Busing Protesters Dispersed by Gas In Louisville, Ky.
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 31 (AP)The police used tear gas to disperse a crowd of more than 1,000 antibusing demonstrators tonight on the eve of the opening of Jefferson County schools for a second year under courtordered busing.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Youth Gangs: Dismantled Troubleshooters Of Banks and Equality

title: 2 Storms in Atlantic
description: MIAMI, Aug. 31 (AP)Two hurriednes, named Frances and Emmy, moved across the open Atlantic Ocean today, but fore casters said no land masses were threatened by either storm.

title: Veterans Cemetery Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) Alabama and Georgia members of Congress met today with officials of the Veterans Administration to urge the organization to support creation of a new national veterans cemetery at Fort Mitchell, Ala. An aide to Representative Jack Brinkley, Democrat of Georgia, said later that Richard Roudebuch, director of the Veterans Administration, and other officials were very, very receptive to the idea.

title: Uranium Price Plot Denied by French
description: PARIS, Aug. 31French officials denied today charges made in the United States that France was a member of a clandestine international cartel fixing artificially high prices for uranium.

title: Cyprus Jails ExPresident For 20 Years for Coup Role
description: NICOSIA. Cyprus, Aug. 31 (AP)Nicos Sampson, the terrorist who was made President of Cyprus for a week in the Greekled coup that temporarily ousted President Makarios in 1974, was sentenced today to 20 years in prison.

title: Buckley, Senator, Supports Wydler After Buckley, Columnist, Aids Rival
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I., Aug. 31Senator James L. Buckley and his younger brother, William F. Buckley, nomally have few differences politically, but when they do, their disagreement has political impact.

title: Swiss Militiamen (Whoops!) Invade Little Liechtenstein
description: BERN, Aug. 31 (AP)Seventyfive steelhelmeted Swiss militiamen set out one night last week on a maneuver with 50 horses, most of them pack animals, and soon discovered that they had invaded Liechtenstein.

title: Aboriginal Art a Hit in Albuquerque
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M.The stark, slender totem poles, painted in the familiar Southwest earthtones of brown, ocher and cream, seem very much at home in the adobe building on the edge of the airport. So do the hypnotic, rhythmic chants being piped through the room over loudspeakers.

title: Kuwaiti Moves Linked to Fear of P.L.O.
description: WASHINGTON Aug. 31Administration officials said today they believed the Kuwaiti Government's decision to suspend the National Assembly and to restrict the press was designed primarily to control the large Palestinian community in Kuwait.

title: Protest Besets a 3d New York Prison
description: Peaceful protests by inmates in state prisons spread to a third maximumsecurity institution in New York State yesterday as the Correction Commission convened an inquiry in Albany into the unrest that began at the Attica Correctional Facility on Aug. 23.

title: Question of Policy
description: But, the causes of street crime are too deep and complex to be dealt with simply by more and longer incarceration. As David Bazelon, Chief Judge of the Court Appeals for the District of Columbia, pointed out recently, If the present debates in corrections are aimed at making prisons less brutal and sentencing more fair, then the effort is worthwhile. But if they are aimed reducing crime, they are dangerously offtarget. They are dangerous because they encourage society to expect magic cures rather than facing the real causes of crime.

title: New Introductions To Offbeat Crafts
Savings Institutions Gave To Checking Bill Sponsor
description: ALBANY, Aug. 31Assemblyman George A. Cincotta, a Democrat from Brooklyn, who as chairman of the Assembly Banking Committee was a key sponsor of the bill that gave savings banks the right to offer checking accounts, has received campaign contributions from 62 savings banks this year, a check of financial records at the State Board of Elections here has shown.

title: People in Sports
description: The Colorado Rockies, @#@based in Denver, the newest @#@franchise in the National @#@Hockey League, named @#@Johnny Wilson as head coach @#@yesterday. The 47yearold @#@ native of Kincardine, Ontario, @#@coached the Cleveland Cru@#@saders of the World Hockey @#@Association last year. Wil@#@son played in the N.H.L. for @#@11 years, with the Rangers, @#@Detroit, Chicago and To@#@ronto. Ray Miron, general @#@manager of the Rockies, @#@said, Wilson works his play@#@ers hard and gets them in @#@super shape. That's impor@#@tant here because of the al@#@titude.

description: Lois Levine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip G. Levine of Ilerzlyia Pituach. Israel, was married yesterday evening to Joel Eisenman, son Of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Eisenman of Monsey, N. Y.

title: F.D.A. Considering A Ban On Common Food Colorings
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration is considering a ban on two widely used food colorings, it was learned today. One is the red used to color Mara schino cherries, the other is black used for licorice and jelly beans.

title: A Grand Jury Indicts Five Participants In Last Year's Summer Food Program
description: Five participants in last year's Summer Food Service Program to feed needy New York City children were indicted yesterday by a grand jury that has been investigating corruption in the federally financed program.

title: Kissinger Gives View On Seoul's Repression
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger was asked here tonight how the United States could reconcile its strong support of South Korea with that Government's repressive policies, including the sentencing of 18 political opponents over the weekend.

title: DIRECTOR OF F.B.I. TARGET OF INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31Clarence M. Kelley, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, acknowledged today that he had been questioned by Justice Department investigators about possible misuse by him of Government services and property in his home.

title: Something Is Up With Pop Tabs
Instant Lottery Begins In New York Next Week
description: The New York State Lottery, which was suspended by Governor Carey last October because of mismanagement, will resume next Wednesday with prizes ranging from a $2 return to $1,000 a week for life, with a minimum payoff of $1 million for the top prize.

title: Dr. Melvin A. Hammarberg, Minnesota Lutheran Head
description: ST. PAUL, Aug. 31 (AP)Dr. Melvin A. Hammarberg died here yesterday of cancer, one day before the effective date of his resignation as president of the Lutheran Church in America, Minnesota Synod. He was 64 years old.

description: In Porno Chicsuch movies as Emmanuelle and The Story of Othe action is given a lush romantic treatment, and the clothes, no longer on the actors, seem to he draped over the cameras: hence the misty effect.

description: LAKESIDE, Conn., Aug. 31  Replacing a graduated starter is never easy, but Coach Bill Campbell of Columbia has an especially difficult road ahead of him in locating a replacement for Doug Jackson, the Lions top league rusher ever and last season's Ivy League player of the year.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) A Justice Department lawyer urged a Federal judge today to reject a consumer move to upset a temporary Agriculture Department rule that allows processors to blend mechanically ideboned meat, including groundup bone, into hot dogs and other foods.

description: Bands, balloons, bikinied models and other assorted ballyhoo were served up in Central Park yesterday as the newly refurbished $2.5 million TavernontheGreen opened for business.

title: New York City Sewage Cited in Study of Algae
description: A study commissioned by a New Jersey legislator concluded Monday that the offshore area where New York City dumps its sewage sludge might have spawned the mass of algae that had been plaguing the Jersey shore this summer.

title: Finley's Money Offer the Key To Future of 6 Unsigned A's
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 31 Oakland's Unsigned Six became the Unsigned Seven with the acquisition by the A's of Willie McCovey, but one more potential free agent isn't going to cause any drastic changes in the life and times of Charles O. Finley.

title: Kissinger Bids Africans Remain Confident in U.S.
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger appealed to black African leaders today not to give up hope that the United States and Britain could negotiate a formula that would end control by the white minorities in Rhodesia and SouthWest Africa without causing warfare.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Government of Ireland moved against the Irish Republican Army by proposing a drastic increase in penalties for I.R.A. membership and emergency legislation to quell terrorists. Prime Minister Liam Cosgrave told the Irish Parliament that the I.R.A. represented a direct challenge to the nation and called it an armed organization dedicated to the overthrow of the state's institutions. He said its crimes had discredited the name of Irishmen and brought death and damage to our own people. Although the main opposition party announced opposition to some proposals. Government officials were confident of enactment by midSeptember. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: About Education
Time Stands Still at an OldEnglish Inn In a Hilly Jungle of Northern Malaysia
Taking It Easy on Labor Day
description: The most obvious way to eliminate labor from a Labor Day feast is to assemble an assortment of good things in advance. It has long been our contention, in fact, that some of the best dishes in the world are those that bear the unseemly and unpalatable label leftovers. Two of the merest cases in pointare roast turkey and roast beef (or even roast pork, for which there is a recipe on this page). We likethem piping hot from the oven, but how much more delectable we find them the day after, thinly carved and tucked between slices of a good bread, smeared with freshly made mayonnaise. That and a pickle. Omar, the tentmaker, probablynever knew his paradise enow.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Aug. 31Construction of 1,001 apartments for the elderly in six New Jersey communities will begin shortly as a result of the sale of almost $66 million in bonds, the State Housing Finance Agency announced today.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 More than 3,000 clergymen and job trainers of the Opportunities Industrialization Centers vowed today to push for passage of a pending bill in Congress that would allow community groups to train and provide jobs for a million unemployed persons in the next four years.

title: Connors, Chris Evert Favored As Richest Open Begins Today

description: HAVE SOME Those attractive flowers behind the Times Square Theater Center on Duffy Square are up for grabsan orderly procedure of acquisition will take place tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 2 P.M. If you line up and await your turn, you can take your pick of some 160 uprooted marigold plants and 12 dozen cultured geraniums, all transferred to small pots and ready for transplanting at home.

title: 2 Die in German Bus Crash
description: ROSENHEIM, West Germany, !Aug. 31 (UPI)A bus spun out of control and overturned on highway near here today, killing two women passengers and injuring 29 other persons, the police said. The bus was carrying vacationers from Duisburg in the Rhineland to St. Veit in Austria.

description: Lured by the presence of Jimmy Carter, some exceptionally welltodo New Yorkers pulled up in their ,chauffered limousines to an East 69th. Street town house last night and gave money to the Democratic. National Committee that the committee will, in turn. he able to give to the CarterforPresident campaign.

title: Viking Experiments In Biology on Mars Called Inconclusive
description: PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 31 (UPI)A scientist, summing up a review of the Viking 1 landing craft's findings on the Martian surface, said today that the results of the biology experiments were inconclusive and not understood.

description: Bismarck, by Alan Palmer (Scribner's, $12.50). Bismarck myth dissected.

title: CARTER DISCLOSES DIVESTITURE PLAN
description: PLAINS, Ga., Aug. 30If he is elected President, Jimmy Carter says, he plans to dispose of his stocks, divest himself of his peanut business and divert royalties from his popular auto(biography to a philanthropic foundation.

title: Benjamin M. McKelway, ExEditor in Washington
description: Benjamin M. McKelway, retired editor of The Washington Star and a former president of The Associated . Press, died Monday of kidney failure at Sibley Hospital in the nation's capital. He was 80 years old.

title: STEEL UNION BACKS NOSTRIKE ACCORD
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 31The United Steelworkers of America convention turned back a challenge today to the union's nostrike agreement in the basic steel industry, which the leadership calls the capstone of its achievement and dissidents call a sellout of the membership.

description: TRENTON, Aug. 31The weather was beautiful in downtown Trenton todaymuch too nice a day to work.

title: Mexico to Float Peso
description: Mexico in effect devalued the peso by abandoning its 22yearold fixed parity with the United States dollar and allowing it to float in currency markets, a move that could have wide impact on American businesses in Mexico as well as on individuals who maintain savings accounts there. Page 49.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31Representative Wayne L. Hays, who until three months ago was one of the most powerful members of Congress, was on the verge of resignation tonight, according to sources on Capitol Hill.

title: Union Assails Ford Motor's Pay Offer
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Aug. 31The Ford Motor Company offered the United Automobile Workers today a wage rise of 3 percent a year over the next three years. That would raise the weekly pay of an automobile assembler to more than $7 an hour in 1979.

title: $412.8 BILLION LID ON BUDGET BACKED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31The Senate Budget Committee proposed today a ceiling of $412.8 billion on Federal spending for the fiscal year starting Oct. 1, leaving a deficit of $50.8 billion.

title: Instant Lottery Begins In New York Next Week
description: The New York State Lottery, which was suspended by Governor Carey last October because of mismanagement, will resume next Wednesday with prizes ranging from a $2 return to $1,000 a week for life, with a minimum payoff of $1 million for the top prize.

description: RIDGECREST, Calif., Aug. 31 (UPI)Two Navy jet fighters collided in flight yesterday, showering flaming debris within 500 yards of a residential area on the edge of the city limits. Three crewmen apparently ejected safely and were taken to the China Lake Naval Air Facility hospital for examination.

description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug 31 (Reuters)Black nationalist guerrillas attacked a military camp in northeastern Rhodesia yesterday and severely wounded six Rhodesian soldiers, a Government statement said today.

title: A Record Channel Swim
description: FOLKESTONE, England, Aug. 31 (Reuters)  A student teacher, Wendy Brooks, 20, of Yorkshire, England, set a new would record today for swimming the English Channel. Her time of eight hours 56 minutes took 29 minutes off the record established only three weeks ago by an American teenager, Tina Bischoff of Columbus, Ohio.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Arrested In Mausoleum Door Thefts
description: A 33yearold Brooklyn man who the police said turned himself in was arrested yesterday in connection with a recent theft of bronze mausoleum doors in Queens. Only five days earlier a 19yearold man was arrested in the theft of such doors from a Brooklyn cemetery. The police said the two cases were linked.

description: A United Press International dispatch published in The Times on Sunday misquoted Dr. George Wald, a prominent biologist, on the synthesis of genes. A corrective article appears on page 32.

title: Market Basket
description: Reversing a twoweek trend. the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City last week rose 1.2 percent above the previous week's level, according to the Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: From the Ballet World, Leg Warmers for All
description: Now and then classical ballet dancers have unwittingly inspired something of a vogue for the way they look, for what they wear. Remember all those ballerina slippers that used to go pattering along the street on people who wouldn't know an entrechat if they saw one? The socalled ballerina skirt was also all over the place.

title: Election Issue Shelved
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, Aug. 31 (AP)Delegates to a constitutional conference today shelved a resolution call ing for free elections in South West Africa.

title: $13,000 Extortions In Grain Industry Laid to 3 in Union
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 31Three present or former officials of a waterfront union were charged by. a Federal grand jury here today with conspiring to extort $13,330 from several small grain companies over a fiveyear period.

title: Exxon Pays $100,000 Fine
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) The Exxon Corporation has paid $100,000 for discharging 500,000 gallons of waste water in Alaska's Beaufort Sea, the largest civil penalty for violation of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act of 1972, the Environmental Protection Agency said today. The discharge of polluted water came from Exxon's exploratory drilling operations in the. Beaufort Sea last summer.

title: Dean Explains Role In Bergman Defense
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 1 During the summer, many Hofstra University law students have been angered and bewildered over what their dean has done, and they have worried that the image of their school may be tarnished.

BRITAIN UTILIZED A CREDIT IN JUNE
description: The British Government in June had to draw some 20 percent of the $5.3 billion shortterm credit provided that month by the major industrialized nations, officers of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday in their semiannual report on United States Treasury and Federal Reserve foreign ex change operations.

title: Toronto a Favorite City of Detroit
description: TORONTOThe train was almost four hours out of Windsor, Ont., when the firsttimers from Detroit, tense with anticipation, craned for their first glimpse of Toronto. the iewel of the Great Lakes.

description: The Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust, the real estate investment trust whose 1975 deficit exceeded $166 million, cut its losses substantially in the fiscal year ended last May 31, according to its annual report yesterday.

title: It Started With Xrays
description: NORTH OLMSTED, Ohio  Letters of the alphabet, like words, enjoy periods of relative importance and obscurity. The letter m, for instance, was snatched from impending oblivion by Vergil and popularized in such memorable expressions as magno misceri murmure. . . . As a result, the letter still occupies a central position in our alphabet.

title: Direct Mail Marketing vs. Privacy
description: The Direct Mail/Marketing Association invited Eleanor Guggenheimer, Commissioner of New York City's Department of Consumer Affairs, to address the group at its annual List Day meeting in New York. And she pulled no punches in telling the organization that the way mailing lists are compiled could constitute an invasion of privacy.

title: GEORG NEUMANN, 77
description: Georg Neumann, a pioneer in the field of audio recording, died at his home in West Berlin last Thursday, it was learned here. He was 77 years old.

title: Senators Shelve A Plan for Ending Peanut Controls
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) The Senate Agriculture Committee today shelved a compromise bill to end peanut acreage controls and reduce crop price supports, but farm leaders still plan to press for a vote on the House floor.

title: Beame Testifies 5 Hours At S.E.C Finance Inquiry
description: Mayor Beame spent five and a half hours in testifying before the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday as part of an investigation that many experts said would produce recommendations for drastic nationwide changes in municipal finance, and might also lead to potentially explosive political problems for local politicians.

title: F H. MUELLER, 82
description: Frederick H. Mueller, who served as Secretary of Commerce under President Eisenhower, died at a hospital in Sarasota, Fla., on Tuesday. He was 82 years old.

title: HAYS, UNDER FIRE, QUITS HOUSE SEAT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1  Representative Wayne L. Hays, under fire since the disclosure earlier this year of his sexual involvement with one of .his employees, resigned.today after Often controversial and sometimes colorful Years of service in the House.

title: Carter and the Bishops
description: The dialogue between the Roman Catholic hierarchy and Jimmy Carter on the issue of abortion has left the candidate's stand inconclusive. The discussion with six Catholic Bishops ended as it began. Mr. Carter maintained his personal opposition to abortion, but he declined, as he has consistently done, to support a constitutional amendment that would repeal the Supreme Court decision affirming the right of women to undergo such operations. He said, however, that he would not oppose efforts by others to so amend the Constitution.

title: Books of The Times
Reaction Called Muted
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) Mr. Hummel said there were clear indications the Soviet Union and China were displeased by the North Korean attack in the Korean demilitarized zone. He noted that Soviet and Chinese information media had been very restrained in their handling of the issue, adding that Moscow and Peking gave it only limited attention and confined themselves to quotes from the North Korean press, avoiding any editorial comment of their own.

title: Winner Prepared For His Big Match
description: Six days before Billy Martin came to Forest Hills, he knew he would be coming to play Harold Solomon in the first round of the United States Open tennis tournament, He figured the match would be held on the center court. He had to get ready.

title: HERSHEY PAYMENTS DISCLOSED IN STUDY
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation said that an investigation of its operations showed that $29,000 in illegal domestic and foreign payments had been made between 1971 and 1975.

title: Census Director Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) President Ford accepted today the resignation of Vincent P. Barabba of Suitland, Md., who has been director of the Census Bureau since 1973. The President also accepted the resignation of Carlyle E. Maw as Undersecretary of State for Coordinating Security Assistance Programs. No successors were named immediately for either posts.

title: Louisville Busing Program Resumes Without Incident
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 1Public schools here opened today free of the violence and open resentment that permeated many sections of this city last fall when school officials began implementing a controversial countywide school desegregation program.

title: Gasoline Found Ample For Holiday Weekend
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP)Motorists should have no trouble finding gasoline during the Labor Day weekend, although they may pay a slightly higher price, the American Automobile Association said today.

title: Belfast Party Building Burns
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Thursday, Sept. 2 (Reutcrs)A fire of unknown origin destroyed the headquarters of the Official Unionist Party here early today. A party member said that files and documents had been lost in the blaze.

title: 6 Retired Police Officers Hired As Public School Consultants
description: The Board of Education has hired six former police officers, five of whom are receiving retirement pensions, as $75aday consultants for the board's school security program, contravening a City Charter provision on employment of pensioners.

description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 1Armed Lebanese Christian villagers today beat off a renewed attack by Palestinian guerrillas close to the Israeli border, according to reports from the frontier area.

title: Vote for New York
description: After a generally lethargic summer, New Yorkers are heading into the final critical weeks of a primary election campaign that could significantly influence the ability of this city and state to survive acute fiscal crises and move toward economic recovery.

title: Yugoslav Player Going Back Home
description: BOSTON, Sept. 1 (UPI)Drazen Dalipagic, the Yungoslav Olympic star, will not be playing in the National Basketball Association this season. Instead, he will return to school in Yugoslavia and spend his spare time learning English.

title: Now: The Ripcord Olympics
description: It's been exactly a month since the Olympic Games ended and everybody left Montreal to go home and, filled with international good will, to count their gold medals: 47 for the Russians, 40 for the East Germans, 34 for the Americans and zero for the athletes of the 15 countries that got shut out.

title: W.A. Cameron Weds Katharine T. Forkner
description: Katharine Torrey Forkner and William Allan Cameron, a partner in the law firm of Carter, Ledyard & Millburn, were married yesterday afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. George A. Pera performed the ceremony.

title: Canada Beats U.S For Stevens Cup
description: The United States was upset by Canada, 21, in the final of the Stevens Cup international senior team tennis tournament yesterday at Tennisport. It was the first time the United States had been defeated since the cup's inception in 1964.

title: Siderowf Gains in U.S. Golf
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 1 (AP)The British Amateur champion, Dick Siderowf, beat the son of an old friend today and advanced to the third round of the United States Amateur golf championship.

description: BASEBALL

title: U.S.T.A. Firm on Dr. Richards
description: In response to Dr. Renee Richards's threat to sue the United States Tennis Association, Stan Malless, president, responded yesterday by saying in effect, Just try it.

title: INFLATION ROPES LIFT AMEX PRICES
description: Prices continued to advance on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, with the exchange's marketvalue index rising 0.43 point to 102.41, its fourth gain in a row.

title: A Railroad Offers Vans to Commuters To Reduce Service
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1(AP)The Southern Paciic Railroad, hoping to discourage commuters from using its trains and thus running up its deficit, wants to give away 1,000 airconditioned vans costing $6,000 each to commuters who each agree to drive eight other commuters to work.

title: Argentine Junta Is Planning Drive to Revive Country
description: BUENOS AIRES Sept. 1The military junta that took power in Argentina five months ago has had a large measure of suc cess in destroying leftwing guerrilla organikations and in restoring economic order

title: A's Defeat Yanks, 50, Behind Blue
Sweden's America's Cup Challenger Gets Christened
description: STENUNGSUND, Sweden, Sept. 1 (AP)Queen Silvia of Sweden, accompanied by her husband, King Carl XVI Gustaf, christened Sverige, the revolutionary computerdesigned Swedish challenger for the America's Cup yachting series, during a ceremony at this west coast fishing village today.

title: Advertising
description: Perhaps 100 different companies are now manufacturing a negativeheel shoe, in which the heel is lower than the toe. So when Levine, Huntley, Schmidt, Plapler & Beaver Inc. acquired the advertising account for Earth shoes two months ago, it recognized that a new approach would be helpful in stimulating sales.

title: President Gets Bill to Open Agency Sessions to Public
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Smile 50 Federal boards would be required to conduct most of their business in public under a sunshine bill that Congress has sent to President Ford. Mr. Ford has said that basically he agrees with the philosophy of such legislation.

title: SEOUL PHONE LINES TO NORTH CUT OFF
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 1Some of the special communications lines through which South Koreans and North Koreans have regularly exchanged messages have stopped functioning, South Korean officials confirmed today.

title: ExAide of Chemical Bank Is Charged in Embezzling
description: A former Chemical Bank official and five other men were charged in Manhattan yesterday with embezzling and misapplying almost $1.145 million of bank funds through a series of improper loans.

title: Israelis Face Sharp Rise In Prices After Holidays
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 1Israelis, beset by rising inflation and burdened with some of the highest taxes in the world, will soon be paying more for basic commodities ranging from bread to Public transportation.

title: U.S. OFFERS HELP ON SEABED MINING
Albany Plans Hatchery On a Contaminated Lake
description: New York State is planning to build a $10million salmon hatchery on Lake Ontario to benefit sports fishermen, even though officials of the Department of Environmental Conservation have been warned for the last year by their own scientists and others that fish from the lake are not safe to eat because of excessive contamination with toxic chemicals, including Mirex.

title: JohnsManville Plans to Lift Asbestos Prices 14% Jan. 1
description: The JohnsManville Corporation said yesterday that it planned to increase tis price on all gradesof asbestos fiber by 14 percent effective Jan. 1.

title: Gold Mine Work Suspended
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 (Reuters)The Homestake Mining Company said it was suspending operations at the Mount Charlotte gold mine near Kalgoorlie, western Australia, because of the recent substantial decline in gold prices.

title: FORD AND CARTER TO MEET SEPT. 23 IN FIRST DEBATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1President Ford and Jimmy Carter will debate domestic and economic issues for 90 minutes on national television Sept. 23 under an agreement reached here today by their representatives.

title: A Case of Too Much Too Soon
SORGHUM FUTURES ARE TRADED AGAIN
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 1Traders were once again shouting their bids for sorghum futures contracts today on the Kansas City Board of Trade as a market for the coarse gain used as livestock feed was resumed after a hiatus of 43 months.

title: Chinese Leadership In a Show of Unity At QuakeAid Rally
description: PEKING, Sept. 1At a meeting today honoring earthquake relief workers, Prime Minister Hua Kuofeng led a show of political unity among the Chinese leadership and delivered his most important public speech since he assumed office five months ago.

title: CARTER'S STATE INVADED BY DOLE
Meat Union Reaches Accord With Union on 3Year Pact
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (AP)A tentative threeyear contract that could set a pattern in the meat packing industry has been reached in talks between the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen and Wilson & Company.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Sept. 1New Jersey Medicaid is spending $600,000 to develop a new system to catch fraud and abuse in the $500 millionayear program. It involves a more complex computer to keep track of patients and health facilities.

title: Market Place
description: Early Tuesday afternoon, when the Treasury Department offered $2 billion of fouryear notes for sale, investors were surprisingly eager to buy them. When orders were tabulated, it turned out that the purchasers were willing to accept yiellds as low as 6.90 percent, well below expectations.

title: Film: Bawdy Tom Jones
GUS S. WORTHAM, 85
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 1 (UPI)  Gus S. Wortham, a founder of the American General Life Insurance Company and a contributor to many Texas politicians, died today. He was 85 years old.

title: Cohabitation and the Courts: The Stigma Is Beginning to Fade
description: American courts, respond ing to the sexual revolution, have begun to remove the stigma of judicial disapproval in sonic cases involving the increasing numbers of men and women living together while remaining unmarried.

title: No Midnight Librarians
description: The unanimous decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, covering the Middle West, should place school boards in every section of the country on notice that it is not their function or right to some books from school library shelves which, for some reason, displease them.

title: Yonkers Crowd Smallest of Meeting As Racing Begins at Meadowlands
description: YONKERS, Sept. 1  As had been expected, Yonkers Raceway tonight found the competition from New Jersey's Meadowlands injurious to its attendance and handle as it played host to its smallest crowd of the meeting.

title: HEARING BEGINS IN DOCTOR'S CASE
description: NEWARK, Sept. 1A hearing officer for the State Board of Medical Examiners convened a hearing today on the board's charges of malpractice against Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, a surgeon who was accused by Bergen County grand jury last May of murdering five patients at Riverdell Hospital in Oradell a decade ago.

title: Discovering the Parks
description: Public opinion polls consistently report that conditions in the national parksand conservation issues generally are of concern to a wide spectrum of voters. It is not surprising, therefore, that as President Ford seeks to win election in his own right, he should manifest a sudden enthusiasm for the national parks.

title: Soviet Ship in Collision
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 1 (Reuters)The Turkish submarine Dumlupinar collided with the 8,151ton Soviet merchant ship Fizik Vavilov in the DarSdanelles today, the Defense Ministry reported. There were no casualties, a ministry statement said.

title: Chemical Blast Hurt Nuclear Plant Worker
description: RICHLAND, Wash., Sept. 1 (AP)  A worker contaminated with radiation in a chemical explosion at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation has problems with his vision, nitric acid burns on his skin and possible internal radiation contamination, his doctor said today.

title: Mets Records
description: BATTING

title: Loss of Jobs in New York City Shows a Big Reduction
Now: The Ripcord Olympics
description: It's been exactly a month since the Olympic Games ended and everybody left Montreal to go home and, filled with international good will, to count their gold medals: 47 for the Russians, 40 for the East Germans, 34 for the Americans and zero for the athletes of the 15 countries that got shut out. If you've been fretting lately how you would while away the next four years on the diplomatic front until the next Olympics, there's good news today: You won't have to wait. More than 500 worldclass performers from 40 nations are now packing their gear for a postOlympic fling, and they will surface in Rome next week for another fortnight of international competition. The weapons: parachutes at 2,300 feet, straight down.

title: President Gets Bill to Open Agency Sessions to Public
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1Some 50 Federal boards would be required to conduct most of their business in public under a sunshine bill that Congress has sent to President Ford. Mr. Ford has said that basically he agrees with the philosophy of such legislation.

title: Series Schedules Sunday Night Game
description: The second game of the 1976 World Series will be played at night on Sunday, Oct. 17, as a oneyear experiment, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn announced yesterday. The decision to shift the game time was made to allow more fans to watch and listen to the game, a statement from the commissioner's office said.

title: New Milford Woman Slain After Abduction at a Mall
The African Kissinger
description: It is hard to avoid skepticism when Henry Kissinger calls for majority rule in southern Africa and says the United States, in acting there, must be true to its own beliefs. For in the Nixon years he played a large part in tilting American policy toward the redoubts of white supremacy in Africa.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 1 (UPI)Gold staged a modest recovery on European bullion markets today, while the dollar fell against all currencies except the British pound.

title: Farm Union Clashes With Castle &
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 A contractnegotiation dispute between the United Farm Workers and one of the nation's largest mushroom growers has been smoldering near here for weeks.

title: KEENAN TO ABIDE BY SAYPOL RULING
description: John F. Keenan, the special state prosecutor, said yesterday that he would not appeal a recent court decision transferring the indictment of Justice Irving H. Saypol of State Supreme Court to the Manhattan District Attorney's office.

title: DOW IS UP BY 1221 FOR 985.95 CLOSE
description: The stock market scored its best gain since midJune yesterl day as the Dow Jones industrial average advanced 12.21 points to reach 985.95 in steppedup trading.

title: People and Business
MALCOLM IN LINE FOR HOSPITAL JOB
description: The New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation is expected to name Correction Commissioner Benjamin Malcolm a senior vice president in charge of personnel and labor relations within the next two weeks.

title: Chess:
description: Anatoly Karpov was dissatisfied with his play in the Torneo del Vino in Montilla, Spain, despite his easy victory without a loss. Chagrined over the many errors in his games, he shook his head ruefully and said: After every, move, the games changed hands. I would be winning effortlessly, then make one mistake, answered by a compensating mistake by my opponent, then make another and so on. I could have been on a seesaw.

title: DELAWARE SALES IN LOTTERY HIGH
description: DOVER, Del., Sept. 1 (AP)Delaware began its controversial football lottery games today with hopes of turning a profit during the National Football League season and indicadims that many fans and some other state lotteries will be watching to see if court officials call a halt to the sports betting games.

title: Two Buffalo Men Sentenced On Manslaughter Charges
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 31 (AP) Two young Buffalo men have been sentenced to up to 10 years in prison after they pleaded guilty to secnddegree manslaughter.

title: VIETNAM BIDS U.S. LET IT ENTER U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 1Vietnam appealed to the United States today not to veto its application for membership in the United Nations. And said American acquiescence to its admission would improve the atmosphere for talks between Hanoi and Washington to normalize relations.

title: The Medicaid Scandal
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1When a scandal breaks over a Government program, the reflex of officials seems to be to pass the blame. The report by a Senate committee this week of rampant fraud and waste in the Medicaid. program provided a case in point. The committee, headed by Senator Frank E. Moss, Democrat of Utah, found poor management of Medicaid over the years by Federal, state and local administrators. F. David Mathews, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, accused Senator Moss of grandstanding and laid part of the blame on Congress. In New York, city and state officials blamed each other.

title: CRISIS PROSECUTOR OPPOSED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Three prominent persons instrumental in bringing the Watergate scandal to a conclusion testified today against a Senatepassed bill to create a permanent office to prosecute wrongdoing by top officials.

title: Thomas H. McKoy Jr., Led Steeplechase Association
description: Thomas Hall McKoy Jr., a sportsman and a retired Philadelphia banker, died yesterday at the home of a daughter, Linda Stewart, in Rumson, N.J. Mr. McKoy was 83 years old and a resident of Hobe Sound, Fla.

title: Freeze on Rates Voted
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP)  Congress acted today to protect workers against higher) taxes for another two weeks.1

title: Jersey Watermelon Thief May Get Painful Surprise
description: METUCHEN, N.J., Sept. 1 (AP)The search for a thief who made off with 20 watermelons growing on a lot here has proved fruitless.

title: Grand Jury Inquiry Called In Parole of Crime Leader
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 1 (AP)Attorney General Julius C. Michaelson said today that he would impanel a grand jury to investigate a reported attempt to influence the parole of Raymond L. S. Patriarca, a reputed New England crime leader.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Sea Law: Pitfalls of U.S. Concessions

title: House Bars a Rise in Congressional Pay
MICHIGAN MOVES TO PREVENT FIRES
description: SENEY, Mich., Sept. 1A ban against cigarette, cigar and pipe smoking outside residences, and buildings and outside vehicles on public roads in all the northern twothirds of Michigan went into effect at noon today on orders of Gov. William G. Milliken.

title: Toronto a Favorite City of Detroit
President Warns Nation On Unilateral Troop Cut
description: WASHINGTON Sept. 1  President Ford warned today against any unilateral troop withdrawals or reductions in defense spending by the United States and seemed to include his rival, Jimmy Carter, among the voices of retreat.

title: Airline Wheel Cover Falls
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 1 (AP) A 250pound wheel cover fell off a Delta Air Lines jet shortly after takeoff yesterday, falling 3,000 feet onto a busy street five minutes before a nearby high school let out, the police said. No one was injured and Delta flight 920 with 182 passengers on board continued to Atlanta without further incident, the authorities said.

title: Rising Laborite Says Change Appeals to Her Most in Politics
description: LONDON, Aug. 30She is an ascendant and highly popular politician, a potential Labor Party leader, a socialist who deftly avoids combative ideology and enacts, instead, a moderate role in the still fiercely divisive debate between the social classes, the political parties, trade unions and management.

title: Albany Plans Hatchery On a Contaminated Lake
description: New York State is planning to build a $10million salmon hatchery on Lake Ontario to benefit sports fishermen, even though officials of the Department of Environmental Conservation have been warned for the last year by their own scientists and others, that, fish from the lake are not safe to eat because of excessive contamination with toxic chemicals, including Mirex.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 2,1976

title: Foundations Get Real and Unreal Pleas for Aid
description: There are serious and reputable people wanting money from foundations. And then there are, the other people, whose bats are in hand and whose Minds seem to have wandered while the lid was off.

title: Police Pass Hat for Injured Mascot
description: About 90 Brooklyn traffic policemen have taken up a collection for Clarence, their mascot, whose sense of traffic is not nearly as good as his master's.

title: A HOUSE CANDIDATE KILLED IN AIR CRASH
St. Ives Is Entertaining Crime Film
FORD AND CARTER TO MEET SEPT. 23 IN FIRST DEBATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 President Ford and Jimmy Carter will debate domestic and economic issues for 90 minutes On national television Sept. 23 under an agreement reached here today by their representatives.

title: Giants Sign Snead Again
description: Norm Snead, who once replaced Fran Tarkenton as a Giant and then was replaced by Craig Morton, yesterday became a New Yorker again. He signed on as backup to Morton following the knee injury Tuesday to Jerry Gotsteyn, who has been placed on the 16day inactive list.

title: Scientists Drilling In Floor of Atlantic For Fresh Water
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass., Sept. 1 (AP)Scientists from the United States Geological Survey are drilling in the Atlantic Ocean floor for fresh water.

title: COMSTOCK EASING PRISON CROWDING
description: COMSTOCK, N.Y., Sept. 1As a peaceful inmate protest went into its third day at the Great Meadow State Correctional Facility here, authorities today began dealing with the problem of overcrowding by transferring 70 prisoners to institutions throughout the state.

title: Worms Turn to Gold
description: GROTON, Conn., Sept. 1 (AP)  Two boys digging for worms yesterday caught something much bigger. Robbie DeVeau and his brother, Timmy, 9, were digging in a wooded area of the Mytic section near Route 1 when they found a white bag marked Federal Reserve of Boston. It contained bills and coins totaling about $200. The police were to trace the money and to learn why it had been buried.

title: Ford Asks Levi for Report On His Findings on Kelley
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1President Ford asked today for a full report on Justice Department data suggesting that Clarence M. Kelley, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, may have misused Government services and property in his suburban apartment and accepted expensive gifts from subordinates.

title: 6 Witches and Channel 13 Auction Fan Turn Out for a FullMoon Ceremony
A Top French Publisher Purchases ParisMatch
description: PARIS, Sept. 1 (AP)Daniel Filipacchi, a magazine publisher whose publications include the French edition of Playboy, announced today the purchase of the weekly ParisMatch, once regarded as one of the world's, foremost picture magazines.

title: Payment Plan Is Effected In Potato Futures Default
description: The New York Mercantile Exchange has put into effect its plan for payment of $980,000 in the default on potato futures contracts.

title: Court Rules Wright Supporter Can Run for Seat in Assembly
description: The Appellate Division ruled yesterday that supporters of Councilman Samuel D. Wright, the Democratic leader of Brooklyn's 54th Assembly District, could replace with another Wright supporter, their Assembly candidate, who was ruled off the Sept. 14 primary ballot two weeks ago.

title: Thousands Are Turned Away as Jersey Track Opens
Schools Suspend 3 In Lunches Inquiry
description: The director and two officials of the Bureau of School Lunches were ordered suspend. ed yesterday as a result of a New York City Board of Education investigation that found that purchase orders totaling more than $2 million during a recent 18month period had been split into small amounts apparently to circumvent the city's requirements for competitive bidding.

title: N.F.L. Sets Player Limit at 43
description: National Football League teams, except Seattle and Tampa Bay, will each be limited to 43 players this season, Commissioner Pete Rozelle said last night.

title: Jenkins of Red Sox Lost for Season
description: BOSTON, Sept. 1 (AP)Ferguson Jenkins, who combined to pitch a fourhit shutout with Toni Murphy and give the Red Sox a 30 victory over Texas, was accidentally spiked in the fifth inning today and will he sidelined for the rest of the season.

title: Hypocrisy at the U.N.
description: On the initiative of Cuba and a few other selfstyled nonaligned nations, the United Nations Decolonization Committee seems headed for its annual exercise in hypocrisy concerning the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. Last year, after strenuous lobbying by Ambassador Daniel P. Moynihan, the 24nation committee shelved by a narrow margin a resolution that would have pompously affirmed the inalienable right of the people of Puerto Rico to selfdetermination and independence.

title: Holtz Wants Jets to Play Despite Pain
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 1 When the Jets arrived at camp today they were greeted by still another written message from Coach Lou Holtz, who may become the Hallmark of the football mentors.

title: Irish Parliament Approves Declaration of Emergency
New Jersey Briefs
description: Judge Leo Yanoff in Essex County Court permanently enjoined a group associated with Imamu Amiri Baraka, the black poet and political activist, from asking the Newark electorate through a referendum on the Nov. 3 ballot to create an elected Civilian Complaint Review Board that would hear allegations of police misconduct in this predominantly black city.

title: One Nurses Strike Ends, Another Goes On in Seattle
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 1 (AP)A strike by about 625 registered nurses against a health coop erative has ended, but another strike by 1,800 nurses at 15 area hospitals is in its eighth week with no end in sight.

title: HAYS, UNDER FIRE, QUITS HOUSE SEAT
The Kissinger Trip: U.S. Goals in Africa
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger departs on Friday for a meeting in Zurich with Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa that may turn out to be a prelude to a longer Kissinger trip to southern Africa next week. Some questions and answers on the subject follow.

title: Hawaii's Doctors Mobilize to Fight Malpractice Law
Auto Tribunal Postpones Hearing
description: PARIS, Sept. 1 (UPI)The International Automobile Federation postponed its Sept. 8 meeting today to consider the Ferrari racing team's protest against James Hunt's victory in the British Formula One Grand Prix. A spokesman said the appeals tribunal was forced to cancel its session because no Judges would be available that day. A meeting in the last week of September is possible, but not definite, the spokesman said.

title: AntiObscenity Unit To Aid Communities Taking Legal Action
WorktoRule Movement Snarls Spain's Airports
description: MADRID, Sept. 1Some 700 ground controllers are applying safety regulations so closely that they have thrown air traffic in Spain into total confusion.

title: Villaflor Gains Decision
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 1 (UPI) Ben Villaflor, the world junior lightweight champion of the Philippines scored a unanmous decision over Rogelio Castaneda last night in a 10 round nontitle fight.
