Judging by what I read in the newspapers, the operations of government intelligence agencies seem to be ratherbungling affairs. Yet, to Quiller, Mr. Hall's famous secret agent, everything is infinitely sensitive and before he makes the simplest move, he takes precautions that even a Freudian revisionist would call analcompulsive.

title: Preservation of Little Italy Urged
description: New zoning rules intended to preserve and enhance the special character of Little Italy were proposed yesterday by the New York City Planning Commission.

title: How to Get There
description: To reach the fair, take the Merritt Parkway to Exit 45, then go north on Route 53, the Black Rock Turnpike, about 10 miles to Redding. Continue past the Spinning Wheel Inn to Christ Episcopal Church, turn left at the church onto Cross Highway and continue through Redding Center to Route 107. Go left on Route 107 to the intersection with Route 53, turn right on Route 53 and go one mile to .the John Read Middle School.

title: New Charges Are Leveled At SchoolLunch Program
description: New York City's Summer Food Service Program today will distribute its last meals of 1978 to needy children, amid new charges of incompetent administration by the state's Education Department and new hints of corruption in the multimillion  dollar, federally financed program.

title: Julie Anthony Is Student Of the Psychological Edge
description: You had to be a psychologist to enjoy playing tennis in the rain yesterday at the United States Open in Forest Hills. Besides the humidity, you had to worry about slipPing on the lines, slugging waterlogged balls and the possibility of popping a string or slipping a disk.

title: The Big Casino in the Sky
description: The older I grow the more impressed I am with the role of luck or chance in life. To be born when and where one finds himself is, of course, from the point of view of the individual person, the sheerest luck of allgood or bad.

title: An Ives Country Fair Comes Fifing And Drumming Into Lincoln Center
description: A musical country fair will spring to life at the Lincoln Center OutofDoors Festival tonight and tomorrow night at 8, with marching bands, barn. dances, evocations of baseball, circuses and Thoreauand a lot of audience participation.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, Sept. 2, 1976

title: ABORTION BACKERS SEEK OUT CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UPI) Religious supporters of the Supreme Court's abortion decision have asked to meet with Jimmy Carter on the issue, the Religious Coalition for Abortion Rights said today.

title: MECHANICS ACCORD REJECTED ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 2 (UPI) Directors of the Southern California Rapid Transit District today rejected, 8 to 3, a contract proposal by 1,100 striking mechanics to end an 11day old walkout against the nation's fourth largest masstransit system.

title: Broadway
description: WHEELBARROW CLOSERS (yes, the title does seem enigmatic), a new play by Louis LaRusso 2d, whose Lamppost Reunion was an artistic success last season, will open at the Bijou Theater on Oct. 17. Wheelbarrow Closers is about a businessman, a tycoon, really, who must face the fact that his retirement is the beginning of the end of his life. Paul Sorvino, best known on Broadway for his performance in That Championship Season, will direct the new production. Danny Aiello, who acted the bartender in Lamppost Reunion, will play the businessman.

title: Selfridge of Giants Traded to Dolphins
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 2  Andy Selfridge looked at the blackboard and got the message.

title: Debates Facing Challenge By McCarthy and Maddox
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 Attorneys for Eugene J. McCarthy and Lester G. Maddox said today that they had been in touch with each other, and that they intended to explore the possibility of joint legal action over the exclusion of the two men from the scheduled television debates between President Ford and Jimmy Carter.

title: Upgrading City's Women Workers in Hard Times
description: The timing could hardly have been less conducive to the formation of a new venture in New York City when the Commission on the Status of Women was sworn in a year and a half ago.

title: Article 5  No Title
Carter and the Bishops
description: In their running dispute with Jimmy Carter over abortion, the nation's Roman Catholic bishops are engaged in a power struggle that is likely to affect both the course of proposed abortion, legislation and the ability of the bishops to lead.

title: Carey Names Sheriff
description: ALBANY, Sept. 2 (UPI) Governor Carey yesterday appointed Harold Horton, a member of the Columbia County Board of Supervisors, as Columbia County Sheriff. The appointment will enable Mr. Horton, a Democrat, to run as an incumbent in the November election against Paul Proper, a Republican and a deputy sheriff who is seeking the job. Horton succeeds Frank W. Appleton, a Republican who resigned from the post.

title: CBS Is Only Network Planning Viking Show
description: The CBSTV network is the only one of the three national networks planning a special program of the scheduled landing tonight on Mars of Viking 2.

title: Private Doctors Allowed to Use Bellevue
description: In an experimental change of policy, the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation has decided to allow private physicians to use Bellevue Hospital  which is publicly owned  to treat their private patients. a corporation spokesman said last night.

title: Commodity Price Index Fell 1.8 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 204.9 from 206.7 last week.

title: A Star Is Born, by 8 Points
description: Between halves of the exhibition game between the San Francisco 49ers and Oakland Raiders, a television star was born. His name is Jimmy Snyder and he is known professionally as Jimmy the Greek, a name that means gambling on sports to anybody who has seen the point spread he disseminates weekly from Las Vegas on National Football League games, read his syndicated column or heard him tell tales of his past as a high roller. Jimmy has some pretty good contacts in pro football, Brent Musburger told viewers. You'll be seeing him every Sunday on CBSTV. Jimmy then undertook to prove how good his contacts were by predicting that San Francisco would get Marty Domres from Baltimore to back up Jim Plunkett at quarterback, a forecast that came true in 24 hours. Jimmy also said he understood that Miami's star quarterback, Bob Griese, had been suffering from headaches and that in his opinion O. J. Simpson would play on the West Coast this year, though not necessarily for the Los Angeles Rams. As he talked, the screen displayed the 11 factorsteam speed, quarterback, discipline and so onthat he considers when he calculates the point spread.

title: Council in Newark Has 2 in Same Job
description: NEWARK, Sept. 2  The Newark City Council, whose members have often criticized Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson for excessive spending, has renewed for the fifth year a$25,000 contract with a public relations firm that appears to perform essentially the same duties as a $19,000ayear employee in a federally financed city program.

title: Rembrandt In New York
description: The only way to know Rembrandt completely is to go round the world and not hurry back. Amsterdam, London, Berlin, Leningrad, Stockholm, Kassel, Brunswick, Dresden and Munich in Germany, Glasgow and Paris are mandatory stops. Time must be no object. Leisure, contemplation and unhurried study are all. But the truth is we can do well enough in New York this weekend while waiting for the ideal circumstances to come along.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 2 (AP)  Volkswagen's parent company has agreed to a demand by Pennsylvania that it stand behind a $40 million loan to its new American subsidiary, set up to manufacture cars at a plant near Pittsburgh.

title: FORD PUTTING OFF CAMPAIGN'S START
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 President Ford, departing sharply from political custom, will delay the formal start of his election campaign until the middle of this month, wellplaced White House officials said today.

title: The Hanford Explosion
description: Since the dawn of the nuclear era more than three decades ago, not a single accident has occurred from either civilian or military uses of atomic energy that resulted in heavy loss of human life or largescale environmental damage. Compared to the toll during this period from dam failures, coal mine tragedies, oil spills, aircraft crashes and other industrial accidentsnot to mention the automobile or the slippery bathtubthe nuclear danger would seem to be mild.

title: Mark of Twain on Town's Big Book Fair
description: William Everts Benjamin, the New York financier and antiquarian, suggested in Mark Twain's guestbook when he visited the author in 1909 at his home in Redding, Conn. that life in that place seemed to him to be relatively slow and peaceful. Even the water doesn't run here, Mr. Benjamin wrote. It sorta saunters from the tapand gives a grateful gurgle when you stop it.

title: Advertising
description: Many marketers have used varieties of consumertesting procedures to introduce new brands, change product formulations or select advertising themes. But how many have turned to market research to pick an advertising agency?

title: Equipment Thefts At 3 City U. Units Reported by Goldin
description: The theft of equipment valued at $68,000 from three colleges of the City University of New York was disclosed yesterday by Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, who charged that most of the thefts were never reported to the police.

title: For Harbor, No More Oops Sail; Impact on Port
description: Data from two television cameras continuously watching ships move past 23 locations around New York harbor for weeklong periods have laid the groundwork for a modernized control network that will bring the harbor traffic into the computer age by 1978.

title: MARK VISHNIAK, RUSSIAN EXPERT
description: Mark Vishniak, a leading figure of the nonBolshevik left in revolutionary Russia and later Time magazine's senior specialist on Soviet affairs, died Tuesday night in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 93 years old.

title: T. CUYLER YOUNG, 76, EXPERT ON NEAR EAST
description: T. Cuyler Young, a n analyst of Near East affairs and proessor emeritus at Princeon University, died of cancer Tuesday at the Princeton Medical Center. He was 76 years old.

title: Truce Zone at Panmunjom Now a Lure for Tourists
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 2  American soldiers who volunteer for oneyear tours of duty in Panmunjom, the tensionfilled truce camp 35 miles north of here, are screened for their ability, physically and emotionally, to survive in the area and then receive special combat training before they go.

title: Park Opens
description: DANCING in the great outdoors is a venerable tradition. The ancient Greeks preferred it that way, and so does the annual New York Dance Festival, which opens a 10day run at Central Park's Delacorte Theater tonight.

title: Sonmor Named Coach
description: ST. PAUL, Sept. 2 (AP)The Minnesota Fighting Saints of the World Hockey Association named 47yearold Glenn Sonmor as their coach today for the 196777. Sonmor, who will also serve as general manager of the new Saints team, will be assisted by Jack McCartan. Both were with the old Minnesota franchise.

title: Phillips Petroleum And Head Indicted
description: TULSA, Okla.,Sept. 2  A Federal grand jury indicted the Phillips Petroleum Company, its board chairman and two formet chairmen today on Federal tax charges alleging a global conspiracy to conceal $3 million in Swiss bank accounts and a secret cache at company headquarters.

title: Martin Is Cosmos Aide
description: Mike Martin, a former executive in both the National and the World Football Leagues, was named yesterday as general manager of the New York Cosmos of the North American Soccer League. Martin was executive assistant for the New York Jets for seven years, and served a year as vice president of the W.F.L. He will handle administrative duties for the Cosmos.

title: Peking Discloses Looting Occurred After Earthquake
description: PEKING, Sept. 2 (Reuters)For the first time Jenmin Jih Pao, the official Communist publication, has used the word looting in discussing the earthquake that devastated parts of northeast China last month.

title: Amassing Power in India
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 2The set of constitutional amendments that Prime Minister Inlira Gandhi's Government laid before Parliament yesterday has ramifications potentially aswide as anything done here since a sweeping state of emergency was declared 14 months ago. In the nameof achieving what it calls a socioeconomic revolution for the people of this country, the long document provides the seeds at least for a drastic reordering of the balances of the Government.

title: Boats to Catch in New York Waters
description: Owning a yacht, it has been said, is like standing in a cold shower tearing up $20 bills.

title: Shanker Assails Mrs. Abzug
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 2Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, today assailed Representative Bella S. Abzug as a scab who had crossed teacher picket lines and taught classes during the 1968 school strike in New York City.

title: Fall Shown In Supply Of Money
description: The nation's basic money supply declined $800 million in the week ended Aug. 25, reversing a large increase in the preceding week that had sent momentary tight money tremors through the credit markets.

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday

title: Irresistible Touches Of Luxury
description: So you're not going to look like a peasant this fall, opulent or otherwise! So fantasy leaves you cold!

title: Japanese Indict Lobbyist In Lockheed Payoff Case
description: TOKYO, Sept. 2 (UPI)Tokyo prosecutors indicted rightwing lobbyist Yoshio Kodama and his secretary today on charges of establishing a Hong Kong cover company to funnel illegal funds from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation into Japan.

title: B.P. QUARTER NET SHOWS 39% RISE
description: The British Petroleum Company and Imperial Chemical Industries, two of Britain's largest corporations, yesterday announced increases in earnings for the second quarter of 1976.

title: Belmont Race Charts
description: 1976, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: Commerce Department Accused Of Collusion in Arabs' Boycott
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3A Congressional report examining the impact of the Arab boycott against companies doing business with Israel asserts that the United States. Department of Commerce acted in collusion with some American concerns to uphold the boycott.

title: 3 AMERICANS SEIZED IN CAIRO SMUGGLING
description: CAIRO, Sept. 3  Three Americans were arrested here yesterday for an alleged attempt to smuggle seven suitcases full of Egyptian antiquities out of the country.

title: Expos Oust Kuehl After Pirates Win
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 3 (UPI) The Montreal Expos dismissed their rookie manager, Karl Kuehl, following a doubleheader loss to the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.

title: MADRID OPTIMISTIC ON REFORM PLANS
description: MADRID, Sept. 3  Prime Minister Adolfo Surez Gonzlez is said to be optimistic about the chances of introducing parliamentary democracy to Spain by the promised deadline of next June despite both conservative and leftist opposition and an economic crisis.

title: TeenAger Gets Patent For an Aid in Reading
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3Becky J. Schroeder of Toledo, Ohio, who attracted attention at age 12 by patenting a method of writing in the dark, was awarded her third patent this week.

title: Dole Calls Carter Uninformed for Saying Ford Uses Veto Too Often
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 3 Senator Robert J. Dole charged today that Jimmy Carter's criticism of President Ford's repeated use of the veto demonstrated a distressing lack of knowledge or understanding of how our Government is constructed.

title: 2 Get Life Terms For Role in Killing Of the Yablonskis
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Sept. 3Two of three men convicted for the 1969 slayings of Joseph A. Yablonski, the United Mine Workers dissident, and his wife and daughter, were given life in prison at their sentencing here today.

title: 4 NEWSMEN BEGIN JAIL SENTENCES
description: FRESNO, Calif., Sept. 3 (AP) Four Fresno Bee newsmen began serving jail sentences today for refusing to disclose a news source, saying they were firmly proud for defending one of our basic freedoms.

title: Tiana Beach Case Is Closed as Review Finds No Evidence Warranting Action
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 3After a sixmonth review of what had once been regarded as a major land scandal in the growing suburbs, the Suffolk County District Attorney announced today that his office had decided to close the Tiana Beach case.

title: W.H.A. Picks MacFarland
description: TORONTO, Sept. 3 (UPI)Bill MacFarland, the former president of the Phoenix Roadrunners, was appointed president and chief operating officer of the World Hockey Association.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Soviet Union, while still feeling the pinch of last fall's crop disaster, is looking forward to a relatively abundant harvest this year that could meet domestic needs. Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist Party chief, said: The crop of grain gladdens our heartsit is evident that the country will have enough grain this year. He conceded that shortages of meat, a result of distress slaughtering last fall, were continuing. [Page 1, Columns 67.]

title: Carter, in Apparent Shift, Stresses Curb on Inflation
description: PLAINS, Ga., Sept. 3In what appeared to be a distinct, shift of political emphasis, Jimmy Carter stressed today the need to curb inflation and achieve a balanced budget, saying that to reach those goals he might delay the start of costly programs if elected President.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The ClevelandCliffs Iron Company of Cleveland announced yesterday that it planned to develop substantial uranium deposits with a group of other companies in the North Butte area of the Powder River basin in Wyoming.

title: LONDON METAL MARKET
description: (In pounds sterling per metric ton)

title: Air Force First Balked New Cadet Study
description: DENVER. Sept. 3The Air Force Academy declined seven weeks ago to reopen its 1975 investigation of cadet forgery and theft despite new evidence and the urging of a civilian attorney pursuing the case, according to documents on file with the Secretary of the Air Force.

title: Walter Langley Dies at 55; Former Senator in Albany
description: Walter Langley, a former New York State Senator, died yesterday at his home in Albany. He was 55 years old.

title: Belmont Entries
description: Horses listed in order or post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Some Consumer Advice On Therapy by the Book
description: Everybody knows you can't tell a book by its cover. But how much can you tell by its content, especially if it's one of that seemingly endless flow of volumes promising the troubled reader inner peace?

title: MEDICAID PAYOUT IS VIEWED AS SLOW
description: City officials yesterday acknowledged delayssometimes up to several monthsin reimbursing shared health facilities for services. But they attributed them to what they called continually questionable billing practices by the facilities, often called Medicaid mills, as well as to severe manpower shortages.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Inmate leaders of the strike at the Green Haven Correctional Facility, which entered its fourth day yesterday, said that they would end their work stoppage if New York  State Legislators agreed to meet with them to discuss grievances. Assemblyman Stanley Fink of the 39th Assembly District in Brooklyn, who is chairman of the Assembly Codes Committee, said that he had been asked by Corrections Commissioner Benjamin C. Ward to meet with the inmates and that members of his committee, and possibly other Legislators would go to Green Haven next Wednesday to discuss grievances.

title: Bridge:
description: Sooner or later, every expert declarer runs into the following situation: he is in the middle of executing a winning line of play when a mean, sneak opponent does something quite unforeseen that turns out to upset the applecart.

title: F.B.I. INFORMER TIED TO PANTHER GUN BID
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (UPI)A Federal Bureau of Investigation suggested to members of the Black Panther party that they blow up an armory to get guns and offered them a satchel of explosives to burglarize a restaurant, according to legal briefs filed in Federal court.

title: People in Sports
description: Darrell Johnson, named manager of the year last season after having led the Boston Red Sok to the American League pennant and having taken the powerful Cincinnati Reds to seven games in the World Series before losing, was named yesterday to manage the Seattle Mariners, who enter the league next season.

title: Because of an Error, Mrs. Abzug Orders the Withdrawal of a Radio Spot Criticizing Moynihan
description: Representative Bella S. Abzug last night ordered the withdrawal of a 30second radio campaign advertisement attacking one of her opponents in the Democratic Senatorial primary, Daniel P. Moynihan, and conceded that the advertisement contained an error.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was incorrectly reported in The Times on Thursday that House and Senate tax conferees had accepted a provision that would make workers' contributions to prepaid legal service plans taxfree. The provision refers to contributions from employers, not workers.

title: Diebold Venture Shares Increase by 20%
description: The Diebold Venture Capital Corporation, after a delayed opening, closed on the American Stock Exchange yesterday with a price gain of 20 percent on trading volume that amounted to more than seven times the stock's daily average for the entire month of August.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company asked state regulators to reject recommendations that millions of doltars be slashed from a proposed rate increase. In appeals filed with the Public Utilities Commission in Newark, the company said that if the cuts were upheld, its longterm financial health and its service capability would be jeopardized.

title: Defusing the Aegean
description: The United Nations Security Council resolution urging Greece and Turkey to resume direct negotiations to settle their dispute over control of Aegean waters seems to have taken some of the heat out of that dangerous controversy. Yet, Turkey appears determined to flout one part of the Council document, which encouraged the two Governments to make use of the International Court of Justice in settling their claims.

title: Students From Princeton Given Taste of Big Apple
description: A score of Princeton freshmen, their eyes wide and their stomachs full of Nathan's pizza, yesterday went through the second day of their universitysponsored introduction to a strange world the city of New York.

title: Irrational Dispute
description: Negotiations over the Board of Education's contract with the United Federation of Teachers continue to be deadlocked over the question whether the Emergency Financial Control Board has the authority to reject the wage increases for which funds are already allocated in the present budget. The lawyers are arguing such issues as whether the raises the city's teachers would get violate only the spirit or the actual letter of the wage freeze. Both the school board and the union seem to believe that when the Control Board vetoes the use of such available funds for wage increases it exceeds its authority merely to keep the city within its budget limits.

title: Telephones Cut Off In Michigan Town After Rate Protest
description: HICKORY CORNERS. Mich., Sept. 3 (UPI)The phones suddenly went dead in Hickory Corners  but not without warning.

title: Yet Another Dixie FlipFlop
description: COLUMBIA. S. C.The transformation of Southern politics, in response to the twin forces of social and economic revolutions, can be illustrated by a look at two states, North Carolina and Georgia.

title: News Summary an Index
description: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1976

title: Kissinger Acts to Put Off Trip to Southern Africa
description: LONDON, Sept. 3Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger moved today to drop his plans to fly to southern Africa after talks this weekend in Zurich with Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa.

title: Officials Expect Little Fraud in New York Voting
description: Election officials yesterday discounted the possibility of substantial illegal voting in the Sept. 14 primary and Nov. 2 general elections, despite the relaxation of the New York State laws governing registration.

title: Amex and OTC Stocks Rise in Sluggish Trading
description: Prices on The American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market advanced yesterday in sluggish trading.

title: Dassault Accountant Vanishes With $1.6 Million in 2 Valises
description: PARIS, Sept, 3The police disclosed today that the trusted chief accountant of France's largest privately owned aircraft company, Dassault, disappeared nearly two months ago after walking out of a Paris bank with $1.6 million in company money.

title: Radio
description: 66:55 A.M., WNYCFM. Songs of the Sixteenth and Seventeenth Centuries. Airs de Cour; Missa Se la face ay pale, Guillaume Dufay.

title: New Auto Sales Rise 8.8% But Are Below Estimates
description: DETROIT, Sept. 3Sales of new American cars totaled 219,675 In the final third of August, up 8.8 percent from 201,895 last year but slightly below estimates for the period, according to reports today from the four domestic automobile makers.

title: New York City Is Pressing RealEstate Concern for Upkeep Accord
description: New York City officials are pressing for an agreement under which the city's largest realestate empirethat of Sol Goldman and the late Alex DiLorenzo Jr.  would make repairs and upgrade services in as many as 30 of the organization's troubled apartment buildings.

title: Late Futures Rally Led by Soybeans; Meal and Corn Up
description: CHICAGO. Sept. 3 (AP)Soybean futures advanced more than 10 cents a bushel in the final minutes on the Chicago Board of Trade today and influenced a rally in most other commodities on the exchange.

title: A Resort in the Poconos Has the I.L.G.W. U. Label.
description: UNITY HOUSE, Pa., Sept. 3  Rain fell here all day yesterday. At daybreak today the mist was thick and chill. The setting was right for that strangest of periods at summer resorts, the 36 hours or so of sudden calm before the final crescendo of summer, the Labor Day weekend crowds.

title: Paris Boutiques: At Home With Fashion
description: PARISMany fashionable Patisians are putting aside their desires for status and labels and are flocking to boutiques built into private apartments where they have found that they can get more fashion for their francs.

title: About New York
description: A city gets the service it deserves. By city and service, one doesn't mean city services and uncivil servantsthe philanthropists of self who give us their lathered personalities every election year, the more or less permanent government of burgomasters bedded down in the city's bureau drawers, the caliphs of the utility companies, the dynasts of the municipal unions, and their uniformed janissaries and sepoys. One doesn't mean, in other words, the surly bureaucratic norm.

title: New Barbados Prime Minister Installed After Upset Victory
description: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Sept. 3 (AP)J. M. G. Adams, the leader of the Barbados Labor Party, who ended the 15year rule of Prime Minister Errol W. Barrow in an election upset, met today with the acting GovernorGeneral, Sir William Douglas, and was sworn in as head of government.

title: Preseason Football
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Experts See No Evidence Mystery Illness Persists
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 3Federal epidemiologists, issuing today their first comprehensive report on the mysterious disease that has killed 29 people in Pennsylvania, said that a survey of guests in four Philadelphia hotels showed no evidence of a continuing epidemic.

title: A Resort in the Poconos Has the I.L.G.W. U. Label
description: UNITY HOUSE, Pa., Sept. 3  Rain fell here all day yesterday. At daybreak today the mist was thick and chill. The setting was right for that strangest of periods at summer resorts, the 36 hours or so of sudden calm before the final crescendo of summer, the Labor Day weekend crowds.

title: Revidere Favored in Gazelle; Optimistic Gal May Skip Race
description: Undefeated Revidere, winner of the Monmouth Oaks, and Optimistic Gal, a 16length victor in the recent Alabama Stakes at Saratoga, are slated for a showdown today at Bel mont Park. But whether the outstanding 3yearTracks old fillies will actually meet in the 1mile, $50,000added Gazelle Handicap depends on LeRoy Jolley, Optimistic Gal's trainer.

title: Premier Under Siege
description: JOHANNTESBURG, Sept. 3 Ten years ago this month a distinguished South African surgeon, an Afrikaner with strikingly liberal views, heard a radio bulletin announcing that John Vorster had been chosen to succeed the assassinated Hendrik Verwoerd as

title: Steelworker Insurgency
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 3The odd thing about Edward Sadlowski's performance at the United Steelworkers convention, which ended here today, was that he made so little noise. Everyone inside and outside the union had expected the rebel leader from Chicago to come out swinging in his campaign for the union presidency, befitting his image as a fighting 38yearold from the steel mills.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Metropolitan Rate Leads U.S.'s
description: Unemployment in the New Yorknortheastern New Jersey area was 25 percent higher than the national average in the first half of 1976, continuing a fiveyear trend, the Labor Department reported Friday.

title: Bonn Confirms That Prince Talked to Schmidt of Plane
description: BONN, Sept. 3 (Reuters)The West German Government confirmed today that Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands had a conversation about sales of the Northrop Cobra fighter plane in Europe.

title: Fire Prevention Week Set
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI)  President Ford today set aside the week beginning Oct. 3 as Fire Prevention Week and noted that each year in the United States more than three million fires and explosions kill 12.000 persons.

title: Vaccine Makers Report Plants at Full Capacity
description: The four manufacturers of swine influenza vaccines said yesterday that they had been operating at full capacity before they were asked Thursday to speed up.

title: U.S. Arms Deal With Saudis Said to Include Base Facilities
description: WASHINGTON Sept. 3 (AP) The Ford Administration's newly proposed $700 million arms package for Saudi Arabia ranges from 2,500 missiles to modernization of King Khalid's National Guard.

title: WHITE MOTOR SALEI OF A UNIT IS SET
description: The White Motor Corporation, producer of large trucks, industrial farm and construction equipment, reached an agreement yesterday to sell its White Industrial Power Inc. subsidiary in Auburn, N. Y. to the General Electric Company of Britain. It is not affiliated with General Electric Company of the United States.

title: G.M. Recalling Vans
description: DETROIT, Sept. 3 (UPI) General Motors announced today that it was asking owners of about 16,000 Chevrolet and G.M.C. 1976 GVans equipped with cruise control to return the vehicles to dealers for possible replacement of a fastener connecting the cruise control bracket to the carburetor accelerator lever.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was incorrectly reported in The Times on Thursday that House and Senate tax conferees had accepted a provision that would make workers' contributions to prepaid legal service plans taxfree. The provision refers to contributions from employers, not workers.

title: EDWARD N. FEINEN
description: BUFFALO, Sept, 3 (UPI)Edward N. Feinen, a newsman for United Press International and The Buffalo Evening News for nearly four decades, died Wednesday. He was 61 years old and lived in Tonawanda, N.Y.

title: Rehnquist Rejects Appeal By Rep. Hinshaw on Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI)  Supreme Court Justice William H. Rehnquist today rejected a plea by Representative Andrew J. Hinshaw, Republican of California, to block his jury trial on Government fraud and theft charms.

title: Article 2  No Title
Csonka Returning For Giant Tuneup
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 3Larry Csonka, who has missed two games because of a neck injury, is scheduled for a full workout tomorrow night as the New York Giants wind up their exhibition season by playing the San Diego Chargers (11 P.M., New York time, televised by Channel 11).

title: Fake Emancipation
description: State agencies in New York and elsewhere express concern over the number of affluent families who claim college tuition subsidies by alleging that their collegeage children are emancipated and therefore have no income from which to pay for their education. While the emancipated label may well be legitimate in the case of older students who should no longer expect to be supported by their parents, for manyprobably mostteenage undergraduates a claim of that independent status has all the earmarks of a ripoff.

title: Japan's Exports Dip
description: TOKYO, Sept. 4 (UPI)Japan's exports in August were estimated at $5.8 billion, down 6.4 percent from July. The new level was up 30.5 percent from August 1975, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry reported today.

title: Aid Lets McCarter Theater Plan Full 197677 Season
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 3 (UPI)A full, program for the 197677 season at Princeton's financially plagued McCarter Theater has been made possible through subsidies from the National Endowment for the Arts and the New Jersey Council on the Arts.

title: In Memoriam
description: Frances Angels Wolff Happy Memories of you Remain

title: Private Tovvaways Distressing to Motorists
description: A greenandwhite private tow truck, one of six that started cruising Manhattan's streets this week in search of ticketed cars in towaway zones, pulled in front of an aging Thunderbird illegally parked on East 41st Street yesterday afternoon.

title: Meadowlands Entries
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Faculty Strike Is Set At Fairleigh Dickinson
description: TEANECK, N.J., Sept. 3 (AP)While the 10,000 Fairleigh Dickinson University students brace for the opening of school next week the faculty is getting ready to strike.

title: Brezhnev Expects Crops To Cover Domestic Need
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 3The Soviet Union, while still feeling some pinch from last year's crop disaster, is looking forward to a relatively abundant harvest this year that could cover domestic needs. The nation's Communist Party chief, Leonid I. Brezhnev, said in a speech today in the central Asian city of AlmaAta:

title: Navy Official Nominated
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI)  President Ford announced today that he was nominating David Macdonald, assistant secretary of the treasury for enforcement, operations and tariff affairs, to be Under Secretary of the Navy. Mr. Macdonald, 45 years old, will succeed David Potter, who resigned April 1.

title: Open Interest
description: Friday, Sept, 3, 1976

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: RETAILERS' SALES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Retail sales in New York City and the metropolitan area, after rebounding from May's biggest monthly decline in more than a decade, again dropped sharply in August from the yearearlier levels, according to a monthly survey conducted yesterday. And for the first time this year, retail business in the area fared worse than in the city.

description: PURSE $263,524 POST TIME1:20 P.M. (E.D.T.) First Heat

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP) Money rates for Friday.

title: Return of PakistantoIndia Train Part of Thaw in Relations
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, Aug. 30 The train is running across the border into India again, helping to erode deepseated enmity.

title: HOUSE UNIT SHIFTS ON SYNTHETIC FUEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3The syntheticfuel bill, once considered dead in the present Congress, apparently has been given a new lease on life by the adroit manuvering of Representative Olin E. Teague, Democrat of Texas.

title: JOBLESS RATE UP TO 7.9% IN AUGUST, 3D MONTHLY RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3The nation's unemployment rate rose for the third consecutive month in August, the Labor Department announced today, forcing the Ford Administration to retreat from its longheld forecast that the jobless rate would fall below 7 percent by the end of the year.

title: Banks Closed Monday
description: Banks in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut area will be closed on Monday because of the Labor Day holiday. Securities and commodities exchanges in the United States and Canada will also be closed.

title: Concern for National Security Rising in U.S., Poll. Indicates
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3  A new survey of American attitudes toward foreignpolicy issues holds that concerns for national security have risen in recent months.

title: Mrs. Carner Leads on 67
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 3 (UPI)JoAnne Carner, trying for her fifth victory on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour this year, a twostroke lead today with a fiveunderpar 67 in the $100,000 Muscular Dystrophy golf tournament.

title: COST RISE FOUND IN ARMS PROJECTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI) The Pentagon reported today a $4.8 billion increase since March in the projected cost of 44 major defense projects because of the addition of a new nuclearpowered aircraft carrier, inflation, changes in contracts and new equipment.

title: Soviet Six Bows, 53, in Canada Cup
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 3In a match between two of the fayored teams in the Canada Cup of Hockey, the Czechoslovak national team beat a new Soviet Union squad, 53 The winning team never trailed.

title: Soweto Student Leader Says Equality Won't Satisfy Blacks
description: LONDON, Sept. 3 (UPI)A black South African student leader said in a television interview yesterday that blacks in his country no longer would be satisfied with equal rights and that they wanted to dominate the whites.

title: Opera: New Hans Sachs
description: The prospect of hearing a new Hans Sachs always puts Wagner enthusiasts in a state of cautious excitement, if such an ambiguity can describe the mingling of dread and hope that is felt over an unknown baritone's first appearance as the humane poet and cobbler in Die Meistersinger. The opera, in the Englishlanguage production that was introduced at the New York City Opera last season, returned Thursday night with Reid Bunger as Sachs.

title: ECONOMIC RECOVERY IS SLOWING IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 4 (UPI)The pace of Japan's economic recovery slowed in the April 1June 30 quarter, with the gross national product growing by only 1.1 percent over the previous quarter, the Government's Economic Planning Agency said today.

title: Adirondack Train Rocky but Still Rolling
description: MONTREAL  Carol Emmanuel and the Adirondack got off to a sloppy start together. But by the time the Montreal English teacher and the New YorktoMontreal passenger train parted company here nearly 10 hours later, their relationship was on firmer ground.

title: Augusta Strong North, 61, Marxist Writer and Teacher
description: Augusta Strong North, a Marxist writer, linguist and teacher of black literature, died Wednesday in Martha's Vineyard Hospital in Massachusetts. She was 61 years old.

title: Nearby Dog Show AT TARRYTOWN, N.Y. TUXEDO PARK, K.C. THE CHIEF AWARDS VARIETY GROUPS
description: SPORTING (Rev. Dr. Braxton Sawyer, Judge) 1, Anne Snelling's Irish water spaniel, Ch. Oaktree's lrishtocrat; 2, Diane Baumann's and John Remondi's German short. haired pointer, Ch. Robin Crest Achilles; 3, Judy Colan's Weimaraner, Ch. Colside Standing Ovation; 4, Mai Wilson's particolor rocker spaniel, Ch. Rexpointe Kaiak.

title: END OF MIREX USE BY MID'78 ASKED
description: The State of Mississippi, which has been operating the only plant in the country that prepares the dangerous pesticide Mirex for use and sale to other Southern states, told the Environmental Protection Agency yesterday that it wanted to terminate use of the substance by June 30, 1978, because there is a question as to the longrange effect that Mirex may have on the environment.

title: Canada Developing Glut in Natural Gas
description: OTTAWA, SEPT. 3Accelerated exploration for new Canadian sources of natural gas, undertaken in expectation of a severe shortage of fuel, and other factors have produced a temporary surplus here instead.

title: Mirex Retains Its Potency
description: Mirex, which has been in use since 1946, is a powerful chlorine compound, one of the most durable chemical substances in the environment. When it is made, it is in crystalline form. It is then ground up very finely so that it may be mixed with soybean oil and corncob grits that can be sprayed or dusted as bait for fire ants.

description: OTB payoffs subject to 5% State tax)

title: Sweden 5, U.S. 2
description: TORONTO, Sept. 3 (UPI)Borje Salming, playing before a hometown crowd 5,B00 miles from home, scored the first of four powerplay goals in the first period, added an assist and led Sweden's national team to a 52 victory over Team USA in the opening game for each in the Canada Cup hockey tournament.

description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Sept. 3Two of three men convicted for the 1969 slayings of Joseph A. Yablonski, the United Mine Workers dissident, and his wife and daughter, were given life in prison at their sentencing here today.

title: Dow Up by 4.32 to 989.11; ShortCovering a Factor
description: Prices on the New York Stock Exchange closed higher in slow trading yesterday despite news of a third consecutive monthly rise in the nation's unemployment rate.

title: 191 Sanitationmen On Dismissed List Are Being Rehired
description: The city is rehiring 191 sanitationmen from the lists of those dismissed in July 1975 because it has lost many more men than anticipated through retirement, resignation or death.

title: The Hammond Museum, Well Crafted for Shopping and Dining
description: NORTH SALEM, N. Y.Perhaps it's the proximity to all that culture that makes museum gift ships generally so good; in any case, it's always nice to hear of another one opening.

title: Ford Farm Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI) James R. Lake, who was Ronald Reagan's press secretary during the Republican nomination campaign, will be a codirector of the Farmers for Ford Committee, the President's campaign announced today. Mr. Lake, a former Deputy Assistant Agriculture Secretary, will work with former Assistant Agriculture Secretary Richard Lyng on the committee.

title: GROUP W ASKS F.C.C. TO STUDY NETWORKS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI) The Westinghouse Broadcasting Company today asked the Federal Communications Commission to investigate the programming policies of the three major television networks and their alleged domination over local stations.

title: Party Dispute Called Peril To Carter Victory in State
description: TRENTON, Sept. 3  The Democratic political feud in New Jersey involving Jimmy Carter, Governor Byrne and State Senator James P. Dugan, the Democratic state chairman, was reported by party leaders here today to be threatening to undermine the Democratic Presidential nominee's chances of winning the state in November.

title: Article 3  No Title
Notes on People
description: Attending the reopening of a synagogue in The Hague yesterday, Queen Juliana made her first public appearance since her husband, Prince Bernhard, resigned from his public and private posts in the wake of his controversial Lockheed dealings. The Queen was guest of honor at the synagogue, closed since the Nazi persecution of Jews in World War II. Although solemn because of the nature of the occasion, she reportedly looked relaxed as well as tanned following her recent Italian vacation with the Prince.

title: The F.B.I.'s Habits
description: The new wave of controversy that has hit the Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun to give rise to a set of largely irrelevant questions about the tenure of the bureau's director, Clarence Kelley, while simultaneously throwing a clear light on basic ills still plaguing that institution.

title: KENNETH WARD
description: Kenneth Ward, an investment adviser and author of the General Technical Survey, a stock market report, died Tuesday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 77 years old.

title: Lester Davis, 57, Official Of College in Westchester
description: Lester Davis, chairman of the department of human services at Westchester Community College since 1971, died yesterday in Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center. He was 57 years old and lived at 17 Wolf Road, CrotononHudson, N. Y.

title: Hewitt Tops Fraser In Over35 Tennis
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 3 (AP)  Topseeded Bob Hewitt of South Africa defeated fifthseeded Neale Fraser of Australia, 63, 46, 64 today and advanced to the second round of the North American men's 35andover tennis championships.

title: The Third Man
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3Eugene J. McCarthy, independent candidate for President, is the lean, gray ghost of American politics.

title: Judge Denies 2 F.B.I. Agents' Bid to Halt Inquiry
description: A Federal judge yesterday rebuffed an attempt by two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to halt a grand jury investigation of illegal burglaries committed by them and other agents in New York City in recent years.

title: Yanks Win, 31; Orioles 11 Out
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 3Except for a bouncing bail that Chris Chambliss lost in the bright lights of Memorial Stadium, the Baltimore Orioles didn't look like a team tonight that stands ready to threaten the Yankees' season long possession of first place.

title: Ford Urges Korean Tax Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (Reuters)  President Ford asked the Senate today to ratify a convention between the United States and South Korea to prevent double taxation as well as tax evasion. The convention, signed in Seoul last June 4, is the first agreement of its type between the two countries.

title: Ford Gets Report on Kelley
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3White House Press Secretary Ron Nessen said today that President Ford had received a Justice Department report on acceptance of gifts from subordinates by Clarence M. Kelley, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and the use of F.B.I. carpenters to construct window valances in Mr. Kelley's apartment. Mr. Nessen said the President planned to read the report over the weekend and would have no comment on it until next week.

title: Search for Tomorrow (Sob!) Holds 25th Anniversary Party
description: There were no wifeswappings or suicides, but never mind. The fans would have loved it anywaythe laughter and tears, the euphoria and despair, the sobbing and drinking and kissing and reminiscing at the 25th anniversary celebration of the country's oldest television soap opera, Search for Tomorrow.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3A Congressional report examining the impact of the Arab boycott against companies doing business with Israel asserts that the United States Department of Commerce acted in collusion with some American concerns to uphold the boycott.

title: END OF MIREX USE BY MID '78 ASKED
description: The State of Mississippi, which has been operating the only plant in the country that prepares the dangerous pesticide Mirex for use and sale to other Southern states, told the Environmental Protection Agency yesterday that it wanted to terminate use of the substance by June 30, 1978, because there is a question as to the longrange effect that Mirex may have on the environment.

title: Irene Richards Dies at 66; OneTime Bowler of Year

M. at Town Hall, as part of the hall's series designed for the elderly. Miss Gordon, whose career has spanned more than 60 years, starting with her Broadway debut as Nibs in Peter Pan in 1915, will offer glimpses from her forthcoming autobiography, My Side.

description: LARGO, Fla., Sept. 3 (UPI) The Professional Golfers' Association and the Ladies Professional Golf Association have agreed to participate in a $200,000 mixedteam golf tournament late next First prize money would be $50,000.

Its assets, however, include some of the nation's most skillful burglars, highly advanced equipment for breaking and entering, and the will to put both to work.

The total was about 20 less than what this familiar Labor Day weekend race has attracted in the past.

Mr. Lisagor was named winner of the award in March but because of illness was unable to travel to the university in the spring to receive it.

title: Drought Intensifies Discontent of Rritain's Summer.

title: OBSERVER
description: American because each new reform deepens the nightmare of income tax law. Just when you have got a purchase on this monster, Congress reforms it and everybody has to start all over again. It has become a complexity to confound a Dickens lawyer, a maze to make King Minos's labyrinth look like a playpen. The conscientious, citizen would have to devote every waking hour to its study if he wanted to make a reasonably close guess at what he owes his Government each April.

The dead girls were Jane Palanis, 17 years old, and Kathy Laizure, 17. Listed in fair condition with head injuries were the driver, Lynn Gillinder, and Victoria Weed.

Led by bornagain Christians from within. the Church of England, the Evangelical movement left few aspects of British life untouched by its highminded proscriptions for morals, manners and politics, dress, books and private emotions. The ethos of the Victorian Age was to a marked extent created by the force of Evangelicalism as applied by generally beneficent but deeply conservative and

title: SPIRIT IS MAKING STRONG COMEBACK
description: Surviving rock bands and musicians from the 1960's have been making a strong showing lately on the pop charts, and Spirit, the latest 60's band to hit the comeback trail, had several pleasantly urgent pop hits during the early stages of its career. They were driven along by Randy California's whining guitar and Ed Cassidy's relatively complex drumming, the rest of the group's members remaining rather faceless.

title: Elizabeth Youth Killed
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 4 (UPI)A 17yearold Union County youth was killed last night when the car in which he was riding went out of control and struck a tree at an Elizabeth intersection, according to the police. The police said Edward Dobaccewski of Elizabeth died when the auto driven by Robert McKenna, about 20, also of Elizabeth, struck a tree at Rahway Avenue and Lyons Place.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: HAS the unexpected economic pause handed Jimmy Carter a surprise campaign issue? This is the question raised by the acknowledgement last week from Alan Greenspan, the President's chief economic adviser, that the economic recovery, now year and a half old, was experiencing a pause. Although Mr. Greenspan also stated his belief that the slowdown was only temporary, his gratuitous comment focused attention on the Ford Administration's economic record. Thus the economy may have come full circle as an election issue.

title: Collegiate Jersey Victor

title: Ferries Still Idle In Washington
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 4 (AP) Deck officers with the Washington ferry system have defied court orders to end their threeday walkout.

title: The Buffalo Creek Disaster
description: This book is particularly significant in the aftermath of the Teton Dam disaster in Idaho this past June. For the flood that followed the collapse of West Virginia's Buffalo Creek Dam in 1972like the one in Idahowas a manmade natural disaster. It killed 125 people and left hundreds of coal miners and their families homeless, disoriented for life. The Teton Dam was a Government project, while the Buffalo Creek Dam was erected by a private corporation. The Buffalo Creek Disaster shows in treat detail how the corporation was forced to pay for its destructive negligence. Thus, the book may be an omen of the scores of similar legal and political confrontations that are bound to occur over the next decade.

title: Why a Runner Runs: He Must
description: I am a runner. Years ago that statement would have meant little more to me than an accidental choice of sport. A leisuretime activity selected for reasons as superficial as the activity itself.

Another day the delivery could be several tons of dried raspberries or olibanum, also known as frankincense, an evergreen resin.

title: Brustein on Theater
description: The American theater renaissance begins, first and foremost, with its playwrights, particularly those who, like Beckett, Bond, and Handke in Europe, are managing to weave a metaphorical action out of the cultural and metaphysical fabric of the times: Sam Shepard, William Hauptman, Robert Auletta, Jules Feiffer, David Mamet, Thomas Babe, Adrienne Kennedy, Christopher Durang, Albert Innaurato, David Rabe, dozens more. Secondly, with those directors who have the capacity to penetrate, with fresh imagination and invention, to the very heart of a text: Andre Serban, Alvin Epstein, Paul Sills, Mike Nichols, John Pasquin (not to mention Andrzej Wajda, Ron Daniels, and Peter Brook when they visit our shores). Thirdly, with those designers who can work poetic images into visual production instead of slavishly reproducing the tasteless parlor: Ming Cho Lee, Boris Aronson, Julian Beck, Santo Loquasto, Anthony Straiges, Michael Yeargan, Sally Jacobs. Finally, with those composers who are able to charge a text emotionally without producing Tin Pan Alley kitsch: Stanley Silverman, Al Carmines, Marvin Hamlisch, Stephen Sondheim, Richard Peaslee.

description: DIX HILLS WHEN I came here I used to be really bad. But now I'm learning to control my anger some. I talk it out, I let it out.

title: TRUDEAU'S PARTY TUMBLES IN POLL
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 4Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau returned this weekend from a trip to Europe and the Middle East to find his governing Liberal Party and the national economy in disarray.

title: The Upper Peninsula: Land of Blue Water
description: The great lure of the eastern half o! the Upper Peninsula of Michigan is waterclear and cold, so blue it seems to crackle, opening up in some directions in an unimpeded sweep to the horizon, in others interrupted by myriads of greencarpeted islands. Here Henry Rowe Schoolcraft, an early Indian agent and ethnologist, compiled the Ojibwa legends that led Longfellow to write the Song of Hiawatha, set in the Upper Peninsula along the shore of Lake Superior, the shining BigSeaWater. Here Hemingway was drawn back time and again to the trout fishing in the TwoHearted River.

title: Emotions, Practicality and Esthetics All Are Involved
description: WASHINGTONWhen the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit last year upheld a lower court ruling that blocked timber companies from harvesting trees in West Virginia's Monongahela National Forest by clearcutting, conservationists were notably pleased. The timner industry was displeased, and became even more so after similar lower court decisions in Alaska and Texas.

title: Shirley A. Billings Wed to Peter Flierl
description: Shirley Ann Billings, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Billings of Albany, was married there yesterday afternoon to Peter John Flierl, son o fDr. and Mrs. Howard H. Flierl of Albany and Winter Harbor, Me. Justice Ellis J. Staley of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Fort Orange Club.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The United States Open at Forest Hills continues with day and night sessions, 11:30 A.M. and 8 P.M., today through Wednesday. Day sessions only begin with the quarterfinals on Thursday, and continue with the women's semifinals on Friday, men's semifinals and women's final on Saturday and men's final on Sunday.

description: To the Editor:

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: SUIT SEEKS ACCESS TO A BANNED DRUG
description: CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 4 (UPI) A police sergeant with a heart ailment has filed a class action suit so that a doctor, charged with malpractice in connection with at least 63 cases of hepatitis, can continue treating his patients.

title: The Region
description: New York's lottery resumes this week, with new rules, new prizes and new safeguards that officials hope will make it work right.

title: A Transsexual Speaks: Muscles Will Change
description: It occurred to me that, as a transsexual and a tennis player, I might be able to contribute something you might use regarding the case of Dr. Renee Richards.

title: A LIBYAN CONDEMNS AIRLINE HIJACKING
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Sept. 4 (AP) The Acting Foreign. Minister of Libya today condemned the hijacking of airliners, and he said that most hijackers who sought refuge in Libya had been tried convicted and Jailed.

title: Radio
description: Today: Leading Events

title: For Schools, New Money and New Hope
description: THE state's 607 publicschool districts will begin their 197677 year this week with new financing, new courses and new hope, but community officials are concerned that local control may be severely tested. For the 1.4 million pupils who will enter the classrooms, the new financing holds the prospect improved educational opportunities; the change in financing is a result of the Legislature having passed an incometax law in July that assures the schools of $374 million in new aid for the year.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Westchester K.C. allbreed and Port Chester Obedience Training Club trial, Lyndhurst, Route 9, Tarrytown, N.Y.; 2,779 dogs; 8 A.M.

title: U.S. Lending States Trailers For Prisons
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 4 (AP) Ten states troubled with crowded prisons, including New York and New ersey, are borrowing hundreds of house trailers from the Federal Government to use as cells, halfway houses or prison offices.

title: AustrianYugoslav Split Over Minority Worsening
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 4A longsmoldering dispute between Yugoslavia and neighboring Austria has become so inflamed that relations between the two have neared the breaking point.

title: Seafood by the Beautiful Sea
description: SNAPPER INN, Shore Drive, Oakdale. LT 90248.

description: Russia's Drift to Revolution 18251917. By Edward Crankshaw. Illustrated. 420 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $12.95.

title: Lebanese Report Intensive Battles East of the Capital
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 4Rightwing Christians reported today that fierce battles were under way in the hills east of here and that artillery, rockets and tanks were engaged in the fighting.

title: New Vaccine for Rabies Is Developed
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 (AP) New clinical evidence was unveiled here this week for a rabies vaccine that researchers say is superior to the painful vaccines now used to combat the disease.

title: Carter Will Press In All the States For Wide Mandate
description: PLAINS, Ga., Sept. 4Jimmy Carter says he will try to avoid concentrating his efforts in the 1976 Presidential campaign on a limited number of large states that might guarantee him victory because he is seeking a broad, convincing nationwide mandate that would strengthen his hand if he reaches the White House.

title: Strikes in State Dipped in 1975
description: THERE were 191 strikes in New Jersey last year involving 65,320 workers; or 2.4 percent of the state's total labor force. The average time lost by the walkouts was 16 days.

title: In Tristate Area, Key Contests Will Be Affected by National Strategy
description: President Ford and his fellow Republicans have made it clear that part of their election strategy will be to attack the record of the Democratic Congress, blaming it for rising budgets and expanding bureaucracies (even though Republicans have been in the White House for the last eight years).

title: Orioles Lose by 42
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 4Thirtyfive years ago today, the Yankees ended the 1941 pennant race by registering the earliest clinching ever. The Yankees didn't end their 1976 division race tonight, but they had the Baltimore Orioles doing a good imitation of a baseball corpse.

title: Charlotte Whinston, Artist And Muralist, Dies at 81
description: Charlotte Whinston, a painter, who was a past president of the National Association of Women Artists died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 81 years old.

title: Tanaka Visit Costs TV Chief His Job
description: TOKYO, Sept. 4 (UPI) Kichiro Ono has resigned as chairman of the Governmentcontrolled Japan Broadcasting Corporation following widespread criticism of a visit he made to the former Prime Minister, Kakuei Tanaka, recently indicted in the Lockheed scandal.

title: PANMUNJOM AIDES MEET FOR 7 HOURS
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 4 Representatives of the United States and North Korea met for more than seven hours yesterday at the Panmunjom truce camp. According to reliable sources, half of that long and uninterrupted session was spent by both delegations staring coldly at each other In an apparent contest of nerves.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Did you ever have the feeling of being totally dislocated in the theater, so that one minute you seemed to know exactly where you stood time and space and the very next you felt yourself on the down escalator going up? I had that feeling rather often last week at the charming Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Conn., where a mildly agreeable but ideologically treacherous new musical version of Little Orphan Annie was being given its formal introduction to a waiting, or perhaps merely tolerant, world.

title: Jeanne Evert Coping in Shadows of Her Big Sister
description: A champion is afraid of losing: everyone else is afraid of winning.

title: Many $30,000 State Jobs Called PartTimeby Panel
description: Dozens of state employees are paid $30,000 to $50,000 year for jobs that are basically parttimein some cases requiring no more than a few hours work a weekand that should be compensated on a parttime basis, a special board set up by Governor Carey reported to him yesterday.

title: Scrappy Corner Put Up a Good Fight
description: A 1953 United States Geological Survey map includes the community of Scrappy Corner in Morris County. Scrappy Corner, according to the map, was in the Pleasant Grove section of Washington Township.

title: Man's Best Friend Scores As Sleuth
description: PORT ELIZABETH HOT, dank, motionless air hung over the port terminal as Tom Ferjo, a United States Customs officer in the K9 Corps, released Duffy from a cage in the back of a station wagon and walked the narcoticsdetecting dog toward a row of parked cars. At the Atlantic Container Line, there are always parked cars, both new imports and others shipped by travelers.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: FEDERAL INQUIRY ON F.B.I. WIDENED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4Justice Department investigators have begun searching files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in at least six major cities in an effort to expand their Inquiry into illegal bureau practices beyond the New York City area, according to sources close to the investigation.

title: Food
description: For every cup of aspic to be used, in a saucepan combine one cup of wellseasoned stock or broth with one envelope of unflavored gelatin, one egg white, beaten until frothy, and one crushed egg shell. Beat with a whisk and place over low heat. Let simmer, without stirring, about 30 seconds.

title: American League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: North Carolina Triumphs Over Miami of Ohio, 1410
description: CHAPEL HILL N.C., Sept. 4 (AP)Mel Collins, a wingback, raced 69 yards for a secondquarter touchdown on a trick play and scored in the fourth quarter on a 9yard pass as North Carolina upset Miami of Ohio, 1410, in a college football season opener today.

title: ART VIEW
description: Letter to Lord Byron is not one of W. H. Auden's more famous poems, though it has quite a lot to tell us about Auden. But it does have in one of those lines which end up in everyone's Dictionary of Quotations. To me, Auden writes, art's subject is the human clay. In the context of the arts In general, we can ally this to Byron's unfeigned and contagious delight in gossip. Not for him the gaseous generalities in which his German contemporaries delighted! What he liked was straightforward talk about who did what with whom. True or untrue, it fed the galloping Dues of Don Juan.

title: Kelley Plans to Marry An ExNan, Paper Says
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 4 (AP)Clarence M. Kelley, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, announced today that he would marry Shirley Dyckes, an elementary school teacher and former nun from Washington, the Kansas City Star reported.

title: 68 Killed in Azores in Crash of a Venezuelan Plane Carrying Choir to Spain
description: ANGRA DO HEROISMO, Azores Sept. 4 (UPI)A Venezuelan Air Force transport] plane carrying a university choir to a festival in Spain, crashed in flames today as it tried to land in a hurricane at a United States Air Force base in the Azores. All 68 persons on board were killed.

description: TOY (Henry Stocker, judge)1, Betty J. Yerington's toy ??e. Ch. Yero?? Done to Perfection. 2. Branch lenerowicz's Maltese. JoanneChen's Nino Maya Dacer 3. Mrs. Walter Jettoras's and Michael Wolf's Pekingese, Ch. Yang Kee Bernard; 4, Anne Seranne's and Barbara Walterman's Yorkshire terrier. Ch. Maytair Baroan Loup ce Mer.

title: Columbia Starters Top Reserves, 1410
description: LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 4  Jay Hickey's 59yard touchdown run in the fourth quarter led Columbia's starting offense to a 14.10 victory over the reserves in an intrasquad football scrimmage today.

title: Opera Is in the Air  And It Has a Most
description: What with the memory of Bayreuth still resounding in the ear (and smarting in the eye), what with La Scala opening on Tuesday in Washington and the Paris Opra opening in New York the very next day, what with the New York City Opera already under way, what with the Metropolitan Opera making noises prefatory to its Oct. 11 opening, one might safely say that opera is in the air.

title: Fiction: a Czech comedy, an Argentinian tour de force, a New York cartoon
description: Milan Kundera is one of the writers and intellectuals closely affiliated with that brief burgeoning, the Prague Spring, Alexander Dubcek's doomed attempt to create a Czech enclave for socialism with a human face, which ended brutally, before it could begin, under Soviet tanks in the cold summer of 1968. Kunderaa poet, playwright, critic, musicologist as well as novelist and shortstory writersuffered the fate of the unrepentant: exclusion from the writers' union; loss of his teaching post at the Prague Film School; denial of passport; banning of his playsfamiliar, depressing exactions of the State's revenge. An official pariah, he would not consent to practice what Isaac Babel called the aesthetics of silence; he went on writing and he has steadily gained a Western European reputation, including the 1973 Prix Mdicis Etranger for his novel Life Is Elsewhere. That novel and another, The Joke, together with a collection of stories, Laughable Loves, have been published in this country, though for some unaccountable reason he is not well known here. A pity, since he arrives not as a literary charity case, but as an uncommonly accomplished, original, disquieting writer.

title: The Senate's Honor
description: The Senate voted unanimously last week to name its new office building for the retiring Michigan Democrat, Philip A. Hart. Despite our reservations about naming buildings for people during their lifetime this action seems appropriate, for around the Capitol, Phil Hart has become a gentle legend in his own time.

title: 1,000 in Zurich Protest KissingerVorster Meeting
description: ZURICH, Sept. 4 (Reuters)About 1,000 people marched through the center of this city chanting slogans in a twohour protest against the meeting between the South African Prime Minister, John Vorster, and Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.

title: The Sky Is Limited
description: WASHINGTONThe surface of the 1976 Presidential campaign, as it has been conducted so far, appears little different from those of the past, but beneath that surface is a difference. For the first time in American political history, there is a limit on the amount of money the two majorparty candidates can spend and a prohibition against private contributions except for limited amounts channeled through various party committees.

title: New Effort by the Arab League for a CeaseFire in Lebanon Thwarted by Conflict Over Troop Withdrawals
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 4Efforts to conclude a new ceasefire in Lebanon have been obstructed by a conflict over the removal of Palestinian forces from the mountains east of Beirut and by disagreements in the rightwing Christian camp and between the Palestinian guerrilla organizations and their leftist and Moslem allies.

title: Union Accused by Brown U.
description: PROVIDENCE, Sept. 4 (AP)Brown University has filed an unfair labor practices charge against Local 134 of the Service Employees Internationa1 Union with the National Labor Relations Board. A university spokesman said the charge alleges that the local has engaged in numerous incidents of illegal conduct during a twomonth strike by 330 food service, housing, library and maintenance workers. Brown contends the strikers have assaulted nonstriking employees, punctured tires, threatened supervisors personnel and broken windows

title: Miss McCracken Bride
description: Georgeann M. McCracken, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George A. McCracken of Rosedale, Queens, was married there yesterday afternoon to John T. Yarbrough, son of Lillian Yarbrough of College Point, Queens, and the late John T. Yarbrough. The Rev. Roger F. McDonough, cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony in St. Clare's Roman. Catholic Church. Mr. McCracken is an assistant to Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes.

title: Girl Killed in Roslyn Heights
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L.I., Sept. 4 (AP)  One teenage girl was killed early today and a second critically injured in a car accident in this Long Island community. Nassau County policemen identified the dead girl as Terry Choplinski, 17 years old of Williston Park.

title: The fortunes of four women
description: Going through the years with Rona Jaffe is rather like reading over old diaries. Were we really like that? Are we still, in spite of everything? The Best of Everythipg, when it came out in 1958, was a chronicle of our own gradeB heartsthere we were, going eagerly to our little publishing jobs in tailored suits and white gloves, looking for love and respect without pregnancy, and, once having crossed over the bridge, having fantasies of sewing kitchen curtains for men who would never notice them. It was all there, the masochism, the Fig Newtons alone in bed, the orgiastic weddings that turned our minds to pulp, stocking seams, crinolines and basic black dresses, New York in its glamour, and the enormous consumption of Scotch on the rocks.

title: FORD HOPES LINKED TO CATHOLIC VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4If President Ford's campaign strategists are correct, the contest between the President, an Episcopalian; and Jimmy Carter, a Southern Baptist, will hinge on the votes of several million Roman Catholics in the industrial states.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: The article about the United States Power Squadrons (Aug. 8) said that, in the past, men who took and passed the boating course were routinely invited to join the squadrons. That is erroneous; taking and passing the course never led to a routine invitation to join the squadrons.

title: TAIWAN DENYING ATOMIC OPERATION
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 4Recent United States intelligence reports that Taiwan has been secretly reprocessing spent uranium fuel into weaponsgrade plutonium may be a result of confusion over a small reprocessing laboratory Taiwan has sought to open, Chinese Nationalist officials and diplomats here believe.

title: Medicaid Cost $1 Billion Since '66
description: SINCE its inception 10 years ago, the Medicaid program, under scrutiny because of abuses and escalating costs, has cost New Jersey taxpayers about $1 billion. In addition, the Federal Government has added another $1 billion or so to that.

description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: MRS. KERSHNER, 84; HELPED ORPHANS
description: DALLAS, Sept. 4Gertrude Kershner, who played a prominent role in the establishment of colonies for orphaned children in World War II and the Spanish Civil War, died yesterday after a short illness at the Methodist Hospital. She was 84 years old.

title: Dutch Plane Hijacked
description: A KLM Royal Dutch Airlines jet with 77 passengers aboard was hijacked after leaving Nice, landed in Tunis and then took off again toward an unknown destination. Page 19.

title: Changes in Power Lines Reduce Death Toll of Eagles in the West
description: PROVO, Utah, Sept. 4The once alarming loss of eagles in power line electrocutions is being significantly reduced as a result of an effort begun four years ago by Western util ity companies. It involves elimmuting dangers to the birds through corrective insulation, pole modifications and wider wire, spacing, according to the Raptor Research Foundation Inc. Raptors are birds of prey.

title: Leigh E. S. Grubstein Wed to Hugh Fenwick
description: St. Bernard's Episcopal Church in Bernardsville, N.J., was the setting yesterday morning for the marriage of Leigh Elizabeth Sulzberger Grubstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Frederick Grubstein of Bernardsville, to Hugh Hammond Fenwick, son of Representative Millicent H. Fenwick of Bernardsville and Hugh McLeod Fenwick of Aiken, S.C.

description: Louise Rison Rhett and Louis Ward Orem, both of Falls Church, Va., plan to be married Oct. 9 in the Episcopal Church of the Nativity in Huntsville, Ala.

description: Your thumb is broken, Jimmy. We'll have to put it in a cast, said Dr. Sam Fleagle.

title: Moore and Sander Gain Final in U.S. Amateur
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4 (AP)South Carolina's Parker Moore beat Stan K. M. Souza of Honolulu on the 19th hole and Bill Sander of Kenmore, Wash., routed James Mason of Kirkwood, Mo., 8 and 7, today as the winners advanced to the final 36 holes in the 76th United States Amateur golf championship.

title: Honors Qaddafi
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Sept. 4 (Agence FrancePresse)President JeanBedel Bokassa of the Central African Republic has decorated the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar elQaddafi, with the Bokassa Grand Order, Libya's press agency has reported. Marshal Bokassa called Colonel Qaddafi Afica's leading hero and soldier.

description: PRAGUE, Sept. 4 (UPI) Ladislav Novomesky, a Slovak Communist poet and politician who spent years in jail in the Stalinist period as an alleged traitor and spy, died in Bratislava today, the Ceteka press agency said. He was 72 years old.

description: Tomorrow  Sports Car Club of America national races at Lime Rock (Conn.) Park. 9 A.M. Information: phone track, (203) 4352572.

title: In Memoriam
description: BELFER, Peter 19461971. HE CHERISHED THE GIFT OF LIFE. We love you and think of you each day, Mom and Dad.

title: Pirates Top Expos And Pull Within 6
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 4 (UPI) Omar Moreno, a rookie, ripped a tworun single with the bases loaded in the ninth inning tonight to help the Pittsburgh Pirates record their 10th straight victory and spoil the managerial debut of Charlie Fox with 53 triumph over the Montreal Expos.

title: Bargains by the Ton
description: GARDEN CITY ALL the world loves a bargain, and whether the source is advertising, flyers, or wordofmouth, bargain hunters manage to stow their quarry and return time and again. So it is that the stalls fill and flow in a busy crosscurrent of buyandsell at The 615 Shop here.

description: By H. Montgomery Hyde. Illustrated. 266 pp. New York: Coward, McCann and Geoghegan. $8.95.

GREEK ISLE SHOWS FEAR OF TURKEY
description: CHIOS. Greece, Sept. 3Only five miles east of this rocky Greek island the lights of Turkey dance in the balmy summer night.
