title: Unveilings
description: GOLDBERGMonument will be unveiled In memory of the late Al Goldberg on Sunday, Sept. 12, at 2:30 P.M., BethEl Cemetery, New Jersey, on the grounds of Concord Lodge, Block 8, Section 11.

title: Canada Cup Team A Challenge to U.S.
description: The Canadian Soccer Association named its World Cup team last Thursday and its manager predicted that the squad would defeat the United States in their World Cup qualifying game on Sept. 24. I really think we can beat the United States, John McMahon, the manager, said after the team was named in Vancouver, British Columbia. The United StatesCanada game, the first in the group, will be played in Vancouver.

title: Nonwhites' Protest Ended by Tear Gas In South Africa City
description: CAPE TOWN Sept. 4 (Reuters)The police fired teargas canisters today to disperse a crowd of about 100 nonwhite demonstrators in the center of Port Elizabeth, 300 miles east of Cape Town.

title: Nonvoters Found Near a Majority
description: Originally it was the joke: Don't voteit only encourages em. But an unusually large group of Americans will act on that principle seriously and consciously by avoiding the polling booths this fall, a new study indicates.

title: GARDENING
description: HERE we go into another planting season. The arrival of Labor Day is a signal to get busy, but the attention of a good many New Jersey gardeners has only begun to turn toward the selection of hardy bulbs and it's almost time to begin planting.

title: STAMPS
description: Soldiers of the American Revolution arrayed in spanking uniforms, and ships of the American Navy of 200 years ago make a proud martial display on a number of Bicentennial commemoratives from abroad that have already become one of the notable omnibus issues of 1976. It makes for eyepleasing stamps, even though the reality has been more than somewhat heightened.

title: Cambodia Bids Thais Return 4 Refugees
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 4 (AP)  Cambodia has asked Thailand to return four senior officials of the former Phnom Penh regime who are living as refugees in Thailand, according to the Interior Ministry.

title: Weddings
description: CoffeyMacLean

title: Usery Backs Jobs for All
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) Labor Secretary W. J. Usery has called on Americans to dedeicate Labor Day to the goal of achieving productive and steady employment for all workers. Only when all people who seek work are able to ciety through productive labor wilt they be assured of their fair share of society's benefits, Mr. Usery said.

title: Undefeated Revidere Takes Gazelle
description: William Haggin Perry's heavily favored Revidere, a filly that almost was sold last season by his owner for $35,000 as a nonracing juvenile, earned almost that much yesterday in capturing the $53,250 Gazelle at Belmont Park.

title: The Paris Opera Successful but Not Very French
description: The Paris Opera that opens a 10day enzagement Wednesday at the Metropolitan Opera house is a company transformed from its sorry state of only a few years ago. But in reversing the company's 100year decline, Rolf Liebermann, its general director, paradoxically risks losing what made French opera great in the first place.

title: Patrice Ann McGurk, Bank Aide, Is Wed
description: Patrice Ann McGurk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Francis McGurk of Hempstead, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Daniel McAuliffe Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McAuliffe of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Sarah K. Burns To Wed Oct. 23
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan Lincoln Burns of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Kendrick Burns, to David Barclay Mitchell, president of the David B. Mitchell & Company, representatives in New York for hotels in Bermuda, the Bahamas and the Caribbean. The wedding is planned for Oct. 23 in the Rye Presbyterian Church.

title: Augusta Strong North, 61, Marxist Writer and Teacher
description: Augusta Strong North, a Marxist writer, linguist and teacher of black literature, died Wednesday in Martha's Vineyard Hospital in Massachusetts. She was 61 years old.

title: Learning to Be an Unernployed Teacher
description: DIANE SACHS is a Long Island teacher. To be more exact, she is an unemployed Long Island teacher who, like hundreds of her Nassau and Suffolk County colleagues, faces the opening of the school year without a classroom of her own or, for that matter, any sort of teaching job.

title: Where the Money Goes
description: Following is how $46,066,613 transferred to the state from the New Jersey Lottery was spent in the 1976 fiscal year just ended:

title: Family Receives $10,000 for Dog Killed in West Islip, L. I., Pound
description: A West Islip, L. I., family whose Old English sheepdog was picked up by a dog warden two years ago and was mistakenly put to death at the Islip animal pound within two hours has accepted a $10,000 settlement from the town's insurance company.

title: Paperbacks
description: A HOUSE FOR MR. BISWAS. (Penguin, $3.95.) THE MIMIC MEN. (Penguin, $1.95.) THE SUFFRAGE OF ELVIRA (Penguin, $1.95.) Three novels by V. S. Naipaui, dating from 1961, 1965 and 1951 respectively, the work of an author unique for his Hindu origin, West Indian birthplace and British education; whether writing about marriage or fantasy and statelessness or politics, his observations are sharp, his comedy wry.

title: PRESIDENT SAYS KELLEY WILL STAY AS F.B.I. DIRECTOR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4President Ford has decided to retain Clarence M. Kelley as Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation despite disclosures that Mr. Kelley accepted some free goods and services from the bureau and some gifts from his top aides, the White House announced today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: OSTUNI, Italy, Sept. 4 (UPI)Kornelia Van Oosten Hage of the Netherlands broke out of a tightly knit pack of 52 cyclists today to win the women's road race at the world cycling championships for the second time. A crowd of 60,000 lined the course at this Adriatic resort town.

title: Bernhard's Northrop Ties Bring a Wave of Questions
description: THE HAGUE, Sept. 4Disclosures that Prince Bernhard retained links with the Northrop Aircraft Corporation as well as Lockheed have stirred a wave of questions here about the Prince's financial dealings, his personal life, his ties to American intelligence officials and even his background.

title: The Hawk That Sings Like A Lark
description: Things are looking up in New York. The Yankees are about ten games ahead in the American League East, Pat Moynihan is leading Bella Abzug for the Senate Democratic nomination, and Mayor Beame seems to have grown at least an inch since the Fourth of July.

title: Massachusetts Divorce
description: BOSTON, Sept. 4 (AP)More than a third of all marriages in Massachusets last year ended in divorce, according to a report released by the state.

title: Susan Hinrichs Sets Oct. 9 Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stuart W. Hinrichs of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Hinrichs, to Peter Addenbrook Thomas Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas, also of Greenwich.

title: Political Experience And the Presidency
description: AMHERST, Mass.Characteristic of the shortsightedness of the Republican high command is its decision to attack Governor Carter on the ground that, by comparison with President Ford, he lacks experience in the conduct of national and foreign affairs. Behind this impeachment is the assumption that in these fields, experience gives some assurance of coinpetence and sound judgment but inexperience condemns to incompetence and confusion.

title: If They Could Reorder It, the HaveNots Would Have More
description: NEW DELHIIn The Camp of the Saints, a recent novel by the French writer Jean Respell, one million Indians, having reached the point of ultimate despair, put together a fleet of rickety old ships on the Ganges River and set sail for Europe, the promised land. Hungry, underclothed and overcrowded in their native country, they headed north as illegal immigrants with no justification beyond the conviction that the economic disparity between them and the world's rich was no longer tolerable simply because it was not fair.

title: The Reason Is Almost Too Simple: Members Value Their Privacy
description: WASHINGTONAlthough morality in government is now a Presidential campaign issue and although the House of Representatives has recently been chagrined by the peccadilloes of some of its members, the House appears reluctant to pass a basic reform measure designed to encourage public confidence in the integrity of Federal Government officials.

title: Combating Terrorism
description: The Agreement by 18 European Ministers of Justice on a draft treaty against international terrorism is the most promising approach that has yet materialized to deter or punish the heinous crimes that extremist groups have for years been perpetrating with impunity. If approved as expected by the heads of government of the 18 countries at their Council of Europe meeting in Strasbourg Sept. 22, a solid basis will be laid for early ratification and, equally important, for action in the United Nations General Assembly this fall to achieve wider adherence to a similar but more limited convention, which West Germany plans to introduce.

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: I have a middleaged lady client who recently came to me, said an accountant the other day. She has all her wealth tied up in New York City notes now under moratorium. She is so worried about her situation that I fear for her mental health.

title: Nastase Debate Rages
description: A report on Ilie Tasiase was turned in to United States Tennis Association headquarters yesterday. However, the debate over the Rumanian's court behavior raged on at the Open championships.

title: A Brick Shield for Spacecraft
description: One key to the type of Space Shuttle the United States plans to put into orbit starting in 1979 resulted from a sort of technological treasure hunt.

title: Monmouth And the Arts
description: LINCROFT It may be a little early to talk of Christmas trees, but writing about the Monmouth Museum and Cultural Center brings to mind its famous annual Christmas tree display. Of all the different kinds of shows this institution has put on, the tree has been an acclaimed favorite and draws large crowds from both Monmouth County itself and elsewhere.

title: North Atlantic Show to Open Thursday
description: With flags flying, sails furled and decks gleaming, more than 300 yachts will be on display Thursday as the fifth annual North Atlantic Boat Show opens a fourday run at Yachthaven West in Stamford, Conn. The show, the first of the 1977 model year and the first of threeinthewater shows in the metropolitan area this month, features a full complement of sailboats from high performance onedesign classes to 50foot cruising yachts, with the emphasis on trailable cruising boats.

title: Soft evidence and hard sell
description: It was discovered almost by accident. Army recruits reporting to Fort Dix, NJ., in January began coming down with respiratory diseases, just as they do every winter when they assemble in close quarters, bringing together infections from the far corners of the nation. Army doctors were not particularly concerned. They thought they were dealing with common adenoviruses, agents that cause coldlike symptomstroublesome, but no reason for panic. Then Col. Joseph Bartley, chief of preventive medicine at Fort Dix, following routine, called to warn the county health officer that the presumed adenovirus outbreak might also spread to civilians. That officer, in turn, alerted state health officials, who immediately suspected an outbreak of influenza, a viruscaused infection of the respiratory tract that is also commonly called grippe or flu. The state officials asked for throat washings from the sick recruits. Sure enough, laboratory tests revealed the presence of viruses belonging to the influenza A family, the type that causes most flu infections in man. But the tests added an element of mystery. While some of the specimens contained the familiar strain of flu known as A/Victoria, others contained a strain of influenza A that could not be identified. These were sent to the Federal Center for Disease Control in Atlanta.

title: Doing Business in Portugal After the Revolution
description: PACO DE ARCOS, Portugal Central General Electronics is a young private company that has learned to live with the Socialist revolution.

title: Sit, Roll Over, Bite the Burglar

In Nassau County, they're heading for Dick Mailer, a former president of the United States Professional Dog Trainers Association who has assisted several police departments in the training of their canine corps.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE WHOLESALE PRICE INDEX dropped 0.1 percent in August to 183.7 [1967=100], reflecting the sharpest decline In farm prices in 18 months, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported. . . . The nation's unemployment rate in August rose to 7.9 percent from 7.8 percent in July, the third monthly increase, the Labor Department ret ported.... The Conference Board said that capital appropriations by the nation's 1,000 largest manufacturers rose 13.2 percent to $12.8 billion in the second quarter. . . . Construction contracts signed in August declined from July but were 9 percent above a year ago at $9.77 billion, F. W. Dodge reported.

description: PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 4 President Ford described today the automated landing of Viking 2 on Mars, without any help from Earth, as a tremendous feat. It was, he told the mission participants by telephone, a superlative demonstration of America's skill and teamwork.

title: DUTCH JET SEIZED FLYING FROM NICE
description: TUNIS, Sunday, Sept. 5 (AP) A KLM Royal Dutch Airlines jet was hijacked on a flight from Nice to Amsterdam last night, landed at Tunis for refueling and then took off after a fivehour stopover with all its 77 passengers and five crew members still aboard.

title: The World
description: More than 450 police officers and civilians have been injured in fighting in and near London's venerable Portobello Road. The violence may simply have begun because there were too many overeager policemen on hand last week for a street fair. But the fighting was distinctly racial in nature Portobello Road is in Notting Hill, which has a large West Indian communityand pointed up anew the racial antagonism that for 20 years has been near the surface in many British cities and towns.

description: Football often defies all the thinking that is poured into this cerebral sport. No definitive conclusions are ever reached as to the best way to play the game, and therefore it is cyclical as to its style and strategy.

title: Labor Day: The Pain of the PostMortem Season
description: The most dangerous part of a summer vacation begins after Labor Day.

title: Up, up and awaythe rise and fall of comic books
description: I read my first comic book on a school playground in Newark, N. J., sometime in the late 1920's, with a sense of entering a world not only forbidden but magical, like the world of my most unconfessable dreams. It was an eightpage Bible slipped to me by the class Bad Boy: a pornographic burlesque of the comic strip Tillie the Toiler in which she and her usually impotent admirer, Mac, performed sexual acts beyond the scope of my unaided 12yearold fantasy. That they had bodies at all under the conventional garb they never shucked in their daily adventures seemed to me wondrous enough, and that they had usable genitals as well at once blasphemous and miraculous.

title: Mary E. Schramm Fiancee of Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Gagan of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Gagan's daughter, Mary Elizabeth Schramm, to William Hughes Mulligan Jr., son of Judge Mulligan of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, and Mrs. Mulligan of Bronxville.

title: STRIKE IS ENDED AT GREEN HAVEN
description: A strike by inmates at the Green Haven Correctional Facility in Stormville, N.Y., has ended, a prision official said yesterday.

title: A Boost for a Ballerina
description: In the nativedaughtermakesgood category, this week's star is Marianna Tcherkassky. Long a favorite of Americall Ballet Theater audiences, the Glen Coveborn Miss Tcherkassky has been elevated to principal dancer with the ballet company. She joined the company in 1970, was made a soloist in 1972, and this past summer made what Clive Barnes of The Times called a dream debut as Giselle. While waiting for the American Ballet Theater fall tour to begin in a couple of weeks, she has been working in New York and Hollywood on the new 20th Century Fox film about ballet life, The Turning Point.

title: Your Isadora
description: In the grand and extravagant spectacle that was Isadora Duncan's life, nothing was ever trivial, least of all her love affairs. I live in my body like a spirit in a clouda cloud of rose fire and voluptuous response, she proclaimed in My Life, one of the most lavishly narcissistic autobiographies ever written. Of course, she had every reason to be selfregarding. Unique in her genius, celebrated in every European capital, indomitable in the cause of advancing modern dance, Isadora lived with what she herself once described as a pagan innocence that led her into one bizarre, unhappy affair after another. The most notorious of her many liaisons was with the Russian poet Sergei Esenin. But Francis Steegmuller has now reconstructed an even more significant (and, if possible, even more disastrous) relationship In  Your Isadora: The Love Story or Isadore Duncan and Gordon Craig.

title: Editors' Choice
description: THE FAMILY ARSENAL, by Paul Theroux. (Houghton Mifflin, $8.95.) Intelligent thriller about futilitarian revolutionaries in London.

title: Atlantis recaptured
description: First came an earthquake, knocking down some buildings, damaging others. Teams of workmen started to clear and rebuild the city. After a certain periodperhaps weeks, perhaps yearsthe volcano erupted. The inhabitants had enough time to take their valuables, and then life stopped short.

title: What Are Schools For, Anyway?
description: ANOTHER school year is about to descend on all of us; parents, teachers, and students. How do we feel about it? I use the word descend advisedly because, more than anything else; I think we feel burdened by our institutions today. We are unhappy and dissatisfied with them. For many reasons, both clear and unclear they aren't doing the jobs we want them to.

title: Time to Come Indoors
description: VACATION time is about to end for houseplants that were taken outside for the summer. They should be brought indoors well in advance of the coming, of outdoor temperatures colder than those they will experience when brought in. The transition from outdoor to indoor conditions will be eased if they are not kept out too long. Waiting until the last minute also exposes them to the risk of frost.

title: New York Label for a London Tailor
description: LONDON  Douglas Hayward left school at 15, and as he looked around his home in the industrial London suburb of Hayes, he decided that he wasn't equipped to work in the factories there. Nor did he want to get into anything very competitive, a characteristic that sociologists have found to be common to the English, except on the playing field. So Douglas Hayward became an apprentice tailor. I didn't know anyone who was a tailor, he said: Mr. Hayward is now 41 and a fullfledged tailor who makes suits to order for an English  American clientele. His career has taken a number of lucrative and sometimes fortuitous turns. Now Mr. Hayward is turning to readytowear suits and to the American market. Both of these segments of the menswear industry are as vigorously competitive as business can get.

title: Three Arrested for the Murder Of Woman, 82, in Coney Island
description: Three young men were arrested yesterday and charged with murdering a 82yearold widow Thursday and robbing her of $8 in her Coney Island apartment.

In either case, what happens in the next few days seems certain to have a profound influence on the future course of life in southern Africa.

Their administration is more flexible, allowing for quicker responses to needs and curiosities. They collect and conserve the heritage of their own communities. A composite of the small museums of America would produce several collections of major importance with values running into many millions of dollars.

title: Dead aheadPlum Gut
description: The Long Island Sound off Larchmont Harbor on the afternoon before the start of the annual Block Island Race is a bedlam of sail. Like feeding sharks, big boats cross and recross each other's wakes harrowingly close, churning the green water. Southwest, to windward, veiled in smog and framed by the ghostly span of the Throg's Neck Bridge, sprawls Queensa weird backdrop for these hybrid chrome and fiberglass toys, no one of which cost less than $30,000 and many several times that figure. The crews perch like gulls on slanting decks, wave and call to friends or offer up muted estimates of each other's talents: I've seen those turkeys set a spinnaker upside down.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: Guest Sees His First Striped Bass
description: GAY HEAD, Mass.Barely ruffled by a gentle southwest breeze, the sea shimmered under a brilliant late afternoon sun when we cut our engine and began to cast for striped bass in the tide rips off Gay Head.

title: Here Comes the Space Shuttle

title: HERBERT E. TWYEFFORT
description: Herbert E. Twyeffort, who retired in 1960 as vice president and head of the corporate trust department of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died last Monday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 936 Fifth Avenue.

title: Headliners
description: Immediately upon being installed last week as Uruguay's new President, Aparacio Mndez did what he had promised to do to get the job. He suspended the political rights of several thousand officials of traditional Uruguayan political parties. His act will not have much effect on politics as practiced by ordinary Uruguayans: They have lived under a military dictatorship since 1973, when former President Juan Maria Bordaberry, with military backing, closed Congress down and suspended most political rights. Mr. Mndez said the new restriction was needed to end the inertia of the political parties and to prepare for broader political participation. But his act seemed to tighten, not loosen, the military's control, and Mr. Mndez did not say when or how the people would be allowed to participate again.

title: Arms Traffic Continues to Flourish, Particularly in Mideast and Africa, London Research Institute Says
description: LONDON. Sept, 4Traffic in arms continues to flourish throughout the world and is probably increasing, an international research institute said here last week.

title: Farewell to Hays
description: Wayne Hays resigned from the House of Representatives and, in short order, the House ethics committee voted unanimously to terminate its investigation, announced it would issue no report and moved on new business.

title: Endpaper
description: The discovery of Daphnia came for me early one Sunday morning, while my wife and our house guests slept. I watched for hours. Peering into her world, I didn't at first feel I was intruding. She and her friends swam at random, free as Daphnias are. In their liquid home, giant green and dark brown specks floated, migrating slowly around like icebergs in the salt sea. The motes of that world I saw were flicked in the backstream of Daphnias on errands I could not even guess at, but I placed a bet on food, with its debris in the wake as they roved. I could not be sure yet. It was my first look at their place.

title: Last Week's Explosion in Notting Hill Was the Worst in Two Decades
description: LONDONNoisy lightning following by sullen silence: The second Notting Hill riot in less than 20 years came and went like a summer thunderstorm. But though it lasted only a few hours, last week's clash between white policemen and black youngsters in West Londonthe worst racial disturbance here in recent memoryleft deep scars and raised broad questions.

title: Julius Strauss Is Dead at 77; Former Chief of General Cigar
description: Julius Strauss, who retired in 1972 as the president and chief executive of the General Cigar Company, died Friday in the North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset, L.I. He was 77 years old.

title: Women Starting To Blaze Trails In State Parks
description: Nancy Reilly decided, as a lark and to prove a woman could do it, to take a civil service examination for state park superintendent. She was in her early 50's and had lived in Queens all her life and worked in various offices of the state park system on Long Island.

title: It Is Important to Know Where the Targets Are
description: A year ago the two pilotless Viking spacecraft were propelled toward Mars on long, looping paths of hundreds of millions of miles that brought them to their destination with a final error of only 50 miles. The aim of the Viking engineers was comparable to putting a bullet through a playing card from a distance of 30 miles.

title: Labor Day: The Battle Against The PostVacation Blahs
description: Are you lying on a Long Island beach, savoring a last bit of summer sun and dreading the imminent end of your vacation? Are you piling the contents of a Maine cabin into a station wagon, hating the thought of returning to a workaday world? Are you waiting reluctantly in a London airport lounge for a flight back to the tensions and frustrations of daily life? Well, there's a lot of that going around right now. Millions upon millions of Americans are coming down with the Labor Day blahs and most of them are not sure how to cope with this annual postvacation state of depression, irritability, anxiety and the rotten feeling of just feeling rotten.

title: R. R. Mouk Fiance of Barbara Buketoff

title: The Legion Disease: So Little Still Is Known About the Body
description: Stumped. Baffled. Five weeks after a mysterious illness killed 26 persons associated with a Philadelphia American Legion convention, two more from a Roman Catholic meeting in the same city, and a 29th victim associated with neither event, the cause was no clearer than initially. The hordes of eager young field investigators loosed on the Pennsylvania countryside, the troops of epidemiologists, the phalanxes of sober pathologistsall have come to dead ends in their investigations of the epidemic which, itself, seems to have burned out spontaneously.

description: THERE'S been a change in the weather, and it seems as if there'll be a change in the fishing too. The seas on, which started off with a bang in the spring only to settle down to one of the worst summers in years, now seems headed for a super autumn.

Rhoda Sweitzer into the canvas tent that was temporary home for the 15 young women of Invaders Squadron.

description: When young suburbanites leave their parents' homes and start looking for places of their own, they are in for a shock.

title: The Body Is the Hero
description: Ronald Glasser is a relative rarity among physicians. He can write lucidly, vividly, even dramatically. He has a real and constant feeling for patients, their hopes, pains, fear and suffering, and at the same time he has remained in touch with his own feelings. He has managed, somehow, despite an impressive mastery of clinical techniques and scientific knowledge, to hang onto his humility and humanity.

description: A major antitrust bill is on the verge of passageor death. It is called the HartScottRodino Antitrust Improvements Act but detractors contend that it is not an improvement. Its fate will be decided within the next four weeks.

title: Popular Spot, SoSo Food
description: SEVERAL restaurants have tried to make a go of it in the quarters now occupied by the Joshua Tree. You don't have to be an expert to predict that this one is not going to fail, not for a long time. Even on weekday nights, the parking space is filled to overflowing and there can be a wait for a table.

title: Peterson Leaving Council
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) President Ford accepted today with the deepest regret the resignation of Russell W. Peterson as chairman of the President's Council on Environmental Quality. In an exchange of letters released by the White House, Mr. Peterson said he was leaving the advisory post effective Oct. 1 to head what he called a citizens' lobby, to be called New Directions.

title: Yonkers Results
description: (OTB Payoffs subject to 5% State tax)

title: POLISH CARDINAL WARMLY GREETED
description: Karol Cardinal Wojtyla, Archbishop of Cracow, Poland, and one of the 10 Roman Catholic prelates most frequently mentioned as a possible successor to Pope Paul VI, got a warm welcome yesterday from New York's Polish community.

title: For young readers
description: In this comic strip designed for entertainment and enlightenment, a busy blob of a pup, having been consigned to a pair of yearning kids by a presence alluded to as the Wise Passerby, proceeds to nip, yip and relieve itself. The jokes number three. When the dog is good, the boy calls it a him. When the dog is bad, the boy calls it a her. The girl does the opposite. When the dog exercises its bodily functions, the children snigger. Most readers snigger too. The Wise Passerby who forever lectures the kids manages to do whatever he deplores their doing to the pup.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Just about a year ago, John Crosby delivered himself of his first novel, a sophisticated espionage thriller named An Affair of Strangers. Crosby, years back, wrote radio and television reviews that are still fondly remembered as among the wittiest and most literate ever to come from an American newspaperman. But An Affair of Strangers showed Crosby's inexperience as a novelist, Even more surprising, considering Crosby's expertise as a phrasemaker, were the stylistic cliches that kept popping up.

title: Sunday Observer
description: I am feeling well disposed to the Republican Party this week, which may indicate either an acute attack of summer euphoria or advanced arteriosclerosis, although I prefer to ascribe it to a sensible terror of having Washington occupied exclusively by Democrats. Whatever the case, this passing twinge of good will prompts a small suggestion for their conduct of the campaign, a suggestion which they will doubtless resent.

title: LETTERS
description: In his analysis of five science fiction films (How SciFi Films Support the Status Quo, July 18), Vincent Canby sets up impossible strictures, and then belabors science fiction for not giving birth to worthy works.

title: Miss Gonzalez Sets Wedding
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jose R. Gonzlez of San Juan, P. R., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maria de Lourdes Gonzlez, to Peter Milan Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Johnson Jr. of Rosemont, Pa.

title: GOLDIN SAYS CITY LOSES $930,000
description: Poor control of New York City's inventory has caused unnecessary storage expense to the city of $930,000 a year, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

title: 30,000 IN ULSTER MARCH FOR PEACE
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Sept. 4 (AP)A crowd of Roman Catholic and Protestant women thought to number about 30,000 met today on a bridge that divides the two sections of Londonderry to call for an end to seven years of sectarian violence in Northern Ireland.

title: 2 Women Leave West Point
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept. 4 (UPI)  Two more of West Point's pioneer female cadets left over the weekenddropping female enrollment to 100 and raising the attrition rate to 16 percent. At the start of training July 7, there were 119 women. Gay Gray and Gertrude B. Huffman trudged through the gates of the United States Military Academy late yesterday, motored to New York City and, according to reports, spent the night in an apartment with acquaintances.

title: Arab Leaders Agree to Hold a Summit Meeting in Cairo Next Month When Sarkis Is President of Lebanon
description: CAIRO, Sept. 4The leaders of the Arab world will hold a summit meeting here on the subject of Lebanon in the third week of October, the Arab League announced tonight.

title: Late Television Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in the Arts and Leisure Section:

title: Nothing But Time on His Hands
description: LIKE countless other harried workers, Tom Corcoran of Phillipsburg always keeps two briefcases on hand. In the one, he carries the routine paperaiork of a project engineer for the state's Department of Transportation.

title: Births
description: Allen

title: State's 6Year Net From Lottery: $258 Million
description: TRENTON SINCE the first sale of a legal lottery ticket in New Jersey on Dec. 17, 1970a 50cent ticket in the weekly lottery drawingsales in the New Jersey lottery have totaled about $575 million.

title: To a Building, Emptiness Means Many Things
description: The towering luxury highrise and the crumbling fourstory walkup stand facing each other, separated by Second Avenue and looking strikingly dissimilar. At first glance, about all they seem to have in common is the neighborhood. But inside, there is the same eerie presence. Emptiness.

title: A Special Love for Special Children
description: HERB AND FREDDA STIMELL had been anxiously waiting for their baby, and Fredda, who was nearly 33 when Nancy was born, could hardly wait to hold her.

title: The Russians Said Hello to Dolly Levi
description: The SovietAmerican film of The Bluebird vanished only days after it opened around the country, but the play it was based on is still going strong at the Moscow Art Theater after 68 years and more than 2,000 performances in the company's repertory.

title: Of Accidie and Longevity
description: Jack Orr, who used to be a newspaperman himself, saw a recent piece here about an insurance company's discovery that third basemen lived longer than shortstops and first basemen longer than managers. On occasion in the dear dead past, one thing or another might drive Jack to drink, but this piece drove him to his typewriter. He wrote: Speaking of death, which seems to be a preoccupation of mine along with I. W. Harper, Liv Ullman and don'tbringtheinfieldinnowdummy, I find myself reading the obituary page first, before turning to the team standings. Wasn't there an EnglishmanWaugh, perhaps who said he read the obits in The London Times in bed and if his name wasn't there, got up andshaved? [don't know about Waugh, but our sportswriting friend Caswell Adams used to say it and then one morning his name was there. Ed. note].

title: On Being Driven to Distraction
description: MY son is learning to drive and, although they seem to do a good job teaching him in school, I have occasionally been taking him out on weekends for practice. This has raised the old question about whether it is helpful for one member of the family to help another member of the family when it comes to driving.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: A significant fact was omitted from your Aug. 15 article entitled A Museum Exhibition of Politics regarding the Vanderbilt Muesum in Huntington. The American Association of Museums has indicated that if a museum of the size and importance of the Vanderbilt Museum were to hire a nonprofessional as its director, particularly a politically oriented person, then the association would seriously have to consider withdrawing accreditation from the

title: The Campaign Begins
description: The preliminaries are over. The organization staffs have been recruited. The leaders of the rival political factions and big interest groups have been consulted. The initial travel schedules have been worked out. The debates have been arranged and the candidates briefed. The time for golf dates and softball games is over. It is the Labor Day weekend and the 1976 Presidential campaign is about to begin.

title: Jean Thompson Bride of Daniel Cohen
description: Jean Bradlee Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Elliott Thompson of Norwalk, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Daniel Leslie Cohen, son of David J. Cohen of Upper Saddle River, N. J., and the late Mrs. Cohen.

title: Nearby Horse Show AT MORRISTOWN. N.J.
description: Variety Groups

title: Soweto Protest Leader Eludes the Police
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 4Police commanders here have begun an investigation to determine how a British television team succeeded in interviewing a 19yearold Soweto student, believed to be a key figure be hind the upheaval in the black (township, who has eluded a police manhunt for more than twc months.

title: Notes: SelfService In Upstate Vineyards
description: The tag end of summer is bringing good, news for that novel breed of migrant farm worker, the vacationer or weekender who wants to pick his own fruit The grape harvest in the Finger Lakes Region of New York state is expected to be quite good, says Thomas Zabadal, Cooperative Extension specialist in Penn Yan, N. Y. It is expected to begin in earnest tomorrow and to continue well into October, peaking about Sept. 20.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Just over six weeks after the successful touchdown of Viking 1 on the surface of Mars, Viking 2, its identical sister ship, has landed at another site on the same planet. Viking 2's target area was on the opposite side of Mars from Viking 1's, and considerably farther north: If Viking 1 were in the latitude of Mexico City, Viking 2 would be in that of Montreal.

title: Acrostic puzzle
Steve Lobell Wins The Hambletonian
description: DU QUOIN, Ill., Sept. 4 The richest race in trotting history, the $263,524 Hambletonian, for 3yearolds, was won here today by Steve Lobell in a rush of world records, injuries and four strenuous heatsspread over five hours in the sunthat nearly cost the colt's life.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on bill designating as a wild and scenic river, a 26 mile segment of the New River in North Carolina, which passed, 69 to 16, Aug. 30.

title: Licensing a Name
description: Doug Hayward's American venture is a variation of the usual namedesigner franchise deal. Typically, a Pierre Cardin or Yves Saint Laurent licenses a manufacturer to produce clothing bearing the designer's label in return for a fee based on a percentage of sales.

title: Agnes Vallo Has Nuptials
description: Agnes M. Katelin Vallo, daughter of Mrs. Richard lhasz of Milford, Conn., and Dennis E. Vallo of Munich, Germany, was married in Purchase, N. Y., yesterday evening to Stanley Freeman Knowles. He is the son of the late Arlene Eugley Knowles of Orleans, Mass., and Stanley F. Knowles of Providence R. I.

title: CALIFORNIA FORBIDS BURIAL OF DEFOLIANT
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 4 (UPI)  California officials have refused to permit a Texas company to bury surplus poisonous defoliant of the type that contaminated the Italian city of Seveso last month.

title: BRIDGE
description: Whenever an expert fails to find the right play and goes down in a contract he could have made, he has a standard excuse available. I had a blind spot, he announces, implying that he would have found the solution on any other day of the week.

title: Meadowlands Results
Nicholson Lamdin 3d Weds Mary P. Drake
description: In St, Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bay Shore, L. I., at noon yesterday, Mary Phoebe Drake, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emmett Tyson Drake Jr. of Brightwaters, L. I., became the bride of Nicholson Gist Lamdin 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lamdin Jr. of West Islip, L. I. The Rev. John Rowan performed the ceremony.

title: Nigerian Leader Sets Up Atomic Energy Commission
description: LAGOS, Nigeria (Agence FrancePresse)Nigetia has set up an Atomic Energy Commission with responsibility for nuclear research and development.

title: TV VIEW
description: By far the most astonishing and, in many ways, brilliant 90 minutes of television this week is The Naked Civil Servant, the dramatized biography of a flamboyantly effeminate homosexual, What is equally astonishing is that the production can be found, this Tuesday evening at 10, on WOR/Channel 9, one of New York City's independent stations, a group not usually associated with original or adventurous programming. The Naked Civil Servant, however, is part of a clever gambit in which, for a full MondaythroughFriday week from 5:30 P.M. close down around 3 A.M., Channel 9 will feature exclusively the programs of Thames Television, the British production company.

title: Melissa Langston Wed to Lawyer
description: Melissa Lincoln Langston, assistant to the president of Howard Weil, Labouisse, Friedrichs Inc., an investment securities concern of New Orleans, was married yesterday morning to Donald Woodward Doyle Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Doyle of New Orleans.

title: What It Cost
Few New York House Colleagues Are Supporting Mrs. Abzug
description: Representative Bella S. Abzug is making a major point of her endorsement by the House majority leader, Thomas P. O'Neill, even using the Massachusetts Democrat's kind words in a radio commercial. Yesterday, she announced the backing of 22 other outofstate Representative for her bid for the Democratic Senate nomination.

title: A No From the Ranks
description: REPRESENTATIVE Jerome A. Ambro, Democrat of East Northport, has elected not to join the vast majority of his Democratic colleagues in hailingin advancethe almost certain promotion to Speaker next year of Thomas P. O'Neill, Democrat of Massachusetts, the House majority leader.

title: Meeting of 5 Leaders Is Pat Off in Tanzania
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sept. 4 (AP)A meeting of five black African Presidents to discuss strategy for eliminating whiteminority rule in southern Africa has been put off one day until Monday.

title: Photos by Viking 2 Show A BoulderStrewn Plain
description: PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 4Viking 2, having landed safely on Mars last evening, has opened its television eyes and gazed on Utopia Plain. The pictures, received here early today, show a landscape very different from that of the Utopia envisioned by Sir Thomas More in his 16thcentury dream of en ideal land.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Historic Site Is Urged For Presidential Debate
description: GALESBURG, Ill., Sept. 4 Knox College has invited the Presidential candidates to debate at what the college says is the only extant site of a LincolnDouglas debate.

title: Trot Victor Collapses, Almost Dies
description: DU QUOIN, Ill., Sept. 4One year after Bonefish had won the Hambletonian in four heats and then nearly died a week later, racing history was repeated tonight when Steve Lobell also won the big prize in four heats but nearly lost his life.

title: The Education Of Patrick Silver
description: The Education of Patrick Silver concludes Jerome Charyn's trilogy of novels (Blue Eyes and Marilyn the Wild are the first two) about New York cops and marginal crooks and killers who suggest an animated cartoon by a Chagall of the Ashcan School. The novels stress, among other things, a fluidity of affiliations between its cops and crooks: Patrick Silver, an expoliceman too addicted to Guinness stout to remain useful to the force, has switched sides. He is now employed by the Guzmanns, a family of criminals headquartered in the Bronx, as bodyguard to the feebleminded 44yearold Guzmann baby, Jernimo.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The 10medal series memorializing Historic American Customhouses is considered one of the Treasury Department's best Bicentennial commemorative efforts. The interesting, artistic and inexpensive series is a joint program of the U.S. Customs Service and the Bureau of the Mint. The eighth medal in the series was announced over a year ago, but when months passed with no official word on the ninth and tenth medals, it was generally assumed that some unavoidable delays had been encountered probably the pressures of the Mint's other Bicentennial commemorative issues. It turns out that the problem was not in the production end but was due to a communications gap.

title: Kool and Company OutRhythm Commodores' Funky Sounds
description: If the Friday evening soul concert at the Beacon Theater was actually a contest, the Commodores Vs. Kool and the Gang, as the posters proclaimed, then Kool and company were the winners. According to the posters, L.T.D., the opening group, was not directly involved in the contest, and this was just as well, since the band's brand of dance music was professional but not very distinctive.

title: Reward for Malaysia Rebel
description: KUCHING, Malaysia, Sept. 4 (Reuters)  Malaysian authorities in Sarawak State are offering a $7,000 reward for the capture of a top Communist guerrilla leader alive, $5,700 if he in taken dead. The reward for the Communist Party Central Committee leader, Hung Cho Ting, was the highest in a list of six bounties offered in pamphlets distributed in areas frequented by guerrillas.

title: Chicago Teachers to Report To Work Without Contract
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (UPI)Chicago's 27,000 public school teachers will report to work Tuesday without a contract, the Chicago Teachers Union president, Robert Healey, said today after two hours of negotiations with the financially strapped school board.

title: Local Boards Get Briefing On Role Under Charter
description: Several hundred neighborhood activists were introduced to the arcana of New York City's budget process last week as their local community boards prepared to take a larger role under the revised City Charter. The board members found the experience brodening, if somewhat bewildering.

title: The Old Man of the Boatyard
description: ALVAH GOLDSMITH took one look at the ad and he was hooked. It was 1922 and in Country Gentlemen magazine there was Ole Evinrude explaining why no boat should be without his new ingenious 3 H.P. outboard motor.

title: Jane Elizabeth Freeze Is Married in South to Ward Graves
description: Jane Elizabeth Freeze and Robert Ward Graves, graduates of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, were married yesterday in Greensboro, N. C. The Rev. Dr. Joseph B. Mullin performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church.

title: FILM VIEW
description: IN theory the most objective kind of movie, the documentary usually comes across as the most subjective. Documentaries invite us to believe that they are about reality and not just about a story. But stories belong to whoever tells them: reality is our own property and those who plant flags on it risk being cited for trespass and littering.

title: Kathleen Acheson Thompson Affianced to John S. McCurdy
description: The engagement of Kathleen Acheson Thompson to John S. McCurdy has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Fred D. Thompson of New York, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of M. Barbara McCurdy of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Joseph R. McCurdy.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 5, 1976

title: Visitors Drop 8th in Row, 73
description: The Mets, happy to be a factor in the National League pennant race although they are not personally involved, dealt another staggering blow to the Philadelphia Phillies yesterday at Shea Stadium.

title: Princeton Blacks' Plight
description: PRINCETON has long had a reputation as the northernmost Southern town and, despite the national civilrights and blackpower movements, its blacks are in many ways a separate community with problems of which the foremost are housing and jobs.

title: Tenafly Decision Due
description: TENAFLY'S long fight to acquire acreage in the East Hill section of the borough for parkland has finally reached the New Jersey Supreme Court, which is expected to rule this week on a taxpayers' suit seeking to block the purchase. Because of Tena fly's insistence that the group filing the suit post a bond of $2 million, the action has taken on wider importance than simple landuse litigation.

title: UNFROCKED PRIEST LIVES AS BEFORE
description: ROME, Sept. 4  A month after a Vatican decree reduced him to the state of a layman, the Rev. Giovanni Franzoni, one of Italy's bestknown priests of dissent, is living almost as if nothing had happened.

title: Greenwich Man Held in Murder Of His Wife and Maid in June
description: A 38yearold New York City clothing manufacturer was arrested in Florida yesterday and charged with the murders of his former wife and her maid last June in a palatial home in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: ART

title: Nassau's Battle of the Police Giants
description: MINEOLA SHOULD a lawyer who represents just about all of Nassau County's police officers also defend those whom the officers arrest, or is it a conflict of interest?

title: The Outlook for Baer
description: NEW JERSEY politicians have habitually underestimated Byron Baer of Bergen County. He is a bit pudgy, wears a smal mustache and peers out from behind hornrimmed glasses, and he has, he would be the first to concede, about as much charisma as a compilation of election statistics. To engage in conversation with him is to risk a marathon recapitulation of everything anyone could ever want to know about him or his legislative record.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market, helped by some encouraging economic developments, registered a strong performance last week in more active trading. The Dow Jones climbed 25.18 points to close at 989.11. In the previous week the Dow had lost 10.14 points. Last week's was the biggest weekly gain in the key barometer since the week ended Feb. 20 when it rose 29.44 points.

title: DICTATORS OFFER BILL OF PUNKROCK
description: The Dictators, who opened a threenight stand at CBGB's Friday, are in the inadvertently ironic position of having predated the currently fashionable New York underground punkrock scene and then being forced to try to cash in on it.

title: New York City Faces 50 Legal Actions Arising From Fiscal Crisis
description: New York City's fiscal crisis has prompted at least 50 legal actions challenging many aspects of the billions of dollars in transactions that have kept the city afloat for the last year and a half.

title: The Cost to Taxpayers Annually Has Been Put at $3 Billion
description: The abuses began in the mid1960's almost as soon as Congress, after years of wrangling, adopted the controversial law to provide aged Americans with governmentbacked health insurance. The break came when supposedly shrewd lawmakers decided to buy off the powerful medical services lobby with a boon they called Medicaid, Federalstate financing of health care for the needy. With this program, medical practitioners could rid themselves of the burden of charity cases. They seized the opportunity.

title: Miss McCarthy to Wed
description: A December wedding is planned by Diane McCarthy, a registered nurse, and John Tobey Devlin, a student at the Cornell University Medical College. Mr. and Mrs. William McCarthy 2d of Westbury, L.I., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Devlin of Ramsey, N.J.

title: Season's Over At the Shore
description: IN a few days, you'll be able to shoot a cannon down the boulevard and not hurt anybody, said Irvin Lees, the Seaside Heights Tax Collector, as the borough prepared for its last big weekend of the 1976 summer season.

title: Corsica Still Struggling for Autonomy
description: AJACCIO, CorsicaA year has failed to erase the inscriptions on the wallsFrench go home and Corsica for the Corsicansor dull the desire of this island region of France for a new economic and political relationship with the central Government in Paris.

title: Mozambique Reports Aid By U.N. to Raid Survivors
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sept. 4 (Reuters)The United Nations has given Mozambique $75,000 to help survivors of a Rhodesian Army raid last month, according to the official Mozambique press agency.

title: Victim of Forgery at Air Force Academy Is Relieved That His Ordeal Has Ended
description: DENVER, Sept. 3For Barnet R. Hellman, a cadet at the Air Force Academy, an eightmonth ordeal in which he was accused of forgery is drawing to a close.

title: LETTERS
description: Those Rabbits

title: U.S. Study Backs Critics Of New York's Drug Law
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4New York State's drug laws have been called the toughest in the nation, but in each of the two full years since they took effect, there have been fewer dispositions, convictions and prison sentences for drug offenses than there were in 1973 under the old laws, according to a Governmentsponsored report released today.

title: CLARK DEPLORES HEALTHCARE COST
description: Ramsey Clark, the former United States Attorney General, accused the health insurance industry yesterday of being partly responsible for the doubling of health care costs and he called for comprehensive national health insurance.

title: Kansas Dallies to Beat Oregon State by 2816
description: CORVALLIS, Ore., Sept. 4 (AP)Nolan Cromwell, quarterback, and Laverne Smith, a running back, combined for 200 yards rushing tonight as Kansas rallied from behind and scored three secondhalf touchdowns to beat surprising Oregon State, 2816.

title: Finding My Father
description: This is a book about knowingand not knowingone's origins and what it does to a man when the truth is kept a secret. Rod McKuen does not remember when or what his mother first told him about his absent father: whether he had just gone away, divorced her or died. He never got much more than his father's name, Mac McKuen (and was never sure how it was spelled), before his mother died four years ago.

title: Renee Richards Controversy: What Is a Woman?
description: Shame on women's tennis. We women are the first to howl when we perceive discrimination on the basis of sex and here we are in the role of active participants.

title: Industry in Portugal
description: LISBON, PortugalThe electronic and electric Industries, severely affected by depression after the revolution are second in importance after textiles and account for 7 percent of Portugal's industrial exports. The group cornprises 87 companies, of whose capital 37 percent is repre sented by foreign investment. It employs 33,000 workers.

title: Merrily They Rolls Along
description: About 13 years ago Joseph Star, a semiretired engineer living on Long Island, bought a dilapidated 1931 Rolls Royce Phantom II Sedanca De Vine. The roof above the passenger seats in the back was tattered, the doors were broken and the engine ran with a cacophony of snorts and rattles.

title: From MehtaWith Chutzpah and Love
description: LOS ANGELES Zubin Mehta is comfortably distributed in an oversized wicker chair on the patio of the lush and rambling Mediterranean villa he bought from Steve McQueen. Perched gorgeously on a private mountain looming above exclusive Brentwood, the property is alive with multicolored flowers and a variety of vegetation. It is a breathtaking sight. Mehta himself looks very much a part of the scene. At 40, the charismatic maestro has lost little of his matinee idol glamour. He is looking forward to a fourweek bicentennial jaunt with his beloved Israel Philharmonic, of which he is musical adviser (he leads the orchestra in performances Wednesday and Thursday at Carnegie Hall). Mehta is the ensemble's best press agent. You will hear how our fiddles and strings play, he exclaims, a lot of Russians are in them now. This is an orchestra which plays with love. Oy, do they lover!

title: Reserve Passer Stars
description: WEST LIBERTY, W. Va., Sept. 4 (AP)  Chuck Hoose, a sophomore quarterback, came off the bench in the third quarter to score one touchdown and pass for another as West Liberty State defeated Shippenshurg (Pa.) State, 2613, today.

title: Dr. Alexander Joseph, 69, Dies; Forensic Scientist at John Jay
description: Dr. Alexander Joseph, a retired physicist, forensic scientist, educator and author, died Friday in Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco, N. Y., after a long illness. Dr. Joseph, who had homes in Palm Beach, Fla., and Mahopac, N. Y., was 69 years old.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Sunday, September 3, 1976

title: Rhode Island Tries Windmill Power
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., Sept. 4 (AP)With a flip of a switch, the New England Telephone Company has turned on an experimental windmill here that may provide the company's island operations with most of their power.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high tide at Asbury Park and Belmar, deduct 34 min. from Sandy Hook time.

title: CHESS
description: MONTILLA, SpainThere is something about a loose pawn that is hard to resist, especially if it can be captured with check, and yet there are situations where the bait ought to be ignored.

title: Life Is All Ups And No Downs On This Carousel
description: Erik Erikson, teacher, psychoanalyst and Pulitzer Prizewinning author (Gandhi's Truth: On the Origins of Militant NonViolence, 1970), is also a widely read, widely quoted, immensely popular writer on psychiatry. His textbook Childhood and Society, first published in 1950, has gone into its 13th printing and his phrase identity crisis is permanently lodged in what psychiatrists call the collective group conscious. He is also celebrated for his division of the life cycle into the eight stages of man (as opposed to Shakespeare's seven) and the positive and negative forces intrinsic to each. According to Erikson, each stage presents crucial conflicts, which need to he resolved in order to go on to the next; if they are not resolved, an emotional crisis develops. His theoriespar ticularly those relating to preadolescence  have become the Bible of many schoolteachers.

title: Coupons: For Some, a Collector's Item
description: THE world is divided into two groups: those who throw out everything and those who collect what the other half throws out. Everyone knows who the collectors are. They tell you. They show you their collections of rolling pins, dolls, frogs, pictures and even barbed wire, always with great pride.

title: National League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to Michigan's eastern Upper Peninsula, the Mackinaw City area has about 70 motels and the St. Ignace area about 40. A double room that in peak season starts at $20 begins at about $15 after Labor Day.

title: Legion Disease Tests Increase Mystery
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 4The investigation of the mysterious disease that has killed 29 persons in Pennsylvania was thrown into further confusion today by results of a new series of tests that experts had hoped would conclusively rule in or rule out nickel poisoning as the cause of the epidemic.

title: Eastern College Football: Penn State or Pitt Likely to End on Top
description: Pittsburgh's impressive triumph over Kansas in the Sun Bowl last winter may have been just a warmup for the 1976 season. Most of that victorious squad has returned. Penn State lost important members of the team that won the Lambert Trophy last year and then was beaten by Alabama in the Sugar Bowl.

title: Design
description: Is it a pillow? Or is it art? It's constructed like a pillow, signed by an artist and produced in limited editions. The artistsmostly young women who have backgrounds in either fine or applied artcall their pillows soft sculpture. They are following in the steps of Claes Oldenburg, who was the first to make soft versions of everyday objects, such as fans and telephones, at the height of the Pop Art movement, in the early 1960's.

title: George Gilder, Author, Fiance Of Nini Brooke
description: Cornelia Ewing Brooke and George Franklin Gilder plan to be married Oct. 23. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John L. B. Brooke of Lenox, Mass., parents of the future bride, who is known as Nini. Her fianc is the son of Mrs. Gilder Palmer of Tyringham, Mass., and the late Richard Watson Gilder, an Army Air Forces lieutenant who was killed during World War II.

title: Miss McNamara Bride of a Broker
description: Christine Ann McNamara, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald C. McNamara of Saddle River, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Daniel Michael Finnegan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Finnegan of River Edge, N.J.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: NEWPORT, R.I. Festivals are curious things, with a special chemistry to them. One needs the right place and the right programming. There needs to be a certain festive atmosphereparties, metaphorical fireworks and solid amusements. The American Dance Festival, which has been going on at Connecticut College in New London, Conn., since 1948, has somehow never been a festive festival. New London, perhaps, is not a particularly festive place. It has a workmanlike air to it.

title: Mystery Surrounds the Selection of New Soviet Sextet
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 4Coach Boris Mayorov is on Coach Viktor Tikhonov's right. Coach Robert Cherenkov is on the left. To the side is Coach Albert Pomortsev. In the stands are Coach Boris Kulagin and Coach Arkady Chernyshov. And out on the ice is a new team of Soviet youngsters who don't seem to have any idea of what is going on.

title: Italian Youth Is Rescued
description: TURIN, Italy, Sept. 4 (AP)The police raided an apartment here today and rescued unharmed a 5yearold boy who was reported kidnapped Thursday. A couple found in the apartment were arrested. The police said they found Enrico Campidonico, son of a Turin oil dealer, hidden under a bed in the apartment. He had disappeared Thursday night with a young woman hired recently to take care of him.

title: Cowboys Get 17 Points in 4th, Toga Oilers in Overtime, 2620
description: DALLAS. Sept. 4 (AP)Scott Laidlaw scored two touchdowns in the fourth quarter and raced 10 yards with 6 minutes 43 seconds elapsed in suddendeath overtime tonight to give the Dallas Cowboys a 2620 victory over the Houston Oilers and bragging rights to the Texas Pro Football Championship.

title: The Faces Are Familiar
description: If some faces on ABCTV screens this fall look familiar to New Jerseyans, there are reasons. For example, Welcome Back, Kotter is loaded with New Jersey types. Juan Epstein, a Jewish Puerto Rican, is played by Robert Hegyes, an actor with an ItalianHungarian background, who is a graduate of Metuchen High School and Glassboro State College. John Travolta, Vinnie in Kotter, was born in Englewood, the son of Salvatore and Helen Travolta, the latter an actress who coached him while he was in Dwight Morrow High School. Also from the state: Sada Thompson, the mother in ABC's Family, who was reared in Femwood; Robert Blake, a native of Nutley, who stars as the detective .Baretta; Richard Anderson, boss of The $6million Man, who hails from Long Branch, and Susan Blanchard, costar of the new comedy Mr. T and Tina, who was born in Trenton and attended Centenary College in Hackettstown.

title: Going to School Abroad A Test of Togetherness
description: Rome WHEN 17yearold Mary McBride of Erial, in Camden County, goes back to school this weekshe'll be a senior in the regional high schoolshe will find things a bit different than they were during the 197576 semesters.

title: Dance Festival Opens With a Strong Program
description: Beset by the elements some years and erratic financing most others, the New York Dance Festival has triumphed to become the official opening of New York City fallwinter dance season. It has endured and when the leaves begin to fly, crowds flock to the Delacorte Theater in Central Park to see the new and the old, the untried and the true.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: THEATER

title: Bird
description: By Liesel Moak Skorpen. Illustrated by Joan Sandin. 39 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $5.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Fewer Suicides in Britain
description: LONDON, Sept. 4 (Reuters)Britain had the lowest suicide rate last year since records were first kept more than 100 years ago, it was reported here today. Dr. Richard Fox, honorary psychiatrist to the Samaritans, who help people in despair, said the rate of 7.5 suicides per 100,000 was especially surprising since it came in a recession year of high economic stress.

title: What's Doing in PITTSBURGH
description: THE IMAGEIt has been many years since a new Pittsburgh rose like a phoenix from the ashes of overindustrialization, yet some firsttime visitors to the city still express amazement at finding not a gritty, sooty, pollutionchoked metropolis but one that's clean, attractive and alive. Pittsburgh's urban renaissance is best exemplified by the Golden Triangle, once an industrial wasteland but now a panoply of modern office buildings, handsome plazas and Point State Park, the last crowned with a fountain that sits at the spot where the Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers meet to form the Ohio. Across the Allegheny, just a few hundred feet from the fountain, is a giant canister called Three Rivers Stadium, home of baseball's Pittsburgh Pirates and football's worldchampion Pittsburgh Steelers. Although the Pittsburgh metropolitan area ranks only ninth in the nation as a population center (2.5 million), it is the country's third largest corporateheadquarters city, with 23 of the world's largest corporations.

title: He rings Gold To Broadway
description: Although he has none of the credentials of a celebrity quiz candidate, Morton J. Mitosky has been in on 123 Broadway shows over the past 25 years and is actively entertaining offers to join 11 new Productions this season.

title: HELP ON POLLUTION CITED BY BUCKLEY
description: Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican, asserted yesterday that an amendment he had attached to the Federal Water Pollution Control Act would help Suffolk County, New York City, Buffalo and other communities in the fiat against pollution by providing a Federal guarantee for the financing of sewagetreatment facilities.

title: Schlesinger May Visit Tibet
description: TOKYO, Sunday, Sept. 5 (UPI)  China has given James R. Schlesinger, former United States Secretary of Defense permission to visit Tibet and its capital, Lhasa, the Asahi newspaper of Tokyo said in a dispatch from Peking today.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: It is a dark and tragic world, only occasionally lit by a ray of hope, that W. Eugene Smith captures in his photographs. Or is it a world that Smith himself creates? Although Smith is a photojournalist, most of whose best known photographs first appeared in Life, he has such a powerful personal style that it is often hard to tell in his photographs where the real world leaves off and Smith's tortured vision of it begins.

title: Nicklaus Gains 2Shot Edge On 69 for 207 in Akron Golf
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 4 Everything is normal again in the Buckeye State.

title: ATOM PLANT FOES PRESS L.I. BATTLE
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 4The explosion earlier this week in a nuclear plant in Washington State has given local opponents new ammunition in their, fight against a proposal for a, nuclear power plant in this rural community.

title: KISSINGER MEETS VORSTER TO BEGIN 3 DAYS OF TALKS
description: ZURICH, Sunday, Sept. 5Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa met for five hours last night and both said shortly after midnight this morning that progress is being made in the discussion of crucial southern Africa issues.

title: A Plea for a Vote Of Confidence
description: YOU be the judge. We wanted to see a change in the county government. A good change. Thought it would make things better. Other counties had done it. Seemed to be working out. Let's try it.

title: Jean Collins Bride of Dr. Peter E. Liggett
description: Jean Elizabeth Collins, director of program development for Core Communications in Health Inc. in New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Peter Eric Liggett, a resident in ophthalmology at the Cornell University Medical Center in Manhattan.

title: The Mess At West Point
description: The Department of the Army may be having some second thoughts, as well it might, about expelling what could be more than 100 members of last year's junior class at West Point. In fact, the socalled cheating scandal in which these young men were involved appears to call for change by the Military Academy rather than the expulsion of cadets.

title: $50,000 Super Jaguar to Be .Christened at Lime Rock
description: The $50.000 flagship of the Group 44 race car fleetand of British Leyland Motors Inc., for that matterwill be christened tomorrow in a Sports Car Club of America national championship race at No Rock Park. No one is scheduled to break a bottle of champagne over the bow of the sleek B Production beauty simply because one does not go around conking $50,000 race cars with bottles, no matter what they contain. But its driver, the unpredictable Bob Tullius, has a flair for the dramatic, and it's hard to tell what publicrelations gimmick he might concoct.

title: Minnesota Sheriff Slain
description: WASECA, Minn., Sept 4 (AP) The sheriff of Waseca County was slain at a farm today, apparently while trying to serve a legal paper. One blast from a doublebarreled .12gauge shotgun killed Donald J. Eustice, 47 years old, sheriff of the southeastern Minnesota county for the last 12 years. Deputy Sheriff Merton V. Schwarz, took Kenneth J. Jewison, a 64yearold farmer, into custody.

title: Economic Indicators
description: Statistics for commercial agricultural loans, carloadings, steel, oil electric power and business failures are for the preceding week and latest available

title: For Anglers, Super Fall Looms
description: THERE'S been a change in the weather, and it seems as if there'll be a change in the fishing, too. The season, which started out with a bang in the spring and then settled down to one of the worst summers in years, now seems beaded for a super fall.

title: September
description: September is almost a season in itself, and this year it seems to have come early. When the last few days of August bring frost to the rural valleys, autumn can't be far behind, no matter, what the almanac and its equinox may say. And this week brings the Harvest Moon, which is almost as autumnal, as the crimson of roadside sumac.

title: Sylvia Jelliffe Married to Paul J. Lawler
description: Sylvia Jelliffe of New York and Paul John Lawler of rvington, N. Y., were married yesterday afternoon in Huletts Landing on Lake George, N. Y. Msgr. John Nolan performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the Roman Catholic Chapel of the Assumption.

title: Fort Lee's Historic Park
description: HIGH up on the Palisades, a spectacular 300 feet above the Hudson River in Fort Lee, sits a new tourist attraction steeped in Bicentennial history. It is Fort LeE Historic Park, which was built on the same blurt where, in July of 1776, America's ragtag Continental Army hastily erected four cannonbatteries and a rifle parapet. to fight the British.

title: Swami
description: By Doug Boyd. 330 pp. New York: Random House. $10.

title: Giants Bow, 1413; Jets 416 Victims
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 4A wide extrapoint try by George Hunt made the difference tonight as the New York Giants lost to the San Diego Chargers, 1413, before 20,000 in SanDiego Stadium.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: We have just purchased a house that has ceramic tile laid in the kitchen and playroom. The tile was put down on top of linoleum and it is now coming up, and the grout is cracking out between the tiles. Can this be repaired?K. K.. Hartsdale. N. Y.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Highlights & Index to Listings

title: Columbia Offense Bolstered by Line
description: LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 4 Columbia's offensive line in football, which helped the Lions to lead the Ivy League in rushing last season, looks even stronger this year.

title: Top Banana At the Market
description: SUPERMARKET are where they are so they can sell food to us. Some do it better than others, with vegetables that are fresher, floors that are cleaner, meat packages that are truly transparent, checkers who smile and don't charge twice for paper napkins.

title: ES. FORBIDS SALE OF MEDICAID BILLS
description: In an effort to check what it says are widespread abuses in Medicaid billings, the Federal Government has issued an order barring physicians as well as shared health facilities commonly known as Medicaid millsfrom selling their accounts receivable to collection agents.

title: Bayberry Dunes, 19631976. R.I.P.
description: BAYBERRY DUNES, the remote Fire Island community that should not have been, will soon cease to be. The easternmost residential enclave of 29 houses, was built in the spring and summer of 1963 and 1964 a mile beyond Ocean Ridge, and therefore threequarters of a mile within the predicted boundary of the Fire Island National Seashore. It was condemned by Congress with the passage of the seashore bill just after Labor Day 1964, and now its last season is ending.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Nightmares That Haunt the Mind
description: The New York Dance Festival at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park is an annual rite of summer in the city. It is a colorful grabbag of ballet, modern, ethnic and jazz dance that lures a wide audience to its picnic setting.

title: Major League TeamAgainstTeam Records
Gwen Braudy Wed to Richard Lerman
description: Gwen Michelle Braudy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Steve Braudy of Yonkers, and Richard Nevins Lerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Lerman of Forest Hills, Queens, were married in Yonkers yesterday. Rabbi Solomon Sternstein performed the ceremony at the Lincoln Park Jewish Center.

title: Yachting Results
description: AT LARCHMONT Y. C.

title: Preserving the Island's Ground Water
description: FOR the last nine years, I have conducted and participated in many studies designed to provide information about the Island's groundwater reserves and the impacts upon them. I have seen and heard many people describe the groundwater system in a manner similar to Julian Kane and Deborah Stuart in their article, Sewers Aren't Always the Answer [Opinion Page, July 18]. But the rebuttals by government officials are usually viewed as defensive reactions, even when they are backed up by scientific studies.

title: A New Force in the Arena
description: THE righttolife movement, which produced a Presidential contender from its Long Island ranks earlier this year, is a major factor in at least three of the nine contests in the Sept. 14 primary on the Island.

title: New & Novel
description: The End of The Party

title: American Talk
description: Where Our Words Came From. By J. L. Dillard. 187 pp. New York: Random House. $7.95.

title: Operatic Events
description: NEW YORK CITY OPERA

title: S.M. Gill, Princeton Alumnus, Marries Patricia M. Jackson
description: Patricia Murnaghan Jackson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Jay Jackson of Baltimore was married yesterday afternoon to Stephen Matthew Gill of Taipei, Taiwan, in the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Baltimore. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew J. Gill of Hingham, Mass.

title: HITS FROM FLOPS SUNG AT MUSEUM
description: The idea behind Hit Tunes From Flop Shows, which was performed Friday and yesterday in the Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modern Art and will be repeated next Friday and Saturday, is scarcely worldshaking, but it is provocative and entertaining. The premise is that many of the most familiar songs from Broadway musicals succeeded even though the shows didn't. The promise is an evening of excellent songs and the surprise of finding how they managed to survive their sources.

title: OFFICIALS HOPEFUL ON BOSTON BUSING
description: BOSTON, Sept, 4 (UPI)The third year of courtordered school busing begins Wednesday and government and school Officials are hopeful that the pattern of tension and sporadic violence set in the past two years will be broken this year.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The Guardian Development Corporation has acquired the Clearbrook condominium community in Cranbury, N.J., for $10 million from the Rossmoor Corporation of Laguna, Calif.

title: Letters
description: James M. Markham's Lebanon: The insane war (Aug. 15) is informative and his theory that the basic conflict is between Syria and the Palestinians with Israel as the underlying issue is thoughtprovoking. However, one must disagree with his closing words:  . . . as Lebanon dies. Any people or nation which has maintained a stable, autonomous society through 3,000 years of invading and plundering empires from the ancient Egyptian to the modern British is not likely to be in danger of imminent disappearance.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Police officials in Howell Township, N. J., said they were interviewing friends and neighbors of Virginia Duerkes, the 20yearold Kean College student who was raped and fatally stabbed in her home Thursday. The police said employees of the Howard Johnson's restaurant on the Asbury Park boardwalk, where Miss Duerkes worked, would also be questioned. A goldcolored or light brown car seen in the area of the victim's home was also being sought. Police officials said they could not account for the car's presence near the victim's home.

title: Hewitt and Stolle Reach 35's Final
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 4 (AP)Bob Hewitt of South Africa beat Barry PhillipsMoore of Australia, 26, 62, 62, and advanced to the final of the North American 35yearsandover tennis tournament today.

title: 3 Women Share Golf Lead at 139
description: SPRINGFIELD. Ill., Sept. 4 (UPI)JoAnne Carrier gambled on driving a green and lost by two feet today, enabling Sandra Palmer and Michelle Walker to tie her at 139 after two rounds of the $100,000 Muscular Dystrophy women's pro golf tournament.

title: Helene Rousseau to Be Bride Of Stephen Epifano on Dec.11
description: Helene Bullard Rousseau, a greatgreatgranddaughter of William George Fargo, a founder of Wells, Fargo & Company and Mayor of Buffalo in 1862, plans to marry Stephen Barry Epifano next Dec. 11 in Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn.

title: Radio
description: 7:30  10:30 A.M., WKCR  FM. Theodora, Handel.

title: Team USA Loses, 42, To Canada
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 5Canada's most famous hockey players put on a wooden performance tonight in beating Team USA, 42, in the Canada Cup hockey tournament.

title: Fashions and Facade: A Look Built for the Era
Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Sept. 5A legislative commission will begin hearings this week to attempt to find out why New Jersey hash the highest death rate in the country from cancer, about 15 percent higher than the national average.

title: Biologists Are Eager For Viking 2's Tests
description: PASADENA, Sept. 5 As preparations are being made for the Viking 2 lander on Mars to reach out next Saturday for its first soil sample from Utopia Plain, biologists here are debating how to determine whether, in Viking 1 experiments, they have discovered life or some new form of chemistry, and whether they will have to revise their definition of life itself.

title: Airliner Competition Stirs British Show
