description: FARNBOROUGH, England Sept. 5The biggest air show of the year opened here today with an impressive exhibition of flying skills but a greater interest by the industry audience in the accelerating contest over new airliners for the 1980's.

title: Giants Make Their Plane in Clutch After Missing Their Kick in Clutch
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 5Because George Hunt's 27yard fieldgoal attempt hit the left goal post with two minutes to play, Norm Snead was deprived of a hero's role here last night, the New York Giants lost a 1413 decision to the San Diego Chargers and Coach Bill Arnsparger got off his brightest dressingroom quip of the year.

title: Books of The Times
description: Why read Geoffrey Wolff's Black Sun: The Brief Transit and Violent Eclipse of Harry Crosby, when its heroand heroine seem scarcely worth a footnote in the annals of 20thcentury American literature? Or to put it more precisely: What draws us through this chronicle of two very minor, writers, Harry and Caresse Crosby, whose most enduring accomplishment was probably to have founded and sustained for a time in Paris the expatriate Black Sun Press, which published among other works Hart Crane's The Bridge and a portion of James Joyce's Work in Progress? Well, to begin with, there is the mystery of Harry Crosby's sensational suicide, which Mr. Wolff, anovelist and literary critic, effectively employs to launch his narrative.

title: Tasteful Tourist Billboards Now Legal
description: ALBANY, Sept. 5A 15month dispute between New York State and the United, States ended last week in a victory for the state and the approval of small, tasteful billboards directing tourists to hotels, motels and restaurants.

title: Personal Finance
description: Back in 1974, when shortterm interest rates all but went through the roof, moneymarket mutual funds couldn't print new shares fast enough to keep up with public demand.

title: Talks Will Try to Avert Shirt Workers' Strike
description: James F. Scearce, the national director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, will meet tomorrow in Washington with union and management negotiators in an effort to avert a nationwide strike Thursday by about 30,000 workers in shirt factories.

title: Aging Soviet Rulers
description: According to recent rumors, Soviet Premier Aleksei Kosygin allegedly nearly lost his life last month when he suffered a stroke while swimming. True or not, the story was given wide currency throughout the world, and the reason for such ready acceptance of an unverified report is to be sought in the fact that the Soviet Union is ruled by a regime of old men.

title: Lester Rand, Pollster, Marries Gloria Levitt
description: Gloria Levitt and Lester Rand were married yesterday in Temple EmanuEl by Rabbi David Posner. The bride is a sales executive and showroom manager of Partout International, sportswear importers. Her husband is president of the Rand Youth Poll, which surveys buying preferences of teenagers, college students and other young people. He also writes a syndicated column on teenage activities.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in The New York Times on Aug. 7 mentioned a suit that blocked city regulation of Medicaid facilities and said it had been filed by the Association of Health Providers. The suit was, in fact, brought by the Association of Health Care Facilities.

title: Sander Is Victor In Amateur Golf
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 5 (AP)Bill Sander, the 20yearold Pacific Northwest titleholder from Kenmore, Wash., captured the 76th United States Amateur golf championship today, overwhelming Parker Moore of Laurens, S.C., 8 and 6, in their final, scheduled for 36 holes.

title: For Shoppers, Not a Day of Rest
description: For midtown strollers enjoying (or enduring) their Labor Day weekend in New York City, it was as though four blocks of Broadway forgot that yesterday was Sunday while the rest of the area remembered.

title: Carter Hopes for a Tie in TV Debate And Gears for TightBudget Campaign
description: PLAINS, Ga., Sept. 5 Tomorrow, Jimmy Carter begins a Presidential campaign that in some ways will be unusual and innovative, and in some ways will be as oldfashioned as a buggy.

title: Israeli Jets Met Plane
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 5The hijacked Dutch airliner with 85 hostages and crew members on board came within 40 to 100 miles of BenGurion International Airport here today before returning to Larnaca airport in Cyprus.

title: Stearns Morse, 83, Former Professor At Dartmouth, Dies
description: Stearns Morse a retired professor of English and a former dean of freshmen at Dartmouth College, died Saturday night at Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital in Hanover, N.H., after a brief illness, the college announced. He was 83.

title: Baltimore Suburb Now Leans to Carter
description: PARKVILLE, Md., Sept. 3On his way to an embarrassing defeat in the Maryland primary last May, Jimmy Carter burst upon the consciousness of a number of Democratic voters in this Baltimore suburb with something of a thud. When he aroused strong feeling, it was usually mistrust.

title: Article 1  No Title
Ryan's 3  Hitter Dims A's Chance
description: The Oakland A's bid to capture their sixth straight American League Western Division crown faltered badly over the weekend as they lost twice to the California Angels. Yesterday they succumbed, 32, to Nolan Ryan's threehitter and wasted an opportunity to gain on the Kansas City Royals, who were defeated by the Texas Rangers. The A's remain seven games behind with 27 remaining.

title: Pie in the Face Jolts Moynihan on Campaign Trail
description: A banana cream pie was smashed in the face of Daniel P. Moynihan as he campaigned yesterday on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

title: PROGRESS CITED IN KISSINGER TALK ON AFRICAN ISSUES
description: ZURICH, Sept. 5Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa reported further progress today in resolving key southern African issues and ordered subordinates to meet and work on specific aspects of the problems.

title: Yanks Fall As Hunter Drops 14th
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 5Since the Orioles 53 victory over the Yankees today hardly made a dent in the distance that separates the teams, interest in the game centered on several moves made by Billy Martin, the Yankee manager, most legal but one illegal.

title: Hirschfeld Goes on Attack As Mrs. Abzug Retreats
description: Abraham Hirschfeld attacked yesterday, accusing Daniel P. Moynihan of failing to vote for 15 years in the state he wants to represent in the United States Senate, but Representative Bella. S. Abzug retreated, backing off from her threat that she would not support Mr. Moynihan if he won the Democratic primary Sept. 14 in New York State.

title: Pie in the Face Jolts Moynihan on Campaign Trail
description: A banana cream pie was smashed in the face of Daniel P. Moynihan as he campaigned yesterday on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

title: Unser Wins on Coast
description: ONTARIO, Calif., Sept. 5 (AP)In a brilliant display of driving, Bobby Unser squeezed everything he could from an underpowered car and beat Johnny Rutherford and Gordon Johncock today in the $323,000 California 500, for Indianapolistype cars.

title: Kelley Lets ExAgents Seek Funds in Bureau's Offices
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 5In an extraordinary move, Clanence M. Kelley director of the Federal Bureau of lnvestigation, has permitted a private organization to solicit in the bureau's 59 field offices funds for the defense of agents accused of burglaries and other illegal acts in connection with investigations of radical groups.

title: KIDNAPPED WOMAN RESCUED IN HARLEM
description: A 21yearold woman who was kidnapped at gunpoint from a Harlem street on Tuesday was rescued last night from an apartment on West 142d street, where she had been chained to a bed, raped repeatedly and shot at, the police reported.

title: Man Helping a Fsriend Is Slain By Thief Near Columbia Library
description: A 22yearold man who had reluctantly come to New York City to help a friend move out of a fraternity house was stabbed to death at an entrance to Columbia University's Butler Library Saturday night. Dozens of other students were moving their belongings into and out of dormitories on the block when the murder took place.

title: LABOR CHIEFTAINS COUNT ON CARTER
description: New York labor leaders are generally gloomy, on this Labor Day, about the outlook for the next year, but they are pinning their hopes for an economic turnaround on the possible election of a Democratic Administration.

title: Tourney's Doctor Scores Injury Rule
description: The ripples from last Friday's match between Ilie Nastase and HansJurgen Pohmann continued to wash over the United States Open tennis championships at Forest Hills yesterday.

title: Anker Asks Investigation Of All NoBid Purchases
description: An immediate inquiry into all purchases made without receipt of competitive bids by the Board of Education's Bureau of School Lunches and Bureau of Supplies has been ordered by Irving Anker, the New York City School Chancellor.

title: Optimism at a New High For Integration in Schools
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 5The second year of courtordered desegregation in Louisville began last week without the protests that marred last year's school opening.

title: Miss Palmer Wins
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 5 (UPI)  Sandra Palmer birdied the third extra hole today to win a fourway playoff and firstprize money of $15,000 in the $100,000 Jerry Lewis Muscular Dystrophy tournament, at the Rail Golf Club here.

title: Promoted in A.C.L.U.
description: In Red Square in Moscow, John Howard Francis Shattuck, as a 20yearold bass in the Yale Russian Chorus singing Russian folk and liturgical music, got into an impromptu debate. In that fall of 1963, just after the Cuban missile crisis, one Soviet citizen couldn't believe that Americans didn't need identity cards to travel around the United States. I pulled out my draft card, and I tore it in half to demonstrate it was totally unnecessary even to carry it, Mr. Shuttuck recalled yesterday.

title: Hang Glider Dies of Injuries
description: WINCHESTER, Ky., Sept. 5 (UPI)  Allan Kling, a 27yearold architect from Cincinnati, died of injuries sustained yesterday while participating in a tournament for hang gliders in the Red River Gorge. Mr. Kling was pronounced dead shortly after rescuers found him semiconscious in a valley of the scenic gorge.

title: Toxic ControlsNow
description: In Virginia, legal proceedings have been going on for some time against officials of the company that dumped millions of gallons of poisonous insectandroach powder into the James River and Chesapeake Bay.

title: Rescue Jaws Are Lifesavers, Not Killers
description: THE SPRINGS, L. I.Dale Greene doesn't remember the crash, the way his car wrapped around the tree trunk, the way he pleaded get me out, get me out, in shock, as smoke curled from the wreckage and rescue workers tried to pry him free.

title: Two Women Bring New Hope to Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept 5Mairead Corrigan puts her faith in God, and Betty Williams trusts in the common sense of ordinary people. They are believers, and this is what keeps them going. What they can't believe is their own success.

title: North Sea Hunt Is On for John Paul Jones Ship
description: ABOARD THE DECCA RECORDER, Sept. 2This 280ton survey ship is standing off Bridlington Bay, Yorkshire, in the area where John Paul Jones and the Bon Homme Richard defeated the British frigate Serapis in 1779.

title: Eskimos Seek to Alter Written Language
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 5Canadian Eskimo leaders will ask the Government here this week to accept a simplified writing system to improve communications and education among the 20,000 native peoples of the Far North.

title: Site of Cornwallis's Landing Pits 2 Communities in Debate
description: CLOSTER, Sept. 5In November 1776, Lord Cornwallis led several thousand British and Hessian troops across the Hudson River to attack General Washington's beleaguered forces at Fort Lee and to put an end to the colonists' dream of independence.

title: Tonight's Entries at Meadowlands
description: Horses listed in order of post p??ons FIRST$7,??00, pace, mile.

title: Harness Drivers Fight Stakes Rules After the Collapse of a Winning Colt
description: DU QUOIN: Ill., Sept. 5Aroused by the collapse of the trotter Steve Lobell a few hours after his victory in the Hambletonian, some of the country's leading harness drivers joined in a fight today to change the rules of racing to save the horses.

title: Mary Barber Wed To William Tanis
description: Mary Winifred Barber, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Hugh Barber of Kew Gardens, Queens, was married yesterday to William Edward Tanis, a lawyer with Ireland, Stapleton, Pryor & Holmes in Denver.

title: LABOR CHIEFTAINS COUNT ON CARTER
description: New York labor leaders are generally gloomy, on this Labor Day, about the outlook for the next year, but they are pinning their hopes for an economic turnaround on the possible election of a Democratic Administration.

title: Pravda Says Ford Speech Violated U.S.Soviet Pacts
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 5 (Reuters)The Soviet Communist Party newspaper Pravda today said that President Ford had contradicted agreements to improve United StatesSoviet relations by saying that American military might was a guarantee of peace.

title: OFFICIALS WATCH PET BUSINESSES
description: State officials are continuing to press a drive against unscrupulous sales of pets, despite a court tieup of new regulations designed to prevent the sale of diseased, defective or unregistered animals.

title: Labor Party Candidate Sees Fiscal Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5The way Lyndon H. LaRouche sees it, the race for the White House is about to narrow down to a field of two contenders: President Ford and himself.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CURTAINS In the heart of midtown you can step into the bygone world of early New York theater at a free exhibition of vintage prints and photographs of performers, performances and showcases set up in the lobby of One Times Square. Although the display doesn't open officially until Sept. 14 and will run for two months, you can see it now.

title: Hoyt Yacht Wins Vineyard Race
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 5The results of the Vineyard race, the Stamford Yacht Club's familiar 238mile distance event which ended here today, suggested to those who did not win that they visit the fall boat shows this month and buy a new one. New fast yachts with speed afoot, advantageous handicap ratings and crew skills in cockpit and foredeck, which cannot be bought, won most of the prizes. The overall winner was Russell Hoyt's Destination from the home club.

title: Nicklaus Triumphs By 4 Shots in Akron
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept, 5It looked close for a few minutes today after Jack Nicklaus lost three strokes in two holes and gave away his lead, but then Nicklaus reasserted his dominance and bounced back and won the World Series of Golf.

title: American Killed in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept.5 (AP)David Kent Sausaman, 38 years old, an employee of the International Minerals & Chemical Corporation of New York, died here yesterday from head injuries received in a traffic accident, according to officials of the Bando Trading Company, which has business ties with the American concern.

title: Results in U.S. Open Tennis
description: THIRD ROUND

title: The Arabs in London: A Summer Chill Sets In
description: LONDON, Sept. 5  Irmgard Chapman runs the Dress Den on Gloucester Road, a shopping thoroughfare in the South Kensington section of London. She has had her fill of the Arabs who are vacationing in London.

title: Study Rebuts AntiboycottLaw Qualms
description: Fears that New York will suffer a serious loss of revenues and employment from the new state antiboycott law are groundless, the American Jewish Congress asserted yesterday, citing a study of exports and imports handled by 12 Eastern and Southern posts.

title: PROGRESS CITED IN KISSINGER TALK ON AFRICAN ISSUES
description: ZURICH, Sept. 5Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa reported further progress today in resolving key southern African issues and ordered subordinates to meet and work on specific aspects of the problems.

title: Jets Can't Laugh Off Losses
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.L. Sept. 5 Some of the young Jets who showed up at camp today to soothe their injured muscles have suffered more losses in six weeks than they experienced in four years of college.

title: Don Carter Quartet Is Paced by Hoff On Alto Saxophone
description: Although the jazz group at Willy's, 7 West Eighth Street, this weekend was billed as the Don Carter Quartet, the musical character of the group was set primarily by Lou Hoff, an alto saxophonist. Mr. Hoff and the quartet's pianist, Vinnie Ruggierl, chose the tunes, set the tempos and were the principal soloists while Mr. Carter, a steady drummer, provided rhythmic support with John Wilmeth, a bassist.

title: Michigan Town Fighting Phone Rates
description: HICKORY CORNERS, Mich., Sept. 5 This is a recording in Hickory Corners, Mich., said the disembodied voice on the telephone. The number you have dialed has been changed or disconnected.

title: Paul Whiteman Sounds Set for Carnegie Hall
description: Paul Whiteman Rediscovered is the title of a concert celebrating the late King of Jazz of the 1920's and 30's, to take place Oct. 29 at Carnegie Hall. An orchestra of 29 musicians will present the original Whiteman arrangements, with Emery Davis as conductor. The Paul Whiteman Collection at Williams College is lending the arrangements to Mr. Davis and will receive a share of the proceeds of the concert.

title: Sinai Pact, a Year Later, Still Prevents Arab Unity
description: CAIRO, Sept. 5The first anniversary of the signing of the interim agreement by Egypt and Israel to disengage forces in Sinai has passed without mention in the Egyptian press.

title: Major League Baseball Box Scores and Standings
description: ELemon. DPMinnesota 1. LOBChicago 13, Minnesota 10. 2BBostock, Cubeage, Brohamer, Randall, Smalley. 3BL Johnson, Cubbage. HRSmalley (3), Ford (14). SORandall, Carew. SSmalley. SFBoslock.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in The New York Times on Aug. 7 mentioned a suit that blocked city regulation of Medicaid facilities and said it had been filed by the Association of Health Providers. The suit was, in fact, brought by the Association of Health Care Facilities.

title: AWOONER TESTIFIES AT TRIAL IN GHANA
description: ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 5 (AP)  Kofi Awooner, the Ghanaian, poetnovelist and former lecturer at the State University of New York in Stoney Brook, L.I., has told a military court that he sheltered a political fugitive at his home for purely hurnanitarian reasons.

title: Brezhnev Back in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Sept 5 (Reuters)Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist Party leader, returned to Moscow today from a threeday visit to Alma Ata, the capital of Kazakhstan.

title: CHARLES McG. BAXTER Jr.
description: Charles McGhee Baxter Jr., a retired securities broker formerly with Baxter & Company here, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 57 years old.

title: Deaths
description: ALBERTEsther, beloved wife of the late Isidor, devoted mother of Betty Sklaroff, Jerome M., and Ruth Levine, precious grandmother of Frances Susan. Lawrence Jon, and Susan Joan. loving motherInlaw and dear sister. Services 10 A.M., Monday, Garlick's, Coney Island Ave. at Ave. N, Brooklyn. Shiva will be observed at 1744 E. 19 S., Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: ARAB HIJACKERS FREE 80 HOSTAGES
description: LARNACA, Cyprus, Sept. 5Three Palestinians who hijacked a Dutch airliner yesterday with 80 people aboard and demanded that Israel release eight prisoners freed their hostages today in return for a promise of safe conduct from Greek Cypriot authorities, airport officials said.

title: Actress Out of Hospital
description: DANBURY Conn., Sept. 5 (UPI)Sylvia Sidney, 66 years, old, a leading actress of the cinema of the 1930's who played a succession of hardluck ladies and ganster molls, has been released from a hospital here after treatment for an unspecified illness. Miss Sidney was admitted to the hospital on Aug. 27 and released yesterday. A hospital spokesman said that because Miss Sidney was a private patient he could not say what she had been treated for or what condition she had been in when she was admitted.

title: STEEL REFLECTS CAR SALES GAINS
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 5 Spurred by a continued rise in auto sales and a quickened pace in capital spending and heavy construction, demand for steel will be strong for the rest of 1976, according to a number of steel makers and industry analysts.

title: To Edna St. Vincent Millay
description: NEWTON, Conn.Dreams (peace to Freud) are fusions (or confusions) of revealing incongruitiesscarcely a new finding but always surprising the dreamer.

title: Emily Johnson Married to Lee S. Parker
description: Emily F. Johnson and Lee S. Parker, associates with the New York law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, were married yesterday afternoon in Scarsdale, N. Y. Rabbi Peter Rubenstein performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Mark H. Johnson of Coral Gables, Fla., and Scarsdale.

title: Louisville Bus Protest Brings Arrest of 18
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 5 (UPI)At least 18 persons, including antibusing leader Bob DePrez, were arrested, and two policemen were injured during demonstrations near two suburban area high schools tonight.

title: Bob Woolf Behind Closed Doors
description: Bob Woolf, a small roundball player at Boston College who turned square and took up the defense of burglars, bank robbers and assorted bums, first negotiated a contract for a professional athlete in the winter of 196667. Even that recently, the feudal lords of the playgrounds still looked upon serfs who hired agents as parricides who were not only unfilial but also unfaithful to the team, the flag and probably their wives. As for the agents themselves, the general manager usually kept a can of Flit on his desk for dealing with them. Aware of this sentiment when Earl Wilson asked him to represent him in salary talks with the Detroit Tigers, Woolf hid out in the pitcher's apartment. First the two of them reviewed Wilson's records for 1966, when he divided the summer between the Red Sox and Tigers 18 victories and 11 defeats, 136 for Detroit  and agreed on what he should get and how he should ask for it. Then Wilson went alone to talk with Jim Campbell, the general manager. Whenever a problem arose, he would excuse himself, go to an outside phone and get his lawyer's advice. Ultimately they worked out an arrangement for deferred compensation which the Tigers are still using with other players.

title: Optimistic Gal Triumphs By a Length in Delaware
description: STANTON, Del., Sept. 5 (AP)  Mrs. Bertram R. Firestone's Optimistic Gal, the 1975 juvenile filly champion, strengthened her claim to national 3  year  old honors today, carrying 119 pounds to a onelength victory in the $108,400 Delaware Handicap.

title: More Investigators Sought For Inquiry on Medicaid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) F. David Mathews, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that he has asked President Ford to more than double the number of investigators looking into Medicaid fraud.

title: Bronx Man Found Hanged
description: The body of a man with a belt tied around his neck was found inside his apartment yesterday in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx, according to the police. The man, whose identity was withheld pending notification of relatives, was found inside 1020 Faile Street, at 5:15 P.M. by other residents.

title: IRAN SLAYS KILLER OF U.S. CIVILIANS
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 5 (AP) Security agents killed one of the assassins of three American civilians after tracing him through the Volkswagen used when the three were ambushed a week ago, the Iranian Government said today.

title: Market Holiday
description: All banks in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will be closed today for Labor Day. Domestic securities and commodities exchanges, as well as those in Canada, will also be closed.

title: South Africa Blacks Said to Plan Strike
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 5 (Reuters)Militant blacks were reported today to be planning a nationwide strike starting on Tuesday. The strike could reignite riots that have taken almost 300 lives in South Africa since June.

title: Cats in Central Park Fare Well
description: Every evening, Josephine Neuman, weighed down by a 15pound bag filled with cans of pet food, goes to the Central Park Zoo to feed the 50 stray cats who forsake their daytime hiding places to roam freely about the area.

title: Holiday Inns Persevering in Hunt for Island's Welcome Mat
description: NANTUCKET, Mass.The colonial guest houses and clapboard inns of this antique whaling outpost may be getting a big modern competitor  a Holiday Inn and many Nantucketers are not happy about this 20thcentury incursion.

title: PROTEIN IS EASING CHRONIC HEPATITIS
description: BOSTON, Sept. 4 (AP)Doctors say they are successfully using a natural human protein to treat longtime carriers of hepatitispeople whose disease until now had no cure.

title: Patriots 20, Eagles 7
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Sept. 5 (UPI)Ike Forte and Don Calhoun scored touchdowns as the New England Patriots defeated the Philadelphia Eagles, 207, in their final preseason game. The Patriots scored 17 points in the second quarter.

title: Itaipu Dam: Brazil's Giant Step
description: ITAIPU, Brazil  In one sweep, the huge power shovel scooped up 15 cubic yards of rich red mud and gray basalt rock and deposited them on top of a 75ton truck with wheels as tall as a fullgrown man.

title: Optimism at a New High For Integration in Schools
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 5The second year of courtordered desegregation in Louisville began last week without the widespread protests that marred last year's school opening.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Article 2  No Title
Refugees Taken on Tanker
description: MIAMI, Sept. 5 (UPI)Thirteen Haitian and four Jamaican refugees were picked up last night in the Atlantic Ocean, floating next to their capsized 18foot boat in which they had traveled from Freeport, Bahamas, immigration officials said. They were taken aboard a Norweigan tanker some 60 miles southeast of Cape Canaveral.

title: FiveWay Democratic Battle for BronxWestchester Representative Is Wide Open
description: Two former Lindsay administration officials, a former Republican Assemblyman, a Yonkers City Councilman and a New Rochelle lawyer are battling for the Democratic nomination for United States Representative in the BronxWestchester 23d Congressional District.

title: A Sartorial Appraisal of the Candidates
description: Clothes maketh the man, but they're unlikely to make a President or Vice President this year, according to a couple of prominent American designers.

title: Nantucket's Lure Offsets Toil for 2 Innkeepers
description: NANTUCKET, Mass.Bill and Jeanne McHugh cannot explain exactly why they gave up their comfortable lives on Long Island three years ago to buy a converted 1865 carriage house here and spend 16 hours a day struggling to run it as a guest house. They cite the Long Island Expressway ... values getting out of balance ... desire for a new life style. But in the end, says Mrs. McHugh, there was no real explanation  it was like falling in love.

title: Ruth Ann Roth Bride Of Jeffrey Liberman
description: Ruth Ann Roth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter L. Roth of Woodbridge, Conn., was married at noon yesterday to Jeffrey Liberman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Liberman of Montreal.

title: Dr. Attilio Robertiello, 84, Cardiovascular Specialist
description: Dr. Attilio Robertiello, a physician specializing in the private practice of internal medicine and cardiovascular disease, died at his home on Friday. He was 84 years old and lived at 145 East 15th Street in Manhattan.

title: Suzanne R. Schott Wed to Mark Kline
description: Suzanne Randy Schott and Mark John Kline, graduates of the University of Michigan, were married yesterday afternoon at the Allison caterers in Manhasset, L. I., Rabbi Herschel Levin performed the ceremony.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: More and more the American public is creating home versions of that rich, thickened and prized ingredient of the French kitchen, crme fraiche.

title: Flurry of Objects Turns Eyes to Sky In Rockland County
description: Some strange things have been reported in the skies over Rockland County lately.

title: ARAB HIJACKERS FREE 80 HOSTAGES
description: LARNACA, Cyprus, Sept. 5Three Palestinians who hijacked a Dutch airliner yesterday with 80 people aboard and demanded that Israel release eight prisoners freed their hostages today in return for a promise of safe conduct from Greek Cypriot authorities, airport officials said.

title: Cultural Council to Begin Second Decade in Arts
description: The North Jersey Cultural Council will soon begin a new season marking the nonprofit organization's second decade of promoting the arts in local communities.

title: Marchibroda Quits Colts In Dispute With Owner
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 5 (AP) The owner of the Baltimore Colts, Robert Irsay, said today that he had accepted the resignation of Coach Ted Marchibroda following a dispute over how to run the National Football League club.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Ellen Ann McGarry Wed to an Ensign
description: In St. Mary of the Isle Roman Catholic Church in Long Beach, L. I., yesterday afternoon, Ellen Ann McGarry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. McGarry of Island Park, L. I., became the bride of Ens. John Emmett Crowley Jr., U.S.C.G., son of Mr. and Mrs. Crowley of Minneapolis.

title: The Arabs in London: A Summer Chill Sets In
description: LONDON, Sept. 5Irmgard Chapman runs the Dress Den on Gloucester Road, a shopping thoroughfare in the South Kensington section of London. She has had her fill of the Arabs who are vacationing in London.

title: Miss Springer Wed in Capital
description: Katherine Curtis Springer and Paul George Hickey, a vice president of the Irving Trust Company, were married yesterday in the Navy Chapel in Washington. The Rev. Robert Curry, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Mexico's Change of Presidents Expected to Improve U. S. Ties
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 5The militant efforts of President Luis Echeverria Alvarez to reduce Mexico's identity with the United States and to align it with the third world have driven relations between Washington and Mexico City to their lowest ebb in recent memory.

title: FRENCH ARCHBISHOP DEFIES BAN AGAIN
description: BESANCON, France, Sept. 5, (Reuters)  For the second week, Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre today celebrated mass in Latin in defiance of a Vatican ban.

title: Outcry Surrounds French Publisher's Bid to Buy Daily
description: PARIS, Sept. 5Unless the Government of President Valry Giscard d'Estaing intervenes, a charming, ambitious 56yearold publisher will increase his already firm control of a substantial part of the French press.

title: DOLE IS REPORTED LINKED TO '73 GIFT BY GULF OIL AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5  A lobbyist for the Gulf Oil Corporation has told a Federal grand jury here that in 1973 he made an illegal corporate contribution to Robert J. Dole, now the Republican VicePresidential nominee, according to sources familiar with the investigation.

title: Phillips Bennitt Hoyt, 70, Former ACF Executive
description: Phillips Bennitt Hoyt, former vice president in charge of purchasing for ACF Industries, a manufacturer of railroad freightand tankcars and car components died Saturday at Flushing Hospital after a long illness. He was 70 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: San Ra's Arkestra Recalls Swing Era At the Bottom Line
description: Sun Ra and his Myth Science Cosmos Swing Arkestra returned to the Bottom Line over the weekend after their latest European tour, essentially the same one Sun Ra has performed with over the years, was in fine form. Although some of the many Sun Ra performances this reviewer has seen were more energetic and abandoned, few were as cohesive, and the Bottom Line's sound system is the best the group has had to work with in New York.

title: Commodities
description: An unusually large number of grain futures contracts is being exchanged for the actual grain these days, according to brokers interviewed in Kansas City last week.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
VAUN GILLMORE McNEILE
description: Vaun Gillmore McNeile, a former trustee and vice president of the Bollingen Foundation, sponsor of individuals and institutions for research and writing in scholarly fields and the humanities, died of cancer Saturday in Roosevelt Hospital. She was 66 years, old and lived at 125 East 74th Street.

title: Belmont Entries
description: Horses listed in order p( post Positions Letter designates Of B. listing

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, 1976

title: ...And the Job Issue
description: Since President Ford and Jimmy Carter have both named jobs as the top issue in their contest for the Presidency, the new data on unemployment must be viewed with concern by Mr. Ford.

title: Mrs. Gundersen Wed to Physician
description: The marriage of Nancy Gunderson, national director of public relations and fashion promotion for Ship'n Shore Inc., to Dr. Martin L. Stone of New York and Water Mill, L.I., chairman of the department of obstetrics and gynecology at New York Medical College, took place yesterday afternoon in Quogue, L. I.

title: New St. Peter's Quad Drew on Creative Angle
description: JERSEY CITYAt a cost of $242,000, Saint Peter's College has ocmpleted the remodeling of the campus quadrangle, drawing on sociological research for its architectural design.

title: Czechoslovakia 8, Finland 0
description: TORONTO, Sept. 5 (UPI)Jiri Holocek turned in the first shutout of the Canada Cup of Hockey tournament today as Czechoslovakia scored an 80 victory over Finland.

title: Labor in Transition ...
description: Labor Day in this Bicentennial year finds organized labor well advanced in a changing of the guard. New faces are appearing in the leadership of many of the nation's biggest and most powerful unions, and many more are scheduled to come to the fore in the next 12 months. Whether the shifts in union command will bring needed gains in standards of industrial and public responsibility remains uncertain, but there is a healthy awareness among most of the incoming leaders that labor's ties to the community badly need repair.

title: Man Helping a Friend Is Slain By Thief Near Columbia Library
description: A 22yearold man who had reluctantly come to New York City to help a friend move out of a fraternity house was stabbed to death at an entrance to Columbia University's Butler Library Saturday night. Dozens of other students were moving their belongings into and out of dormitories on the block when the murder took place.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Three cakemix companies that do business in New York State have agreed to specify on their mix boxes that the mixes are not complete in themselves, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowski announced yesterday. Until now, he said, the labels on Proctor & Gamble's Duncan Hines cakemix boxes show a fully frosted cake, even though frosting is not included in the mix. Nabisco meanwhile has been selling Dromedary cake mixes and GilsterMary Lee has been selling storebrand mixes whose labels show the finished product, without saying on the front of the box that these mixes do not include such necessary ingredients as eggs, milk and shortening, Mr. Lefkowitz said.

title: Woman Builds Church With Own Cash
description: EAST GRANBY, Conn., Sept. 5With tears in her eyes, 85yearold Rushia West consecrated her life's dream here today, a plain gray church shel built with her own money, her own hands and a little help from her friends.

title: About New York
description: Sometimes the swing room is a cubicle in a huge garage and terminal for city buses. Sometimes it is a store front in an aging apartment house. It has nothing to do with music of the 30's. In these swing rooms city bus drivers gather between stints at the wheel, to chat for a while, to eat out of paper bags, to spin tales of the wondrous city they see and experiencesometimes unhappilyas the bus bounces over potholed streets, collecting and discharging passengers in variof irritation.

title: Two Women Bring New Hope to Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 5Mairead Corrigan puts her faith in God, and Betty Williams trusts in the common sense of ordinary people. They are believers, and this is what keeps them going. What they can't believe is their own success.

title: Navigational Error Caused Azores Crash, Officials Say
description: PONTA DELGADA, Azores, Sept. 5 (AP)The crash of a Venezuelan air force transport that killed 68 persons, most of them members of a college choir, was caused by an apparent navigational error during a hurricane, Portuguese officials said today.

title: Rising Pupil Suspensions in New York Sparking a Dispute Over Their Causes
description: The number of pupils suspended from the New York City public schools has increased significantly over the last five years, mostly at the high school level, but the reasons for the increase are in dispute.

title: Suspect in Two Murders To Return to Greenwich
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. Cobwebs run from ground floor windows to the scraggly branches of philodendrons outside the white splitlevel home where Joanne Kim Klein and her companion were murdered last June.

title: Nastase Calmly Defeats Riessen, 62, 75
description: Ilie Nastase was all business with his tennis and temperament in a 62, 75 victory over Marty Riessen yesterday at the $416,600 United States Open championships.

title: Magazine Reports Israel Has Pact With Lebanese
description: Time magazine said yesterday that Israel had established a secret alliance with Lebanese Christians and Moslem moderates to undermine the power of Palestinian guerrillas in Lebanon.

title: WARRING GROUPS MEET IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 5The head of the security wing of Al Fatah, the main Palestinian guerrilla organization, has begun meeting with Christian and rightist leaders in an effort to end the fighting in Lebanon.

title: Crash Kills Brooklyn Man
description: MONROE, N. J., Sept. 5 (UPI)  A 72yearold Brooklyn man was killed in a onecar accident on the New Jersey Turnpike, authorities reported today. The man, Charles Mopsik of 1569 Ocean Avenue, was killed about 2 P.M. yesterday when his car left the turnpike and struck a tree near the Jamesbury exit, the state police said.

title: Tibet and SelfDetermination
description: For centuries Tibet has captured the imagination of the world as a land of magic and mystery, high up on a plateau, surrounded by impregnable mountains forming an awesome natural barrier. Tibet kept to herself through the centuries, but by the end of the Second World War she was finally poised to open her doors and ready to be swept along by the global advancement in technology and human relations. However, this did not happen. A foreign army marched into Tibet and closed her borders once more. And this time the flow of people across the Himalayas probably reached its lowest ebb since the early records of Tibetah history.

title: Pasta Price Rise Comes as Surprise To Italian Families
description: ROME, Sept. 5Italians returned from summer vacation this weekend to rainy weather and the grim news that the price of pasta had been raised.

title: Black SchoolLockout Victims Reunite
description: FARMVILLE, Va., Sept. 4A bitter sweet class reunion of more, than 400 blacks who were locked out of Prince Edward County's public schools for five years in the era of South's massive resistance to racial integration was being held over the Labor Day weekend in this tobacco trading center and county seat.

title: Pitcher's 2 Homers Top Mets
description: There was a lot of bad luck on the line yesterday at Shea Stadium, with the Philadelphia Phillies putting an eightgame losing streak against Mickey Lolich's inability to get many runs while pitching for the Mets.

title: Bridge:
description: One might think that it would never be right to bid on to a virtually hopeless slam when you could rest in game. In normal circumstances, such action would certainly be foolish, but circumstances were far from normal on the diagramed deal, played yesterday.

title: END TO JOBLESSNESS IS FORECAST BY FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UPI) President Ford forecast today, on the eve of Labor Day, that full employment would be achieved.

title: HE IS REPORTED LINKED TO '73 GIFT BY GULF OIL AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5  A lobbyist for the Gulf Oil Corporation has told a Federal grand jury here that in 1973 he made an illegal corporate contribution to Robert J. Dole, now the Republican VicePresidential nominee, according to sources familiar with the investigation.

title: Ethics Committee Is Finally Gaining Respect in House
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6For years, the House Ethics Committee was the standing joke of Capitol Hill. Its very name brought smirks to the faces of the Congressional cognoscenti whose use of the nickname powerful ethics committee became de rigueur.

title: CLERGY CITE NEED FOR SPIRITUAL AID
description: The church pastor, symbol of the helping hand, often wants someone to minister more adequately to his needs, a study shows.

title: Mexico Plans to Let Foreigners Serve Prison Terms at Home
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 5The Mexican Government tonight proposed a constitutional amendment that would allow foreigners in prison here to serve their sentences in their own countries.

title: Study of Black Family Life Scores Moynihan Report
description: A major new historical study of black family life in the United States, to be published this month, challenges the findings of the socalled Moynihan Report of 11 years ago as fictive history.

title: Over Hill, Over Dale, DiNatale Hits the Trail
description: OSWEGO, N.Y.In the mail today was another reminder for my student loan. Pay up, it says. Pay up or we will call out the dogs. Pay up or we'll levy 40 percent interest. Pay up: That's what we sent you to college forto pay up.

title: The Outrageous Practice of Medicaid Medicine
description: Just about everyone agrees that physicians who submit false hills under Medicaid are engaged in an unethical practice. But so far, despite widespread disclosures of such cheating in New York State, not one of those physicians has been removed from the profession. It's totally unethical, Dr. John Finkbeiner, the president of Manhattan's Medical Society of the County of New York, said yesterday about the physician: who cheat the government by billing for services to the poor under Medicaid that they never performed.

title: Danger Signals for Carter in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5One of the few elected Democrats is California who came out early for Jimmy Carter was asked the other day how the Presidential race looked in this state. It will be real close here, he said. If I had to bet today, I'd give slight odds on Ford.

title: Solti, Back at the Met, Is Opera Optimist
description: Sir Georg Solti is as famous an opera conductor as we have these days. But Le Nozze di Figaro and Otello with the Paris Opera. at the Metropolitan Opera House starting Wednesday will be the first time New York opera lovers have had a chance to hear him in an orchestra pit here since the longgone days of the old Met.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Negotiators for the Jersey City school board and the city's 2,000 teachers began another round of talks with a mediator yesterday in an effort to avert a walkout by the Jersey City Education Association on Wednesday. The mediator, Stanley Aiges, who declined to comment on the progress so far, said he expected the talks to run through the weekend. Wednesday is the first day of the school year for the city's 38,000 students.

title: FARM WORKERS ENDORSE CARTER
description: FRESNO, Calif., Sept. 5Cesar Chavez, president of the United Farm Workers of America, today promised Jimmy Carter the support of the union in his bid for the Presidency after the Democratic candidate had told the union's first political endorsements convention by telephone that he supports a controversial union representation measure on the November ballot in California.

title: 5 African Presidents Meet in Tanzania
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sept. 5 (AP)  Presidents of five black African nations prepared today for a summit meeting that is expected to set the course for future efforts to end white minority rule in southern Africa and decide what role, if any, Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger should play.

title: Brookville Polo Victor
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., Sept. 5Harvey Rhein scored four goals and led the Brookville polo team to a 76 victory over Bethpage today. Dave Rizzo was high scorer for Bethpage with three goals.

title: Tonight's Entries at Yonkers
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: 17 Citgo Dealers Suing to Block Conversion to Pumper Stations
description: Seventeen North Jersey gasoline station operators have filed a joint suit against the Cities Service Oil Company (Citgo), charging illegal coercion to force them to terminate their franchises so Citgo can convert the stations to gasonly pumpers.

title: Marilyn Beckhorn Bride of Glenn Reiter
description: Marilyn Sue Beckhorn, a graduate fellow in art conservation at the Winterthur Museum and the University of Delaware, was married at noon yesterday to Glenn M. Reiter. He is law clerk to Judge Arlin Adams of the United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit, Philadelphia.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Following 10 hours of discussions between Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa in Zurich Saturday and yesterday, both sides strove to give the impression that the discussions on SouthWest Africa and Rhodesia had been productive, providing Mr. Kissinger with something concrete to present to black African leaders when and if he goes to Africa. The talks are expected to be completed today. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Audrey E. Gold Is Bride on L.I.
description: Audrey Ellen Gold, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Gold of Oceanside, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Allen H. Gueldenzopf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gueldenzopf of Sheboygan, Wis. Rabbi Nathaniel Schwartz performed the ceremony at the Gold home.

title: Catherine Malfitano Excels as Mimi in Boheme
description: The New York City Opera's first La Bohme of the season on Saturday afternoon was by and large a smoothly executed, enjoyable performance. One singer, Catherine Malfitano as Mimi, stood out from the other cast members in terms of musical polish and sheer vocal endowment, but her colleagues were not far behind in quality.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: New Orleans Police Call Holiday Walkout
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 5 The Policemen's Association of New Orleans called a Labor Day walkout of its 700 members to protest a cut in holiday pay ordered by the city's Civil Service Commission.

title: Theodor Siegl, 49, Conservator Of Philadelphia Museum, Dead
description: Theodor Siegl, who as conservator of the Philadelphia Museum of Art was widely known for his work in preserving and restoring paintings, died of a heart attack Saturday morning while swimming at Beach Haven Park, Long Beach, N.J. He was 49 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: Landing on Utopia
description: The United States has scored its second historic space triumph on Mars this summer with the successful landing of the Viking 2 instrument capsule on Utopia Plain. Both the Viking landers now operating on Mars had to make blind landings because scientists neither knew the detailed topography of the target sites nor was there any way available to aim the capsules as they neared their destinations.

title: Pirates Defeat Phils Twice and Draw to Within 5 Games
description: Thirteen days ago the Philadelphia Phillies enjoyed a 15game lead over the secondplace Pittsburgh Pirates in the National League's Eastern Division, and, since the three other divisional races were also onesided, baseball fans had to look to the playoffs and the World Series for excitement.

title: John K. Watson Is Dead at 76; Lawyer and Collector of Armor
description: John K. Watson, a former partner in the law firm of Dorr, Hand, Whitaker & Watson, died yesterday in Orange (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 367 Ravine Drive, South Orange, N.J.

title: TV: Thames on 9 Is a British Showcase
description: The new television season will not be delivered officially for a couple of weeks, but WOR/Channel 9 has managed, in this current period of inevitable prenatal hoopla, to divert a remarkable amount of attention to its infinitely more modest operations. This week, Monday through Friday, from 5:30 P.M. to closedown around 3 A.M., the independent station will be presenting, exclusively, programs produced by Thames Television, a major supplier to Britain's single commercial channel (the two other channels belong to the statesubsidized British Broadcasting Corporation).

title: Laos, Stressing SelfReliance, Is Finding the Road to Socialism Rough
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 1The Communist Pathet Lao, who for nine months have been firmly in control of the Government and people of Laos, are attempting to rebuild the tiny landlocked country into a selfsufficient socialist state.

title: Dance Spell Wins Jerome, Pays $17.60
description: The orders from the trainer, James Maloney, as he sent Ruben Hernandez out to ride Christiana Stable's Dance Spell in yesterday's $111,000 Jerome Handicap at Belmont Park were to keep the colt off the pace and to keep him away from the rail.

title: 253 IN A SOVIET DIOCESE SEEK BISHOP'S DISMISSAL
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 7 (Reuters)Churchgoers in the city of Sverdlovsk have appealed to Dr. Philip Potter, general secretary of the World Council of Churches, to help them get rid of their bishop, who they say is not fulfilling his pastoral duty.

title: One of World's Fastest Planes
description: The twinjet Soviet fighter that landed in northern Japan is one of the world's fastest warplanes. It has been described in the United States as the standard against which the efficiency of the Western defense systems must be evaluated.

title: Russian Lands New MIG25 In Japan, Seeking U.S. Refuge
description: TOKYO, Sept. 6A Soviet Air Force lieutenant flew one of the most advanced Soviet jet fighters, the MIG25, to Japan today and said he wanted to seek refuge in the United States.

title: LOUIS FARBER
description: Louis Farber of Hallandale, Fla., a founderand former president of the Sheffield Silver Company and Farber Brothers in New York City, died Sunday in White Plains Hospital. He was 90 years old.

title: Fewer Teacher Strikes Reported But Many Disputes Are Unsettled
description: WASHINGTON, SEPT. 6(AP) The new school year has started with fewer teacher strikes than in 1975, the National Education Association says. But the association warns that more teacher contracts are unsettled this year, which could mean trouble ahead.

title: Books of The Times
description: Deft, economical, controlled, carefully shapedit occurs to me that such a description of Richard Yates's latest novel might be doubleedged. If these qualities are usually seen as virtues in a novel, why do I feel dissatisfied after reading The Easter Parade? suppose it seems to me that Mr. Yates has been too deft in disposing of his characters, too economical in his view of their choices, too autocratic in controlling their fates, which are too shapely to sustain much tension or carry much conviction.

title: MAJOR IRRIGATION DAM IN PAKISTAN COLLAPSES
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 6 (UPI) The Bolan dam, one of Pakistan's main sources of irrigation for the arid tracts of Baluchistan, collapsed today and washed away 26 villages, officials reported.

title: HERMAN L. WEISS, 60, AN EXECUTIVE AT G.E.
description: Herman L. Weiss, a director and vice chairman of the General Electric Company, died yesterday of cancer in Memorial Hospital in New York City at the age of 60. Mr. Weiss, who lived in Greenwich, Conn., had spent 37 years with General Electric, rising from a craftsman in its lamp division to the post he held at his death.

title: Troops Disrupt Berlin Traffic
description: WEST BERLIN, Sept. 6 (UPI)Soviet troop movements along a road connecting West Germany to West Berlin blocked traffic for almost an hour tonight, producing long traffic jams, the West Berlin police said. No traffic moved along the route through East Germany to West Berlin between 9:50 P.M. and 10:30 P.M.

title: Ten Police Officials Join Group To Study Enforcement Methods
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP)Ten more police officials have joined the Police Executive Research Forum, a new national organization designed to encourage debate and experimentation in methods of law enforcement.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: Among life's lesssoughtafter encounters must be included those with the Internal Revenue Service, Nevertheless, some two minion of the more than 70 million individual tax returns filed each year are likely to be audited by the I.R.S.

title: SLAIN MAN'S FRIEND CHASED THE KILLER
description: The friend of a 22yearold man who was stabbed to death just south of the Columbia University campus last Saturday night said yesterday that although he was at the scene when the incident occurred, things happened so fast that he was not aware that his friend had been stabbed in the heart.

title: CARTER OPENS DRIVE BY DENOUNCING FORD AS TIMID PRESIDENT
description: Jimmy Carter formally began his election campaign yesterday in Warm Springs, Ga., portraying himself as the representative of a new generation of leadership and his opponent, President Ford, as timid and ineffectual.

title: 5 African Presidents Hear Rebel Leaders
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sept. 6 (UPI)Five black African Presidents opened a meeting here today to discuss strategy for gaining black majority rule in southern Africa and heard reports from leaders of liberation movements in Rhodesia and SouthWest Africa.

title: BARRETT C. GILBERT
description: Barrett C. Gilbert, who retired in 1971 as president of the Bowling Green Storage and Van Company, Yonkers, and honorary board chairman since then, died of a stroke yesterday in Southside Hospital, Bay Shore, L. I. He lived at 43 Lawrence Lane, Bay Shore, and was 83 years old.

title: Philippine Volcano Erupts
description: MANILA, Sept. 6 (AP)The Taal volcano sent rock fragments and ashladen steam more than 3,000 feet into the air today as underground explosions were recorded for the first time in four days of eruptions, the Commission on Volcanology said. The volcano, on an island 45 miles south of Manila, showed a marked intensification in activity during a threehour period. The Government has ordered residents to leave.

title: Yanks Win On Disputed Homer, 65
description: Unable to create excitement by losing enough games to manufacture a pennant race, the Yankees discovered a way to add spice to their lives last night in a 65 victory over the Boston Red Sox at Yankee Stadium.

title: Telluride Film Fete Is a Party
description: TELLURIDE, Colo., Sept. 6The Cannes Film Festival is a manic treasure hunt where only steely organization and inside tips will get you through the industrial din and distraction and into some good movies.

title: Oil Burner Victor in $101,000 Pace Before 22,328 at The Meadowlands
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Sept. 6 When Stanley Dancer sold Oil Burner early last May for $40,000, he said the 3yearold colt just wasn't aggressive enough to keep in the barn. Even an expert horseman like Dancer can make an occasional mistake.

title: Trapshooting and Skeet Shooting Growing in Popularity in the State
description: BOONTON, Sept. 6  Trapshooting and skeet shooting appear to be growing in poularity in New Jersey.

title: Bridge Open One DayJust Time for Wedding
description: ST. IGNACE, Mich., Sept. 6 (UPI)Jerry Root and Verna Coger exchanged wedding vows today in the middle of a fivemile bridge that is open to pedestrians only on Labor Day. The ceremony was atended by 26,500 persons, including Gov. William G. Milliken.

title: Contrasting Campaign Symbols
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The decisive phase of the 1976 Presidential campaign opened today on the orthodox occasionLabor Daybut in highly unorthodox locations as the two candidates presented contrasting political symbols.

title: Nicosia, Cycylya Zee Win
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP)Nicosia and Cycylya Zee, both trained by women, won divisions of the Arlington Matron Handicap at Arlington Park today.

Cole Funeral Home, 22 North Main St., Cranbury, N.J. Calling hours Wednesday evening 79. Contributions to The Heart Fund or favorile charity.

title: To Our Readers
description: Beginning with this issue, The New York Times is changing its format of eight columns on a page to one of six columns for news and nine columns for display advertising.

title: $1 Million Race to Real Wind
description: RUIDOSO DOWNS, N.M., Sept. 6 (AP)Undefeated Real Wind became the first New Mexicobred quarter horse to win the $1 million All American Futurity by beating Lord Winsalot to the wire today in the world's richest horse race.

title: DEMOCRATS' RECORD SCORED BY BUCKLEY
description: Senator James L. Buckley, in a campaign statement yesterday, blamed the Democrats who control Congress for savingsdestroying, jobdestroying, economic irresponsibility.

title: JACOB MARKOWITZ, 72, 22 YEARS ON BENCH
description: Justice Jacob Markowitz, a judge on the State Supreme Court here since 1954, died last night at the Memorial Hospital for Cancer & Allied Diseases after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

title: Market Place
description: Propertycasualty insurance companies are traditional buyers of municipal bonds for their investment portfolios. The idea is to provide taxfree income as an offset to underwriting profits.

description: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil (Reuters)A new gold rush is on in Brazil with atl the tales of gun battles, bloody feuding and hardship that characterized the early prospecting days of the American West.

title: Auto Workers and Ford Resume Contract Talks as Deadline Nears
description: DETROIT, Sept. 6With the deadline just eight days away, company and union negotiators still had the big question before them: Is there going to be a strike against the Ford Motor Company?

description: Although by the terms you propose, you take four openings and closes to my three, I accede, and thus close the arrangement.

title: India Orders Civil Servants to Limit Their Families
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 6The Government of India, continuing its steppedup program of birth control, has decided to limit the size of its employees' families to three children each.

title: LUNCH PROGRAM BIDS ARE CALLED FLAWED
description: A review by the state of competitivebidding procedures used by food distribution sponsors in the Summer Food Service Program here has found apparent irregularities in 80 of the 134 contract assign??ents.

title: Arab League Decides to Grant Full Voting Membership to P.L.O.
description: CAIRO, Sept. 6The Palestine Liberation Organization was granted full voting membership in the Arab League today. Meeting in regular session following Saturday's emergency conference on Lebanon, the league made the organization its 21st member.

title: Warm Springs: A Taste Of Thriving Yesteryear
description: WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Sept. 6This fading village has seen few exciting days lately. But this was one of them.

title: ... American Guarantee
description: Taiwan's presumed nuclear violation brings into question the American security guarantee. That guarantee, as in the case of Japan and South Korea, is designed to provide an American nuclear umbrella in place of national acquisition of atomic weapons.

title: The Yankees' Voice of Experience
description: In the hours before the New York Yankees celebrated Labor Day by laboring against the Boston Red Sox last night, Gabe Paul was not celebrating the Yankees' lead the American League East.

title: Bridge:
description: The honor of being the country's youngestever life master was earned earlier this year by Regina Barnes of Modesto, Calif., just before her 15th birthday. There is now another claimant to the title: Alex Weinum of New York City, who was some two months younger than Miss Barnes was when he reached life master.

title: Shoemaker Mount Triumphs
description: DEL MAR, Calif., Sept. 6 (UPI)Riot in Paris, under the expert handling of Bill Shoemaker, came on with a rush in the stretch today and captured the 37th running of the $100,000 Del Mar Invitational Handicap.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Ralph Ginzburg, the former publisher of Eros, a quarterly magazine, announced yesterday that he was giving 3,216 copies of the fourth and last issue of the defunct publication to the American Civil Liberties Union, which defended him. The A.C.L.U. will auction them off to raise money. Now the publisher of Moneysworth, Mr. Ginzburg was convicted on Federal charges of sending obscene material through the mails because of his sponsorship of Eros and two other publications. He served eight months of a threeyear sentence before being paroled in 1972.

title: Club Can't Find Time For a Be Late Event
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 (UPI)The Procrastinators Club of America celebrated its Be Late for Something Day by putting it off until next year.

description: Music

title: $148 MILLION GIVEN FOR SEWERS ON L. I.
description: MINEOLA, L. I. Sept. 6Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive announced today that the county would receive almost $148 million in Federal funds for sewer construction that would bring lower sewer taxes and an increase in employment.

title: Downtown Rutherford Enlivened by Street Fair
description: RUTHERFORD, Sept. 6  Thousands flocked to the downtown business district of this Bergen County community today for a street fair commemorating both Labor Day and the Bicentennial.

title: 4 Die as Plane Crashes After Hitting Power Line Near Small L.I. Airport
description: All four persons aboard were killed yesterday when a singleengine plane crashed less than half a mile from Zahns Airport in North Amityville, L.I., where it was apparently trying to land.

title: U.S. Pressing New York On Medicaid Data System
description: The Federal Government is seeking to speed up New York State's threeyear timetable for installing a statewide Medicaid management and information system.

title: 4 Held in Cairo in Train Bombing
description: CAIRO, Sept. 6 (AP)Three Egyptians and a Libyan have been arrested on charges of planting a bomb in a crowded train in Alexandria that killed eight persons and injured 60 Aug. 14, the official Middle East News Agency reported today. They were said to have been agents of Libyian intelligence.

title: Finley Suit to Be Heard
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (UPI)A hearing tomorrow before Judge Frank McGarr will open Charles O. Finley's $10.5 million damage suit against Commissioner Bowie Kuhn and organized baseball The owner of the Oakland A's filed the suit because Kuhn voided the said of Vida Blue to the New York Yankeesand Joe Rudi and Rollie Fingers to the Boston Red Sox. Finley would have received $3.5 million for the three players.

title: Fire Breaks Out at Macy's; Third in Less Than 2 Weeks
description: A fire that the police called suspicious burned bolts of cloth and a rug on the seventh floor of Macy's department store on Herald Square last night.

title: REPORTER TURNED OVER TO BRITISH IN KHARTOUM
description: LONDON, Sept. 6 (Reuters)Jon Swain, the correspondent for The Sunday Times of London who has been a prisoner of rebels in Ethiopia since midJune, was handed over to the British Embassy in Khartoum last night, a Foreign Office spokesman said today. The spokesman said Mr. Swaim seemed well and was expected to return to Britain shortly.

title: F.B.I. Joins Inquiry In Blast in Kentucky; Classes to Resume
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 6 (AP)The Federal Bureau of Investigation has entered the investigation of a predawn bomb blast today at a high school here. Despite the bombing and sporadic nighttime disruptions by antibusing protesters, school officials said that classes would resume on schedule tomorrow throughout the city.

title: With Money on the Line, Coast Skateboards Roll
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 6The sparsely filled seats of the Long Beach Arena, with its makeshift plywood hill, didn't look like nevernever land. In fact, the main floor of the arena, which had been roped off with plastic blue and white flags, looked rather amateurish for what was billed as the World Professional Skateboard Championship this past weekend in Long Beach.

title: Crucial Job
description: Two incidents underscore the importance of the decision facing Mayor Beame as he chooses among the candidates to fill the vacancy that Benjamin Malcolm's imminent departure will create at the top of the city's Corrections Department. The first is the recent flareup of racial violence on Rikers Island and the other is the high level of tension that the unhappiness of the guards contributed to, the strike at Attica last month.

title: For Adolescents, Pediatrician's Voice Is Changing
description: Sharon has outgrown her pediatrician. I won't go back to Dr. Gordon even if I'm dying, she vows. Sharon is 13 years old and in the best of health.

description: BARBERTON, Ohio, Sept. 6Senator Walter F. Mondale today charged the Ford Administration with economic mismanagement as he moved west across the country in a Labor Day marathon campaign that began when he shook hands with airport workersand, in a definite break with tradition, shook the leg of one manbefore leaving Washington.

title: DeBakey Foresees the Routine Use of Artificial Hearts in a Few Years
description: BELGRADE, Sept. 6Dr. Michael E. DeBakey, whose hearttransplant patients have lived up to six years, believes that within a fairly short span of years artificial hearts will be routinely implanted in humans.

description: CHICAGO, Sept. 4  Two political scientists who have completed a massive statistical study of American voting registration laws said yesterday that turnouts in Presidential elections would probably grow by more than 10 percent if all states made registration much easier.

description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 6 (UPI)A commuter train crashed into the rear of a stationary Mozambiquebound express train east of Johannesburg today, killing at least 31 persons and injuring more than 70, railroad officials said.

description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 6Intrepid Hero set a course record today in winning the $100,000 United Nations Handicap at the Atlantic City Race Course. The 4yearold son of Forli ran the mile and threesixteenth race on the grass in 1:52 3/5 and won by threequarters of a length.

description: TOKYO, Sept. 6A Soviet Air Force lieutenant flew one of the most advanced Soviet jet fighters, the MIG25, to Japan today and said he wanted to seek refuge in the United States.

title: MILTON I. MARCUS
description: Dr. Milton I. Marcus, former president of the New York County Optometric Society and secretary of the New York State Optometric Society, died Sunday in the home of his son, Dr. Joel Marcus, in Clinton, Conn. He was 67 years old.

description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich.When the clock strikes noon here, many downtown office workers and department store clerks think about more than lunchtime. They think about music, too.

description: Eleventh Street between Avenues A and B was not looking its best yesterday, but that was before the East 11th Street Housing Movement and the neighborhood's AdoptaBuilding program decided to celebrate Labor Day by laboring.

description: LONDON, Sept. 6Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that after three days of crucial talks with Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa, I believe that the conditions for a negotiation exist for black and white Africans to settle the key problems of Rhodesia and SouthWest Africa before violence engulfs the area.

Swiss, Stable and Affluent, Facing Problems From Too Much Success
description: ZURICHSwitzerland is in trouble. Its money is too strong, its banks are too reliable, its democracy is too stubbornly entrenched and its Government is too responsive to the grass roots.

title: Iranian Executed as Terrorist
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 6 (Reuters) An army firing squad today executed a man convicted of terrorist activities and the attempted murder of a university professor, the Government announced. Three American civilians were slain in Teheran by unidentified gunmen last month.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6Claude C. Wild Jr., a former Gulf Oil Corporation lobbyist who dispensed some $4 million in legal and illegal political contributions, said today that he gave Republican VicePresidential nominee Robert J. Dole $2,000 in cash in 1970 to pass on to Republican candidates.

title: Americans Finding Few Mexicans Who Will Accept a Devalued Peso
description: TIJUANA, Mexico, Sept. 6Carl Frederick sat huddled over his salty Margarita at the Caesar Hotel bar, gloomily regarding a wad of Mexican money he had been trying all day to spend.

description: Labor Day is a traditional time for American business to feel its pulse, to gauge the economic tempo and the appetite of consumers for products ranging from new cars to new clothes.

title: Militancy of Coloreds Shocks South Africa's Whites
description: CAPE TOWN, Sept. 6Last week's disturbances here, touched off by marches of colored schoolchildren, have alarmed white South Africa perhaps even more than the earlier rioting by blacks in cities across the country.

title: MANY SCHOOLS FACE TROUBLE THIS YEAR
description: members and pupils.

title: Ford Victory Seen as Best For Economy by Executives
description: An overwhelming majority of the corporation and bank executives responding to a recent New York Times inquiry believe the reelection of Gerald Ford as President would be better for the nation's economy than a victory by Jimmy Carter.

title: Still Taking Curtain Calls at 79, Howard Dietz Remembers It All
description: When Barbra Streisand sings the torch song Moanin Low on television or Lawrence Welk mounts a big TV production of Dancing in the Dark, Howard Dietz looks, listens and smiles contentedly to himself. It's not just because the performances involved will lead to others, and thus to more money in the bank for him, but also because, as lyricist of these and about 1,000 other songs of Broadway musicals of past years, Mr. Dietz is proud of his creations and gratified by demonstrations of their continuing durability and popularity.

title: Fashion: Getting Into the Spirit of '76
description: To keep in step with fall fashion, it's not necessary to throw out last year's clothes and start from scratch. It would be foolhardy to suggest this and nobody has. The new clothes are an extension of trends that have been simmering for the last few years. Without resorting to such desperate measures as baring the navel or other parts of the anatomy, invoking the aid of plastic or paper, or raising or lowering the hemline by a yard or two, designers have nevertheless, in a lowkeyed way, turned out clothes that are fresh and inventive.

title: Chess:
description: The Manhattan Chess Club International Tournament, the first for which New York has been host since 1951, ended in a triple tie for first prize among Norman Weinstein, a United States international master; Leonid Shankovich, an Israeli grandmaster, and Anatol Lein, an expatriate Russian grandmaster. Each scored 104 in the roundrobin event jointly sponsored by the club, the United States Chess Federation and the American Chess Foundation.

description: Partial Iist of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: A Carter Son Confirms He Smoked Marijuana
description: MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 6 (AP)  Jeff Carter, the 22yearold son of Democratic Presidential candidate Jimmy Carter, confirmed today that he has tried marijuana, but he said, I don't recommend it to anybody.

title: Laotian Calls on Brezhnev
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 16 (AP)The Soviet Communist Party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, met today with the Laotian Prime Minister, Kaysone Phomvihan, and suggested that Laos had an important role to play in supporting progressive movements in Asia, Tass reported. The Laotian leader is making his second visit to the Soviet Union in five months.

title: Jet Borrowed by Amin Is Returned to Israelis
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 6President Idi Amin of Uganda returned his presidential jet to its Israeli manufacturer today. The move appeared to be the first step toward implementing his pledge earlier this year to return all the aircraft he had obtained from Israel but not paid for.

title: SCHOOLS IN SUBURBS FACE TROUBLED YEAR
description: As public schools in the New York area's suburbs open throughout this week, the academic year is once again beginning against a backdrop of budget defeats, staff cutbacks and a generally continuing decline in enrollment. But this year, a record number of school districts will operate on austerity programs, and a record number of teachers may go on strike.

title: 13 FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS WARNED ON HEALTH CODE
description: The New York City Health Department has cited 13 foodhandling establishments for violating the Health Code and issued the results of final inspections at six previously cited establishments:

title: President Signs Bill To Extend Tax Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI)President Ford signed a bill today to extend the tax cut until Sept. 15 and urged Congress to consider the needs of the people, not just of the special interests, in writing a tax reform measure.

title: VW HOPEFUL IT CAN ERASE $384 MILLION IN LOSSES
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany, Sept. 6 (Reuters)The Volkswagen group may this year erase its carriedforward losses of some 960 million marks ($384 million) if the considerable improvement in firsthalf earnings continues, Volkswagen AG said in a letter to shareholders released today.

title: Belgian Commission Suspends ForeignOwned Bank a Week
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 6 (Reuters)  The Belgian Banking Commission said it had appointed a special commissioner to the Banque Pour l'Amerique du Sud and suspended all the bank's activities for a week, except repayment of customer deposits in Belgian francs.

title: Planners Find Welfare Payments In New York Attracting Recipients
description: The interaction of four factors has created substantial monetary incentives for welfare recipients to live in New York City and financial incentives, for taxpayers to leave, according to two experts for the Regional Plan Association.

title: Bill Hardey Dead; Was Restaurateur, Jockey and Dancer
description: Bill Hardey, a restaurateur whose name and taste survive in the Bill's Gay Nineties restaurant at 57 East 54th Street, died Saturday in his home at 400 East 57th Street. He was 82 years old.

title: Fans at Open Dissatisfied at Food Prices, Parking, Night Play
description: They have no complaint over ticket prices, are delighted with the additional toilet facilities and water fountains, and like bigtime tennis enough to show up more than once at the United States Open at Forest Hills.

title: Pearson Captures Southern 500; Petty 2d
description: DARLINGTON, S.C., Sept. 6 (AP)David Pearson took the lead with 56 miles to go today as he drove his Mercury to victory in the 27th annual Southern 500 stock car race. Pearson became the second driver to win the sport's triple crown.

title: Eustace Seligman, a Civic Leader And Retired Lawyer, Dead at 87

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6Retired Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court was resting comfortably, after a twohour operation tonight to repair a broken left hip, according to a spokesman at Walter Reed Army Hospital.

title: Soiled White Collar
description: Disclosures of whitecollar crime have swept over the American public in steady, consecutive waves. Flagrant breaches of the law have involved politicians, corporation executives, lawyers, physicians, and operators of social services from daycare centers for infants to nursing homes for the aged. Billions of dollars have been misappropriated, diverted from their public purposes, used as political or commercial bribes, or just plain stolen. Careers have been destroyed; untold suffering has been caused.

description: Two years ago, as the regular organization candidate, Leo C. Zeferetti won the Democratic primary in Brooklyn's 15th Congressional District by 62 votes out of the more than 24,000 cast.

description: Dr. Renee Richards said last night she had filed formal applications with the Women's Tennis Association and United States Tennis Association to play in their fall and winter women's tours as a professional.
