description: PARIS, Sept. 6The Vietnamese Embassy here today made public the names of 12 missing American pilots and said they had been killed in action in the war in Indochina.

title: Japanese Airline Executive Out On Bail in Lockheed Scandal
description: TOKYO, Sept. 6 (UPI)The president of AllNippon Airways, in jail for two months in connection with Japan's Lockheed payoff scandal, was freed today on bail of nearly $84,000.

title: Shrimpers Fear a Loss of Good Waters
description: BROWNSILLE, Texas, Sept. 4Rough seas, sharks, Mexican gunboats and foul weather as well as old Confederate ship anchors have plagued Carl Gayman's shrimp boats in the past. But he has fended them off and prospered.

title: U. S. REACHES ACCORD WITH NORTH KOREANS TO PREVENT CLASHES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The Americanled United Nations Command and North Korea today concluded an agreement on new security arrangements for the truce site of Panmunjom aimed at preventing clashes such as the one on, Aug. 18 in which two American Army officers were killed.

title: To Our Readers
description: Beginning with this issue, The New York Times is changing its format of eight columns on page to one of six columns for news and nine columns for display advertising.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Congress is scheduled to consider this week hills proposed by New Jersey lawmakers that would allow a state to pinpoint and control carcinogenic and other toxic chemicals from industrial sources. Tomorrow, a joint Congressional conference committee will act on an amendment to the Toxic Substances Control Act that would provide up to $1.5 million in research funds to states experiencing high incidences of cancer. The amendments were drafted by New Jersey's Senators Clifford Case, Republican, and Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat, and Representative Andrew Maguire, Democrat of Ridgewood. The state's cancer rate is about 15 percent higher than the national

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Yonkers Racing
description: RESULTS

title: An Audit by Goldin Reports Laxity In Office of Neighborhood Service
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, in ar audit report, gave the city's Office of Neighborhood Services a generally good bill of health yesterday, but found instances of overstaffing, lax fiscal management and tardiness in seeking available financing.

title: ORGANIZATION HELPS COMPULSIVE EATERS
description: Overeaters Anonymous, an organization that fights food addiction, arrives in Paterson tonight at 7:45for the first in a series of meetings at the Schneider branch of the Young Men's  Young Women's Hebrew Association, 39th Street near McLean Boulevard (Route 20).

title: Con Ed to Test TimeofDay Rates
description: An electric rate experiment will offer 1,320 Consolidated Edison customers in New York City and Westchester County a chance to save money by basing their bills on the time they use electricity. But they could just as well end up paying more.

title: Test Linking 6 Automated Clearing Houses by a Fed Network Debated
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6A planned test that would link, six of the nation's automated clearing houses through the telecommunications network of the Federal Reserve System has created a debate on the proper role of the Government in electronic fund transfers.

title: CHEMICAL INDUSTRY IS OPTIMISTIC ON BILL ON TOXIC SUBSTANCES
description: After four years of lobbying, threatening and cajoling, the chemical industry believes that, in regard to control of toxic substances, it has won the best deal possible in a bill passed by the House of Representatives last week.

title: Guam Votes by a Wide Margin To Continue Close Ties to U.S.
description: AGANA. Guam, Sept. 6 (AP)Guam residents have voted overwhelmingly to continue the island territory's close relationship with the United States and draft its own constitution. Results of a Saturday referendum made available today showed that 10,221 of the 17,607 votes were in favor of improving portions of the Organic Act, by which the island has been governed since 1950.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Not Carter but Ford Is The Issue
description: Gerald Ford's campaign may be off to a good start in the attempt to make Jimmy Carter, rather than the record of the NixonFord Administrations, the issue of the 1976 campaign.

title: Prince Wan Waithayakon Is Dead; Was Thai Envoy to U.S. and U.N.
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 6 (AP)Prince Wan Waithayakon, former Thai Ambassador to the United States and President of the United Nations General Assembly in 195657, died yesterday of a heart ailment, Radio Thailand announced today. His age was 85.

title: Fine Weather Aids Busy Retail Trade On 3Day Weekend
description: Clear, cool weather yesterday helped to generate what retailers termed very good Labor Day traffic in downtown and suburban stores.

title: Israel Rejects Appeal by Church For Release of Bishop Capucci
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 6 (Reutes)Israel has turned down an appeal by the Greek Catholic Church to pardon Archbishop Hilarion Capucci, head of the Greek??atholic community in Jerusalem, who was convicted in 1974 of running guns for Arab guerillas, Justice Ministry souces said today.

title: SOLARENERGY DRIVE ASKED BY MRS. ABZUG
description: Representative Bella S. Abzug yesterday called for New York State to take the lead in becoming the solarenergyequipment capital of the nation. She did so in a position paper that also proposed that large oil companies be broken up and that emphasis be placed on energy sources that made greater use of labor.

title: Municipals May Be Nudging Year's Lowest Yields
description: Interest rates on bonds issued by states, cities and towns have been declining all summer and have reached their lowest levels in 18 months. That is good news for local government finance officials and taxpayers but bad news for investors. If Wall Street is correct in assessing the outlook, taxexempt bond yields will continue to decline a while but they are also thought not far from their lowest levels of the year. Sometime this ?? likely will begin to head upward one again.

title: Notes on People
description: Gamelaw citations, charging illegal baiting of mourningdoves with corn, have been sent to Gov. Daniel Walker of Illinois and eight companions who hunted with him on a friends farm last week. The State Representative Gale Schisler, a fellow Democrat and hunter, said yesterday that the Governor knew nothing about the corn and may have been set up for the violation.

title: Dole Sees Carter at Southern 500
description: DARLINGTON, S.C., Sept. 6Senator Robert J. Dole came to the Southern 500 stock car race here today to face down Jimmy Carter and prove that the Republicans intended to make the South a battleground in this fall's Presidential election.

title: Banks and Exchanges Closed
description: All banks in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut were closed yesterday in observance of Labor Day. Securities and commodities exchanges in the United States and Canada were also closed, but most foreign markets were open.

title: The Times Alters Its Column Format For News and Ads
description: With today's issue, The New York Times adopts a new format of six columns of news and nine columns of advertising on a page, replacing the eightcolumn news and advertising format it has used since 1913.

title: Anahid Sofian Gives Traditional Mideast Dances
description: Novelty is the staff of life to the New York Dance Festival, which has launched new companies and choreographers with egularity during its decade and a half of existence. Anahid Sofian needs no such launching but was a decided first for the festival as she presented traditional Middle Eastern dancing Sunday evening at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.

title: Cole, After G.M. Retirement, Finds Business Life Increasingly Active
description: DETROITEdward N. Cole is scarcely an average retired auto worker.

title: Tullius Wins at Lime Rock
description: LIME ROCK, Conn., Sept. 6Bob Tullius of Herndon, Va., won the feature race today at the Sports Car Club of America's national championship. Tullius, driving a Jaguar XJE in competition for the first time, broke, the lap record on the second lap as he defeated Sylvan Cornblatt of Baltimore.

title: Trafalgar Unit in Ship Deal
description: LONDON, Sept. 6 (Reuters)Trafalgar House Investments Ltd. today said its subsidiary, the Cunard Steamship Company Ltd., had signed a conditional agreement wtih Maritime Fruit Carriers to buy for $112 million Maritime's 13 British flag refrigerated vessels.

title: Bronx Man Found Hanged
description: The body of a man with a belt tied around his neck was found inside his apartment Sunday in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx, according to the police. The man, whose identity was withheld pending notification of relatives, was found inside 1020 Faile Street, at 5:15 P.M. by other residents.

title: Major League Scores
Koosman Defeats Cubs As Kingman Hits No. 34
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 6Dave Kingman doesn't know why, he says, but he seems to hit better at 60yearold Wrigley Field than at most other National League ball parks. He couldn't explain the reasons today, but substantiating evidence was a kingsized home run and a double off the centerfield wall that accounted for three runs in a 74 triumph for the Mets over the Chicago Cubs.

title: STAVISKY BILL VOTE HAUNTING SANTUCCI
description: Last April 14, when Senator John J. Santucci stood on the State Senate floor to denounce the StaviskyGoodman bill as a sham and to vote against overriding Governor Carey's veto, he knew he was asking for trouble. Last month, he got it.

title: Gold Price Jumps to $115 On Deluge of Buy Orders
description: LONDON, Sept.6 (AP) The price of gold shot up $5 to $8 an ounce on European bullion markets today, and closed at $115.50 an ounce in London and $113.50 in Zurich. The dollar weakened slightly on most exchanges in light trading.

title: Teachers in Buffalo Approve A Strike Despite 2 Injunctions
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 6 (AP)Teachers defied two court injunctions and voted tonight by a 2to1 margin to strike.

title: Judge Rejects Plea to Step Down In a PoliceAbuse Case in Alabama
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 5  A Federal District Judge has rejected a lawyer's demand that the judge step down because he has shown personal bias in a case involving allegations of the most extensive police misconduct in Montgomery in 15 years.

title: 2 Killed and 3 Injured in Florida When Rescue Unit Hits an Auto
description: MIAMI, Sept. 6 (AP)  Two people, one a paramedic, were killed today and three others were injured when a fire department rescue unit that was responding to a call for help smashed into an automobile, the authorities said.

title: Kenneth B. Appel, 70, Starred In Tennis While at Princeton
description: Kenneth Brooks Appel, a Princeton University tennis star in the 1920's and a manager at American Cyanamid Company and Lederle Laboratories for 36 years until his retirement eight years ago, died yesterday in New York Hospital alter a heart attack. He was 70 years old.

title: Kuwait Newspaper Is Told To Shut Down for 3 Months
description: KUWAIT, Sept. 6 (Reuters)The Kuwait Government has ordered the weekly newspaper AlRisala to close for three months. The publication was the fourth to be suspended since the Government acted to control the press a week ago.

title: Vietnam Tells U.S. 12 of Missing Pilots Were Killed in War
description: PARIS, Sept. 6The Vietnamese Embassy here today made public the names of 12 missing American pilots and said they had been killed in action in the war in Indochina.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SWING HIGHIf any proof is needed that country music has come a long way from Nashville, there's the opening tomorrow, 65 floors above Manhattan, of a whole festival of strawcircuit performerscountry singers, dancers and groups from Tennessee and Texasat the Rainbow Grill in Rockefeller Center. This is the first countrystyle roundup in the cabaret's 42year history (with a downhome menu added to the regular fare).

title: Man Who Beat Lottery System Gains Little
description: PORTLAND, Me.  It had to happen, right?

title: Colt Players Meet, Discuss a Boycott
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 6 (AP)The Baltimore Colts, clearly, demoralized by the sudden resignation of their head coach, Ted Marchibroda, held a players' meeting today and discussed a possible boycott. Meanwhile, assistant coaches reportedly considered resigning, and one city official warned of a possible rebellion by the fans.

title: BILL PEEPLES
description: GREENVILLE, S. C., Sept. 6 (UPI)Bill Peeples, the managing editor of The Greenville News, died today of an apparent heart attack while vacationing in St. Augustine, Fla., with his wife, Edith, and daughter Ann. He was 51 years old.

title: MANY SCHOOLS FACE TROUBLE THIS YEAR
description: Public schools are scheduled to open throughout New Jersey this week against a backdrop of budget defeats, cutbacks in personnel, and a continuing general decline in enrollment.

title: Dog Kills an Infant Left in Apartment; Mother Is Arrested
description: A 4dayold baby girl, left alone on the floor of an East Harlem apartment, was killed yesterday morning by the family's German Shepherd, which had not been fed for several days.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1976

title: New Orleans Police Conduct a SickOut To Protest Pay Cuts
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 6 (AP)Community relations and police academy officers manned squad cars today after 60 percent of the city's patrol force staged a Labor Day sickout to protest holiday pay cuts.

title: Passer Among 6 Cut
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I, Sept. 6Speaking in whispers and avoiding what J. J. Jones would refer to as eye contact, the Jets walked around their locker room in a slowmotion daze this morning as they learned which teammates had not made it into the regular season.

title: Parties Backing Makarios Sweep Cyprus Election; 2 of Them Are on the Left
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 6 (UPI)An alliance of Communists and two other parties supporting President Makarios won all but one seat in the 35member Greek Cypriote House of Representatives today.

title: Contrasting Campaign Symbols
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The decisive phase of the 1976 Presidential campaign opened today on the orthodox occasionLabor Daybut in highly unorthodox locations as the two candidates presented contrasting political symbols.

title: Birmingham Publisher Propelled by Regionalism
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 6The South has a verb, to countryboy, which means to gain the upper hand by playing dumb.

title: Pledges Tough Management and Careful Planning Leading to a Balanced Budget
description: CARTER OPENS DRIVE BY DENOUNCING FORD AS TIMID PRESIDENTWARM SPRINGS, Ga., Sept. 6Jimmy Carter formally began his election campaign today, portraying himself as the representative of a new generation of leadership and his opponent, President Ford, as timid and ineffectual.

title: Erratic Couriers
description: A letter mailed recently from New York City to a small community in upstate New York took six days to get there. It was properly stamped and carried a clearly typed address, including zip code.

title: Taiwan's ABomb ...
description: The American intelligence report that Taiwan clandestinely has built a reprocessing facility that is extracting weaponsgrade plutonium explosive from spent nuclear reactor fuel rods demands immediate investigation by the appropriate Congressional committees. Taiwan's denials have not impressed Washington insiders.

title: Memorial Services
description: MARTINKathleen McFadden. Memorial service. Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Ave. and 91st St. on Wednesday, September 8 at 4 PM.

title: U.S. REACHES ACCORD WITH NORTH KOREANS TO PREVENT CLASHES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The Americanled United Nations Command and North Korea today concluded an agreement on new security arrangements for the truce site of Panmunjom aimed at preventing clashes such as the one on Aug. 18 in which two American Army officers were killed.

title: VIKING LANDER'S TV TURNS EYES TO EAST
description: PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 6The Viking 2 lander has focused its television eyes on the eastern horizon of Mars and has disclosed in the images received here today a series of distant, flattop hills. It has gazed more closely than before at the nearby rocks, many of which resemble weathered coral but are thought to be of volcanic origin.

title: Poster Proclivities Plaguing Politicians
description: Somewhere in Queens, there is a phantom poster plucker, much to the annoyance of political candidates, but to the delight of Robert A. Low, the city's Environmental Protection Administrator.

title: WOODCOCK SCORES FORD IN LABOR DAY MESSAGE
description: DETROIT, Sept. 6 (UPI)Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Automobile Workers, said today that President Ford's way of fighting inflation was to create mass unemployment.

title: Thai Insurgents Kill Policeman
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 6 (AP)A policeman was shot to death and another seriously wounded today in an attack by Communist insurgents in southern Thailand, a police spokesman said.

title: Conservative Rabbis Told Not to Officiate In Mixed Marriages
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI)Rabbis in the Conservative Jewish movement have been told not to participate in marriages between Jews and nonJews, but to try to convert the nonJewish partner.

title: 84 Released by Hijackers Welcomed Home by Dutch
description: AMSTERDAM, Sept 6 (Reuters)The 79 passengers and five crew members of a Dutch DC9 airliner freed in Cyprus yesterday after being held by three Arab hijackers arrived here today to an emotional welcome.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Sept. 6With the stroke of his pen at 1 P.M. Wednesday, Governor Byrne almost surely will set the stage for the major political issue in next year's state electionswhether to reenact the state income tax.

title: Arab League Says Christians Shelled Its Forces in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 6The Arab League's peacekeeping force reported today that its troops on the line between Moslem and Christian sections of the capital had come under shelling for three consecutive days,, and it said Christian forces were to blame.

title: In Memoriam
description: LERGMANSteven H. 9/7/66 to 6/27/75. In loving memory on his birthday.

title: Boola Boola, Blah Blah
description: As a Yale senior, I am, of course, concerned about the jeans issue, but I feel that the shetland sweater question is of more widespread importance to today's college youth. Why must America believe that there is any consensus among college students on anything, from foreign policy to aerosol sprays? In trying to establish just who and what the undergraduate set is in the mood to buy, politicians, merchandisers, magazines and film studios have created a false impression of universal student agreement.

title: Sucrest Asks Stock Trading Halt; Says It Can't Meet Report Deadline;
description: The Sucrest Corporation, one of the largest sugar refiners in the nation, asked that its stock be suspended from trading by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday because it could not meet a deadline for filing its annual report for the year ended last May 29 with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Bank Held Partly . By Arabs Buys 10% Of Reynolds Firm
description: A Parisbased investment bank partly owned by Arab interests has purchased a nearly 10 percent stake in Reynolds Securities International, the Big Wall Street brokerage firm said yesterday.

title: FORD AIDES EXPECT DOLE CASE TO FADE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7Several of President Ford's key political advisers said today they believed the controversy over whether Senator Robert J. Dole, the Republican Vice Presidential candidate, accepted illegal political contributions from the Gulf Oil Corporation would soon blow over, as one of them put it.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: (Figures in parentheses are season's wonlost records.)

title: Corporation Affairs
description: BETHELEM, Pa., Sept. 7The head of the nation's secondlargest steelmaking corporation indicated in an intervies here today that business spending for new plant and equipment had not increased so much as the steel industry had hoped.

title: In Memoriam
description: EDWARDSGordon F. The third anniversary without you. But today and every day, my Best Beloved Forever.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 8, 1976

title: COLLUSION CHARGED IN FEEDING PROGRAM
description: Representative Elizabeth Holtzman, Democrat of Brooklyn, said yesterday that affiliates of a major association of New York City summer food sponsors were operating $7.6 million worth of programs in four other cities, and charged that their contracts in those cities indicated collusion with two New York City caterers.

title: LOUISVILLE SCHOOLS REOPEN PEACEFULLY
description: Nearly 51,600 black students and white students were bused without incident yesterday from neighborhood schools in Louisville, Ky., Omaha, Dayton, Ohio, and Milwaukee for a better classroom racial balance. Boston officials hoped to continue the peaceful busing pattern today.

title: Radioactive Waste at the Nation's Nine Storage. Centers Is Termed a Major Hazard to Health
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7A prominent nuclear energy expert has concluded that the 75 million gallons of highlevel radioactive waste and the 51 million cubic feet of lowlevel waste now stored at nine scattered locations in the United States represent a major health hazard.

title: Technology
description: Dim light has long created problems for amateur photographers who want to take candid color shots at parties or of their children opening presents at Christmas.

title: Keystone Pioneer Wins Trot at Meadowlands
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Sept. 7 Keystone Pioneer, driven by Bill Haughton, won the $50,000 Hiram Woodruff freeforall trot tonight at The Meadowlands, but another entrant stood in the spotlight following the race.

title: Girl, 13, Held in Setting Store Fires
description: A 13yearold Bronx girl has been arrested and charged with setting 17 fires in midtown Manhattan stores in recent weeks.

title: Fishing Banned in Georgia River
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 7 (UPI)The Georgia Board of Natural Resources today ordered an end of commercial fishing on the Coosa River because of PCB poisoning and urged sportsmen to throw back fish they catch on the river. The emergency 120day ban was imposed from Rome to the Alabama line after laboratory tests of fish caught in the Coosa showed levels of PCB's up to 25 times the safe content.

title: Mayor to Name A Top Executive In San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7Mayor George R. Moscone will nominate tomorrow Budget Director Rudy Nothenberg to be the city's sixth chief administrative officer, by charter the most powerful appointive position in the local government.

title: Princess Grace Back on Stage For Edinburgh Poetry Reading
description: EDINBURGH, Sept. 7 (Reuters)Princess Grace of Monaco, the former film star Grace Kelly of Philadelphia, made a triumphant return to the entertainment world at the Edinburgh International Festival last night.

title: Personal Decision by Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (Reuters)President Ford personally has decided that the United States should grant political asylum to the Soviet pilot, the White House said today, adding that Mr. Ford had also decided to leave to Japan what to do with the plane.

title: Joan Micklin Silver Prepares To Film Between the Lines
description: Joan Micklin Silver, the independent director whose first film, Hester Street, scored with the critics and public alike, will start shooting her second production, Between the Lines, in Boston on Monday.

title: Lumberjacks Bested by Mechanic
description: SCHAGHTICOKE, N.Y., Sept. 7A 35yearold diesel mechanic, equipped with an ax and a soupedup chain saw, became New York State's champion lumberjack here yesterday.

title: Metropolitan College Football: C. W. Post Capable of Attaining Undefeated Season
description: Although Dom Anile, the C. W. Post football coach, knew his teams had won 39 games and lost only 11 for a .780 percentage over thelast five years, he did not know this placed the Pioneers fifth in the nation among Division III smallcollege teams for that period. He did not even know that his own coaching record of 5922 in eight seasons at Post was 11th best among Division III coaches.

title: Hirschfeld Has Spent $465,000 of His Own Money
description: Abraham Hirschfeld, who is generally believed to be trailing in the fiveway race for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senator from New York State has already spent at least $465,000 of his own money on his campaignmore than most of his opponents have raised for their entire campaign.

title: Team USA, Czech Six Tie, 4 to 4
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7An American team that was considered to have no chance in the Canada Cup '76 managed tonight to tie Czechoslovakia, 44, in a contest at the Spectrum.

title: British Family Held in Ethiopia Said to Be Under Intense Strain
description: LONDON, Sept. 7Jon Swain, a British newsman who was held for nearly three months by Ethiopian guerrillas, returned home today and said that a kidnapped British family of four was alive but under heavy strain.

title: THEODORE L. HOLDEN
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 7 (AP)Theodore L. Holden, an editor of The Hartford Times for 46 years, died Sunday in Portland, Me. Mr. Holden, a native of Lynn, Mass., retired in 1969 as the newspaper's state editor and literary editor.

title: JERSEY CITY SCHOOLS FACE A STRIKE TODAY
description: JERSEY CITY, SEPT. 7The Board of Education and the teachers union continued intensive bargaining tonight in an effort to head off a strike against the city's 38,000student public school system tomorrow morning.

title: INELIGIBILITY FOUND AT WELFARE CENTER
description: A total of 40 percent of the welfare cases accepted in one month by a frequentlycriticized Upper East Side center were ineligible for public support, state investigators said yesterday. They recommended that administration of the center be taken out of the city's hands.

title: Senate TV Coverage Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP)The prospect of live television coverage of the United States Senate is once again under consideration. The latest recommendation for coverage of floor debates was submitted to the Commission on Operation of the Senate by Len Allen, a commission consultant.

title: Embattled Schools ...
description: Vacations are over. This week and next, pupils across the country are entering, or returning to, school. They may go back with mixed feelings; but as they look toward a new school year, few are likely to experience the sense of gloom that seems to affect the adult view of education's present state.

title: CITIZEN ACTION UNIT FORMED IN CAPITAL
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 7Plans for a new international citizens action organization, sponsored by a group of prominent figures in many fields and aimed at expediting solutions to a wide array of human problems, were disclosed today.

title: Berkeley Turns Into Mecca for Handicapped Persons
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 5The Free Speech and People's Park struggles are long gone, but Berkeley has become a mecca for a new, equally radical movement  the growing numbers of handicapped people who are determined to live independent lives in the community, out of their family basements, out of the institutions that have kept them hidden for so long.

title: AFRICAN TALKS CLOSE WITHOUT ENDING RIFf OF BLACK RHODESIANS
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sept. 7The Presidents of five black African countries ended two days of talks here today without achieving their objective of reconciling the feuding factions of Rhodesia's black nationalist movement.

title: The U.N. Today
Dr. William Sweeney, 55; Medical Research Chief At Lederle Laboratories
description: Dr. William M. Sweeney of Montvale, N. J., director of medical research at the Lederle Laboratories Division of American Cyanamid Company. Pearl River, N. Y., died Monday in Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N. J., after a long illness. His age was 55.

title: New York State's Lottery Is Started Prematurely; One Dealer Loses Permit
description: The sale of tickets to New York State's first instant lottery, officially scheduled to get under way today, had an embarrassingly premature, albeit successful start yesterday as several dealers in the city and upstate sold thousands of the $1 tickets.

title: Gregory to Open at Right End
description: Jack Gregory, the defensive end, left camp to be at the bedside of his 3yearold son, who is undergoing another tracheal operation Thursday morning. Gregory will miss the defensive day of the preparation for the Redskins, but will open at right end in any case at Washington.... The Redskins have listed Billy Kilmer, their regular quarterback, as questionable for the opener because of bruised ribs. Joe Theismann is the replacement.

title: Kissinger Expected to Fly to Africa Next Week to Renew Negotiations
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Sept. 7Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger is expected to fly to southern Africa next week to resume attempts to negotiate solutions to the whiteblack conflicts in Rhodesia and SouthWest Africa.

title: WINE TALK
description: The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms recently advanced a proposal to inspect foreign vineyards and wineries that ship to this country. The purpose would be to insure that their wine conforms to United States standards, particularly with regard to additives.

title: CAPT. ROBERT E. BAKER
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 7Capt. Robert E. Baker, 75 years old, of this city, a retired naval surgeon who served for 30 years in the Navy before retirement, died Sunday at the Naval Regional Medical Center here after a long illness.

title: Studies of Teeth Link Japanese To Influx of Chinese in 200 B.C.
description: Studies of ancient and modern teeth from Japan and China have led an American anthropologist to conclude that the Japanese people of today are descendents of a colony of Chinese people who sailed to Japan about 2,200 years ago and displaced a culturally more primitive people who had been living there for thousands of years.

title: The Standings
description: Wednesday, September 8, 1976

title: 2 F.B.I. AGENTS TOLD THEY NEEDN'T TESTIFY
description: The Justice Department yesterday won an attempt in court to compel two special agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to appear before a special grand jury investigating allegedly illegal burglaries and possible criminal violations of civil rights by them and other agents.

title: JOHN J. CLARK
description: John Clark, executive vice president and secretary of Boyd, Weir & Sewell, Inc., steamship brokers, died Sunday in his home in Short Hills, N. J., after a short illness. He was 68 years old.

title: Giscard Tells Kissinger He Backs Plan
description: PARIS, Sept. 7President Giscard d'Estaing told Mr. Kissinger today that France would join an effort of the. international community to ease the transition for whites living in Rhodesia.

title: Buffet of Many Courses
description: If a proliferation of cooking schools can be regarded as a vital life sign, New York is in great shape. After touring 50 or so in Manhattan alone last season, one gets the feeling that at any given moment in any part of town, hundreds of, men, women, teenagers and children are mastering the art of mincing, pureing, braising and sauting, raising souffls, flipping crepes and rolling out puff pastry, pasta and egg roll skins with speed and agility.

title: Gunmen Kidnap Drug Executive, Force Him to Turn Over Narcotics
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 7 (AP)Drugs with a value estimated at $200,000 to $500,000 when sold illegally were stolen from the McKesson & Robbins Drug Company warehouse here yesterday, the police and Federal officials said.

title: Money to Aid Baby Was Already in Mail When Dog Attacked
description: When Joanne Bashold telephoned her parents last week to ten them she had given birth to a baby daughter, she sounded terribly happy, her mother recalled yesterday, and she asked for $23 to buy a crib.

title: Belmont Racing
description: RESULTS

title: Market Place
description: Some securities analysts began recommending the Rucker Company, a major producer of such oil company goods as drill bits and blowout preventers, as a turnaround industry more than a year and a half ago.

title: For South Koreans, Truce Site Accord Has Unhappy Side
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 7To many South Koreans, the new security arrangements agreed upon yesterday for the truce site at Panmunjom have the unhappy significance of completing the partitioning of the Korean peninsula.

title: Last Log Drive in U.S. Floating to End in Maine
description: SKOWHEGAN, Me.The last log drive in America is floating to an end on the Kennebec River.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: It may come as a surprise to many people to learn that food cooperatives may purchase articles from brandname processors as well as from wholesale produce and meat dealers whose willingness to deal with coops is widely known.

title: G.E. TO PAY 3 MILLION FOR DUMPING PCB'S INTO UPPER HUDSON
description: General Electric, in a negotiated settlement with the Department of Environmental Conservation, has agreed to pay $3 million toward cleansing the Hudson River of highly toxic PCB's that it dumped there. The company has also agreed to pay $1 million for research on ending the problem.

title: Aboard This Ship, Everybody Gets to Dine at Captain's Table
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R.I.It isn't the largest galley afloat and it certainly isn't the smallest. It measures about 9 by 12 feet, about the size of a decent apartment kitchen in Manhattan. Whatever its size, out of it comes some of the best meals in Atlantic and surrounding waters.

title: Santa Barbara Drilling Opposed
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Sept. 7 (UPI) City officials here urged the Federal Government today to exclude the Santa Barbara Channel from a proposed offshore oil lease sale, contending that drilling activity could have serious environmental results. The Santa Barbara Channel was the site of an oil well blowout in 1969 that spread more than 230,000 gallons of crude oil over the waters of the channel, blighting the beaches and killing more than 3,500 birds.

title: ExAide to Ribicoff Wins Fairfield Primary Vote
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 7Geoffrey G. Peterson, a 30yearold former legislative aide to Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, won a surprise victory tonight in the state's only Congressional primary this year.

title: Clean Air, Low Priority
description: After all She laborious effort that has gone into amending the Clean Air Act of 1970, there is an acute danger that heavy pressures from both the automobile industry and the utilities, coupled with remarkably inept scheduling, will scuttle the entire legislation.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: List of Victims
description: Long Island detectives list among socalled dinner burglaries the following cases with victims and estimated losses:

title: JOSEPH C. BERKWIT SR.
description: Joseph C. Berkwit Sr., who retired three years ago as a maritime executive, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a short illness. Mr. Berkwit, who had residences at 799 Park Avenue and in Hollywood, Fla., was 79 years old.

title: TV: British Fare on WOR Ranges From Giddiness to Pertinence
description: Thames on 9 is turning out to be the most intriguing television project of the year, While WOR/Channel 9 provides Thames Television with a MondaythroughFriday showcase for its better productions, the New York metropolitan area is being afforded an invaluable glimpse of what can be found in Britain, at least occasionally, on the single commercial channel that competes with the British Broadcasting Corporation.

title: Senate Vote Blocks A Rise for Congress In CostofLiving Pay
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7The Senate blocked today a scheduled costofliving pay increase for members of Congress bit agreed to allow the raise for Federal judges and toplevel officials of the executive branch.

title: Finley Hearing Put Off
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP)A hearing on suit filed by Charles O. Finley, the Oakland A's owner, to overturn an order by the baseball commissioner, Bowie Kuhn, preventing the sale of Joe Rudi, Rollie Fingers and Vida Blue was postponed today until Nov. 8. The action in the United States District Court means the three stars will remain with Oakland for the rest of the season. They will become free agents at the close of the season

title: Nominee Vows to Urge Industries Not to Move Out of New York City
description: Jimmy Carter said yesterday that, if he is elected President, he would try to persuade business and industrial leaders not to move their headquarters from New York, thus arresting a deteriorating economic situation that he said is feeding on itself.

title: MILTON W. WILLENSON, 60, FOUNDED A PHOTO SCHOOL
description: Dr. Milton W. Willenson, owner of the Germain School of Photography, died Sept. 1 at his office in Manhattan following a heart attack. He was 60 years old.

title: GOV. MANDEL AND 4 GO ON TRIAL TODAY
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 7Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland and four of the five friends and associates indicted with him 10 months ago on Federal charges of mail fraud and bribery come to trial here tomorrow.

title: Amin Is Said to Have Set An Operation of Revenge Against Neighboring Kenya
description: PARIS, Sept. 7Intelligence information reaching Paris today said that President Idi Amin of Uganda has planned a revenge operation against Kenya.

title: Italy, Amid Outcry, Banishes 2 Accused Men to Island
description: ROME, Sept. 7  Two neoFascists charged with bombing a Milan bank seven years ago were sent today to forced residence on a tiny island off the Tuscan coast after having been released from jail last week. Sixteen people died in the bombing.

title: Yanks Beat Red Sox, Tiant, 42
description: The Boston Red Sox made their final Yankee Stadium appearance of the year last night, and not even old Luis Tiant could reverse the fortunes of baseball war that one summer had brought.

title: Brazilian Squatters' Inroads in Amazon Provoke Indians
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 3A new conflict between Brazilian Indians and whites in which two settlers have been killed has been provoked in the Amazon in re cent weeks as 5,000 poor white squatters have invaded land set aside for the Surui tribe.

title: United Airlines Took Million Overbookings in Year
description: Air travelers have long been simultaneously irritated and mystified by the airlines' apparent practice of overselling flights on the theory that many people with reservations do not show up. United Airlines may riot have soothed its bumped passengers, but it has recently enlightened them.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Mets' 16Hit Attack Routs Cubs, 110
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 7Jon Matlack suggested today that all the Met pitching staff needs to win any particular game is to be supported by a hallway decent defense and four runs.

title: A Mechanic Bests Lumberjacks
description: SCHAGHTICOKE, N.Y., Sept. 7A 35yearold diesel mechanic, equipped with an ax and a soupedup chain saw, became New York State's champion lumberjack here yesterday.

title: The New Cadets
description: And nosy for the good news from West Point.

title: The Presidential Debates and Network Frustrations
description: Although the commercial networks have sought televised debates between the major candidates for every Presidential election since that of 1960, their purposes have been more frustrated than fulfilled by the agreement between President Ford and Jimmy Carter to meet in a series of televised debates this fall under the sponsorship of the League of Women Voters. Indeed these debates, because of the legal means by which they have been arranged, represent a severe setback for the broadcast industry in its 17year drive for repeal of Section 315 of the Communications Act, which contains the socalled equaltime rule. Broadcasters have maintained that this rule which requires television and radio to grant all legally qualified candidates for an office equal access to the air  hampers their ability to cover politics.

title: HurricaneRuined BeachBuilder May Get New Chance
description: LONG BRANCH, Sept. 7For a week, despite a major break in its midsection, a concrete sandgrabber was overcoming beach erosion by building up sand on a test beach at Matilda Terrace.

title: Joblessness vs. Inflation
description: What is the major campaign issueunemployment, inflation, or both?

title: Transport Authority Votes Offer to Rock Island Lines
description: CHICAGO, Sept: 7 (UPI)The Regional Transportation Authority board today voted to offer $7.5 million to the bankrupt Rock Island Lines in a purchaseofservice agreement.

title: Kissinger Is Back in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7Secretary of State Kissinger returned to Washington tonight from his negotiations in Europe on the future of southern Africa.

title: Article 5  No Title
The U.N. Today
AFRICAN TALKS CLOSE WITHOUT ENDING RIFT OF BLACK RHODESIANS
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sept. 7The Presidents of five black African countries ended two days of talks here today without achieving their objective, of reconciling the feuding factions of Rhodesia's black nationalist movement.

title: Music: Debut
description: Calvin Simmons, a black conductor associated with the Los Angeles Philharmonic, made his New York debut Sunday night with the American Symphony in Lincoln Center's Damrosch Park. Very lanky, very spry, he is only 25 years old, and looks it. But he led the orchestra with plenty of confidence and authority.

title: Major League Scores
description: ST. LOUIS (N.)

title: Experts Ponder Economic Trends In Europe as the Recovery Falters
description: PARIS, Sept. 7western Europe's recovery from its most devastating postwar economic recession has slowed, and experts here are unsure whether the economy has merely entered a pauseas the current softening in the United States is being characterizedor whether the problem is more severe.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: New Bond Issues
description: UTILITY BONDS

title: William J. Foote, Retired Editor Of Hartford Courant, Dead at 71
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn. Sept. 7 (AP) William J. Foote, former managing editor and editorial page editor of The Hartford Courant, died of cancer yesterday. He was 71 years old.

title: LANDING OF CONCORDE IN NEW YORK IS SEEN WITHIN 2 OR 3 MONTHS
description: FARNBOROUGH, England, Sept. 7 Approval for the Concorde supersonic airliner to land in New York is likely in the next two or three months, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration said here today.

title: 2 Cape Town Protesters Killed As Paramilitary Police Open Fire
description: CAPE TOWN, Sept. 7 (Reuters)At least two people were shot to death and scores were wounded here today when paramilitary policemen clashed with rioters in a fresh outbreak of racial violence, the police reported.

title: New York State and Israeli School Join to Train Americans as Doctors
description: TEL AVIV, Sept 7New Yorkers crowded out of congested medical schools at home will be helped to become physicians by the State of New York in a fouryear study program at Tel Aviv University.

title: House Unit Charges Commerce Officials Aided Arab Boycott
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7A House subcommittee accused the Commerce Department today of fostering compliance of American business concerns with the Arab boycott of companies involved with Israel.

title: Around the Nation.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP)John D. Ehrlichman, once the chief adviser on domestic affairs to President Nixon, was ordered today to begin serving a 20month prison sentence on Sept. 17 for his role in breakins carried out by the socalled White House plumbers.

title: G.E.TO PAY 3 MILLI0N FOR DUMPING PCB'S INTO UPPER HUDSON
description: General Electric, in a negotiated settle ment with the Department of Environmental Conservation, has agreed to pay $3 million toward cleansing the Hudson River of highly toxic PCB's that it dumped there. The company has also agreed to pay $1 minion for research on ending the problem.

title: NL Industries Plans Merger With Rucker Co.
description: NL Industries Inc. and the Rucker Company of Oakland, Calif., agreed to merge in an exchange of stock amounting to between $164 million and $165 million. Discussions between the two companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange were held from Friday until Monday in California, with final approval voted by both boards of directors.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHAT REALLY HAPPENED TO THE CLASS OF '65. By Michael Medved and David Wallechinshy. 285 pages. Illustrated. Random House. $10.

title: Old Baez Image Is Slow to Fade
description: Joan Baez has cut her long black hair. She is 35 years old now, and she likes to wear good shoes. But an image lingers of Joan Baez at 18, singing All My Trials at the 1959 Newport Folk Festival, with her long hair streaming down her back, or Joan Baez at 21 embracing a guitar on the cover of Time magazine, or Joan Baez the queen of folk musicat a time when that was the music to be queen of singing barefoot on a California mountaintop.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: An elderly welldressed woman who was found wandering the New York City's streets two weeks ago by the police is at St. Clare's Hospital, trying to remember her name and where she came from, according to the police. When found lying in front of a Chock Full o'Nuts restaurant at 39th

title: Transkei, as It Prepares for Independenco, Finds Itself to Be Outcast Among Nations
description: UMTATA, South Africa, Sept. 6When the bullcrested banner of the Transkei is raised here on Oct. 26, signifying the independence of Africa's newest country, the band will strike up Nkosi Sikelel i Afrika, or God Bless Africa. But Africa, and most of the world, will be looking the other way.

title: Military Windfall for West
description: The United States and allied intelligence services regard expected access to the MIG25 that a Soviet pilot flew to northern Japan on Monday as the most important EastWest coup since the Russians shot down an American U2 spy plane 16 years ago. Since then, the Israeli successes in the 1967 and 1973 wars with the Arabs have yielded a harvest of Soviet weapons, including the two main surfacetoair missile systems, the SAM2 and the SAM3, and the Soviet T62 tank.

title: S.E.C. Suit Charges Investment Adviser Did Not Warn of Risk in the Mexican Peso
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that an investment adviser had failed to disclose the possible risk of devaluation of the Mexican peso in inducing thousands of Americans to invest in highyielding peso notes offered by the Mexican equivalent of savings and loan associations.

title: Commercial Overshadows Senate Race
description: Controversy over 30 seconds of radio time continued to overshadow an entire day of campaigning by the five Democratic candidates for the United States Senate from New York yesterday.

title: 5 LAWYERS INDICTED IN SELLING OF BABIES
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 7A Bergen County grand jury indicted lawyers in New York, Illinois and Michigan today on charges of conspiring with a New Jersey lawyer to sell babies for as much as $8,000 to childless New Jersey couples.

title: Advertising
description: The most ambitious invasion of American television to date began Labor Day and will end at about 3 o'clock Saturday morning.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 8, 1976

title: Carter Would Have Ousted Kelley, But Won't Say He Will if President
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7Jimmy. Carter said today that, unlike President Ford, he would have dismissed Clarence M. Kelley, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, for accepting gifts and personal services from members of his staff.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: RESULTS

title: Companies Post Earnings Results
description: COMPANY REPORTS

title: Article 6  No Title
Wealthy Families Fall Victim To Thief Who Arrives at Dinner
description: WOODBURY, L.I.Just as the etiquette books would recommend, the uninvited guest did not disturb the dozen dinner guests at a Long Island estate recently. Rather, he unobtrusively helped himself to whatever he could find in the bedroom, then slipped away into the thick woods, without a guest spilling a drop of soup in terror. This is how one commits a burglary in the better circles.

title: The Presidential Debates and Network Frustrations
description: Although the commercial networks have sought televised debates between the major candidates for every Presidential election since that of 1960, their purposes have been more frustrated than fulfilled by the agreement between President Ford and Jimmy Carter to meet in a series of televised debates this fall under the sponsorship of the League of Women Voters. Indeed these debates, because of the legal means by which they have been arranged, represent a severe setback for the broadcast industry in its 17year drive for repeal of Section 315 of the Communications Act, which contains the socalled equaltime rule. Broadcasters have maintained that this rule which requires television and radio to grant all legally qualified candidates for an office equal access to the airhampers their ability to cover politics.

title: Deaths
description: BAGGERMrs. Agnes (nee Yorgensen), on Sept. 6, 1976, of 636 Wslip Ave., Westfield, N.J.. age 83. Wife of the late William R. Bagger, mother of Donald H. Bagger, N. Bruce Bagger and Mrs. James A. Marsh, grandmother of nine. Memorial services will be held Friday, 4 P.M., at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Westfield, N.J. Interment private. In lieu of flowers kindly make contributions to your favorite charity.

title: Capitalism's Fate
description: Capitalism is stumbling toward its end, which will come, not with a bang but with a whimper.

title: Kissinger, His Power Ebbing, Pursues an African Solution
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Sept. 7Henry A. Kissinger was asked the other day aboard his Air Force jet whether time was not running out on his. Afri can peacemaking mission. The questioner had in mind the American election and the good chance that no matter who wins in November, there will be a new Secretary of State.

title: Today's PairingS
description: STADIUM

title: SELIGMAN & LATZ TO DROP AMEX LISTING ON SEPT. 15
description: Seligman & Latz Inc., a New Yorkbased operator of a chain of beauty salons, said yesterday that it would drop its American Stock Exchange listing on Sept. 15 when its New York Stock Exchange listing begins.

title: STEEL OUTPUT OFF 0.6% FROM WEEKAGO LEVEL
description: Steel production for the week ended Sept. 4 fell to its lowest level since the week ended last Feb. 28, when 2.46 million tons of raw steel were poured and the production capability level stood at. 82.3 percent.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York State's highest court was asked yesterday to declare unconstitutional New York City's 10monthold moratorium on payments of shortterm notes worth $1.6 billion. In arguments before the Court of Appeals in Albany, an attorney for the Flushing National Bank said the measure not only violated state and Federal Constitutions, but also caused hardships for thousands of noteholders.

title: La Scala Offers a Controversial Macbeth
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7How embarrassing. Before a distinguished audience of diplomats, legislators, musicians, critics (some 60 are in Washington for the Music Critics Association meeting) and other wellwishers, American technology failed. The United States debut of the Teatro alla Scala from Milan was delayed tonight almost an hour when the orchestra pit refused to be a pit. It was in the raised position and decided not to descend. Finally it did, as the Kennedy Center stage crew cranked it down by hand, inch by perspiring inch.

title: Wealthy Families Fall Victim To Thief Who Arrives at Dinner
description: WOODBURY, L.I.Just as the etiquette books would recommend, the uninvited guest did not disturb the dozen dinner guests at a Long Island estate recently. Rather, he unobtrusively helped himself to whatever he could find in the bedroom, then slipped away into the thick woods, without a guest spilling a drop of soup in terror. This is how one commits a burglary in the better circles.

title: For the Members, Their Club's Routine Falls Apart During Open at Forest Hills
description: Deep in the belly of the clubhouse at the West Side Tennis Club, in an underground office paneled with wood and tiled with linoleum the color of fresh green beans, the busiest man in the borough of Queens is chain smoking and answering the telephone. His office most closely resembles those of insurance salesmen who rent business space near railroad stations.

title: CORSICAN MILITANTS BLOW UP FRENCH JET
description: AJACCIO, Corsica, Sept. 7 (Reuters)Corsican militants favoring home rule today blew up an Air France airliner parked at Ajaccio airport, police sources sold.

title: Soviet Six Sinks Finland, 113
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 7 (AP)Viktor Zhluktov scored four goals and Vladimir Vlikulov and Alexander Maltsev tallied twice apiece tonight as the Soviet Union routed Finland, 113, in a Canada Cup hockey game, Zhluktov scored twice in each of the first two periods as the Soviet six sent the Finne to their third lopsided loss of the tournament, The Finns were crushed, 112 Team Canada in their opener and downed 80, by Czechoslovakia Sunday night.

title: Mr. Flip And Mr. Flop
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7President Ford and Governor Carter are now charging one another with flipflopping on the Presidential campaign issues, but the voters should not be deceived. For this is obviously a contest between Mr. Flip and Mr. Flop.

title: Memorial Services
description: McALLISTERBreck Parkman Legal scholar, died on August 4. 1976, survived by his widow, the former Charlotte Laura Heussy, a daughter Mrs. Peter Ketchum, and two grandsons. Contributions would be appreciated to the American Diabetes. Assoc. or to the Univ. of Calif. Law School. A memorial service will be held at 11:00 A.M. on Friday, Sept. 10 at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Ave.

title: Ford Campaigns From White House by Signing Bills
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7  President Ford, establishing a pattern for a back porch campaign, used the White House today as a setting to demand an accounting of Americans still missing in Vietnam, for the most part, in the White House to display compassion for flood victims and to further his thesis that vetoes are a vital tool of government.

title: Suffolk Accuses Chief of Aviation In Landing Case
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 7The Suffolk County Commissioner of Aviation was indicted today for turning off the instrument landing system at Suffolk Airport as a plane was approaching in a thick fog. The action was reportedly taken to keep a principal in a hotel purchase, who was in the plane, from consummating the deal.

title: Little Rock School Now Integration Model
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 4In the late 1950's, Central High School became the world's most notorious public school. Segregationists pointed daily to the strife there to prove that white and black students in the South could not go to school together in peace.

title: Article 1  No Title
Stock Average Rises 7.48 Points; Rucker Up 6 as Kodak Gains 2
description: The stock market, after some early hesitation, closed higher yesterday, aided by strength in bluechip, gold and electronic issues.

title: Unveiling
description: SCHWIMMERFlorence. Sunday, Sept. 12, 1976, at 3 P.M., New Monteflora Cemetery, Southern State Parkway, Exit 35, Wellwood Ave., Pinelawn, Section 4, Block 17.

title: Meadowlands Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: . . . and Campuses
description: The by now almost chronic warnings about the fiscal crisis of the nation's colleges and universities are not phony cries of wolf; they point to an alltooreal wolf closing in on the campuses, while the public fails to heed the warnings.

title: Canada Will Relax Curbs on Earnings To Spur Investing
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 7  Finance Minister Donald S. MacDonald announced today that limits on company profits, enforced under the Government's antiinflation program, would be relaxed slightly to encourage lagging investments.

title: Giants Laughing Again; End of Cuts Quells Fear
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 7There was laughter again today in the Giants' locker room.

title: Military Windfall for West
description: The United States and allied intelligence services regard expected access to the MIG25 that a Soviet pilot flew to northern Japan on Monday as the most important EastWest coup since the Russians shot down an American U2 spy plane 16 years ago. Since then, the Israeli successes in the, 1967 and 1973 wars with the Arabs have yielded a harvest of Soviet weapons, including the two main surfacetoair missile systems, the SAM2 and the SAM3, and the Soviet T62 tank.

title: Notes on People
description: Former Representative Wayne L. Hays, 65 years old, was admitted at the Barnesville, Ohio Medical Center in very good condition yesterday after the pickup truck he was driving Collided with another truck near Wheeling W. Va. Mr. Hays, who recently resigned from Congress over a sex and payroll scandal, suffered rib bruises, according to his personal physician, Dr. Richard Phillips. Ohio County sheriff's deputies said no citations were issued in the accident, which took place on W. Va. 88 about 30 miles from the Hays home.

title: MARION S. VESTAL
description: LANSING, Sept. 7 (UPI)Marion S. Vestal, a veteran political reporter for the Booth Newspapers and biographer of President Ford, died yesterday at a Lansing hospital after an extended illness. He was 56 years old. Mr. Vestal, who covered the Michigan capital for 10 years, was eulogized by Gov. William G. Milliken as one of the more perceptive, alert and discerning members of the press corps.

title: Fishermen Ignoring Perils Of Infected Upstate Salmon
description: PULASKI, N.Y.Thousands of salmon many of them believed to be seriously contaminated by Mirex, PCB's and other toxic chemical compounds have begun to leave Lake Ontario to begin their annual spawning run in the rivers and streams that flow into the lake.

title: Carter Would Have Ousted Kelley, But Won't Say He Will if President
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7Jimmy Carter said today that, unlike President Ford, he would have dismissed Clarence M. Kelley, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, for accepting gifts and personal services from members of his staff.

title: ISRAELIS BAR WORK BY A U.S. OIL SHIP
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 7An American oildrilling vessel under contract to Egypt has been stopped twice by Israeli gunboats since Saturday from prospecting in the Gulf of Suez.

title: 4 Killed in L.I..Crash Identified As Port Authority Aides, Wives
description: The four persons who were killed Tuesday afternoon in the crash of a singleengine plane less than half a mile from Zahn's Airport in North Amityville, L.I., were identified yesterday as two coworkers for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and their wives.

title: Yankee Box Score
description: DPYankees 3. LOBBoston 5, Yankees 4, 38Chambliss. HRGamble (15), Fisk (14), Yastrzemski (19).

title: Miss Holtzman Charges That Collusion Is Indicated In Summer Food Program
description: Representative Elizabeth Holtzman, Democrat of Brooklyn, said yesterday that affiliates of ,a major association of New York City summer food sponsors were operating $7.6 million worth of programs in four other cities, and charged that their contracts in those cities indicated collusion with two New York City caterers.

title: Partition at Panmunjom
description: Partitioning of a territory is not an ideal solution to a problem of recurring violence but it is sometimes the least unsatisfactory way out of a chronically dangerous situation. So it should be with the new agreement for partitioning the joint security area at Panmunjom between the forces of North Korea and those of the Americanled United Nations Command.

title: Kissinger Expected to Fly to Africa Next Week to Renew Negotiations
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Sept. 7Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger is expected to fly to southern Africa next week to resume attempts to negotiate solutions to the whiteblack conflicts in Rhodesia and SouthWest Africa.

title: Milan's La Scala Makes U.S. Debut
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7Milan's re nowned La Scala Opera made its historic debut in America here tonight before an audience that was both glittering and demanding.

title: WARNER SIGNS PACT TO PURCHASE ATARI
description: Warner Communications signed a contract yesterday to acquire the privately owned Atari Inc. for cash and debentures. The total purchase price is approximately $28 million, according to Warner. Atari is a technological company that applies advanced semiconductor technology to consumer products. The company has invented an electronic paddle ball game and also produces coinoperated video games.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CAMERA MAN Some photographers would be famous if they only survived six plane crashes, a battlefield explosion and a beating by six men during a demonstration. But W. Eugene Smith, now in his late 50's, and who has been through all that, is famous because of the photographs he made in 19 years at Life magazine and since.

title: Letter's to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: DAM BREAKS IN PAKISTAN, FLOODING 5,000MILE AREA
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 7 (UPI) Flood waters broke through a 442foothigh dam and inundated more than 5,000 square miles of Baluchistan Province, the Government said today. Entire villages were washed away, officials said.

title: George Harrison Guilty of Plagiarizing, Subconsciously, a '62 Tune for a '70 Hit
description: George Harrison, the former Beatle, was found guilty yesterday of subconsciously plagiarizing the 1962 John Mack tune He's So Fine for Mr. Harrison's 1970 hit record, My Sweet Lord.

title: The Cast
description: MACBETH, opera in four acts by Giuseppe Verdi; text by Francesco Maria Piave otter the play by William Shakespeare. Conducted by Claudio Abbado; staged by Giorgio Strehler; designed by Luciano Damiani. Presented by La Scala of Milan at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Last Log Drive in U.S. Floating to End in Maine
description: SKOWHEGAN, Me.The last log drive in America is floating to an end on the Kennebec River.

title: Events Today
description: Film

title: Article 2  No Title
description: held everyone spellbound. Meanwhile, under their very feet, a great performance went unnoticed.

title: Instant Lotteries Prove to Be Popular, With 12 States Besides New York Operiting or Organizing Them
description: Instant lotteries, such as the offer for immediate payoffs in the gambling game on which New York State starts selling tickets today, have met with success and popularity, according to reports from other states.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article in The Times on Saturday, the chef at the Hammond Museum, Lynne Bierer, was inadvertently referred to as he.

title: British Union Leaders Are Heckled on Unemployment
description: BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 7Some of the most powerful union leaders in Britain were jeered and heckled here today by demonstrators protesting the country's rising unemployment rate and what they regard as the labor movement's failure to demand stronger action from the Government.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing
