title: Screen: Monument From Japan
description: MASAKI KOBAYASHI, the Japanese director, makes long, movies. "The Human Condition," his adaptation of the six-volume antiwar novel by Jumpei Gomikawa, ran nine hours in three three-hour segments. It was not the sort of film that would have been easily enoured by the late Harry Cohn, the movie mogul, who, when asked how he could tell whether a movie was good or bad, said, though more bluntly, "My backside tells me." Mr. Kobayashi's best film, "Harakiri," ran a mere two hours and 10 minutes. His new (1974) film, 'Kaseki" (Fossil), now at the New Yorker, runs close to three hours and is mostly about a man who is dying of cancer.I say that quickly because, although I think "Kaseki" is a monumental film, not everyone wants to see a monument, and even those who do might want to prepare themselves for the experience. Mr. Kobayashi's method is conventional enough at first. He photographs everything more or less straight on. There are no ornamental dissolves, just plain, clean cuts from one scene to another, and such very conventional devices as shots of airplanes (Pan Am) taking off and landing to let us know that someone who planned a trip has actually made it.The method seems conventional, but it isn't at all. Mr. Kobayashi has made "Kaseki" the way a novelist writes. He supplies detail upon detail  sometimes visually, sometimes in dialogue, sometimes through the voice of an omniscient narrator  to such an extent that he finally pierces the surface of things that no ordinary, conventionally employed camera ever does. This takes time. To appreciate "Kaseki" you must be ready to pay attention to a director who doesn't bother to smile and say "please." There's no attempt to beguile."Kaseki" is the story of Itsuki (Shin Saburi), a self-assured, self-made construction-industry tycoon, a widower with two married daughters and self-interested enough to tell his pregnant daughter that she must have a boy. "Your sister has a daughter so I would like to have a son." Itsuki runs a benign autocracy.As postwar Japan has flourished, so has he until one afternoon, while on a business-pleasure trip in Paris, he feels the first pangs of trouble. When he learns the truth, that he has an inoperable cancer of the stomach, Itsuki locks himself in his hotel room. He considers suicide, but that's not his style. He drinks too much. He pats the place where the pain is as if to soothe the crab within, the cancer that is eating him aiive."Kaseki" is an almost clinical, hour-by-hour report by a man reassessing his life. On a trip through Burgundy with a young Japanese couple and a beautiful, thirtyish Japanese woman, the wife of a wealthy Frenchman and someone whom Itsuki has come to associate with death, the materialist begins to see a world quite different from any he's known before. He becomes aware of a sense of serenity while walking through an ancient cathedral that has provided continuity for generations.Back in Tokyo he goes about putting his business affairs in order, attempts to re-establish ties with his elderly, addled stepmother, whom he once hated, and has a reunion with an old Army comrade with whom he served in China. Itsuki, who has envied French resistance fighters for being able to die in a just cause, remembers his own service with bitterness. He agrees with the old comrade who say that ever since their war they both have lived on borrowed time.As played by Shin Saburi, Itsuki initially seems impassive, then a man of such immense, painful sensitivity that when fate changes course and provides a dnouement somewhat different from the one we've expected, what would be a happy ending in any other film isn't. Mr. Kobayashi isn't interested in such distinctions.Though "Kaseki" is almost totally humorless, it's not pompous. It is a thoughtful, contemplative film, composed of sometimes beautiful, sometimes banal, sometimes picture-postcard-pretty images that ultimately reveal the profound desolation of one rather ordinary fellow. Itsuki, I suspect, may also be Mr. Kobayashi's image of the Japan of Sony, Toyota, Asahi Pentaxes and those Japanese rice crackers now being exported to the cheese dips of the world.

title: 5 Hurt in Chinatown Gang Fight; FlareUp Follows Month's Truce
description: A flareup between two rival youth gangs in Chinatown late Wednesday night left five young people injured and gave police in the area reason to fear retaliations and a new wave of street fighting after a onemonth respite.

title: The Mustsas Cartier Sees Them
description: To collectors of status symbols. owning a Cartier Santos watchor its later variation, the tank watchis a must. Louis Cartier first made the watch in Paris in 1907 and named it for a French aviator, Santos Dumont. It started a fad for wristwatches among the international smart set and continues to be a way an in person recognizes a brother in taste.

title: McCarthy's Impact On Vote for Carter Feared by Strauss
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Robert S. Strauss, the Democratic national chairman, conceded today that the independent Presidential candidacy of Eugene J. McCarthy was causing some concern for his party's national ticket by its current strength in the polls.

description: Senator Robert J. Dole, the Republican Vice Presidential nominee, said last night that the Ford Administration will never jeopardize the security of Israel in the search for peace, nor will it retreat one inch from its commitment to the security of Israel.

title: Nixon Terms Mao Unique
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Sept. 9 (Reuters)  Former President Richard M. Nixon described Mao. Tsetung today as a unique man in a generation, of great revolutionary leaders and said he was confident that dtente between the United States and China would continue under Mao's successor.

description: THE FIRST MAJOR institutional show of the fall season is Shinto Arts at the Japan House Gallery, 333 East 47th Street. None of the objects on view there have been seen in this country before, and many are virtually invisible in Japan itself. They belong to the innermost sanctum of the Shinto shrine; to that sanctum neither the parishoner nor even the most qualified and dedicated SchOlar can normally hone to penetrate.

Hoffmann once again pledged here today to investigate any new reports of Honor Code violations by West Point cadets, and he urged lawyers representing students accused of cheating at the United States military Academy to give the Army such reports without condition.

title: The Pop Life
description: Doily Parton's latest album might have been expected to vary the pattern of most of her records up to now. Regarded by many observers as the most original and evocative songwriter and singer in country music, she has received increasingly adulatory critical notices in the last year. Now, with a new syndicated weekly television show, beginning locally tomorrow night at 11 on Channel 5, she might have made a firm move in the direction of general pop accessibility.

title: Weekend Gardening
description: The muchpublicized canning lid shortage last year produced an unexpected bonus for the larder, when many gardeners rediscovered drying as a means of storing their superabundant crops. Of all the methods of preserving food, drying is probably the oldest, and although it was more or less relegated to the back shelf by canning and the more recent convenience of freezing, there are still several advantages to this means of stocking the larder. High on the list are simplicity and low cost. Add to these the fact that the method is virtually foolproof, and there is more than enough justfication to give drying a try this year.

title: Congress Votes Put Budget Ceiling Near $413 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9  Congress, nearing the end of the critical phase of its budgetmaking process, voted today to limit Federal spending to about $413 billion, some $13 billion more than President Ford has projected, in the fiscal year starting Oct. 1.

title: Mao Tsetung
description: Mao Tsetung's place in history is assured. When the saga of our times is written, he will be one of the towering figures of this violent, revolutionary century.

title: EXTRA IMPORTS OF FOOD NEEDED BY THE E.E.C.
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 9 (Reuters)The European Economic Community will have to import extra food and animal fodder this year to make up losses from EUrope's worst drought in decades, E.E.C. Farm Commissioner Pierre Lardinois warned today.

title: Youths Hoping A Big Brother Wili Volunteer
description: MADISON, Sept. 9Saturday may be Ralph's big day. The I2yearold has a gnawing ambitionto find a friend,; not just any friend, but some one who_ would care about and be sensitive to his needs.

title: Bob Smith Ties Watson, Burns For Lead at 65
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Sept. 9 (AP)Bob Smith, often a challenger but not yet a winner on the pro tour, oneputted 12 times on his way to a sixunderpar 65 today that tied him with Tom Watson and George Burns for the firstround lead in the $200,000 World open Rolf tournament.

title: Steve Cady
description: In rapidfire order, the player wearing the purple jersey designating Post Position 8 mowed down the opposition.

title: KISSINGER IS CAUTIOUS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that he did not think Mao Tsetung's death would set back ChineseAmerican relations, but he cautioned that when any historical figure disappears it is extremely difficult to predict everything his successor will do.

title: An OldFashioned Circus Pitches Big Top in the Big Town
description: An oldfashioned tented circusthe kind boys used to dream of running off with, the kind not seen in New York in 40 yearsis coming to town this weekend. Bears and elephants, trapeze artists and jugglers, clowns and Ere eaters will be entertaining children of all ages, starting tomorrow afternoon, when the traveling show pitches its canvas big top in an empty lot on Second Avenue and 100th Street.

title: A Mural Effect for HomesAnd Not a Mural in Sight
description: A check of the linen and bedspread departments in stores this fall will find murals popular as design themes. Inspired by antique patchwork and appliqued quilts, designers have picked up the charm and pictorial whimsy of the 100yearold quilts and adapted them to new designs for pillows, bedspreads, comforters, wall hangings and even shower curtains.

title: Soviet Pilot Who Defected on MIG Flown to U.S For Political Asylum
description: TOKYO, Sept. 9The Soviet Air Force officer who landed a MIG25 jetfiehter in Japan flew today aboard a commercial airliner to the United States. where he has been offered political asylum.

title: Even Poets Don't Last Forever
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9In early 1975, when Mao Tsetung was already drifting into the shadows of his final Long March, he wrote a poem to his political and military comrade, Prime Minister Chou Enlai:

title: MAO TSETUNG: FATHER OF CHINESE REVOLUTION
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 9Map Tsetung, who began as an obscure peasant, died one of history's great revolutionary figures.

title: Music: Israeli Zeal and Warmth
description: THE Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, which was last here in 1974, is back for another American tour, and it played the first of two Carnegie Hall concerts on Wednesday night, under the direction of Zubin Mehta, its music adviser and conductor and the music directorelect of the New York Philharmonic.

title: Art People
description: FRAMING a work of art these days is sometimes more expensive than buying it. And that's whyto the deep regret of artists and collectorsone of the city's bestknown custom framemakers, Kulicke Frames Inc. at 43 East 78th Street, has just gone out of business.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Classes for 47,000 public school children were disrupted for a second day yesterday as striking teachers in Jersey City and Bayonne ignored a judge's back  to  work order. Spokesmen for both school systems said only a token force of teachers reported to classes and a majority of the students stayed away. Jersey City officials urged parents to keep their children home. Bay

title: Chinatown Reacts to the Death of Mao With Intense but MixedEmotions
description: Three decades and half a world away from the China he left in 1941, FaiChing, a chef in a Chinese restaurant, sat, stunned, in a dimly lit Chinatown bookshop yesterday and spoke of the death of Chairman Mao Tsetung.

title: State Court Rules Badillo Cannot Run as Republican In the November Election
description: Representative Herman Badirlo, who is fighting Councilman Ramon S. Velez for the Democratic nomination for the 21st Congressional District seat in the South Bronx, has been removed from the Republican line on the ballot in the general election because of gross irregularities and fraudulent practices.

title: Yankees
Antiques
description: MOST OF THE BIGGEST merchants in the tiniest antiques will be on hand Sunday for this town's most important show of miniatures, dollhouses, toys and such. The exhibition and sale, now in its fourth year and enlarged, benefits the Hudson Guild Counseling Service, a mental health clinic of the Chelsea Settlement House. The admission charge of $2 is turned over to this charity.

title: When a Wedding Is Canceled...
description: Thelma Golden was to have been married last month. Several hundred engraved Cartier invitations had been sent out, her dress had been custom made, the flowers were ordered and a prestigious midtown hotel had been booked for the reception and dinner.

title: Experts Say It Will Take Six Years To Establish Seabed Mining Unit
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 4United States experts in seabed mining estimate it will take five to six years to set up a socalled International Enterprise to undertake profitable extraction of minerals from the ocean floor by 1983 the date on which private companies are expected to be in fullscale commercial operations.

title: Ford Asserts Rival Would Create Peril To Defense of U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9President Ford said today that Jimmy Carter's plans to reduce Pentagon spending and troop levels overseas would make it impossible to have a defense adequate to maintain our freedom and the freedom of our friends.

title: Judge in Connecticut Is Disbarred For Notarizing Forged Signature
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 9The administrative judge of Superior Court in Fairfield County was disbarred as a lawyer and fined $250 today following his conviction on charges of having improperly notarized a signature.

title: 2 UNWANTED ISSUES CONFRONTING FORD
description: Insofar as issues determine how people cast their votes for President, Gerald R. Ford's fate in November may well turn largely on how well he handles two unwanted issues he inherited from his discredited predecessor  the uncertain economy and the Watergate scandal.

title: Regret in Tokyo, Cheers in Taiwan
description: TOKYO, Sept. 9 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Takeo Miki of Japan sent a message of condolence to the Chinese Government on the death of Mao Tsetung, the Foreign Ministry reported.

title: Restaurants
description: ALTHOUGH THE NUMBER of good German restaurants. in New York City has dwindled noticeably in the last 8 or 10 years, there are still a few aboveaverage choices left for lovers of sauerbraten and gemutlichkeit. A personal favorite for a number of years has been the Cafe Geiger, 206 East 86th Street, between Second and Third Avenues, in Yorkville, at first glance a pastrycafe in the true konditorei tradition. But at second glance it is a fullfledged restaurant and a very good one.

title: Sketches of 6 Chinese of Major Influence in Leadership
description: Hua Kuofeng

title: PARENTS /CHILDREN
description: You don't have to ponder it very long to begin to suspect that too many children are being labeled learning disabled these days. One widely heard estimate is that 10 to 20 percent 01 the nation's children suffer from such learning disabilities as subtle perception disorders and hyperactivity.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 9 (UPI)Eastman Kodak's topoftheline EK8 instant camera will not be sold in the United States and Canada this year as announced earlier, company officials said today.

title: 2 Young Children Left Alone Perish In a Fire in Bronx
description: Two brothers, 5 and 4 years old, left unattended by their parents were killed last night when fire badly damaged their apartment in arr impoverished neighborhood in the Morrisania section of the Bronx, the Fire Department said.

title: South Africans Divide People Into 4 Groups
description: In South Africa, where every inhabitant is classified by the Government under one of four racial groupings, colored is the official designation for those whose ancestry traces to MINtures of white and Bantu, nr blacx, and whites and Asians or of all three.

title: One Instant Winner of the New Lottery Is New York State
description: The state's new instant lottery had another $1million sales boom on its second; day of operations yesterday as long lines of players queued up at ticket outlets and numerous vendors in the city and upstate sold out their ticket supplies.

title: Stuart D. Shaw Marries Linda Robins, Professor
description: Linda Carol Robins, associate Professor of French at the Bergen Community College in Paramus, N. J., was married last evening to Stuart Darling Shaw, who is on the businessadministration faculty of the college. Rabbi Roy Armand Rosenberg perfomed the ceremony in the chapel of the Crystal Plaza, caterers, in Livingston, N. J.

title: BUCKLEY SAYS CURBS IMPEDE BUSINESSES
description: Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican, called on Congress yesterday to reform the nation's taxing, spending and regulatory policies, which have impeded the ability of the financial community to function efficiently.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey  Cemal Kamaci, Turkey, outpointed Luciano Laffranchi, Italy, 10 rounds, welterweights.

title: Tennis
description: U.S. Open

title: Reserve Reports Money Stipply Dropped for 2d Consecutive Week
description: The nation's money supply declined for the second consecutive week, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday. The narrowly defined money supplydemand deposits and currency, and known as M1declined $300 million in the week ended Sept. 1, compared with a revised $900million decline the orevimic week

title: Complaint by Bellevue Is Reported On Use of BabyDeath Information
description: Bellevue Hospital has filed a complaint against Dr. Michael M. Baden, deputy chief medical examiner for New York City, for allegedly discussing with his wife confidential information regarding the death of a 5dayold baby earlier this week, according to Madeline Bobman, the hospital's deputy executive director.

title: A brown thrasher carving by Jack and Bette Holt, on view this weekend in Fairfield, Conn.
description: Like John James Audubon, the 20 bird carvers who will be showing their work this weekend at the Connecticut Audubon Society in Fairfield are artists as much as naturalists, They have had to match their craft against the subject's swiftness and its peculiarities: how it holds its head, the angles at which it stands or bends.

title: Advertising
description: Good Housekeeping will raise its newsstand price of 95 cents a copy in October from its present 75 cents buoyed by indications that its circulation revenues in 1976 will exceed advertising revenues for the first time in memory.

title: Poll Shows Ford Trailing in Bid For 2 Voter Groups G.O.P. Needs
description: President Ford is trailing Jimmy Carter among selfdescribed independents and moderates, the two elements of the electorate without whose strong support Republican nominees have been unable to win Presidential elections in the postWorld War II era.

title: KISSINGER IS CAUTIOUS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that he did not think Mao Tsetung's death would set back ChineseAmerican relations, but he cautioned that when any historical figure disappears it is extremely difficult to predict everything his successor will do.

title: Knicks Obtain McMillian; Nets Seeking Archibald
description: The Knicks purchased Jim McMillian from the Buffalo Braves yesterday and the Nets were close to a deal for Nate Archibald of the Kansas City Kings.

title: Vast Ocean of Heavy Oil A Challenge for Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 9Lying beneath the broad, and plains that stretch north of the Orinoco River is a vast ocean of petroleumso vast that it may dwarf the reserves of Saudi Arabia, the world's largest exporter of oil.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 10, 1976

title: Political Uncertainty in China
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 9The death today of Chairman Mao Tsetung comes at a time when China's political situation seems more uncertain han at any point since the end of the Cultural Revolution.

title: People and Business
description: JohnsManville Top Officeit Are Realigned by President

title: Eckerd Drugs to Merge With Jack Eckerd Corp.
description: The Jack Eckerd Corporation or LIMwater, Fla., and Eckerd Drugs Inc. of Charlotte, N. C., have agreed in principle to a merger in an exchange of stock valued at $112 million. Both companies were founded by members of the Eckerd family and are outgrowths of the same familyowned drug store operations.

title: A Novel Week At Brentano's
description: It's as if vaudeville had returned for a nostalgic romp. From 2 to 4 on Sunday afternoon, portions of Fifth Avenue will be closed to traffic in front of Brentano's bookstore, and the Amazing Randi and Bill Noble, magicians both, will offer a number of tricks; Denise Carcel and David Makoff, memory experts, will perform marvels of memory; John Towsen, a clown, will provide comic interlude. There will be music by But zmn's Ragtime string quartet; experts will demonstrate how to play backgammon and Conrad Daniels, champion dartthrower, will give a few pointers in that art. There will be demonstrations of pillowmaking, creative handweaving and one illustrating all the wonderful things you can do with paper.

title: Commodity Price Index Rose 1.9 From Last Week's Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 206.8 from 204.9 last week.

title: Task Force Named to Aid WNYC
description: An 11member task force headed by Arthur R. Taylor, the president of CBS, has been named by Mayor Beame to recommend a future course for the cityowned Municipal Broadcasting System, whose budget has been cut by a third in the city's fiscal crisis.

title: Carter Unsure What to Call Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI)Jimmy Carter has said that he is not sure what to call President Ford during the debates. Mr. Ford believes that Mr. President will do nicely. The Democratic Presidential candidate told reporters last week, I don't want to indicate in the heat of the debate any disrespect for the office of the President or any disrespect for the President himself. I think he's a good man and I don't know whether to call him Mr. President or President Ford or, Mr. Ford,

title: View of City With Sound Of Country
description: After 40 years, the Rainbow Grill, which looks longingly westward from its glasslined 65th floor perch on the RCA Building, has finally decided to find out what kind of music is played and sung beyond the Hudson. The room, which normally offers singers and comedians with a distinctly urban orientation, is featuring country music this weekend and for the next two weeks.

title: CHRYSLER IS PLACING STRESS ON COMPACTS AS 77 LINE IS SHOWN
description: DETROIT, Sept. 9 The Chrysler Corporation introduced its 1977 models today with a forecast that compact cars would replace larger, intermediatesized autos as the industry's biggest sellers in the year aheadand that, in addition, consumers by 1980 would perceive the compact car as the standard familysize automobile.

title: 16 REPORTED KILLED AROUND CAPE TOWN
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 9At least 16 people were shot to death by the police today as a ring of nonwhite townships around Cape Town exploded in violent protests against apartheid. It was the worst single day's death toll in years for a protest by colored people, as the Government calls those of mixed racial ancestry.

title: Text of the Announcement Issued by Peking Reporting Death of Chairman Mao
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 9 (Reuters)Following is the text of the announcement on the death of Chairman Mao Tsetung issued by Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency:

title: In Memoriam
Life With Nastase: It's Tempestuous, But Love Shines Through the Tears
description: Just as she was about to marry The Nastase, just before she would say, Oui, Dominique Grazia listened very carefully to the words, pour le meilleur, et le pirefor the best and the worst.

title: Recollections of Talks With Mao in Yenan in 1944
description: BERKELEY, Calif.Mao Tsetung, when I first met him in 1944, was 51 years old. For four months I saw good deal of him, certainly two or three times a week: perhaps 50 occasions in all under all sorts of circumstances, official and relaxedprivate conversations, group discussions, meals, theater and other entertainments, public speeches, and even Saturday night dances during warm summer evenings on the packed earth of orchard.

title: Political Uncertainty in China
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 9The death. today of Chairman Mao Tse tung comes at a time when Chines political situation seems more uncertain than at any point since the end of the Cultural Revolution.

title: Broadway
description: CIRCLE IN THE SQUARE is expanding its downtown self, and returning in a way, the kind of experimentation it was famous for when young. On Oct. 7, the downtown Circle. will present The Club by Eve Merriam, musical that takes place in a men's club at the turn of the century. It will be directed by the dancer and choreographer Tommy Tune. Moreover,. the downtown Circle will also do workshop productions of Sandra Hochman's Walking Papers, which Phyllis Newman will direct, and Richard III, which Arthur Sherman will direct; Ron Leibman will play Richard. Our philosophy is to give creative people a chance to be creative, Ted Mann, the Circle's artistic director, says, adding that henceforth, the downtown Circle will also search out new American plays.

title: Correction Commission Planning Hearings on an Incident at Attica
description: The New York State Commission of Correction will conduct hearings into an incident earlier this year in which eight guards and one inmate were injured at the Attica State Correctional Facility. Stephen J. Chinlund, chairman of the commission. said yesterday.

title: Giants and Jets Are Both Underdogs in Openers Sunday
description: The National Football League's 57th season opens on Sunday with a television treat, the SteelersRaiders game from Oakland on Channel 4 at 4 P.M. These rivals have met in the playoffs the last four seasons with Pittsburgh

title: At the Movies
description: ROBERT, ALTMAN awoke from a weird dream one recent Saturday night, and on the following morning he called Shelley Duvall. He told me the story of the dream, said it was going to be his next film and that he wanted me to be in it, said. Miss Duvall. I was sort ofdazed and didn't quiteknow . what to think. I mean, who ever heard of a director turning his dream into.a movie, except maybe Fellini? But on Tuesday Bob left for New York, and by Friday he had closed; deal to make the movie.

title: Mississippi Blacks Picketing Stores in Suit Over Boycott
description: PORT GIBSON, Miss., Sept. 9We're not getting any colored trade, said George Hudson as he closed up his Piggly Wiggly grocery here one night and began checking the cash register. Normally, blacks account for onehalf of his customers.

title: Article 3  No Title
Borman Son Denies Bribe at West Point
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept. 9Lieut. Frederick P. Borman, a 1974 West Point graduate, categorically denied tonight that he had received $1,200 to change his vote on an honorcode board.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE RUDIMENTS of the story that Richard P. Brickner tells in My Second 20 Years: An Unexpected Life are simple and startling. An automobile accident, on a gorgeous May afternoon shortly after the author's 20th birthday, that left him on the farthest rim of existence, his neck broken, his body paralyzed from the chest down. And the struggle back from the rim to the point where he could function as normal man, albeit confined to wheelchair. It is an inspiring story too, considering that Mr. Brickner was told shortly after the accident that he might as well prepare himself for a profession as a lens grinder, and yet succeeded through determination and cunning in making for himself not only the social life of an exuberant young man about New York City but also a career as a book editor, teacher, essayist, novelist and latelythough not lastthe author of this wholly effective autobiography. (Equally important to himand, by dint of his eloquence, to ushe also overcame who knows what psychological odds eventually to regain his sexual potency.)

title: Creavy, at 78149, Leads Seniors Golf by 2 Shots
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Sept. 9 (AP)Jack Creavy ballooned to six over par today in the second round of the New York State Senior golf championship at the McGregor Country Club, but still managed to hold a twostroke lead. Of the 78 golfers over 55 years of age who were invited to compete in four age divisions, 72 were slated for the final round tomorrow.

title: U.F.T. PAY DEFERRAL IS STILL NOT SETTLED
description: Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, met yesterday with representatives of the city, the teachers and the Board of Education in a new effort to work out a pay deferral agreement acceptable to them and the the Emergency Financial Control Board.

title: Radar Images From Venus Depict Vast Area of Possible Lava Flow
description: American astronomers who have obtained the first detailed radar images of a large portion of the surface of Venus say they reveal a possible lava flow the size of Oklahoma, an impact basin much like those on the moon and evidence of mountainbuilding processes similar to those that have shaped the Earth.

title: Management
description: Although oil, natural gas and coal are the basic fuels used to energize most of the nation's factories and heat and cool commercial buildingsand probably will be for many yearsincreasing attention is being paid to alternate energy sources.

title: Amex Trading Due In Options ofGold And Silver Bullion
description: The American Stock Exchange said yesterday that it was planning to start trading next year in options contracts for gold and silver bullion, subject to Government approval.

title: A's Need 4 Pitchers to Hold White Sox and Gain 21 Victory
description: OAKLAND, Sept. 9 (AP)The Oakland A's needed the efforts of four pitchers today to beat the Chicago White Sox, 21, and keep the pressure on Kansas City in the American League West.

title: Events and. Openings
description: Friday

title: Opera: La Scala's Boheme
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9  La 130heme is arguably Puccini's most successful opera because, more than any other of his works, it retains an innocence of inspiration and of means, mirroring its theme of young love in dramatic structure and musical invention that never seem portentous.

title: Kills Laid to Disturbance
description: HIGHLANDS, Sept. 9The fish kills off New Jersey this summer now are believed to be a result of a massive oceanographic disturbance, marine scientists said today.

title: THREATS FAIL TO END ARGENTINE CAR STRIKE
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 9Militant auto workers remained on strike today for higher pay in defiance of arrests and threats of strong reprisals against organizers of the strike by Argentina's military Government.

title: AGREEMENT REACHED ON TAX REVISION BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9  House and Senate conferees agreed tonight on all provisions of the sweeping tax revision bill after adopting the first major reform of the nation's system of estate taxes in 35 years.

title: Market Place
description: Shares of Cook Industries soared yesterday following the company's announcement on Wednesday that would seek shareholder approval of plan to become a private company.

title: The New York Times
description: Concern over a possible increase in inflation sent stock prices lower yesterday in slower trading, The Dow Jones hide'strial average was off 6.07 points to 986.87, near its low for the session.

title: JOHN R. SCOTFORD, 88; CHURCH
description: The Rev. John R. Scotford, a Congregational minister and an expert on church architecture, died yesterday at his Hamilton, N.Y., home. He was 88 years old.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: Friday

title: Campaign on Swine Flu Virus Recalls the Pandemic of 1918
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9During the last days of August 58 years ago a small flu outbreak was beginning in Boston.

title: Democratic Senate Hopefuls Debate a 2d Day in Row
description: Meeting for their second public debate in two days, four of the five candidates for the New York Democratic Senatorial nomination reiterated wellknown positions on various issues, and then concentrated on sniping at each other.

title: Wreck Is Thought to Be Bonhomme Richard
description: A BritishAmerican expedition believes it has found the wreck of the Bonhomme Richard, flagship of John Paul Jones, in 180 feet of water, where it sank after defeating the more heavily armed British warship Serapis in 1779.

title: Deaths
Stage:Dark Passage
description: THE ingredients are familiar in Steve Gooch's play, Female Transport, which opened at the Performing Garage on Wednesday and will run Thursdays through Sundays until Sept. 26. Familiar, surely, to readers of historical fiction and watchers of costume films on the late show.

title: Panel on Paperwork Assembling A Litany of Constant Redundancy
description: The Commission on Federal Paperwork convened in New York City yesterday to communicate on the feasibility of implementing a restriction in the ongoing paperflow.

title: NEW ISSUES IN BONDS GET GOOD RECEPTION
description: Newissue offerings met with good reception yesterday, while prices of existing creditmarket securities finished virtually unchanged after release of the weekly moneysupply figures by the Federal Reserve. We had a late after

title: Screvane Calls Charge Against OTB Inaccurate
description: The charge that legalized offtrack betting has created 90,000 new customers for illegal bookmakers was denounced yesterday by Paul R. Screvane, OTB chairman and president, as inaccurate, unfair and based on questionable statistics.

title: F.B.I. Data Disclose Gray Was Told About Misdeeds When He Was Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Shortly after becoming acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in 1972, L. Patrick Gray 3d was advised of a number of improprieties and irregularities in the bureau's operations, including the misappropriation of thousands of dollars of public funds by its exhibits section, according to published bureau documents.

title: Belmont Racing
description: 1976, by Triangle Publications, Inc. The Daily Racing Form)

title: Some in Moscow Look to Improvement in Chinese. Ties as Leverage Against US.
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 9The death of Mao Tsetung has raised a possibility for the Soviet Union to relax, but not eliminate, its tensions with China, a development that could ultimately affect Moscow's relationship with Washington, according to some analysts of China here.

title: Colgate Plans to Acquire Marisa Christina Inc.
description: The ColgatePalmolive Company is plkning to add to it leisureentertainment division Marisa Christina Inc., importers and distributors of women's snortswear. mainly sweaters.

title: Moynihan for the Senate
description: The distinguished public servants who seek the Democratic nomination for Senator are treating us to a most undistinguished campaign. Having found few real differences of philosophy or policy, they are asking the voters to choose on the basis of personality, temperament and electabilitv.

title: RADIO
A Lieutenant's Credo
description: Western intelligence experts are understandably elated over the delivery of a Soviet supersonic MIG25 fighter plane, the most advanced of its type, which was landed in Japan by a defecting pilot, Lieut. Viktor I. Belenko. Even more noteworthy than the military's access to this remarkable plane's engines, electronic gear and other equipment, however, may be the lieutenant's credo.

title: Cause of Mao's Death Remains Unresolved
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 9  Today's lengthy death notice on Chairman Mao left a puzzle unresolvedthe cause of his death.

title: Meadowlands Racing
description: FIFTHS9,500, pace, cl., mile.

title: Turn Out for Badillo
description: For six years the 21st Congressional District in the South Bronx has enjoyed the services of a superior Representative. In return there is no reason to doubt that the overwhelmingly Democratic district will reelect Herman Badillo in Novemberif it has the opportunity. But it will not have that opportunity unless voters turn out in large numbers in next week's primary to choose him as the Democratic candidate.

title: Article 2  No Title
SOVIET STATEMENT STIRS BEWILDERMENT IN BEIRUT
description: BEIRUT, Sept. 9Reacting with surprise to Soviet criticism of ultraleftists in Lebanon. the Lebanese alliance of Moslems and leftists sent a delegation to the Soviet Embassy here today to ask if there had been a change of policy.

title: Armenian Church Is Host to a Reunion of the Human Family
description: Chinese, Norwegian. and Mexican dancers, Spanish bagpipers and African drummers, purveyors of Greek, Thai and Japanese food, Roman Catholics, Copts and Orthodox Syrians will gather in all their diversity this weekend to celebrate the unity of the human family at the fourth annual One World Festival sponsored by the Armenian Church of America.

title: Notes on People
description: Susan Ford has moved out of the White House and into an Alexandria, Va., townhouse with three classmates and a Secret Service detachment, which is housed in the basement of the townhouse. The President's I9yearold daughter will share the rent with three other. sophomores from Mt. Vernon Junior College for women, but she still plans to attend the University of Kansas at Topeka in January.

title: BRITISH SEEK BLOCK OF SEAMEN'S STRIKE
description: LONDON, Sept 9The Government and its allies in the labor movement held urgent meetings today in aneffort to avert a strike that could damage Britain's economic strategy and bring acute political embarrassment to Prime Minister JamesCallaghan.

title: Carter Warns That Abortion Issue Might Backfire if Rival Exploits It
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 9Jimmy Carter said today the sensitive abortion issue was a very serious problem for him but that it might backfire on any Presidential candidate who tried to exploit it politically. Presumably, he meant his Republican opponent, President Ford.

title: Criminal Justice Courses Urged By Black Police Officers
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Sept. 9The newly formed National Organization of Black Law Enforcement Executives urged today that all American high schools offer courses in criminal and social justice and that the nation establish equitable and uniform penalties for convicted criminals.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% State tax.)

title: Yankees Down Brewers by 42; Lyle Placated
description: The Yankees took one small step toward harmony and another big step toward the division title last night.

title: The New York Times/Arthur Charles F. Butler, president of Air New England, at Logan International Airport in Boston
description: BOSTONIn 1974, Air New England, a bustling commuter airline serving the hamlets of the Northeast, managed to produce a modest profit of $78,553. Just a year later, despite a $3.2 million transfusion from the Federal Government and healthy revenues of $13.4 million, the line posted a loss of more than a million dollars.

title: Czechoslovaks Beat Team Canada
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 9With patience, stamina and clean play the Czechoslovak national hockey team upset Team Canada tonight, 10, in the Montreal Forum.

title: Edward Verplanck, 86, Surveyor Was Descended From Dutch Settlers
description: Edward Fenno Verplanck, a direct descendant of Abraham Verplanck, one of the original Dutch settlers who came to what is now New York City in 1638, died Wednesday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: Kaufman Asks Code Requiring Lawyers To Volunteer Aid
description: Chief Judge Irving R. Kaufman of the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has proposed that lawyers develop a tradition of tithing, requiring them to provide free legal services to worthy endeavors.

title: Foreign Agencies Ranked Second In Holdings of Federal Securities
description: Foreign institutions, such as central banks or other official financial agencies, have become the second largest holders of United States Government securities, according to a new study prepared by Salomon Brothers.

title: Hospit and Budgets Sent Back
description: Mayor Beame has rejected the most recent budget submissions from the Health and Hospitals Corporation and the Transit Authority as lacking sufficient detail. Both independent agencies were ordered to produce revised financial plans by the middle of next week.

title: Around the Nation

description: President Ford is playing a dangerous and highly political game in his support for a constitutional amendment that would permit the states to ban abortion. His repetition of that support, at a White House news conference left little doubt that he intends to press this issue.

description: BELGRADE, Sept, 9The clerk at a Belgrade department store took the new light bulb a customer had handed him, plugged it into a test socket, and when it failed to light, tossed it away with a shrug.

description: NEW DELHI. Friday. Sept. 10An Indian Airlines plane, flying from here to Bombay. Was hijacked this morning and flown across the border to Lahore, Pakistan.

title: HELENE BERG, 92, WIDOW OF COMPOSER, IS DEAD
description: Helene Berg, widow of Alban Berg, the composer, died in Vienna on Aug. 30, it was learned today. She was 22 years old and had been ill for a long time.

title: Pop Music: Hattie Wilson
description: The energy and sparkle that Hattie Winston puts into her performance at Reno Sweeney, where she is appearing through Sunday, would, as a rule, create the momentum on which an exciting act could be built. But Miss Winston, a singer who has appeared on Broadway in the musical version of Two Gentlemen of Verona and The Me Nobody Knows, off Broadway in Billy Noname and with the Negro Ensemble Company, is so wrapped up in extraneous mannerisms  giggling introductions, simpering asides, empty dramaticsthat much of, her potential is diluted.

title: About Real Estate
description: For the last year or more the New York City Housing Authority has been mastering the art of administering new type of Federal housing subsidy program. Connoisseurs know it as the Section 8 program for existing housing, as opposed to Section 8 subsidies for new housing or major rehabilitation.

title: Waving The Flag For Art
description: Betsy Ross, the legend goes, was the first American to devise a flag that was a winner. Now there are others, and visitors may take their hats off to 25 recent winners in a nationwide flagdesign competition. Their flags will be on exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, starting tomorrow and through Oct. 24.

title: A Love Letter to His Daujhters
description: Ralph Schoenstein has committed a dangerous book, a love letter to his children. On the internal evidence, Mr. Schoenstein seems to have led a blameless life, is happily married, never drinks anything stronger than Ovaltine, has spent most of his adulthood writing humor at home in agreeable Princeton, N.J., and is approved of by his daughters, Kate and Debbie, for whom he rises each morning at six o'clock to prepare breakfast while singing Come to the Fair. Even when he trifles with what he calls a nervous breakdownthe children are growing up, I will eventually dieit's over in 24 hours, like a virus. Just watch me when I have mine, says his wife, Judy, and you'll see how it's supposed to be done.

title: Nixon's White House Is Criticized in Audit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI)  A General Accounting Office audit of the Nixon White House books shows total lack of accountability of public funds including the disappearance of 58 typewriters worth $18,000, Representative Jack Brooks, Democrat of Texas, said today.

title: Shades of Chanel: A Remake From Paris
description: Coco Chanel would have loved the idea of 23 shades of lipstick and 13 eyeshadows to play with. Even when she was well into her 80's (she was reputed to be 88 when she died five years ago), a makeup person would arrive daily to do her face before she met the world. Her red slash of a mouth was as well known as the gardenia pinned to her suit. She also made up her hands, and since some of the tint would rub off on her white cuffs. she had extra pairs to change into. Her clients at 31 rue Cambon were permitted to buy the makeup items she produced during the 1920's and 1930's, but the makeup disappeared with the outbreak of World War IL tew items appeared briefly in the 60's, but were shortlived in the United States. With her No. 5 perfume still a household word after 55 years, the Paris company decided it was time to reenter the face embellishing business. The eight treatment products and 16 makeup items currently sold France will be on local store counters next week.

title: Richie Havens Is at Bottom Line

He would flail mightily at his guitar, which was tuned to an open chord, and sing the same set of songs, finishing off with High Flying Bird or San Francisco Bay Blues. But his voice had an appealingly grainy quality and he always pleased his audiences, even when they had heard the same songs and arrangements dozens of times.
