description: Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, criticized the Board of Education yesterday for the hiring hall arrangements at board of fices for the reassignment of teachers who had been notified they would no longer be needed at schools where they had previously taught.

title: Mondale, Citing Kennedy in 1960, Bids Voters Not Misiudee Carter
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 10Senator Walter F. Mondale said today that he did not want Jimmy Carter to be held suspect by some voters because of region, accent, religion, as he said John F. Kennedy had been in 1960.

title: More Women Entering Ministry But They Still Meet Resistance
description: Parishioners more often comment to the Rev. Sue Ellis Mellrose on how well her voice carried rather than on what she said in her sermon.

title: Wilkins, Feted at 75, Still Vigorous Rights Figure
description: At 75 years of age, Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, still displays some of the vigor enthusiasm, and determination of his youth.

title: Reaction in Mao's Death Restrained in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 10The Hong %Kong stock market plunged sharply today following the announcement of Chairman Mao Tsetung's death, but otherwise this prosperous British colony, whose future depends on China's good will, displayed little outward reaction.

title: Tests Cast Doubts on Nickel Carbonyl as Cause of Legionnaires Illness
description: Nickel carbonyl, one of several possible causes suggested for the Philadelphia mystery disease, has emerged as the subject of not only one of the most tantalizing hyptoheses but also in some ways one of the most improbable.

title: Today's Football at a Glance
description: Home Team Record 1975

title: On Jobs For All
description: WELLESLEY., Mass,  The debate over the HumphreyHawkins Full Employment and Balanced Growth Acthas clouded the meaning of ,ftill employment. Most Americans have expressed, in public opinion polls and by their response to employment offices and want ads, a continuing strong belief in the work ethic. They support the goal of full employment because they object to handouts or the dole or makework or temporary jobs. But to adhere to this work ethic means that jobs must be available so that everyone who is willing and able to work can find employment opportunity.

title: Aborted Cruise Brings Suit
description: MIAMI, Sept. 10 (UPI)The Miamibased Norwegian Canibean Line is being sued on behalf of 802 passengers who were aboard the luxury liner Skyward last June when it developed engine trouble and had to cut short its cruise. Stanley Langfus, a Los Angeles lawyer and a passenger on the cruise, filed the suit, charging breach of warranty, fraud and misrepresentation. The suit seeks actual and punitive damages of $71,OpO for each of the passengers.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: G.E. to Make 2 Satellites For European Space Unit

title: Military Honor
description: The continuing investigations of the cheating charges at West Point have raised questions about the manner in which the Military Academy's honor code is enforced. Defenders of West Point traditions are angered by any suggestion that the code's rigidity may have contributed to the moral as well as pedagogical confusion which turn has led to the allegation of cheating by at least 200 members of last year's junior class.

title: The Opera: Superlative Otello
description: Verdi's Otello last night at the Metropolitan Opera House was the second production shown to New York by the visiting Paris Opera., It made an even stronger impression than Wednesday's Nozze di Figaro. This performance not only offered some superlative singing. It also was an ensemble performance, and an illustration of the fact that even the big international stars can work together as tightly and as dramatically convincingly as, say, the New York City Opera, which is primarily an ensemble house.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10The molding and die casting of high melting point steel and many other metals are expected to be improved by a new method of lubricationthe use of vapors, rather than liquidsso that the castings can be easily removed from the forms.

title: Business Records
Defecting Soviet Fighter Pilot Disappears Into Hiding in U.S.
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 (Reuters)The defecting Soviet fighter pilot, Viktor Belenko, who arrived here last night, disappeared today into a hideout provided by American security officials.

title: U.S IS CONCERNED BY CANCER IN STATE
description: TRENTON, Sept. 10A Federal Environmental Protection Agency official told a state legislative commission today that the presence of cancercausing agents in the air over sections of New Jersey is a cause of great concern and something should be done about it.

title: HELEN R. BRYAN, 82, OF REFUGEE GROUP
description: Helen R. Bryan, who had been executive secretary of the Joint AntiFascist Refugee Committee in New York City in the 1940's and who had been sent to prison in 1950 for contempt of Congress after a long court fight, died Thursday in Medford Lakes, N. J., at the age of 82.

title: American Stock Exchange Transactions: Consolidated Summary of Yesterday's Trading
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 10, 1976

title: The Judicial Candidates
description: Once again New Yorkers are being called upon judge the judges in the Democratic primary on Sept. and later on Election Day. Many of the candidates have not sat on the bench; most of the names on the ballot will be wholly unfamiliar to voters.

title: New Era for U.S.C. Eleven
description: A new era with an old gimmick starts for the University of Southern California tonight when it opens its 1976 football season against Missouri in the Los Angeles Coliseum.

title: History Tapestries Offered New York
description: A collection of 21 tapestries depicting historic New York events, the work of the late American muralist, Albert :Herter, has been offered to New York City by an Armenian school in Pennsylvania as a Bicentennial thank you gift.

title: Panel Urges That Psychosurgery Be Continued on Research Basis
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10A Governmentappointed commission recommended today that the controversial brain operation called psychosurgery be permitted to continue on a research basis with strict safeguards for the rights and welfare of the patients.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Sept. 10A year ago, the Trenton Psychiatric Hospital, a state institution, lost its accreditation after the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Hospitals reported an inadequate fire  prevention program, rundown buildings and equipment, and the use of nonqualified personnel.

title: Rain Brings a Deluge Of Changes at Belmont
description: My program looks like a Chinese crossword puzzle, said a bettor in Belmont Park's clubhouse yesterday as changes kept cropping up as the afternoon progressed. The racing program, in fact, was a study in changes. A heavy At the rainfall just before the first race found the seven startRace ers competing on a wetTracks fast surface. The track's condition was changed to good for the second race, muddy for the third and finally sloppy for the rest of the card.

title: Carey Comes to Queens to Repay State Senator Who Stood by Him
description: Repaying one's political debts is the cement that binds politicians together, and yesterday Governor Carey repaid his debt to a Democratic State Senator from Queens who had stood by him on one of the most trying days of his governorship.

title: MRS. CONSUELO BAILEY, VERMONT POLITICAL LEADER
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 10 (UPI)Consuelo,Northrup Bailey, the only woman to ever serve as Lieutenant Governor in Vermont and the first woman admitted to practice law before the United States Supreme Court, died yesterday after a long illness. She was 76 years old.

title: McCarthy Sues to Gain Place in Election Debates With Ford and Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP)Eugene J. McCarthy, an independent Presidential candidate, filed suit today in Federal court seeking to gain a place in the Presidential election debates between President Ford and Jimmy Carter.

title: Marine Corps Shifts 2
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP)The Marine Corps announced today that Lieut. Gen. Robert H. Barrow will become cornmending general of the Fleet Marine Force, Atlantic. Lieut. Gen. Robert L. Nichols, now in that post, will replace General Barrow as deputy chief of staff at Marine Corps headquarters here.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 11, 1976

title: Lyle Weighs in at 211, Isaac, 205, for Utica Bout
description: UTICA, N. Y., Sept. 10 (UPI)Ron Lyle, the fourthranked heavyweight, weighed in at 211 pounds todayin preparation for his bout tomorrow against Kevin Isaac of New York. Isaac, a 21yearold former Golden Gloves champion, is ranked 10th with a record of 9 victories, 3 losses an a draw. He weighed in at 205.

title: Spanish Prime Minister Pledges Strong 2Unit Parliament by June
description: MADRID, Sept. 10  Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez Gonzales, promised the Spanish people tonight that by next June they would be able to elect a new twohouse Parliament that would have the power to change the Constitution.

title: Decline in Money Supply and Rise In Retail Sales Lift Stock Prices
description: Stock prices moved in a narrow range yesterday throughout the session and ended slightly higher in moderate trading.

title: Catholic Clerics Are Encouraged By Ford Support of Abortion Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10Spokesmen for the Roman Catholic hierarchy said today that they were encouraged but not totally satisfied by President Ford's support of a proposed constitutional amendment that would permit states to regulate abortions.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Crosby and Nash Catch On
description: David Crosby and Graham Nash have attracted neither the publicity nor the public adulation accorded Stephen Stills and Neil Young, their partners in the onagainoffagain Crosby, Stills, Nast and Young supergroup. But while they are not as spectacular on stage as Mr. Stills, nor as enigmatic, and therefore intriguing, as Mr. Young, they have staying Dower.

title: Corn Forecast Pared by Hot, Dry August
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10The Agriculture Department reported today that hot and dry weather in large parts of major producing states during August caused continued deterioration of the country's important corn crop, although it predicted the total harvest would still set a record.

title: Mrs. Wallace's Wiretap Spurs Questions on Marriage
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 10The disclosure this week that many of Gov. George C. Wallace's bedroom telephone conversations. had been surreptitiously recorded, apparently by his wife, has raised questions about the stability of, the Governor's marriage.

title: Rail TonMileage Rises 28.2%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16 billion tonmiles, 28.2 percent above the corresponding week year agowhich included the Labor Day holiday. Carloadings in the sa=ne period totaled 492,236 cars, 26.9 percent above last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc., disclosed intercity truck tonnage was 29.4 percent above last year.

title: Supermarket Produce: A Search for Freshness
description: To lovers of fresh fruits and vegetables, this might well seem to be the time for celebration. For in spite of poor weather that has kept this year's harvest from being as plentiful as had been expected, we are in the midst of the season that offers the greatest variety of locally grown  products at their peak of perfection.

title: Column Dates Changed
description: The Personal Finance column, which formerly appeared Monday and Thursday, will be published Wednesday and Saturday, beginning today. The Market Place column will appear Monday through Friday instead of Tuesday through Saturday as formerly. Market place does not appear today.

title: People in Sports
description: Niki Lauda, recovering from burns and smoke inhalation. suffered in a crash during the German Grand Prix on Aug. 1, drove a Ferrari over the Monza autodrome course in a trial yesterday for tomorrow's Italian Grand Prix. Heavy rain pounded the track most of the day and the 27yearold world champion from Austria drove only two laps before returning to the pits. It's impossible to run in this rain, he said. I feel good. I seem to revive when I'm behind the wheel. I'm here to train myself with a view toward winning races after Monza. There's no rancor between me and [Carlos] Reutemann. The Argentine recently was hired by Ferrari as a third driver behind Lauda and Clay Regazzuni of Switzerland.

title: South Africa Makes Concessions To People of Mixed Racial Origins;
description: CAPE TOWN. Sept. 10 (Reuters)Sporadic rioting flared again in townships around Cape Town today while the Government was announcing concessions to the mixedrace community.

title: ManhattanSurrogate's Court
description: This sensitive office has been a center of patronage that favors politically connected lawyers and is a burden on the estates of decedents and their families. The Surrogate's Court urgently requires reform through state legislation.

title: JET WITH 92 HIJACKED OUT OF LA GUARDIA
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 10Six persons hijacked a Trans World Airlines jetliner carrying 92 people on a New YorktoChicago flight tonight, diverted it to Montreal and said they wanted to go to Europe, officials said.

title: Rubin Carter Trial Is Moved by Judge
description: Declaring that a fair trial is not possible in Passaic County for Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis because of prejudicial pretrial publicity, a NeW Jersey judge yesterday moved their new triplemurder trial from Paterson to Jersey City in Hudson County.

title: Clifford J. Nuttall Sr. Dies at 77; Promoted Major Antiques Fairs
description: Clifford J. Nuttall Sr., former manager of antiques shows and other exhibitions in metropolitan New York, died Sept. at Mercy Regional Center, Vicksburg, Miss. He was 77 years old and a resident of Vicksburg.

title: Judge Moves Rubin Carter Trial it After Citing Prejudicial Publicity
description: Declaring that a fair trial is not possible in Passaic County for Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Arils because of prejudicial pretrial publicity, a New Jersey judge yesterday moved their new triplemurder trial from Paterson to Jersey City in Hudson County.

title: Kissinger Plans to Leave Monday On Tour Including South Africa
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10The White House announced today that Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger would leave Monday for talks in southern Africa to seek solutions to the problems of SouthWest Africa and Rhodesia before conflicts between blacks and whites engulf those areas.

title: Hoffmann Says Honor Code Inquiry Is Ending, With 12 Cases Pending
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10Secretary of the Army Martin R. Hoffmann said today that he believed the overwhelming majority of violators in the West Point cheating scandal had been detected and, punished.

title: Agents Are Being Given Immunity In Inquiry Into F.B.I. Burglaries
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10Justice Department lawyers investigating recent burglaries by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation have apparently decided to forgo wholesale prosecutions of the agents in favor of focusing on those F.B.I. officials whq knew of or approved the breakins.

title: Auto Workers End Strike in Argentina; Plants in Operation
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 10Argentina's striking automobile workers returned to their jobs today. The strike, which involved 20,000 workers .at its height, was the most serious that the ruling military junta has faced since it took power in March. The labor action was met by a decree threatening the strike's organizers with as many as 10 years in prison.

title: Welfare Ends In Woodstock As a Reaction To Drifters
description: WOODSTOCK, N. Y.This town has finally closed its welfare office and just refuses to pay its relief clients.

title: Bridge: Generalizations Break Down In Heat of Tournament Play
description: The defenders can normally assume that if the declarer leads trumps it is not in their interests to do so, and vice versa. But there are times when this generalization breaks down, and it did so on the diagramed deal from the Summer National Championships in Salt Lake City.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An appeals .court in Rochester ordered Erie County yesterday to resume immediately the payment of statemandated welfare costs and reimburse the state for temporarily payin. the county's share of the financing.The unanimous decision by the Appellate Division, Fourth Department of the State Supreme Court. gave the county permission to appeal to the State Court of Appeals, New York's highest tribunal. The county attorney, James L. Magavern, said he would appeal.

title: RICH AND POOR LANDS DUE TO RESUME TALKS
description: PARIS, Sept. 10After two months or quiet and apparently effective diplomacy, rich and poor countries are ready to resume their deadlocked talks on ways to improve distribution of the world's wealth. Diplomatic sources reported that week

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: RENTING BIAS IS LAID TO COOP CITY BOARD
description: A civilrights group is charging that the tenantmanagement group that recently took over the giant Coop City housing project in the Bronx has instituted blatant discriminatory practices against black applicants in filling vacant apartments. It has demanded that Governor Carey intervene. The charge, mane by the New York Urban League's Open Housing Center in a letter sent to the Governor on Thursday, was denied yesterday by the head of the resident management board.

title: La Scala Offers La Cenerentola
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10The production of Rossini's La Cenerentola that the Teatro ans. Scala offered at the John F. Ken nedy Center for the Performing Arts last night might have seemed to have all the ingredients for success. But although it should be reported that many in the audience seemed to enjoy the results, this observer left the scene disgruntled. The ingredients stubbornly refused to blend, and the blame can be apportioned pretty equally all around.

title: Jerry Lewis Hailed in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP)  The Senate adopted a resolution of appreciation today for the contribution of Jerry Lewis to the fight against muscular dys. trophy. Senator John 0. Pastore, Demo. crat of Rhode Island, said in offering the resolution that Mr. Lewis's Labor Day, telethon had raised about $23 million.

title: MORRIS L. WOLF
description: Morris L. Wolf, president of the HenigsonWolf. Corporation, furriers, of .208 West 30th Street, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Brooklyn. Mr. Wolf, who came k to the United States from Horodcnka, Austria, in 1 92 1 , was 74 years old.

title: Soybeans, Wheat and Oats FuturesPrices Close Sharply Lower
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP)Farm commodity futures declined sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade today because of speculative liquidation in the major pits at the close. The opening had been relatively strong. Soybean futures were dovin 8 cents; meal lost nearly $5 a ton, and oil was down some 50 points, or  cent a pound. Wheat and oats futures were down more than 3 cents a bushel, and corn lost almost as much, although the nearby September delivery closed a penny hig,her,.1 Iced broilers gained Wcent a pound after a very lightly traded session.

title: JET OUT OF LA GUARDIA IS HIJACKED
description: Six persons hijacked a Trans World Airlines jetliner carrying 92 people on New YorktoChicago flight Last night and forced it to fly to Montreal.

title: R.J. Reynolds Tells S.L.C. of Payments
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 10R.J. Reynolds Industries reported today that it had made more than $25 million in questionable corporate payments in the United States and overseas since 1968 to promote its business and political interests.

title: I.M.F. Will Be Asked to Slow Its PaceReuss Cites Objections
description: COPENHAGEN, Sept. II) (Reuters)Italy secured the backing of its European Common Market partners today for its call to the International Monetary Fund to slow down its rate of gold sales.

title: Bill Before House Panel Could Prepare Way to Pay $100 Million to the Sioux
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10A technical legislative measure now pending before a House committee could prepare the way for a payment of more than $100 million to 60,000 Sioux Indians for lands taken from them a century ago, according to testimony at a hearing today.

title: Badillo and Velez Trade Charges In Their First Campaign Debate;
description: Representative Herman Badillo and Councilman Ramon S. Velez traded wide range of charges as they met in debate yesterday for the first time in their heated Congressional primary race.

title: Japanese Steel Exports UD 200/0 in Seven Months
description: A heavy influx of steel imports from Japan4.62 million tons in the first seven months of this yearwas reported today by the American Iron and Steel Institute. The association said the total so far this year was 20 percent more than in the comparable period a year ago.

title: Man Slain, $100,000 Calf Killed In Bizarre Case in Connecticut
description: State and local policemen in southwestern Connecticut have disclosed details of a bizarre case involving the theft and slaughter of a $100,000 high pedigree Holstein calf and the murder of a young man on a wooded hilltop.

title: BrooklynSurrogate's Court
description: Three candidates are competing: Daniel Eisenberg, specialist in the field of trusts and estates; Abraham Schulman, an able Civil Court judge, and Bernard M. Bloom, an open advocate of patronage. Because of his scholarship and ability, we recommend Daniel Eisenberg.

title: Buckley Pictures Forced Busing As Racial, Not Educational, Aim
description: senator James L. Buckley said yesterday that the United States was pursuing objectives in its schools that had nothing to do with providing educational opportunities, and that the worst example of this was forced busing to achieve arbitrary racial balance.

title: Thai Student Victory
description: Life along the klongs, the charming odoriferous Venicelike canals of Bangkok, undoubtedly exercises profound attraction on Thai exiles. But it is doubtful whether it was this that brought the recent sudden secret return from Taiwan of the strongman of the military regime ousted by a student revolt in 1973, Field Marshal Praphas Charusathien. Nor is it likely, as he claimed when discovered, that he came for a medical checkup. There are better doctors elsewhere.

title: Welfare Ends In Woodstock As a Reaction To Drifters
description: WOODSTOCK, N. Y.This town has finally closed its welfare office and just refuses to pay its relief clients.

title: Going,Going, Goooonnnnne
description: DALLASDesign and manufacturing knowhow lie at the foundation of America's world position, both military and economic. The Soviet Union is richer in untapped resources, Europe has prolific scientists, and Asia has a billion workers. But in just 200 years we've outdistanced them all, through the peculiar genius of Americans to turn laboratory dreams into realities.

title: Tarzans of the Apes Meet Abe of City Hall
description: You Tarzan, me Abe.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 11, 1976

title: IMPACT OF TAX BILL IS CONSIDERED MILD BY MANY IN WALL ST.
description: Will Street executives and other businessmen maintained yesterday that major legislation to revise the tax laws, as approved by the HouseSenate conference committee, could have been considerably worse.

title: Chinese Subdued Rather Than Distraught Over Mao
description: PEKING, Saturday, Sept. 11A journey of 1,500 miles through China yesterdayfrom Hong Kong to Canton, to Shanghaiand finally to this capitalfound the Chinese people subdued and pensive rather than shocked and distraught after the death of Chairman Mao Tsetung.

title: Laotians
description: VIENTIANE, LaosSix months ago eight letters arrived at the New Viengratri Restaurant, one of the few people's nightclubs left in Vientiane. They were signed by the socalled Provocating Group and announced to their recipients that they had been leading improper lives and would have to study. Chansamone, one of those who received a letter, was shaken and went home to ponder her next move. An entertainer at the club, she has a mother, a 13yearold daughter, a sister and two nieces to support. I decided not to go across the river to Thailand, she recalled. But I decided I would not stay at home and wait for them.

title: The BronxCivil Court
description: In this countywide contest, there are four candidates running for three vacancies. They include Burton G. Hecht, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee the State Assembly; Martin B. Klein, an independent trial attorney; Harold Silverman, a criminal trial specialist, and Alexander E. Scheer, deputy chief of the Homicide Bureau in the Bronx District Attorney's office. We prefer Burton G. Hecht, Martin B. Klein and Harold Silverman.

title: Connors Knows He's Going to Win
description: With the look of the terrier that he resembles, Jimmy Connors hurried out of the old greenwalled room adjacent to the thirdfloor locker room at the West Side Tennis Club.

title: Bank Americard to Get A New Name: Visa
description: The BenkAmericard is headed for extinctionat least in name. Starting some time next year, according to National BankAmericard Inc., the name of this credit card will be changed alt over the world to Visa, a word exnected to be universally acceptable.

title: Historic Occasion Fatigue
description: It is disappointing to hear that the FordCarter debates will be historic. One had hoped for more. Almost everything is historic these days, except for speeches, which all seem to be major.

title: Ouster of 3 Senior Peking Aides Is Indicated in Mao Funeral List
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 10The official list, of the committee for Mao Tsetung's funeral, which was published yesterday, suggests that three senior Chinese officials, the Minister of Education, the Minister of Railways and the director of the official press agency, Hsinhua, may have lost their posts as a result of this year's antirightist campaign.

title: Peyser Over Buckley
description: Whatever their political affiliations, New Yorkers are entitled to a choice between the best Senatorial candidates the respective parties can offer. We have already stated our preference for Daniel P. Moynihan in Tuesday's Democratic primary. On the Republican side our strong hope is that the nomination will go, not to Senator James L. Buckley, whose one term in office has been largely negative and undistinguished, but to Representative Peter A. Pevser.

title: Rothko Heir Asks Contempt Fine From Director of Marlborough
description: Another development in the lengthy litigation between the heirs of Mark Rothko, the late abstractexpressionist painter, and the Marlborough Gallery in New York took place yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

title: ARTHUR E. TEALE
description: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Sept. 10The Rev, Arthur E. Teale, D.D., pastor emeritus of the Soiith Congregational Church, Granby, Conn., and chaplain of the Connecticut Supreme Court for 25 years, died here yesterday. He was 92 years old.

title: Article 6  No Title
Mayor Institutes Computer System To Check the Abuse of Medicaid
description: In yet another attempt to crack down on fraudulent Medicaid practices, Mayor Beanie instituted yesterday a computerized program that he estimated would double recoupment by the city for improper claims.

title: Mets Defeat Cards, 43; Lolich Is Injured at Bat
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10After five starting appearances without a victory, Mickey Lolich finally triumphed tonight at Busch Memorial Stadium. But he was not around at the end of wild 43 victory by the Mets over the Cardinals before  a crowd of 14,935 that saw some exceptionally shoddy basebalL

title: Dursett
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 10A lot of Pittsburgh linemen are going to fall and take their lumps trying to assist Tony Dorsett in his quest for the Heisman Trophy. But they apparently .don't mind it a bit. They feel they have a share in the action.

title: Police Arrest 10 Youths in Attack In Park. That Injured 13 Persons
description: In a sweep through Greenwich Village late Thursday and early yesterday morning, the police rounded up 10 youths who they said had been part of the marauding band that swarmed through Washington Square Park Wednesday evening attacking black and Hispanic men.

title: BISHOPS'ENCOURAGED BY FORD ON ABORTION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10Spokesmen for the Roman Catholic hierarchy said today that they were encouraged but not totally satisfied by President Ford's support of a proposed constitutional amendment that would permit states to regulate abortions.

title: YOUTH, 16, IS SEIZED IN BERGEN MURDER
description: RIVERDALE, N. J., Sept. 10A 16yearold. youth was arrested today at his home in this Bergen County suburb and charged with the %abduction, rape and murder of Kim Montelaro, a 20yearold college student from New Milford whose body was discovered in a secluded field in nearby Washington Township last week.

title: Shipping/Mails
The Standings
description: Saturday, September 11, 1976

title: Text of Croation Fighters
description: The American people, in 1776, proclaimed in the Declaration of Independence that every nation has a right to national selfdetermination and freedom, and this declaration, which inspired later the protagonists of the .French Revolution in their formulation of the Declaration of the Rights of Man, has served as a model to many other nations throughout the years, which have strived to free themselves from colonialistic or imperialistic forces.

title: BrooklynCivil Court
description: For three countywide vacancies, eight candidates are competing: Martha Gibbell, a specialist in landlord and tenant law; Elliott Golden, Chief Assistant District Attorney of Kings County; Abraham Reingold, an arbitrator in the Small Claims Part of the Civil Court and adjunct professor at New York Law School; Bernard Fuchs, an attorney who has served in Small Claims; Stanley J. Glantz, law secretary in the Civil Court; Samuel W. Held, an attorney; Ruth Moskowitz, an attorney with Legal Aid Society experience, and Solomon A. Shapiro. an attorney.

title: Other Company Reports
Deaths
Nets. Complete Archibald Deal, Sending 2 Players to Kings
description: Nate Archibald and Jim McMillian, a pair of New Yorkers, officially came home yesterday and Bill Brad1py confirmed that he would retire after next season.

title: Edward Fennell Dies in Illinois; United Airlines General Counsel
description: Edward Fennell, general counsel and secretary of United Airlines and its parent company, UAL Inc., died Thursday at his home in Lake Forest, Ill. He was 50 years old.

title: KISSINGER INDICATES POSSIBILITY OF TALK WITH RHODESIA HEAD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger held out the possibility today that, under certain conditions, he might meet with Prime Minister Ian D. Smith, the head of the whiteruled Government of Rhodesia, during his forthcoming trip to southern Africa.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Byrne's Tactics on Tax Are Termed Brilliant

title: Grambling Eleven to Play In Pontiac, Mich., Nov. 6
description: PONTIAC:, Mich., Sept. 12 (UPI)Grambling and North Carolina A. and have scheduled a football game on Nov. 6 in the 80.000seat Pontiac Stadium.

title: Food
description: Like a lot of other Americans, this summer I spent my vacation in a kitchen in Europe. I took a oneweek cooking course in Bologna with Marcella Hazan (pronounced HahZAHN), who was leading her first culinary excursion with American students to her native land, although she teaches regularly in Manhattan. She says, What I always longed to do, when teaching Italian cooking or writing about Italian foodshe recently wrote her first cookbook, unabashedly entitled The Classic Italian Cook Book''was to take my students and readers beyond a recipe's boundaries and step with them into that special, joyous way of life that flows around the making and partaking of an Italian meal. We were going to experience Italian cooking from Antipasti to Zampone.

title: Put the Players in Charge
description: An effort at redemption of athletics in American schools and colleges today would provide Hercules a 13th Labor worthy of his mettle. Still, an auspicious start could easily be made. For a simple remedy exists that, if adopted, would go a long way toward rendering high school ancl college athletics a rational, even educational (!), activity. Furthermore, it would cost no money.

title: Lifting Morale As Well as Faces
description: BAYVILLE LA MATSON DE RENAISSANCE, a 10acre estate, sits in Gatsbyish splendor facing Long Island Sound. The 10acre grounds of the estate, once the residence of wealthy New Yorker, now contain an indoor swimming pool, a tennis court mad a parking lot, and the second and third floors of the estate house have been divided into guest rooms.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Liberalism, or Just Avarice?

title: New Spending Law Called Unworkable
description: TRENTON OVER the last 12 years, the annual increase in the cost of state government in New Jersey 15.8 percenthas been about double the yearly rise in the personal income of the state's residents.

title: The Colonial Life At Strawbery Banke
description: Kids. Streams of kids, their admission tags dangling from their shirt buttons, their sneaker laces flapping, their maps folded into paper airplanes. Their hands busy picking dandelions, punching each other, pointing to whatever it is they want their best friend to lookit. Lookit the guy making boats. Lookit the funny chimney on that house. Lookit the sign: They spelled strawberry wrong. And bank, too,

title: College Football Scoring and. Statistics
Barge Traffic Is Badly Crippled On Shrunken Mississippi River
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 (AP)Low water has slowed Mississippi River barge traffic to a crawl, causing costly delays to companies that haul grain, coal and other commodities along the 1,800mile waterway.

title: Gallup Poll Finds New Evidence Of the Religious Character of U.S.
description: During a Presidential campaign in which Jimmy Carter's born again faith has helped raise curiosity about the nation's overall religious character, some new evidence that the Gal1p Poll indicates that the United States is as pervasively religious as it was a quarter century ago.

title: Science
description: Two manmade objects, called Viking 1 and 2, now sit on the surface of Mars, sending back scientific data. The achievement is remarkable. But in the larger scheme things it is also inconsequential. As the universe goes, Mars is simply not very far away, a very junior member of a cadet system. Beyond Mars, beyond Pluto, beyond the Solar System, the Milky Way and the farther visible galaxies there is More. Much much more, most of it, by any reasonable estimate of forever, forever unreachable. But not wholly unknowable. What is it all, where did it come from and what is become of it? The question, and the answers, go to make up cosmology, the study of the totality of everything.

title: Harper &
description: Harper & Row, a trade and textbook publisher and one of the oldest in the country, is planning to move its religious book department to San Francisco, where it will join Canfield Press, the West Coast textbook house that Harper established in 1970. DOROTHY F. RODGER
description: Dorothy F. Rodger, who had been a teacher of handicapped children in the New York City public school system for 23 years until her retirement in 1969, died yesterday at her home in the Richmond Hill section of Queens. She was 79 years old, and was the widO, of John A. Rodger, who was president of the RodgerPalliser Press or Richmond Hill. Mrs. Rodger was born in Candor, N. Y., and graduated from Wellesley College in 1919. She was president of the King Manor Association, which cares for the Rufus King mansion in King Park in Jamaica, Queens. She was also past regent of the Elizabeth Annesley Lewis Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution In Jamaica. She is survived by three sons, and a daughter andi, 10 arindchildren.

title: HIGHLIGHTSOF THE WEEK
description: THE AGRICULTURE DEPARTMENT forecast that the corn crop, based on Sept. I conditions, would total 5.89 billion bushels this year, 5 percent or 295 million bushels below the Aug. I forecast, but still a record harvest.. .. The Department also raised its estimate of the 1976 Soviet Union grain crop to 2.05 million metric tons, up 10 percent from the previous forecasts and 46 percent above last year.

title: Edvard MunchA Film Truer to Life Than to Art
description: It was one of the ambitions of the great Norwegian painter, Edvard Munch (18631944), that someday he would change the way in which people looked at art. No longer would people regard painting as a source of polite distraction. Instead of painting pictures of men reading and women knitting, I shall paint real human beings who breathe, feel; suffer and love. People will realize how sacred that is and they will take off their hats as though they were in church.

title: Time to Gather Seeds from Nature
description: An autumn walk through the September woods and fields is a perfect opportunity to take advantage of nature's own seed packets. There are many kinds of seeds to find, free for the taking, and easy to grow at home. Woods are likely to yield a few birch catkins, winged seeds (samaras) of maples, ripe pine cones, honeylocust pods, tawny acorns or nutlike seeds of hickory or horsechestnut.

title: Mr. Troy Changes His Mind
description: Despite having signed a statement admitting his guilt, New York City Councilman Mathew J. Troy Jr. has suddenly changed his plea to not guilty on a charge of income tax evasion. The action surprised both the judge and the Federal prosecutors. Why did he do it? Mr. Troy said was because the judge in charge of sentencing had no previous record on tax cases, whereas the judge who had originally heard his guilty plea had a record of leniency on tax offenders. That judge has since died. Mr. Troy also said he had signed his statement of guilt under extreme emotional strain and without reading it carefully. A decision on whether a trial will be held will be made later this month.

title: The Siren Song of
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON IT sounded like a fireworks display run amuck. The horrendous whomps and cracks emanating from the back yard of the Bridgehampton Historical Society overpowered the constant drone of summertime traffic on the Montauk Highway. To the welltuned and amused ears of residents, however, the murderous rhythmic explosions signalled that Russell Simons, a retired East End plumber, historian, and collector of antique farm machinery, had several of his pride and joys primed and working.

Arthur Lesslie, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony in the couple's new apartment in New York. The bride is book designer for the Chanticleer Press. Mr. Phinizy is an associate with the New York law firm of Huber Magill Lawrence & Farrell. Mr. Nehring is senior vice president and secretary of the Franklin Savings Bank in New York.

Those who enter the system with strong characters formed at home and who fall under the guidance of a good coach emerge strengthened in their convictions_

title: For the Moment, $8.20, First in Futurity at Belmont
description: It took only one phone call two days ago for Gerald Robins to become the owner of a colt that yesterday became the winner of one of thoroughbred racing's richest and most prestigious juvenile events.

description: Sandra Louise Henschel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Henschel of Bedford, N. Y., was married yesterday morning to William Cohn McKeveny, a lawyer with the New York law firm of Dunnington, Bartholow & Miller.

title: He Sees a Bigger Picture For Public Television
description: Ever since he became president of the Public Broadcasting Service in February, Lawrence K. Grossman has been behaving like a candidate. He has traveled the country to meet operators of noncommercial stations and he has been making speeches, giving press interviews and issuing position papers. Like Jimmy Carter, he has made capital of coming from outside the Washington clique (PBS has its headquarters there, too). And like Mr. Carter, he has been something of a healer, reconciling the traditional regional and ideological differences in the system in his lowpressure way.

title: Found Space For a Winter Garden
description: Entry foyers, windowed sunporches or enclosed breezeways are potential areas for winter gardens, if they have plenty of daylight. These unused portions of the house will keep plants fresh during the winter months. And until very cold weather, pots of summer annuals can be tucked here and there for accents of color. Some of the showiest anrruals can be potted up now.

title: 20 Years at the Fair
description: WESTBURY IN the beginning, in 1956, there was a plain canvas tent pitched at the bottom of an abandoned gravel pit dug into the potato fields of Westbury. Then Levittown pushed out beyond Huntington, Times Square moved lightyears away from Long Island, psychologically at least; and Judy Garland, Jack Benny and Liberate came to entertain.

title: Steve Cady
description: Strip gambling of its theatrical trappings. a noted research foundation concluded, and it's nothing more than a consumer swindle.

title: U.M.W.'s Miller Has Opponent
description: MADISONVILLE, Ky., Sept. 11 (UPI)Lee Roy Patterson, a United Mihe Workers leader from western Kentucky, says he will run against Arnold Miller, the union president, in next year's U.M.W. election. Mr. Patterson, 41 years old, is a leading critic of Mr. Miller. In announcing his candidacy yesterday, Mr. Patterson said that he doubted the union would survive another five years under Mr. Miller.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. II (AP)Moslem leftists and their Palestinian allies said tcklay they repulsed an attempt during the night by rightwing Christian troops and armorto break into Moslemheld west Beirut.

description: PARIS, Sunday, Sept. 12The surrender of the Croatian terrorists who seized the Trans World Airlines jet and landed here last night with about 60 passengers and crew members aboard followed the arrest early today of one of the hijackers.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: SUMMER does not officially end until a week from Tuesday, but once Labor Day has passed most Long Island homeowners start thinking about getting their house ready for winter. Those with beach houses or vacation homes out on the eastern end of the Island start planning for the an nual chore of moving out and closing up their summer residences (although an increasingly large number of these people have learned to enjoy using their second homes during fall and winter weekends).

title: Music: Italian Groups at Tully
description: One of Italy's observances of the United States Bicentennial was to send here the Alessandro Scarlatti Orchestra of Naples and the Chamber Chorus of Radiotelevisione Italiana. On Friday night they were in New York, presenting a program in Alice Tully Hall, not of Neapolitan music, as might have been expected, but of Venetian music from the 16th and 18th centuries. Except for two choruses by Andrea Gabrieli, all the works were by Vivaldi.

title: Team Canada Subdues Russians, Gains Final
description: TORONTO, Sept. 11Horns blared and a standingroom crowd of 16,485 shouted out the last 10second countdown of the game tonight as Team Canada advanced to the final of the Canada Cup of Hockey with a 31 victory over the Soviet Union.

title: SAN DIEGO STUDIES LEGAL HEROIN PLAN
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 11A proposal to set up the country's first experiment in supplying legalized heroin to hardcore addicts, either free or at low cost, is under serious study by San Diego County officials.

title: London Sings Out For Sondheim
description: Asurprise success in London this season is a show called Side by Side by Sondheim, which opened at the Mermaid Theater and was then transferred to Wyndham's on the West End, where it has settled for a long prosperous engagement. Its success is a surprise for several reasons. First of all, few American musical'A Chorus Line is a notable recent exceptiondo extremely well in ritain. Second, Sondheim is definitely American, an urbane, sophisticated New Yorker who does not write popular songs. In fact, his show songs are paragons of integration. Furthermore, Side by Side is that curious stage foundling, more cabaret than theateran anthology, a divertisement, an andthenIwrote missing only the author's presence. The Mermaid's previous anthologies were salutes tb Cole Porter and Noel Coward. Isn't Sondheim too young to be anthologized? The final, seeming contradiction is for an American visitor to see the show in London.

title: A Terrier From Britain Moves Into the Spotlight
description: In a year when no one dog is dominating the show scene, a newcomer has arrived from Britain and quickly moved to the front of the stage. He is Harwire Hethman of Winlatter, a wire fox terrier who will be 2 years old next month. Purchased by News Cliff Hallmark for Constance Jones of Sewickley ley Heights, Pa., Harry, Dogs as he is called, gained his American championship last weekend in just four shows.

title: LOTTERY SAFEGUARDS CALLED SUFFICIENT
description: Governor Carey and John D. Quinn, director of the state's new lottery system, are confident that an alert public and the quick discovery of isolated cases of cheating by vendors will halt any spread of lottery irregularities.

title: The Catholic in Politics: From Pariah to President
description: The roots of antiCatholic feeling in the United States lie deep in the nation's history. Colonial America was a largely Protestant America, only generation or two removed from the English hatred of the Church of Rome. For the first century and quarter of the American political experience, Catholics remained a small and relatively powerless minority, but the Irish, German, Slavic and Italian immigrants who poured into New York City and other ports at the end of the 19th century and the beginning of the 20th ultimately made their weight felt.

description: Marilyn Eliznbeth Miller and John Sloane Griswold Jr. were married yesterday afternoon in Greenwich, Conn., at the home of the bridegrocm's George Lauder Greenway. The Rev. Raymond D. Scott. a Presbyterian minister. performed the ceremony.

title: World Cup Team Faces More Tests
description: The United States World Cup team, which hopes to bring soccer prominence to this country, will meet the national teams of Peru on Tuesday and Venezuela on Thtltsday. The matches, in Lima and Caracas, will be in prep aration for the World Cup qualifying matches against Canada and Mexico. Under the coaching of Walt Chyzowych, the Americans played three more games in South America last week to get ready for the first qualifying match against Canada on Sept. 24 in Vancouver, B. C. The Canadians, in the meantime, played two games against the touring New York Cosmos.

title: Bishop Proposes Episcopal Women As Priests in Receptive Dioceses
description: ST. PAUL, Sept. 11 The Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church, John M. Allin, proposed today that women be ordained to the priesthood in areas where they would be accepted.

description: RILENS AIRES, Sept. 11President Jorge Rafael Videla has committed Argentina's military junta to support of academic freedom in universities against any authoritarian system of education.

description: ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 11  Senator Walter G. Mondale, the Democratic VicePresidential nominee, appealed to. New Jersey's top Democratic party leaders here today to resolve their differences and unite behind Jimmy Carter, the party's Presidential candidate.

Moynihan in what is viewed as essentially a twoway race between Mr. Moynihan and Representative Bella S. Abzuz.

The tome, off the Farrar, Straus & Giroux presses this week, is heralded by heavy praise ('I wrote it myself, confesses the owlish Mr. Schoenstein) like Here is a celebration of fatherhood and parenthood that is hilarious, touching and unforgettable.

description: The trend has been for European designers to bring their collections to the United States where an eager buying public has snapped up their offerings as if to say, If they're foreign, they must be.fashionable. It took French labels to make high fashion of such allAmerican staples as blue jeans and pea coats.

description: IT'S been a week for fish stories. And they run the gamut, from abundant to awful, from zany to zero.

title: 25,000 Hold Rally In Spain for Return Of Catalan Rights
description: SANT BOI DE LLOBREGAT, Spain, Sept. 11The first legal demonstration in favor of Catalan liberties since this region lost them in the civil war brought more than 25,000 cheering, flagwaving people to this industrial town today to demand autonomy.

description: This has been a year for omnibus issues, for 100year occasions like the Bicentennial and the centenary of the telephone, for quadrennial occasions like the Olympic Gaines, and the familiar but ever rewarding annual omnibus issue, the Europa stamps.

title: Art
Black Enlistments Up in Army
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)Black enlistments in the Army rose this summer to the highest level in about three years, according to Martin N. Hoffmann, Secretary of the Army. The black percentage of recruits reached about 30 percent, Mr. Hoffmann said. The rate has generally been in the mid20 percent range since the summer of 1973. Mr. Hoffmann told a news conference that there is no highlevel concern about this.

title: The Tax Bill ...
description: The massive tax bill that the Senate and House conferees have agreed upon is no model of tax reformbut it is now more acceptable than it threatened turn out only a few weeks ago. The improvements the billespecially the junking of a great many giveaways that it originally containedare a tribute to the new budget process and the tax reformers.

title: E. S. Coale 3d Weds Christine A. Graham

Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to Edmund Starr Coale 3d, son of Mr. Coale Jr. and Mrs. Hicks Coale. both of Towson, Md. The Rev. Charles Sullivan performed the ceremony in St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church. title: Croatian Exiles and Tito's Police Fight Clandestine War Worldwide
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 11A chain of terrorism and unsolved murders that stretches from Stockholm to Sydney touched New York last night when Croatian separatists hijacked an airliner and left a bomb behind thatkilled a policeman.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q. My dining room floor Is solid quarried bluestone (not slate) and there is a stepdown from the dining room to the living room where the stone projects almost a lull inch. Recently a careless workman hit the overhanging edge with a heavy implement and snapped off a section about 1 inch wide by 43A inches long. The break is irregular but clean because the pieces fit together neatly. How can I adhere this piece in place permanently?E.F.S., Auburn. N.Y.

title: The Region Continued
description: The largescale layoffs of city workers during the last year and a half have caused considerable controversy and personal hardship, but New York City's government is also suffering from an exodus of middle managers that is threatening the future delivery of services.

title: Answers/Questions
description: ASAVING TOMATO SEED [Aug. 29] C. H. Bronx, N. Y., asked if seed from Better Boy, Marglobe and other tomatoes will come true type and how can he save the seed. Better Boy tomato is a hybrid variety and would not come true to seed, but Marglohe, one of the older openpollinated varieties probably would come true to seed as nonhybrid tomato varieties will naturally selfpollinate. Theodore Fastje, a Westchester County reader, saves his tomato seed by picking one fruit each variety, when fully ripe. He spreads the seeds, including a little pulp, on a paper towel to dry and labels each towel. The towels are stored in his dry cellar until spring when he peels off the seed and plants it. There is more to seed saving. To perpetuate the highest quality in the end product, buying fresh seed every year is recommended. Isolating varieties the home garden is difficult and open field pollination invites cross breeding with less desirable varieties. Also, so many advances have been made with hybrids, particularly with regard to disease resistance and vigor, they are worth the extra price. Only when vegetable varieties are of rare or odd interest or unobtainable is saving your own advised. Ed.

title: Laffite Wins Pole at Monza
description: MONZA, Italy, Sept. 11 (UPI)Jacques Laffite drove his Matra racer round the Monza track at a 12:7.731 mileanhour clip today to register a top onelap clocking of 1 minute 41.35 seconds, earning the Frenchman the pole position in tomorrow's Italian Grand Prix race. Niki Lauda of Austria, the world driving champion, seriously injured in the Aug. 1 German Grand Prix, posted a 1:42.09, fifth best time, as he prepared for his Ferrari comeback. He underwent extensive plastic surgery to cover facial burns suffered in the nearfatal accident and missed the Austrian and Dutch Grand Prix races.

title: Is anybody out there?; Scientists at the world's largest radio telescope are reading messages from stars, quasars and pulsars, and broadcasting advertisements for the human race.
description: ARECIBO, P.R. Trying to remember which are smaller, atoms or molecules, I am looking down into an enormous empty aluminum bowl. It is wok 1,000 feet across and 300 feet deep. Rice could be fried in it for every Red Guard in China. I am making myself believe that every second this utensil is being bombarded by countless billions of electromagnetic particles, when there isn't even a sign that the local birds know it's there.

title: The Cast
description: ()TELL, opera in tour acts by Giuseppe Verdi. Text by Arno Boit, after the Play by Shakespeare. Conducted by Sir Georg Solti; staged by Terry Hands; designed be Joseph Svoboda. Presented by the Paris Opera at the Metr000litan Opera House.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: An anniversary passed unnoticed last March 26. Fifty years ago Franz Kneisel died. The name probably means little today, except to a few oldtimers and connoisseurs of the violin. But in his day the man loomed big. He was to the development of the string quartet in this country what Theodore Thomas was to the symphony orchestra. Concertmaster of the Boston Symphony, leader of the Kneisel Quartet, a great teacher at the Institute of Musical Art in New York (his pupil. Joseph Fuchs, continues the Kneisel tradition at the Juilliard School, which grew out of the old Institute), he was a most valuable musician.

title: Article 5  No Title
Schuler Finishes First In 105Mire Cycle Race
description: NORTH CONWAY, N. H., Sept. 11 (AP)Tom Schuler, 19 years old, of Birmingham, Mich., beat five other Olympic bicyclists by a wheel today to win a 105mile road race round the backbone of the Presidential mountain range. Schuler made the tour in hours 38:30 minutes. The road race was the first step toward the top spot in the $5,000 International Bicycle Grand Prix. There were 51 riders entered in the race.

title: Town Stages Demonstrations in Westhampton Beach in an Effort to Fight Plans for Condominium Project
description: A oitter Tight is going On in Westhampton Beach, L.I., over the construction of a large condominium complex. The community, ordinarily a pleasant resort in which trendy summer folks mix with downtoearth locals, has been beset by demonstrations, a mass meeting and talk of impeaching the Mayor.

title: From American Graffiti To Outer Space
description: Right now, I'm contemplating retirement, said George Lucas. A polite laugh seemed the best answer. With the dazzling success of American Graffiti, his comic and touching portrait of 50's teenagers, still fresh in everyone's mind, and in the middle of shooting Star Wars, a $6.5 million spaceadventure spectacular for Twentieth CenturyFox, the idea of one of America's hottest directors renouncing fame and fortune at 32 soundedwell, whimsical.

title: Burke Hedges, 65, Dies in Texas Once Served as a Cuban Envoy
description: Burke Hedges, an Americanborn busi. nessman who served as Cuba's ambassa. dor to Brazil before Fidel Castro came to power, died in Houston, Texas, Thursday after a long illness. He was 65.

title: Women in Sports
description: For. many women in college sports, the first day of the school year will mean the first day of a new job. Over the summer, many have been named to positions previously held by men, and some jobs have been created for woman on the nation's campuses.

title: Mr. Mandel Goes to Court
description: The trial of Gov. Marvin Mandel bf Maryland, indicted 10 months ago on Federal charges of mailfraud and bribery, has begun. The charges against Mr. Mandel involve an alleged scheme to use the Governor's political influence to enhance the value of a racetrack owned by five,of his friends and associates. All five were indicted with ;him: Defense attorneys managed to sever the.,case of one, Irvin Kovens, from the other defendants, because he is ill. The move may hurt the prosecution's case, because Mr. Kovens allegedly put up the money for the scheme.

title: The World In Summary
description: The Vietnamese have listed as dead 12 more of the 2,500 American servicemen Washington considers still missing in action as a result of the Indochina war. Hanoi said the action was gesture to help settle postwar problems between the two countries. But Washington's position is that not until all the missing are accounted for can there be any improvement in relations.

title: Albert Bergfeld, 66, Dies; Head of Case &
description: Albert J. Bergfeld, chairman of Case & Company of Stamford, Conn., an international general management consulting concern, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Stamford. He retired as president of the company last spring. He was 66 years old.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10After seven years of study, a task force of Federal, state and region, al agencies has sent final report to Congress recommending preservation of the upper Delaware River by inclusion in, the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System.

title: Windsor Locks Seeks First Foreign Trade Zone in New England
description: WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn., Sept. 11 (AP)The first foreign trade zone in New England may be set up here if town development officials can convince Federal authorities that the area would benefit from it.

title: Vermont Governor in Close Democratic Senate Race As 4 New England States Hold Primaries Tuesday
description: BURLINGTON, VT., Sept. 11If Gov. Thomas P. Salmon had wanted to leave the State House two years ago, Vermonters agree that he, not Senator Patrick .T. Leahy, would almost certainly have become the state's first Democrat in the United States Senate. Mr. Salmon stuck instead with state government in a period of severe economic distress, and he paying the price this yearfor courage, his friends say, or, as others see it, for a stolid lack of initiative.

title: Weekend Packages: Manhattan for Sophisticates
description: A new kind of package tour of Manhattan is turning on thousands of suburban and exurban citylovers. For prices ranging from $39.50 a couple to well over $100 a person, and covering one or two nights in a hotel, some food and perhaps theater tickets, they are able to take a bite of the Big Apple while avoiding the hassle of arranging everything themselves. Even some Manhattanites are going the package route.

title: New Zealand: Prim Amid the Splendor
description: We thread through, not over, the mountains. Raw nature is in our lap, granite crags nudging our elbow. The bottom drops out of everything in plunge down a deep ravine. My wife and I are the only passengers in the fiveseater Cessna going from New Zealand's lake town of Te Anau to Milford Sound on the Tasman Sea. Our pilotguide, Capt. Bert Wilson, is a sixyear veteran of this gorgeous obstacle course. The plane is a moth, brushing a peak, as if drawn by the burning sunshine on the snow. I am totally atinglehalf in fear, half in aweat the intimacy with the dangerous grandeur of nature.

title: Oklahoma Wins, 24 to 3
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 11 (AP)Dean Blevins directed Oklahoma to three secondhalf scores today as the Sooners overcame a lethargic first half and routed Vandervilt, 243.

title: Carter Returning Up to $40,000
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 11 (UPI)The campaign of the Democratice Presidential candidate, Jimmy Carter, is refunding more than $30,000 to donors whose cumulative contributions exceeded the legal limit of $1,000. Robert Lipshutz, campaign treasurer, said yesterday that an internal audit revealed that 30,000 and up to $40,000 in donations would have to be refunded. We're writing the checks this weekend, he said.

title: China and America
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11Watching China in her recent adversity and bereavement reminds us of the wisdom of very old societies. Politics aside, they have learned in their thousands of years a great deal about the mysteries of life and death and the triumphs and disasters in between.

title: Text of Hijackers Of Jet Is Published By 4 Newspapers
description: Told that the fate or many people hangs in the balance, four major newspapers  The New York Times, The Washington Post, The Chicago Tribune and The Los Angeles Times  yesterday published the text of the demands of the Croatian hijackers.

title: China After Mao
description: Events since Mao Tsetung's death have shown how delicately poised is the political situation in Peking. China's leaders required sixteen hours after Mao's actual passing before they announced his death. China's new leaders obviously have decided to prevent any mass spontaneous demonstrations of grief that could get out of control. Even the few wreaths some mourners brought to the monument in Tien An Men Square have been removed. The list of 373 officials named for Mao's funeral has been found to omit three key officials, the Minister of Education, the Minister of Railways and the Director of the Chinese press agencyomissions which suggest the three men have been quietly purged.

IISimmy Carter says he emphasized relatively conservative themes during his first week of Presidential campaign to restore what Ite thinks is the more accurate image he enjoyed in the spring before selecting a liberal running mate and before Republicans branded hint an ultraliberaL

title: PEOPLE
description: Florence Howe, a professor of humanities at the State University of New York College at Old Westbury and a leader in the fields of women's studies and feminist literature, has been named a faculty exchange scholar by the Chancellor of the State University system. The faculty exchange scholars program is designed to extend and share the expertise of talented faculty members with other campuses in the state system. Under terms of the program, participating scholars are invited by sister institutions to appear as visiting lecturers and guest instructors. Professor Howe is the president the Feminist Press, an independent nonprofit publishing concern headquartered at the College at Old Westbury, and a former president of the Modern Language Association.

title: Barry ManilowThe Master Of Romantic Pop
description: Bany Manilow, once the voice of Big Mac and Kentucky Fried Chicken and more recently After Dark magazine's Entertainer of the Year and the avatar of Romantic Pop, is pacing the living room of his luxury apartment in the East 20's, his lanky, Ichabod Cranelike figure almost shaking with nervous energy. Bagle, the faithful beagle, is following in his master's footsteps and offering consoling licks. The strawberry plants and roses on the shaded terrace are radiating color. Everything, from the sliding glass doors to the spotless kitchen counter to the big plastic cheeseburger in the den, is gleaming in the late morning sunlight.

title: Sunday Observer
description: It was one of those amusing checkroom mixups. They happen in the best of checkrooms. The woman misplaces a numbered slip of paper, and you arrive home to find you are wearing someone else's cape or carrying the wrong cane. In this case, there was a confusion of brains, and Simcox, who had taken more wine than usual, did not notice it until he arrived home.

title: A Personal Memoir of an Unchanging Peasant Leader
description: I had met Mao Tsetung before and was to meet him again, but I best remember him standing on a loess terrace, of an early afternoon in February, 1947, before the caves that were his home and office in Yenan. He wore a soldier's old padded cotton uniform with a tiny cap and a short scarf around his neck. He had apparently come down the mountain path from another level, but I had not heard him approach.

title: New York Is a City of Miracles
description: IT's the gospel truth, folks, really is. For New Jerseyans, trip to New York City these days doesn't have to be a terrifying experidnce, and so leave your Mace and police whistles at home.

title: Both Talking and Killing in Africa
description: The political leaders of southern Africa, both black and white, have begun what appear to be urgent diplomatic negotiations, though not yet with each other. But, as in the past. there is question whether diplomacy will be as fast or as effective as events in deciding the area's future.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND

Before I was finished, I had traversed Pontiac, Mercury and Cadillac Drive. It was a new neighborhood and there was no Edsel Street or GrahamPaige Boulevard.

title: Text of Declaration
description: National selfdetermination is a basic human right, universal and fundamental, recognized by all members of the United Nations, a right which may not be denied or withheld any nation regardless of its territorial size or number of inhabitants. Only the inhabitants of an historically determined and limited territory can objectively and competently prescribe its future trends and its own fate. Any force imposing itself against the desires of a nation can be termed nothing if not occupation, and, as is widely recognized, occupation is maintained exclusively by brutal force.

title: Miss Evert Retains Title, 63, 60; Connors and Borg Advance to Final

title: Harvard, Led by Kubacki, Favored to Retain Ivy Football Title
description: Ivy League coaches complained for years when their teams had to open against nonleague opponents that had held spring practice. These teams have an edge over the Ivies, who are not permitted to drill in the spring. The most notable example was the. PrincetonRutgers game. Now Ivy coaches have what they want and some are complaining even louder.

This ranking is taken from a survey made by the Council of State Governments.

title: ART
description: TRENTON THE presence of two outstanding and attractive quilts, on the walls of the State Museum here fills one with reassurance in variety of ways. For one thing, it is reassuring that the museum recognizes, and has recognized for some time, the esthetic value of quiltmaking, a folk Art that can amalgamate the best of color, design, imagination and craft. It also is reassuring to know that one cities not have to be an established artist in order to be represented in respectable institution like the State Museum. The criterion for judgment is, rather, that the art work be worthwhile, no matter who made it.

But one astounding figure has emerged from the mammoth New York convention that was held Aug. 2429 in the Americana Hotelthe fivesession auction, conducted by Stack's, grossed more than four million dollars! mere were 4,178 lots in the sale; the exact total of prices realized was $4,000,810which averages out to well over $950 per lot.

title: The Opera: Superlative Otello
description: Verdi's Otello Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House was the second production shown to New York by the visiting Paris Opera. It made an even stronger impression than Wednesday's Nozze di Figaro. This performance not only offered some superlative singing. It also was an ensemble performance, and an illustration of the fact that even the big international stars can work together as tightly and as dramatically convincingly as, say, the New York City Opera, which is primarily an ensemble house.

Wydler, Republican of Garden City, is trying to get the Federal bureaucracy down to basicsmainly, moneyin the long debate over whether to build a new office building at Mitchel Field. The idea of Isaac Stern and Friends, as the programs are called, literally originated in Mr. Stern's living room during evenings of informal music making.

Within this line of thinking, the English are reserved in their dancing, the Thissians are dramatic, the French have flair if not form, the Danes are charming and the Americans infuse their ballet dancing with an ingrained athleticism and exuberance.

title: At home with St. Mug
description: LONDON. Malcolm Muggeridge, a grinning, talking shadow, vanishes weekly from several million British parlors when the TV studio clock runs out, a painless rehearsal for the grand disappearance he expects before very much longer (he is 73). Since boyhood he has known spells when the living world felt a strange place, where he was a stranger. Psychologists have a name for this: depersonalization. Muggeridge calls it a peephole into reality, like the recurrent dream in which he stumbles onstage having studied a different script from everyone else.

title: ... Toward Equity
description: The tax bill has made some modest progress toward greater equity by increasing the minimum tax on. socalled preference income (that is, income shielded from regular income taxes). This will make it virtually impossible for the rich to avoid paying any taxesunless the whole of their income is derived from the interest on municipal bonds. But whatever their other deductions, they now would have to pay a tax of 15 percent on all other preference income after deducting either $10,000 or half the taxpayer's regular taxes, whichever is greater. Though still too generous, this is an improvement over the present situation that allows very, wealthy people to pay ridiculously low taxes.

Two SingerSongwriters Move to Center Stage
Opera:NiskainMakropoulos
description: The Makropoulos Affair. a wonderful. mysterious opera by Leos Janacek, made a welcome reentry to the New York City Opera repertory Friday night. One says welcome because Janacek's music is so haunting and idiosyncratically convincing, and the tale that it tells, based on a play by Karel Capek and sung in Norman Tucker's straightforward English translation, is full of strangely compelling poetry, for all its farcical oddities.

title: The Ultimate Judges and Victims

DEELEY Jr. [Opinion Page, Aug. 22] writes, We seem to be hearing more and more these days the argument that judges should sentence the crime rather than the criminal . . . I believe Justice Deeley touched on a very real problem that concerns our society todayour society, our laws and our safety. I see one of the problems in the criminaljustice system expressed in Justice Deeley's opening word, we. The judges must stop thinking of themselves as we and start including themselves in our society.

Heading News the fleet of over 300 boats of will be some of the biggest production yachts ever Boating turned out by American manufacturers. Manufacturers now are coming out with designs that were held in abeyance because of the recession. They've had the boats on the drawing boards but couldn't afford to build them before, says Frank Scalpone, the show manager and executive vice president of the N.A.E.B.M.

Cartouche, choreographed by Phoebe Neville, fit perfectly and in fact almost seemed designed for so large an area. The piece was seen on the New York Dance Festival's third program, Friday evening.

In the dark shadow of Vietnam, those were palmy days for artists and museums, a thriving period of artagogo, seemingly endless invention and the wherewithal to realize great plans. description: The Horsemen's Hall of Fame, now in its third year, is accepting nomination proposals for its next induction early next year. This is the first time we actually have made an announcement inviting proposals: In our first two years, we took inforHorse mal surveys of the entire horse world, says Bev Show Walter, one of the hall's News founders. Frank Chapot, captain of the United States Equestrian Team, was the first horseman inducted. Last year, Bill Steinkraus, the team's president, was chosen along with the late Earl Teeter, a wellknown saddlehorse trainer.

title: Saldana Wins Race
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 11 (AP)Joe Saldana surged past a struggling A. J. Foyt with 32 laps to go today and won $50,000 Hoosier Hundred. A fivecar pileup midway through the race took out most of the early leaders .and sent Jan Opperman to the hospital with head injuries. Foyt barely got into the 24car field, qualifying last for the United States Auto Club race. He gradually threaded his way through the pack and took the lead on the 53d lap of the 100 laps around the onemile Indiana State Fairgrounds track.

title: TV VIEW
description: Will the real Melvin Van Peebles please stand up? No, Mr. Van Peebles is not about to pop up grinning on To Tell the Truth. But he is making his debut on television, this Tuesday evening at 8:30 on CBS, as writer of a G.E. Theater presentation called Just an Old Sweet Song. The word sweet would appear to be one of his favorites. At least one interviewer, several years ago, noted that the black writer/entrepreneur liked to call people sweetie pie. And, of course, the project that brought him the most attention, if not notoriety, was the 1971 film Sweet Sweetback's Baadasssss Song, a film about, as he put it, the radicalization of a stud.

title: OTB Pushes for Theater Racing; Tracks Skeptical on Fan Impact

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY

With one child heading for graduate school and another a college freshman, my lovehate relationship with the public schoolswhich began when I was years old and continued through 18 years as a student, 12 as a teacher and 16 as parentis over.

title: Nerve de Vathaire Is Back.
description: Herve de Vathaire, the accountant who disappeared two months ago with $1.6 million and a bunch of secret files belonging to DassaultBregeut, the French conglomerate that manufactures the Mirage warplane, has returned voluntarily to Paris, but without the money. The case has intrigued the French because it has become more bizzare as time has passed. The President of Dassault, Marcel Dassault, publicly forgave his accountant on a national television broadcast, and welcomed him back as a prodigal son returned. Mr. de Vathaire, he said, was simply despondent over his wife's death earlier this year, and had fallen in with bad company. Police have said that Mr. de Vathaire no longer has the money, and they are looking for one of his acquaintances, a former mercenary named. Jean Kay.

title: The men in the middle
description: BOSTON. Policemen across the country began adding little Americad flag pins to their uniforms in the late 1960's to express their stand against what they saw as an assault on the nation's values by black mobs and student radicals. In Boston, which recruits most of its police force from its white ethnic neighborhoods, it is common to see a policeman wearing a small enamel pin on which the American flag is crossed with the green, white and orange tricolor of Ireland. Like the American flag alone, the crossed flags have represented patriotism, order, family, the established way of life. Now, however, the two flags could represent the deeply conflicted position of Boston's police, who are caught between clashing values of the neighborhoods and the law after the Federal court order to desegregate Boston's public schools. As this written, just before schools opened last week, Boston's police were coping with that conflict for the third straight year.

title: L.S.U. Ties Nebraska; Texas Falls

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: In 1893 Philip Armour, mainly of meatpacking fame, set out to test his talents (in the modern sense) and multiply them (in the biblical sense) by wagering that the price of wheat would go down. Accordingly, he sold wheat futures short on the Chicago Board of Trade. He put his money where his opinion was. Others (notably one Joseph Leiter, a young man come out of the East with his father's money) held the contrary opinion, and they too cast votes that countedin the election that is run off by taking positions in wheat futures.

My husband earns a good salary, she said, but because of inflation it's tough to get ahead on one salary.

Now, however, the banks that handle them have become snarled in the wrangle over the Arab boycott, currently going on in New York and Washington.

title: Mr. Sindona Is Arrested
description: Michele Sindona, the Italian financier who held a major interest in two large banks declared insolvent, has surrendered to authorities in New York City on a warrant for his extradition to Italy on fraud, charges. Italian officials allege that Mr. Sindona took about $225 million from three Italian banks, and then attempted to hide the theft by falsifying bank records. Mr. Sindona was also a director of the Franklin National Bank, whose failure here in 1974 was the largest in United States history. His surrender is likely to be only the start of a prolonged legal battle, since Mr. Sindona has vowed not to return to Italy unless the charges are dropped.

title: What's Doing Along the BRITTANY COAST
description: THE VISTABrittany is France's wetternmost protrusion into the Atlantic, known for rocky coasts, craggy cliffs and pocket harbors. Behind the dunes the province is all farms. There is little industrial activity, few large towns. Tourists favor the southern coast, where most of the sandy beaches and worthwhile sights are to be found, among them the alignments of prehistoric stone slabs (menhirs and dolmens) in the Carnac region. From east to west the bestknown beaches are Pornichet, La Baule, Carnac, Quiberon, ForetFouesnant, BegMeil and Audierne. Le Croisic, Quiberon and Lorient are charming old ports with centuriesold houses and small

title: Protecting the House Against Wood Rot
description: Most homeowners are aware of the potential threat that termites and other insects pose to the wooden parts of their house, but they often forget that the wood has one other constant natural enemywood rot. Although some people call it dry rot and others call it wet rot, both are actually talking about basically the same thinga form of decay or rot that is caused by tiny plantlike organisms known as fungi.
