title: Ideas &Trends
description: Scientists in Puerto Rico have taken detailed radar pictures of Venus, giving astronomers the first broad view of the planet's topographic features. The radar images are considered to be of high quality, almost like photographs. This alone is considered a significant step in planetary exploration, but what the pictures disclose is of major importance, too: processes at work on the earth and moon are also probably acting on Venus.

title: The Annals Of Apartments: Courtyards
description: At the turn of the century, affluent New Yorkers dreamed of Renaissance palaces, and when means allowed, built lavish, scaleddown examples along Fifth Avenue and Riverside Drive. Andrew Carnegie built one for himself on 91st Street. S. P. Morgan had Charles McKim execute his neoItalian Renaissance library. In the same classic tradition, with the same highminded and rather dreamy commitment to excellence, a handful of apartment housesa new breed of buildingwere erected like palaces too. The most imperial were literal translations of the Italian Renaissance palazzos, gracious dwellings distinguished by the fact that they were built around spacious, landscaped open courtyards.

title: Music:
description: There were three cast changes among the five principals in the Paris Opera's Le Nozze di Figaro Saturday evening, but even the weakest of the newcomers couldn't detract from the excellence of the whole. With Sir Georg Solti's refreshingly unaffected, clean, clear conducting; Giorgio Strehler's lively yet respectful production and a cast that included Jose Van Dam and Frederica von Stade as well as a host of capable smaller players, it was an evening to remember.

title: Man Drowns in Upstate Channel
description: KEUKA PARK, N.Y., Sept. 12 (AP)Gordon Laursen, 22 years old, of Penn Yan, drowned in a channel off Keuka Lake near her today, according to the village police and Yates County sheriff's deputies. Mr. Laursen jumped off a dock to swim to some friends about 50 yards away, called for help once and went under, the authorities said. His body was recovered about 15 minutes later.

Senator Dick Clark of Iowa, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on Africa, puts prospects for a Kissinger success as one in 25 or one in 30. On the face of it, the Senator's gloomy assessment seems more realistic than that of the Secretary.

Sands, who had been an advertising and public relations executive for many years for the Grace Line, the shipping concern, and then for PrudentiialGrace Lines and Chandris America Lines until his retirement in 1973, died Saturday of a heart attack in McLean, Va., where he was vacationing. They said the American President Lines ship ran aground off the northern Taiwan port in stormy seas several days ago.

title: ERNEST SCHEUER
description: Ernest Scheuer, a journalist and writer who became an international specialist on anthropology, ethnology and primitive art, died yesterday of cancer at the Carini Health Center. He lived in Manhattan and conducted his business from an office at 112 East 17th Street. He was 70 years old. He was born in Frankfurt, Germany, and was educated there. He was the editor of a SocialDemocrat newspaper in Berlin until he left in 1933 and went to Paris, where he worked for newspapers. He came to the United States in 1941. In World War II, he worked for the Office of War Information in New York. He survived by his wife, Rosi, and a daughter. Irene Scheuer.

The paper quoted a wellinformed source as saying the service had served a deficiency notice on Mr. Scott for 1973. A deficiency notice represents a conclusion by the Agency that the taxpayer failed to pay taxes on some income, but did so without any willful intent to defraud.

title: TV: Dylan Special, Hard Rain,
description: At the outset, I should try to outline my feelings about Bob Dylan, the composer/folk singer who is starring in his first television special tomorrow night at 10 on NBCTV. His material can be, and often is, brilliant, distilling the essence of a social group or cultural/ political movement. On the other hand, he is humanfrail, vulnerable and not beyond the entrapment of occasional misjudgments and mediocrity. I admire much of his work. I find some of it tedious, a few of his public posturings suspiciously tinged with opportunism. do not consider him a patron saint, but I also would not miss an opportunity to listen to him.

title: 'Edvard Munch,' Superlative Film By Watkins, Limns Life of Artist
description: Nothing that Peter Watkins, the English director ("The War Game," "Privilege," "Punishment Park"), has done before quite prepares us for the moving, complex, beautifully felt portrait of the great Norwegian artist Edvard Munch (1863-1944), one of the most influential painters in the founding and defining of European Expressionism.The film "Edvard Munch," which opened yesterday at the Festival Theater, 6 West 57th Street, is one of the few ever to dramatize successfully the sensitivity, the profound emotional chaos and the discipline that occasionally combine to produce the special molecular structure of a major artist.At the heart of this portrait there remains the mystery of the creative process  still unsolved  which is the way it should be. What Mr. Watkins has succeeded in doing is to suggest the multiplicity of psychological and social factors at work on the man, using a narrative form that is simultaneously journalistic and as freely associated as a dream.In the past, the director's fondness for a simulated cinma vrit style has resulted in ludicrous anachronismsfacetious television interviews with people on the point of being gunned to death, hand-held camera footage of situations unlikely to be recorded even by a secreted Kodak Brownie. The method got in front of the subject and then ridiculed it. Not so this time.The style is now muted. When members of Munch's family, his friends, associates, critics and contemporaries talk directly to the camera, it's the perfectly acceptable device of fiction that's been used by Bergman, Godard and others. You don't get the queasy "You Are There" feeling that you once got when Walter Cronkite interviewed Julius Caesar on his way to the Forum."Edvard Munch" is a long film just under three hours. It covers the painter's life from his child hood when, as he wrote, "illness insanity and death were the black angels that kept watch over my cradle," until 1908 when, at the age of 45, he had completed his important "Frieze of Life" paintings and was slipping into nervous collapse.Art historians may object that this hardly gives a complete picture of the man who, though tormented, perhaps psychotic, continued to work fruitfully with increasing recognition for another 35 years, dying at 80, a substantial age for anyone but especially for someone so ravaged by the demons within.That may be so, but "Edvard Munch," though it's based upon the life and celebrates the talent of a real artist, is fiction, as are all films except possibly newsreels. The form that Mr. Watkins has imposed on the material illuminates a major part of that life, the obsessions that drove Munch to his seminal attempts to express visually states of mind, including his own anxieties, his fears, his longings to reach to others through love that was was both spiritual and intensely sexual.The two major themes of the film are his death-haunted childhood in Oslo (then Cristiania), when his sister and his mother both died of tuberculosis, and a tumultuous love affair with a still-anonymous married woman identified only as Mrs. Heiberg.In the manner of an obsessed mind, the film keeps returning to images of his dying sister and to those of later humiliations at the hands of Mrs. Heiberg. At the same time, Mr. Watkins gives us what is virtually a documentary report on the conservative, middle-class, puritan society that shaped his life, a society where (in 1884) prostitution was legalized but there were no laws against child labor.The movie cuts almost manically back and forth among a half-dozen different periods of time like the thoughts of a man on a couchfrom the childhood of disease and death, to disastrous exhibitions in Norway and Germany, to the unhappy love affairs, to youthful discussions in Cristiania's little bohemia, to the later encounters with celebrate dcontemporaries, including Strindberg.We see the artist painting and a number of his canvases, woodcuts and lithographs, but the emphasis is on the man and his time, as the director seems to understand that he can't recreate the process by which these extraordinary works came into being.Geir Westby is fine as the artist whose vision we share in much of the beautiful color-camerawork by Odd Geir Saether. Gro Fraas, whose looks recall Liv Ullmann's, plays Mrs. Heiberg, seeming to be as arbitrary, untrustworthy and tender to us as to Munch. The film, shot in Norway by Mr. Watkins, has Norwegian, Swedish, French and German dialogue, translated by subtitles, as well as English narration based on Munch's own letters and journals.Admittedly the competition isn't great, but "Edvard Munch" must be one of the few films about a serious artist that can be taken seriously.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Newark Board of Education was to appear in Superior Court today to seek an injunction against a strike by the 2,500 noninstructional employees in the state's largest public school system. Workers in various service areas, including those employed in cafeterias and those responsible for maintenance of the city's 100 schools, yesterday voted overwhelmingly to begin striking this morning. Carl Dawson, president of the Board of Education, characterized the job action as ridiculous. He said the School Board had offered its noninstructional employees an 8.5 percent wage increase over two years, the same given earlier this to the Newark Teachers Union.

Stern and Dr. Margaret Lora Ewing, a pediatrician he met at a Park Lincoln Free Democrats meeting two years ago, were married yesterday at the Park East Synagogue. I'm really. happy I met someone like Peggy. He feels certain that his demanding politicial career, involving as it does many evening meetings, will fit in nicely with his wife's profession.

title: 21 Bald Eagles Hatch in Maine

title: Colts Pin 2713 Loss On Patriots
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Sept. 12Robert Irsay, the owner of the Baltimore Colts, played the game under wraps. He did not go down to the sidelines to exhort his athletes during the second half and he did not enter the locker room afterward for more of the same. Left to their own devices the Colts defeated the New England Patriots, 2713, today, helped by the home team's ineptitude, and the Colt players and coaches regarded the outcome as a silent message to the owner and the general manager, Joe Thomas. The message? Just leave us alone.

But the full House of Representatives, acting under the pressure of C.I.A. and Mministration charges that the report did endanger national, security, voted 246 to 124 to keep the report secret.

title: The Arab Boycott
description: The Arab boycott against Israel raises difficult politiCal, economic, legal and moral issues for the United States. The boycott is repugnant. It violates American principles and laws when it requires American companies, as a condition for doing business with Arab countries, to discriminate against American citizens because of their religion. It unfairly imposes secondary boycotts against American companies that hire Jewish employees or directors, or trade with Israel.

East River 250 feet below. He really wanted help, of course, said Officer Richard Powers pointing at left) who led an Emergency Service rescue team that gave it to him. When they were just three feet away Mr. Maldonado suddenly grabbed the hand rail above and dangled beside the cable.

title: YUGOSLAVIA ASSAILS ES. ON JET HIJACKING

title: Police Fire at Demonstrators
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 13TheSouth African police fired birdshot and tear gas today at crowds Of black demonstrators who were attempting to enforce a work boycott among black commuters from the suburb of Soweto. The demonstrators succeeded in persuading about half of the 320,000 commuters not to go to work.

title: Women's Fete Screens Film Made in Japan
description: "Being a wife is important, but it's even more important to be a woman," says the spunky heroine of Kinuyo Tanaka's "Love Under the Crucifix," the Japanese film that opened the second International Festival of Women's Films at the Cinema Studio. The heroine goes on to add, rather damply, "A woman must live for love."That's hardly the gospel according to Erica Jong, but those would have been revolutionary words in the late 16th century, which is the period of Miss Tanaka's stately melodrama about a well brought-up young woman, a convert to Christianity, which was then about to be suppressed in Japan, who chooses something other than dishonor when faced with the prospect of becoming the regent's newest concubine."Love Under the Crucifix" doesn't have very much to do with Christianity, though its heroine wears a cross and has taken a vow of chastity because the man she loves, who is Christian, is married. It has more to do with various Japanese interpretations of honor and sacrifice, this time seen largely from a woman's point of view.Of more interest than the film ifself, a sort of feudal soap-opera that was made in 1960, is Kinuyo Tanaka, who is apparently Japan's only woman director. Born in 1910, she was one of the country's leading film actresses during the 30's and 40's and turned to directing in the 50's. Students of Mizoguchi's films will remember her performances in "Life of O-Haru" and "Sansho the Bailiff."The film will be shown again today at 6 P.M. and tomorrow at 8 P.M. The color print is not in the best condition.Two showings last night of "Lumire," Jeanne Moreau's first film as a director, were the highlight of the opening. That film will be reviewed when it opens its commercial run later in the year.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Board Allows Wilkins To Remain in Job Till Next Aug.

title: Strategists Say World Peacekeeping System Is Failing
description: BADEN. Austria, Sept. 12The politicalmilitary system that has more or less kept global order since World War II is breaking down and nothing is in sight to replace it, in the view of 200 scholars, government officials and military experts who have been meeting here for the last four days.

title: Article 14  No Title
description: IMPRINT FOR ALL PUBLICATIONS

title: Edward Maguire, 77, Labor Lawyer And Adviser to La Guardia, Is Dead
description: Edward C. Maguire, a labor lawyer and adviser to Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, died yesterday at his home, 130 East 39th Street. He was 77 years old.

title: $39 Million Complex Dedicated In Newark for Essex College
description: NEWARK, Sept. 13 (AP) A crowd of nearly 2,000 people gathered to dedicate the $39.6 million Essex County College complex in downtown Newark yesterday.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Monday, September 13, 1976 NEW HIGHS 100

title: Klan Leader Arrested in Scuffle
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 13The selfproclaimed national grand dragon of the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan was arrested yesterday on a charge of inciting to riot because of a scuffle with sheriff's deputies. David Duke, 26 years old, of Baton Rouge was arrested by the state police and released on bond a few hours later, He was one of four persons arrested in connection with an incident at Klan meeting in suburban Metairie, Jefferson Parish, sheriff's deputies said.

title: Voters Can Telephone To Find Polling Sites
description: Voters confused about the whereabouts of their polling places in New York City may telephone a special number2679800for information, the Board of Elections said yesterday.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Sept. Lsraces Wail a logjam of pending legislation, Speaker Joseph A. LeFante of Bayonne today scheduled three meetings of the State Assembly.

title: Insurgent Steel Union Campaign Begun With Attack on Abel, Meany
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 13Ed Sadlowski. the 38yearold insurgent steelworker from Chicago's South Side, formally announced today his candidacy for the presidency of the United Steelworkers of America, the largest industrial union in the country.

title: No Tears for the Giants
description: With the death of Mao Tsetung the age of giants is closed at last. To mourn it would take a heart of stone, for it has been barbarian's passage through oceans of blood and the charnel it washed on the shore makes Attila seem in retrospect as fetching as Peck's Bad Boy.

title: DialaPhone System Has Southern Roots
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 10  It happens to almost everyone sooner or later. It's late, toe electric ciock has stopped, you forgot to wind your Bulova and your chic $150 Mickey Mouse watch fell down the garbage disposal a week zeo.

title: ALLON ASSAILS A PLAN TO CURB GALILEE ARABS
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 13 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Yigal Allon denounced as a miserable document today a report by a Government official who recommended curbs on Arab population growth in Galilee.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 14, 1976 president of the union, said the company's revised offer left too big a gap to be bridged before the deadline. A company spokesman said he was not optimistic. [1:12.]

title: Yugoslavia Detains 4 Air Controllers In Zagreb Collision
description: ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Sept. 13 (Reuters) Four Yugoslav air traffic controllers will remain in custody on suspicion of responsibility for the plane collision on Friday in which 176 people died, a judge said here today.

title: Tax Reform Act Seeks To End Home Deduction
description: The end of the deduction for the part time use of a home as an office is at hand if the Tax Reform Act of 1976 becomes law. This deduction a favorite of parttime, writers, teachers and many others would be ended for most taxpayers under provisions agreed upon by members of the HouseSenate Conference Committee that ironed out the differences in the bills nassed by each chamber.

title: Chance of Averting a Ford Strike, Due at Midnight, Is Put at 1 in 100
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 13It appeared all but certain today that the United Automobile Workers would strike the Ford Motor Company at midnight tomorrow.

title: School Year Begins in New York With Numerous Signs of Cutbacks
description: The new school year got under way in New York City yesterday with many teachers and pupilsdespite some openingday confusion and uncertaintytrying to adjust to large classes and reductions in services caused by the system's financial predicament.

title: WOOLWORTH TO SELL ITS CREDIT OPERATION
description: The F. W. Woolworth Company announced plans yesterday for the sale of about $175 million in customer accounts receivable of its Woolco and Woolworth department store operations in this country to the General Electric Credit Corporation.

title: Audit Finds DayCare Syndicates Share Leases to File Tax Losses
description: Guaranteed profits and tax shelters available from ownership of daycare centers have spawned closely knit syndicates that share leases acid churn .them among themselves, according to auditors in the office of the New York City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin.

title: Bridge:
description: Anyone who wished to prove that women bridge players were tougher than men could point to Mamie Lee of New York. This wellknown expert was in a serious automobile accident two weeks ago while returning from a New Jersey tournament.

title: Greenspan
description: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said yesterday that new evidence of increased consumer spending and capital expenditure commitments by industry showed that a reacceleration of the current economic recovery was in process of gettine under way.

title: NEW SUNSHINE LAW GIVES PUBLIC ACCESS TO FEDERAL RECORDS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 President Ford signed into law today the Government in Sunshine Act requiring many Federal agencies to open their meetings and their records to the public.

title: Article 7  No Title
Student Survives 5Story Fall
description: BOSTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)A student from Livingston, N.J., has survived a fivestory plunge from a dormitory window at Grahm Junior College. The student, Denise Berardo, 19 years old, landed on the roof of an adjacent building, where she was found by a policeman Saturday morning. Miss Berardo told the police that the fall had been an accident. She was taken to Beth Israel Hospital with an injured right arm and leg and numerous internal injuries and was in stable condition today.

title: Around the Nation
description: BRIGHTON, Fla., Sept. 18 (AP)Fivo persons were killed today when an Air Force Phantom jet and a small civilian plane collided over a swampy area near Lake Okeechobee, the authorities said.

title: Chicago's Stunning Architectural Quality Lacks Diversity
description: CHICAGOIt is a milestone of sorts to be invited from the provinces to America's first city of architecture.

title: Memorial Services
Corporation Affairs Shell UK and Esso Fail to Agree on British Plan
description: Representatives of Shell UK Ltd. and Esso Petroleum Ltd., meeting in London yesterday, were unable to agree to British Government proposals for its participation in their North Sea oil operations. It was understood representatives of the two companies met for three hours with Anthony Wedgwood Benn, British Secretary of State for Enerev Affairs.

title: Gromyko Leads Soviet Delegation To Sign Condolence Book for Mao
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 13 (UPI)Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko led a fourmember Soviet delegation to the Chinese Embassy today to sign a book of condolences on the death of Chairman Mao Tsetung.

title: Advertising
description: John E. O'Toole, the silvertongued president of Foote, Cone & Belding, will be in Los Angeles tomorrow to give a speech entitled What I did on my summer vacation. Has a familiar ring, hasn't it ?

title: DEMOCRATS WIND UP 5WAY SENATE DRIVE
description: Hours before the New York state primary polls opened, five Democratic contenders for the United States Senate wound up their campaigns last night as they Had begundebating nuances and images rather than substantive differences.

title: Bishop's Compromise Proposal on Ordination of Women Stirs Varying Reactions at Episcopal Convention
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 13The comproraise proposal by the Presiding Bishop, John M. Allin, that women be ordained to the priesthood in areas that would accept them has evoked strong but widely differing reactions from delegates to the Episcopal convention here.

title: It's the Debbie Reynolds Show, ForVariety,Vaudeville and Fun
description: A week before her Broadway opening, Debbie Reynolds stopped traffic on West 45th Street. I hate heights, but there's nothing duller than another picture of Debbie Reynolds, she had said to the photographer, and up she climbed to the top of the Minskoff Theater marquee to pose, waving to the crowd below and wailing cheerfully about the dirt on her precarious perch. Cab drivers screeched to a halt, policemen shook their heads and laughed helplessly and the fans loved it.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CITY OF OPPORTUNITY Outlanders often accuse New Yorkers of being knowitalls. It can't be helped. Living here has some drawbacks, but there is just so much going on that those who take advantage of the city have to be better informed. An example of this is the extraordinary African Woman/African Art exhibition that opens today at the AfricanAmerican Institute.

title: Article 6  No Title
Use of Police Red Squad
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 13The Civil Service Commission, which has the responsibility for investigating the backgrounds of most applicants for Federal jobs, has routinely relied on the subversive intelligence files of local police agencies as source material in such inquides, according to a House subcommittee.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL ON PLANE LOST IN THE PHILIPPINES
description: MANILA, Tuesday, Sept 14AP)A plane carrying American, German and Japanese officials has vanished in a tropical storm and the search for it has been hampered by heavy rain, the Manila rescue coordinating center said early today.

title: Israeli Court Bars Bankers Trust From Seizing Refrigerated Ships
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 13An Admiralty Court in Haifa has temporarily blocked the Bankers Trust Company of New York and other creditors from disposing of five refrigerated ships sailing under the Israeli flag and impounded in Britain, West Germany and Japan for alleged default debts.

title: Religious Groups Open Campaign To DefeatGambling in Referendum
description: TRENTON. Sept. 13A coalition of religious groups opened a drive today to defeat a proposed constitutional amendment that would authorize casino gambling at Atlantic City, and said it would file suit in Superior Court here to prevent the proposal from appearing on the ballot an Nov. 2.

title: Vietnam at the U.N.
description: The application of unified Vietnam for membership in the United Nations is scheduled to come before the Security Council today. President Ford has ordered Ambassador Scranton to cast a United States veto. Twice before, the United States has vetoed Vietnamese membership, first on the ground that the two separate governments of North and South were insufficiently established in authority, and thenwhen that pretext fell apartbecause the world body would not at the same time consider membership for the two Koreas. Now that second excuse has also collapsed: Vietnam is no longer a divided country; the old goal of unification has clearly been achieved under Hanoi's Communist leadership. The dubious Korean connection is no longer relevant.

title: U.S. DECIDES TO VETO VIETNAM'S REQUEST FOR U.N. MEMBERSHIP
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13President Ford directed the United States delegation today to veto Vietnam's application for membership in the United Nations.

title: Oldest Federal Inmate Dies Before Parole
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)The Federal Government's oldest prisoner. Vicente Sanza, has died at 83 after half a century behind bars.

title: American Bank Avoids Comment
description: The American Bank and Trust Company, a New York institution under study by bank examiners concerned about its financial stability, declined yesterday comment on reports that it had millions of dollars in problem loans coupled with declining deposits.

title: New Yorkers Continuing to Bet on Instant Lottery
description: Heavy sales of the instant lottery tickets continued throughout the state yesterday, according to officials in charge of New York's newest game of chance.

title: SHADOW COMMITTEE CALLS TO EXTEND MONEY GROWTH
description: The Shadow Open Market Committee, a group of business and academic econ omists who meet semiannually to criticize Federal Reserve policy, issued yesterday a policy statement calling for continued moderate growth in the nation's money supplycurrency and deirand deposits.

title: California Sued Over Practice of Investigating Prospective Jurors and Selling Reports to Lawyers!
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13A legi, attack on the practice of investigating jurors and selling the reports to trial lawyers was opened here today by Godfrey Lehman, an advertising man who has served on three jury panels over the last 20 years.

title: New Bond Issues
26,000 PETITIONS SIGNED BY M'CARTHY SUPPORTERS
description: The independent Presidential campaign of former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy met its deadline yesterday and filed what its coordinators believe were petitions containing enough signatures to get their candidate on the ballot in New York State.

title: Big Board Seat Price Declines
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported a seat sale yesterday at $80,000, down sharply from the last sale at $95,000 on Aug. 13. Brokers were offering to buy seats at $66.000 while seats were being offered for sale at $94,000.

title: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title
MAJ. GEN. ROBERT TAYLOR, HEADED ATOMIC BOMB UNIT
description: SOUTH LAGUNA, Calif. Sept. 13 (AP)Maj. Gen. Robert K. Taylor. the Man who commanded the United States Army Air Corps unit that dropped the first atomic bomb at the close of World War II. is dead. He was 74 years old.

title: Devout Catholic and Unionist
description: DETROIT, Sept. 13It was 9:30 A.M.. and negotiators for the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers were about to begin another round of bargaining talks on a new threeyear contract for the 165.000 Ford workers rep

title: Ford to Delay Ads on TV Until After First Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13President Ford's strategists have decided not to start his campaign advertising on television until three days after his first debate with Jimmy Carter, even though this means that such commercials for the Democratic nominee will have a head start.

title: Chess:
description: Wilhelm Steinitz, world champion from 1866 to 1894, remarked that if you want to refute a gambit, you have to accept it. He was right, in general, ;although in the case of such a formidable, weapon of counterattack as the Marshall gambit, one may well give up the idea of a refutation and search for a reasonable way to decline it and stay nut of trouble.

title: Jersey City Strike In Public Schools Coming to an End
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 13A tentative contract agreement was reached today on the fifth day of a strike by 2,000 teachers here. The terms of the agreement were not disclosed pending a ratification vote by union members tonight and tomorrow.

title: Deauville Gang Hits the Jackpot
description: DEAUVILLE, Franc. Sept. 13 (UPIFour masked gunmen broke into the Deauville casino at closipg time early today and took $600.000 from customers, croupiers and an open safft.

title: Hard Line
description: The weekend hijacking to Paris of New YorktoChicago airliner has accelerated a process of official rethinking on how to deal with terrorists while the lives of hostages are regarded to be in jeopardy.

title: Man, 22, Dies of Injuries Suffered In Washington Sq. Gang Rampage
description: A 22yearold man who was clubbed in the head last Wednesday night during a gang attack on blacks and Hispanic people in Washington Square Park died Sunday night without regaining consciousness.

title: Notes on People
description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, one of the finalists whom President Ford did not pick as his VicePresidential running mate, and Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, were among the 10member delegation named by Mr. Ford yesterday for the United Nations General Assembly session beginning Sept.

title: Head of G.O.P. In Suffolk Says He'll Quit Jan. 1
description: BLUE POINT,L.I., Sept. 13 The Suffolk County Republican committee chairman, Edwin M. Schwenk, declared today he would resign his party job in January. He has served for the last eight years.

title: Gold Drops $1.50 an Ounce, Reflecting Apprehensions Over Auction
description: LONDON, Sept, 13 (AP) The price of gold closed $1.50 an ounce lower in London today at $114.875 in apprehensive trading prior to Wednesday's gold auction by the International Monetary Fund in Washington. The United States dollar had a mixed day.

title: Manufacturers Hanover Expects Profit to Gain
description: Earnings of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation in the third quarter of this year will show improvement over this year's second quarter and over the third quarter of 1975. Gabriel Hauge, the company's chairman, predicted yesterday. Mr. Hauge provided no doller estimates, but he made it clear that he expected improvement.

title: Bid to Grumman For Nixon Fund In '72 Is Charged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 The former head of a Grumman Corporation subsidiary told a Senate subcommittee today that a White House aide urged the company to contribute $1 million to the 1972 Republican reelection campaign in return for .President Richard M. Nixon's assistance in arranging an aircraft sale to Japan.

title: Britton Takes City Golf By 12 Strokes With 66
description: Bill Britton, the 20yearold metropolitan amateur golf champion, scored. a 66 and won the New Yok City public links championship Sunday by ]2 strokes at the 6,540yard LaTourette course. The Staten Islander became the first man to hold both the city and district titles in the same year.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Mixed at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  Yields were mixed on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Friday to Be Citizenship Day
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)President Ford today designated Friday, Sept. 17, the 189th anniversary of the signing of the Constitution, as Citizenship Day. In a proclamation, he also designated the period from Sept. 1723 as Constitution Week.

title: Article 3  No Title

10YEAR NOTES DROP TO BELOW 8% LEVEL
description: The investment return on 10year notes sold by banks fell below 8 percent yesterday as the Northwest Bancorporation, a wellregarded Minneapolisbased company that owns 81 banks in seven states, agreed to terms of $75 million of

title: Jersey CriminalCase Backlog In U.S. Court Said to Clear Up
description: NEWARK, Sept. 13 (AP)United States Attorney Jonathan L. Goldstein says that the once heavy backlog of criminal cases in New Jersey's Federal rnurts has been cleared uo.

title: A STRIKE IS STARTED BY INMATES IN BRONX
description: Inmates at the Bronx House of Detention began a peaceful strike yesterday, protesting visiting restrictions, *hat they termed excessive bail and the lack of speedy tridts and other phases of the criminal justice system.

title: Levi Strauss Reports Payments
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Levi Strauss & Company disclosed today in a document filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it made questionable foreign payments of about $70,000 through three foreign subsidiaries in 1974 and 1975. This was in addition to $75,000 in similar payments the company reported earlier this year. The San Franciscobased denimproducts producer said no officers or directors had any prior knowledge of the payments and that its investigation was now ended:

title: Commodity Futures Commission Plans Options Trading Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)The Commodity Futures Trading Commission voted unanimously today to begin draft; ing regulations for trading in commodity options in such goods as coffee, cocoa, gold and silver.

title: Reagan Will Help Gov. Thomson
description: CONCORD, N. H., Sept. 13 (UPI)Ronald Reagan will visit New Hampshire on Oct. 1 to help the state Republican Party and to help his good friend, Gov. Meldrim Thomson, the Governor's campaign office said today. The Governor seeking reelection. His office said plans were still sketchy but that Mr. Reagan might make two speeches, one in Concord and one in Manchester.

title: Fire Cuts Power, Strands Thousands In Downtown Area
description: Thousands of workers in seven office buildings near the Battery were affected yesterday by a series of power blackouts; that trapped some in elevators, forced the evacuation of others from offices and left large crowds milling about on sidewalks, unable to return from lunch hours.

title: Todd Pleased at His Efforts in Brief Debut With Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, Li., Sept. 13As he has been in every practice since 1965, Joe Namath was the Jets No. 1 quarterback today. As always, he was watched by an understudy.

title: Key Canadian Aide Will Quit Cabinet In Planned Shuffle
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 13 (AP)The leader of the governing party in the House of Commons, Mitchell Sharp, has delivered his resignation to Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and says he will not seek reelection to the House in 1978.

title: Rolling Stone Is Tilting Toward the East Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13Rolling Stone magazine was born here in 1967 as a balladier sang about going to San Eancisco with flowers in your hair and tens of thousands of young people responded with an influx that was named the summer of love.

title: China's Military Now Expected to Play a Bigger Role
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 13The Chinese armed forces are suddenly being given heightened public attention and could play a key role in any struggle for leadership of China following the death of Chairman Mao Tsetung, analysts here believe.

title: Model School in Bronx Forced To Drop Many of Its Programs
description: Public School 152 in the Bronx is supposed to be a model of what a bigcity elementary school can be.

title: Drought in Wales Is Forcing Monsanto to Drill for Water
description: LONDON, Sept. 13The Monsanto Company started drilling for water today in the dusty earth around its factories in southeastern Wales. It also reserved 36 railroad tank cars to haul water into the plants if necessary.

title: WARNACO DISCLOSES RECEIPT OF FUNDS FROM OCEAN CARRIER
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 13Warnaco Inc., has made what is believed to be the first admission by a company that it was on the receiving end of questionable payments, according to a document made available by the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

Yonkers Racing

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Board of Collective Bargammg affirmed the award of an impasse panel calling for a shorter work day for police officers and also dismissed an appeal of the award by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. Police Department officials have indicated that new work schedules, incorporating an eightandaquarterhour day rather than the present eightandonehalfhour day, will go into effect early . next month. As a result, police officers will have to work 10 additional days over the year.

title: Driver of Bus In Kidnapping Is Back on Job
description: CHOWCHILLA, Calif., Sept. 13Surrounded by reporters, photographers and television crews, Frank Edward Ray drove his school bus today for the first time officially since July 15, when it was stopped on a country road near here and he and 26 children aboard the bus were kidnapped.

title: CHICAGO CONCERN LINKED TO HOME RESALE FRAUD
description: CHICAGO, Sept 13 (UPI)Federal officials said today that an investigation is norlerway into disclosures that a South side contracting concern brought up s( ores of abandoned houses from the FedGovernment, performed cheap repairs and sold them for large profits.

title: 1 Killed, 9 Hurt as Truck Hits Van
description: One perscn was killed and nine others were injured early this morning when a Texaco gasoline truck collided with a van at West 18th Street and Seventh Avenue in Lower Manhattan, the police reported.

description: A winner for the third straight time since he shook off a drought of eight weeks in which he could not win game, Seaver struck out 12 Pirates and walked only one. In only one inning did Pittsburgh pose a serious threat.
