title: 12 States Hold Primaries Today; Kennedy and Humphrey Opposed
description: Twelve states conduct primary elections today in the year's biggest day of selection for Congressional and state offices.

title: KIDDE IS EXPECTING TO SELL U.S. LINES
description: A spokesman for Walter Kidde & Cornpany disclosed yesterday that it had eceived a number of bids for its United itates Lines and subsidiary and that xpected a sale to be completed within he next several weeks. The shinning

title: Leader of Florida Terror Gang Facing Term of Up to 120 Years
description: BARTOW, Fla., Sept. 13 (AP)The man police identified as the leader of a skkimasked gang that invaded and looted rural homes and terrorized their victims in central Florida last year as sentenced today to 99 years in prison, to be served after he completes a 30year term on an earlier conviction.

title: Women's Demands for Equality in Money Are Threatening $11 Million Tennis Tour
description: Jimmy Connors collected $30,000 for beating Bjorn Borg in a 3hourl0minute men's singles final at the United States Open tennis championships on Sunday.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Article 4  No Title
Taxes &
description: If the figures don't lie, public accounting, despite its staid image, may be one of the glamour professions of the 1970's for college students. The reason, according to Charles G. Steele, the partner in charge of personnel and administration at Haskins & Sells, is simply that jobs are available for graduates in the profession.

title: A Democratic Drive Aims at Registering New York's Voters
description: Acting on the premise than an unregtrs tered voter is a Democrat who got away, the New York State's top Democrats yesterday opened a drive to register 2.1 million voters in the three weeks left before registration closes for the Nov. 2 general election.

title: The Dance: Park Festival Ends
description: For its last program, the New York Dance Festival came up with an evening of inspired mediocrity Sunday night at Central Park's Delacorte Theater. Most of the inspiration was visible in the ideas behind the six works, including two premieres, that were on view, but it was the flawed realization of these ideas that accounted for the mediocrity.

title: TANZANIAN STRESSES SOUTHWEST AFRICA
description: ZURICH, Sept. 13President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania was reported today to prefer that Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger give priority to resolving the question of independence for SouthWest Africarather than black majority rule in Rhodesiaduring Mr. Kissinger's African trip.

title: China's Military Now Expected to Play a Bigger Role
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 13The Chinese armed forces are suddenly being given heightened public attention and could play a key role in any struggle for leadership of China following the death of Chairman Mao Tsetung, analysts here believe.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 14, 1976

title: Indians Win Suit Against Railroad
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 (AP) A Federal appellate court ruled today that the Southern Pacific Railway does not own the rightofway and never has had a revocable license to operate 24.75 miles of mainline track on an Indian reservation in western Nevada.

title: Bills Lose To Dolphins; O.J. Plays
description: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y., Sept 13O. J. Simpson's reappearance in the Buffalo lineup was a matter of cool indifference to the Miami team tonight as the Dolphins defeated the Bills, 3021, before a crowd of 77,683 that filled almost every seat in Rich Stadium. The Dolphins displayed a precise and methodical offense that scored 13 points in the second half to bring Miami its 13th straight victory over Buffalo.

title: Geologists Fascinated and Puzzled by Shape of Mars
description: The expeditions to Mars of Viking and 2 have aroused worldwide interest in the possibility of finding some form of life on that planet.

title: Books of The Times
description: The great hurricane that hit the northeast corner of the United States on Wednesday, Sept. 21, 1938, was one of the worst natural disasters in American history. It is estimated to have taken 680 lives and cost $400 million in property damage, compared with parallel figures of 450 and $350 million for the San Francisco earthquake and fire of 1906, and 200 and $200 million for the Chicago fire of 1871. (Also: some 26,000 automobiles were smashed; 275 million trees were downed; and more than 6,000 boats lost damaged.)

title: Quintuplets Born in France
description: DIJON, France, Sept. 13 (AP)A French woman gave birth to quintuplets three girls and two boysin a Dijon hospital early today, but only the boys survived, doctors said..

title: Badillo and Velez Trade Charges Of Dictator
description: In a climax to a bitter primary campaign, Representative Herman Badillo yesterday accused his challenger, Councilman Ramon S. Valez, of running dictatorship in the South Bronx that included intimidation of poverty workers.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Trooper and Suspect Shot in Gun Battle

title: Schorr Says Earlier Publication Of Pike Report Obviates Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13In refusing to disclose how he obtained the Pike committee's intelligence report, Daniel Schorr will charge before the House ethics committee Wednesday that the investigation is irrelevant, since most of the document was published by The New York Times before it appeared in The Village Voice.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Article 12  No Title
Hijackers Were Cleared After a Thorough Search Before Boarding Airliner
description: Two gray cooking pots that Croatian nationalists used as fake bombs to hijack a Trans World Airlines jet plane last weekend were examined by guards during a preflight baggage search at La Guardia Airport, a security company official said yesterday.

title: Seaver Tops Pirates, 50, Fans 12 in Fifth Shutout
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 13Describing his performance by saying, I couldn't throw any better than that, Torn Seaver tonight slowed the Pittsburgh Pirates pursuit of the Philadelphia Phillies, allowing just five hits in a 50 victory for the Mets at Three Rivers Stadium.

title: AUTO STRIKE FEARS SEND MARKET DOWN
description: Fears of a strike against the Ford Motor Company sent the stock market moderately lower yesterday in continued slow tradintt.

title: A.T.&T. Describes Its Policy on Releasing Unlisted Phone Numbers to Law Enforcement Agencies
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, as a matter of national policy, recommends that its member companies release unlisted telephone numbers to law enforcement agencies or other governmental units that have subpoena power. The policy does not require that affiliates insist on subpoenas.

title: TV: An Old Sweet Song
description: Last year an executive producer, Lionel Ephraim, and an agent, Tony Ford of William Morris, had an idea about doing a television drama on the subject of reverse migration, the phenomenon of Northern blacks returning to the South. MTM Enterprises then hired Melvin Van Peebles to write the script. Mr. Van Peebles had a somewhat unwarranted reputation for being an abrasive militant in his work, hut MTM took a chance on his devising something suitable for television.

title: APARTMENT OWNER HELD FOR ARSON IN HARTFORD
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 13 (AP)An apartment building owner, beaten by tenants as he watched a fire damage his building last night, was arrested on arson charges today, the police said.

title: FORD PLANS TO ISSUE NUCLEAR GUIDELINES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13President Ford is preparing to make a comprehensive statement soon setting national and international guidelines for United States nuclear policy, three highranking Administration officials reported today.

title: The Right to Write and to Read
description: As a writer, I have always fought for the right to write, for writing is a timehonored means of communication. Lack of communication, the refusal of some to understand, or outright refusal to learn about other human beings is based on fear. Fear is what keeps people apart.

title: Opera: La Scala's
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  verai Simon Boccanegra is an opera that is in and out of the repertory. It was a failure at its premiere in 1857, but Verdi thought a great deal of the score and revised it in 1881. Like Don Carlo, also revised, it contains elements of middle period and late Verdi. Its glorious moments, such as the great Act 1 finale, or the third act trio, make occasional performances mandatory. But there are some dull stretches, and it has never really been an audience favorite.

title: Article 9  No Title
The New York Primaries
description: In the contest for United States Senator in today's New York primary election, The New York Times has endorsed Daniel Patrick Moynihan for the Democratic nomination and Representative Peter A. Peyser for the Republican nomination.

title: $250 Million of Notes To Be Repaid Today
description: New York State will repay today $250 million of 8.70 percent oneyear notes, the highestyielding publicly offered oneyear issue ever sold by the state, the controller's office said yesterday.

title: Equus
description: Although Equus closed its long Broadway engagement last Saturday, Peter Shaffer's hit drama is already set to return. It will reopen Oct. 5 at the Helen Hayes Theater, with Anthony Perkins again playing the starring role of Dr. Martin Dysart.

title: Canada's Prime Minister Announces a ShakeUp Affecting 16 in Cabinet
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 14 (Reuters)Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada announced three Cabinet resignations tonight including the unexpected departure of Postmaster General Bryce Mackasey. The changes affected 16 ministers.

title: Article 4  No Title
Japanese Cabinet Quits, Clearing the Way Today For Leadership Changes
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept, 15 (UPI)Prime Minister Taken Miki is scheduled to make sweeping changes in his conservative Cabinet and party leadership today in an attempt to end the political turmoil resulting from the Lockheed payoff scandal.

title: $125,000 Award in Death is Upset
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn, reversing both himself and a jury, has set aside an award of $125,000 to the parents of George Haber an 18yearold youth shot to death Sept. 29. 1972, in a scuffle with a police sergeant in the Nassau Coliseum parking lot in East Meadow. L.I.

title: President's Campaign Debut
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  President Ford's campaign debut tomorrow at the University of Michigan is more than a sentimental homecoming 41 years after his graduation.

title: Miss Goolagong is Sued BY Her Former Coach
description: A $34,800 suit charging breach of contract was filed against Evonne Goolagong by Vic Edwards, her former coach and manager, in Manhattan Supreme Court yesterday.

title: Auto Workers Call Strike at Ford As Negotiations Are Deadlocked
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Wednesday, Sept. 15More than 163,000 members of the United Automobile Workers struck the Ford Motor Company at midnight last night, shutting down 102 plants and other facilities in 22 states.

title: U.S. Envoy to Israel Will Be Sent to Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP)President Ford has decided to name Malcolm Toon, a career diplomat and a specialist on Soviet affairs, as Ambassador to Moscow, Administration sources said today.

title: Less. Risk Found in LowTar Cigarettes
description: Cancer researchers reported yesterday the first definitive evidence that smoking cigarettes lower in tar and nicotine can reduce smokingcaused deaths from cancer and heart disease.

title: About Real Estate
description: The city may be in store for an unpleasant surprise once the City Council enacts, as currently predicted, a law to speed up the takeover of taxdelinquent property. The surprise could be not merely the numbers but also the types of properties falling into city hands setting in motion an even greater writedown in property values than has already been witnessed in the mid 1970's.

title: PINBALL REGULATION IS TERMED A FLOP
description: The three monthold law legalizing pinball machines in bars, motels, hotels and movie houses in New York City was described yesterday by Elinor C. Guggenheimer, Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, as a flop as of right now.

title: Michener Bids Pro Sports Repay Colleges for Talent
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI)James Michener, the author, told Congressional football and basketball professional football and basketball should pay colleges that develop their players an amount equivalent to that spent by hockey and baseball in subsidizing their minor leagues.

title: Philadelphia and Hotel Strive to Overcome People's Fear of Getting Eekion Disease
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept, 14  Three welldressed, middleaged businessmen striding suoth on Broad Street at lunchtime yesterday stopped suddenly under the stainless steel marquee that juts incongruously from the rococo, graystone pile of the Bellevue Stratford Hotel. Laughing nervously and wrestling with one of their number who appeared reluctant, two of them took him by the arms up the stairs and into the Bellevue's nearly empty Hunt Room.

title: MOYNIHAN EDGES OUT MRS. ABZUG; BUCKLEY ALSO VICTOR IN PRIMARY; BADILLO, MRS. CHISHOLM WINNERS
description: The New York Times/Joe Traver

title: Black and White Students Clash, Bringing 17 Suspensions in Boston
description: BOSTON, Sept. 14Clashes today between black and white students on the second full day of classes at South Boston High School, the site of numerous racial incidents since the city's public schools weredesegregated under a 1974 Federal court order, confirmed school officials fears that the school would continue to be the city's major integration trouble spot.

title: Recording Stock Transactions
description: Keeping accurate records of stock transactions may forestall problems later with the Internal Revenue Service. Page 63.

title: Vietnam and the M.I.A.'s
description: The Security Council's decision to postpone consideration of the application of Vietnam for United Nations membership until after the American Presidential election is the least unsatisfactory way out of an unfortunate dilemma. A twomonth delay will give the Ford Administration time to think again about the wisdom of tying Vietnam's admission to the question of the M.I.A.'s  some 800 members of the United States armed forces and others still counted as missing in action in the toll of the Vietnamese war.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor.

title: REYNOLDS SECURITIES AGREES TO ABSORB BAKER, WEEKS FIRM
description: Baker, Weeks & Company, one of Wall Street's foremost institutional brokerage houses, will be absorbed by Reynolds Securities International Inc., the big retail investment house, under the terms of a consolidation agreement announced yesterday.

title: ExF.B.I. Informant Says Agents Ordered 2 Oregon BreakIns in 74
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 14The home of a lawyer whose son is believed linked to the Weather Underground Organization was burglarized twice in 1974 by an operative of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the operative acknowledged today.

title: Congress Confronts Two Competing Bills On A torn Safeguards
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 14The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, with substantial assistance from the Ford Administration, approved a bill today that would tighten United States control over the spread of nuclear explocives.

title: Filing With S.E.C. Tags McCulloch Oil As Inquiry Target
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 14The McCulloch Oil Corporation has become the target of several investigations into possible improprieties in its land development projects, which include Lake Havasu City, Ariz., according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: CADET GETS HARD LABOR ON GUILTY PLEA TO RAPE
description: WEST POINT, N Y., Sept. 14 (UPI)A court martial jury today sentenced a West Point cadet to dismissal from the Army and five years at hard labor for the rape of a Smith College student.

title: Dow Off 4.65 to 978.64 on Fears Of Ford Strike and Steel Layoffs
description: The stock market, reacting to fears that a strike at the Ford Motor Company at midnight was certain, continued to decline yesterday with, the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 4.65 points to 978.64.

title: Presidential Debates to Lose Money and Upset Schedules for Networks
description: ABC, CBS and NBC each expects to lose more than $2 million in revenues for the forthcoming Presidential debates, ail of which will be televised without commercials.

title: The Key Issues In Ford Dispute
description: PARTICIPANTSThe Ford Motor Company, with 200,000 employees in 39 states, and 102 plants, depots and research and engineering facilities in 23 states. The United Automobile Workers, with 16:5,000 members in 91 Ford plants and installations in 22 states.

title: Jet Returns After Bomb Threat
description: A National Airlines flight to Miami was returned to John F. Kennedy International Airport just seven minutes after takeoff yesterday afternoon after the airline received a warning that a bomb had been placed aboard the plane. After the 54 passengers and six crew members left the Boeing 727, the plane was searched and no bomb was found, the police said. The nonstop flight, which had taken off at 3:38 P.M., was delayed for several hours.

title: TrentonPrison Official Named
description: TRENTON, Sept. 14 (UPI)Donald F. Tucker of Neptuna, N..1., was named yesterday as assistant superintendent of the Trenton State Prison. Mr. Tucker, who 57 years old, began his state career in 1947 as a psychiatric technician. He was foralerly ombudsmen for the Division of Correction and Parole, which runs the prisons.

title: BLACK LOSES RUNOFF FOR CAROLINA OFFICE
description: CHARLOTTE. N.C. Sept. 14 (AP)Howard Lee the former Mayor of Chapel Hill failed today in his bid to become one of the few blacks popularly elected to statewide office in the South.

title: Gold Falls on Worry Over Auction
description: LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP)The price of gold in London closed $3 an ounce lower today, reflecting market nervousness over tomorrow's third scheduled International Monetary Fund auction.

title: LOUIS J. SCARAMELLI
description: Louis J. Scararnelli Jr., president of L. & S. Packing Company Inc., condiment packagers in Flushing, Queens, died yesterday at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset. L. I., after suffering a heart attack at his home in Lake Success, L. 1.. He was 69 years old.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Committee on Relations with the United States as host country10:30 A.M.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Police Department yesterday announced that beginning today one fourman crew comprising one policeman and three senior enforcement agents from the Traffic Department would set up a truck roadblock in Manhattan to check for violations of limitations on truck weight.

title: Blacks in Soweto Continue Strike
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 14Fresh violence was reported in Soweto tonight at the end of the second day of a threeday protest strike that has kept tens of thousands of workers away from their jobs at whiteowned businesses in Johannesburg. But the police and black reporters differed widely in their casualty counts.

title: Port Authority Aide Killed by Car
description: A Port Authority field operations agent was killed yesterday in a collision neat the Manhattan exit of the Lincoln Dinned, the authority reported. The officer, Kenneth Kochka, of Secaucus, N. J., was driving a small patrol van out of the tunnel when the vehicle was struck by an auto. He was tossed from the van and was hit by the car. The driver of the car, John Dinnen, 28 years old, of Staten Island, was taken to St. Clare's Hospital, where he was reported in satisfactory condition.

title: Low Tar and Nicotine Cigarettes
description: (Brands below 17.6 milligrams of tar  and 1.2 milligrams of nicotine)

title: New H.D.A. Chief Urges Preservation Of Existing Housing
description: Thomas Appleby, named by Mayor Bcame yesterday to be New York City's new Housing and Development Administrator, said that his first effort would be to concentrate on the preservation of the existing housing stock.

title: World Open Golf Event Seeks August Dates
description: PINEHURST, N.C., Sept. 14 (UPI)The decision on whether the World open returns next year hinges greatly on whether the American Golf Classic remains on the Professional Golfers Association tour.

title: Kips Bay Today Has Other Woes
description: Kips Bay is a stable little piece of East Side Manhattan. it is only eight blocks square and, as befits its size and current temperament, its concerns are little as well.

title: Extension of Revenue Sharing For 5 Years Passed in Senate
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 14The Senate voted today to extend the Federal revenue sharing program for another five and threequarter years.

title: White Stresses Need of Talks On SouthWest Africa Moves
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, Sept. 14 (AP)The white leader at multiracial talks on independence for SouthWest Africa spoke today of possible future negotiations with the SouthWest African Peonle's Oreanization or SWAPO.

title: LOUIS J. ROLLAND
description: Louis 3. Rolland, former columnist and senior editor of Financial World magazine, died of a heart attack Sunday in Kings County Hospital, He lived at 408 East 53d Street, Brooklyn, and was 55 years old.

title: State Aides and Insurance Officials Met Informally to Discuss Rates
description: Insurance company officials testified yesterday that as a matter of routine, private, informal meetings were held with staff members of the New York State Insurance Department before the companies filed formally for premium increases. Since July 1975 the department has approved auto insurance premium increases of $725 million.

title: N.Y. Plan to Stock Lake Ontario Halted
description: ALBANY, Sept. 14The State Department of Environmental Conservation today canceled the salmonstocking program scheduled for Lake Ontario this fall and said the department was having second thoughts about building a $10 million salmon and trout hatchery near the lake.

title: Two Dominicans Charge G. & W. Busted a Union And Pay is Substandard
description: Two Dominican labor leadersone of them now a Pentecostal minister in the Bronxdescribed Gulf and Western Industries sugar producing subsidiary in the Dominican Republic as a unionbusting octopus that paid substandard wages.

title: Jane Olivor at Bottom Line
description: Jane Olivor is the latest New York cabaret entertainer to emerge into the world of recordings, network television appearances and promotional tours, and emerge she has. Her performances at the Bottom Line, where she is opening shows for Don Shirley through this evening, are being touted by her record company as the birth of a new superstar, and on opening night the club was filled with wetwishers. Many of them were from the company, Coumbia, but many more seemed to be genuinely enthralled.

title: Stern, His Friends and Schubert
description: Isaac Stern and Friends played Schubert at Carnegie Hall on Monday night, though you would never have known it from looking at the program. The composer's name was not on it anywhere.

title: NATHAN N. GORDON DEAD; EXTREASURY OFFICIAL, 61
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14Nathan N. Gordon, a former Treasury Department official who specialized in international tax matters, died of a heart attack Sunday in Jerusalem. He was 61 years old.

title: Last 215 Foreigners Flown From Vietnam
description: GENEVA, Sept. 14 (Reuters)The Red Cross made its last airlift from Vietnam today, bringing out 215 foreigners who remained behind when Communist forces conquered the South in April 1975.

title: Daguerreotypes Film on Paris
description: The second International Festival of Women's Films, being held at the Cinema Studio, came to glowing life yesterday with the first commercial New York showing of Daguerreotypes, by Agnes Varda, the French director who made her debut as a director of documentaries, switched to narrative films (Cleo from 5 to 7, Le Bonheur,) and combined the two methods with a good deal of comic success in Lion's Love.

title: A LUTHERAN LEADER QUITS DISTRICT POST
description: The Rev. Rudolph P. F. Ressmeyer, a central figure in a prolonged religious and political dispute it the Missouri Synod of the Lutheran Church, yesterday resigned as president of the church's Atlantic District and pledged to work for a new breakaway church.

title: Suffolk Jury's Report Said to Criticize O'Brien And Police Commissioner
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 14A special grand jury investigating the personal and political feud between Suffolk County's District Attorney, Henry F. O'Brien, and its Police Commissioner, Eugene R. Kelly, men.

title: N.Y. Drops Plans For Lake Ontario
description: ?? Sept. 14The State Department et Environmemal Conservation today canceled the salnlonstocking program scheduled for Lake Ontario this fall and said the department was having second thoughts about building a $10 million salmon and trout hatchery near the lake.

title: Another Crawford in Blue
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 (AP)Shag Crawford's 29yearold son, Jerry, was one of three young umpires added to the National League staff of umpires for the remainder of the season. Crawford's flther retired recently after many years as a National League umpire. Joe West and Eric Gregg were the other two umpires.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: APPEALING TOWER There are at least 75 reasons for climbing to the tower of Riverside Churchone is the splendid view of the city and New Jersey, the other 74 are bells.

title: Personal Finance
description: Howard B. was faced with a serious financial problem. He had received an audit notice from the Internal Revenue Service and learned that one area of questioning would deal with his securities purchases and sales two years ago. But he had not saved any records to help prove his claims.

title: Soybeans Fall Permissible Limit
description: CHICAGO. Sept. 14 (AP)Soybean futures prices fell the permissible daily limit again today on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: State Supervisors Dispute Fed Views On Bank Members
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14The Conference of State Bank Supervisors asserted here today that a key Federal Reserve argument for compelling bank membership in the Reserve had no factual basis and that bank regulation would be significantly harmed if such a proposal should become law.

title: News Summary
description: Daniel P. Moynihan narrowly edged out Representative BeIla S. Abzug in the contest for the Democratic nomination to the United States Senate. The three other candidates trailed far behind. In the Republican primary, the incumbent, James L. Buckley, defeated his challenger by a margin of 3 to 1, with Representative Peter A. Peyser conceding within 90 minutes of the closing of the polls. [Page 1, Cols. 46.]

title: On Gulf's Dole?
description: Senator Robert Dole was obviously annoyed the other day when reporters persisted in asking him questions about two unreported campaign contributions that were alleged to have been made to him by the Gulf Oil Company. The Republican VicePresidential nominee denies any memory or knowledge of the payments and says he has searched his records and finds no indication that he received them. And he thinks the matter should rest right there so he can get on with the campaign.

title: Private and Parochial Schools Begin Year on Note of Optimism
description: After prolonged concern over their ability to cope with inflation and the middleclass flight to suburbia, the private and parochial schools of New York City have opened their doors for a new term on a note of optimism.

title: 4 Aides Testify In Ethics Panel On Pike Report
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14The House ethics committee heard secret testimony from Congressional aides for almost 10 hours today seeking to find out who had provided an intelligence report to Daniel Schorr, who himself is due to testify tomorrow.

title: Mondale Disagrees With Carter Over Some Supreme Court Decisions
description: CHAMPAIGN. Ill., Sept. 14Senator Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, differed publicly today for the first time since the campaign began with the man who chose him, saying that there was a difference in emphasis between his view and Jimmy Carter's on certain Supreme Court decisions.

title: Moans by Kallinger Spur His Removal By Judge in Jersey
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 14Judge Thomas F. Dalton of Superior Court ordered Joseph Kallinger removed from the courtroom in his murder trial today after the defendant wailed, moaned, sang and chanted for about 50 minutes.

title: U.S. Industry Profit Down In Sales Dollar to New Low, Standard &Poor's Reports
description: The average profit as a percentage of sales in American industry fell last year to a record low of 4 cents for each sales dollar, Standard & Poor's reported yesterday. in 1974, the comparable figure was about 5.25 cents.

title: SOVIET CONDOLENCES REBUFFED BY PEKING
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 14China today rejected messages of condolence on the death of Mao Tsetung from the Communist parties of the Soviet Union and its East European allies in a move seen by analysts as one of the clearest indications yet that Peking's antiSoviet foreign policy will remain largely unchanged.

title: Kips Bay Today Has Other Woes
description: Kips Bay is a stable little piece of East Side Manhattan. it is only eight blocks square and, as befits its size and current temperament, its concerns are little as well.

title: Jersey FoodStamp Eligibility
description: TRENTON, Sept. 14 (UPI)About 266,000 New Jerseyans are eligible for food stamps, but they are not aware of it or do not know how to obtain them, the Department of Institutions and Agencies said yesterday. The department is engaged in an outreach program to reach eligible persons and help them improve their diets. Food stamps, a spokesman said, are not welfare, but a service of the Federal Government and are administered through county welfare offices.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Two mayor steerpaiducers, the United States Steel Corporation and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, citing poor demand for steel products, have announced additional layoffs at their plarts.

title: Teamsters Plan Poll on Choice in 76
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the largest labor union in the country, is planning to poll its 2.3 million members to determine whom to endorse for President.

title: Alfred E. Schumacher Dies at 80; Retired Chase Manhattan Official
description: Alfred E. Schumacher, a former senior vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died Monday at Woodcliff Lake Manor Nursing Home, Woodcliff, Lake. N. J. He was SO years old and lived in Ridgewood, N. J.

title: U.N. COUNCIL DELAYS VIETNAM'S ENTRY BID THROUGH NOVEMBER
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 14The Security Council decided today to put off consideration of Vietnam's request for United Nations membership until November.

title: WILDER BEAL
description: Wilder Beal, a former vice president of the ore division of the Union Carbide Corporation, died Friday of a heart attack in Whiteville, Va. He was 72 years old and lived in Sarasota, Fla.

title: BUCKLEY WINS EASILY IN G. O. P. BALLOTING
description: Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican, easily defeated Representative Peter A. Peyser, Westchester Republican, in their primary battle ye5terday for the Republican nomination for Senator.

title: Session is Called a Full and Frank Exchange of Views on Rhodesia
description: Which will also hinge on the readiness of Rhodesia's factionridden black nationalists to return to the negotiating table with Mr. Smith.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP)The Agriculture Department ordered its inspectors today to ban meat packers from using mechanically deboned meat for such products as hot dogs and processed meat. The ban will last until final regulations on mechanically deboned meat are developed.

title: Soviet Accuses Japan of Plotting With U.S. to Detain MIG and Pilot
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 14The Soviet Union charged tonight that the Japanese Govemment had colluded with the United States in obstructing the pilot of a MIG25, a swift and highflying interceptor and reconnaissance jet, from returning to the Soviet Union.

title: PENTAGON WILL SEEK $130 BILLION BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14The Pentagon is preparing to ask the White House to approve a military budget of about $130 billion for the 1978 fiscal year$9 bi lion more than it estimated only seven months ago and $18 billion more than Congress voted for the current fiscal year.

title: Technology
description: The disposal of past and future nuclear reactor waste is moving to the forefront of the nuclear industry's many technical, economic and social problems.

title: Carter Sees His 1 st Administration Producing $60 Billion in New Funds
description: BILLINGS. Mont., Sept. 14Jimmy Carter today tried to rebut Republican arguments that his programmatic promises conflict with his commitment to balanced budgets by predicting once again that there will be enough money for both.

title: Court to Hear Oklahoma Case
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 14 (UPI)  The State Supreme Court will hear arguments tomorrow on a request from the National Collegiate Athletic Association that it be allowed to limit the University of Oklahoma football coaching staff. The N.C.A.A. asked the court yesterday to lift a temporary injunction issued last month in District Court that permitted two assistant coaches, Don Jimerson and Bill Shimek, to retain their jobs.

title: POUND DOWN TO $1.14 DESPITE SHARP DROP IN BRITAIN'S DEFICIT
description: LONDON, Sept. 14 Britain's painstaking effort to rebuild an economy that a year ago was the worst off of any major country is showing signs of coming undone.

title: PENTAGON WILL SEEK $130 BILLION BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 14The Pentagon is preparing to ask the White House to approve a military budget of about $1301 billion for the 1978 fiscal year$9 bi lion I more than it estimated only seven months ago and $18 billion more than Congress voted for the current fiscal year.

title: SPIEGEL TAKES LEAD IN SURROGATE RACE
description: Justice Samuel A. Spiegel of State Supreme Court appeared headed for an easy victory early this morning in the fiveway race for the Democratic nomination for Manhattan surrogate.

title: Lions J. D. Hill Has Surgery
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 14 (AP)J. D. Hill, wide receiver of the Detroit Lions, underwent surgery today to repair torn ligaments in his left knee. Hill, who was hurt last Sunday in Detroit's 103 National Football League loss to the Chicago Bears, chose Dr. Joseph Godfrey, the Buffalo Bills team physician, to perform the operation. Hill was traded to Detroit by the Bills earlier this year.

title: Snow Halts Mt. Everest Climb
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Sept. 14 (AP)Continuous heavy snow on Mount Everest for the last four days has halted tho American Bicentennial Expedition, the Nepalese Foreign Ministry reported today But a message from the expedition's base camp said the Americans and their Sherpa porters were safe and in good physical condition.

title: DoubleDeck Buses Make Debut And Stop Traffic (Pedestrian)
description: At long last doubledecker buses are back in towneight very tall ones in fact and all newly built in Britain and ready for regular service today.

title: News Summary
description: Daniel P. Moynihan led narrowly over Representative Bella S. Abzug in the contest for the Democratic nomination to the United States Senate. The three other candidates trailed far behind. In the Republican primary, the incumbent, James L Buckley, defeated his challenger by a margin of 3 to 1, with Representative Peter A. Peyser conceding within 90 minutes of the closing of the polls. (Page 1, Cols. 463

title: Hildegarde Recalls Last Time She Saw Paris
description: Hildegarde, in all her years as the starring singer at the Persian Room at the Paza Hotel, never had an audience like the one that almost filled Town Hall for a onehour matinee yesterday.

title: Kansas Poll Pleases Carter Aide
description: TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 14 (UPI)The coordinator of Jimmy Carter's Kansas campaign, Robert Vincent, said yesterday he was encouraged by a statewide poll showing Mr. Carter trailing by 3 percentage points in the home state of the Republican VicePresidential nominee, Senator Robert J. Dole. The poll showed President Ford leading with 44 percent to Mr. Carter's 41 percent. it was conducted by the Central Research Corporation for The Topeka CapitalJournal. Four percent of Kansans polled support other candidates while II percent are undecided.

title: Sports Today
description: Mats vs. St. Louis Cardinals twilightnight doubleheader at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 5:35 P.M.

title: CHALLENGE BY VELEZ TURNED BACK EASILY
description: Representative Herman Bacilli survived with unexpected ease yesterday a vigorous challenge to his hold on the Congressional district in the South Bronx.

title: Books of The Times
description: On the dust jacket of Maigret and the Apparition, we are told that there are still many more Maigret mysteries awaiting, translation, and it occurred to me to wonder what determined the order in which they were brought out in English. Since the French publication dates show that chronology has nothing to do with it, the thought suggests itself that they are being translated in the order of their merit. it is an ironic and disturbinab notion that, after a writer retires from the genre that made him famous, his work should be made available in this fashion.

title: U.N. COUNCIL DELAYS TO NOVEMBER ACTION ON VIETNAM'S ENTRY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 14The Security Council decided today to put off consideration of Vietnam's request for United Nations membership until November.

title: More Recipes, First Rate and Robust, in the Neapolitan Style; Melanzane Ripieni (Stuffed Eggplant)
description: The eggplant.

title: House Unit Passes Bill Drawing Guides In Gas Station Deals
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 24With strong bipartisan support, the House Commerce Committee approved today a bill to define the circumstances in which an oil company or whclesaler may cancel or fail to renew a fillingstation lease.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Sept. 14The New Jersey State Capitol and much of its environs were added today to the national register of historic places.

title: PRESS PLANE COSTLY, A CARTER AIDE SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14The Carter campaign, which is charging reporters who ride its press plane 50 percent more than first class commercial fares, is complaining that the Democratic candidate is going to lose money on the deal.

title: F.B.I. TO END INQUIRY INTO SOCIALIST GROUP
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  Attorney General Edward H. Levi has ordered the Federal Bureau of Investigation to end its 38year inquiry into the Socialist Workers Party, Department of Justice and party representatives said today.

title: Helping the Family Pet. Find Contentment
description: A better catnip?

title: Susan E. Lyman is Dead at 70; Writer on New York City History
description: Susan E. Lyman, an author specializing in New York City historical subjects. died Monday in Rhode Island Hospital in Providence, R. I. She was 70 years old and lived at 14 East 90th Street.

title: 18 Indicted in Arizona Land Fraud Costing 10,000 Victims $40 Million
description: PHOENIX. Ariz., Sept. 14. (AP) A Federal grand jury today indicted 18 persons and five corporations in the Cochise College Park land fraud and securities swindle that cost victims nearly $40 million.

title: Joseph Durso
description: Let's face it, Ralph Houk was saying as he watched the New York Yankees take batting practice, this ball club bought a pennant. I think the Yankees will keep spending, too. But they didn't develop the club. They went out and bought it.

title: Senate Committee Votes to Tighten the Medicaid Rules to Prevent Abuses and Fraud
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14Responding to reports of widespread cheating in the Medicaid program, the Senate Finance Committee unanimously approved today a bill making fraud in public health programs a felony, punishable by up to five years in fail and a $25,000 fine.

title: Market Basket Up 1.3% in a Week
description: It wasn't what you ate, it was what you drank last week that caused a 95cent increase in the cost of feeding a family of four here.

title: Tavern on the Green: Another Opening, Another Show
description: Step right up, ladies and gentlemen, for a genuine gala New York restaurant opening, starring that super social interior decorator, Lee Radziwill, costarring that sizzling Romeo of the sports world, Joe Namath; featuring a supporting cast of luminaries known, for no apparent reason, as beautiful, and produced, directed and catered by that showman cum restaurateur, Warner Le Roy.

title: Lawyers in India Fear a LongCherished Legal System is Bein Politicized
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 14One of India's most prominent lawyers sat in his elegantly furnished office the other day, his head in his hands, his face contorted in anguish.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14The Senate, the FederalTrade Commission and the Federal Energy Administration have all designed plans to re quire that gasoline pumps meet the Federal rules for displaying octane ratings, but the Environmental Protection Agency warned recently that such efforts might actually not benefit consumers.

title: Sales of New Cars Increase by 8.4%
description: DETROIT. Sept. 14 American newcar sales increased S.4 percent in early September comparad with last year but the annual selling rate dropped because raports of cme 1977 model car sales were being held back until Octooer.

title: Events Today
description: FOR COLORED GIRLS WHO HAVE CONSIDERED SUICIDE/WHEN THE RAINBOW IS ENUF, ct real teem by Ntezake Shan lc; u.rectc.: by on Scott; presented by Joseph Pao and the New York Shakespeare Festival, in association with Woodie King. Jr. and the Henry Street Settlement's hew Federal Theater; at the Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street, 7:30.

title: Prosecutors Agree on Trials for Croatian Nationalists
description: The five Croatian nationalists who hijacked a jet airliner last weekend will be tried on Federal airpiracy charges in Brooklyn and on state murder charges in Manhattan, Federal and city prosecutors agreed yesterday.

title: Music: Paris Opera Sings Faust
WINE TALK
description: The Bicentennial has not been a total losswe've rediscovered Thomas Jefferson. Earlier this year we learned that he enjoyed eating, collected recipes and tried to improve the quality of what he and his friends consumed in Virginia and at the White House.

title: About Education
description: The power struggle that developed between the State University of New York and the Board of Regents last year over efforts to consolidate doctoral programs in the state has now developed into a farranging academic war with several fronts.

title: A $250 MILLION LOAN IS REPAID BY M. A. C.
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation yesterday repaid a $250 million loan that New York State had rushed to New York City at the height of the city's cash crisis last year.

title: Weather: To MidOctober
description: The New York Times/Seel 15, 1976

title: Mengert Captures Golf In SuddenDeath Playoff
description: DAVISON. Mich., Sept. 14 (AP)AI Mengert sank a 5foot birdie putt on the first hole of a suddendeath playoff today to defeat Gary Groh and Dick Horgan and capture the 55th Michigan Professional Golfers Association championship.

title: Team Canada Superiority Acknowledged by Rivals
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 19On the verge of clinching the Canada Cup tournament, a vehicle it created to prove its strength in hockey, Canada has already convinced the Czechoslovaks of its superiority on the ice rink.

title: Krulevitz Upset Victor At Bermuda Net. 63. 61
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, Sept. 14 (AP) Steve Krulevitz of Baltimore upset sixthseeded Bernie Mitton of South Africa, 63, 61, today in the first round of the $50,000 Bermuda tennis tournament, a Grand Prix event.

title: Hoboken Hospital Steps Up Activity for Eye Week
description: HOBOKEN, Sept. 14Anne Kelly was back at the hospital's registration desk today, counting names. We've got 65 to go to catch up with last year's registrations, she said.

title: Yorster and Smith Have Long Discussion in Pretoria
description: PRETORIA. South Africa, Sept. 14Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia left here grimfaced today after a fourand  a  half  hour meeting with Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa in which the two men had what were described as a full and frank exchange of views on the Rhodesian situation.

title: Advertising
description: Before going ahead with its first corporate TV campaign, which was intended to support the freeenterprise system, Textron's top management asked the question, Could advertising by business in defense of business be sufficiently credible to have any impact?

title: New jersey Briefs
description: A state trooper who was shot while trying to apprehend two suspects in an 58,000 bank robbery was reported in fair condition in Somerville Hospital while one of the suspects who was also wounded in the gun battle, was reported in critical condition in the same hospital. The state police said that Trooper Richard Roberts sustained wounds in his arm and chest when Benjamin F. Washington, of East Orange, the suspect who was wounded, suddenly fired at the trooper who had stopped his car.

title: In Black and White
description: Daniel Patrick Moynihan's decadeold report on the black family and his benign neglect memorandum to President Nixon have long been the targets of strong criticism by black spokesmen and scholars. During the recent campaign, those criticisms have in turn come under heavy attack by some of Mr. Moynihan's most influential supporters.

title: Mishaps Plague Ships On East and West Coasts
description: LEFT: in Manchac, La., a barge rammed a bridge over

title: Bank of England Suspends Aide; Yard Called In
description: LONDON, Sept. 14 The Bank of England disclosed today that a topgrade supervisor had been suspended from duty after investigations of a scheme to cheat the British Treasury on currency deals.

title: Bergman Given OneYear Term; Signs Over His Assets to the State
description: Bernard Bergman was sentenced yesterday to one year in a city prison for bribery by a New York State Supreme Court justice who brushed aside a plea bargain under which the nursinghome promoter would have received no jail term.

title: Nurses in Seattle Area Reach Tentative Accord After 65DayOld Strike
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 14 (AP)Striking nurses and 15 Seattlearea hospitals reached a tentative agreement today to end one of the longest and largest health care strikes in recent history, a Federal mediator announced.

title: Big British Guns From 3 Frigates Rocked Kips Bay During Invasion 2 Centuries Ago
description: Seventy guns on three British frigates opened fire on the American earthworks. Eighty flatbottomed assault boats packed with infantry crossed the glassy calm of the river to land at Kips. Bay. it was Sept. 15, 1776, and the first and last invasion of Manhattan Island had begun.

title: MOYNIHAN IS LEADING MRS. ABZUG; BUCKLEY A VICTOR
description: The New York Times/Jack Mannins and Joe Traver

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Associated Press

title: Moynihan and Abzug Supporters Hold Their Spirits in Abeyance
description: Supporters of the two chief contenders for the Democratic Senate nomination gathered to rejoice last night. Instead the crowds at the two campaign headquarters waited and waited and waited.

title: Jackson is 82 Victor In First Yankee Start
Market Place
description: Eastman Kodak, an institutional favorite, has dropped steadily this week as a light tarnish has settled over the company's image of infallibility.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: MISSISSIPPI LLOYD (NedLloyd). Dubai Cct. 13 and Abudhabl 15; sails tress Furman St., Brealyd.

title: When In Doubt, Shut Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14The Wall Street Journal has come up with a revolutionary idea, which is so sensible but also so subversive that it will either save or destroy democracy and what we call the free press of America.

title: Royals Raise Lead to 41/2
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP)Andy Hassler braked a twogame Kansas City skid with a fivehitter and the Royals backed him with three double plays en route to a 21 victory over the Chicago White Sox today.

title: Second Debate Scheduled for Oct.6
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP)The second and third debates between President Ford and Jimmy Carter will be Wednesday, Oct. 6 and Friday, Oct. 22, and the single debate between the VicePresidential candidates will be sandwiched in between, the League of Women Voters, the debate sponsor, announced today.

title: Madrid Fears the Effect on Its Future of Regions Demand for Autonomy
description: MADRID, Sept. 14A weekend of agitation in Catalonia and the Basque country has increased fears in Madrid that regional demands for autonomy may become the single most disruptive issue in Spain's political transformation from dictatorship to democracy.

title: Oh, Japanese Slugger, Homers
description: TOKYO, Sept. 14 (UPI)The Yomiuri Giants Sadaharu Oh homered for the first time in nearly a month in the ninth inning today as the Central League leaders and the secondplace Hanshin Tigers battled to a 66 tie.

title: U.S. Orders Accounting Of Swedish Arms Deals After Illegality Charges
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 14 (Reuters)Air Force Secretary Thomas C. Reed today ordered an accounting of financial transactions with Sweden, following charges ci secret cash payments to the Air Force from the Swedish Government.

title: Mass Transit Pushed for Giants Meadowlands Games
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, Sept. 14In an attempt to avoid a repetition of the massive crush of traffic that marred the recent opening of harness racing at the Hackensack Meadowlands Racetrack, Governor Byrne and Transportation Commissioner Alan G. Sagner announced today that special rail and bus service would be in operation for the first home football game of the Giants at the $340 milion Sports Compex on Oct. 10.

title: Notes on People
description: For a price reported to be well over $1 million, Marietta Peabody Tree has sold her East 79th Street house, long a sort of salon for Democratic Party and United Nations social life. Early next month, Sotheby Parke Bernet will sell the furnishings and art worksmost of them from Ditchley, the 18thcentury English country house formerly owned by Mrs. Tree and her husband, Ronald Tree, who died in July at age 72. The 20room house here, known to their friends as Little Ditchley, has been bought by John S. Samuels 3d, a 42yearold lawyer from Texas who also bought the former J. P. Morgan estate in Glen Cove, L. I. Principal owner of Carbomin International Corporation, coal brokers, Mr. Samuels has been called Young King Coal. Last year he became board chairman of City Center.

title: Hundreds of Italians Flee Homes As New Quakes Hit Stricken Area
description: UDINE, Italy, Sept. 14 (Reuters)Hundreds of families evacuated their homes today in the quakestricken Friuli area as the 32d tremor in two days hit the devastated district.

title: RULING PARTY IN TRINIDAD ELECTED FOR FIFTY TERM
description: PORT OF SPAIN. Trinidad, Sept. 14 (Reuters)Prime Minister Eric Williams and his governing People's National Movemdnt swept unexpectedly to a convincing victory today in general elections in Trinidad and Tobago.

title: CAMILO PONCE DIES AT 64; WAS PRESIDENT OF ECUADOR
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Sept. 14 (AP)Camilo Ponce, President of Ecuador from 1956 to 1960, died today of a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

title: Charges by Gambling Foes Scored
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 14A leader of the campaign for casino gambling here charged today that opponents were playing loose with the truth, and said the committee he headed would demand that they back up their racketeer infiltration charges or be quiet.

title: July Increases Slowed In Business Inventories To More Moderate Pac
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14Total business inventories rose by a moderate $1.5 billion in July, less than the $3.7 billion increase in June but about in line with the average for the first five months of the year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: The Standings
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Article 3  No Title
description: United Press International

title: O.J. is Back but Bills Lose Braxton for the Year
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 14The significance of the return of O. J. Simpson, pro football's premier running back, to the Buffalo Bills lineup was lost in translation last night as a swirl of other events took precedence. The Bills regained Simpson, who had been holding out, but they lost the game to the Miami Dolphins, 3021, and they lost their fullback, Jim Braxton, who has been so complementary to Simpson as a blocker and inside runner.

title: Tito Misses Important Meeting
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept 14 (Retlters)President Tito missed, an important meeting of the collective presidency today because of the acute liver ailment that has afflicted him in recent days. There was no further word on the 84yearold leader's condition.

title: An Actress Full of Passion, Pain and Energy, Miss Beverley of Colored Girls Won't Let Up
description: She is billed simply as the Lady in Red and enters, unremarkably, as one in an ensemble of seven women. But by the end of the play For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf, Trazana Beverley establishes herself as one of the season's major theatrical experiences.

title: Filly is Sold For $200,000 At Keeneland
description: LEXINGTON, Ky. Sept. 14 (AP)A bay filly by Northern Dancer, a Kentucky Derby winner, and a hay by Never Bend brought record prices at today's third session of the 33d Keeneland September Yearling Sale.

title: With 6 Games Left With Royals, A's Stretch Run Resembles Crawl:
description: OAKLAND. Calif., Sept. 14Somewhat short on sleep, the Oakland A's will resume their pursuit of the Kansas City Royals tomorrow night in a race that has resembled the mythical tortoise and another tortoise, but which is now reaching the decisive stage.

title: SUFFOLK POLITICIANS SQUABBLE ON BOUT
description: HAUPPAUGE, L,I Sept. 14The Suffolk County Legislature's Democratic majority, faced with an election campaign next year, is squabbling with the County Executive, who is a Republican, over who should be blamed for the bad news the 1977 county budget is expected lo contain.

title: Sakharovs Travel to Siberia to Visit an Exiled. Dissident
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 14Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident physicist, traveled nearly 5.000 miles from Moscow into the remote wilderness of Siberia last month seeking out a friend who had been exiled there for antiSoviet activity.

title: South African Urges New Apartheid Term
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 14 (Reuters)A Cabinet minister today suggested that the term apartheid be replaced as an official name for the Government's race policies.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a computer error, The New York Times erroneously stated Sunday that President Ford had characterized antitrust legislation now be fore Congress as the product of a very small mind. Mr. Ford has made no such characterization, although he has expressed serious reservations about the bill.

title: Board of Doctors Demands Opening Of Bronx Hospital
description: The medical board of the North Central Bronx Hospital demanded yesterday that the new $100 million facility, which has been the focus of controversy over who, should run it and how, be opened immediately.

title: Vermont Democrats Back Salmon for Senate, Woman for Governor
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 14  Gov. Thomas P. Salmon tonight won a slim victory for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate over Scott Skinner, a 34yearold public interest advocate and political neophyte.

title: PRESS UNION MOVES CLOSER TO MERGER
description: Two major unions in the paper and printing industries are considering merging into a single union of 445,000 members that would have greatly increased strength in collective bargaining and organizing.

title: VISCOUNTESS KEMSLEY
description: NORTHAMPTON, England, Sept. 14 (AP)The Dowager Viscountess Kernsley, widow of the British newspaper magnate, died in a hospital here today. Her husband, chairman of the Kernsley chain of British newspapers, died in 1968. They were married in 1931 after the death of his first wife. The second viscountess was a native of Mauritius.

title: Parish Aids Village Church in 50th Year
description: Our Lady of Pompei Church is. 50 years old this year, and the church's parishioners are giving it the kind of birthday presents that they hope will restore the church's original beauty and some of its prominence.

title: People in Sports
description: Mentally and physically, I'm ready right now, Ken Norton said yesterday after a strenuous drill for his world heavyweight title fight against Muhammad All in Yankee Stadium on Sept. 28.

title: CANADIAN UNIT TO RAISE PRINT PRICE $20 A TON
description: Prices of newsprint will be raised $20 a ton by the Canadian International Paper Company through the International Paper Sales Company, effective Dec. 1, the company said yesterday. Both Canadian companies are subsidiaries of the International Paper Company, with headquarters here.

title: Legionnaires Disease
description: The most disturbing aspect of the outbreak of socalled legionnaires disease is that one of the most intensive and extensive epidemiological investigations in history has had no luck in ascertaining its cause. A large number of possible factors have been eliminated, but the actual responsible cause is as unknown now as when the first American Legion member fell ill last July.

title: Brookville Polo Team Romps
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.L, Sept. 14The.., Brookville polo team defeated Bethpage, 114, today in a Long Island League match at Hickock Field. Butch Butterworth, G. H. (Pete) Bostwick and Charles Bostwick paced the Brookville attack with three goals each.

title: Avoiding Further Atticas
description: With these words the New York State Special Commission on Attica began its factfinding report about the tragic events at Attica five years ago. The story of those four days is more than history; it has become a symbol of the failures of the American corrections system.

title: Watergate's Prosecutor Declares He Didn't Get Dole Gilt Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14The Watergate Special Prosecutor said today that no White House official had made inquiries at his office about allegations that the. Republican VicePresidential candidate, Senator Robert J. Dole, had accepted illegal campaign contributions prior to Mr. Dole's selection as President Ford's running mate on Aug. 19.

title: Violence Ends Soccer Match
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 14 (Reuters) A friendly soccer match between two northeastern Brazilian teams ended in a violent freeforall between players and fans, with one fan being kicked to death. The trouble started when fans: of one of the teams apparently disturbed the opposing goalie in last Sunday's match, according to reports reaching here.

title: Haywood, as Disc Jockey, Plays for New Audience
description: The two hours were just too short, said Spencer Haywood as he walked out of the Riverside Church onto Claremont Avenue. He had obviously had a better time than if he had just put in 48 minutes against Dave Cowens. I was just getting warmed up. I really like to have the people call in and talk on the phones. I didn't want to play anything too heavy today. I want to capture that youngster 10 to 12 years old and keen him. he continued.

title: Santucci Wins Easily in Queens Deepite Opposition From U.F.T.
description: State Senator John J. Santucci, a Queens Democrat opposed by the United Federation of Teachers, easily won renomination last night to a fifth term in Albany.

title: Labor Council Backs Democrat
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 (AP)The Philadelphia A.F.L.C.I.O. Council endorsed today the Senate candidacy of Democrat William J. Green over Republican H, John Heinz 3d. The council represents 350 union locals with about 250,000 members, The unanimous, voicevote endorsement, followed an endorsement of Mr. Green last month by the state American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

title: KALLINGER EJECTED AFTER COURT SCENE
description: HACICENSACK, Sept. 14  Judge Thomas. F. Dalton of Superior Court ordered Joseph Kallinger removed from the courtroom in his murder trial today after the defendant wailed, moaned, sang and chanted for about 50 minutes.

title: Iraquis Pe Said to Have Crossed Border Into Kuwaiti Territory
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 14  Iraqi forces have reportedly crossed the border into neighboring Kuwait and established a tent camp about half a mile inside Kuwaiti territory.

title: Screen: Pain of Exile Is Detailed:Mekas's 'Lost Lost Lost' Opens Whitney Series
description: Using techniques that imitate the lack of technique of a home movie, the film maker and critic Jonas Mekas has been taking poetic notes of his adult life ever since he entered the United States as a young Lithuanian refugee in 1949. To open its annual series of American experimental films, the Whitney Museum is showing a three-hour swatch of these notes, under the title "Lost Lost Lost."They are grainy and elliptical, these brief scenes, with Mr. Mekas's voice making a keening, accented commentary upon them. They begin with his first years, living with Lithuanian relatives and friends in Brooklyn; then making a break along with his brother Adolfas, moving to Manhattan and slowly and painfully becoming an experimental film maker and member of an avant-garde that included Allen Ginsberg, Frank O'Hara, Andy Warhol and others.As time passes, the straightforward awkwardness of Mr. Mekas's camera is replaced by a mannered awkwardness, the shots tumbling, blurring and distorting. It is a process the author uses quite deliberately to illustrate the process of pain he is trying to record."Sing Ulysses, sing your travels," Mr. Mekas's voice begins, and he goes on to speak of "a man who never wanted to leave his home . . . who was thrown into the world." The movie, from start to finish, is about the damage done by exile; only in the first part it is shown directly, and thereafter, indirectly.It is the first part that has most of the power: it is an infinitely moving and perceptive record of the exile of a whole community. Mr. Mekas, at the time fully a part of this community, records the meals, the weddings, the Sunday outings. He records the pain of the refugee doctors, lawyers, poets, politicians who suddenly find themselves transplanted as truck drivers, messengers and factory hands.They meet, they form committees, they dress up for a picnic in the country at the end of which they sit, in rows of garden chairs, to hear a former Cabinet minister talk about the situation. They take all the steps, these educated and decent people, that they have taken all their lives; but suddenly, in the hard soil of a new country, they leave no footprints. The fact that Mr. Mekas used a silent camera strengthens the image of ghosts who gesture, pace, talk and make no sound.And then Jonas, and his brother Adolfas, seeing nothing ahead but a future of Lithuania Day dances, leave this futile reality, move to Manhattan and, as the author puts it, "start from scratch."Even a futile reality is not so easily replaced. They write, they take odd jobs, they work on film, they make friends in the avant-garde. But there is no center. Mr. Mekas follows and filmssometimes quite beautifullyall the vigils and peace marches of the late 1950's. (How peaceful the demonstrators look from this side of the late 60's; how gentle the police look.) He makes experimental films, makes filmed haikus in the snow.It is pretty, some of it, but dated and pretentious by now. With the novelty long past, the caperings of Mr. Mekas and his friends remind us of children who protest the lack of anything to do by posturing and grimacing. It is a frenetic hopefulness mustered against a real emptiness of exile, and the exile is not just for two Lithuanian brothers from Brooklyn but for their American contemporaries as well.We get the message, but it does not touch us as the message in the first part does. A dying reality is material for a splendid film; a living emptiness hardly ever is.

title: Thousands at L.I. Rites for Officer Killed in Bomb Blast
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, Li., Sept, 14Brian Murray, the 28yeavold New York City police officer who was killed early Saturday in the blast of a bomb planted by Croatian terrorists, was eulogized and buried today amid mournful pomp.

title: Civil Liberties Union Sues Over Intelligence Records Memphis Police Burned
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 14The American Civil Liberties Union filed suit in Federal Court here today in an effort to unravel a series of events that led last week to destruction of about 180 secret domestic intelligence files gathered by police.

title: The Washington Star Publisher Buys a Paper in Massachusetts
description: WESTFIELD, Mass. (AP)  The publicaser of The Washington Star has purchased The Westfield Evening News and named a former publisher or The Fort Worth (Texas) Press as the Westfield paper's new publisher.

title: Lands Unspoiled
description: In the endless struggle to save the little open since left on Long Island, Suffolk County conservationists won a major battle on one front last week and a preliminary skirmish on another.

title: Case Closed
description: According to a spokesman for the Justice Department, Attorney General Levi has ordered the Federal Bureau of Investigation to wrap up its 38year investigation of the Socialist Workers Party. in so doing, the Justice Department will bring down the curtain on a saga involving some 92 illegar burglaries of the party headquarters between 1960 and 1966, write off the salaries of hundreds of paid F.B.I. informants, and stamp case closed on the 8 million separate files they accumulated.

title: Finley Makes New Effort To Sign 5 of His Players
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 14 (UPI)The Oakland A's owner, Charlie Finley, will meet tomorrow with Jerry Kapstein adviser to five top A's players. in an effort to get them to sign contracts and keep them from becoming free agents at the end of season. The five are Rollie Fingers, pitcher; Gene Tenace first baseman; Joe Rudi and Don Baylor, outfielders, and Campy Campaneris, shortstop.

title: The Other Carter In the Running
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept: 14Mrs. Rosalynn Carter, wife of the Democratic Presidential candidate, attended the California premiere here of the new show, Eleanor. The symbolism of this event was wellchosen for, if Mr. Carter is elected, his wife is likely to be the most influential First Lady since Eleanor Roosevelt. The nation's women will have acquired an articulate and attractive spokeswoman, one who is a loving wife and devoted, mother and also a strong, independent personality in her own right.

title: Giants Hoping to Get Well While Eagles Are Just Hoping
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 14Coach Bill Arnsparger of the Giants was playing What's My Line? and Coach Dick Vermeil of the Eagles was doing oneliners today as the National Football League season headed for its second weekend.

title: Mrs. Stringer Beats 3 Rivals In a Manhattan Council Race
description: Arlene Stringer, a Democratic district leader, was the apparent winner in yesterday's fourway race for the party's nomination in the Sixth Council District in upper Manhattan, the only Councilmanic seat being contested in the city this year.

title: VOTER TURNOUT LIGHT
description: Daniel P. Moynihan held a slight edge cvor Representative Bella S. Abzug last night in the contest for the Democratic normination for the United States Senati. in what apparently was one of the tightest statewide primaries in recent years.

title: About Newyork
description: If there were an Anxiety Index for the cityand some day the Jovial 11 P.M. weatherman may offer that, too, along with the air unacceptability reading and other mortality measurementsthen a primary monitoring post would have to be inside the QueensMidtown Tunnel.

title: Kips Bay Foes No Longer Fly The Union Jack
description: Neighborhood. Now its 330 students come from all over the city.

title: FundRaising Image of Strauss Strained by Party's Shortages
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Robert S. Strauss, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, has somehow maintained a public reputation as a fundraiser even though in the better part of a decade in which Mr. Strauss has been either treasurer or chairman, the party has Campaign never been out of big debt. Notes The durable image of a Texan Midas is under fresh strain this fall in the CarterMondale campaign. Mr. Strauss acknowledged in an interview today that the National Committee would get nowhere near the figure of $10.5 million it is entitled to spend on Presidential, Senate and House races. The party is still scratching for the $1.8 million it is committed to spending on voter registration. it will take a miracle, Democratic financiers say, to come up with the $3.5 million supplement that the committee is authorized to add to the Federal subsidies for the Presidential ticket. There will be no national committee money at all, Mr. Strauss said, for Senate candidates.

title: Two Share Lead on 78's In Senior Women's Golf
description: SOUTHERN PINES, N. C., Sept. 14 (UPI)Dorothy Porter of Cinnarhinson, N. J., and Georgine Dunning of Middletown, N.Y., shot sixover par 78's today to share a twostroke lead after the first round of the United States Senior Women's golf tournament.

title: Lebanese Plan New Talks on Truce
description: BEIRUT. Lebanon. Sept. 14Lebanon's Presidentelect and the leaders of Syria and the Palestinian guerrilla movement have reportedly agreed to meet tomorrow to try once again to work out a ceasefire in the 17month civil war.

title: Kissinger in Africa On Mediation Trip; Meeting Skepticism
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sept. 14Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger arrived here tonight at the start of a mediating mission in southern Africa that he hopes will convince black leaders of American sincerity in seeking peaceful solutions in SouthWest Africa and Rhodesia.

title: Badiilo Turns Back Velez Easily; Wright Trails in a Close Race
description: Representative Herman Badillo survived with unexpected ease yesterday a vigorous challenge to his hold on the Congressional district in the South Bronx.

title: President Signs New Law Ending 4 States of National Emergency
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14President Ford ended with the stroke of a pen today four different states of national emergency under which Presidents have wielded a broad array of powers for more than 40 years.

title: VOTER TURNOUT LIGHT
description: Daniel P. Moynihan narrowly edged out Representative Bella S. Abzug for the Democratic nomination for the United.; States Senate yesterdayln one of the clotest statewide plimaries in recent years.

title: From a Family of Chefs, a Feast of Robust Neapolitan Food
description: It looked for all the world like a cooking marathon but it was in truth just another day in the life of the Migliucci family. The only difference was, on this day they were doing it for pleasure. They were cooking a dinner for 20, which included themselves, their family and friends.

title: Maritime Fruit Seeks to Salvage Fleet
description: Maritime Fruit Carriersone of the major seagoing successes of the 1960's has seen its once proud fleet of almost 50 vessels cut to a small flotilla of ships that are either being offered on the open market for purchase or have been impounded in various countries around the world for the company's alleged nonpayment of debts.

title: INTEREST RATES FALL ON AAA STATE BONDS
description: Interest rates on topgrade state bonds declined yesterday to their lowest levels I since early 1975 as South Carolina sold $70 million of these taxexempt securities. The bonds, some of which mature each year from 1977 to 1991, were priced to give yields ranging from 3 percent to 5.05 percentrates as much as 20 percent below those investors could obtain a year ago, when taxexempt bond yields were at their highest levels on record. it was difficult to tell how readily investors accepted these lower yields. The underwriters that bought the South Carolina securities reported that all but about $16 million of the $70 million had been sold within an hour and a half after bids were submitted at 11 A.M.

title: Leaders in Several Cities Praised For Peace in School Integration
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14The United States Commission on Civil Rights today praised the leadership in several cities for promoting what the commission called relative peace and calm in the implementation of school desegregation plans this fall.

title: Rhodesia's Unswerving Prime Minister
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 14For more than 12 years, despite increasing pressure, Ian Douglas Smith has held unswervingly to his view of things.

title: Bridge
description: No player has even won three major New York events in three days, if onesession events are excluded from consideration. But it almost happened during the weekend.

title: 8 Nations Join Soviet In Astronaut Training
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 14 (AP)  Astronauts from eight Communistruled nations will join Soviet fliers in space flights beginning in 1978, Tass, the official press agency, said today.

title: Jersey Ice Cream Vendor Slain
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 14 (UPI)A Good Humor ice cream vendor was shot and killed in an attempted robbery last night, the police said. The vendor, Jack Libes, 52 years old, of Union died at the Jersey City Medical Center three hours after being shot by one of three robbers. The police said that Mr. Libes had driven his ice cream van for several blocks despite his wounds, but it finally crashed into several parked cars. Witnesses told the police that the gunmen nad opened fire as Mr. Libes had tried to drive away to escape the robbery attempt.

description: The Broadway season crawled to a start last night with a situatson comedy about dying. The comedy is Checking Out, a first play by Allen Swift, who also assumes the role of Morris Applebaum.
