description: The New York Times survey is Imsed on interviews with a random sampling of New York State voters as they left Cie polls yesterday. Twentyfive etecLion districts  seven upstate and 18 downstatewere sampled, and within er.ch election district, each voter had an courtl chance of selection.

title: 11 Communities in Hudson County To Consolidate Fire Departments
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 15A plan that would save $8.2 million a year by consolidating Fire Departments in 11 of the 12 municipalities in the county, was unveiled today by Hudson County Executive Edward F. Clark and Mayor Paul T. Jordan of Jersey City. This would be the first regionalization of services on a countywide basis in the state, the officials said at a news conference here today.

title: A Bridge in the African Crisis
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sept. 15 Julius K. Nyerere is fond of invoking Mount Kilimanjaro as a metaphor for his country's aspirations. and dignity where there was only humiliation.

title: Mrs. Abzug Offers to Aid Winner; Buckley Calls Moynihan'to the Left
description: Daniel P. Moynihan won what he called a gracious promise of help yesterday from Bella S. Abzug in his campaign for United States Senator from New York.

title: Senate Primary
description: Daniel P. Moynihan emerges at the hair'sbreadth winner of the hardfought, sometimes bitter, Democratic primary for United States Senatora victory none the less sweet for the narrowness of his margin over Representative Bella S. Abzug.

title: First Juror is Selected In Trial of Susan Saxe For Murder and Robbery
description: BOSTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)  A young Boston housewife became today the first juror in the murder and bank robbery trial of Susan E. Saxe.

title: Emmylou Harris's Twanging More Natural and Confident
description: ROSLYN, L.1., Sept. 15Emmynu Harris spent years in the late 1960's and early 70's trying to find her place in music. She made a popsy solo album a few years back that she now repudiates, and then she sang backup and duets with Gram Parsons. Finally, a couple of years ago, after Mr. Parsons's death, she ventured out on her own.

title: Engineer in New Canaan Train Crash Says Brakes Did Not Take Hold
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 15The engineer of the commuter train that crashed in New Canaan on July 13 testified here today that he had jammed on the train's brakes in an attempt to avoid the accident, but that the brakes had failed to slow the crowded rushhour train.

title: Audrey Osborn Elliott Dies at 83; A Leading Figure in Real Estate
description: Audrey Osborn Elliott, a leading figure in the New York realestate world for many years, died yesterday at her home on the East Side of Manhattan. She was 83 years old.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)  The House has defeated a proposed twoyear ban on commercial reproduction of former President Richard M. Nixon's Watergate tapes.

title: Barkum is a Receiver In Ali s Bailiwick, Too
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 14For most of his adult life, Jerome Barkum had this fantasy: He would finally stand next to Muhammad Ali. Barkum would dance around the champion, he would shout at him and he would look pretty, floating like a butterfly.

title: Labor Department Offers Proposal to Spur Affirmative Action Hiring
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15The Labor Department said today that companies doing business with the Government might be able to satisfy affirmative action employment requirements by training women and minority males for skilled jobs without being obliged to hire them.

title: Starr's Exit From Beame Administration Marks the End of a Hectic Era
description: The appointment of John Apple by chief executive officer of the United Nations Development Corporation, as the city's top housing administrator, marks the end of an era. Roger Starr, the incumbent, had served as the administrator of the Housing and Develits occupant controversial, and Mr. Starr was no exception. From his backgroundnot as an administrator but as a writer and advocate during years as executive director of Citizens Housing and Planning Council, a public interest groupMr. Starr was expected by many housing specialists to excel more as an articulate spokesman and planningminded theorist than as a departmental administrator in the narrow sense on that score, as it turned out, many think they were right.

title: People in Sports
description: Why should I feel guilty? says George Atkinson, Oakland defensive back, whose hit on Lynn Swann caused the Pittsburgh wide receiver to suffer a concussion in the Raiders victory over the Steelers on Sunday. I don't think I've done anything wrong. it was nothing intentional. There are no hard feelings. I don't know the man. I'm iust doing my job.

title: Notes on People
description: India's new Ambassador to the United States was announced yesterday as Kewal Singh, who retired as Foreign Secretary six months ago. He will succeed T. N. Kaul, Ambassador since 1973. who also proceeded Mr. Singh as foreign Secretary.

title: Maj. Gen. John Willems Dies at 74; Served Under Patton in Africa
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 15 (AP)Maj Gen. John M. Willems, former chief of staff in the Army's postwar occupation of Germany, died in a hospital here yesterday. He was 74 years old.

title: Reagan to Campaign in 8 States
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 (AP)Ronald Reagan is hitting the campaign trail again, returning favors to candidates who helped him in his attempt to win the Republican. Presidential nomination. The former California Governor has scheduled fundraising speeches in eight states over the next six weeks for 15 candidates.

title: VANCE LOOKING TO TIES WITH THE THIRD WORLD
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 15 (AP)Cyrus R. Vance, mentioned as possible Secretary of State if Jimmy Carter becomes President, said today that the United States had its best chance in years to reach sound economic agreements with developing countries.

title: A Family That Preys Together, As Told by the New York Police
description: In late summer, the police say, Sixton Carrion began dropping in on elderly men and women in housing projects in upper Manhattan with his wife and 3yearold daughter.

title: 1111G'S PENETRATION WORRYING TO JAPAN
description: The undetected final approach of the vagrant Soviet MIG25 to Japan has brought home to Government circles in Tokyo the loopholes in the country's air defense, according to United States defense sources.

title: District Attorney Denies Sex Chargel
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 15 (UPI)  District Attorney Jon Holcombe of Onondaga County, who was indicted today on charges of sexual abuse and driving while intoxicated, pleaded not guilty and said he would decide next week on his official future.

title: WorkWeek Dispute Spurred Ford Strike
description: A basic difference in approach between union and company on how to reduce the standard 40hour workweek precipitated the strike of 165,000 Ford Motor Company employees, a classic case of a strike no one wanted. Both Ford and the United Automobile Workers entered the negotiations confident that they would arrive at an agreement with no need for a test of economic muscle. With car sales booming, the company was eager to keep General Motors from spreadeagling the market at the introduction of the 1977 model lines. The union, for its part, had no desire to create fresh distress for thousands of its members still struggling to pay debts acquired during the 197475 recession.

title: Rep. Boggs's Opponent Quits
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 15 (UPI)Representative Corinne C. Boggs, Democrat of Louisiana, is virtually assured of another twoyear term in Congress. Her only opponent in the Nov. 2 race withdrew.

title: Street Songs Presented By Geraldine Fitzgerald At Reno Sweeney Show
description: Geraldine Fitzgerald, her dusty blond hair billowing down to her shoulders, wearing a black cape from Connemara, Ireland, and skirt over a red petticoat, her eyes sparkling and dancing, her voice ranging from a gentle nasal wail to raucous bray, is singing what she describes as street songs at Reno Sweeney through Sunday.

title: Business Leaders, Assailing Isolationism, Urge a New Nuclear Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Assailing tendendencies toward nuclear isolation ism in the United States, a group of American business leaders today called on the Ford Administration to put together a new nuclear energy policy integrating foreign and domestic need.

title: CRUDE OIL IMPORTS RISE; HEATING FUEL SUPPLY UP
description: Imports of crude oil rose to nearrecord levels last week while stocks of heating oil moved higher, according to statistics released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Steven Ford to Quit Studies To Campaign for His Father
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP)Steven Ford, the President's youngest son, has decided to take a leave of absence from college until January to campaign for his father, a White House spokesman said today.

title: Natomas Corp. Agrees to Acquire Apexco for $127 Million in Cash
description: A preliminary agreement whereby the Natomas Corporation would acquire Apexco Inc. for about $127 million in cash, or $31.50 an Apexco share, was announced yesterday by the Apache Corporation. Apache holds 2.41 million.

title: Three Czechoslovak Cabinet Officials Are Dismissed
description: PRAGUE, Sept. 15 (Reuters)Czechoslovakia's Agriculture Minister and two Deputy Prime Ministers were dismissed from their posts today after criticism of the state of the economy by Communist Party leaders.

title: Utah Republicans Pick a Political Novice in Effort to Oust Rep. Howe
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 15 (UPI)Dan Marriott, a political newcomer, scored an easy Republican primary victory yesterday in Utah's Second Congressional District. He is a heavy favorite to oust Representative Allan T. Howe, a Democrat whose campaign is shadowed by a sex scandal.

title: 2 Buses Firebombed Outside Johannesburg
description: JOHANNESBURG, Thursday, Sept. 16Two buses were firebombed in separate incidents in the white suburbs of Johannesburg last night, the first time that black protesters have struck in the white areas of the city since the antiGovernment upheaval here began three months ago.

title: Big Board Reports Large Sales Of Shares by Two Executives
description: Hamilton B. Mitchell, chairman of the executive committee of Dun & Bradstreet Inc. the large financial service firm, sold 20,000 shares early in August, leaving him with 17,320. His office reported that Mr Mitchell, who retired as chairman more than a year ago, was slowly unwinding and that the 20,000 shares sold had been obtained through exercise of a stock option. He plans to continue as a director and chairman of the executive committee.

title: Cordero in Belmont Spill
description: Angelo Cordero, one of America's leading riders, was unseated at Belmont Park yesterday and his misfortune brought good fortune to a lesserknown iockev.

title: Another September for the Phillies
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15  When the games dwindle down to a precious few in September, that's when baseball is at its best. Magic numbers, Pennant races at a glance. Check the scoreboard. But, until a few weeks ago, it appeared that there would be no September baseball this year. At the time the Philadelphia Phillies were 151/2 games ahead of the Pittsburgh Pirates, while the Cincinnati Reds, the New York Yankees and the Kansas City Royals were dominating their divisions. But then the Phillies and the Royals began to lose, and the Pirates and the Oakland A's began to win. And now September baseball exists. It's a new experience Kansas City, where September always was a month for football. But here September is the month where, in 1964, the Phillies blew the National League pennant by losing 10 of their last 12 games. All over Philadelphia the number 76 honors the Bicentennial, but tonight 64 was the number in the minds everybody at Veterans Stadium as the Pirates narrowed the Phillies lead to five games with a 72 victory in the opener of a twogame series.

title: A Strong Islander Team Opens Camp
description: FARMINGDALE, L.I., Sept. 15Bryan Trottier married during the summer. So did J.P. Parise. Gerry Hart refinished a house in Port Washington, and Bert Marshall built one near Lake Tahoe.

title: 2 FIRES IN BRONX FORCE 25 FAMILIES FROM HOMES
description: Firemen battled two multiplealarm fires in the Bronx last night in abandoned and partially occupied tenements. At least 25 families were forced from their apartments. No one was reported injured.

title: Mrs. Abzug, Out of Race, Won Talk About Future
description: Of all the Senatorial candidates, Bella S. Abzug had the most to losea seat in the United States House of Representatives. it was a job she has said she loved, one in which she had gained considerable influence in the six years she held it.

title: Bridge:
description: Until the beginning of this decade team play was the preserve of a tiny minority of experts and nearexperts. The ordinary tournament player was not attracted by events lasting four days or more, and was content to play in pair games. This state of affairs was revolutionized by the introduction of Swiss team events, in which teams play short matches and the contest lasts one day, or perhaps two.

title: Hennigan Back With Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 15Players continued to shake hands on the Jets today as they introduced themselves. The newest shuttle had Mike Hennigan, a linebacker, reactivated after failing his physical examination but signing an injury waiver. To make room for him, Jim Rosecrans, also a linebacker, was dropped.

title: INDIA REPORTS GAINS IN POPULATION DRIVE
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 15After years of lagging efforts, the Government of India mys that it is finally making some real progress in the battle to slow the rapid growth of population.

title: Financial Data of U.S. Military Unit In Iran Are Reported Destroye
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15The financial records of the United States military mission in Teheran have been destroyed in an apparent attempt to thwart an inquiry by service ivestigators, according to wellplaced sources.

title: CANADA SETS DEADLINES FOR METRIC CONVERSION
description: HALIFAX', Nova Scotia, Sept. 15 (AP)The Metric Commission today announced timeables for metric conversion affecting automobiles, schools and real estate.

title: Article 6  No Title
PANEL IS OPTIMISTIC ON ECONOMY FOR 77
description: The United States economy for 1977 was painted in largely rosy colors yesterday by economists and executives at a Conference Board meeting, with the only somber tones being references to the persistent presence of inflation and unemployment within an overall improving situation.

title: Book World Meets in Frankfurt
description: FRANKFURT, Sept. 15The Frankfurt Book Fair, which opens here tomorrow, will be the biggest in its 28year postwar history.

title: Golf
description: AT PIPING ROCK CLUB

title: U.S. Carrier in Collision
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 15 (UPI)  Tie Navy reported today that the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy and the destroyer Bordelon collided last night while the smaller ship was being refueled north of Scotland. Six men aboard the Bordelon were injured, two of them seriously, and both ships sustained structural damage, the spokesman said.

title: The Moon Church: From Parents Who Approve
description: No, they insisted, their children had never been brainwashed into forsaking their heritage to follow the Rev. Sun Myung Moon and his controversial Onfication Church.

title: Senate Confirms 8 Ambassadors, Including Stoessel in Bonn Post
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)The Senate today confirmed the nomination of Walter J. Stoessel Jr. to be ambassador to West Germany.

title: Printing Union Endorses Carter
description: The 41st convention of the International Printing and Graphic Communications Union endorsed Jimmy Carter, the Democratic Presidential nominee, and his running mate, Senator Walter F. Mondale, the Associated Press reported yesterday. The union, representing more than 300,000 employees, is negotiating a merger with the United Paper workers International Union that would combine 445,000 members in one unit.

title: ExYale Nursing Director Dies
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. Sept. 15 (AP) Helene Mary Fitzgerald, retired director of nursing at the Yale University Health Service, died Sunday at New Rochelle Hospital. A graduate of the first class of the Yale School of Nursing in 1926. she later taught at the school. She retired in 1973.

title: Scientists Planning Studies of AerosolOzone Problem
description: LOGAN, Utah, Sept. 15 Observation programs on both national and international levels are being developed to attack the uncertainties cited in this week's report by the National Academy of Sciences on the suspected threat of some spray can propellants and related chemicals to the atmospheric ozone layer.

title: 'Bugsy Malone' Puts youth in 20's Gang Movies
description: "If it were raining brains," says the narrator at the start of "Bugsy Malone," "Roxy Robinson wouldn't even get wet." We then see a close-up of the terrified face of Roxy Robinson as he's pursued down a dark Manhattan alley by the gunmen of a rival gang. Suddenly he's cornered. Roxy pleads for his life. "Hey, fellas . . ." But in vain. Right in front of our eyes Roxy Robinson is executed with gangland's newest secret weapon, the Splurge gun, a machine gun loaded with what looks like Reddi-Whip.That custard pies can maim and whipped cream should kill are only two of the ways in which some basic laws of the cinema are cheerfully junked in this wildly uneven but imaginative and stylish satire of 1920's gangster movies. The film, which opened yesterday at the Baronet, was written and directd by Alan Parker, an Englishman with a lot of improbable talent.I mean that only someone with an improbable talent and an emerging death wish would attempt to make such a film, which also includes a first-rate musical score and choreography, along with a cast of kids. They aren't "Our Gang" toddlers by any means, but young teen-agers, some of whom look pre-pubescent and others in their mid-20's, a discrepancy that haunts the film and makes for some uneasy moments.But discrepancy is virtually the method of the movie, which is at its best when the satire is played straight without cute mannerisms. When one isn't aware that most of the girls look years older than the boys, and when we don't see that the cars they are driving are propelled by pedals, "Bugsy Malone" has a good deal of the charm of the stage version of Sandy Wilson's "The Boy Friend."In addition to Mr. Parker's very funny screenplay and his apparent ability to tone down the natural stridency of his young actors, the film's chief assets are the 10 Paul Williams songs that are very much of this decade, but presented in orchestrations that wittily recall the sounds of the 1920's.They are lip-synched by the actors, but sung on the soundtrack with much verve by Mr. Williams and some other uncredited singers, including a young woman who does two Streisand-like numbers, "I'm Feeling Fine" and "Ordinary Fool," as well as the now-comparable Barbra might do them.Gillian Gregory's choreography, with much emphasis on the Charleston, is the first real choreography we've had on the screen in a couple of years. It has a nice, old-fashioned (by movie standards) directness to it, especially in a song called "Bad Guys," in which five fresh-faced hoodlums sing and dance the pleasures of being absolutely rotten ("We could have been anything we wanted to be. . . . But we're the very best at being bad").Scott Baio, who looks young in a small, slight, sort of ageless way, plays the title role, that or a good-hearted fellow who joins a gang to get money to send his true love, named Blousey (Florrie Dugger), to fulfill her dreams in Hollywood. I have no idea how old Miss Dugger is, but by being pretty, fat-faced and very, very prissy she is marvelously funny as the ingnue. The star of the show, though, is Jodie Foster who, at 14 (14?), comes across as a combination of Jean Harlow, Twiggy and Glenda Farrell. She is tough, comic, and on her way to becoming one of the screen's great beauties.The boys in the cast, including Mr. Baio and John Cassissi, who plays Fat Sam, the speakeasy owner and failed ganglord, have a much tougher time because they always look to be in adult masquerade, even when you suspect that they might be older than they look and victims of arrested development. Their performances are good, but their appearances are disorienting, which is not true of the girls because, I suspect, we expect girls to be older for their ages than boys."Bugsy Malone" is a picture for Humbert Humbert to see again and again. It is also something of an achievement in the cinema of the G-rated bizarre.

title: Events Today
description: DEBBIE REYNOLDS SHOW, staged and choreographed by Ron Lewis; at the Minskoff Theater, West,45th Street, 7.

title: News Summary
description: Tanzania's President was pessimistic after several hours of talks in Dar es Salaam with Secretary of State Kissinger. Julius K. Nyerere said he had beard nothing to encourage the possibility of negotiated solutions for either SouthWest Africa or Rhodesia. Mr. Kissinger suggested later that the statement might turn out to be only positioning in preparation for later talks with South Africa's Prime Minister. [Page 1, Columns 12.]

title: PRINCE PAUL DEAD AT 93
description: PRINCE PAUL DEAD AT 93; PREWAR YUGOSLAV REGENT

title: White Rhodesians Ruling Party Opens 3Day Congress in Umtali
description: UMTALI, Rhodesia, Sept. 15 (Reuters)Surrounded by barricades and with military aircraft patrolling nearby hills, white politicians of Rhodesia's ruling party today discussed their future policy.

title: HOSPITAL EMPLOYEES GET A 4 INCREASE
description: A compromise award that grants about 40.000 hospital workers a 41 percent wage increase for the first six months of next year and gives some costsaving changes to management was handed down yesterday by an arbitrator.

title: 11 Towns in Jersey's Hudson County Will Consolidate Fire Departments
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 15A plan that would save $8.2 million a year by consolidating Fire Departments in 11 of the 12 municipalities in the county, was unveiled today by Hudson County Executive Edward F. Clark and Mayor Paul T. Jordan of Jersey City. This would be the first rationalization of services on a countywide basis in the state, the officials said at a news conference here today The proposal envisions a Hudson County Metropolitan Fire Department, responsible for combating fires and arson on a countywide basis and would combine the men and equipment in the 11 municipal Fire Departments under one command.

title: Yankees Alexander Checks Indians on FourHitter, 20
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 15The Baltimore Orioles may refuse to die easily, but the Yankees hardly notice, for they are winning the division title on their own.

title: FORMER NIXON AIDE DENIES SOLICITING CAMPAIGN FUND
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)Richard V. Allen, former deputy assistant to President Nixon for international economic affairs, today strongly denied that he had ever solicited an illegal campaign contribution from the Grumman Corporation.

title: The Key Issues in the Ford Dispute
description: PARTICIPANTSThe Ford Motor Company, with 200,000 employees in 39 states, and 102 plants, depots and research and engineering facilities in 23 states. The United Automobile Workers, with 165,000 members in 91 Ford plants and installations in 22 states.

title: I.M.F, GOLD AUCTION PUSHES PRICES DOWN TO $109,40 AN OUNCE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15The International Monetary Fund auctioned an additional 780,000 ounces of its gold today at an average price of $109.40 an ounce.

title: Bonn Official Will Fly to U.S. For Data in Lockheed Inquiry
description: BONN, Sept. 15A high West German Government official will fly to Washington on Sunday to negotiate with the Justice Department for access to files on possible Lockheed payoffs here in the early 1960's, it was announced today.

title: Books of The Times
description: One of the more impressive things about Paula Fox's new novel, The Widow's Children, is the extraordinary difficulty one encounters in trying to describe it. it is simple enough to read for adjectivesdramatic, subtle emotionally precise, Chekhovian is possible to sum up the action of the plot: Some relatives and a close friend of Laura Maldonada Clapper, a dclass Spanish lady now living in the United States, have gathered in New York City for drinks and dinner to wish Laura and her husband, Desmond, bon voyage on the eve of their departure on a tour of Africa. As the evening limps along and already taut tensions of the group's relationships approach their snapping points, it becomes increasingly mysterious why Laura is withholding the news she has received at the beginning of the evening of the death of her mother, Alma, who is important in one way or another to every member of the gathering. When the news finally does come out, in a remarkable display of histrionics, it leads to a series of tiny but significant rebellions among the group, which, for better or worse, will forever after alter its relations.

title: Rights Activist in Poughkeepsie Released by Judge in Vote Case
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 15 (AP)Clement Parkinson of Poughkeepsie has been given a conditional discharge and $100 fine after pleading guilty to misdemeanor charges of attempted false voter registration.

title: Episcopal Bishops Vote to Permit Women to Be Ordained as Priests
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 15The House of Bishops of the Episcopal Church voted 95 to 61 today to probity the ordination of women to be priests and bishops.

title: The Standings
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: McClain Sold by Nets to Nuggets; N.B.A. Votes on 3 Officials Today
description: The Nets sold Ted McClain to the Denver Nuggets yesterday in a deal that left Kevin Loughery, the coach, and Bill Melchionni, the assistant to the president, perplexed and angered. Neither had been consulted and both were upset when they About learned about the loss of one of the top defensive Pro backcourt men in the now Basketball defunct American Basketball Association. But Roy Boe, the Nets president, in his many wheelings and dealings, apparently had promised to give up the 6foot1inch McClain to Carl Scheer, the Nuggets president. Making the deal less understandable was the fact that the Nets, like the Nuggets, are in need of outstanding guards.

title: Democrats Parley On Major Issues Has Uneven Start
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15The Democratic National Committee started series of weekly news conferences on major campaign issues today with an attack on Republican housing policies, and virtually everything went wrong.

title: South Africa Begins Mass Removal Of 45,000 Tribesmen to New Area
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 15The South African Government, acting under a policy of clearing blacks from areas reserved for whites, began the forcible removal today of 45,000 tribesmen from land 120 miles west of Johannesburg.

title: Miss Turnball Scores Upset Over Miss Casals
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 15 (AP)Li known Wendy Turnball of Australia upset thirdseeded Rosie Casals, 46, 76, 62, in the first round of the national women's indoor tennis championships today.

title: Singapore Bank Americard Plan
description: SINGAPORE, Sept. 15 (UPI)The Bang of America announced today plans to begin a joint venture credit card servic* with a Singapore bank aimed at Southeast Asia market.

title: Staff Seeks to Open Bronx Hospital
description: Some doctors at the new North Central Bronx Hospital were said yesterday to be considering opening the hospital for full services themselves if New York city's Health and Hospitals Corporation did not move to open it officially. tile hospital, which was to replace the aging Morrisania Hospital in the South Bronx and Fordham Hospital, also in the Bronx, was scheduled to open last month. It is awaiting its operating certificate from the State Health Department spokesman for the Health Department said, however: The decision is awaiting a fiscal review by the Emergency Financial Control Board. The only part of the $100 million, 420bed facility now open is the outpatient clinic.

title: I.R.S. Agent Fined in Tax Fraud
description: NEWARK, Sept. 15 (AP)A former Internal Revenue Service agent who pleaded guilty in Federal court here to conspiracy charges has been fined $2,500 and placed on two years probation. The agent, Emmet Diehl, 63 years old, of Rahway was fined yesterday by Judge Lawrence of Federal District Court. Mr. Diehl, who had been assigned to examine the books of Power Flow Inc. of Linden, was accused of conspiring with 'he company's former president to file false tax returns. The president of the concern, Edward Krogstad, is scheduled to stand trial on related charges. An accountant retained by the company, Joseph Vetere, has pleaded guilty to conspiracy charges.

title: State Monitoring Efforts by City To Find Absent Welfare Fathers
description: The state yesterday put 35 state monitors into the city to supervise what it called unsatisfactory efforts in tracking down absent fathers to get them to help support their welfare families.

title: Pirates Top Phillies, Cut Margin to 5
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 (AP)Bill Robinson slammed a tworun homer, single and drove in three runs tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat Philadelphia, 72, and moved within five games of the frontrunning Phillies in National League East. Both teams have IS games left.

title: Meadowlands Drivers
American Bank and Trust Bought by Leumi of Israel
description: Charging practices in violation of law and an unsafe and unsound condition, New York Superintendent of Banks John G. Heimann yesterday took over the American Bank and Trust Company, and arranged for it to be purchased by the Bank Leumi Trust Company, an Israeli concern.

title: Inmates at the Bronx Jail End Their Strike After Promise of Action on Their Demands
description: Striking inmates at the Bronx House of Detention agreed to return to their cells yesterday after they were promised that many of their demands would be met.

title: Leonard Silk
description: Ever since the breakup of the Johnson Administration, the Brookings Institutionthe halfcenturyold publicpolicy research center on Massachusetts Avenue in Washingtonhas been known as the government in exile. The title, whether regarded.

description: Those jolly makers of mixerstonic water and all thatat Schweppes U.S.A. will become network television advertisers for the first time in the fourth quarter. Terribly exciting, what?

title: A Family That Preys Together, as Told by the Police
description: In late summer, the New York Police say, Sixton Carrion began dropping in on elderly men and women in housing projects in upper Manhattan with his wife and 3yearold daughter.

title: MISSISSIPPI RIVER LOWEST IN 20 YEARS
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 15The droughtstarved Mississippi River a major inland waterway, has ebbed to its lowest point in 20 years in the last month, spawning a rash of groundings, dangerous barge breakaways and costly delays just as the river moves into its period of heaviest traffic.

title: Lehigh Seeks to Bolster Defense After Season of Offensive Stress
description: Lehigh made the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II football playoffs last year and won the Lambert Cup as the East's best division II team During 12 games in 1975, Lehigh scored 430 pointsproof of the Engineers offensive strength. But the Engineers gave up 280 points during a 93 wonSports lost season. New Hampshire Notes beat Lehigh, 3521, in the first round of the playoffs. John Whitehead took over as head football coach this season after 10 years as an assistant to Fred Dunlap, who moved to Colgate. Whitehead said, What I've tried to do is to alleviate the feeling that we had on the squad a year ago that we put too much emphasis on the offense. At least I let them know I'm interested in defense. I think it has helped a little bit. The defense had a pretty good game last week.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Upper Volta Aide Dies in Air Crash
description: OUAGADOUGOU, Upper Volta, Sept. 15 (Agence FrancePresse)Capt. Jean Luc Koulidiati, the Minister of Information, Posts and Telecommunications, and five other persons were killed when their helicopter crashed in a storm last night 40 miles west of this capital.

title: Fight to Control Mister John Pits Designer Against Partner
description: Mister John, an internationally known company that produces millinery and highpriced fashion clothes, is now the prize in a bitter fight for control between John P. John, the designer who founded it half a century ago, and Leonard Brown, a businessman who became a partner late last year.

title: WHITE FAMILY ACCUSED IN A HOUSING BIAS CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)  The Justice Department asked a Federal judge today to enjoin a white family in suburban Philadelphia from trying to prevent a black couple from buying the house next door.

title: Bodyguards of Mao Portray Him As Having Led Frugal Existence
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 15 (UPI)In the most intimate portrait of Mao Tsetung ever released officially by China, his bodyguards portrayed him today as a frugal and selfsacrificing worker for the ideals of Communism.

title: New York Mercantile Exchange Reaches Agreement in Potatoes
description: The New York Mercantile Exchange, still enmeshed in the potato default scandal that jolted the commodity futures in: dustry last May, has received a tentative, agreement with the recalcitrant holders of short positions who failed to deliver potatoes.

title: WILLIAM ADAM MOORE
description: William Adair Moore, manager for 34 years of the Racquet and Tennis Club here until he retired in 1970, died of heart attack Saturday evening on a Manhattan subway train. He was 71 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: MYRA L. FRIES, 66, DIES; OFFICER OF NEW YORKER
description: Myra L. Fries, who rose from stenographer in the accounting department of The New Yorker to become the magazine's first woman officer and director, died yesterday at Glen Cove (11.) Hospital following a heart attack. She was 66 years old and lived in Old Brookville, L.I.

title: Business Briefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 15 (AP)Saudiarabia will set up a $2.8 billion stateowned company for heavy industries, the Middle East Economic Survey reported today. it added that, based on a decree passed Aug. 31 by the Saudi Cabinet, the planned company is to undertake petrO: chemical, iron and steel, aluminum and cement projects.

title: McCarthy Could Play Critical Role Though on Ballot in Only 16 States
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15Eugene McCarthy, running as an independent candidate for President, has assured himself of a place on the ballot in only 16 states, liut they include a halfdozen important ones that could affect the outcome of a close election.

title: 3 TeenAgers Indicted in Slaying
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 15 (AP)Three Plainfield teenagers have been indicted in the murder of a 62yearold chemical engineer at his home. Authorities said Jerry Powell, 16; Glenn Simmons, 18, and Robert Thompson, 19, were charged yesterday with the July 30 stabbing murder of Benjamin G. Southwick, who could not cry out for help because throat disease had damaged his vocal cords.

title: Stocks Up a Bit as Trading Rises; Ford Strike Called a Selling Spur
description: Stock prices moved in a very narrow range throughout the session yesterday and closed slightly higher in heavier trading.

title: Black Days in the Cone
description: Within the span of a single week recently, these were the top news stories from the southern cone of South America.

title: Ford Auto Strike Begins Quietly; Talks Will Resume Next Monday
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 15A nationwide strike that shut down the Ford Motor Company began quietly today, and the peace on the picket lines was matched by a marked absence of the rancor between company and union officials that has often accompanied walkouts in the automobile industry.

title: MYRON F. WARNER
description: Myron F. Warner, president of Warner & Vance Inc., manufacturers representatives to variety chain stores, died of cancer on Tuesday in St. Joseph's Hospital, Stamford, Conn. He was 63 years old and lived at 5 Oak Crest Road, Darien, Conn.

title: Giants Careful About Tangling With a Villain
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 15When he hits the tackle dummies, the rest of the Giants stand around and watch. Just looking at 6foot3inch, 275pound Ron Mikolajczyk they know he's not a man to mess with.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th, Flushing Meadow. Queens, 8 P.M. WNEW, 7:50 ?AU

title: Jury Selection Goes on With Kallinger Out of Court
description: HACKENSACK, SEPT. 15The chair reserved for Joseph Kaflinger was empty today as jury selection proceeded in his murder trial.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Nassau County Board of Supervisors said yesterday that it would mandate a oneyear contract for the 13,000 members of the Civil Service Employees Association that would not provide for a raise this year. Francis T. Purcell, the Presiding Supervisor of Hempstead and the vice chairman of the Republicancontrolled board, said that increments for employees would continue.

title: New Books Today
description: Art of the Twentieth Century by Maurice Besset (Universe Books. $7.95).

title: Text of Opening Statement by Daniel Schorr Before House Committee
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15Following is the text of the opening statement by Daniel Schorr before the House Standards of Conduct Committee on the publication of a classified intelligence document.

title: WORLD SYNAGOGUE COUNCIL IS IN ZIONIST ORGANIZATION
description: The World Council of Synagogues the umbrella organization for 2.5 million Jews who are members of the Conservative movement in Judaism, joined the World Zionist Organization yesterday.

title: A.T.&T. FIRST TO EARN $1 BILLION IN QUARTER
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has become the first publicly owned corporation in the nation to earn $1 billion in any single threemonth period.

title: A Harrison Realty Man to Run Ford Campaign in New York State
description: ALBANY, Sept. 15 (AP)Robert C. Baker of Harrison, N.Y., has been named executive director of President Ford's election campaign in New York State. Mr. Baker, who is 41 years old, is in the realestate business and until last March was secretary of the State Dormitory Authority.

title: Mondale Guards Evict An Hispanic Publisher
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 15The publisher of a Spanishlanguage newspaper who is also a cochairman of the Hispanic community's CarterMondale effort in Illinois was removed from the press section of a Mexican independence day rally by the Secret Service tonight. Mr. Mondale was one of the sneakers.

title: CONFEREES VOTE BAN ON MEDICAID FUNDS FOR MOST ABORTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15A SenateHouse conference committee voted today to outlaw in most instances abortions performed under the Federal Medicaid program, but the committee specified certain cases in which such abortions would be permissible.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Sept. 15Governor Byrne signed today a bill increasing the penalties against physicians and others who cheat on Medicaid charges and said that he would ask the Legislature for more money to step up investigation of the $500 millionayear state Medicaid program.

title: Kissinger Aides Find Americans Distrust Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15Top aides of Secretary of State Henry A, Kissinger who, at his request, went to five cities to find out what the American people were thinking about foreign policy have reported back to him that the people find it lacking in idealism and moral content.

title: Nine Are Injured in Bomb Attack On Northern Ireland Newspaper
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 15 (Reuters)Guerrillas today bombed The Belfast Telegraph, Northern Ireland's only evening newspaper, injuring nine people, one seriously.

title: STOCK OPTIONYIELDED TO END SIMPLICITY SUIT
description: Judge Milton Pollack approved an amended settlement of a stockholder's suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan this week after two top officials of the Simplicity Pattern Company agreed to relinquish stock options worth more than $1 million.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Seneca Indians have lived in upstate New York for hundreds of years. They are known as the people of the mountains, and today many Senecas live upstate on the Allegany Reservation. Avery Jimerson, a member of the tribe, has lived most of his 60 years on this reservation, and he is regarded in his community as walking repository of Seneca culture and history.

title: 4European Nations and Iran Plan 2d Uranium Enrichment Facility
description: PARIS, Sept. 15France, Spain, Italy, 1Belgium and Iranpartners for the last 18 months in building one of the world's most important uranium enrichment facilitiesare now planning a second such Iplant to meet nuclear power demands of the 1980's.

title: News Summary
description: Tanzania's President was pessimistic after several hours of talks in Dar es Salaam with Secretary of State Kissinger. Julius K. Nyerere said he had heard nothing to encourage the possibility of negotiated solutions for either SouthWest Africa or Rhodesia. Mr. Kissinger suggested later that the statement might turn out to be only positioning in preparation for later talks with South Africa's Prime Minister. [Page 1, Columns 12.]

title: Ehrlichman Gets 2Month Delay On Starting His Prison Term
description: WASHINGTON, Sept., 15 (UPI)John D. Ehrlichman, former Nixon aide, won reinstatement of his bond today and at least a twomonth delay of the prison sentence he had been ordered to start serving Friday.

title: RUSSIANS PUT 2 MEN INTO ORBIT OF EARTH
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 15The Soviet Union launched two astronauts Into orbit today to carry out research on geological and geographical features of the earth's surface.

title: Soybeans Close Weak; Wheat, Corn and Oats Are All Firm to Strong
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) Soybeans, soybean meal and oil futures closed on generally weak tones today, but wheat, corn and oats prices were firm to strong. The fall of soybean futures prices was the fourth in succession and brought the total decline to more than 60 cents bushel since last Friday.

title: Canadians Take Hockey Cup, 54, In SuddenDeath
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 15The simulated sound of church bells pealed through the Montreal Forum tonight as Team Canada established its world supremacy in Canada's religionhockeyby winning the first Canada Cup with a 54 overtime victory over Czechoslovakia.

title: Prime Minister in Japan Shuffles Cabinet to Strengthen His Position
description: TOKYO, Sept. 15  Prime Minister Takeo Miki shuffled his Cabinet and appointed three government party executives today in an effort to brace his eroding political position.

title: Democrats Split on Moynihan
description: Although he declined to acknowledge publicly that he had party unity problems yesterday, Daniel P. Moynihan's squeaking tight victory in the Democratic senatorial primary exposed some divisions over his candidacy within the Democratic Party. But it also demonstrated strength among swing voters who are likely to decide the outcome of the election. First, the bad news for Mr. Moynihan Black and Puerto Rican antagonism to him was evident in the election returns and in a New York Times survey of voters as they left the polls.

title: CARTER SCORES FORD FOR ECONOMIC WOES
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 15Jimmy Carter sharply accused the Administrations of Richard M. Nixon and President Ford today of creating the country's worst economic conditions since the Depression of the 1930's.

title: Democrats Split on Moynihan
description: Although he declined to acknowledge publicly that he had party unity problems yesterday, Daniel P. Moynihan's squeaking tight victory in the Democratic senatorial primary exposed some divisions over his candidacy within the Democratic

title: End of War is Foreseen
description: CAIRO, Sept. 15Prime Minister Rashid Karami of Lebanon, said here today that there was evidence that an end to the Lebanese civil war was imminent.

title: Emily Hubbard Roosevelt Dead; Opera Soprano and Lecturer
description: STANFORD, Conn., Sept. 14Emily Hubbard Roosevelt, a soprano with the Festival Opera Company of Chicago in 192.8 and the Philadelphia Civic Opera in 1929, died today at a private convalescent home here. She was 82 years old.

title: Mineola Teachers Authorize Leaders to Order a Walkout
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 15 (AP)The Mineola Teachers Association voted today to authorize a strike against the six schools serving 4,000 students in this Nassau County town. No deadline for a walkout was set.

title: ISRAEL AND SYRIANS LET DOES REUNITE
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 15Israel and Syria opened their security fences along the Golan Heights today and permitted Arab Druse villagers from the Israelioccupied side to meet with relatives from Syria in the United Nations buffer zone.

title: Franjieh Shuffles Beirut Cabinet; Curtails Powers of the Premier
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 15President Suleiman Franjieh, whose term of office ends in eight days, announced a Cabinet shuffle today that reduced the powers of Prime Minister Rashid Karami, a Moslem.

title: H.E.W. Plans to Set First Limits on Cost 01 Antibiotic Drug
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15The Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced plans today to make the nation's largest selling antibiotic the first drug on which reimbursement cost limits will be set in programs funded by the department.

title: To Our DoubleDecker Buses
description: On trails once yours, moles now clank fast gray prose. Dawdling, your twotier Bicentennial rainbows Hintright through smogManhattan's lyric past. herd too pious for hectic methtech haste.

title: 6 Football Players Demoted at Georgia
description: ATHENS, Ga., Sept. 15 (UPI)Vince Dooley, the Georgia coach, has demoted six varsity football players, including three starters and two freshman, on training rules violations. The six players reportedly engaged in a brawl in a bar.

title: Stage: Colored Girls Evolves
description: What does it mean to be a black woman in white America? The search for self, the struggle for singularity, the anguished urging to be loved are at the root of Ntozake Shange's remarkable evening of theater, For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow is Enuf.

title: The Iconoclast of Collie Breeders Offers His Theories
description: Kenneth Goldfarb, a New York patent lawyer, is known as the iconoclast of the collie owners. Whereas most fanciers are strong advocates of line breeding, he has decided opinions of his own on the subject. Then he breeds across colorsblues to News sablesand he has own ideas when it comes to of feeding. I believe line Dogs breeding has become the panacea for the breeder, said Goldfarb, but I feel it frequently is a fallacy. it is justified when you have great or very good specimens and want to mold a line. But if you take averagetogood animals and breed them, you merely repeat the faults that existed in the bloodlines.

title: U.S. Investigating Loss of Notebook With Security Data
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15The Department of Justice is conducting an investigation to determine how a notebook, which contained national security information gathered on a foreign trip by one of President Ford's key intelligence advisers, was lost and fell into the hands of an exconvict and selfstyled journalist, Government officials said today.

title: Screen: A Danish Role Reversal:'Take It Like a Man, Madam' Neither Funny nor Moving
description: "Take It Like a Man, Madam," which was shown yesterday at the second International Festival of Women's Films at the Cinema Studio, is a creditable job of women's lib film making that is likely to leave anyone who hasn't been long dead asking what else is new.The 1974 Danish film, communally written and directed by Mette Knudsen, Liv Vilstrup and Elisabeth Rygaard, observes the autumnal plight of a woman who, at middle age, her children grown up and away, her husband a bit of a boor, demands something better than tranquilizers to get her through menopause.The woman is played with much intelligence by Tove Maes, but there's not one spontaneously funny or moving moment in the entire film, the centerpiece of which is an extended fantasy in which men and women have reversed roles. It's material for a revue sketch, at best.The film will be shown again today and tomorrow at 6 P.M.

title: Venezuela Borrowing $1 Billion; 9 Banks Managing 7Year Loan
description: The Royal Bank of Canada said yesterday that, along with eight other international banks in the United States and Europe, it was managing a $1 billion Eurodollar loan to the Government of Venezuela.

title: Trudeau Reshuffles Cabinet in Attempt To Broaden Appeal
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 15 (Reuters)Canada's expanded, reshaped Cabinet, sworn in today, is apparently a response to two problems facing Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeaua decline in the popularity of his party and general displeasure about the state of the Canadian economy.

title: 600 Additional SafetyGlass Bus Shelters Planned for New York City in Next Year
description: In the next 12 months there will be 600 more of those popular safetyglass bus shelters that have been springing up around town as fast as pizza stands and massaep parlors.

title: No Leads in Woman's Slaying
description: ROCKY HILL, N.J., Sept. 15 (UPI), State police said today they lacked al motive and a suspect in the slaying of a woman on a dirt road near an industrial plant. The woman, 37yearold Sandra Kucks of Rocky Hill, was found strangled in her station wagon yesterday on the property of the Keptner Tregoe Company in Somerset County. State police said she was reported missing yesterday morning by her husband, Howard, who is a training officer at the E. R. Squibb & Sons pharmaceutical facility in New Brunswick.

description: *The PickIt number was identical 3T Fterday to one selected Tuesday.

title: Chicago Options Seat Tops Big Board Cost
description: It's a sign of the investment times that seats on the Chicago Board Options Exchange are selling these days at higher prices than memberships on the venerable New York Stock Exchange.

title: People and Business
description: Burlington Industries, the nation's largest and most diversified textile company, announced yesterday the election of William A. Klopman as chairman and chief executive officer, replacing Horace C. Jones, who retired.

title: Chess:
description: It doesn't make sense to ride a dead horse and yet there are players who won't give up a favorite defense no matter what powerful weapons are developed against it.

title: Mondale Shows Wit in Accepting Supporting Role in the Campaign
description: LAKE CRYSTAL, Minn., Sept. 15After reassuring the crowd that the tractorpull would resume after the speeches, the master of ceremonies of the farm fest today promised them that soon they would see Mr. Carter and his friendsin just four and a half minutes we will have Jimmy Carter here on this stage!

title: Mrtitorial Seruires
description: WATSONDr. Benjamin Philip. A memorial service will be held in the Hartford Memorial Chapel of the Prosbyterian Hospital, New York City, on Friday, Sept. 17, at 5:15, Memorials may be made to the Beniamin P. Watson Teaching Fund of the Dent, of Obstetrics and Gynecology at Columbia University.

title: Gov. Noel Trailing in Rhode Island Senate Contest
description: BOSTON, Sept. 15Rhode Island Gov. Philip W. Noel was narrowly trailing today in his bid for the Democratic nomination to the United States Senate in what could be the single major upset in yesterday's primaries in the New England region.

title: Murder Trial of Kallinger Proceeds Without Him
description: HACKENSACK, Sept. 15  The chair reserved for 3osepti Kallinger was empty today as jury selection proceeded in his murder trial.

title: Dangerous and Pointless
description: The proceedings of the House Ethics Committee against Daniel Schorr violate at once some basic principles of press freedom and the simple dictates of common sense. The inquiry is both improper and pointless.

title: Annenberg to Drop Publication Of a Conservative Newsletter
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 (AP)Walter Annenberg, former newspaper owner and United States Ambassador to Britain, has announced that he is dropping American Views, a conservative newsletter he began six months ago.

title: Spiegel Gets the Democratic Nomination for Manhattan Surrogate
description: Justice Samuel A. Spiegel of State. Su preme Court easily won the Democratic nomination in Tuesday's fiveway pri mary for Manhattan surrogate.

title: Norton Tired of Excuses
description: GROSSINGER N.Y., Sept. 15Ken Norton pounded a table in anger today as he discussed All and his excuses.

title: Connecticut Taxes Increased
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 15 (AP)Most Connecticut cities and town increased their taxes for the 197677 year, according to a survey by the Connecticut Public Expenditure Council. The private research group said today that 130 of the state's 169 cities and towns passed tax increases ranging from 52 percent to more than 30 percent. Twentyfour cities and towns kept 197576 tax levels, and eight reduced taxes.

title: Paul W. Ramsey, 71, a Newsman And Retired Government Employee
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP)Paul W. Ramsey, 71 years old, a longtime newsman and a retired State Department employee, died today at George Washington University Hospital after a long illness.

title: Poisoned Apples Given Boston Police Horses
description: BOSTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)Strychninefilled apples were used in an unsuccessful attempt to poison police department horses in South Boston, officials said today.

title: MOSCOW AGAIN ACCUSES JAPAN IN MIG INCIDENT
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 15 (UPI)The Soviet Union, in a sharp new statement on the case of the MIG25 fighter plane whose pilot flew to Japan, accused Tokyo today of being unfriendly to the Soviet Union and of disregarding international law.

title: Greenwich Stiffens Zoning Regulations On Office Buildings
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 15In an effort to retain Greenwich's residential character, construction space for office buildings here will be reduced from potential eight million square feet to one million under regulations that go into effect today.

title: ONEYEAR BILL RATES OF TREASURY DECLINE
description: The trend toward lower interest rates, which was evident earlier this week in such disparate sectors of the credit markets as high grade bank holding company notes and triple A taxexempt bonds, shifted yesterday to Government and Federal agency securities. The Treasury sold oneCredit year hills at the lowest rate Markets since February 1975 and the the Farm Credit System sold shortterm bonds at the lowest rates since April. Credit Markets ancing activity in the newissue market for notes and bonds continued yesterday, and underwriters generally appeared to be successful in persuading money managers to accept the loweryielding securities they were marketing.

title: Jan Peive is Dead at 70; Farm Scientist in Soviet Rose to Latvian Premier
description: Jan Peive, a Latvian scientist who served as Prime Minister of Soviet Latvia from 1959 to 1962, has died at the age of 70 after a long illness, the official press agency Tass reported yesterday Moscow.

title: Butz Campaigns On a Platform Of Good Time
description: LAKE CRYSTAL, Minn.Ignoring rain that made the roads nearly impassable,. Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz descended by helicopter into quagmirelikefairgrounds here this week to bring his freemarket doctrine and his fight for President Ford's election to Midwestern farmers.

title: Once Again, Cutting Redwoods is an Issue
description: ORICK, Calif., Sept. 15The battle for the big trees has erupted again here in Redwood Country on the northern coast below Oregon.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Associated Press Senator Edward M. Kennedy celebrating Tuesday night at his campaign headquarters in Boston after winning the Democratic nomination for a third term. With him is his campaign manager and nephew, Joseph P. Kennedy

title: Schorr is Silent; Contempt Move Likely to Falter
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  Daniel Schorr refused nine specific demands from the House ethics committee today to disclose details of the way he had obtained a copy of the Pike Committee's report on intelligence activities, but the panel apparently will not cite him for contempt of Congress.

title: Beame's Plan Proposes 52 Districts for Delivery of Most City Services
description: Mayor Beame proposed yesterday to divide the city into 52 community districts for decentralized delivery of most municipal services, including the police and sanitation but not fire protection, as mandated by revisions to the City Charter adopted by the voters last November.

title: Connecticut Insurance Chief Named
description: T. F. Gilroy Daly, deputy state treasurer of Connecticut, will become State Insurance Commissioner on Oct. 1, Gov. Ella T. Grasso said. Mr. Daly who is from Fairfield, will replace Jay Jackson of West Hartford, who left the Insurance Department to become Governor Grasso's legal counsel. As Insurance Commissioner, Mr. Daly will get $27,800 a year. Mr. Daly, who is 44 years old, has been deputy treasurer since January 1975. He also is a lawyer and helped Peter Reilly win a new trial in the deather of his mother in 1973.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Antiwar Marchers Reach Ft. Lee On Way to Rally in Washington
description: FORT LEE, Sept. 15New Jersey participation began today in a Continental Walk for Disarmament and Social Justice sponsored by SANE, the antiwar organization, as marchers arrived here from across the George Washington Bridge behind a banner carried by a Buddhist monk.

title: CONGRESS CONFEREES CUT $3 MILLION URUGUAY AID
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15House and Senate conferees approved today an amendment to the Foreign Assistance Appropriations Act for 1977 deleting $3 million in military aid for Uruguay.

title: Washington and Business
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15The Agriculture Department's chief economist, asked to take a look at the world grain situation in light of the recent droughtcaused deteriorations of the big United States corn crop, has found the outlook generally stable.

title: STUDENT PROTESTS fl CONTINUE IN PANAMA
description: PANAMA, Sept. 15 (AP)  Antiriot squads wielding rubber truncheons broke tip a student demonstration tonight after the Government banned all demonstrations until further notice.

title: 140 Pakistanis Dead in Collapse
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept 15 (AP)Rescue workers recovered 140 bodies from the debris of a sixstory residential building that collapsed on Monday. The municipal authorities said the collapse Intel been caused by defective building materials.

title: RCA Unit Increases Prices 6% On Its Radio and TV Equipment
description: Price increases averaging 6 percent on RCAmanufactured radio and television broadcast equipment were announced yesterday by RCA Broadcast Systems, Camden, N.J. Attributing the increases to higher manufacturing and materials costs, Neil Vander Dussen, vice president of the RCA Corporation division, said the new prices would be effective Oct. 15.

title: ADM. WILLIAM READ DIES; NAVAL FLIER AND BANKER
description: Vice Admiral William Augustus Read, United States Naval Reserve, retired, and a former New York City banker, died Tuesday in his summer home at Tupper Lake, N.Y. Mr. Read, who also had home in. Purchase, N.Y., was 81 years old.

title: CONFEREES VOTE BAN ON MEDICAID FUNDS FOR MOST ABORTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15A SenateHouse conference committee voted today to outlaw in most instances abortions performed under the Federal Medicaid program, but the committee specified certain cases in which such abortions would be permissible.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Wednasday.

title: McGovern Asks U.S. to Leave Korea
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)Senator George McGovern today described President Park Chung Hee of South Korea as a disreputable tyrant and called for withdrawal of United States forces from the country.

title: CIGARETTE DISTRIBUTORS IN WARNING ON A STRIKE
description: New York City's wholesale cigarette distributors warned yesterday that strike by Local 805 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, threatened for midnight tonight, would cost the city and state $1 million a day through increased sales of untaxed bootlegged cigarettes.

Mrs. Abzug Offers to Aid Winner; Buckley Calls Moynihan to the Left
description: Daniel P. Moynihan won what he called a gracious promise of help yesterday from Bella S. Abzug in his campaign for United States Senator from New York.

title: ARGENTINE GUNMEN RAID; HOME OF A FORD EXECUTIVE
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 15 (AP) Guerrillas fired submachine guns and threw hand grenades today at the house of an Argentine executive of the Ford Motor Company, the police said.

title: Mortgages of $125 Million Bought By Bank of America in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15 (Reuters)The Bank of America said today Itpurchased $125 million in conventional home mortgages from the Government National Mortgage Association to yield 9.075 per cent.

title: State Expects to Appeal Thaw On Medicaid Fees for Nursing
description: ALBANY, Sept. 16 (AP)State health officials said they would likely appeal a court ruling that could force the state to increase Medicaid payments to nursing homes by $50 million to $100 million.

title: Article 5  No Title
BARBARA CONRAD SINGS CARMEN AT CITY OPERA
description: The season's first performance of Bizet's Carmen was given by the New York City Opera at the New ork State Theater on Tuesday night, with Barbara Conrad appearing in the title role, Ermanno Mauro as Don Jose, Gleny's Fowles as Micaela and Samuel Ramey as Escamillo, The only cast members new to their roles were David Ronson, who was Andres, and Elizabeth Hynes, the Frasauita. Imre Pallo conducted.

title: FORD OPENS DRIVE, PLEDGING SPECIFICS INSTEAD OF SMILES
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 15President Ford formally began his election campaign here tonight with a promise to offer specifics, not smiles and plan to spur home ownership.

title: Pro Transactions ;BASKETBALL
description: PHOENIXWaived Paul Miller. PHILADELPHIASigned Terry Furiow, Michigan State forward and No I draft choice, to twoyear contract.

title: VATICAN HEARING SOUGHT BY DISSIDENT ARCHBISHOP
description: ECONE, Switzerland, Sept. 15 (Reuters) Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, suspended from his church functions by the Vatican for opposing liturgical reform, said today that he had asked Pope Paul VI for permission to defend his beliefs before the highest Roman Catholic doctrinal body.

title: TV: The Last of Mrs. Lincoln With Julie Harris is a Sensitive and Detailed Drama
description: Public TV's Hollywood Television Theater, produced by Los Angeles station KCET, tends to specialize in small dramatic presentations requiring few actors and even fewer sets. Obviously, Norman Lloyd, the executive producer, labors within the hellish vineyards of skimpy budgets, and the product occasionally is noticeably ragged around the edges. But, also occasionally, Mr. Lloyd finds a vehicle that can smash through relatively modest production values for maximum dramatic impact. A distinguished example can be found this evening, at 9 on Channel 13, in James. Prideaux's The Last of Mrs. Lincoln, starring Julie Harris.

title: Flu Shots. Corning
description: Federal epidemiologists began preparations yesterday to ask Americans to roil up your, sleeve as partof a massive publit awareness campaign aimed at getting 200 million Americans to line up for immunizations against swine influenza.

title: Deaths
description: BERTINJack. Beloved husband of Edna, dear father of Lenny and Bette, dear grandfather of Lawrence, Jason, Adam. Funeral services today I at 10 A.M. at The Riverside, 180 St. and Grand Concourse. Interment Beth David.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A strike by municipal workers in Jersey City, in its second day, continued to slow work at City Hall and the maintenance of streets and sewers.

title: Economic Dun Kirk
description: Despite a decline in Britain's trade deficit last month, the pound is still sinking. it has declined every day for the past five, and closed yesterday at $1,735. What is the reason?

title: Congress Shall Make No Law
description: BOSTON, Sept. 15Even in a country that rightly celebrates its freedom, there is a deep strain of deference to authority. When the words national security are murmured, some expect the individual to how automatically to the state. After two hundred years, principles of our constitutional liberty still escape understanding.

title: Tanzanian Leader is Pessimistic After Conferring With Kissinger
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sept. 15President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania said tonight that after several hours of talks with Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger he had heard nothing to encourage the possibility of achieving negotiated solutions for either SouthWest Africa or Rhodesia and thereby avoiding racial wars there.

title: Article 9  No Title

description: PARIS, Sept. 15The most ambitious and audacious temple of culture ever erected in Paris, or perhaps anywhere, is nearing completion in the heart of the capital, amid rising controversy over its facade and facilities.

title: 14 Navy Men Injured Off Manila
description: MANILA, Sept. 15 (AP)An unusually large wave struck the Navy fuel ship Wabash on Monday during a refueling operation at sea, 50 miles west of Manila, injuring 14 crew members, one seriously, Navy spokesman announced today.

title: Dorothy Porter Leads In Senior Women's Golf
description: SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. Sept. 15 (AP)Dorothy Porter of Cinnaminson, N. J., shot a fouroverpar 75 today over the 5,349yard Pine Needles course to take the second round lead in the United States senior women's golf championship. Her 153 total put her one shot ahead of Georgine Dunning of Middletown, N.Y., who shot a 76.

title: Draft Evader Who Fled to Canada Taken Into Custody While Seeirig His Parents During Change of Planes
description: Samuel Mark Israel was planning to see his parents for a couple of hours at Kennedy International Airport while he changed planes. Now that brief stopover may cost him a couple of years of his freedom.

title: The Peasant Look Hits the Resort Trail
description: Peasant power, especially under the intrepid leadership of Oscar de la Renta, is making decided inroads on the resort fashion scene on Seventh Avenue. It's marked by big taffeta skirts, petticoats and babushkas or turbans.

title: Failure of Scoop on Viking 2 Is Traced to a Faulty Switch
description: PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 15 (UPI)Viking 2's soil scoop on Mars malfunctioned because of a faulty switch, project officials said today. They added that computer commands would be sent to override the switch and get it working again.
