title: Corporation Affairs
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 15 (AP)Gov. Milton J. Shapp and a Volkswagen official signed an agreement today that would bring VW its first American assembly plant, create thousands of jobs and turn small New Stanton, Pa., into a bustling industrial town. The agreement spelled out the financial incentives that Pennsylvania used to attract the West German auto maker.

title: Pact A lows Workers To Maintain Furnaces
description: TULSA, Okla., Sept. 15 (UPI)A pact between the Ford Motor Company and the striking members of the United Automobile Workers allowed 12 workers to cross the picket lines today to keep two glass furnaces at the Ford plant working.

title: Council Panel Shelves a Beame Bill
description: A City Council committee shelved and effectively killed yesterday a Beame administration bill that would have mandated panels that resolve impasses in labor negotiations to take into consideration the city's ability to pay wage increases to municipal union employees.

title: FORD OPENS DRIVE, PLEDGING SPECIFICS INSTEAD OF SMILES
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 15Presldent Ford formally began his election campaign here tonight with a promise to offer specifics, not smiles and a plan to spur home ownership.

title: Britons Now Tapping Hydrants for Water.
description: LONDON, Sept. 15Britons queued up at street hydrants today though it has been raining in many parts of the, country for a week now. Little has been trickling into the nation's reservoirs, however so the drought is still on.

title: Carey Signs Order Ending Job Bias
description: ALBANY, Sept. 15Governor Carey today signed an executive order intended to provide more and better jobs in state government for women, blacks, other minorities and the disabled.

title: What is the Press?
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15What the press? asked Congressman Olin Teague of Texas, in a serious effort to define the scope of the First Amendment at the House Ethics Committee's final hearing on the leak of the Pike Report.

title: 200 Coop City Workers In Strike Over Contract; Tenants Fill in for Guards
description: About 200 maintenance and security employees went on strike yesterday at Coop City in the Bronx in a dispute over a new job contract.

title: GOVERNOR TELLS KEENAN TO PURSUE CASE ON JUDGE
description: ALBANY, Sept. 15 (AP)John F. Keenan, the special state prosecutor, has received authorization from Governor Carey to pursue conspiracy charges against former Civil Court Judge Fred Moritt of Brooklyn.

title: STEEL ORDERS DROP AND LAYOFFS WIDEN AS PRODUCTION LAGS
description: The steel industry, after enjoying brief recovery from its weak performance in 1975, is again beginning to suffer from sluggish orders and, as a consequence, is laying off workers.

title: CORRECTION
description: The starting date for cooking lessons by Cook's Corners of Westport Conn., was listed inaccurately in Times last Saturday because of Wm.rect information provided by the school The starting date is Sept 21.

title: Kissinger Aides Find Americans Distrust Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Slept, 15Top aides of Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger who, at his request, went to five cities to find out what the American people were thinking about foreign policy have reported back to him that the people find it lacking in idealism and moral content.

title: Irish Anti terrorist Measure Is Approved by Lower House
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 15 (UPI)The lower house of the Irish Parliament today approved all stages of the Criminal Law Bill, an important part of the Irish Government's new anti terrorist legislation.

title: CORRECTION
description: The starting date for cooking, lessons by Cook's Corners of Westport, Conn., was listed inaccurately in The Times last Saturday because of incorrect information provided by the school. The starting date is Sept 21.

title: FEW SCHOOLS START BREAKFAST PROGRAMS
description: Despite the mandate of a new state law, few public schools in New York City have so far started federally financed free breakfast programs for needy pupils.

title: Bosses and Losses
description: New York's primary election hardly turned out well for organization politics in this city, the machines failed to rally much support for City Council President Paul O'Dwyer; and Joseph F. Crangle, the Erie County chairman, was unable to carry his own territory for Mr. Moynihan, whose chief strategist he was throughout the Senatorial campaign.

title: In Paris, Controversy Builds Over New Temple of Culture
description: PARIS, Sept. 15The most ambitious and audacious temple of culture ever erected in Paris, or perhaps anywhere, is nearing completion in the heart of the capital, amid rising controversy over its facade and facilities.

title: Briton Asked to Postpone Tito Visit
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept.15 (Reuters)Yugoslavia has asked the British Conservative leader, Margaret Thatcher, to postpone a visit tentatively scheduled for midOctober because President Tito is ill, informed sources said today. It the third official visit to be postponed because of the 84yearold leader's illness.

title: Senator Buckley Puts Moynihan Left of Majority of New Yorkers
description: Senator James L. Buckley opened his campaign for reelection yesterday by stressing the differences between what he called Daniel P. Moynihan's liberal stance on issues and his own conservative views.

title: New York State Will Monitor City's Search for Absent Welfare Fathers
description: The state yesterday put 35 state monitors into the city to supervise what it called unsatisfactory efforts in tracking down absent fathers to get them to help suonart their welfare families.

title: Flu Shots Conlin Roll Up Your Sleeve
description: Federal epidemiologists began preparations, terday to ask Americans to roll up your sleeve as part of a massive public awareness campaign aimed at getting 200 million Americans to line up for immunizations against swine influenza.

title: SURVEY FINDS BEAME IS WIDELY CRITICIZED
description: Mayor Beame, whom most politiciansexpect to seek reelection next year, is regarded unfavorably by half of New York City's Democratic voters, a New York Times survey of voters in Tuesday's. Democratic primary has shown.

title: VAT, FIRST TO EARN $1 BILLION IN QUARTER
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has become the first publicly owned corporation in the nation to earn $1 billion in any single threemonth period.

title: Alleged Conspirators Held Sane
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 15 (UPI)The two men alleged to have conspired to assassinate Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, have been ruled competent to stand trial. Robert E. White, 42 years old, and David J. King, 37, both of Springfield, were arrested last weekend along with Sandra Rondeau, 37, of Westfield and charged with conspiracy to murder. A psychiatrist in the District Court yesterday said the two men could stand trial. He did not examine the third defendant.

title: Carter Reception Shifted to inn
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 15 (UPI)A $100aperson reception next Sunday for Jimmy Carter will be held in a hotel instead of an exclusive private club that has no black members. The switch from the Carriage Club to the Hilton Plaza Inn was made at the insistence of Carter staff members and local Democrats.

title: U.S. Judge Tells Bergman to Begin Sentence Today
description: Appeals by Bernard Bergman for reduction and delay of his Federal sentence for Medicaid and tax frauds were denied yesterday, and he was ordered to begin his fourmonth term this morning. At a brief evening hearing, Judge Marvin E. Frankel of Federal District Court turned down a motion by Mr. Bergman's counsel to suppress the sentence on the ground that a pleabargain had been breached by the New York State Supreme Court that had added a oneyear sentence for bribery.

title: Ford's Campaign Speech Attacked on Four Fronts By Democratic Senators
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) Wasting no time in criticizing President Ford's campaignopening speech today, four Democratic Senators each attacked separate point emphasized by Mr. Ford.

title: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS
description: WILLIAM A. BRAND, 2771 Windmill Drive, Yorktown, N.Y. Liabilities, 56,373: assets. 5265.

title: 2 AGENCIES ARE LATE ON BUDGET DEADLINE
description: Two independent city agenciesthe Transit Authority and the health and Hospitals Corporationyesterday failed once more to meet a deadline set by Mayor Beame for submitting detailed plans on their balanced budgets for this year.

title: Coroner Blames Massive Drugs For Death of Former TV Star
description: OCEANSIDE, Calif., Sept. 15 (AP)Drugs taken at a party killed Mary Annisa Jones, the former television child star who was Buffy on the show Family Affair, investigators said yesterday.

title: Cards Denny, Curtis Beat Mets, 70, 41
description: There's no place like home. So goes the refrain, supposedly a popular one.

title: Advertising
description: The folks attending the first of a new series of seminars sponsored by the New York Council of the American Association of Advertising Agencies at the WaldorfAstoria got a little bonus yesterdaya preview of some TV advertising that hasn't run yet. That doesn't happen often.

title: In Memortam
description: ISKIYANGarabed (Charles). Died AerII 9, 1975. Survived by son Peter, daughter Marian and daughter Elizabeth.

title: Market Place
description: A new kind of municipal bond designed to reassure investors while reducing interest costs to hardpressed cities in New Jersey has made a quiet debut in the Garden State.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: My father visited Mao Tsetung in his cave city, Yenan, in 1940 during a tour of duty with the Y.M.C.A. in China. Later, as director of UNRRA work on the Yellow River project, he worked with Chou EnIai. Chou at one time slept in father's bed. I have therefore had a personal, if indirect, interest in the life of Mao over the subsequent years.

title: Bettors Tax Is Tightened By Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP)Congress passed and sent to the President today legislation that increases by millions of dollars the taxes paid by investors in professional sports franchises. The measure also requires that a person who wins $1,000 or more on a single horse race or at least $5,000 in a lottery must pay a 20 percent withholding tax immediately to the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Film: Rising Target
description: ADOCIJMENTARY, such as Barbara Frank's film about the killing of Robert F. Kennedy, has a peculiar power to reverse the order of time. it should be used with delicacy or the emotional effects it produces will be fraudulent.

title: Film: 'Paper Tiger'
description: "Paper Tiger," which opened yesterday at Radio City Music Hall, is a sentimental, fraudulent little comedy about a faint-hearted English schoolmaster. David Niven, who hires himself out as the tutor to the son of the Japanese Ambassador, Toshiro Mifune, to a mythical Southeast Asian country, played by a real country named Malaysia. When the small boy, played by a small boy named Ando, and the schoolmaster are kidnapped by local revolutionaries, the Niven character gets a chance to prove its mettle.The film was directed by Ken Annakin with so little style that even the scenery in and around Kuala Lumpur is boring."Paper Tiger" has been rated PG in recognition, I guess, that the no-nonsense violence that erupts near the end, when the kidnappers are caught, has a stronger reality than anything else in this labored daydream.

title: Charles P. Corry is Dead; News Photographer Won Awards for Wartime Work
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP)Charles P. Gorry, a news photographer who portrayed wars, the waning days of colonialism in Asia and many of the world's leaders during his career with The Associated Press, died yesterday of a heart attack after a long illness. He was 64.

title: United Press International Mourners wearing the armband of the Red Gilard weep as they view the body of Mao Tsetung in Peking. The Red Guard was instrumental in carrying out the Cultural Revolution inspired by the Chairman about 10 years ago.
description: HONG KONG. Sept.16In a major joint editorial in Peking's papers, China today affirmed its commitment to the policies of the late Chairman Mao Tsetung and i said he had adjured the Chinese people to act according to the principles laid down.

title: Buckley and Moynihan, at Meeting, Disagree Mostly on Aid to Cities
description: In their first joint appearance since they Won their party nominations for United States Senator from New York, James L. Buckley and Daniel P. Moynihan differed a trifle yesterday on abortions for the poor and a lot on Federal aid for the cities.

title: Israel Widens Its Military and Civil Involvement in Lebanese Conflict
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 16  Israel is providing arms and military equipment to Lebanese Christian villagers in southern Lebanon as part of its determination to prevent a regrouping of Palestinian forces in enclaves abutting on Israel's northern frontier, according to informed Israeli sources.

title: New Dance Adventures At Brooklyn College
description: Fresh from the glitter of American Ballet Theater's summer season, the Japanese ballerina Yoko Morishita lifts the curtain tonight on a new and adventurous little dance series at Brooklyn College.

title: Lakers Sign Chaney To a 3Year Contract
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16The Los Angeles Lakers, have signed Don Chaney to a threeyear, nocut contract. The 30yearold Chaney, a guard, had played out his option with the Boston Celtics after the 197374 season and jumped to the Spirits of St. Louis of the American Basketball Association. After the St. Louis club folded, the 6foot5inch Chaney became a free agent.

title: Ordination of Women as Priests Authorized by Episcopal Church
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 16The Episcopal Church approved today the ordination of women to be priests and bishops.

title: Broadway
description: ITS IN THE AIR. I smell it, Cyma Rubin said. Mrs. Rubin was talking about the music of George Gershwin, or more precisely, about what she thinks will be a great new longing to hear the music of George Gershwin. it is one reason (there are others) why she is now producing a revival of Oh. Kay!, which will cost $900,000 and most likely will reach Broadway late in the season. Gershwin musicals are not often revived, Ira Gershwin having been reluctant to allow revivals. But Mrs. Rubin persevered and negotiated, and last July she got the rights to Oh, Kay! from the Gershwin estate. Sydney Zelinka, who, among other things, wrote Phil Silvers's Sergeant Bilko shows and Jackie Gleason's The Honeymooners for television, is now rewriting the Oh, Kay! book.

title: Leone is Chosen to Run For State Supreme Court By Brooklyn Democrats
description: Brooklyn Democratic leaders have selected Borough President Sabastian Leone to run for the State Supreme Court in the November general election.

title: The Pop Life
description: RINGO STARR was always the least controversial of the Beatles. Refreshingly unblessed with the creativity of John Lennon and Paul McCartney or the brooding mysticism of George Harrison, he moved amiably through life, everybody's friend.

title: Rhodesian Leader Gets Full Backing Of His Ruling Party
description: UMTALI. Rhodesia, Sept. 16The governing white party of Rhodesia today gave Prime Minister Ian D. Smith full hacking to negotiate on the country's future.

title: For Children
description: NICHOLSON'S BRIGADE, will set up cams in Roger Morris Park, near MorrisJumet Mansion, Jumel Terrace And West 160th Street (lust east of St. Nicholas Avenue), to mark 2130th anniversary of the Baffle Harlem Heights tomorrow. Three shows of military drills and crimes will be given at 1, 2 and 3 P.M. Sponsored by the Washington Headquarters Assoalien, the mini encamement will feature everyday camp activities. The mansion, Manhattan's oldest residence, owned by the city, is open from 10 A.M to 4 P.M. on Friday, Saturday and Sunday, WA 3.8008.

title: ARCHBISHOP ASSERTS CHURCH IS NEUTRAL IN WHITE HOUSE RACE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16The chief spokesman for the nation's Roman Catholic hierarchy said today that the church leadership was absolutely neutral in the Presidential contest and stressed that the hierarchy's recent statements on abortion indicated no preference for either candidate or party.

title: The New York Times/Robert Walker
description: Take place Oct. 24. From left, Robert Abrams, of Bronx; Sebastian Leone of Brooklyn; Mr. Shorter; Donald R. Manes of Queens andPercy E. Sutton of Manhattan. John T. Connor of Staten Island was absent. Article, page D15.

title: Ford Pressing Congress For Additional 1.1 Billion To Increase Shipbuilding
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16The Administration has mounted a major lobbying effort to prevail upon Congress to approve a $1.1 billion increase in this year's defense budget for an expanded Navy shipbuilding program.

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: CHICAGO  Has the American economy emerged frorh its summer doldrums? Has the pause in consumer spending that developed after the fastpaced first quarter finally ended? Alan Greenspan, President Ford's chief economic adviser, suggested earlier this week in a Boston speech to a group of building contractors that the answer to both of those questions was affirmative, and he introduced a new label for the present state of the national economy that will probably be accorded great currency in coming weeks.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: Spencer's Pilots, which can be sampled on CBSTV at 8 this evening, might be considered the opening salvo in commercial television's new season. It might, except that CBS has already shown an episode of Delvecchio, a series that will be carried regularly on Sunday nights. it might except that the new season isn't officially admitted to be open until this Sunday, and meanwhile the debut schedule is being jumbled by the Presidential debates and nervous network strategies for counterprogramming. traits of elderly persons leading normally active lives  is handled with sensitivity by William Peters, the director, writer and producer.

title: Credit Demand and Rates Below Summer Predictions
description: Contrary to widely held expectations among credit market analysts at the beginning of the summer, the demand for credit has stagnated and interest rates have tumbled.

title: Koosman Gets 20th, And Fans 13 Cards
description: Jerry Koosman struck out 13 batters, high for the National League this season, won his 20th game as the Mets beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 41, last night at Shea Stadium.

title: NOMINATION OF WILEY CONFIRMED IN SENATE
description: TRENTON, Sept. 16The State Senate confirmed today the nomination of Senator Stephen B. Wiley of Morristown as an associate justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court. However, the Senator said he would not allow himself to be sworn in until the courts rule on the constrtutionality of the appointment. The vote for confirmation was 30 to 5.

title: Settlement is Proposed in Gulf Suits
description: PITTSBURGH. Sept. 16  A settlement has been proposed to a group of eight lawsuits filed by stockholders against the Gulf Oil Company and former and present officers and directors for the operation of Gulf's $12.3 million political slush fund.

title: Nyquist Agrees to Allow New York To Shorten the City's School Days
description: The State Education Commissioner yesterday reluctantly allowed the New York City Board of Education to continue its policy of shortened school days during the current academic year.

title: Restaurants
description: THE NEXT TIME you hear a restaurateur say, he has gone out of business because he was in a bad neighborhood, tell him to go to Sammy's Roumanian Steakhouse, on the Lower East Side. Situated on the outer reaches of Chrystie Street, just north of Delancey, it has become in only two and a half years an alive and jumping New York institution. Although it offers no decor to speak of, the big bright dining room with freshly laundered tablecloths attracts a loyal and mixed following.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Committee on Relations with the United States as Host Country3 P.M. Decolonization Committee3 P.M. Committee Against Apartheid10:30 A.M.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The J. C. Penney Company's chairman, Donald V. Seibert, said the company had increased its estimate of the amount of new store space it expected to open in fiscal 1977. The retail chain now expects that the addition to new store space will be more than 7.5 million square feet, Mr. Seibert told meeting of Securities Analysts in New York. Last November the company estimated 5.5 million square feet would be added. The company has also increased its estimate of fiscal 1977 capital expenditures to about $280 million from an original projection of about $265 million.

title: NEW YORK CITY ACTS ON TAX DELINQUENTS
description: Legislation designed to speed collection of $220 million in delinquent real estate taxes owed New York City was approved yesterday by the City Council. The measures, which would go into effect Jan. are expected to be signed into law shortly by Mayor Beanie.

title: $2 Double and Exacta Are Back at Yonkers
description: Starting tonight, horseplayers at Yonkers Raceway once again will be able to buy daily double and exacta tickets for $2 each. The price of a ticket for the triple remains at $3.

title: Fleeing Indochinese Often Rebuffed by Passing Ships
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 16Ships on the high seas are tending to pass up boatloads of refugees fleeing Indochina as nations in the area become more reluctant to grant them a haven.

title: 66's by Pooley And Edwards Lead by Stroke
description: MASON, Ohio, Sept. 16 (AP)Danny Edwards and Don Pooley, a rookie, nonwinners on the tour, gained the limelight from their more heralded opposition as they fashioned fourunderpar 66's today and shared the firstround lead in the $150,000 OhioKings Island open.

title: U.N. SeaLaw Conferees Favor New Talks in City in May 1977
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 16Delegates to the sealaw conference agreed tentatively today to hold another session in New York beginning next May in hopes of breaking a deadlock over oceanfloor mining.

title: More Informal Instruction Policy Is Being Introduced at West Point
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 16New academic procedures emphasizing a more informal and personalized approach to instruction, testing and grading are being introduced at the United States Military Academy in the aftermath of its largest cheating scandal.

title: Oilmen in Libya Learn To Live With Qaddafi
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Sept. 16After a long chain of crises, American and foreign oil companies operating here seem to have reached a mutually satisfactory modus vivendi with Col. Muammar elQaddafi's revolutionary regime.

title: Jets Reactivate Gresham
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 16 (UPI)Tne New York Jets of the National Football League today waived Ed Marshall, acquired only last week as a wide receiver, and reactivated a running back, Bob Gresham. Marshall had been acquired on waivers from the Detroit Lions and saw action on special terms against the Cleveland Browns in a 38.17 openinggame loss Sunday. Gresham was with the Jets last year but was cut last week.

title: N.B.A. Board Rejects Use of a Third Official
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 16The costconscious National Basketball Association board of governors rejected today a proposal to use three officials for the coming season. it was the second straight year the owners had disapproved adding an additional official.

title: Associated Press As nonwhites widen their strike in Cape Town, white South Africans find themselves doing the menial chores their employees used to do. At this store, a manager trainee mops the entrance to the establishment.
description: JOHANNESBURG. Sept. 16An organization that vigorously opposes apartheid said in a statement tonight that South Africa's IS million blacks would look skeptically on Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's visit here this weekend unless he insisted on meeting some of the black leaders detained by the Government.

title: City Approves Trust for Building Museum of Modern Art Complex
description: The Museum of Modern Art cleared its final governmental obstacle yesterday in its effort to build a condominium apartment tower above an expansion of its galleries on 53d Street.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Poinsettia: a shortday plant

title: Detroit Fear of Youth Crime Appears to Be Subsiding
description: DETROIT, Sept. 16A month after one cf the most publicized outbursts of crime here in recent yearsthe Cobo Hall incidentthis city's intense fear of crime by youths appears to be subsiding.

title: TITO WILL BE INACTIVE FOR 2MONTH TREATMENT
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 16 (UPI) President Tito has canceled all official functions for two months on the advice of doctors treating him for acute liver trouble. Government sources said today.

title: Congress Approves Tax Revision; President's Signature Is Expected
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Both Houses of Congress passed and sent to President Ford today the final version of the tax revision billmore than 1,000 pages long and three years in the making.

title: A Virtuoso Quartet
description: Those who can, do; those who can't, teach, goes the old saying. it is a doubtful dictum at best, and at the Eastman School of Music in Rochester, where performing excellence has long been a way of faculty life, the theorem has flunked out completely. Eastman, proud of its artistteachers, is undertaking its second annual cultural invasion of New York. Starting this Sunday evening, and continuing on four monthly Sundays thereafter, some 18 playing or singing professors will appear in Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center in a variety of chamber programs.

title: Hunted Terrorist Reported in Yugoslavia
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  American officials believe that the international terrorist known as Carlos was in Yugoslavia last week and that the Yugoslays knew it but made no attempt to capture him.

title: Notes on People
description: Samuel B. Gould, chancellor of the State University of New York from 1964 to 1970, has been named chancellor pro tempore of Connecicut's Commission for Higher Education. The 11yearold commission has been studying steps toward coordinating the boards of regents of the sixbranch University of Connecticut, four state colleges, 12 community colleges and four technical colleges. Dr. Gould will be paid $3,000 a month, plus travel expenses from his home in Florida. He will share control with the commission chairman, Donald C. McGannon of New Canaan, president of Westinghouse Broadcasting, and W. Robert Bokelman of Simsbury, director of finance and administration.

title: RamViking Game Gets Top Billing With Giants and Jets on Sunday
description: The RamsVikings game at Bloomington, Minn., is the specialty of the weekend for pro football's television fans. Channel 2 will televise that contest here starting at 4 P.M., completing a doubleheader which begins with the Giants at Philadelphia at P.M. The Jets are playing in Denver before a full house of 64,000 (Channel 2, 4 P.M.). Here is a preview of all games with ronlost record in parentheses.

title: Music: Marian McPartland, Aided By Teddi King, Salutes Mercer
description: Marian McPartland opened her third season at the Bemelmans Bar in the Carlyle Hotel. Madison Avenue at 76th Street, on Monday with an evening devoted to the songs of the late Johnny Mercer. Mr. Mercer's songs run such varied gamutwithin a single set one might encounter Goody Goody, Tangerine, Blues in the Night and Days of Wine and Rosesthat holding to his songs puts scarcely any limitations on a performer.

title: BP COAL IN ACQUISITION BID WITH UNIVERSE TANKSHIPS
description: British Petroleum Ltd., announced yesterday that its subsidiary, BP Coal Ltd. had exchanged letters of intent with Coal Universe Tankships Inc. of Australia concerning its proposed acquisition of a 50 percent interest of Universe Tankships coal interests in New South Wales. The acquisition, valued at $162 million in Austrialian currency, the equivalent of about $202 million, would become effective on Jan. 1 following certain regulatory approvals.

title: Interest Rate on Mortgages Up In August to 76 High of 9.03%
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 16 (UPI)The average interest rate for new home mortgages in August climbed past the 9 percent level for the first time in 1976, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

title: Carter Says Debate Will Pit Ford Against His Own Record in Office
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 16One week before his nationally televised, facetoface debate with President Ford, Jimmy Carter today predicted sarcastically that Mr. Ford would be pitted against his own performance in the White House.

title: News Summary
description: Vowing to fight to the last man if necessary, an emotional Kenneth D. Kaunda, President of Zambia, told Secretary of State Kissinger that he had only a few days to succeed in bringing about black rule in Rhodesia and SouthWest Africa. Mr. Kaunda said that if Mr. Kissinger failed, the black African nations would be forced to fight. [Page A1, Column 1.]

title: Jersey Lottery Picks 2 Groups of Numbers
description: TRENTON, Sept., 16 (AP)  Two pairs of winning numbers were selected loday in the New Jersey weekly lottery drawing.

title: THE FINANCIAL CHRONICLE TO BECOME NEWSLETTER
description: The owner of The Commercial and Financial Chronicle, one of the nation's oldest financial newspapers, told its staff yesterday that beginning in October the weekly tabloid would no longer be published as a newspaper but as a weekly 8 x 11 newsletter.

title: Levitt and SUNY Aides Clash Over Control of Funds
description: State Comptroller Arthur Levitt clashed yesterday with officials of the State University over who should control the funds collected and spent by the State University Research Foundation.

title: BOND ISSUE SOLD OUT BY A HOUSING AGENCY OF NEW YORK STATE
description: New York State received one more convincing sign that it is recovering from its fiscal crisis when the Housing Finance Agency went yesterday into the private financial market for the first time in more than a year and found its onceunmarketable bonds so popular that it had to turn customers away.

title: Bridge:
description: The conclusion of the Von Zedtwitz double knockout team championship earlier this week serves as a reminder that the new knockout season is approaching. For three of the eight knockouts played in the metropolitan area the entries close this month. The full list is.

title: Change in South Africa
description: Two things stand out in the epidemic of manifestations against apartheid that continues to rock South Africa; and both are menacing, not simply for white rule but for the longrun chances for a peaceful racial and political evolution.

title: Digest of Tax Bill Passed by Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Following a digest of the tax law approved by Congress today and sent to President Ford.

title: Action Attributed to Rightists
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP)The State Department confirmed today that an American, Patricia Erb, had been abducted in Buenos Aires, but it declined to give further details. Informed sources said the abduction was believed to be the work of rightists since the left usually publicizes its kidnapping exploits.

title: Industrial Output Advanced Strongly In August and July
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Industrial production advanced by a fairly strong fivetenths of 1 percent in August and July revising output upward, the Federal Reservs Board reported today.

title: Advertising Glass Bottlers Aim at Wider Market
description: Heartened by an increased share of the packaging market, the makers of glass bottles are taking the offensive in hopes of doing even better.

title: Buchholz is Named Commissioner of W.T.T.
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept., 16 (AP)Earl (Butch) Buchholz was named commissioner of World Team Tennis today.

title: Petition Demanding Vote to Recall Rizzo Is Upheld by Judge
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept 16  A city judge upheld today the validity of a petition demanding a special recall election of Mayor Frank L. Rizzo.

title: United Parcel Offices Hit by Strike Upstate
description: Workers at all United Parcel Service offices in New York State except those in New York City and Long Island were on strike yesterday as part of teamsters action against the carrier in 15 Eastern states.

title: New Haven Will Offer OTB With Television
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 16 (AP) Tentative agreement was reached today on a New Haven site for an offtrack betting parlor offering closedcircuit television display of races.

title: Improper Ticketing Of Cars is Charged
description: Parking summonses, which rank high with potholes and taxicabs as the bane of New York City drivers, are often put on legally parked cars or issued to nonexistent cars, all to meet a cityenforced daily summons quota, according to three parking violations agents and a Brooklyn Assemblyman.

title: DEBT PURCHASERS SUE OVER NEW CURB
description: Representatives of factors, who buy and collect debts, are suing the Federal, state and city governments charging that a recent Federal directive barring physicians from selling their Medicaid accounts receivable to factors was unconstitutional and that it would put them out of business.

title: RCA Head Quits, Admits Failure To File Tax Returns for 5 Years
description: The RCA Corporation announced last evening that it had accepted the resignation of its chief executive officer, Anthony L. Conrad, who acknowledged that he had failed until recently to file personal income tax returns for five years through 1975.

title: MILDRED LAWSON MOSS
description: Mildred Lawson Moss, a dog breeder, died Wednesday at the Hunterdon Medical Center in Flemington, N.J. She was 67 years old and the wife of Edgar G. E. Moss, publisher of The New Brunswick Spokesman, a weekly newspaper. Mrs. Moss was the owner of Roned Kennels in Flemington, which specialized in the breeding of bulldogs.

title: TROY AGREED IN MAY TO HELP U.S. INQUIRY
description: City Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr. has disclosed in papers filed in Supreme Court in Queens that he signed a memorandum of agreement with the United States Attorney's Office in Brooklyn last May 6 to give fully complete and truthful cooperation and testimony in connection with other Federal investigations.

title: CHEMICAL BANK OFFERING RATE CUTS ON SECURITIES
description: Chemical Bank said yesterday it would introduce a discount securities service on a test basis for about 19,000 checking account customers in six midManhattan offices. it said the bank would charge a $30ayear membership fee and a flat $35 for orders of stock up to 500 shares. Orders of 501 to 1,000 shares would cost $55.

title: News Summary
description: Vowing to fight to the last man if necessary an emotional Kenneth D. Kaunda. President of Zambia, told Secretary of State Kissinger that he had only a few days to succeed in bringing about black rule in Rhodesia and SouthWest Africa. Mr. Kaunda said that if Mr. Kissinger failed, the black African nations would be forced to fight. [Page A1, Column 1.]

title: Daughter Opens Ford Offices
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 16 (UPI)Susan Ford opened her father's South Carolina campaign headquarters today, describing President Ford as a hardworking, determined leader who needs public support. But he can't do it without you, she told about 150 persons at the ceremony. If you will work for him, he will work for you.

title: Martin Unlikely to Shuffle Yankees Coaching Staff
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 16Upon being rehired the other day as Yankee manager for three more years, Billy Martin credited the players and the coaches for contributing to his success.

title: Contractors to Work for Ford
description: BOSTON, Sept. 16 (AP)The Associated Builders and Contractors New England chapter plans to work actively for the Republican Presidential ticket, Bob G. Crothers, chapter head, said today. But the group stopped short of a formal endorsement.

title: The New Charms of 3 Musical Classics
description: Noel Coward used to advise Mrs. Worthington not to put her daughter on the stage. Nowadays conventional theatrical wisdom would have advised any Broadway producer not to have put a musical revival on the stage. They seemed to be about as necessary as refrigerators in Iceland.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Associated Press

title: Coop City Fears Effect of Strike
description: Many of the tenants at Coop City fear that the strike of nearly 250 maintenance security and office workers there sharply challenges the tenant's contention that they can avoid an increase in their apartment maintenance charges.

title: Antiques
description: WHERE BUT in America would silversmiths have used spoons to shape a Torah pointer and the dome of a Torah crown?

title: Extradition of Bordoni is Asked By United States in Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 16 (UPI)The United States Justice Department has asked Venezuela to extradite Carlo Bordoni, one of eight men indicted by a Federal grand jury in New York City last month for their participation in the Franklin National Bank failure, according to United States Embassy sources.

title: Vietnam's Gulag Archipelago
description: ELIZABETH, N.J.  Nearly 18 months after Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu's dictatorship collapsed, many former thirdforce leaders, whom President Thieu once persecuted for advocating democratic liberties and a compromise peace, are again political prisoners.

title: Mexico and U.S. Set Timetable for Treaty on Prison Exchange
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 16 (AP)The Governments of the United States and Mexico have agreed to complete negotiations by November on a draft treaty on prisoner exchanges.

title: Art People
description: ASHAPELY and imposing yellow mound is ensconced in the rotunda of the Guggenheim Museum, looking as if it were made for the place and meant to stay awhile. Put together of Styrofoam blocks and covered with thousands of tiny yellow spheres, it rises just above the viewer's eye level, giving the impression ofwell, a shapely and imnosine yellow mound.

title: July Steel Imports Rose 47.9% Over Similar Month a Year Ago
description: July steel imports were 1.19 million Irmo and were 47.9 percent higher than in the same 1975 month, the American Institute for Imported Steel reported yesterday. However, this figure was 12.2 percent below June imports. The cumulative total of 7.57 million tons ran 1.6 percent lower than imports for the first seven months of 1975.

title: Art of the American Past Gets Its Due
description: THE CLASSICS of 19thcentury Amerian painting, which not so long ago were gathering dust and contempt in the storerooms of American museums, have lately been enjoying a new vogue. Art historians no longer risk their reputations by specializing in this material, and art collectors no longer earn the condescension of their peers for investing sizable sums of money in the pictures. The momentum of revival, which was swiftly gaining, speed before the Bicentennial celebration, has this year reached avalanche force as the result of that event.

title: Parents/ Children
description: There's the modern parent. See him? He's the one trying so hard to look comfortable. He knows that parents often unwittingly convey their own anxieties, their own hangups to their children. So he tries to take it easy, even in such tensionfilled areas as sexuality and nudity.

title: Ordination of Women as Priests Authorized by Episcopal Church
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 16The Episcopal Church approved today the ordination of women to be priests and bishops.

title: A COAST COURT BARS SPECIAL ADMISSIONS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16In a landmark decision today, the California Supreme Court rulea unconstitutional a program favoring students from minority groups for admission to state medical schools.

title: 2,600 Walk Out at Sperry Rand After Talks on New Contract Fail
description: LAKE SUCCESS, LI., Sept. 16Work on defense contracts at the Sperry Division of the Sperry Rand Corporation was halted today when 2.600 employees walked out after the union and the company were unable to agree on a new contract.

title: Some Lebanese Christians Back Criticism of Cabinet Reshuffling
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 16  Some rightwing Christian leaders joined Moslems and leftists today in criticizing President Suleiman Franjieh for shuffling the Lebanese Cabinet yesterday with the aim of reducing the powers of Prime Minister Rashid Karami, a Moslem.

title: 11 Said to Forge Cigarette Stamps Worth $3 Million
description: The New York State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance yesterday announced the arrest of 11 persons, most of them cigarette dealers, on charges of counterfeiting state cigarette tax stamps by which they allegedly siphoned $3 million from government treasuries.

title: Gamblers Anonymous Marks 19 Years of Abstinence Today
description: HACKENSACK, Sept 16  One man seeks $400 from his fatherinlaw to pay for an abortion for a woman who is not his wife. Another man says his wife has just had a miscarriage, so he asks his boss for a large loan.

title: Music: Sy Oliver's Dance Band
description: When Sy Oliver's orchestra opened at the Rainbow Room a year and a half ago Mr. Oliver was stressing the crisp, precise and rhythmic arranging style that was associated with him when he established a sound for the Jimmie Lunceford band in the 1930's and a somewhat similar sound for Tommy Dorsey's orchestra in the 40's.

title: Racially Mixed Family Harassed By White Youths in Pelham Bay
description: Ten days ago Nicholas Troiano, who is white, and his wife, Louise, who is black, took possession of a $60,000 twostory frame house in the predominantly white Pelham Bay section of the Bronx.

title: U.S. Hopes to Raise F14 From Sea
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16The Navy is studying the possibilities of retrieving an F14 Tomcat fighter plane from the floor of the North Atlantic, about 100 miles northwest of Scotland, where the plane rolled off the deck of the carrier John F. Kennedy into 1,890 feet of water on Tuesday, a Navy spokesman said tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Many newspapers are carrying reports of late about a Catholic strategy by President Ford, whereby he hopes to win millions of Catholic votes in Eastern industrial states in his quest for the Presidency. The reasoning is that if Ford stresses social issues such as abortion, Catholics will vote their consciences over their pocketbooks.

title: FIVE JOURNALISTS BEGIN YEAR LAW STUDY AT YALE
description: Five journalists have begun a new oneyear fellowship program at Yale Law School that is designed to improve reporting on legal matters.

title: Anglers Likely to Do Well When Weather Clears a Bit
description: As of yesterday afternoon, cold, wet and windy weather was moving up from New Jersey into the New York CityLong Island area, and if it persists through the weekend not many anglers will go forth.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Jury selection began in White Plains in the case against Mel Patrick Lynch and Dominick P. Byrne, who are charged with the kidnapping in August 1975 of Samuel Bronfmem 2d, the Seagram's heir. The defendants also are charged with grand larceny in demanding a $2.3 million ransom, which was paid by the Bronfman family and then recovered: Justice George Beisheim Jr. began hearing applications in State Supreme Court of jurors wishing to be excused. He has summoned 1,000 prospective jurors in a process to be continued next Tuesday and Wednesday.

title: KEY ANTITRUST BILL SENT TO WHITE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16The House of Representatives passed and sent to the House today a major antitrust bill that is designed to give consumers added protection against corporate price fixing.

title: 2 Substances Found in Atmosphere Strengthen Theory on Spray Cans
description: LOGAN, Utah, Sept. 16Detection of two substances in the atmosphere has reinforced conclusions by the National Academy of Sciences that certain spraycan propellants are depleting the ozone in the stratosphere.

title: Soybeans and Oat Futures Advance; Corn and Wheat Are Mostly Lower
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP)  Soybeans, soybean meal and oats futures advanced in moderately active dealings on the Chicago Board of Trade today, but wheat, corn and soy oil prices were mostly lower.

title: The Troubled Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16The Democrats are getting a little edgy about the Presidential election. The pros at the top of the party still feel that Governor Carter will hold most of the states in the Old Confederacy, and that they will carry enough of the Northern industrial states to win an electoral majority, but their voterregistration drive so far has been a disappointment.

title: ROLAND S. HOMET, 85, LED MOBIL OVERSEAS DIVISION
description: Roland Stevens Hornet, former board chairman of Mobil International, the overseas division of the oil company, died yesterday at the Rosary Hill Nursing Home in Hawthorne, N.Y. He was 85 years old and lived in Scarborough, N.Y.

title: KISSINGER IS WARNED OF URGENCY IN AFRICA
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 16Secretary of State Henry A, Kissinger was warned by President Kenneth D. Kaunda today that unless he succeeded soon in bringing about black rule in Rhodesia and SouthWest Africa, black Africans will fight to the last man if necessary,

title: Agents Arrival by Air Reported
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 16Western sources here reported today that Carlos arrived in Belgrade on Sept. 6 ona commercial flight from Algiers with five accomplices, two of them West Germans.

title: Stage: Debbie Reynolds at the Minskoff
description: In order to sustain a oneman, or a onewoman, entertainment in a big Broadway theater, a performer has to have a force of personality, style, a signature, nerve or at least a repertory of our old memories. Debbie Reynolds, who opened last night at the Minskoff Theater in an act called Debbie, has pep, energy and a certain amount of singing, dancing and comedic talent.

title: Explosion at California Aqueduct Tied to Outsiders by Residents
description: INDEPENDENCE, Calif., Sept. 16Sccurity patrols were guarding today parts of the 233mile aqueduct that supplies Los Angeles with 80 percent of its water following a bomb blast yesterday that ripped open a section of the waterway.

title: Struggling Farmers Show Little Enthusiasm for Candidates
description: YAMPA, Colo., Sept. 12The hardprossed cattlemen of the West have revived an old joke that has a special bite in this election year.

title: Fleeing Indochinese Often Rebuffed by Passing Ships
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 16Ships on the high seas are tending to pass up boatloads of refugees fleeing Indochina as nations in the area become more reluctant to grant them a haven.

title: Petition Demanding Vote to Recall Rizzo is Upheld by Judge
description: PHILADELPHIA. Sept. 16 A city judge upheld today the validity of a petition demanding a special recall election of Mayor Frank L. Rizzo.

title: GRACE FINLAY M'PHERSON
description: Grace Finlay McPherson a past presi dent of the New Jersey chapter of the National Society of Colonial Dames, died Wednesday at her Bernardsville, N.J., home. She was 79 years old and the wife of Chauncey R. McPherson, retired vice president and director of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: New York Lottery Tickets Selling Faster Than State Can Print Them
description: The New York State Lottery sold at least 18.9 million tickets in its first week of operation, more than twice as many tickets as any other state has ever sold in a week, John D. Quinn, the state directory announced yesterday.

title: Unnecessary Strike
description: The United Automobile Workers and the Big Three auto manufacturers rank close to the top among the power centers in American industry and labor. Their actions influence the health of the economy and the pace of inflation. They long ago abandoned guerrilla warfare of the type that attended the union's formation forty years ago.

title: At the Movies
description: Despite gloomy predictions that Hollywood will soon expire in an epidemic of sequels,. disastrodramas and nostalgic fever, Brian De Palma is defiantly sunny about the condition of the American film. This is going to be an exciting year, he insisted. Talented directorspeople like Francis Ford Coppola, George Lucas, Steven Spielberg, Marty Scorsese and John Miliusare directing the projects they want to direct, making difficult and inventive films. I'd set these men up against the best of today's European directors. Their movies have more energy, are more audacious and tell us more about our own times and culture than of the European films do.

title: Management Column
description: The Commerce Department, for a $25 daily fee, is offering businessmen traveling abroad office spaceequipped with typewriters and telephonesaccess to a telecommunications and areas wherearketing displays can be set up. Page D5.

title: Politicians Jump Marathon Gun
description: The New York City Marathon got off to a false start yesterday, but didn't surprise the starter or the star runner.

title: Gold Prices Move To $114 an Ounce After I.M.F. Sales
description: The price of gold moved up yesterday on world bullion markets following Wednesday's auction of 780,000 ounces of the metal by the International Monetary Fund in its latest sale to aid poor countries.

title: Events and Openings
description: PARIS OPERA, Metropolitan Opera House, Gounod's Faust, 8.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Sept. 16A decision by the State Pension Board to revoke the pension of former Gov. Robert B. Meyner won't cause him any any financial problems.

title: Frenchman Killed in Acident
description: LE MANS, France, Sept. 16 (UPI)Gilbert Lavelle was killed in an accident today while practicing for Saturday's Bol d'Or 24hour motorcycle endurance race on the Bugatti race track at Le Mans. The Frenchman lost control of his 1000 cc Motorcycle on a fast bend shortly after the trials began.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a report in The Times yesterday on the New Hampshire primary election, it was erroneously stated that John Adams had been nominated as a Democratic candidate for the House of Representatives. Mr. Adams won a Republican contest.

title: 19 NATIONS PLAN TEST OF OIL POOL IN EVENT OF A NEWE EMERUNCY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Simulating an oil embargo like the one that grew out of the 1973 ArabIsraeli war. 19 industrial countries plan to test this autumn new arrangements for sharing oil in an emergency.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: The New York Times/Jack Manning

title: Where to Pick em
description: Ulster and Columbia Counties for pickityourselfers, prepared by the State Department of Agriculture and Markets and agents of the Local Cooperative Extension Service in both areas there are other orchards that also welcome pickers.

title: BOND ISSUE SOLD OUT BY A HOUSING AGENCY OF NEW YORK STATE
description: New York State received one more convincing sign that it is recovering from its fiscal crisis when the Housing Finance Agency went yesterday into the private financial market for the first time in mom than a year and found its onceunmarketable bonds so popular that had to turn customers away.

title: 20,000 More Are Left Homeless In New Tremors in Northern Italy
description: UDINE, Italy, Sept. 16 (Reuters)About 20,000 more people are now homeless after a new series of earth tremors in this area of northern Italy, officials said today.

title: A Legislative Veto
description: In an effort to regain powers that seem to have slipped away to the White House and the executive branch, Congress in recent years has become intrigued with the idea of a legislative veto. Under this concept, the legislators delegate authority but keep a string on it by requiring that any decision or regulation be referred back to Congress for approval or disapproval within 60 days.

title: Bergman Begins U.S. Jail Term
description: Bernard Bergman, the nursinghome operator whose activities focused public attention on corruption and neglect in care for the aged in New York City, ended months of legal wrangling yesterday and began serving a fourmonth Federal sentence for Medicaid and tax fraud.

title: Atlantic Avenue, a Bazaar of Middle East Delights, Holds an Antic
description: A belly dancer riding a camel? On Atlantic Avenue? Yes, and many other bizarre and bazaar things, this Sunday, at that yearold Brooklyn tradition, the annual Atlantic Antic.

title: Books of The Times
description: PETRARCH, the 14thcentury poet, was the first recorded man to climb a mountain in order to enjoy the view. He was in advance of his time the idea of looking at untranslated nature as a source of direct pleasure was a revolutionary one in the monastic attitude of the Middle Ages, nature amounted to a kind of pornography of sensuous stimulation, and was accordingly frowned upon. Medieval artists would no more draw a beautiful tree than they would a naked woman. Their trees, and the rest.

title: INTERIM S.E.C. POST IS OFFFRED DELANEY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16The Democratic leadership of the Senate Banking Committee, faced with the politically delicate task of dealing with two key Ford Administration appointments, has fashioned a plan under which Patrick Delaney would accept an interim designation as a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, according to Capitol Hill and S.E.C. sources.

title: Foreign Trade Deficit in France Up 40% in August to $492 Million
description: PARIS. Sept. 16 (UPI)France's foreign trade deficit rose by more than 40 percent in August to $492 million in seasonally adjusted figures, the Foreign Trade Ministry said today.

title: Improper Ticketing Of Cars Is Charged
description: Parking summonses, which rank high with, potholes and taxicabs as the bane of New York City drivers, are often put on legally parked cars or issued to nonexistent cars, all to meet a cityenforced daily summons quota, according to three parking violations agents and Brooklyn Assemblyman.

title: President Gets Olympic Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)The Senate approved and sent to the White House today compromise legislation that would authorize $49 million to build facilities for the 1980 winter Olympics, in Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: Nuclear Power: Program Controversy in Sweden Gives New Jolt to Already Threatened Social Democrats
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept, 16Sweden's ruling Social Democratic Party, fighting for survival after 44 years in power, has been jolted by the emergence of a controversy over the nation's nuclear power program.

title: Furs Restful Loveliness
description: Thank goodness! We're back to lovely fur coats, at least at Ben Kahn, where designs by Halston are being featured and at Bergdorf Goodman, which is carrying on in the best tradition of the late Emeric Partos.

title: Challenges Holding Up Swearing in of Jury in Murder Trial of Kallinger
description: HACKENSACK, Sept.16Judge Thomas F. Dalton of Superior Court completed selection today of a jury that satisfied him for the murder trial of Joseph Hollinger, but challenges from the defense prevented swearing the jury in.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: The ApplePicking Season Opens
description: It's applepicking time in the Hudson River Valley and, even though this year's crop of McIntosh, New York's favorite apple, is poor, some of these apples and other varieties as well are available for pickityourselfers or for purchase at roadside stands.

title: At $20 or $1,550, Everything is a Bargain
description: PLAINVIEW, L. I.If you say the magic word bargain, it is usually enough to stir the interest of even the most indifferent shopper. And if you add that the bargain applies to sleek, modern furniture from some of the top European designers, the kind usually available only through decorators and architects, you will probably have the consumer of modern furniture beating a path to your door.

title: Utah Democratic Leaders Back WriteIn Candidate In Race With Rep. Howe
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 16Utah Democrats took a major step tonight toward promoting a writein candidate against Allan T. Howe, the freshman Democratic Representative from the crate's Second Congressional District.

title: BOND PRICES REACH YEAR'S TOP LEVELS
description: Surprised and delighted by the big drop in the nation's basic money supply that was disclosed at 4 P.M., traders raised bond prices to their highest levels of the year late yesterday. As a result, interest rates on municipal bonds dropped to their lowest levels since early 1975, and interest rates on corporate bonds fell to their lowest levels since early 1974. The credit markets had moved toward higher prices and lower interest rates early yesterday, but they made much of their gains during the final hour of the afternoon.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Federal judge cut in half the twoyear sentence for obstruction of justice now being served by the former Republican state chairman, Nelson G. Gross. District Court Judge Lawrence A. Whipple granted the reduction 24 hours after the United States Parole Commission declined to give Mr. Gross a parole. Under the ruling, Mr. Gross, who has been serving his sentence since June, is eligible for parole immediately. The Judge's opinion was written before the commission acted, but was not released until after the parole was rejected. Mr. Gross was sentenced in 1974 after a jury found him guilty of arranging illegal tax writeoffs for contributors to the 1969 gubernatoral campaign of William T. Cahill. He was finance chairman of the campaign and became party chairman when Mr. Cahill won the election.

title: Week's Auto Production Expected to Rise 4.8% Despite Ford Walkout
description: DETROIT. Sept. 16  Domestic automobile plants tire scheduled to build 155,625 cars this week, up 4.8 percent from last week despite the Ford Motor Company strike, according to the Detroit trade publication, Automotive News.

title: Citing Polls, a Carter Aide Says Candidate Will Draw The Bulk of Catholic Vote
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 16Jimmy Carter's success in winning support among oncesuspicious Jewish voters illustrates how the Democratic Presidential candidate will also gain strength among Roman Catholics, Charles H. Kirbo, one of his closest personal advisers, said today.

title: Dole is Jeered by Students Upstate And Then Upstaged by Rockefeller
description: Senator Robert 3. Dole, the Republican VicePresidential nominee, got his first strong dose of heckling by students yesterday at Binghamton, N.Y., and responded, grimfaced, with a facetious jab at the Democratic Presidential candidate.

title: Joseph Durso
description: BOSTON, Sept. 16A 33yearold lawyer who has been on the road seven days a week for four years will place a telephone call some time tomorrow from Providence, R.I., to Chicago and could make baseball history.

title: MONEY SUPPLY DOWN $1.7 BILLION IN WEEK
description: The growth in the nation's money supply continued to decelerate, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday.

title: Director Returns to Film His Past
description: Ralph Ferrara

title: Waldheim Supports Move By Kissinger to Mediate Southern African Dispute
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept 16Secretary General Kurt Waldheim today endorsed American mediation efforts in southern Africa despite the skepticism about Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's shuttle diplomacy expressed by some African governments.

title: A Guide to the Best French Pastries in Manhattan
description: For true pastry lovers every weekend is prime time. No matter how resolutely one may stick to the noncaloric straight and narrow on weekdays, from Friday through Sunday, thoughts invitably stray to whippedcream and custardfilled indulgences, to crisp crusted fruit tarts and chocolateglazed petits fours, to buttery croissants and brioches, and coffee cakes fragrant with cinnamon and nutmeg.

title: 25,000 at Mao Service At Bank in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 16  About 25,000 people, including Sir Murray Maclehose, the Governor of this British colony, paid their last respects to Mao Tsetung today at mourning services held in the Bank of China here.

title: STOCKS UP SHARPLY; CUT IN PRIME IS SEEN
description: The stock market advanced sharply yesterday8.64 points on the Dow Jones industrial average to 987.95as investors stepped up purchases in the expectation of a general drop in the prime lending rate today.

title: Economists Meeting Eases Rules To Hear Partisan Political Debate
description: ATLANTIC CITY. Sept.16Economists are more and more entranced by numbers, but the spell of mathematics was broken, briefly at the annual gathering of the American Economic Association in Atlantic City today by the more powerful magic of politics.

title: MODERATE ELECTED HEAD OF SEOUL'S OPPOSITION
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 16Lee Chuff Seung, a political moderate who is known for his willingness to cooperate with the authoritarian Government of President Park Chung Hee, was elected head of the opposition New Democratic Party today in a close contest with Kim Young Sam, the party's leader for the last two veers.

title: At Yale's Happy Hours, a Dispiriting Word
description: NEW HAVENThe Yale education, heralded in song as a spree from here to eternity, may soon become a dry run if the university's Secretary, Henry Chauncey, has his way in a memorandum to the school's 24 deans and college masters, Mr. Chauncey said. I do not believe that any master or dean should permit the sale of liquor in any form, and I believe any master or ean could be liable if a violation is detected.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  Children and adolescents with chronic illnesses will need two doses of swine flu vaccine given at least four weeks apart, a committee of experts has advised the Government.

title: How to Get There
description: To reach Kingston from New York City by car, take the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway to Exit 19 at Kingston. Turn east on Washington Avenue. From New Jersey, take the Palisades Interstate Parkway to the Thruway and then follow the directions above. From Connecticut, take the New England Thruway to Interstate 287, which runs into the Dewey Thruway. Then follow the directions above.

title: Market Place
description: Victor Posner's well publicized efforts to expand his empire are taking on the characteristics of a family matter.

title: U.S. Businessmen Offered Help Abroad
description: An office away from home for $25 a day is being offered by the Department of Commerce to businessmen traveling abroad. The fee covers office spaceequipped with typewriters and telephones access to telecommunications, and areas where marketing displays can be set up.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: You may have gone to Dance Theater Workshop and marveled at the footwork. Now you can visit and just listen to music. The workshop is still doing dance, of course, but it has also moved into music, affording exposure to young musiciancomposers who deal with new music. A new program gets under way tonight and tomorrow night at 11 P.M.. one reason the series is called ALittle (More) Night Music. The opener is Laurie Spiegel, who works in computerproduced music. Next week, Friday and Saturday at the same time, Mike Ross, saxophonist, and his jazz ensemble, Four Rivers, take over. Takes place in the American Theater Laboratory, 219 West 19th Street, second floor (Reservations: 9240077, information: 6916500). Admission: $3. A cup of coffee or tea costs 10 cents.

title: Pirates Win, Move 4 Back Of Phillies in Last Meeting
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (AP)Rennie Stennett doubled home a pinch runner, Miguel Dilone, from second base in the ninth inning tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat Philadelphia, 76, to move within four games of the frontrunning Phillies in the National League Eastern Division. Both teams have 17 games to play, but none against each other.

title: Jewish Museum's Reproductions, From Middle Ages to the Present
description: Spanning the centuries from the Middle Ages to the 20th and the globe from the Middle East to France and Britain, a selection of reproductions from the collection of the Jewish Museum is being introduced for sale to the public.

title: Maine Judge Rules for Jimmy
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 16 (AP)A judge reversed a decision by Maine election officials today and ordered that the name of the Deocratic Presidential nominee be listed on Maine ballots as Jimmy Carter.

title: Giants Look for Surprise or Two From Gimmicky Eagles Sunday
description: PLEASANMLLE, N.Y., Sept. 16Today was DDay at the Giants training camp, and Steve Crosby was a lefthanded Mike Boryla and Bill Arnsparger was drawing circles in the rain.

title: About Real Estate
description: It is too early for the tenants at Willoughby Walk apartments in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn to fling their hats into the air, but they have marched the longest part of the road toward a hardwon victory.

title: Tests by Viking 2 Keep Alive Belief in Biological Activity
description: Viking 2's lifeseeking experiments on Mars have returned data confirming the rather active but mysterious soil chemistry found by Viking 1, project scientists reported yesterday.

title: G.0 P. IN NEW YORK PLANS TO HELP FORD
description: New York Republicans, shaking off earlier fears that the Ford campaign committee was writing off the state for the November election, said yesterday that they were convinced that the President would make a major effort here and that they were willing to reciprocate.

title: The New York Times/Edward Hausner
description: Negotiators are holding private meetings in Detroit this week to seek an end to the nationwide walkout by 170,000 auto workers. Formal talks will resume on Monday.

title: And on Mulberry St., a Midway With a Neapolitan Flavor
description: A festa e tutte e ffeste, the Societa San Gennaro calls itThe Festival of All Festivalsand most likely it is. An 11day pasticcio of Neapolitan eating and drinking, and religious observance, it is expected to attract a millionplus visitors, who will cram into and around Mulberry Street through this weekend and next.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Down 7.6%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the Labor Day holiday week totaled an estimated 13.8 billion tonmiles, 7.6 percent below the yearearlier level. Carloadings in the same period totaled 425,685 cars, off 11.7 percent from last year, which was also affected by wildcat coal strikes. The American Trucking Associations Inc. reported intercity truck tonnage was down 8.6 percent from last year.

title: Celebrating Kate At the Regency
description: WHEN THE REGENCY Theater, having finally done with the Brothers Warner, begins its Katharine Hepburn retrospective with a double bill of Christopher Strong and A Woman Rebels on Sunday, there'll be those who bide their time until they can see their favorite Hepburn films (Little Women, perhaps, or African Queen), and those others who dash off to catch the ones they've never seen, perhaps never even heard of (how about Sylvia Scarlett, or Spitfire?). Twentytwo films, spanning a 30year stretch from 1932 to 1962, will arrive at the theater on Broadway near 67th Street in due time, with Holiday and Suddenly Last Summer wrapping everything up in midNovember.

title: Loan Approved by Asian Bank
description: MANILA, Sept. 16 (UPI)The Asian Development Bank today approved a $27 million loan to develop marine fishery resources off the east coast of the Malaysia peninsula.

title: ARCHBISHOP ASSERTS CHURCH IS NEUTRAL IN WHITE HOUSE RACE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16The chief spokesman for'the nation's Roman Catholic hierarchy said today that the church leadership was absolutely neutral in the Presidential contest and stressed that the hierarchy's recent statements on abortion indicated no preference for either candidate or party.

title: Lowenstein Endorsed By 2 ExNixon Aides
description: Former Representative Allard K. Lowenste in a Democrat, yesterday won the endorsement of two aides to former President Richard M. Nixon in his effort to unseat Representative John W. Wydler, a Republican, in Nassau County's Fifth District.

title: DELAY IS FORESEEN ON 2 NUCLEAR BILLS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16A controversial Ford Administration plan to bring private industry into the business of preparing natural uranium for use in atomic power reactors almost certainly will not be approved by Congress this year, according to Senators, staff members and energy lobbyists.

title: Abortive Medicaid
description: The very basis of Medicaid when it was adopted a decade ago was to assure adequate medical care to those who otherwise couldn't afford it. This goal of removing the distinction between rich and poor when it comes to health services is being callously subverted by the decision of a SenateHouse conference committee in effect to deny abortions to Medicaid clients except in special cases. Only if the life of the mother would be endangered by carrying the fetus to term, or if the mother were the victim of certain specific diseases of incest or rape would she be able to receive an abortion under Medicaid if the decision of the conference committee becomes law.

title: Club's Facade Erased, But Not From Memory
description: To those who wanted its sculptured facade preserved, the fourstory, stoneandbrick building on East 79th Street was an architectural gem. To its new owner, it was a vacant, hazardous eyesore to be converted to new housing. To the Landmarks Preservation Commission, it was handsome but not uniaue.

title: Miss Hearst Faces Sentencing Sept. 24 For Bank Robbery
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16Patricia Hearst will be sentenced on Sept. 24 for armed bank robbery.

title: Ford to Campaign in Deep South In a Direct Challenge to Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16President Ford announced today that he would undertake an ambitious challenge of Jimmy Carter in the Deep South with a threeday tour by airplane, automobile and Mississippi River boat.

title: The Old Thrill of Travel Is Reawakened In Passengers Crossing America by Rail
description: Two dozen passengers waited on the highbacked wooden benches in the Transbay Terminal for the bus to Oakland, where the Zephyr begins its 2,400mile Chicago run. They seemed tentative, with an uncertainty that used to be found in front of airline counters but no onger is. There was a tendency to ask porters the same questions twice. The answers were deliberate and solicitous.

title: RCA Head Quits, Admits Failure To File Tax Returns for 5 Years
description: The RCA Corporation announced last evening that it had accepted the resignation of its chief executive officer, Anthony L. Conrad, who acknowledged that he had failed until recently to file personal income tax returns for five years through 1975.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a report in The Times yesterday on the New Hampshire primary election, it was erroneously stated that John Adams had been nominated as a Democratic candidate for the House of Representatives. Mr. Adams won a Republican contest.

title: The Trust Busters
description: Trust is not having to guess what candidate means. Trust is leveling with the people before the election about what you're going to do af..er the election. Trust is not being all things to all people. Trust is not cleverly shading words so that each separate audience can hear what wants to hear, but saying plainly and simply what you mean, and meaning what you say.

title: Yes, but Who  Who ?Fires the Administrators?
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J.I am one of several professors who teach ecology at Cook College, a part of Rutgers University. The introductory course is a popular one, with an enrollment of 300 studentsa foundation course for many of our undergraduate programs. For this reason, it is always embarrassing to me when our students, whose tuition was just raised, ask me why our facilities aren't as good as those they were accustomed to in high school.

title: Art: Homer's Small Masterpieces

No bound set of Harper's magazine (in which many of them first appeared) is safe from vandalism and there are casesSnap the Whip is a prime example  in which the wood engraving that Homer did for Harper's has a linear energy that he did not quite achieve with oil paints on canvas.

title: Weekend Gardening
description: Put your old poinsettia in the closet this weekend, and you'll have flowers by Thanksgiving. Poinsettias are shortday plants. That is, the natural signal that initiates the hormonal changes leading to flower production is a long period of days with less than 12 hours of light. (Actually it's easier to think of them as longnight plants, but that's botany for you.)

title: Screen: 'Zig Zig' From France:Comedy About Prostitutes Much Less Than Funny
description: "Zig Zig," the 1974 French comedy that opened yesterday at the 72d Street Embassy and 59th Street Twin 1 Theaters, is so heavy with undigested ideas that its ankles collapse in the first 15 minutes. Almost everything afterward is pure pain.It's about two Pigalle hookers who call themselves "love's little nurses" and dream of building a house in the forest with their earnings. It's also about a police inspector who talks philosophically of his relationship to his tapeworm, a kidnapper who turns himself into a human torch (I think) to make the police feel sorry, and a man who says cheerily of his wife's kidnapping, "Women are so easily carried away."The film is the work of Laszlo Szabo, the Hungarian actor-directora filmmaker who hasn't yet found how to recycle bad jokes into good ones and how to blend slapstick comedy with melodrama in the manner of something like "Shoot the Piano Player.""Zig Zig" is chaotic. It also forces Catherine Deneuve and Bernadette Lafont to make idiots of themselves trying simultaneously to be funny and touching as the hookers, who also sing and dance in a Pigalle nightclub numbers that makes one feel embarrassed for them. That's impolite film-making.

title: Today's Football Games
'Street People,' Mafia Mystery, At Film Houses
description: The fact that a half-dozen names are flashed on screen as the writers of "Street People" goes a long way toward explaining why this movie of Mafia fratricide has the look of having been stitched together by script doctors who couldn't manage to close all the seams.As a result, "Street People," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, suffers from a plot that seems to be pushed along, willy-nilly, despite an inclination toward collapse; from relationships never quite clarified; from characters developed for a while, then allowed to drop: from injections of what must have been hoped were cinematic wonder drugscar chases reminiscent of "Bullitt," flashbacks reminiscent of "The Godfather, Part II."None of it helps to cultivate much interest in finding out who smuggled narcotics with a street value of $3 million into San Francisco inside a crucifix imported from Sicily, thanks to the generosity of a Mafioso.Although the real mystery in "Street People" is the whereabouts of the police during all the shooting, the unraveling of the movie's putative mystery is entrusted to Roger Moore, who plays an Anglo-Sicilian Mafia counselor, and to Stacy Keach, whom he employs to assist him. They play it so cool that they congeal long before most of the blood.

title: 'Riddance,' Hungarian Film
description: There may no longer be easily recognizable social classes in Communist Hungary, but there remain class distinctions that can be as malignant as any under the old order."Riddance," the 1973 Hungarian film directed by Marta Meszaros, is the rueful account of the love affair of a pretty, spirited young woman who works in a textile factory and a young university student whose parents are grossly more equal than other people. Having just emerged from the working class, his mother and father guard their bourgeois status not tenaciously, but primly, as if it were their bookcase full of fragile, unspeakably awful knickknacks."Riddance," which was shown yesterday at the Second International Festival of Women's Films at the Cinema Studio, will be repeated Monday at 6 P.M. and Tuesday at 8 P.M.The film is the second by Miss Meszaros, whose "Adoption," was one of the better selections shown this spring at the Museum of Modern Art's New Directors/New Films series.On the basis of these two films, Miss Meszaros is a director of real sensitivity with an affection for characters who pursue unpopular causes, including honesty, to lunatic lengths. Although the heroines in both films are women of fire backbone and wit, the movies themselves look deceptively austere. It's not that the director is without humor, but rather that she prefers to let it surface so perfectly surrounded by unhappy circumstances that it's easy to overlook. The humor has the effect of a joke remembered in tranquility. It's lonely.Thus, though "Riddance" is a serious film, it's likely to seem more solemn than it actually is. In addition, Miss Meszaros's characters don't share happy or funny moments with the audience. When they occur, it's as if they are simply meant to be a measure of the extent of some future loss. Miss Meszaros does not believe in leaving us laughing or crying, only, if possible, more thoughtful.Erzsebet Kutvolgyi, as the young woman, a sort of Hungarian Alice Adams whose family doesn't come up to the snobbish standards of her suitor's, is pretty and lithe and as close to being funny as anything in the film. Gabor Nagy is good as the young man whose bourgeois affection and respect for his bourgeois parents are stronger than his love for the girl. A coincidence: Laszlo Szabo, who plays the young man's father, is the director of the French film "Zig Zig," which also opened yesterday.

title: The Right to Health
description: In literature antedating modern medical care, one senses the patient's resigned attitude toward illness, the expectation of some suffering, and the gratitude to God (and occasionally the physician) when recovery, albeit with persistent symptoms, occurred. These days, one might infer from patient's attitude that failure to render an immediate cure reflects the doctor's ignorance of treatment and that any adverse surgical effects result from butchery.
