title: Kurt Klippstatter Makes An Impressive Debut Conducting City Opera
description: La Traviata may not be exactly a conductor's opera, but a good man in the pit can often make quite a difference between a routine and a better thanaverage performance. Kurt Klippstetter made his debut at the City. Opera Thursday night, leading Verdi's hardy perennial and, on the whole, he made an excellent impression.

title: About New vyork
description: Wednesday evening, Joseph A. Carmona attended to his sauces, puttering contentedly in the kitchen of his ninemonthold East Side restaurant, talking tennis with one customer, paella with another. Thursday evening, he attended to his homicides, unbundling the paperwork of several dormant cases as he toiled in a bilegreen office at the Ryer Avenue Station House in the Bronx, only two months short of having to decide about his future. Basically, he is going to decide whether to get out after 20 years as a city policeman and detective. But actually he will choose between two places, two conditions, two edges of the city, each with different risks for him. On the East Side, he has made new opportunity for himself among affluent, appreciative people interested in his creativity at the stove. But life there can be fickle. His restaurant is going well now, but he is not convinced of its certain future.

title: How the Phillies Phainted in 64
description: As the Philadelphia Phillies struggled to hold what's left of their oncephabulous 15game lead over the Pittsburgh Pirates in the National League East, the frame of reference for historians and vultures is the memory of the 1964 Phillies phaint. Those phamous Phillies were in first place by 6 games with only 12 games remaining. Every baseball triviot knows that they then lost 10 consecutive games and finished in a secondplace tie with the Cincinnati Reds the St. Louis Cardinals won the pennant and the World Series. But who were those Phillies, and how did they turn the magic number into the tragic number? Many people in Philadelphia still blame Gene Mauch, the bristling manager, but he did not have much of a team. In retrospect, the Phillies 6game lead was more surprising than their eventual tie for second place.

title: 3 FOREIGN COMPANIES NEIGHING U.S. DEALS

Crinavis designs constructs and finances liquefied natural gas carriers, and it will a id in development of the Kalingas project, which involves the utilization of sizable gas reserves in Iran.

title: CONGRESS APPROVES CURB ON ABORTIONS, BUT VETO IS LIKELY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17The Senate, by a vote of 47 to 21, gave final Congress sional approval today to legislation that would apparently prohibit most abortions paid for by Medicaid.

title: Jets for Iran: Did Grumman Influence U.S.?
description: An alleged White House shakedown provided the headlines earlier this week, but the real issue before the Senate subcommittee investigating arms sales to Iran is far more complex how sales pressure from a major defense contractor may have determined a maior foreignpolicy decision.

title: U.S. Merchant Marine Honors Heroes of Sea
description: A corps of 900 merchant mariners gathered at the New York Hilton Hotel last night and paid respects to their finest, both living and dead.

title: Golf
Wounded Robbery Victim Chases and Shoots Attacker
description: A Brooklyn truckinggarage owner was robbed of $1,600 last night, touching off a chase through a busy subway station, a bloody showdown between the robbery victim and an assailant on a crowded rushhour train, and a search of darkened subway tunnels.

title: 15STATE STRIKE HITS UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
description: Operations of the United Parcel Service have been halted in 15 Eastern states, including New Jersey and Connecticut, by a strike of 18,000 warehousemen and deliverymen represented by the Teamsters Union.

title: CONGRESS APPROVES CURB ON ABORTIONS, BUT VETO IS LIKELY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17The Senate, by a vote of 47 to 21, gave final Congressional approval today to legislation that would apparently prohibit most abortions paid for by Medicaid.

title: Croatian Hijacking Leader Takes Full Blame for Seizure and Bomb
description: The leader of the Croatian hijackers has told investigators in Manhattan and Queens that he alone planned the seizure of a T.W.A. jetliner Sept. 10 and was responsible for planting the explosive device in Grand Central Terminal that eventually killed a police officer seeking to detonate it, lawyers for the defendants disclosed.

title: Hurricane Leaves Trees Confused About Seasons
description: EAST MORICHES, L.I.Most trees have a pretty good idea of what they should be doing and when they should be doing it.

title: Newark Makes $350,000 Net Profit On Sale of 120 Vacant Properties
description: NEWARK, Sept. 17  A profit of $350,000 was realized by the city today in a sale of 120 properties at the 10th auction of vacant real estate held here since December 1974.

title: Quadraplegic Sues Restaurant
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 (UPI)A quadraplegic has sued Castagnola's, a popular San Francisco restaurant, for $100,000 on grounds that he was denied the table he sought because of his physical disability. James Donald said he and a companion went to the restaurant on April 16 to have dinner and asked for a table which afforded a pleasing view. He said they were refused access by the maitre d who, he said, told them that seating wheelchairbound patrons in the area violated restaurant policy because it would be offensive to other patrons.

title: Spain's Balance of Payments Up
description: MADRID, Sept. 17 (Reuters)  The Spanish basic balance of payments showed a surplus of $293.2 million August, up from a surplus of $58 million in July and a surplus of $253.9 ???? in August last year, the Bank of Spam said today. At the end of August, foreign reserves stood at $5.46 billion, up from $5.17 billion in July but down from $6.86 billion at the end of August last year, the bank said.

title: Poland's Leaders Decide To Defer Price Increase For Food Until mid1978
description: WARSAW, Sept. 17 (UPI)Poland's Communist leaders have abandoned all plans to increase basic food prices until mid1978 to avoid provoking further riots, the Communist Party weekly Polityka disclosed today.

title: Mansfield Goes Out Quietly With Sadness and Gladness
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  Mike Mansfield got to work a little late at the Capitol this morning and left a little early this afternoon, doing it a way that typified his 16 years as Senate majority leaderquietly and without fanfare.

title: Police Kill at Least One in Soweto During an AntiKissinger Protest
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 17The police shot and killed at least one black student and possibly as many as six today during demonstrations in Soweto against the threeday visit of Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, who began talks this afternoon with Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa.

title: Chrysler Recalls 41,000.'76 Cars
description: DETROIT, Sept. 17 (UPI) Chrysler Corporation said today that it was recalling 41,000 1976 model compact and midsired cars because of a defect in the power brake system that could make It more difficult to stop them. Chrysler said fewer than 3,000 of the Plymouth Volare and Fury. Dodge Aspen, Coronet and Charger and the Chrysler Cordoba models that are being recalled may actually have the defect. There has been no record of any accidents or injuries as a result of the problem.

title: Efforts to Block 3 Debates on TV Barred by Court
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 17Efforts by two Presidential candidates to block next week's televised debate between President Ford and Jimmy Carter as unfair to other nominees failed today in Federal district court.

title: Braves Executive Resigns
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 17 (AP)John Alevizos, executive vice president and general manager of the Atlanta Braves, resigned today. Alevizos said he resigned because of the pressing demands of his private business.

title: Bureaucratic Momentum
description: Students of bureaucracy have long recognized the tendency of government prcigrams to achieve nearimmortality regardless of changes in circumstance or the passage of time. Many such programs develop a set of vested interests quite independently of whether any objectively useful purpose is being served.

title: KEY FILES ON LOCKHEED ARE MISSING, BONN SAYS
description: BONN, Sept. 17The West German Defense Ministry said today that its attempts to investigate possible Lockheed payoffs in this country had been frustrated because of the unexplained disappearance of key files dating from the late 1950's.

title: Japanese Sign Brazil Ore Pact
description: TOKYO, Sept. 17 (UPI)Seven major Japanese steel makers said today they had signed a longterm contract to import 280 million tons of iron ore from Braill. The companies will purchase an average of 19 million tons of iron ore over a 15year period beginning in 1979. The agreement was signed by the Japanese concerns, including the Nippon Steel Corporation, and Fernando P. Reis, president of Brazil's staterun mining company, Cia. Vale do Rio Doce, on the occasion of Brazilian President Ernesto Geisel's state visit. Brazil now supplies about 20 percent of the iron ore imported by Japan.

title: 10 Suicides at Ft. Benning
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Sept. 17 (AP)In six months, 10 enlisted men at this huge infantry, center have killed themselves, and the Army wants to know why. A preliminary investigation shows that the only common denominator to turnup so far is family problems, according to Maj. Robert P. Bevan, chief of psychiatrists at Martin Army Hospital. The 10 suicides for the sixmonth period this year compared with 8 for the comparable period last year, Major Bevan said he does not consider it an alarming rate. although I am concerned enough to investigate it. Senators Herman Telmidge and Sam Nunn, both Georgia Democrats, have asked for an investigation.

title: BENJAMIN FINKELSTEIN, REPORTER FOR 50 YEARS
description: Benjamin Finkelstein, a reporter for 50 years for The New York Tribune and its successor, The New York Herald Tribune, died Thursday at the age of 80 in Miami Beach, where he lived. He was also for many of his newpaper years an adiertising man.

title: MICHAEL F. FLYNN Sr.
description: Michael F. Flynn Sr., the president of the Leather Industries of America from 1955 to 1957, died in Salem (Mass.) Hospital Thursday morning of a heart attack. Mr. Flynn, whose home was in Peabody, Mass., was 75 years old.

title: 140 Toll in Mozambique Mine
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 17 (AP)Three miners were killed and 140 others were feared dead today after a gas explosion in a coal mine 25 miles from the town of Tete, in northern Mozambique, the Mozambican radio reported.

title: 2 Striking Unions Reach 3Year Contracts at Coop City
description: Strikes by nearly 250 employees of the huge Coop City housing development in the Bronx ended yesterday when the project management negotiated new job contracts with two unions. The maintenance, security and office workers involved immediately ratified the accords, ending walkouts that had begun on Tuesday at the 15,000family complex.

title: Part Plane and Part Boxcar, New Space Shuttle Unveiled
description: PALMDALE. Calif., Sept. 17Under a harsh desert sun, and while a brass band played The Scene From Star Trek, the first manned spacecraft developed by the United States since the Apollo moon landings made its public debut today.

title: 2 Get 3 Years Probation in Suspected Try on Life of Hirohito in New York
description: A ChineseAmerican couple linked With a possible assassination attempt pty:the life of Emperor Hirlhito of Japan during his visit to New York City last Oct. 4 were sentenced to three years probation yesterday for failure to register 8 rifle transported from California to New york.

title: People in Sports
description: Bill Sharman is a winner, said Jack Kdnt Cooke, the Lps Angeles Lakers owner in announcing Sharman's promotion to the general manager's post made vacant yesterday by the resignation of Pete Newell. He [Sharman] has won world championships as a player and as a coach, and I'm confident that with his tremendous basketball knowledge, he will prove to be; just as successful as the Lakers general manager. Cooke also said that he would miss Newell.

title: Rhodesia's Black Factions: Tribal Enmities and Distrust
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 17One of the persistent problems dogging any solution to the Rhodesian crisis has been the factionalism that has led black nationalist leaders both inside and outside the country to attack, discredit and even kill one another.

title: School Milk Bidding Under investigation In New York City
description: The State Attorney General's office has begun an investigation into the possible rigging of bids for milk purchased by the New York City school system. These purchases amount to about $9 million a year.

title: 4 Jailed Newsmen Are Free on Coast
description: FRESNO, Calif., Sept. 17Four newsmen with The Fresno Bee were freed tonight after being jailed for two weeks in contempt of court for refusing to identify a source for a series of articles published in the paper in 1975.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor. As a citizen I am disturbed by the spread of the costofliving adjustment (COLA) into labor unions and now into the salaries of judges, top officials of the executive branch and probably Congressmen.

title: Steven Ford Campaign Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) President Ford's son Steven will campaign by motorhome van for his father in 11 Western states between now and Election Day, a family spokeswoman announced today.

title: Unearned Run Key to 43 Cubs Triumph
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP)Jerry Morales's basesloaded single with two out in the 12th inning sent Champ Summers home with an unearned run today and gave the Chicago Cubs a 43 triumph over the slumping Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: DORIC (Home). Left Bermuda Sent. 16; arrives 8 A. M. at W. 55th St.

title: Carnegie Home Parts With Desk
description: Andrew Carnegie's old rolltop desk,last vestige of the steel magnate'S, presence in his mansion at Fifth Avenue and 91st Street, was removed yesterday in preparation for the building's Oct. 7 reopening as Cooper Hewitt, the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Design. Built of Scottish oak to Mr. Carnegie's specifications, the desk remained in the philanthropist's sealedoff study even after the building became Columbia.. University's School of. Social Work in the late 1940's. Until Yesterday, if had not been moved from Mr. Carnegie's study.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a Washington dispatch in The Times on Thursday, John Lofton was incorrectly described as an interloper at a news conference of the Democratic National Committee. Mr. Lofton is a columnist for United Features Syndicate, gives radio commentary for the National Broadcasting Company and edits Battle Line, a publication of the American Conservative Union. He has White House and Congressional credenttals.

title: Transkei Accord Signed
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 17 (AP) Prime Minister John Vorster and the Transkei Paramount Chief, Kaiser Matanzima, signed a series of agreements here today as a prelude to the independence Oct. 26 of the Transkei homeland, or tribal reserve. The agreements cover cooperation on economic and industrial development, movement across borders, antipollution measures, civil aviation and taxation. They also include a nonaggression Pact.

title: A New Consensus
description: The Vietnam war and Watergate undermined the consensus that guided Americans role in the world for more than two decades after World War II, bringing into doubt both the nation's foreign policy and its confidence in the President who must conduct it. Foreign policy and defense became critical issues in the 1972 Presidential campaign.

title: EGYPT RENOMINATES SADAT FOR 6 YEARS IN PRESIDENCY
description: CAIRO, Sept. 17President Anwar elSadat, running unopposed, received nearly unanimous support for a second sixyear term in a referendum yesterday, the Government announced today.

title: Part Plane and Part Boxcar, New Space Shuttle Unveiled
description: PALMDALE. Calif., Sept. 17Under a harsh desert sun, and while a brass band played The Scene From Star Trek, the first manned spacecraft developed by the United States since the Apollo moon landings made its public debut today.

title: Consumer Notes
description: The New Jersey division of the American Cancer Society will reduce the number of Xrays in tests for breast cancer at the United Hospitals Annex in Newark from four to two, according to Dr. Benjamin F. Rush jr., the director of the project at the center.

title: KISSINGER'S MEETING WITH VORSTER OPENS ON A HOPEFUL NOTE
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 17Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and Prime Minister John Vorster opened talks tonight amid signs that progress had been made toward overcoming at least one of the key obstacles to a settlement in southern Africa.

title: NATURAL GAS MOVES OF F.E.A. ATTACKED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI)While the Federal Energy Administration was warning Americans of severe shortages of natural gas last winter, it had word from some experts the shortages would be small and manageable, Representative John D. Dingell contended today.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 A New York inventor and author has created an advertising sign that revolves on a new source of power warm radiation from the people below who watch it.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Qatar has completed its takeover of 100 percent of the Qatar Petroleum Company, the official Qatar Radio has reported. Terms of the takeover were not disclosed.

title: Deaths
Shopper In Jersey Is Shot
description: NORTH PLAINFIELD, N. J., Sept. 17 (UPI)  Muriel Lisk, 22 years old, of Scotch Plain, was shot in the leg late yesterday, apparently by a sniper's bullet that crashed through the window of a store on Route 22 while she was shopping, the police said.

title: Utah Democrats Meeting Today on Whether to Endorse WriteIn Candidate Against Representative Howe
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 17Utah bemocrats were poised today to repudiate their embattled Second District Congressman, Representative Allan T. Howe, by endorsing a writein candidate against him in the November election.

title: Machinists Strike T.W.A. As Talks on Contract Fail; Airline Begins Shutdown
description: WASHINGTON, Saturday, Sept. 18 (AP) The International Association of Machinists struck Trans World Airlines at 12:01 this morning as negotiations on a new contract broke off. A union representative said she knew of no plans for the talks to resume.

title: Quiet Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17The protection of the environment is the quiet issue in this Presidential campaign, not stressed as yet by either Presidential candidate. But it is politically significant that the leadership of the environmental movement overwhelmingly supports Democrat Jimmy Carter.

title: GEORGE GARDNER DIES, ART PATRON IN BOSTON
description: George Peabody Gardner, a firiancier, philanthropist and member of one of Boston's oldest and most noted families, died yesterday in Dresden Mills, Me. He was 88 years old and lived in Brookline, Mass.

title: Panel Says Reviews Cut Some HealthCare Costs To Companies and Unions
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17Companies and labor unions, including several in New York City, have slowed down spiraling healthcare costs by exercising some control over decisions traditionally made unilaterally by doctors and dentists, the Government reported today.

title: Cash Prices
description: Friday, Sept. 17, 1976

title: Forego Must Cope With Weighty Task
description: Any time Forego runs in a handicap race, the 6yearold gelding's toughest opponent is the extra weight piled onto his back.

title: Conrad Associates Puzzled By Failure to File Tax Data
description: Anthony L. Conrad, who was dismissed Thursday as chairman of the RCA Corporation, was reported yesterday to have left for his home on Gibson Island on the Maryland shore, following a conference with attorneys on Thursday in Manhattan.

title: Major Banks Resist Reduction in Prime Lending Rate
description: Major banks, resisting the general downtrend in interest rates, held the line yesterday and announced no reductions in their prime lending rate for business loans.

title: China's Economy Is Still Growing, but It Shows Signs of Slowing Down
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 17With the death of Chairman Mao Tsetu??g, China's new leaders inherit an economy that has achieved a remarkable record of growth over the past decade, but one that has shown signs of slowdown this year under the impact of labor unrest and factional quarrels.

title: Moynihan, Seeking G.O.P. Votes, Pictures Buckley as Man Outside
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 17  Daniel P. Moynihan declared here today that Senator James L. Buckley was a man outside the political consensus in New York and invited Republicans to support the Democratic ticket.

title: Mary Lou Williams Changes Bassists To Suit Her Piano
description: Mary Lou Williams, who seems utterly unflappable at the piano, can work herself up into quite a flap about bassists when she gets away from the keyboard. For several years, she has been trying to train young bassists to accompany her to her satisfaction. The problem, she was saying the other night at the Cookery, where she is now playing, is that they do not listen to what is being played. And there is a further problem if they have been involved in rock.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The former operator of a Long Island nursing home indicted for Medicaid fraud was allowed to plead guilty to a reduced charge after she agreed to repay $80,000 to the state. The nursing home operator, Dolores Esposito, 48 years old, of the Crandon Boulevard, Key Biscayne, Fla.. pleaded guilty to one count of thirddegree grand larceny, which carries a maximum prison term of four years. Suffolk County Court Judge J. J. Jones released her in her own custody and ordered her to return to court for sentencing on Nov. 5. The indictment alleged that Mrs. Esposito fraudulently billed Medicaid for inflated operational expenses of the Sayville Nursing Home at 101 Elm Street. She sold the 100bed nursing home in November 1974 and later moved Florida.

title: Around the Nation
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Sept. 17(AP)The Governor of Alaska is sending art emergency force of judges, prosecutors and public defenders into this transAlaska pipeline town to crack down on prostitution ry. mugging and robbe.

title: 3 MAJOR OIL COMPANIES REDUCE GASOLINE PRICES
description: Three major oil companies reduced their gasoline prices yesterday in various parts of the country. One, however, raised its prices in four western states.

title: Since 1932
description: Fortyfour years ago, the world and the nation were to me a large, unpromising blur. Twentysome jobs, several children, and innumerable arguments later, the world and nation are even less promising than in 1932, though for different reasons.

title: Reagan to Appear On TV Tomorrow To Assist G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI)Ronald Reagan will make a 30minute television appearance Sunday night for the Republian Party, including its national committee's fundraising efforts, Mary Louise Smith, the party's national chairman, announced today.

title: Met Opera's Financial Outlook Is Brightening
description: The Metropolitan Opera, which only one year ago seemed to be fighting for its very life, is now making plans for the future with guarded confidence.

title: Israeli Reports Talks With Syrian Officers On Uniting Families
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 17 (AP)Highranking officers of the Syrian and Israeli armies have been meeting to discuss the reuniting of Arab families divided since 1967 by the Golan Heights truce line, Defense Minister Shimon Peres disclosed last night.

title: Women Stablehands Bring Change to Belmont's Barns
description: An hour earlier, fumbling for the alarm clock in her suburban home at 4 A.M., she had thought to herself, Corinne, you have to be crazy.

title: U.S. Climber Dies on Peak Whose Name She Bore
description: NEW DELHI. Sept. 17 (AP)  An American woman has died of acute high altitude sickness on the Himalayan peak she was named for by her father, a conqueror of Mount Everest, the Indian Mountaineering Foundation reported today.

description: BILOXI, Miss., Sept. 17Jimmy Carter, an avowed champion of civil rights, went looking for Southern support here today, arm in arm with two of the country's most prominent segregationists, Senators James O. Eastland and John C. Stennis.

title: AIDE OF NBC CHARGES FAHNESTOCK BROKER APPLIED PRESSURE
description: A National Broadcasting Company executive embroiled in a commodities trading dispute testified yesterday that M. Donald Grant, a prominent Wall Street broker and chairman of the New York Mets, had tried to head off his complaints by putting pressure on his employer.

description: If the New York Mets expected to continue the role of spgiler in the taut Eastern Division race of the Na,tonal League, they reckoned without two former Yankees, Doc Medich and Bill Robinson, a former Met, Duffy Dyer, and Frank Taveras.

description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 17Few contemporary economic debates have as much capacity to generate heat as the socalled capitalshortage issue, no doubt largely, as some economists have pointed out because the argument is essentially about the distribution of wealth.

description: MASON, Ohio, Sept. 17 (AP)Mike Hill his injured leg aching like a toothache used some outstanding putputting today in a light rain as he posted a sixunderpar 64 and took the secondround lead in the $150,000 OhioKings Island open golf tournament.

description: LAKE CRYSTAL, Minn., Sept. 17George Meany, Proposition 14 and grain reserves seem to be the key scare words for Republicans worried that farmers will vote this fall for their fellow farmer, Jimmy Carter, the Democratic nominee.

description: WASHINGTON Sept. 17The Mobil Oil Corporation contended today that charges it created an intricate secret mechanism to supply petroleum products to the boycotted Rhodesian Government probably represented a skillfully contrived publicity scheme for political ends.

description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 17In the wake of the historic and traumatic step of approving the ordination of women as priests and bishops, talk at the Episcopal convention here has focused on reconciliation.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI)President Ford has told Federal officials to move as fast as possible in recommending ways to develop, produce and transport the oil at Naval Petroleum Reserve No. 4 in Alaska, the White House said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: It is safe to say that most Americans know next to nothing about the Arab world, although its growing importance to the United States economy as a producer of oil and as a purchaser of arms would suggest that we should take a cram course, and speedily. Just such a course, but on a sophisticated level, has been put together by Bernard Lewis of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, N.J. With the help of some 13 ranking Islamicists and Arabists in the West., Professor Lewis has produced a splendid survey that is agreeably enriched by almost 500 photographs, reproductions, drawings and maps, 160 of them in color.

Schanwald, a regional engineer in the State Transportation Department was indicted on charges of soliciting up to $140,000 in bribes from the engineering concern of Porter and Ripa. Mr. Schonwald, 52 years old, of Trenton, has been on a 60day leave of absence for personal reasons.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 17The Law of the Sea Conference closed sevenweek session today, deadlocked by a dispute over exploitation of the mineral wealth of the deep seabed.

title: Israelis Kill an Arab Demonstrator, Wound Another
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 17Israeli border policemen, pelted by stones and bottles hurled by Arabs demonstrating near the Jewish quarter of the walled Old City, opened fire today, killing a 24yearold West Bank Arab and wounding an Arab teenager.

title: Rumor on Kissinger Denied
description: A false rumor that Secretary of State Henry A Kissinger had been assassinated spread through Wall Street and international financial circles yesterday. The rumor was quickly denied by the White House and the State Department.

title: Company Preparing for Casinos In Atlantic City Defends Record
description: Resorts International, the conglomerate that operates casinos on Paradise Island, the Bahamas, and has bought Atlantic City's largest hotel in anticipation of passage of a November referendum permitting gambling in that resort city, said yesterday that, contrary to what its opponents had suggested, it was free of the taint of organized crime.

description: HACKENSACK, Sept. 17  Judge Thomas F. Dalton, noting Joseph Kallinger's continued absence from his own Murder trial, told prospective jurors in Superior Court today that the absence was voluntary.

title: Chekhov Sweeps London With Three Plays Going

description: Mgr. Thomas F. Curry, pastor emeritus of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Oradell, N. J., died Friday at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck of a stroke. He was 80 years old.

title: A Sampling of Short Tours From New York
description: Three companies operate snort tours from New York to a variety of destinations. Tours to the same place are essentially similar, regardless of who operates them. The main variables in pricing are the number of nights away and the meals (including tips) in the package.

title: Economics Of Racism in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURGA cartoon in one of the newspapers here last week showed Prime Minister John Vorster, apron tied to Ifis ample waist and broom in hand, greeting Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger at the door of Mr. Vorster's official residence.

title: Food
description: We have a special liking for foods that adapt themselves to a multitude of flavors and seasonings, and pork chops most assuredly fall into that category. They have a chameleonlike capacity for changing flavor in skillet or casserote to agree with other foods tomatoes and peppers, or a good brand of mustard combined with those green peppercorns that have become so popular within the past few years, or apples flamed with Calvados. These three combinations are the essence of the recipes outlined here. The pork and apple dish is from Normandy; the pork, tomato and pepper dish, adapted from Mexico, and the chops with mustard, a basically French concept.

title: He Sells to Men Who Have It Made
description: The Old Man and the Sea? Hemingway missed this version, by Don Aronow. Aronow's old man is steering his powerboat across the Mediterranean at 64 miles per hour while surrounded by pretty young girls.

title: A Law on Toxics Seems a Certainty
description: WASHINGTONThere is a consensus here that after five years of maneuver and compromise the first controls on the manufacture and use of toxic substances will finally be imposed. Last week, a bill emerged from a joint HouseSenate conference committee after having died in similar committees twice before.

title: Parole Board Chief Fights the System
description: TRENTON AFTER serving for a year as chairman of the State Parole Board, Christopher Dietz finds himself frustrated by a system of criminal justice that, he maintains, often sees the police, the courts, the correctional institutions and the Parole Board itself working at crosspurposes.

title: Article 1  No Title
Norcross and Williams Share Same Platform for First Time in Senate Campaign in Jersey
description: EAST ??RUNSWIC?? N. ?? Sept. 3 (AP) Senatcr Harrison A. William, J. and his Republican opponent, David N. Norcross, made their first joint campaign appearance here today.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The great numismatic decision of 1976  long awaited, much debated and inevitably destined not to please every collector  has finally been made. The U.S. Mint (via the Treasury Department) has announced that the special Bicentennial reverse designs on the Washington quarter, Kennedy half dollar and Eisenhower dollar will be discontinued after this year and the old reverse designs  the eagles  will be restored.

title: I.R.S. BARS REOPENING OF HOOVER ESTATE AUDIT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18The Internal Revenue Service has decided against reopening its audit of the estate of the late J. Edgar Hoover despite sworn testimony before a Congressional subcommittee that Mr. Hoover's valuable private papers were destroyed following his death in May 1972.

title: The Basques of Bridgeport
description: In the harsh, agglutinized language Basques call Eskualdene, as mysterious in origin as the Eskualdunaks themselves, there is a poem that goes, On, the jai alai court, the Basque from his youth shows that he has red blood in his veins. For years, young Basques have exhibited skill and courageand actual bloodon jai alai courts in Europe, Asia, Latin America and Floridaespecially Florida, where there are nine frontons, as jai alai courts are called.

title: Give'em hell, Jerry!
description: Dear Mr. President: Although I realize that time is growing short, I believe you should use a little of what's left to assess the strategy you intend to follow in your campaign against Mr. Carter. To fail to do so when your opponent enjoys a sizable lead could be fatal, for only a frontrunner can afford the luxury of focusing merely on tactics.

title: Rutgers Faculty To Offer Concerts
description: NEW BRUNSWICK TEN faculty members from Rutgers University will present original compositions in a series of five concerts to he held at Carnegie Recital Hall in New York this fall. The first concert is scheduled for Oct. 5.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Meadowlands Lease

title: Excerpts From Hua Talk At Mao Funeral
description: Over the last few days, the whole party, the whole army and the people of all nationalities throughout the country have been immersed in boundless sorrow at the passing of Chairman Mao Tsetung. The cause that our great leader Chairman Mao devoted his whole life to is linked by fleshandblood ties with the masses of the people.

title: Terrence A. Tobias Weds Cynthia du Pont Oct. 16 in Wilmington
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irne du Pont Jr. of Wilmington, Del., have announced the ertgagement of their daughter, Cyrthia du Pont, to Terrence Arthur Tobias of Cambridge, Mass., son of Mrs. Arthur Tobias of Morton Grove, Ill., and the late Mr. Tobias.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error in a story in the Review of Sept. 12, the age of the universe was incorrectly stated. It is thought to be between 13 and 19 billion years old.

title: Reading Between the JobAd Lines
description: I HAD this great idea for a writing project last year: Document my return to work with an article entitled Can a MiddleAged Suburban New Jersey Housewife Find Happiness Returning to the Business World? Unfortunately, my project never got off the ground because I never got beyond the jobhunting stage.

title: Hoey's Jury Calls for Action
description: ALMOST a year after it was empaneled to investigate charges of sodomy and sexual misconduct that had been filed against the Suffolk District Attorney by the county's Police Commissioner, a special state grand jury last week handed up 10 reports recommending that disciplinary action he taken against some Suffolk public officials.

title: New System Will Free Policemen From Appearing at Arraignments
description: A new arraignment plan that could free thousands of New York City police officers from waiting around idly on overtime in criminal courtrooms is expected to begin next month, high law enforcement officials disclosed yesterday.

title: U.S. Climber Is Buried On Himalayan Peak
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 18 (AP)Nanda Devi Unsoeld has been buried on the Himalayan peak for which she was named.

title: Conrail Deals Out Poker Players
description: THERE are regular commuters on Conrail's venerable Jersey Shore line who will tell you that just getting aboard for a ride is a form of gambling. Regularly, they write to newspapers to complain of nonexistent airconditioning (or its failure), of broken seats and windows, of indescribable lavatories and of long, unexplained delays.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Medical malpractice suits were on an uninterrupted climb in the country when Dr. Leonard Berlin, a 41yearold radiologist in Skokie, Ill., put a dent in the trend last June 1.

title: Future Events
description: Sept. 23That Min?? thing you can't bear to look at may be a museum piece, or just another china chow to hide under dust. But for this third annual Heirloom Discovery Day, a Jot of antiques will be blown clean for appraisal by experts from Sotheby Parke Bernet, John F. Fleming Inc., J. S. Shrubsole and Knoedler Gallery in the Larchmont Yacht Club's red and while waterfront tent between its Victorian building (circa 1880) and the Pandemonium Room, the covered dance floor put up at the turn of the century and open on three sides, but with curtains to keep out the rain. Here antique dealers will show and sell at 13 booths from 10:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. A buffet luncheon for browsers will be served on the club's quarterdeck above Long Island Sound, with Garry Moore of Rye, N. Y., the television host, doing the honors for the Westchester Council on Alcoholism Inc. in White Plains. The day's admission includes one appraisal and lunch. Additional appraisals are $4 an item. Tickets: $15 at the door.

title: Northrop's Flying Wing Of Yesterday
description: The Northrup Corporation is an airplane maker whose most famous product was scrapped 23 years ago, and whose best known product today is seldom seen in its native country.

title: Did the B stand for bashful?; B. Traven
description: An Introduction. By Michael L. Baumann. 184 pp. Albuquerque, N.M.: University of New Mexico Press. $9.50.

title: A prisoner's testimony
description: Of all the national minorities contained within the borders of the U.S.S.R. probably none have suffered in greater numbers from Soviet rule than the Ukrainians. In the recently published third volume of The Gulag Archipelago Alexander Solzhenitsyn complains that no books exist to commemorate their fate. A few such books have in fact been written but these are scarcely adequate to the enormity of the matter. Solzhenitsyn intends his chapter on the subject to serve as a marker, a little pile of stones indicating that place where one day I think a new Church of Christ the Savior will be erected.

title: Levittown Division Shut Out On Field but Not in ??
description: Levittown Division discovered yesterday that scoring points was almost as difficult as getting its school budget passed as it dropped an 80, nonleague opener to Uniondale in one of the more important games of a small opening day schedule on Lone Island.

title: SWEDISH SOCIALISM FACING TEST TODAY
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, Sept. 18Prime Minister Olof Palme, winding up tonight a sharply fought campaign, predicted a narrow triumph in tomorrow's general elections and said that Sweden's sweeping social changes were threatened if voters elected a powerful coalition of opposition parties.

title: The collapse of the great Teton Dam; At 11:57 A.M. on June 5, 80 billion gallons of water began surging forward in a torrent of destruction. Could it have been predicted?; Teton Dam
description: They finished building Teton Dam in southeastern Idaho during the winter of 1975. There it stood, a massive earthandrock structure, rising up 300 feet from the floor of the Teton River canyon and stretching 3,000 feet across. Above the dam, 80 billion gallons of reserve water flooded the canyon, backing up 17 miles.

title: ParklandThe Battle Goes On
description: MORE than $500 million in state, Federal and county funds has been spent in New Jersey in the last 15 years to acquire parkland for recreational purposes. But many officials in the state feel that too much emphasis has been placed on maintaining rural areas, rather than on helping the more populous urban and suburban regions.

title: A FEELING OF CRISIS IS RISING IN POLAND
description: WARSAW, Sept. 18Poland's Communist Party leaders have become acutely and painfully aware of what several high officials candidly call their credibility gap and are engaging in intense secret arguments over what, if anything, they can do about it.

title: Peking Throng Bids Mao Farewell
description: PEKING, Sept. 18At least 750,000 Chinese gathered in the center of their ancient capital this afternoon to mourn Chairman Mao Tsetung at a brief and austere rally that ended in a wave of sobbing.

title: Half of Town's Residents Ordained To Qualify for TaxExempt Status
description: HARDENBURGH, N.Y.  In the face of rising taxes, half the residents of this Catskill Mountain town have been ordained to qualify them as taxexempt clergymen.

title: PEOPLE
description: Last time we looked in on John Pacella it was the middle of winter, and the righthanded pitcher, who is the property of the Mets, was limbering up here and there not far from his home in Oakdale in preparation for spring training. Now, after what one Mets official described as a pretty good year with Lynchburg in the Carolina League (11 wins, 11 losses and an earnedrun average of 3.19 were the latest available statistics), John is scheduled for more during the autumn in the Florida Instructional League, a sign that the Mets regard him as one of their brighter prospects. One of his teammates at Lynchburg was the outfielder Stuart Greenstein, who played the college circuit for C. W. Post before the Mets signed him. He started the season at Marion in the Rookie League and showed enough to be moved up fast to the Carolina League.

title: The New York School, continued
description: David St. John's poetry functions as a congeries of beautiful effects. The reader sees the verse being built before himit is invention, skilled and careful, but little is disclosed. The world does not seem to be enough for these poems, and so they turn it a little this way and a little that, overlay it with a high gloss or embroidery. Often they will start out as recordings of clarities seen but then flake away. In The Empty Dance Hall the poem sets out:

title: Katharine Culbertson Is Wed
description: Katharine Kirby Culbertson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Harrison Culbertson of New Vernon, N. J., and Sea Island, Ga., was married yesterday afternoon in New Vernon to E. Miles Prentice 3d, son of Mr. Prentice Jr. o?? Montpelier, Vt, and the late Anna Kiernan Prentice. The Rev. George Chorba of the New Vernon Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony in the garden at the Culbertson home.

title: Miron Yampolsky, Cellist, in Debut
description: Miron Yampolsky, a Russian cellist who studied with Mstislav Rostropovich for 16 years, then emigrated to Israel in 1972 and to this country in 1974, where he is now assistant principal cellist of the Baltimore Symphony, made his New York recital debut at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night. With Jeffrey Chappell at the piano, he played a Frescobaldi Toccata, Beethoven's Sonata No. 2 in G minor, Schumann's Pieces in Folk Style, Rachmaninoff's Vocalise, Shostakovich's Sonata (Op. 40) and a Stravinsky arrangement of a ballet pas de deux.

title: Criminals At Large
description: There'll always be an England, at least as long as James Fraser continues to write his British mysteries featuring Superintendent Aveyard. In WHO STEALS MY NAME (Doubleday, $5.95) a peer of the realm walks into the clubroom of his home and finds two peopleone a police officer, the other his own son. The officer has been murdered. The son is zonked out on drugs and alcohol. Lord Mawsley does what any rightthinking peer should do. He rings for the butler.

title: Show to Aid Henry Street
description: Proceeds from a theater party to California Suite, the Neil Simon comedy, at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Oct. 7, will go to the Henry Street Settlement. Tickets at $70, $55 and $40 each are available from Mrs. Gillette Boland, 40 East 68th Street.

title: Marylou S. Millard And Arthur Ferrara Are Wed in Jersey
description: Marylou Slattery Millard and Arthur Joseph Ferrara were married yesterday in St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Glen Rom, N. J. by the Rev. Paul Clifford of Loyola University in Chicago.

title: Reshuffle in Britain ...
description: Although it has now been in power for more than 30 months, Britain's Labor Party remains an uneasy coalition of left and moderate wings whose rival claims must be kept in delicate balance by any Prime Minister. James Callaghan's Cabinet reshuffle on the occasion of the departure of Home Secretary Roy Jenkins was an example of that balancing act; but in spite of that it did bring promotions for some of Labor's abler moderates.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The City Center of Music and Drama, as we have known it, has passed away and no one seems to care. It is a sign of our timesof the change in attitude toward the arts as public servicethat so little attention has been paid to the transformation of the country's most vital performing arts center into a holder of real estate leases on two theaters.

title: House Tours
description: The following chronological listing, compiled by Ruth Rejnis, is a selection of notable house tours in the metropolitan area through the end of the year.

title: GARDENING
description: AUTUMN marks the end of outdoor gardening for the year, but the Island is fortunate in that it has a long growing season of more than 200 days. Being surrounded her water, with its modifying effect on otttdoor temperatures, we have a longer transition from one season to another than do many other parts of the country, and therefore more time to accomplish the many tasks that must be done before the advent of cold weather.

title: Jean Ann Dornhoefer Is Wed to Mark Gromer
description: Jean Ann Dornhoefer and Mark Francis Gromer, who graduated in 1974 from Middlebury College, were married yesterday afternoon in the Roman Catholic Chapel of SS. Faith, Hope and Charity. The Rev. Simeon Gardner performed the ceremony.

title: No Leads Found to Burglar Who Caused Death of a Woman, 82, in Peter Cooper Village
description: Detectives investigating the death of 82yearold Sarah Bernhard in her Peter Cooper Village apartment reported yesterday that they had no leads to the whereabouts of the burglar who they said had caused her to die.

title: John Lyman 2d Will Wed Peggy Anne Perrett Oct. 9
description: Peggy Anne Perrett and John T. Lyman 2d, manager of the announcing division of the American Broadcasting Companies, plan to be married Oct. 9.

title: Three Gunmen Fleece 15 Gambling Couples
description: Fifteen couples were having a merry time gambling at poker and dice in the basement of an apartment house in Inwood, L.I., Friday night until three masked gunmen barged in and broke up the games.

title: Headliners
description: Anthony L Conrad, president and chairman of the RCA Corporation, has resigned from both posts after admitting that he had not until recently filed personal income tax returns from 1971 to 1975. Mr. Conrad said that his tax problems were purely personal and were unrelated to company business. Mr. Conrad was named president last November in what was described as a revolt against Robert W. Sarnoff, the son of the company's founder, prompted by the company's declining profits. Under Mr. Conrad, profits had soared. However because of the sudden change in its executive leadership, RCA has had to withdraw a planned public offering of five million shares of common stock.

title: GARDENING
description: IN ADDITION to the popular tall irises with huge, bearded flowers that brighten New Jersey gardens from about the middle of May to midJune, there are several other littleknown and very different, but equally desirable, irises.

title: Panama's Charge of Role by U.S. In Riots Reflects Delay on Treaty
description: PANAMA, Sept. 18Panama's attempt to blame the United States for recent student riots over food prices was seen today as a reflection of the problems being caused here by delays in the conclusion of a treaty with Washington over use of the Panama Canal.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: `Simple, Stark Truth Behind Malpractice

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Windflowers and Squills

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayGlen Head Fall, Kings Dairy Farm, Jericho Turnpike, Huntington, L.L. Regular, green, maiden, nonthoroughbred. amateurowner and junior working hunters; intermediate, amateurowner and junior jumpers; adult horsemanship, ponies, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Bucknell Board Head Chosen
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., Sept. 18 (AP) Charles F. Baird, a former Under Secretary of the Navy, was elected chairman of the board of Bucknell University today. Mr. Baird, of Short Hills, N.J., is chairman of Inco Ltd., formerly the International Nickel Company of Canada. He served in the Administration of President Johnson.

title: Debates: What's the Question?
description: WASHINGTONThe first phase of the Presidential campaign since the nominating conventions has been needlessly negative and even destructive. For President Ford and Governor Carter have been scaring rather Than inspiring the voters, concentrating on each other's weaknesses, real or imagined, and creating the impression that the nation has a choice between an oldtimer who can't lead, and a newcomer who's not ready.

title: American Food In Saddle River
description: UPPER SADDLE RIVER WITH the growing sophistication of the American palate, it was inevitable that a rash of cookbooks would erupt in this Bicentennial year. One of the most interestingan eclectic collection of regional and historic recipes has been produced by a group of residents here in the hope of raising sufficient funds with which to finance a Bicentennial memorial.

title: Lewis W. van Amerongen
description: Clothing, for me, says Lewis W. van Amerongen. 36, a general partner in the private investmentbanking firm of Gibbons, Green & Rice, is more functional than decorative. Before joining G. G. & R., Amerongen worked as a securities analyst for several firms and as an auditor for Price Waterhouse & Company. Accordingly, his special interest now is the numerical aspect of my workpulling apart balance sheets and income statements. And, perhaps reflecting his position in New York's business world, he avoids trendy apparel and considers himself a conservative dresser.

title: Selected Poems
description: By Austin Clarke. Edited by Thomas Kinsella. 207 pp. WinstonSalem, N.C.: Wake Forest University Press. Cloth, $12.50. Paper, $6.95.

title: Passengers Shift in Strike at T.W.A.
description: Thousands of weekend travelers shifted to alternate airlines as Trans World Airlines was grounded yesterday by a strike of 12,000 mechanics and ground crew members, whose contract with the airline expired last Oct. 31.

title: The Myth of Busing: Some Contradictory Evidence
description: On August 2, 1971, Richard Nixon disavowed, with a bitter antibusing statement, a plan put forward by his own Department of Health, Education and Welfare for the desegregation of schools in Austin, Texas. The next day, in littlenoticed testimony. Dr. David H. Porter described to a Congressional committee how busing had been used to end segregation in the schools of Harrisburg. Pa., in 1970.

title: H. C. Blackiston 3d And Pamela Schall, Fashion Editor, Wed
description: Pamela Gordon Schall and Henry Curtis Blackiston 3d were married yesterday in Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Samuel Clevenger Walker, associate rector of the church. A reception was given at Round Hill Club.

title: 12 Blocks Along Atlantic Avenue To Be Closed for a Street Festival
description: A dozen blocks along Atlantic Avenue in downtown Brooklyn will be closed to traffic today for AtlanticAntic 2, a street festival that will include arts, crafts, foods, computer games and a bicycle race.

title: A Bug Becomes A Watchdog
description: A BUILDING alarm system so attuned that it can pick up the sound of a handball bouncing off an outside wall has helped Nassau County prosecutors trace fraudulent overtime claims by custodians in school districts, officials say.

title: What's Doing in HONG KONG
description: WHERE EAST MET WESTBorn of ?? encounter between a brash British Empire and a decaying Chinese dynasty, Hong Kong today continues to reflect its mixed parentage. In this Crown Colony of 4.4 million people, both Chinese and English are official languages, though English is the more equal. The British Governor is known to the Chinese populace as Mak LeeHo (his name is MacLehose), while local luminaries, such as Y. K. Kan, are Knights of the British Realm. Hong Kong has come a long way since the 1840's, when the Union Jack was planted on this thendesolate island frequented by pirates and opium traders. Hong Kong designers have won recognition in the world of haute couture, and the colony has become the world's largest exporter of clothing, having outstripped Italy two years ago. A million lights glitter at night along Victoria Harbor; new skyscraping hotels and office blocks crowd the Central District, which is the financial hub of the colony, and residents and visitors pack Hong Kong's many restaurants and nightclubs.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Tobacco wholesalers have reluctantly agreed on a new wage and benefit contract with the Teamsters Union, averting a threatened strike. Nat Berman, managing director of the Wholesale Tobacco Distributors of New York Inc., said the agreement might force a 4cent increase in the cost of cigarettes. Mr. Berman. said his 38 member association agreed to a $15 aweek increase in wages and benefits for 1,200 employees represented by Teamsters Local 802. Mr. Berman said the new contract would mean retailers would have to pay 25 cents additional for a carton of cigarettes, and that this would be passed along to consumers by increasing the cost of a cigarette pack by 4 cents.

title: Johnstone Paces 41 Defeat of Cubs
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 18Jay Johnstone decided today that the solutions to the Phillies problems were a lot less analysis and a lot more base hits. The result was a ?? victory over Chicago that raised Philadelphia's lead over Pittsburgh to four games.

title: Michigan Thwarts Stanford, 510, as Huckleby Stars
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 18 (UPI)Rick Leach, a sophomore quarterback, guided an explosive Michigan offense today to a 510 victory over Stanford. The Cardinals failed to make a first down for 26 minutes of the first half.

title: Who Was the Villain at Forest Hills?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Atlas of Early American History
description: This magnificently designed and produced volume is in every way extraordinary. Large in format (1318 inches) and printed on specially made paper, it contains 286 newlydrawn, datafilled maps, 271 of them reproduced in as many as six colors. Threaded among the maps are narrative captions that amount to a running commentary; 60 additional pages provide interpretive background content. The stunningly beautiful maps

title: The Region
description: In Summary

title: In guards we trust
description: It was early evening, but outside the street was already empty except for a uniformed private guard swinging his nightstick in the amber glare of the anticrime sodium lamps. I was sitting in the dining room of a large, beautifully furnished home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan where I had just asked a womanwhom I'll call Mrs. Smithwhy she and ter neighbors had hired a private guard to patrol a public street. I was trying to find out why private security services have become a $12 billion industry in America, growing at what a Rand Corporation survey calls a recessionresistant average rate of 10 to 15 percent annually. But instead of explaining the fears that had prompted her to pay for private pro tection, Mrs. Smith was demonstrating them. She refused to let me use her name or to divulge any detailsabout her neighborhood, her house or her patrol serviceso that muggers and burglars would not be able to strike when her block was unguarded. I'm sure that muggers don't read The New York limes Magazine, Mrs. Smith told me. But I'm not that sure. You probably think I'm paranoid, she said.

title: Questions and a Yawn
description: President Ford last week officially launched his campaign for election with an address that limped haltingly to its anticlimax.

title: The World
description: In Summary

title: Belmont Jockeys
The First 30 Odd Years
description: Michael Braude has had an interesting life, a recapitulation in one man of the Jewish immigrant experience, the striving for intellectual excellence, the struggle to make good in business. He was born in Czarist Lithuania, the son of an Orthodox rabbi; caught in World War I; an immigrant to the United States in 1920; a graduate of the University of

title: Tremors Continuing in North Italy
description: ROME, Sept. 18 (UPI)The ground kept shaking today in Friuli and mild tremors rocked the town of Genzano in the Alban Hills.

title: Beirut's Residential Districts Shelled Heavily Amid Spread of Fighting
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept.18Residential areas of Beirut were heavily shelled today and rival factions reported an intensifification of fighting on all fronts in the country.

title: Robin Williams Wed To John Piermattei
description: Robin Magan Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Gotwalt Williams Jr. of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon in Purchase, N.Y., to John Preston Piermattei, son of Barbara Piermattei of Rye and Fred Piermattei of Framingham, Mass.

title: New Mexico and Arizona Suing Land Concerns Over Sales of Lots
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M.About 45 miles south of here sits perhaps the most sprawling subdivision in the sunbelt, the cornerstone of Horizon Corporation, a $40 million, Tucsonbased land sales company that is currently in trouble with two state governments and the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Dance: The Mobius Company
description: The sense of puzzlement aroused by Mobius, a company of skilled dancers and limited creativity was epitomized in a dance called Really, Really (Truly) Really on Friday evening at 579 Broadway. It was technically demanding, mysteriously selfinvolved and ultimately vacuous.

title: Bottles Sold by U.S. To Require Deposit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP)Following the lead of Oregon and Vermont, the Federal Government has decided to require a five cent deposit on all bottles and cans of soft drinks or beer sold on Federal property.

title: A MAN, 82, IS BOUND AND FATALLY BEATEN
description: An 82yearold Brooklyn real estate broker was fatally beaten and slashed yesterday afternoon in his office on Fulton Street in the BedfordStuyvesant section.

title: 21 Wild Horses in Nevada, Facing Death, Win Reprieve Through Adoption Program
description: BATTLE MOUNTAIN, Nev., Sept. 18The 21 aging wild horses that had been scheduled to be killed earlier this week because homes could not be found for them have won a quick reprieve and will be placed through the United States Bureau of Land Management's AdoptaHorse program.

title: Filling Empty Stores
description: Store closings by the bankrupt W.T. Grant Company, by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, and. by regional discounters have prompted S.S. Kresge Company to double its store opening pace this year.

title: Paperbacks
description: New and Noteworthy

title: Study Finds Injury Risk in Medical Research Similar to Normal Living
description: A first broadscale attempt to determine how many persons may be harmed by their participation in federally funded medical research has indicated that the risk of injury is similar to that faced in ordinary living.

title: A Trilogy That Probes Society's Soul
description: As the new Broadway season gets underway, the most anticipated event, according to this section's recent theatrical preview, isn't a razzledazzle musical or an allstar comedy but rather A Texas Trilogy, three fulllength interrelated dramas by Preston Jones, a Dallas actorturnedplaywright. This week, The Last Meeting of the Knights of the White Magnolia, Lu Ann Hampton Laverty Oberlander and The Oldest Living Graduate, open at the Broadhurst Theater on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday evenings, in the order named, and will be presented on a continuous repertory basis.

title: The Key Issues In Swedish Vote
description: The opposition says that it is time for a change after 44 years of Social Democratic dominance. The opposition Moderates maintain that it is democratically unhealthy for one party to govern for so long. The Social Democrats argue that the opposition would dismantle the health, education and social welfare system built up over the last four decades.

title: Funny Business in Prime Time
description: When it comes to depicting the world of business, network television has always been as snobbish as any nobleman of the ancient regime.

title: Putting Hospitality to the Test: The Visitors From Germany
description: It's early August and we're waiting on the sidewalk outside a shabby bus depot The afternoon sunlight is blinding but we catch sight of the vistadome roof of a Bonanza Scenic Cruiser when it is still three blocks away. When the bus pulls in, a tall youiig man with his equally tall wife are maneuvering two bulky suitcases down the steps. He is wearing tan, pointy European shoes with tiny holes for ventilation; she has Swedish orthopedic sandals. We recognize them by their feet even before we see their faces. The only people expecting anyone on this brutally hot day, we step forward to claim them. Howdy, folks, welcome to Danbury U.S.A.

title: Must everything be destroyed?; The author of Cry, the Beloved Country asks whether there is any hope for South Africa.; South Africa
description: DURBAN, South AfricaI write not to express my detestation of the policies of apartheid, not because my Government has cruelly and ruthlessly treated its more articulate opponents, including many of my friends, but because I fear for the future of Afrikanerdom. I fear it is going to be destroyed and I fear that the process of destruction has actually begun. If so, it began on June 16, 1976. The riots in Soweto, Cape Town and other citiesthis burning down of shops and clinics and schools and universitiesare they going to stop, or is this a chain reaction that cannot stop until everything is destroyed?

title: New Passenger Trains to Start New York CityAlbany Service
description: New FrancoAmerican turbinepowered passenger trains will begin regular service tomorrow between Grand Central terminal and the Rensselaer station serving Albany, and one of them will be on public display in New York City this afternoon.

title: Major League Scores
Irish memories, Irish poetry
description: By Edna O'Brien. Photographs by Fergus Bourke. 144 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $12.95.

title: Egyptians Sentence 3 Hijackers to Life
description: CAIRO, Sept. 18 (Reuters) Three men who hijacked an Egyptian airliner flying foreign tourists from Cairo to Luxor last month were sentenced by a military tribunal today to hard labor for life, but they were acquitted on charges of collusion with Libya.

title: Woman Wins $200,000 in Lottery
description: HARTFORD, Sept, 18 (AP)  Sophie Pierog, who marked her 41st anniversary Tuesday, won $200,000 in the Connecticut state lottery. Mrs. Pierog, a 62yearold housewife from Enfield, said she would like to use the money to help her family, which includes a son, a daughter and two grandchildren.

title: Lester E. Mitchell
description: Lester E. Mitchell Jr., 32, is a field underwriter for New York Life Insurance Company, which means he sells all kinds of insurance. His field takes him across both town and country. I could be in Chicago one day talking to a vice president about group coverage for his company, and be in the Bronx the next day planning a family health policy.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market, buoyed by the prospects lower interest rates, made a moderate advance last week in heavier trading. The widely watched Dow Jones industrial average closed Friday at 995.10, up 7.15 points for the week.

Ltd., died Thursday of a heart attack at his home in Bayside, Queens, He was 63 years old, He was horn in Sag Harbor, L.I, and held a degree in business administration from New York University. He is survived by a sister, Elsie Obergfoll.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18The three commercial television networks and the League of Women Voters were at a temporary impasse, at least, today over the terms for televising next week's debate between two Presidential candidates.

description: THE Heritage of Freedom exhibition at the Montclair Art Museum addresses itself to one of the most important and most neglected aspects of American art: The role that the artistimmigrant has played in introducing visual attitudes in this country and in the development of esthetics.

But 25 years (Igo you were in the hospital, and you needed a blood transfusion, and I gave you my blood. I never asked you for anything in return. But now, I really need two World Series tickets.

description: Members of the Unification Church of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the South Korean evangelist, make their presence felt only sporadically in the streets of New York, but the church's real estate holdings are growing steadily, here and throughout the country.

description: IADORE food. My taste buds are really well developed, and my salivary glands react promptly to the sight and smells of wholesome dishes. Thus, having experienced the vagaries of spring and enjoying the glorious summer, I revel in the opportunity of buying fresh New Jersey produce.

title: Waiting for the Upturn
description: THE CALENDAR indicates that there are still more than three months remaining in this rather erratic 1976, but the business world traditionally views the passage of Labor Day as the turning point into its new year and anticipates a faster tempo of economic activity.

description: Kimberley Stratemeyer Adams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Stratemeyer Adams of Rossiya Farms, Pa., formerly of Pottersville, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Mark Raymond Depman in St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Gladstone, N.J. title: Official at Green Haven Prison Is Shifted After Inmate Strike
description: STORMVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 18 (AP)The state's Department of Correctional Services has transferred Green Haven State Prison's chief of security, but it denies the move is connected to a recent prisoner strike.

title: Soviet Dissident Finds His Home In a Shambles
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 187Veniamin Bogomolny, a Jew who is a dissident, looked around the shambles of his house. Bookcases had been overturned, the books scattered and crumpled in the yard. Windows were smashed, the glass ground into clothing on the floor. Desk drawers lay broken. Lamps had been ripped from the walls.

title: Will the Debates Really Matter?
description: WASHINGTONThere is a recurring tendency on the part of the press and the public to view a Presidential campaign as a cross between a beauty contest and a tennis match. It is like a beauty contest in that the candidates are judged on their physical endowments such as their smiles, their profiles and their hair; and like tennis match because they are judged on their acquired skills such as speechmaking and news conference technique.

title: Gunnar Lange, Former Minister Of Trade in Sweden, Dies at 67
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 18 (UPI)Gunnar Lange, who was Sweden's trade minister from 1955 to 1970, died Thursday after long illness. He was 67 years old.

description: OAKDALE. L.I.The mists of dawn had not yet lifted from the meadow beside the parking lot at. Connetquot State Park and the wraithlike forms of four deer could he seen only 100 yards away.

title: Injured Estep Bows
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 18 (AP)Brian Teacher of San Diego beat an injured Mike Estep of Waco, Tex., 57, 63, 61, 36, 63, in the semifinals of the $35,000 Hall of Fame tennis tournament today. Estep strained a muscle in his arm.

title: Wiley and The Hairy Man
description: Outwitted monsters have whined and bellered in Western folklore ever since Odysseus pulled the wool over the Cyclops eye. Two modem artists tell satisfying stories of vicious monsters duped by innocents whose only power lies in their courage, virtue and imagination. Though both artists tell

title: TV VIEW
description: Alternatives. As of this writing, just about all of the new programs scheduled for the fall season on television, which begins this evening, had not been made available for prescreening reviews. But glancing over the lineup and detecting the predictable glut of sitcorns and bionictype creatures, the reasonable observer is understandably preoccupied with the possibilities for alternatives. There must be, one hopes, different waysdifferent means, different ends. And there are indeed indications that other ways are available for the risking.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: I WAS not mugged in downtown Newark. I was mugged on Valley Road in Upper Montclair. .Upper Montclair, not downtown Montclair. Theoretically, there is a difference.

title: CHESS
description: FOR Michael Rohde, the Manhatan Chess Club international tournament proved to be a marvelous opportunity. By scoring 9 points in 15 rounds, the 16yearold New Jersey player not only tied for fifth place, but also achieved his first international master norm.

description: Ken Mandeville, Matawan's 200 pound tailback, scored his third touchdown with 2 minutes 36 seconds to play. yesterday and gave his team a 3631 openingday victory over Piscataway in Piscataway.

description: Gregor Piatigorsky the cellist, left an estate of about $2.8 million.
