title: A Debater's Art Is All Wit and Witticism
description: The Republican and Democratic Presidential candidates will commence this week a series of facetoface encounters that have been described as debates. To the extent that the candidates adhere to the traditional structure of a formal debate, they will be practicing a form of disputation that has been developed to a fineart in collegiate societies and legislative chambers.

title: A New Look At Bulbs for Spring
description: This may be the year to break away from the old familiar varieties of tulips, hyacinths and daffodils. Try a little variation on the theme. Explore a little, and create new combinations. It can be a lifetime hobby if you enjoy it as much as I do.

title: Royals Top White Sox, Stay 5 Games Ahead
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 18 (AP)Jim Wohlford's ninthinning single, his third hit of the game, scored Fred Patek from second base and gave the Kansas City Royals a 65 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The death of Chairman Mao, with all of the uncertainties it implies, makes two questions more compelling than ever:

title: Fighting Words
description: The contest for the United States Senate seat in New York State promises to offer a choice in political philosophy and campaign style, with the relatively liberal and absolutely flamboyant Daniel P. Moynihan, who won the Democratic primary by a single percentage point, trying to unseat the classic conservative and selfeffacing James L. Buckley.

title: Regents Chancellor Says Suburban Education Falls Prey to Outside Forces
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 18Theodore M. Black. the Chancellor of the Board of Regents of the State of New York, told a group of educators today that suburban education was at the mercy of unpredictable and uncontrollable outside forces and external decisions.

title: Malaysian Government Censors Magazine's Pictures of Mao
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Sept. 18 (AP)The Malaysian Government delayed this week's issue of the Hong Kongbased Far Eastern Economic Review to censor material connected with Mao Tsetung's death, according to distributors.

title: 32 Reported Killed by Bombings In First Seven Months of '76
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UPI)  The Federal Bureau of Investigation says there were 945 bombing incidents that claimed 32 lives and injured 145 others in the United States and Puerto Rico in the first seven months of 1976.

title: TV: An Odd, Late Season That Is Full of Gaps
Going Up Is a Musical Charmer
Aides Narrow Risk in Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19It will be presented to a national audience as a spontaneous encounter. But by the time President Ford and Jimmy Carter finally take their places behind specially constructed; waisthigh podiums Thursday night for the first of their three televised debates, their staffs will have done everything possible to banish the last vestige of surprise and risk from the confrontation.

title: Case &
description: Case & McGrath has won the Banquet Frozen Foods account that had been handled by the J. Walter Thompson Company. Billings are in the $3 million area.

title: Economists Sound Off on Boardwalk
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 19  Three themes seemed to emerge at this year's annual reunion of the economics profession in Atlantic City last week. Intellectually. there was more outspoken criticism than ever before of monetarist economic theory; professionally, there was great cheer about the current boom in economic tudiesin jobson university campuses; and personaly. universal griping about setting in this old seaside town, which proved that economists like shiny new hotels as much as anyone else.

title: Bus Drivers in Cairo, Out For 2d Day, Are Stopped By Police Fire at Depot
description: CAIRO, Sept. 19 (AP)Egyptian riot policement fired over the heads of striking bus drivers today to prevent them from attacking Cairo's main bus terminal, police sources said. No injuries were reported.

title: IRVING N. BRANT, 91, MADISON BIOGRAPHER
description: EUGENE, Ore., Sept. 19 (AP)Irving Newton Brant, author of six books and an authority on the Constitution, died last night of pneumonia. He was 91 years old.

title: In Interest of Clarification: The Uses of Egg Shells, Indian Ghee
Thai Leader Overthrown in 1973 Returns From Exile
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 19Field Marshal Thanom Kittikachorn, for 10 years head of an authoritarian military government in Thailand, returned from exile today, the second major figure from his regime to reenter the country in the last month.

title: Constance S. Rosenblum Is Married to Andrew Geller
description: Constance Sage Rosenblum and Andrew Geller, who received master's degrees from the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, were married yesterday afternoon. State Supreme Court Justice Sybil Cooper performed the ceremony in the couple's new apartment on Brooklyn Heights.

title: Boston Police Raid a Lottery
description: BOSTON, Sept. 19 (AP)Nineteen persons are scheduled to face court charges tomorrow for allegedly setting up an illegal lottery. A road by the police last night on a boat in the Boston harbor resulted in the confiscation of about $6,800 and ended an operation that the police said they believed had been ongoing for a couple months.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Katharine Kaufman Bride of Nicholas Weber
Carter on China
description: WASHINGTONWhen Jimmy Carter gave a somewhat confused answer to a question about United StatesChina relations this summer, an essayist seeking clarification was told by a Carter aide: We'll have to check this out with Professor Cohen.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Sept. 19The New Jersey A.F.L.C.I.O. will begin a threeday meeting in Atlantic City tomorrow to endorse political candidates in the Presidential and Congressional elections.

title: EXBISHOP ANTHIMOS DIES
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 19 (Reuters)A former Cypriot bishop who was defrocked for trying to oust Archbishop Makarios in 1973 died today while conducting an unauthorized mass in Limassol.

title: EAST GERMAN CHURCHMEN URGE RELIGIOUS FREEDOM
description: EAST BERLIN, Sept. 19A month after the death of a clergyman who set himself afire as a protest against oppression of the young by the Communist Government, Protestant churchman throughout East Germany read a sermon today that called for tolerance and religious freedom.

title: British Clerics Want To Organize a Union
description: MANCHESTER, England. Sept. 19 (AP)A group of English clergymen is trying to organize a nationwide whitecollar trade union for clerics.

But by the time President Ford and Jimmy Carter finally take their places behind specially constructed, waisthigh podiums Thursday night for the first of their three televised debates, their staffs will have done everything possible to banish the last vestige of surprise and risk from the confrontation.

title: American Missionary Is Freed After a Year in Mozambique Jail
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)  An American missionary has been released after a year of imprisonment in Mozambique, the State Department said yesterday.

title: Margaret Moench, Art Student, Married To Ira Seth Mellman, Doctoral Candidate
description: Margaret Detzer Moench, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Christopher Moench of Guilford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Ira Seth Mellman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin L. MelImam of Great Neck, L.I. The ceremony was performed at the Moench home by Justice of the Peace Marley A. Weinstock.

title: Raymond C. Firestone Retires As Chairman of Tire Company
description: The Firestone Tire & Rubber Company announced yesterday that its chairman, Raymond C. Firestone, was leaving that post after 10 years because he had passed the mandatory retirement age.

title: RABBI SHRAGOWITZ AT 81
description: Rabbi Moses J. Shragowitz of Congregation Kneses Tifereth Israel in Port Chester, N.Y., died yesterday in Glenville, Conn., while conducting a memorial service. He was 81 years old and had served the Port Chester congregation since 1937. He was made rabbi emeritus last Jan. 1.

title: Boonton Temple Buries Books And Shawls Damaged by Fire
description: BOONTON, SEPT. 19Temple Beth Shalom buried its firescarred prayer books and prayer shawls today in a simple graveside ceremony on the synagogue grounds.

title: Marching From Pretoria
description: BOSTON, Sept 19In South Africa last year, in a YMCA in Soweto, I saw a play written and directed by en African playwright, Gibson Kente. It was a musical called How Long? In the simplest terms of tragedy and faith it expressed the yearnings of South African blacks for such things as the chance for an education, the right to own a home, equality before the law.

title: Grogan Helps Lowly Patriots Upset Dolphins, 3014
description: Steve Grogan, New England's second year quarterback out of Kansas State, who replaced the traded Jim Plunkett enjoyed his finest pro game yesterday. He directed a 3014 upset victory over the Miami Dolphins at the Patriots Foxboro Stadium.

title: Crenshaw Wins by Stroke For 3d Triumph of Year
description: MASON, Ohio, Sept. 19 (AP)Ben Crenshaw joined Hubert Green today as a threetime winner on this year's pro golf tour by winning the $150,000 OhioKings Island open. He carded fourunderpar 66 for a 72hole total of 27] winning by a stroke.

title: WOMEN POLITICIANS FIND PROGRESS SLOW
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19Although the number of women who are running for public office is continuing to increase slowly this year, it is not clear whether the number who will get elected will grow very much.

title: TV Lighting Expert for Debates Hopes Work Will Not Be an Issue
Advertising
description: The summer doldrums have passed and the pace of the advertising business is starting to quicken even before the leaves begin to turn.

title: KISSINGER EXPECTS SMITH TO APPROVE BLACK POWER PLAN
Metropolitan Briefs
description: In an effort to sharpen the reporting and management of city finances, Mayor Beame and City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin yesterday announced the formation of the Financial Information Services Agency. It will be responsible for giving government agencies and the public access to material gathered by the city's financial information network under the Integrated Financial Management System.

title: Reborn CooperHewitt Museum Has New Home
description: When Cooper Union ousted the CooperHewitt Museum of Design from its premises in 1963, the future did not look rosy for the destitute institution, one of the world's greatest treasurehouses of the decorative arts.

title: TIGHTER CONTROLS IMPOSED BY SEOUL
description: TOKYO, Sept. 19The Communist threat from North Korea, seemingly underlined by the slayings last month of two American guards in the demilitarized zone, is being used as justification for a wide range of new Government controls in South Korea.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an error in editing, it was erroneously reported in The Times on Friday that Prince Saud of Saudi Arabia functioned outside his own country, as a foreign affairs representative for the Foreign Minister, King Khalid. In fact, King Khalid relinquished the post of Foreign Minister, which he had inherited from his father, the late King Falsal, on Oct. 13, 1975. On that day, Prince Saud was appointed Foreign Minister, a post he has filled since then.

title: The New Romanticism, With a Tailored Touch
description: Gloria Vanderbilt swept down the runway that bisected the grand ballroom of the Hotel Plaza in a dress that had a skirt as wide as anything Scarlett O'Hara ever woreand a waistline as small.

title: Changes in German Schools An Issue in Coming Election

description: TETERBORO, N.J., Sept. 10Several thousand spectators lined a runway at Teterboro Airport here today to see an air show and to witness the dedication of New Jersey's first aviation museum.

title: Cremation for Mao Is Still Not Certain
description: PEKING, Sept. 19 (Reuters)China has completed the public funeral rites for Mao Tsetung without disclosing what will happen to his body.

title: MORE SEEN QUITTING FUND OF TEAMSTERS
description: At least a halfdozen more trustees of the teamsters largest pension fund are expected to resign in coming weeks as the fund seeks to reach an accommodation with the Government that would blunt the threeway investigation now under way into its operation.

title: Gottfried and Ramirez Capture U.S. Pro Doubles Tournament
description: WOODLANDS, Tex., Sept. 19 (AP)The team of Brian Gottfried and Raul Ramirez recovered from a 25 deficit in the fourth set to beat Phil Dent and Alan Stone, 61, 64, 57, 76 today and win the $100,000 United States professional doubles tennis championship.

title: Music: Stern and Friends' Finale
description: The fiveconcert Isaac Stern and Friends chambermusic series came to a glorious conclusion yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. Not all of these concerts may have been received with total rapture, but this one deserved to be.

title: Flyers Beat Islanders On Goal by Kelly, 43
description: PHILADELPHIA. Sept. 19 (AP)Bob Kelly's close backhanded shot past the New York Islander goalie, Bill Hughes, at 12:15 of the third period snapped a tie and gave the Philadelphia Flyers a 43 victory tonight in a National Hockey League preseason game.

title: Open Market Meeting Is Expected To Produce Lower Interest Rates
I.T.T. IS ACQUIRING CARBON INDUSTRIES
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation plans to move into the energy field by acquiring Carbon Industries, a Charleston, W. Va., coal mining company for roughly $256 million in stock, I.T.T. announced over the weekend.

title: Louisiana City Gets Federal Aid For Defaulted Municipal Payroll
description: MONROE. La., Sept. 19 (AP)The 1,000 municipal employees in Monroe are scheduled to get paid tomorrow, thre,e days after the city said it did not have enough money to cover its payroll. On Friday. Monroe became the first American city to default on its payroll since Hamtramck, Mich., in 1970.

Promises and performance, nowever, match poorly.

title: Guidelines Cover Experiments on New York City Hospital Patients
description: A new set of guidelines controlling any research on human patients in the city's 16 municipal hospitals was made public yesterday, in part to counter a myth that patients there may be used as guinea pigs.

title: Japanese Newcomer Dances In Guest Series at Brooklyn
description: Yoko Moroshita, the Japanese ballerina who was featured prominently in American Ballet Theater's summer season, introduced her regular partner from Japan to American audiences this weekend at Brooklyn College's new Guest Artists Series in Dance. He is Tetsutaro Shimizu, a handsome young man with long hair and stylish vitality to his dancing. Miss Moroshita and Mr. Shimizu are the leading dancers of Tokyo's Matsuyama Ballet, directed by Mr. Shimizu's parents.

title: Parole Board Head to Retire
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)The chairman of the United States Parole Commission, Maurice H. Sigler, announced today. that he would retire on Sept. 30. Mr. Sigler, 67 years old, became chairman in July 1972.

title: SWEDISH SOCIALISTS LOSE TO COALITION AFTER 44YEAR RULE
description: STOCKHOLM, Monday, Sept. 20 Sweden's Social Democratic Party, architect of one of the most advanced welfare states in Europe, was narrowly defeated early today by a coalition of three nonSocialist parties.

title: FRANK FOX, 84, CHAIRMAN OF REALTY ASSOCIATES
description: Frank Fox, a Brooklyn realestate man who headed a concern that built many homes in Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island in the 1920's and 1930's, died Thursday at his home in North Salem in Westchester County at the age of 84.

title: Bush Sees Bonanza In Pilot's Defection With a Soviet MIG

description: Jacqueline Suzanne Stark, daughter of Mrs. Marshall Wolcott Stark of Rochester and the late Major Stark, U.S.A., was married yesterday afternoon to Marc Flores Plattner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving H. Plattner of Lido Beach, L.I.

title: Mintoff Appears Headed for a Slim Victory in Malta
description: VALETTA, Malta, Monday, Sept. 20Prime Minister Dom Mintoff and his Labor Party appeared this morning to be heading for a slim victory in Malta's general elections but the results remained inconclusive.

title: Reaction to District Plan
description: One of the axioms of political theory is that every bold new program idea is bound to have unexpected, unintendedand perhaps even unwantedconsequences, Specialists at City Hall are wondering these days whether this axiom will apply to a somewhat technically defined but nonetheless significant step that the city government is in the process of undertaking, a step that reaches a critical turning point today. That step has to do with the proposed slicing up of New York City's five boroughs into 52 uniform community districts designed to facilitate the decentralized delivery of most municipal services. The new lines are distinguished by the fact that they are coterminouseach affected city agency has the same local district lineswhich many experts feel will drastically change the way services are delivered from now on.

title: Carey Names Banking Aide
description: ALBANY, Sept. 19 (AP)Governor Carey has named a former assistant defense secretary, Anna Rosenberg Hoffman, to the State Banking Board. Mrs. Hoffman, who served President Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman, was assistant defense secretary from 1950 to 1953.

title: ROUTINE I.R.S. AUDIT REVEALED TAX CASE OF EXHEAD OF RCA
description: The failure of the ousted RCA Corporation chairman, Anthony L. Conrad, to file income tax returns for five years was discovered by the Internal Revenue Service in a routine audit of the corporation, according to company sources.

title: U.S. Recoups Medicaid Fraud Funds
description: The Federal Government has recovered 20 operators of Medicaid mills in New York City but the Beame administration is unhappy because the city and New York State will not share in the proceeds.

description: Congress, after laboring for three years over the tax reform bill, has finally passed it and sent the mammoth document of over a thousand pages to the President for his signature. The bill has its virtues and faults, but on balance it is acceptable legislation that the President should sign.

title: A Fleeing Suspect Was Killed
description: A Plainfield man was shot to death by police officers Saturday night after he held a woman hostage and threatened to kill her, authorities said. The man, identified as Douglas C. Johnson, 26, years old, was shot as he tried to flee from a thirdfloor apartment through the rear fire escape. The name of the woman hostage was not released.

title: Cynthia Singer Is Married
description: Cynthia Rae Singer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. Singer of New York, and Vincent Frank Bruno, son of Grace E. Bruno of Port Chester, N.Y., and the late Mr. Bruno, were married yesterday morning in Pleasantville, N.Y. Village Justice Frederick L. Scofield performed the ceremony at his home. Mrs. Bruno, a graduate of Barnard College, is an engineer at radio station WQXR. Her husband, an alumnus of New York University, is a staff announcer for radio stations WICC and WEZN in Bridgeport, Conn.

title: .. Enter the Enterprise
description: Out in California the other day, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration finally rolled out the Enterprise, the major component of the space shuttle which will begin a new era in space travel. The ungainly craft was originally scheduled to be called the Constitution, but President Ford yielded to the entreaties of the many admirers of TV's Star Trek, whose fictional spaceship is the Enterprise.

description: A 29yearold Queens man who was shot Saturday as he sat in a parked can with his three children while his wife was in an, automatic laundry died yesterday, apparently the victim of a stray bullet, the police reported.

description: When the season opened nine days ago, Pittsburgh's coach, Johnny Majors, had two excellent quarterbacks and the pleasant problem of trying to decide which one should start. Now he has no choice.

title: Veterans Bonus Cutoff Nears
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 19 (UPI)World War I veterans have until Oct. 1 to apply for the state's World War I Veterans Bonus Program, Treasurer Henry E. Parker said today. Connecticut pays a $300 bonus to eligible veterans or their surviving spouses.

description: DOVER, Del.. Sept. 19 (AP)Cale Yarborough overcame a freakish mechanical problem and then outdueled Richard Petty to win the Delaware 500 today, his second victory in a row and third in the last four National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing events.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19President Ford said in an interview published today that he would favor giving greater tax relief to families earning $8,000 to $30,000 a year.

description: HONG KONG, Sept; 19 (AP)Fourteen, Taiwanese crewmen from a missing Panamanian freighter, the Chieh Lee, were picked up by a Danish ship today, officials said.

description: For nearly three years I have served as deputy chancellor and chief business officer of the New York City public schools. Life on Mars? ...
description: The scientists trying to analyze the results of the experiments on Mars being conducted by the landers from Vikings 1 and 2 are understandably cautiousin fact, they are leaning over backward. They are doing so because probably the most sensational scientific conclusion in history would be the verdict that life had been found to exist outside this planet, in this case on Mars. So every possible objection to the hypothesis of Martian life is being considered and given due weight.

title: Sweden Said to Be Secretly Buying U.S. Satellite Pictures of Troops

title: Nancy Holstein, Artist, Bride of Jeffrey Loewy
description: Nancy Jane Holstein, a designer artist, and Jeffrey M. Loewy, a vice president of Oppenheimer & Company, stockbrokers, were married yesterday morning in the Harmonie Club. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony.

title: San Gennaro Festival Feast Day Proves a Delight for Gastronomes
description: The new James Beard would not approve. Sausages positively dripping with fat. Noodles floating in cream. Not to mention the cheese cake, cannoli and pizza smothered in mozzarella. The stuff weight watchers' wildest dreams are made of.

title: A Scandal Behind Scandals
description: A memorandum to State Comptroller Arthur Levitt on Sept. 2 raised a question that could apply to virtually any of the civic misdoings that have recently caught the public eye. Mr. Levitt had asked for a list of audits by his office of the Medicaid program since it began in 1966. His staff came up with 42 and, as the memorandum said, they detailed almost all of the findings which now appear to have burgeoned into a national scandal.

title: RHODE ISLAND GOVERNOR LEADS IN SENATE CONTEST

description: BUDAPEST, Sept. 19 (Reuters)Cardinal Laszlo Lekai of Hungary, sharing a platform with Communist leaders, has offered to intensify a national dialogue between Roman Catholics and Marxists.

title: Sponsor Asks Ford and Carter to Drop Debate Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)  The League of Women Voters is going back to President Ford and Jimmy Carter, the Republican and Democratic Presidential nominees, to ask if they will abandon their insistence that television cameras should not show the audience during their forthcoming debates.

title: Reagan Is Too Busy to Aid Ford in 5 States
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  Ronald Reagan will not campaign for President Ford in five states where the White House wanted his help because, a Reagan aide said, the White House did not ask in time. In six other Southern and Middle Western states Mr. Reagan, who nearly denied Mr. Ford the Republican nomination, will speak up for the President during the next six weeks, because he was going to be visiting those states anyway, helping Republicans who helped him challenge the President. Nearly a month ago, the White House said that Mr. Ford's chief of staff, Richard Cheney, had been dispatched on a peace mission to the former California Governor. As Mr. Reagan and his staff waited for word and heard none, they went about filling their barnstorming schedule for other candidates.

title: India's New Envoy Predicts Better Ties With U.S.
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 19Kewal Singh, who will become India's Ambassador to the United States next month, says that he envisions a very bright future for the oftenstrained relations between the countries.

Uselyte, daughter of Eugenia Uselyte of Kew Gardens, Queens, was married in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon to Manuel Yglesias, son of Frances Yglesias of Brooklyn and the late Manuel Yglesias. The Rev. Charles A. Kraus performed the ceremony in Our Lady of Angels Roman Catholic Church. The bride is with the JOC Oil Exploration Company. Mr. Yglesias is with the office of the United States representative of the First Curaao International Bank.

title: Books of The Times
description: There comes a point about a third of the way into Thomas Thompson's nonfiction thriller about a recent series of crimes in Houston, Tex., when the excitement of the narrative seems to ease a bit. The heroine of the piece is dead. The man suspected of murdering her has finally been indicted and brought to trial. And for a while it looks as though Mr. Thompson may be devoting the balance of his story, over 300 pages, to an account of that trial. Not that this would be the worst thing in the world that could happen to the reader. We have already had enough action, mystery, passion and gore to fill up most truecrime dramas of the sort that Blood and Money is successfully trying to be.

Tarkenton Doesn't Think His Call Was a Bad One

But could they agree on a definition of greed? Did Francis Tarkenton, who will be in the Hall of Fame some day too, fall victim to greed in the 74th minute of the Los AngelesMinnesota game here at 6:05 P.M. yesterday? Tarkenton had the Vikings on the Rams 11yard line with a first down and the score tied, 1010.

Rushing headlong toward an Oct. 2 adjournment, it has yet to resolve major legislative questions concerningamong other mattersair pollution, control over toxic substances, management of the national forests, regulation of strip mining and protection of wetlands.

Sunday night the Cleveland Quartet, currently in residence at Eastman, provided the focal point of the first concert, and the players were joined by five of their colleagues in a program of chamber music.

description: LONDON, Sept. 20 (AP)Two British warships collided in the North Sea today and one capsized, killing two crewmen, the Defense Ministry announced. Ten men were listed as missing.

title: Carter, in Early Stop at Trenton: Cheers, Jeers and Jersey Peaches
description: TRENTON, Sept. 20Enthusiasm at 8 o'clock on a Monday morning in downtown Trenton is a contradiction in terms.

title: Mariko Sanjo's Dances Have Hypnotic Intensity Extraordinary to the Eye
description: The hypnotic intensity of Mariko Sanjo's dances derives in part from their understatement and sculptural shaping. but most importantly from the intense feeling of ritual that Miss Sanjo imparts to anything she does. At the American Theater Laboratory Sunday evening, one had the feeling of participation in a weighty esthetic ceremony.

title: Beame Opens a Series of Hearings On New CommunityDistrict Lines
description: I don't even want my garbage going to Queens, a resident of Roosevelt Island in the East River heatedly told Mayor Beame yesterday as the Mayor opened a series of public hearings on his propotals for new communitydistrict lines under terms of the revised New York City Charter.

title: Screen: 'Aloise' Deals in Madness:Liliane de Kermadec Work Is Divided Into 2 Sections, Youthful Protagonist and Later Days in the Asylum
description: "Aloise" is a very static and occasionally very beautiful movie that suffers mainly from not being about as much as it attempts to be about.It is the story of a repressed, grave girl with lopsided angers who goes from Switzerland to Germany as a governess, falls in love with her employer, is sent back to Switzerland when World War I breaks out, goes mad, and spends the rest of her life in an asylum.In her old age and the film's, her clogged, mismatched gifts find a sudden channel. Aloisethe protagonistmakes a remarkable series of paintings: bright-colored, Chagall-like figures with a rocketing sexuality and, invariably, closed eyes."Aloise," which was shown yesterday in the Second International Festival of Women's Films at the Cinema Studio, is divided by its director, Liliane de Kermadec, into two very distinct sections. The first is an elliptical series of scenes, filmed with deliberate stillness and a white light, showing the protagonist as a young girl.She is the daughter of a Swiss railroad employee; she lives with him and her sister. Her mother is dead. "My name," she says, "has every vowel except 'u.' I wish I were called 'Lulu'." She is sure she is a singer; she takes lessons, practices, glares at other less-determined singers at church. But her voice won't serve; it is tuneful, but hard and reedy.As played by Isabella Huppert, the adolescent Aloise is, in her unvarying gravity, a figure of some mystery. What is this frustrated effort, this self-delusion building toward?The scene shifts suddenly, and so does the actress. She arrives in Germany for her job as a governess; almost at once the role is taken over by another actress, Delphine Seyrig. She falls in love hysterically, is sent home, and breaks down.The mystery of the child is resolved: All those nuances were preparation for madness. But this is asserted, not demonstrated. There is no real link: First she was sad as Isabella Huppert, then she was mad as Delphine Seyrig.The bulk of the film, then, is Miss Seyrig in the asylum. We see the doctors talking, the other patients, Aloise serself. It is most painfully and well observed, and Miss Seyrig's performance is breathtaking. But for quite a while we are never really sure why we are seeing it.The ending puts things together to some extent. Aloise begins to paint on wrapping paper, the doctors encourage her, and her work is put on exhibition in a big-city gallery. There is one splendid scene: She inspects the display, this aged sparrow of a woman, still quite mad, hopping by those evidences of a life that lives only on the wall and that she only faintly recognizes. And making banal comments such as this one, in front of a picture of two lovers: "This is a little vulgar; pretty, but not my cup of tea."A startling image of disassociation, it almost makes up for the long, long passages that precede it.

title: FELONY ARRESTS RISE 6% IN NEW YORK CITY
description: Arrests in New York City for feloniesthe most serious crimesincreased by almost 6 percent in the first half of the year despite cuts in police manpower, according to Police Department statistics.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HISTORY REVIEWED The exhibition Pioneer Photographers of Brazil: 18401920 may well be an example of parallel but independent developments in technology. The oldest surviving daguerreotype in the Americas was made by a Father Compte, in Brazil in 1840. That was three months after announcement of the invention in Paris and earlier than any surviving daguerreotype in New York.

title: Trolley Returns to the Motor City, and Mayor Foresee Revitalization
description: DETROIT, Sept.20  Washington Boulevard, once the Fifth Avenue of Detroit, has become a somewhat lonely, desolate place in recent years. Many of its stores, known for offering the finest merchandise in town, have moved out or closed. It has lost its wellmanicured look. And its sidewalks are no longer filled with pedestrians.

title: HIRSCHFELD THROWS SUPPORT TO BUCKLEY
description: In the lobby of a Manhattan public school yesterday, Abraham Hirschfeld, who ran fifth in the fivecandidate race for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from New York, endorsed James L. Buckley for the job.

title: Franklin D. Roosevelt Carter
description: ABOARD THE CARTER SPECIAL, Sept. 20Jimmy Carter was in full cry this morning at Philadelphia's Overbook Station when a commotion broke out in the crowd. The candidate, already suffering an audibility gap caused by a circling police helicopter (Rizzo's revenge, someone called it), suddenly was being drowned out as well by screams from schoolchildren perched in a stand of bleachers near the track.

title: Market Place
description: Carbon Industries, a West Virginia coal company that the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation over the weekend said it would buy, opened after a delay yesterday at 38 on accumulated orders for 13,200 shares for an explosive gain over Friday's closing price on the American Stock Exchange of 22.

title: PANDIT PRAN NATH RAGAS ARE REWARDING CONCERT
description: Pandit Pran Nath's concerts of morning ragas represent the only opportunity that New Yorkers have to experience an important aspect of Indian music. According to Hindu tradition the morning is a prayerful, meditative time of day, and Pran Nath's concerts, which are being held on Sundays at 10 A.M. at Heiner Friedrich Inc., 141 Wooster Street, often take on the feeling of a devotional service.

title: ALTITUDE ERROR BY PILOT IS SEEN IN TURKISH CRASH
description: ISPARTA, Turkey, Sept. 20 (UPI)The pilot of an airliner that flew low over this village in southern Turkey and crashed into a mountainside, killing all 155 persons aboard, apparently thought he was flying at 13,000 feet, reports from the scene indicated today.

title: Neuman Memorial Service
description: A memorial service of music will be held tomorrow at 11 A.M. at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and 10th Street, for Herman Neuman, retired music director of the municipal radio station, WNYC, who died in May. The service is being sponsored by the Bohemians, a musicians' club. Among the participants will be Andre Kostelanetz, conductor; Vernon de Tar, organist; Robert Russell Bennett, composer and arranger; Floyd Worthington, baritone; Martin Ormandy, cellist, and the Manhattan String Quartet.

title: A Death in Central Park
description: At about the time the Croatian hijackers were being returned from Paris to New York to answer for their spectacular and fatal misadventure, a crime of considerably less worldwide interestbut with a peculiar viciousness of its ownwas being committed against a young woman doing nothing more provocative than walking her dog in broad daylight in Central Park. We wish we could be as confident that the obscure pursesnatchers responsible for the death of Karen Singer will receive as speedy and certain justice as will the hijackers who captured world attention that same day.

title: Ford, Easier Home Purchases and the Election Campaign
description: There was a certain Americanasapplepie quality to President Ford's pronouncements on housing when he formally opened his election campaign in Ann Arbor last week. His pitch, indirectly, was to the young, middleclass family aspiring to buy a home. These would be the principal presumed beneficiaries of his call for a reduction in the down payment required for a mortgage guaranteed by the Federal Housing Administration. And these voters would also be helped by the ?? cycle concept  low debtservice payments in the early years of mortgage loans and rising payments as the years go on and the owner's income rises. The President proposed to try this experimentally.

description: Jacqueline W. Felter, who retired in 1974 as director of the Medical Library Center of New York, died Sunday in Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center. She lived at 1525 84th Avenue, Richmond Hill, Queens, and was 67 years old.

Everyone suspected and, after Watergate, everybody knew, that all kinds of favors were bought, jobs bartered and the whole democratic process warped.

title: Alleged Plot Organizer Released
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 20 (AP)Robert White, alleged organizer of a plot to kill Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, was released from jail today on personal recognizance. Judge George Bregianes decision came after the prosecutor, Eugene Mulcahy, requested a reduction of Mr. White's $25,000 bail. The case of Mr. White and his two alleged coconspirators, David King and Sandra Rondeau, were continued to Sept. 30.

description: A lawyer critical of research on human patients asserted yesterday that New York City municipal hospitals had engaged in experiments on unsuspecting patients or on other patients for whom, according to his charge, no informed consent could be legal.
