title: U.S. Cancer Institute Head Quits To Join American Cancer Society
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20Dr. Frank J. Rauscher Jr., director of the National Cancer Institute during its rapid expansion in the last four years, will leave about Nov. 1 to become senior vice president for research of the American Cancer Society.

title: Episcopal Bishops Approve Revision of Prayer Book
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 20 Despite long and heated controversy over the issue, the Episcopal Church has shown overwhelming support for the most extensive revision of the Book of Common Prayer in more than 400 years.

title: Correction Monitor Assails Probation And Parole System
description: The chairman of the New York State Commission of Correction, Stephen J. Chinlund, yesterday called the state's parole system a shambles and probation more of a shambles than parole. He said he was in favor of scrapping the whole thing and starting over because these programs did not stem recidivism.

title: Court Rules F.T.C. May Release Ashland's Records to Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20The Ashland Oil Company cannot prevent the Federal Trade Commission from giving Congress confidential information about its naturalgas holdings, a Federal appellate court ruled today. Ashland had argued against such disclosure on the grounds that the information might then become public.

title: L.I. Doctor Fights Use of a Statement On Death of Wife
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 20The defense in the case of Dr. Charles E. Friedgood, who is being tried for the murder of his wife, Sophie, 48 years old. sought today to establish that the Kensington physician had not been advised of his constitutional rights when he made a statement to Nassau County homicide detectives.

title: Article 5  No Title
Senate Fails to Act on Bill to Let S.E.C. Set Standards for Advisers
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20A controversial bill that would have given the Securities and Exchange Commission authority to set standards of competence and financial responsibility for investment advisers floundered today when the Senate, less than two weeks from its target adjournment date, failed to take it up.

title: Woman Gets 2 Tickets After Just Settling 300
description: A Brooklyn woman paid off 300 parking tickets yesterday only to discover that her car was being towed away for yet another parking violation.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE CURSE: A CULTURAL HISTORY OF MENSTRUATION. By Janice Delaney, Mary Jane Lupton, and Emily Toth. 276 pages. Dutton. $9.95.

title: TV: Series on Pappy Boyington
description: If this evening's special twohour premiere can be taken as a reliable gauge, Baa Baa Black Sheep could turn out to be one of the most objectionable projects of the new season. Based loosely on the World War II exploits of Marine Corps Maj. Gregory (Pappy) Boyington, the series offers a glorification of drinking and brawling misfits.

title: An Indian Town Recalls Lillian Carter Fondly.
description: VIKHROLI, India  Ten years ago a whitehaired Peace Corps nurse from Plains, Ga., who was working in the community center here would talk a lot about her son Jimmy, predicting great things for him.

title: Around the Nation
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 (AP) The Pennsylvania Supreme Court will hold hearing next week to determine whether Mayor Frank Rizzo of Philadelphia should face a recall election on Nov. 2.

title: Irving, a Loser on Hughes Book, Wins Case With Own Legal Brief
description: WESTBURY, L.I., SEPT. 20Clifford Irving, who served 17 months in a Federal prison for conspiracy and fraud in connection with his bogus book about Howard Hughes, the late billionaire, has had more success as a lawyer than he did as a biographer.

title: Maltese Premier Sees Victory as Socialist Mandate
description: VALETTA, Malta, Sept. 20Prime Minister Dom Mintoff, who led this strategic island away from the Atlantic Alliance and toward nonalignment, has won reelection for another fiveyear term.

title: . . .And She Has Fond Memories of Work in Its Health Clinic
description: PLAINS, Ga., Sept. 18Lillian Carter's memories of her Peace Corps stint in Vikhroli include working long hours in the health clinic, mingling with all classes of people, attending weddings and folk festivals, and participating in community projects.

title: U.N. Prepares for Session: Finesse Heads the Agenda
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20The 31st General Assembly had not even opened yetthat comes tomorrowwhen the Palestine Liberation Organization came up with the first of this year's inevitable plays for status among diplomats.

title: Panama University Is Closed Following March by Students
description: PANAMA, Sept. 20Classes were suspended indefinitely in Panama's National University tonight after a day of clashes between heavily armed soldiers and students protesting the high cost of living and alleged government repression.

title: Soviet Union Narrowed Trade Deficit With West By 25% for 2d Quarter
description: MOSCOW, Sept. ZU (UPI)The Soviet Union registered a trade deficit with the West of nearly $3 billion in the first half of this year, continuing a trend official Soviet statistics showed today. But the deficit narrowed in the second quarter.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: End of an Era in Sweden
description: The voters of Sweden have ended 44 years of rule by the Social Democratsthe longest tenure of uninterrupted power for any party in the world except for the Communists in the Soviet Union. The Scandinavian upheaval, not entirely unexpected, also retires to the opposition benches in the Riksdag the colorful, controversial Olof Palme, still only 49 after seven tumultuous years as Prime Minister.

title: Dave Anderson
description: KIAMESHA LAKE. N.Y.In his white terrycloth robe, Muhammad Ali was shouting, Norton must fall and waving his right arm in a chanting motion. Soon all the spectators who had attended his workout at the Concord Hotel were shouting, Norton must fall, Norton must fall, and the world heavyweight champion was conducting a rehearsal. I want everybody at Yankee Stadium, he was saying now, to yell on my call, Norton must fall, Norton must fall, and the people resumed their chants. Boxing's, doctor of crowd psychology wants to raise the odds against Ken Norton to 60,000 to 1 (from 8 to 5 as they are now) next Tuesday night. He's done it before. When he dethroned George Foreman in Zaire, he had thousands chanting, Ali, bomaye, meaning, Ali, kill him. And in Manila a year ago he had people chanting, Frazier must fall. Muhammad All never bothered with a chant for Richard Dunn or Jimmy Young or JeanPierre Coopman he didn't take them seriously. But obviously he is taking Ken Norton seriously.

title: Correction Monitor Assails Probation And Parole System
description: The chairman of the New York State Commission of Correction, Stephen J. Chinlund, yesterday called the state's parole system a shambles and probation more of a shambles than parole. He said he was in favor of scrapping the whole thing and starting over because these programs did not stem recidivism.

title: FELONY ARRESTS RISE 6% IN NEW YORK CITY
description: Arrests in New York City for feloniesthe most serious crimesincreased by almost 6 percent in the first half of the year despite cuts in police manpower, cording to Police Department statistics.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A demonstration by 50 housewives and children stopped traffic in East Meadow, L.I., several times yesterday morning on Hempstead Turnpike. Nassau County policemen held back cars as the demonstrators marched at the Prospect Avenue intersection, near the spot where 14yearold Deborah Kaplita was struck and killed by a passing car June 9.

title: Marathon Oil Buys All the Stock of Ecol For $140 Million
description: The Marathon Oil Company announced yesterday that it had bought all the stock of Ecol Ltd., for $140 million in cash.

title: South Africa Cited For Harsh Methods In Curbing Unrest
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 20The Christian Institute of Southern Africa suggested in a report made public tonight that moves by the Government since the outbreak of unrest in the black community three months ago had taken the country a significant step further toward becoming a police state.

title: Article 1  No Title
G.N.P. and Profits Climb With Prices
description: The Commerce. Department reported yesterday that the real gross national product, aftertax corporate profits and prices all rose more rapidly in the second quarter than previously estimated, according to revised figures for the period.

title: Thailand ExLeader Now Begs as Monk
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 20 (AP)Thanom Kittikachorn, front man for the military dictatorship ousted in 1973, walked the streets of Bangkok today, with shaved head, wearing the saffron robes of a Buddhist monk and begging door to door for his food.

title: Article 4  No Title
EUROPE'S SOCIALISTS WEIGH SWEDISH LOSS
description: BONN, Sept. 20In West Germany and elsewhere in Europe today the biggest political question appeared to be whether the defeat of Prime Minister Olof Palme in yesterday's elections in Sweden meant that the tide was running against Social Democrats on the Continent.

title: GOLD ARTIFACTS STOLEN FROM, FLORIDA MUSEUM
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 20 (AP) About $750,000 worth of gold bullion and jewelry recovered from Spanish galleons sunk off the Florida coast was stolen early today from the Museum of Sunken Treasure, the authorities reported.

title: ExKings at Prince Paul's Funeral
description: The evidence in our possession of the German movements seems overwhelming. In the face of it Prince Paul's attitude looks like that of an unfortunate man in the cage with a tiger, hoping not to provoke him while steadily dinnertime approaches.

title: California Snubs Alaska Oil, Forcing U.S. to Reconsider
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif.  Unexpected opposition by the State of California to the delivery by tankers of Alaskan oil to a terminal near Los Angeles has forced Washington to reconsider basic assumptions concerning the longawaited Alaska pipeline.

title: YALE TEACHER QUITS OVER PRONAZI ROLE
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 20 (AP)A Yale University teacher of Russian has resigned under pressure from his colleagues because of his newly disclosed work for the Nazis during World War II in the Germanoccupied Soviet Union.

title: MEXICO GETS U.S. AID PENDING I.M.F. LOAN AFTER DEVALUATION
description: WASHINGTON, D.C., Sept. 20Mexico has arranged a major package of financial support from the International Monetary Fund, with loans from the United States until the I.M.F. money is in hand, it was disclosed today.

title: Trolley Returns to the Motor City, and Mayor Foresees Revitalization
description: DETROIT, Sept.20  Washington Boulevard. once the Fifth Avenue of Detroit, has become a somewhat lonely, desolate place in recent years. Many of its stores, known for offering the finest merchandise in town, have moved out or closed. It has lost its wellmanicured look. And its sidewalks are no longer filled with pedestrians.

title: Bus Driver Shoots at 3 Youths, Hitting One, After Being Stabbed
description: A New York City bus driver, who the Transit Authority said was carrying a gun in apparent violation of the, agency's regulations, shot and wounded a youth early yesterday, moments after the youth and two accomplices had refused to pay the fare and had stabbed the driver in the back, the police said.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 20,1976

title: Business Records
description: Monday. September 20. 1976

title: HEALTH CARE IN HOME SUPPORTED FOR AGED
description: Home health care is preferable to institutional care for many of the elderly and handicapped, but only if it is closely monitored, witnesses told a panel of officials of the United States Department of Health. Education and Welfare yesterday.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Gillette Company disclosed yesterday that unidentified foreign units of the company had made certain illegal or questionable payments in foreign countries amounting to $400,000 from 1972 to 1975.

title: Johannesburg News and Notes: Vorster Is Hopeful Over Rhodesia
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 20Prime Minister John Vorster said today that the proposals put to Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger had laid the basis for a solution to the Rhodesian crisis, which formed the major topic at weekend talks between the three men in Pretoria.

title: Chiefs Defeated By Raiders, 2421, As Stabler Stars
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 20 (AP)Ken Stabler, Oakland Raider quarterback, using the forward pass like a surgical instrument, carved through the Kansas City defense for 224 yards and three touchdowns tonight, and the Raiders held off the Chiefs. 2421,

title: F.B.I.'s Interrogation of Suspect In Bronfman Case Is Challenged
description: WHITE PLAINS. Sept. 20An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation acknowledged in State Supreme Court today that Dominic Byrne, one of the alleged kidnappers of Samuel Bronfman 2d, the whisky heir, was not advised that a lawyer had been engaged to represent him before he confessed to the abduction.

title: Victor Over Swedish Socialists
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 20His hands are gnarled and blistered, his suits baggy, he speaks in a murmur, gripping a pipe and slouching restlessly in a chair. In the midst of a noisy news conference he seems a curiously brooding politician. Even this morning, in the aftermath of a stunning triumph over the Social Democratic Party, News Thorbjorn Falldin spoke solemly and nervously, biting his lip and perspiring heavily as he answered questions about the formation of a new government in Sweden the first nonSocialist government in 44 years.

title: Catholic Families in Cleveland Area See Abortion as Minor Election Issue
description: PARMA, Ohio, Sept. 19It is only a halfhour drive from the Urminski home here to the Cullo home in the more fashionable Cleveland suburb of Solon, but the two Roman Catholic families live in very different worlds. They share a deep devotion and antipathy to abortion, but little else.

title: CARTER IS URGED TO BACK CUT IN PEANUT SUPPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP)Representative Margaret M. Heckler, Republican of Massachusetts, called today on the nation's best known peanut farmer; Jimmy Carter, to endorse a $25 million cut in Federal price supports for peanuts.

title: Some Cocoa Futures Fall The 4Cent Daily Limit
description: Holders of long positions in cocoa futures, discouraged about prospects for further strength after a recent sharp rise, sold heavily yesterday. Prices dropped the limit in some months in trading on the New York Cocoa Exchange.

title: HIRSCHFELD THROWS SUPPORT TO BUCKLEY
description: In the lobby of a Manhattan public school yesterday, Abraham Hirschfeld, who ran fifth in the fivecandidate race for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from New York, endorsed James L. Buckley for the job.

title: Brewers Stop Yanks, 42
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 20The Milwaukee Brewers gave the expiring Baltimore Orioles at least one extra day of life tonight and gave the Yankees additional time to ice their champagne.

title: Dole Makes Emotional Plea to Handicapped in Florida
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Sept. 20Senator Robert J. Dole dropped his accustomed tough, tailgunner tone here today in an emotional moment before the physically handicapped people he called his community.

title: Chinese Province Chiefs Back Home
description: HONG KONG, Tuesday, Sept. 21Most of China's provincial leaders have returned to their home areas after a brief visit to Peking last week, broadcasts and news reports from China show, suggesting that a meeting of the Communist Party's Central Committee to elect a new leadership is not imminent.

title: Democratic Presidential Drive in New York Is Closely Knit to the State Party for the First Time Since 1964
description: For the first time in 12 years, the Democratic Presidential campaign in New York is being fully integrated with the Democratic state party and local Democratic campaigns for Congress and the legislature in a move that is likely to curb the squabbling that has characterized past presidential campaigns in the state.

title: Arnsparger Isn't Ready To Break Up the Giants
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 20 Bill Arnsparger won't break up the Giants.

title: Advertising
description: The next step in the advertising for the Empire Stakes, New York State's new and apparently successful lottery, will be to run newspaper ads showing the number of winners in various localities and maybe even listing their names.

title: Gromyko, Here for U.N., Planning To Take Up Case of MIG25 Pilot
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union, on arriving in New York yesterday by air for the United Nations General Assembly, said he would take up the case of the MIG25 pilot with American officials.

title: Disillusion Over Joblessness Is a Threat to Schmidt
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, Sept. 16Peter Gede, 17 years old, parked his yellow motorbike at the stone steps of the employment office here and walked up to the second floor to see a youth adviser.

title: End of Cuban Refugee Program Recommended by Federal Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP)A Federal task force recommended today that the Cuban Refugee Program, which has helped 650,000 Cubans fleeing the Castro regime resettle in the United States during the last 15 years, be phased out within five years.

title: Board of Elections To Begin Canvass Of Primaries Vote
description: With the outcome of at least three Assembly primaries still in doubt, the Board of Elections today begins the official canvass of the city's 5,500 voting machinesa process that, barring the almost inevitable suits by defeated candidates, will between now and Oct. 8 produce the official list of candidates for the November ballot.

title: WITNESS IS IMPUGNED IN KILLING AT MOSQUE
description: The key prosecution witness in the murder trial of a black Muslim accused of shooting a policeman at a Harlem mosque in 1972 testified yesterday that he was under two separate indictments for grand larceny involving credit cards and forgery.

title: STOCKS END MIXED ON LOWER VOLUME
description: Despite an early show of strength resulting from primerate reductions by two major banks, the stock market closed mixed yesterday in slower trading.

title: The Political Bestiary
description: The Ape Man had been restless ever since Jane had insisted on moving to the political jungle. He missed those long evenings on the veld with Simba the Lion. He missed the tree house with its natural cooling. He missed the rapidtransit system which sped him swiftly on vines to his daily work of routine vicious elephant hunters.

title: The U.N. Today
Butz Orders CentaGallon Rise In Milk Support to Aid Farmers
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI)Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz announced today an increase of 1 cent a gallon in Government milk supports, effective Oct. 1, but predicted it would have only minimal impact on consumer prices. Retail prices for most dairy products now are above the new support levels, Dr. Butz said in a statement.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Carter and the Job Issue: IllTimed Retreat The Money Lenders

title: Bias Again Bars Selection of Jury For Trial of Kallinger in Slaying
description: HACKENSACK, Sept. 20Bias again prevented the selection of a jury today in the murder trial of Joseph Kallinger. Judge Thomas F. Dalton of Superior Court questioned 52 prospective jurors. Fortyfive told him they had unalterable opinions on the case as a result of pretrial publicity.

title: Carter, on Morals, Talks With Candor
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 20Jimmy Carter has said in an interview that he has looked on a lot of women with lust and that he has committed adultery my heart many times, but that God forgives me for it.

title: Potash Debate in Canada Heightens
description: SASKATOON, Saskatchewan  A yearlong effort by the Canadian Government to nationalize partially the country's potash industry  largely owned by United States interestsis drawing sharp criticism on both sides of the border.

title: MAN KILLED IN QUEENS AN APPARENT BYSTANDER
description: A 29yearold man who was fatally shot Saturday afternoon as he sat in a parked car with his three children on a busy Queens street was believed to have been the innocent victim in an apparent shootout between the operators of a numbers racket and a group trying to rob them. the police said yesterday.

title: . . . And She Has Fond Memories of Work in Its Health Clinic
description: ??, Ga., Sept. 18?? Carter's memories of her Peace Corps stint in Vikhroli include working long hours in the health clinic, mingling with all classes of people, attending weddings and folk festivals, and participating in community projects.

title: Ford, Vowing Tax Relief, Asserts Carter Hits at MiddleIncome Class
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20Presiden Ford contended today that Jimmy Carte was proposing to increase Federal taxa tion of middleincome families at a time when we should be going in the oppo site direction.

title: Judge Upholds Award by Jury To Connie Francis. in L.I. Rape
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn upheld yesterday a jury award of $2.5 million to Connie Francis, the singer, to compensate for her rape in a Long Island motel on Nov. 8. 1974.

title: Enrique Batiz of Mexico Leads Concert by American Symphony
description: The American Symphony Orchestra concert Sunday evening in Carnegie Hall wasn't an ordinary American Symphony Orchestra concert. The regular series begins Oct. 10.

title: An Indian Town Recalls Lillian Carter Fondly . . .
description: VIKHROLI, India  Ten years ago a whitehaired Peace Corps nurse from Plains, Ge., who was working in the community center here would talk a lot about her son Jimmy Predicting great things for him.

title: Philharmonic Finds Soviet Tour Is a Time for Spirited Exchanges
description: MOSCOW, Sept 20  Whether they come here as musicians, scientists, diplomats or just plain tourists, many Americans are developing strong, conflicting attitudes about the Russians and Soviet life, feeling simultaneously great attraction and great revulsion.

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: PITTSBURGHLike the crossstate rivalry of Pennsylvania's two major league baseball teams, the Philadelphia Phillies and the Pittsburgh Pirates, there has long been a friendly, though intense, competitive battle between the nation's titans of the metals business directed from their headquarters offices a block apart in this city's Golden Triangle area. In interviews with their top executives recently, it was apparent that there is consislerable similarity in the current business position, future prospects, goals and economic philosophy of the United States Steel. Corporation and the Aluminum Company of America, the two largest producers in their respective fields. And they continue to compete headon in various markets, especially for the can business, where the battle is particularly fierce. But, at the moment, the aluminum outlook seems somewhat more shiny.

title: I Have a Dream Pays Tribute On Stage to Martin Luther King
description: Montgomery, Selma, Memphis, all that sad, long litany of Southern towns, whose names marked like tombstones the eventual triumph of the Civil Rights movement and the Constitution. The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., that militant pacifist preacher destined to become a winner of the Nobel Peace Prize and defensibly America's most pertinent martyr. A rifle crack one early April evening in 1968 on the balcony of a Memphis motel. The agony of a nation, the anguish of people.

title: Paul Taylor Is Disbanding Dance Troupe
description: The Paul Taylor Dance Company, long one of the country's leading moderndance troupes with an international reputation, has announced that it will disband indefinitely because of financial difficulties.

title: Study Finds Few U.S. Concerns Plan Cuts Abroad
description: Production costs overseas have been rising faster than in the United States for the last three years, a trend that has slowed the pace of American direct investment abroad. Nevertheless, few American companies plan substantial cutbacks in their overseas facilities, according to a study by the Conference Board released yesterday.

title: FordCarter Stands on Abortion Held Similar, With One Exception
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20The delicate, divisive, complex and intensely personal subject of abortion has, somehow, exploded into the first major issue of the Presidential campaign.

title: Mr. Carter Toes the Line
description: Presidential candidates cannot afford and cannot be expected to reject the political support of all those who do not agree completely with them. And yet there are limits to the embraces of expediency. Even by the most relaxed standards of campaign promiscuity, former Governor Carter's Mississippi love feast with Senators James O. Eastland and John C. Stennis stretched the limits of political decency.

title: Zaire, Rwanda, Burundi in Pact
description: GISENYI, Rwanda, Sept. 20 (Agence FrancePresse)Zaire and its neighbors, Rwanda and Burundi, signed conventions today to establish an economic community. The grouping of the three African countries, called the Economic Cornmunity of the Countries of the Great Lakes, was inaugurated by the Presidents Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire, Juvenal Habyarimana of Rwanda and Michel Micombero of Burundi.

title: People and Business
description: The stock of Dart Industries Inc. dropped 12 points, closing at $36, yesterday after an announcement that Gary A. Childress, 42, had resigned as president of the company and as a member of its board of directors. Officials of the company, a diversified consumer goods manufacturer that markets Tupperware plastic containers and other products, declined to elaborate on the reasons for the resignation.

title: L'Heureux Turf Victor With Great Contractor
description: Great Contractor and L'Heureux both came from far back and won the two divisions of the $87,100 Lawrence Realization for 3yearolds at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: 5 South African Blacks Wounded By Police After StoneThrowing
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 20 (AP)The police wounded five blacks who threw stones at police fighting a bush fire near Johannesburg, a police spokesman announced today.

title: Dibbs Wins, Fillol Upse In Pacific First Round
description: WESTWOOD, Calif.. Sept. 20 (AP)Eddie Dins fought off 5 set points in the opening round of the $125,000 Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today before gaining a 64, 76 victory over Andrew Pattison of Rhodesia.

title: Waiting Room Only
description: LONDONIn Clitheroe, a town in Lancashire, there is an unhappy Englishwoman who has been waiting since September 1957 for Britain's National Health Service to provide her with an orthopedic operation.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Dr. Edmund O. Matzal, who will be on New Jersey's generalelection ballot as the American Party's Vice Presidential candidate, has been charged with failing to file Federal income tax returns. Dr. Matzal, a 42yearold Blairstown. physician, is a staunch opponent of Federal and state income taxes. Last Saturday, he attended a rally at the State House where protesters spoke against a recently enacted state income tax.

title: Irate Erving Warns Nets: Won't Report
description: In the promotion of the Dr. J. and Tiny A show, the Nets give Julius Ering top billing, but Nate Archibald is paid more for his basketball skills. As a result of thatand what Erving calls broken promises by Roy Boe, the club president  Erving notified Boe yesterday he would not report when training camp opens Friday at Manhattanville College.

title: In This Enchanted Garden, Exotic Creations and Loving Care
description: People walk into Madderlake, a plant store at the corner of 10th Street and Seventh Avenue South and tell the shopkeepers that they would like to move inliterally. This is just the way I want to live, one might say to the coowners, Tom Pritchard and Jim Reilly.

title: Scientists Gassing Seedlings to Save Urban Trees
description: There may not be many blacksmiths around these days, and a blight cut down all the native spreading chestnut trees some time ago. But there will always be honey locust, and green ash, and Norway maplesif scientists at the Cary Arboretum have anything to say about it.

title: Rangers Update Uniforms And Game, Too, They Hope
description: Like the losing gambler who requests new cards or dice, the New York Rangers changed their uniform yesterday. It will be introduced Oct. 6, when they open the National Hockey League season against Minnesota at Madison Square Garden.

title: Notes on People
description: The favorite soap opera of Cambridge, Mass., reached a denouement in the nature of a compromise yesterday. Harvard University announced that Doris Kearns Goodwin would receive a threeyear appointment to teach halftime, without tenure, as professor of government. She had been. recommended for Harvard tenuresomething akin to beatification, one intellectual called it yesterdayon the basis of the original version of her now best selling Lyndon Johnson and the American Dream.

title: CHARLES T. OERGEL
description: Charles T. Oergel, a retired professor of engineering at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, died Saturday of cancer at his home in Long Valley, N.J. He was 73 years old.

title: Adult Home for Chinese Is First of Its Kind
description: Chinatown is one of the most crowded communities in New York. Staten Island is one of the least. Small wonder, then, that to about 50 elderly former Chinatown residents a new adult home set in among the tall trees and Victorian houses of St. George, S. I., is a rather special place.

title: KISSINGER REPORTS TO ZAMBIAN LEADER
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 20President Kenneth D. Kaunda received a personal report today from Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger on his talks yesterday with Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia but declined to say whether the results were acceptable to black Africa.

title: Felix J. Aulisi, a Retired Judge Of State Supreme Court, 75
description: Felix J. Aulisi, a retired New York State Supreme Court justice, died yesterday in Amsterdam, N. Y., after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

title: Fighting Flares in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 20Palestinian, Syrian and rival Lebanese forces stepped up military operations today following the failure yesterday of ceasefire talks among their political leaders.

title: Democrats in Oklahoma Voting Today to Choose Nominee for Albert Post
description: The Democratic nomination for the Congressional seat being vacated by the retiring House Speaker, Carl Albert, at stake today in a runoff election between an Oklahoma state senator and Mr. Albert's longtime chief aide.

title: Networks Will Carry FordCarter Debate, Despite Reservations About Selection of Members of the Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20The three commercial networks, all expressing some reservations about arrangements, said tonight that they would broadcast live on radio and television Thursday night's debate between President Ford and Jimmy Carter.

title: JUDGE UPHOLDS REPORTER WHO WITHHELD HIS SOURCE
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday upheld the right of a Newsweek reporter, Anthony Marro, to refuse to divulge the sources of a story he had written.

title: RealtyTax Delinquencies Increase
description: Uncollected real estate taxes in New York City rose by $35 million during fiscal 1976, which ended last June 30, bringing the total tax delinquency to a new high of $242.6 million, according to Finance Department figures released yesterday.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Monday.

title: KIBBEE SEEKS A RISE IN THE NEXT BUDGET
description: Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, chancellor of the City University, has called for a budget increase next year of $18.4 million to overcome what he described as the adverse educational effects of the current starvation budget.

title: Grambling's Tokyo Bill Won't Be Sent to Louisiana
description: Grambling and Morgan State, two of the best known predominantly black college football teams, are exporting their game. They will meet Friday night in Tokyo's Korakuen Stadium, a 50,000seat arena that is the home field for the Tokyo Yomiuri Giants, a baseball team. This will be the first regularseason American college. football game to be played outside the Western Hemisphere.

title: DEMOCRATIC PLATFORM IS SCORED BY REAGAN
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 (UPI)  To Ronald Reagan, the most important debate this election year is not between the two major Presidential candidates but over the Democratic and Republican platforms.

title: Ford, Vowing Tax Relief, Asserts Carter Hits at MiddleIncome Class
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20President Ford contended today that Jimmy Carter was proposing to increase Federal taxation of middleincome families at a time when we should be going in the opposite direction.

title: Article 2  No Title
Little Gain Since Helsinki Accords, Eastern and Western Aides Agree
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 20For differing reasons, Western and Communist diplomats are expressing growing agreement that the 1975 Helsinki summit meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe has produced disappointingly few results.

title: Books of the Times
description: THE SONY VISION, By Nick Lyons. 235 pages. Illustrated. Crown. $7.95.

title: Smith, After Cabinet Talks, Says Kissinger Plans Need Deliberation
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 21Prime Minister Ian D. Smith emerged today from consultations with his Cabinet saying that the question of accepting proposals for a Rhodesian settlement that he had discussed with Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger required cautious deliberation since it involved the future of Rhodesia and the lives of our people.

title: HarvardNavy Rowing Gets Middendorf Cup
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 21Secretary of the Navy J. William Middendorf 2d announced today a trophy to be awarded to the winner of the annual rowing regatta between the United States Naval Academy and Harvard University, starting next June.

title: TV: MenBoys, Inanity and Blood
ROHATYN SAYS CITY MUST STRETCH OUT REPAYMENT OF BONDS
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, proposed yesterday that New York City stretch out the payment on more than $10 billion in longterm bonds as a way of softening the need for drastic new budget cuts next year.

title: Forecast in Japan Steel Output
description: TOKYO, Sept. 21 (UPI)  The Ministry of International Trade and Industry predicted today a slow growth in Japan's ordinary steel production for the OctoberDecember period of this year. The ministry said the steel output in terms of crude steel was estimated at 28.4 million tons, up 500,000 tons or 1.8 percent over the current threemonth period.

title: Carter Proposes a Unified Agency In the Cabinet for Energy Policy
description: PLAINS, Ga., Sept. 21Jimmy Carter proposed today that Federal Government agencies and bodies involved in making policy about energy, regulating the energy industries, and fostering research in the field be combined into a new cabinet level government department as the first step in developing a new national energy program.

title: BUS STRIKE IN CAIRO ENDS AMID CHARGES OF SABOTAGE
description: CAIRO, Sept. 21A twoday bus strike that tied up Cairo over the weekend has ended in violence and sabotage. The strike, described here as the biggest in Egyptian public utilities in 20 years, began Saturday and ended yesterday morning.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, SEPT. 21Ann Klein, Commissioner of Institutions and Agencies said today that voter approval of bond issues, that will be on the ballot in November would mean the renovation of hospital and prison facilities and the restoration of accreditation to Trenton State Hospital.

title: Ford Plans New Engine to Shift Cylinders and Save 10% in Fuel
Police Asking for Some Horses They Needn't Look in Mouth
The Tax Dodge
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21Tax reform is a fundamental test of whether an open, liberal society such as ours can achieve justice for a majority of its people. Up to now, we have failed that test. Relatively small numbers of individuals who already have large fortunes or large incomes have used their economic power to rig the tax laws in their favor. As a result, they pay a smaller share of taxes than they should and place an unfair burden on ordinary people who are struggling to make ends meet.

title: Berlin's 26th Fall Arts Festival Gets Stimulating Taste of SoHo
description: WEST BERLIN  Scores of artists from New York's SoHo are offering a rich and unusual feast for this city's 26th Fall Arts Festivaland though the West Berliners pick at some unfamiliar mornsels, they seem to be joyously intoxicated by the stimulating spirit of New York.

title: WINE TALK
description: If there is anything predictable and consistent about the succeeding vintages in France it is that each one will he called the vintaee of the century.

title: Senators Ask U.S. For Action to Avert West Coast Oil Glut
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI)Senators and Administration officials discussed at a hearing today how to get rid of a coming glut of Alaskan oil on the West Coast without selling it abroad while the rest of the nation continues to be plagued by shortages.

title: G.O.P. FUNDRAISING IN MICHIGAN STUDIED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21The White House said today that President Ford did not need to be defended in connection with an inquiry into Republican fundraising in Michigan because nobody has said there has been any wrongdoing in the case.

title: $128,000 Loss to Check Writer Is Discovered in an Audit of OTB
description: The Offtrack Betting Corporation has discovered an $128,000 lossbut not to bettors.

title: Puerto Rico's Governor Joins Moynihan in Campaign
Western Democratic Chiefs Tell Carter Not to Ignore the Area
description: TETON VILLAGE, Wyo., Sept. 21Gov. Calvin Rampton of Utah came to the annual meeting of the Western Governors' Conference here this week with a 15 pound bronze cast in Salt Lake City.

title: Gold Price Climbs By $5.62 an Ounce In London to $120
description: LONDON, Sept. 21 (AP) The closing price of gold in London today climbed $5.625 an ounce after a day of active trading to reach a nineweek high of $120 an ounce

title: Portugal Acts to Return Some of Farms Seized During Leftists Control
description: LISBON, Wednesday, Sept. 22 (UPI)The Socialist Government decided early today to start returning next week more than 100 farms it said were illegally seized by Communist and other leftist workers last year.

title: Notes on People
description: President William R. Tolbert Jr. of Liberia was welcomed at the White House yesterday by President Ford and nodded in agreement as the President said Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's African mission must succeed in order to prevent increased violence and bloodshed.

title: Salvadoran Colonel Goes On Trial in a Plot to Sell 10,000 Guns to Gangsters
Liberalized Views Changing Mormon Haven
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 20  Let Virtue Garnish Thy Thoughts, proclaims a placard held aloft by an earnest young man outside a theater showing Xrated films in downtown Salt Lake City.

title: Embargo on Clamming Could Help Save Industry Hit by Pollution
President Raises Duty on Sugar
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21President Ford announced today an increase of about 1.2 cents a pound in the duty on imported sugar as an interim measure to help alleviate the problems of domestic growers brought about by a collapse in the world sugar price.

title: U.S. Election Panel Unveils a Computer And Some Figures
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21The Federal Election Commission unveiled today a new computer system designed to keep voters informed on candidates sources of campaign money and on political spending on a daytoday basis.

title: Mandel's Policy on Race Tracks Saved Money, His Lawyer Says
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 21The chief defense counsel for Gov. Marvin Mandel, being tried here on charges of bribery and conspiracy involving a race track, asserted today that the twoterm Democrat had saved Maryland taxpayers millions of dollars through his interest in consolidating the state's horseracing industry, one of the things he is charged with attempting to do for the benefit of wealthy friends.

title: Dow Soars 20 to 1,014.79, Highest in Almost 4 Years
Rhode Island Governor Has Lead Of 100 in Senate Race Vote Count
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 21 (AP)Gov. Philip W. Noel held a 100vote lead over Richard Lorber, a wealthy car dealer, tonight in the weeklong counting of ballots from a primary election to choose a Democratic nominee for the United States Senate.

title: Radio
Cunningham Is Given Lesser L.I. Charge
description: The Nassau County District Attorney, Denis Dillon, has agreed to allow Patrick J. Cunningham, the embattled Democratic leader, to plead guilty to a reduced charge of speeding rather than stand trial on a charge of driving while impaired by alcohol, Mr. Cunningham's lawyer, Michael P. Stafford, said last night.

title: Pirate Bid Slowed By Split With Cubs
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 21Playing the Chicago Cubs for 22 innings while chasing the Philadelphia Phillies and fighting a slump proved too much for the Pittsburgh Pirates to manage today. After beating the Cubs, 43, in the first game of a doubleheader at Wrigley Field, the Pirates dropped the second contest. 21. in 13 innines.

title: Navy Flies Equipment to Britain In Hunt for F14 on Ocean Floor
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)The Navy has flown special search equipment to Scotland and will start hunting for an advanced F14 fighter plane on the Atlantic Ocean floor as soon as weather permits, the Pentagon said today.

title: Thailand Will Oust ExMilitary Leader
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 21 (AP)Prime Minister Seni Pramoj said today that Thailand's former military ruler, Thanom Kittikachorn, who returned from exile to visit his ailing father and enter a Buddhist monastery, would be asked to leave the country after the death of his father.

title: THE BLACK FAMILY RECONSIDERED: I
description: The contempt we have been taught to entertain for the blacks makes us fancy many things that are founded neither in reason nor in experience, Alexander Hamilton said nearly 200 years ago. That remains true, especially in very mistaken ideas about the slave family and the generations of poor black families since Emancipation, in 1865. Such myths inevitably affect how urban poverty is explained and policies to control or abalish it are defined.

title: London Dubious on Rhodesia Gains
description: LONDON, Sept. 21Britain cast a hopeful but skeptical eye today on reports from southern Africa that Rhodesia's white leadership was prepared to transfer Dower to the black majority.

title: CurbSweeping by Stores Sought
description: A City Council committee yesterday voted out a bill requiring not only that sidewalks in front of stores and residences be swept clean, but also that an additional 18 inches beyond the curb into the gutter be swept.

title: WEISS WON'T GIVE UP RACE FOR ABZUG SEAT
description: Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak has unsuccessfully tried to talk Bella S. Abzug's likely successor in Congress into stepping aside so that Mrs. Abzug could regain the Democratic nomination for her ManhattanBronx seat.

title: Weiss Spurns Plea To End Bid for Seat Left by Mrs. Abzug
description: Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak has unsuccessfully tried to talk Bella S. Abzug's likely successor in Congress into stepping aside so that Mrs. Abzug could regain the Democratic nomination for her ManhattanBronx seat.

title: Royals Win, 31, Nudging A's 7 Back
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 21 (AP)Hal McRae and John Mayberry lashed successive runscoring singles tonight as the Kansas City Royals defeated Oakland, 31, fattening their lead over the A's in the American League West to seven games. Both teams have 11 games left, five with each other.

title: Kuhn Tells Hearing N.L. Will Expand
Rate of Inflation Remains Steady For Third Month
Carter In A Slump
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 21Maybe the debates will bring him out of it, but Jimmy Carter, like President Ford before the Republican convention, is in a slump. His timing and even his judgment seem to be off. He looks and sounds tired and maybe overexposed just when the debates will expose him to the largest audience of the Presidential campaign.

title: Ratio of Blacks and Puerto Ricans Was Heavy in Primary Balloting
description: Spurred by bitter primary contests in the South Bronx and in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn, Black and Puerto Rican voters, often criticized for voting apathy, turned out in greater numbers proportionately in last week's Democratic primary than upstate voters, a survey of the primary returns showed yesterday.

title: Patriots Upset of Dolphins Fails to Alter Week's Odds
description: The most startling score of the National Football League's new season, New England's 3014 rout of Miami last Sunday, failed to impress those who determine the next weekend's favorites; the outcome was regarded asan isolated phenomenon typical of the sport. Releasing its wagering line yesterday from Reno, Nev., for Sunday's games, Harrah's Racebook decided the Dolphins were 19point favorites over the Jets and the Patriots 15point underdogs to the Pittsburgh Steelers. There was no downgrading of Miami and no upgrading of New England.

title: Advertising
description: During the dark ages of the agency business media people were forced to really study magazines in order to evaluate them for their clients advertising.

title: Thomas McGrath Dead
description: Thomas A. McGrath, a retired consumer finance industry executive, died Sunday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N. J. He was 72 years old and a resident of Summit.

title: Helstoski Defeats Baer in Rerun Of Jersey Congressional Primary
description: Representative Henry Helstoski of Rutherford, despite a Federal indictment, won renomination yesterday in a special Democratic primary election in New Jersey's Ninth Congressional District, defeating Assemblyman Byron M. Baer of Englewood by a surprisingly decisive margin.

title: Liberalized Views Changing Mormon Haven
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 20  Let Virtue Garnish Thy Thoughts, proclaims a placard held aloft by an earnest young man outside a theater showing Xrated films in downtown Salt Lake City.

title: Canadian Tells U.S. Supplies of Potash Will Be Adequate
Film: Indolent Femmes au Soleil
Market Place
description: IngersollRand faded like a spent compressor yesterday, adding to losses in the stock that followed word from its chairman on Monday that earnigs forecast earlier for 1976 now appeared unattainable.

title: About Education
U.S. Defeats Japan In Collegiate Tennis
description: TOKYO, Sept. 21 (AP)American college tennis players completed fourdays of play against Japanese Collegians today, capturing the first United StatcsJapan college allstar tennis series 203, and sweeping the exhibition matches, 310.

title: About New York
U.S.Soviet Talks on Strategic Arms Resume in Geneva, but Progress During Election Campaign Is Doubted
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21The slowmoving strategic arms talks resumed in Geneva today, their future now beclouded by a Presidential campaign in the United States.

title: Curb on Kickbacks Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)  The Senate passed a bill today to make it a Federal crime to demand political kickbacks from state employees paid in whole or in part with Federal funds. The measure, previously passed by the House, now goes back there for action on minor, clarifying amendments.

title: J.W.T. Again Wins Marine Corps Vote
description: At 1600 hours yesterday (4 P.M. for you civilians) buglers stationed on each of the seven floors of the J. Walter Thompson Company began blaring The Marine Corps Hymn. It was one way of telling the troops that the agency, which had handled all of the Marine Corps recruiting for the last 26 years, had once again won the account. The Corps is now spending $10 million annually.

title: EXPERTS BACK PLAN FOR SCIENCE COURT A Meeting in Virginia Decides Concept of QuasiJudicial Panel Should Be Tested
description: LEESBURG, Va., Sept. 21The proponents called it an idea whose time had come a possible new social invention to deal with some of the most perplexing questions raised by the inventions of modern science and technology.

title: Surprise for Polish Communists: Leaders Lost Touch With Public Opinion
description: WARSAW, Sept. 21The Polish Communist Party's leadership has been severely shaken by its finding that it lost touch with public opinion.

title: JOHN QUINN DIES AT 68
description: SANTON, Calif., Sept. 21 (AP)John Quinn, a general manager in the National League for 28 years, died at his home last night at the age of 68. He had been ill for some time.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Rupee Revalued Against Pound
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 21 (AP)The Indian Government revalued the rupee against the British pound for the seventh time in 12 months. The revaluation of about 4 percent lowered the value of the pound sterling to 15.40 rupees compared to 16 rupees since last May 29. A year ago one pound was worth 18.31 rupees.

title: Israeli Educator Develops Method To Help Culturally Disadvantaged
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 21For more than 40 of his 72 years Dr. Carl Frankenstein has labored in search of a method to enable slum children with low to normal intelligence quotients to overcome their disadvantages and cultural deprivations and cope successfully with abstract concents.

title: Around the Nation
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 21 (UPI)The National Center for Disease Control said today that a nationwide shortage of polio vaccine has developed at a time when demand for the drug is greatest because of mass immunization among school children.

title: Article 1  No Title
N.L.R.B. RULES ON WORK OF TYPOGRAPHICAL UNION
description: The National Labor Relations Board has ruled that employees of The New York Times Company represented by Typographical Union No. 6 are entitled to perform the work of preparing some advertising copy so that it can be handled by computer.

title: Giants Shown Game Films
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 21The Giants reported back to work today, watched the films of their 207 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles and Larry Csonka became ill.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: Delicate Diplomacy to Photo Fraud
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sept. 21On the way to Lusaka yesterday, Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and his top aides were congratulating themselves on so managing the news while they were in South Africa that they were able to confer for eight hours with Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia without having a photograph taken of Mr. Kissinger and the white supremacist together

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the Canadian Government was incorrectly reported in The Times yesterday as having nationalized certain potash operations. These operations, in fact, have been taken over by the Province of Saskatchewan.

title: SWISS CONCERN BUYS U.S. SEED COMPANY
description: Northrup, King & Company, one of the country's largest seed companies, announced yesterday that its directors and those of Sandoz Ltd. of Basel, Switzerland, had approved an agreement in principle for the purchase of Northrup, King by Sandoz at a cash price of $19.40 a share. The transaction, involving all of the 10,133,578 outstanding common shares of the seed company, amounts to about $196 million. Northrup, King's common stock was the most actively traded in the overthecounter market yesterday and rose 4 points to 16 on a turnover of 330,200 shares.

title: Jack Ansell, 50, Novelist Who Wrote About Jews In Southern U.S., Dies
Friedgood Not Advised Of His Rights, Detective Tells Murder Hearing
Amnesty International Declares Jakarta Holds 100,000 Prisoners
TANZANIAN REPORTS RHODESIAN AGREEING ON BLACKRULE ISSUE
Reflections on Medicaid and Good Care
description: LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y.In view of the present hysteria concerning Medicaid, I think it fitting that there should be some light shed on this entire problem.

title: The U.N. at Sea
description: The United Nations General Assembly convened yesterday under the shadow of another international diplomatic failurea deadlock in the world organization's threeyearold Law of the Sea Conference which, if it persists, could poison prospects for peaceful cooperation on land as well as on the twothirds of the earth that is covered by water.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CRAFTY CURBS The Museum of Contemporary Crafts, which doesn't look a day over 15, is 20 years old and is kicking up its heels tonight all over the block on West 53d Street, where it is housed at No. 29. The street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas will be closed off from 8:30 P.M. to 10 P.M. Everyone's invitedno charge.

title: Hiring in Northeast Encouraged As U.S. Finds Slower Wage Rises
The Other Brooklyn Bridge: Spacious Offices and Labyrinthine Caves
description: Ever since the first greenhorn bought a share in the Brooklyn. Bridge, ithas become common lore that the bridge is not for sale. It is, however, for rent.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The American Optical Corporation, a subsidiary of the WarnerLambert Company, said yesterday it had purchased fights to the Union Corporation's soft contact lens. The lens was recently approved for vision correction use by the Fond and Drug Administration.

title: Regulations on the Establishment of Fees on Individual Retirement Accounts Are Criticized by Accountant
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21The retirement dreams of millions of Americans could become nightmares unless Congress and the Internal Revenue Service act to help people make rational selections of Individual Retirement Accounts, a House subcommittee was told today.

title: TANZANIAN, REPORTS RHODESIAN AGREEING ON BLACKRULE ISSUE
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sept. 21President Julius K. Nyerere met with Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger today and said afterward that the Rhodesian Prime. Minister, Ian D. Smith, had accepted the principle of black majority rule for Rhodesia within two years.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: U.N. Agenda Headed By Southern Africa
description: The smoldering political situation in southern Africa is expected to be the dominant issue during the 13week 31st General Assembly of the United Nations, which opened yesterday. Initiatives will also be taken to combat terrorism and to deal with the ArabIsraeli conflict.

title: Mott Is a Political Host at New Penthouse
description: Stewart R. Mott, the philanthropist, threw open that controversial multimilliondollar quadruplex penthouse on East 57th Street for the first time last night, at a party in honor of the National Committee for an Effective Congress.

title: Daley Welcomes Mondale at End Of WhistleStopping Train Trip
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 21The Democratic train for a change ended its 28hour whistlestop journey from New York and cheering crowds of the Party faithRepublicans as strong for labor but ful greeting Senator Walter F. Mondale as he arrived.

title: GENERAL ASSEMBLY AT THE U.N. OPENED
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21The 31st annual session of the General Assembly convened today with a complex of African issuesthe fate of Rhodesia, SouthWest Africa and South Africahanging over the crowded hall.

title: S. Joseph Tankoos Jr., Realty Investment Leader And Engineer, Dies at 55
description: S. Joseph Tankoos Jr., chairman of the MussTankoos Corporation; founder and general partner of the Tankoos Company of New York, a realty investment concern, died yesterday at Memorial Hospital in Manhattan. He was 55 years old.

title: Boe Taking a Hard Line Over Demands by Erving
Columbia Tennis Center Fund Drive Is Under Way
description: Columbia's Tennis Center at Baker Field, where Dr. Renee Richards has been practicing frequently, is trying to raise $100,000 for its yearround program. In addition to improving the layout, the funds would help support the tennis team and Columbia's project to teach the game to community youngsters.

title: 10 MEN AND 6 WOMEN ON KALLINGER PANEL
description: HACKENSACK, Sept 21A jury of 10 men and six women, including four alternates, was empaneled today for the murder trial of Joseph Kallinger.

title: SMALL BOMB SET OFF AT NEW YORK HILTON
description: A small bomb exploded in a stairwell on the 24th floor of the New York Hilton Hotel last night, lightly damaging the walls of the stairwell but injuring no guests or employees.

title: British M.P.'s Face Rising Scottish Dem ??
Situation Wanted: FieldGoal Kicker
description: I hit the first one good, the recently fired fieldgoal kicker was saying, but they blocked it. The second one, a 39yarder, curved to the right at the last minute. On the third one, the easy one, I was so tense I never had a chance.

title: Opening City Space
description: The only thing that is rarer than a builder in New York today is one who, in the ordinary course of development, will of his own accord make the city a more beautiful or livable place. It has been the job of zoning to mandate amenities such as open space; most builders have become experts on how little can be done to make these spaces attractive or usable.

title: U.S. Indicts 5 Croatian Hijackers
Monitors Find No Deterioration In Reading of U.S. Schoolchildren
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21The Federal program for monitoring the achievement of American schoolchildren has found, contrary to the beliefs of many educational critics, that reading ability has not deteriorated during the 1970's and that nineyearolds, especially, have improved markedly.

title: G.O.P. FUNDRAISING IN MICHIGAN STUDIED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21The White House said today that President ford did not need to be defended in connection with an inquiry into Republican fundraising in Michigan because nobody has said there has been any wrongdoing in the case.

title: New Lebanon Chief To Be Inaugurated In SyriaHeld Area
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 21The Lebanese National. Assembly will meet in Syriancontrolled territory of eastern Lebanon on Thursday to inaugurate Elias Sarkis as President.

title: Solomon Eliminated by McNair, Ramirez Advances at Coast Net
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 (AP) Fred McNair of Chevy Chase, Md., upset Harold Solomon, seeded seventh, in the first round today of the $125,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis tournament at Pauley Pavilion at the University of California. Los Angeles.

title: Episcopal Bishops Urge That 15 Woman Priests Be Ordained Again
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 21The House of Bishops of the Episcopal Church today urged that the 15 women who hade been irregularly ordained to the priesthood undergo conditional ordination in case their original ordinations were not valid.

title: Carter Surprises Ohio Politicians By His Show of Strength in State
description: MANSFIELD, Ohio, Sept. 21The 1976 Presidential contest is disrupting political patterns of 30 years' standing, and there is no better evidence of the changes than in the industrial states clustered around the Great Lakes.

title: $400 Million in Credits for Peru
description: LIMA, Peru, Sept. 21 (AP)Peru will get $400 million in credits to strengthen its balance of payments, it was officially announced. Six United States banks have already signed an agreement to provide $125 million, and other credit institutions will provide $75 million more, it was announced.

title: NATO TESTING ABILITY ON NORWEGIAN COAST
description: STEINKJER, Norway, Sept. 21 Amphibious tractors waddled ashore from Namsen Fjord and discharged shouting United States marines. Helicopters dumped a company of reserves from Kansas and Missouri onto high ground above the beachhead. Jets flew cover for the maneuver, being conducted by the Atlantic alliance.

title: DOLE HAS PHYSICAL
description: Senator Robert J. Dole, the only majorparty candidate for President or Vice President who has not made public his health record, underwent a physical examination yesterday at the Capitol medical office in Washington, according to his press secretary.

title: Ford Would Protest An Affair of Susan's
description: Betty Ford caused considerable eyebrowraising last year with her remark that she wouldn't be surprised to discover that her daughter Susan was having an affair.

title: Memorial Services
description: GLICKMANRabbi Jack Stanley, Memorial Day is second day of Rosh Hashanah from 20757951. Brooklyn, N. Y. C

title: BEN C. LIMB IS DEAD
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 21Ben C. Limb, a former South Korean Foreign Minister, died of a heart attack in, Seoul this morning. He was 83 years old.

title: Bishop F. Gerald Ensley Dies
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 21 (AP)Bishop F. Gerald Ensley, resident bishop of the West Ohio area of the United Methodist Church, died today in Dublin. lie was 69 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: President William R. Tolbert Jr. of Liberia was welcomed at the White House yesterday by President Ford and nodded in agreement as the President said Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's African mission must succeed in order to prevent increased violence and bloodshed.

title: Terror in Washington
description: Some ten days ago, the Government of Chile revoked the citizenship of Orlando Letelier, who had been Ambassador to the United States and had held three Cabinet posts during the late President Salvador Allende's Popular Unity coalition. The decree charged that Mr. Letelier, who had moved to Washington last year, was interfering with normal financial support to Chile.

title: House Passes Measure To End OutofState Bets
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI)The House voted today to outlaw betting on horse races taking place outside the state in which the bet was made. The measure would effectively end all offtrack betting on outofstate races by 1982.

title: Preston Jones's Texas Trilogy Opens With Portrait of a Loser
Psst! Want a Saint Laurent (Well, Almost) Cheap?
description: Step right up folks. Get them while they're hot. The latest Saint Laurent copies, direct from Paris. Complete down to the last pair of high heel boots. See the challis shawl, just the way it was shown in the haute couture salons in France. See the fur hat. Step right up.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: AUTO TALKS MAKING ALMOST NO HEADWAY
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 21 The nationwide strike against the Ford Motor Company by more than 165,000 of its workers headed into its second week tonight, and despite a lengthy session at the main table between company negotiators and representatives of the United Automobile Workers, no measurable progress was made toward resolving the key issues that could end the walkout.

title: Ash, ExLitton President, Named AddressographMultigraph Chief
description: The beleaguered AddressographMultigraph Corporation yesterday turned to Roy L. Ash, the former president of Litton Industries, and Cabinet member in the Nixon and Ford Administrations, and in a move that surprised Wall Street named him chairman and chief executive officer.

title: G.O.P. in House Assails Carter's Economic Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21Jimmy Carter's national economic proposals drew charges and countercharges from Republican and Democratic leaders in the House of Representatives today, with each side contending that the other was distorting the record.

title: Family Food Prices Off by 1.3%, Biggest Drop in More Than Year
description: The city last week experienced its largest overall price decline in more than a year as the cost of feeding a family of four dropped by 1.3 percent to $71.20, or 93 cents less than the week before.

title: Screen: 2 Poor Documentaries
Queens College Head to Replace Controversial Bennington Chief
FUND CASHINS SEEN A MARKET DETERRENT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21Investors cashing in mutualfund shares continued to exert a drag on the stock market last month, according to data published today by the Investment Company Institute, the industry's principal trade association.

title: The Old Debates, and New Skepticism
description: After watching the televised reruns of the 1960 KennedyNiion debates last week, I intend to look at the CarterFord debates with considerable skepticism, and some reservewith the hope of spotting any lies either candidate may float, and of hearing what the candidates actually say, rather than what I want to hear them say.

title: Patricia Hearst Devout Episcopal Priest Says
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept.,21Patricia Hearst, a Roman Catholic, has become what an Episcopalian describes as a deeply devout communicant of the Protestant Episcopal Church since her arrest and imprisonment a year ago.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Puerto Rico: The Genuine Issue

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: Philadelphia has the Consumer Education and Protective Association. San Francisco has a group called Consumer Action. Cleveland, has the Consumer Action Movement. And New York City? New York has no citywide, or even boroughwide, consumer group.

title: Helstoski Is Victor Over Baer in Rerun Of Jersey Primary
Curb Sought on City Pension Investments
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21The chairman of a House labor subcommittee said today that he was preparing legislation to place stringent limitations on the ability of a city pension fund to invest in the city it served.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New schedules requiring city police officers to work 10 more days a year will go into effect on Oct. 3, the Police Department announced yesterday. Officials said the changes should improve police patrol coverage.

title: Chrysler Plant Picketing Ends
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 21 (AP)Workers at the Chrysler Corporation plant here returned to work today after the facility was closed for six days in what the company called an illegal secondary boycott. Members of the United Automobile Workers refused to cross picket lines set up by food workers who had lost their jobs when the company switched catering services. The pickets left the plant about 10 P.M. yesterday without mentioning why they were leaving.

title: Soybeans Decline by 5c to 7c
description: A small price rally in soybeans yesterday led to a large amount of selling on the Chicago Board of Trade, and by the end of the session contracts were 5 cents to 7 cents lower than the previous day. November beans closed at $6.43, down from $6.53 a bushel.

title: QUEENS RESIDENTS PROTEST DISTRICTING
description: Residents of Queens turned out in force yesterday to protest proposed new boundaries for police, sanitation and other municipal services as mandated by the revised New York City Charter.

title: Democrats Open a General Store
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21The Democratic National Committee began selling peanuts today to raise money for the party's election campaign.

title: Former Representative Hastings Indicted on Charges of Kickbacks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI)A federal grand jury today indicted former Representative James F. Hastings, Republican of New York, on charges of obtaining kickbacks from his staff to buy automobiles, boats and snowmobiles and to pay his children's college tuition.

title: House Rejects Regulatory Powers, Votes Bill That Would Reduce OTB
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21The House of Representatives, failing to heed an appeal to regulate the regulators, rejected tonight legislation that would have given Congress sweeping veto power over rules and regulations of the Federal departments and agencies.

title: Expos Defeat Mets, 40, On 2Hitter by Warthen
Nine Major Oil Companies Forming Cooperative to Clean Up Spills on New YorkNew Jersey Waterfront
description: LINDEN, N.J., Sept. 21A group of nine major oh companies with refining and marketing facilities on the New YorkNew Jersey waterfront plan to form a mutual aid cooperative that would clean up major oil spills in the harbor.

title: Bick Lost to U.S. Cup Team
description: With its opening game for the World Cup only two days away, the United States squad has encountered several problems. Besides the unavailability of a goalscorer at this point, Sam Sick, one of the key men on defense, will not play against Canada in Vancouver on Friday night because of stretched ligaments in his left ankle, the coach said yesterday.

title: Some Basic Facts About Veal and How Fine It Can Be

The centers are needed for more than 5 million Americans 65 years or older who are not institutionalized but who are limited in the kinds of activities they can undertake, the study said.

title: Bridge
TV Networks' Pique Over Plan for Debates
description: The protests by Richard S. Salant, president of CBS News, against the restrictions on television for the Presidential debates were made in a climate of frustration and defeat for the networks. Some observers believe that if that had not been the case, Mr. Salant's views might have been received more sympathetically by other journalists than they were. Even officials and reporters of the other networks have privately expressed annoyance with Mr. Salant for having angrily walked out of a meeting on the television arrangements last Friday and leaving open the question, over the weekend, of whether CBS would carry the debates.

title: NO LEADS IN BOMBING AT NEW YORK HILTON
description: The police said yesterday that although a Puerto Rican independence group had claimed responsibility for the small, powerful bomb that exploded at the New York Hilton on Tuesday night, they knew almost nothing about the organization and had absolutely no leads on the person or persons who had planted the bomb in a 24thfloor stairwell.

title: DraperRockwell Strike Ends
description: HOPEDALE, Mass., Sept. 22 (AP) Members of the United Steelworkers of America have ended a twoday walkout at the DraperRockwell Corporation by voting to accept a contract that includes a pay cut in the first year. An estimated total of 550 striking workers had vetoed a similar proposal last Sunday. Under the threeyear agreement, the workers will have a pay cut of 9.1 percent the first year. The cut will be restored in a lump sum in October 1977. Under the old agreement employees averaged about $5.751 hourly.

title: Bleak Film Depicts Urban Woman
description: Stockholm has rarely looked so bleak as it does in Stig Bjorkman's "The White Wall," which was shown yesterday at the International Festival of Women's Films. Except for the protagonist, the streets are all but empty and the few people in sight pass like fish swimming 1,000 feet below the surface of a cold sea.This numbness, this uncommunicating despair is intended to be the message and consequence we draw from one day and night in the life of a lonely woman. Instead it is applied beforehand, as it were; it flows into the story rather than flowing from it.Monika, played by Harriet Andersson, is divorced and lives with her son. She is looking for a job and picks up men for company. When the film opens, she sits up in bed, climbs over the stranger sleeping beside her, totters into the next room, takes a pill, looks at a newspaper and sends her son off to school. She is wearing white, the bed coverlet is white, the walls are white; the whiteness is a symbol of isolation and sterility.The man, who has picked her up the night before at one of the dances she regularly goes to for that purpose, comes out to dress. He is perfectly nice, they are both civilized and wry, and they have nothing whatever to say to each other.She teeters through the dayjob-hunting unsuccessfully, buying a skirt, bickering over the telephone with her ex-husband, visiting a friend and going to another dance with her and picking up still one more stranger.Lank, dispirited, numb; she is, or is intended to be, the symbol of the modern urban woman as victim of an impersonal society and of men who are victims too. Men and women are rival gangs: The men gather in knots at the dance hall and plan their attack; the women sit in pairs and mock the attackers. The transactions take place, from sheer need; but they are hostile transactions."White Wall," which will be repeated at the Cinema Studio Theater tonight and tomorrow night, has force but it lacks life. Monica's depression, her inability to give or receive anything, her selfishnessthees are meant to be wounds but in fact they are knives. Our sympathy is never aroused; and our sense of distance from her and the film may be a pity, but it is a fact.

title: The Battle Over Taxes
description: President Richard M. Nixon's, landslide victory over Senator. George McGovern in. 1972 was, beyond a doubt, greatly aided by the Republicans ability to portray the Democratic candidate's proposal of a $1,000 demogrant for all citizens as a radical and extreme costly scheme for shifting income to the poor in a way that would hurt not just the wealthy but also the great American middle class. Now President Ford and Senator Robert J. Dole have been moving to replay the antiMcGovern strategy against Jimmy Carter. They are hitting him as a big spender who would raise taxes on the upper half of the population in order to benefit the lower half. And they are picturing themselves as the champions and protectors of the middle class against Mr. Carter's fiscal designs.

Murphy, the new president of the college. A corrective article appears on Page 16.

title: Bounds of Disclosure
description: At first glance, one is inclined to write off as part of the political silly season such true confessions as Jimmy Carter's unrequited lust and President Ford's announcement that he, unlike his wife, would vigorously, protest if his daughter, Susan, were found to be involved in an affair. On second thought, however, these unnecessary and tasteless selfinflicted violations of personal and family privacy by Presidents or Presidential candidates seem symptoms of a deeper malaise. They suggest that public figures are increasingly reluctant to post no trespassing signs at the legitimate boundaries of their private lives and intimate feelings.

title: Bonds Show a Sharp Drop, Then Recover Partially
description: The credit markets fell sharply early yesterday and then recovered some ground, partially in a response to news that durable goods orders had declined in August. The report was taken as sign that business capital spending might not pick up so much as expectedan economic development that might reduce the demand for borrowed funds and lead the Federal Reserve to adopt a more accommodative monetary policy.

title: OUTLOOK STILL DIM FOR LEBANON PEACE

title: Burke Proposes a System to Rate Every School Teacher in the State

Burke, the State Education Commissioner, proposed today a system to evaluate New Jersey's more than 100,000 public school teachers and administrators, a move that was immediately assailed by teacher groups. Under a bill that Governor Byrne signed into law today, the state's 1.5 million students will be evaluated twice a year under uniform standards to be defined by the State Board of Education. However, there is no formal system to evaluate teachers.

title: Bridge:
description: One of the few European.tournaments at which the casual visitor cane sure of hobnobbing with, the world's great players is the Melia Don Pepe Festival at Marbella in Spain. This year's tournament, to be played Nov. 6 through Nov. 13, will attract Benito Grarozzo, perhaps the world greatest gayer, Omar Sharif, a star in bridge as well as another medium, and a party of American enthusiasts. title: Viking 2 Finds Martian Polar Cap Is Frozen Water

description: The Kennecott Copper Company yesterday said a group of compaines headed by the Newmont Mining Corporation had submitted a revised and substantially improved proposal to buy the Peabody Coal Company, the nation's largest coal producer. Kennecott is required by a Federal Trade Commission order issued in 1971 to dispose of Peabody Coal. The Newmont group includes Newmont itself the Williams Companies and Texasgulf Inc., each with a 25 percent interest, the Fluor Corporation with a 20 percent interest and Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States with a 5 percent interest.

Many renowned pianists do not attempt to play the work in public and the brave ones who do so are ordinarily graying veterans who have wrestled with the sonata for many years before putting it on a program.

title: The Challenger Is a Movie Star
description: GROSSINGER, N.Y., Sept. 22On the marquees, he's a movie star in a title roleKen Norton in Drum. Earlier he was in Mandingo and now he's talking about taking drama lessons from Lee Strasberg at the Actors Studio before my next flick. No more slave movies. His next role might be as a black James Bond or in a Western as a cavalry sergeant. As an actor, Ken Norton is not a heavyweight. But he hopes to be. And that's what disturbs many boxing people about his chances of dethroning Muhammad Ali as the world champion in Yankee Stadium next Tuesday night. He'll be protectin his face, those people say with a smirk. You can't protect your face and be a prizefighter. Ken Norton even acknowledges, when I'm sparring, I protect my face sometimes, but he insists that when the bell rings in Yankee Stadium, he won't be worrying about having his looks rearranged.

title: S.E.C. Fights Grant Rule
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 22 (AP)Southeastern Conference athletic directors unanimously approved today a proposal to fight the controversial National Collegiate Athletic Association rule that limits schools to 95 scholarship football players. The proposal will be given to the S.E.C. Executive Committee, which meets in Birmingham, Ala., Oct. 56. The rule, effective next fall, stipulates that a school may not have more than 95 football players on scholarship, although it is allowed 30 scholarship awards each fall.

title: Carter Will Speak First Tonight But Ford Will Have Last Word
