title: Jets to Keep Namath In All the Way
Decent Is as Decent Does
description: BOSTON, Sept. 22  Some liberals who are uneasy about Jimmy Carter for one reason or another have taken to speaking of President Ford's decency. That overworked word, covering a variety of rationalizations, has taken on a code significance. A California Democrat said: We don't really know Carter. And Ford's not so badhe's decent.

title: At Lord &
description: Lord & Taylor, the first big store to squirt perfume into the Fifth Avenue air, to support American designers and to name a woman (Dorothy Shaver) as its president, opened its 150th anniversary celebration last night with a party on its newly renovated main floor.

title: GOING OUT Guide
Brokers Approve of Companies Listing Stock on 2 Exchanges
description: A rule to enable companies to list their stock on both the New York and American stock exchanges has been approved by brokers, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday. Even before the change, Varo Inc. of Texas became the first dually listed company last month.

title: The Smell of Scandal in Fragrant Oils From Indonesia
description: J. Manheimer Inc., a New York importer, recently received its order from Indonesia of 32 barrels of essential oils, the fragrant raw material used in perfumes and soaps. But when the barrels were opened at the company's warehouse in Long Island City, Queens, they were found to contain muddy tropical water.

title: House Passes Another Bill to End Compliance With Arab Boycott
Cancer Institute Head Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI)President Ford today accepted the resignation of Frank Rauscher of Rockville, Md., as director of the National Cancer Institute, effective Nov. 1. No successor was named. Mr. Rauscher joined the institute in 1959 and was appointed director on May 5, 1972.

title: Gold Drops $2 an Ounce
description: LONDON, Sept. 22 (AP) Profit taking $2 an ounce to $118 in Zurich and $1.75 here to $118.25. It had risen $5 yesterday. The British pound fell to a low against major currencies and dragged the American dollar down with it.

title: F.D.I. Bans Use of Red No. 4 Dye And Carbon Black in Food Items
description: WASHINGTON, Sept.22 (AP)The dyes that make jelly beans black and maraschino cherries red were banned today for use in foods.

title: $100,000 Telephone Fraud Laid To Inmates of Manhattan Prison
description: The New York Telephone Company charged .yesterday that prisoners of the Metropolitan Correctional Center had made more than $100,000 in fraudulent longdistance calls from the Federal detention facility since it opened in August 1975.

title: Moderate Inflation?
description: Consumer prices rose by 0.5 percent in August, or 6 percent at an annual rate, and some observers were apparently quite pleased. For instance, The Wall Street Journal noted in a news story that consumer prices had risen, for the third month in a row, at the relatively moderate rate of 6 percent.

title: Shifts in Insider Stock Positions Listed by Big Board and Amex
description: The New York and American stock exchanges issued their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by leading shareholders, directors and officers of listed companies. The lists include the following:

title: Andrei Amalrik Is Free to Remember
description: FRANKFURTIt was only for a few fleeting moments, and it will not go down in the annals of Soviet intellectual history or of dtente. Yet is was one of those brief human encounters that perhaps says a little about the feelings of a former political prisoner in Siberia who, looking over his shoulder, has a heartthumping experience or dj vu in the West.

title: Two Soviet Astronauts Prepare to Come Back to Earth
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 22 (AP)The two astronauts orbiting the earth in Soyuz 22 were preparing to return to the Soviet Union after a week in space, Tass announced today.

title: Testimony Disputes Accused Physician On Timing of Death
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 22Stephen P. Scaring, the chief of the Nassau County District Attorney's homicide bureau, testified today that it was anatomically impossible for Mrs. Sophie Friedgood to have been alive on the morning of June 18. 1975, when Dr. Charles E. Friedgood contends he spoke to her before leaving for his Brooklyn office.

title: School Buses Themselves Are No. 1 Topic in Richmond, Ind.
description: RICHMOND, Ind., Sept. 15  James Ladd is the father of eight children, three of whom ride buses to school. And on the subject of school buses, one can hear an earful from this man anytime.

title: STRICT CURBS URGED FOR DNA RESEARCH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22Scientists testifying before a Senate subcommittee, said today that strict guidelines for potentially hazardous research on the master chemical DNA should be universally binding.

title: Bangladeshis Give Dutchman 14 Years After Secret Trial
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Sept. 22A 27 yearold Dutch social worker and freelance journalist has been sentenced to 14 years in prison here, after a secret martiallaw trial, on charges of conspiring to overthrow the Government.

title: KELLEY NOTES DROP IN SECURITY CASES
CLOSING IS AVERTED IN COLLEGE'S PLAN
description: NEWARK, Sept. 22Bloomfield College and Seminary filed today a reorganization plan under the Federal bankruptcy laws that will keep the 108yearold institution from closing. Creditors will receiver partial payment.

title: Editor of Village Voice Resigning
description: Thomas B. Morgan resigned yesterday as editor of The Village Voice.. He said he was leaving the weekly newspaper to start a national weekly magazine.

title: Nuclear Haste
description: A number of people in Washington are engaging this morning in one of those periodic demonstrations of how not to govern the country.

title: PETITION ASKS CURB ON COLOR TV IMPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22Five manufacturers and 11 unions filed a petition with the United States International Trade Commission today seeking to curb rapidly growing imports of color television sets, mainly from Japan.

title: DEBATE ON TONIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22When the Presidential campaign began in earnest two weeks ago, Jimmy Carter was considered by most politicians a prohibitive favorite to defeat President Ford. This week, with roughly a quarter of the campaign gone, experts in both parties were calling the race a virtual tossup.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: SeaLaw Impasse: The U.S. Burden

title: Jones, Olympian, Appointed
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 22 (AP)  An Olympian, Johnny Jones, 18.years old, of rampagas, has been appointed to the Governor's Commission on Physical Fitness. Jones, a freshman football player at the University of Texas, was on the 400meter relay team that won the gold medal at Montreal.

title: U.S. Signs Aid Accord With Israel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP)  The United States and Israel signed three agreements today, at a total of $75 million, for American aid to Israeli's industry and agriculture. The agreement consist of a commodity import grant of $35 million, a $15 million cash grant and a $25 million commodity import loan.

title: The U.N. Today
Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: COMMENTS IN AN ARTICLE ATTRIBUTED INCORRECTLY
description: Because of an editing change, an article in The New York Times yesterday reporting the selection of Dr. Joseph S. Murphy as the new president of Bennington College incorrectly attributed to the husband of the former president comments that actually had been made by Dr. Murphy.

title: City Planning Commission Approves the Construction of a Hotel incorporating Landmark Villard House
description: After several months of debate and public controversy, the City Planning Commission voted yesterday to approve construction of a 51story luxury hotel incorporating the landmark Villard Houses behind St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Kodak Changing Name in Chite
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 22 (UPI)Representatives of the Kodak Company in Chile said today that the company would continue to operate in this country but under another name. The official government newspaper published a decree that canceled the authorization of the company to operate under the name Sociedad Kodak Chilena Ltd., registered in Chile in 1944. Company officials said the decree implied a change in the name to Foto Interamericana de Chile and not cancellation of right to operate in this country.

title: Cashier at Y.M.C.A. Wounded by Gunman
description: A cashier at the Sloane House Y.M.C.A. cafeteria was shot and seriously wounded during an apparent holdup last night, the police reported.

title: Market Place
description: Some in Wall Street view this week's bid by International Telephone and Telegraph for Carbon Industries, a major coal producer, as the most recent manifestation of a developing trend whereby major industrial companies are getting control of energy resources while the getting is good.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Carey approved contracts yesterday for New York City and 16 other public entities to start buying electricity from the State Power Authority's Indian Point 3 and Astoria 6 plants. He noted the authority's estimate that when both plants were fully operational the public agencies expected to pay $85 million to $90 million, less than what they now paid for Consolidated Edison Company power. The approval included contracts for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Port Authority, Westchester County and the city governments of New Rochelle, Peekskill and Yonkers.

title: DEBATE ON TONIGHT
Scottish Deerhounds Draw Clan
description: It wilt be Sadie Hawkins Day on Sunday at the New York Institute of Technology. But the women students won't be pursuing the men on the 600 acre campus at Brookville, L.I. There will be a gathering of the clan. for Sadie Hawkins is vice president of the Scottish Deerhound Club of America. The club is supporting the entry. of the Westbury Kennel Association, which is holding its 54th annual event at Tech.

title: House Panel Ends Schorr Inquiry After Rejecting Any Punishment
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22The House ethics committee today rejected three proposals, to punish Daniel Schorr, a CBS News correspondent, and ended its investigation into his unauthorized disclosure of a House intelligence committee report.

title: Not One Day Out in 35 Years
description: Neither rain, sleet, snow, hail, flu, stomachache nor lack of sleep has once in 35 years kept Lieut. Robert Kappes of the New York City Police Department from reporting to work.

title: Renee Powell Survives Pressures To Make Good on Pro Golf Tour
description: CALABASAS, Calif., Sept. 22It's tough to be a good golfer. It's also tough to be Renee Powell, a 30yearold professional golfer. Miss Powell is black. In fact, Miss Powell is the only black among the 140 touring pros of the Ladies Professional Golf Association.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Nonleague Foes to Berough For Ivy Teams on Saturday
description: Now that each of the eight Ivy football teams has a league game under its belt, the ancient group goes out against the world this week playing nonleague games. And it appears to be a hostile world out there. What used to be mere warmups for later important Ivy play now seem to be difficult assignments for at least five of the teams and possibly all eight. Dartmouth plays New Hampshire, the defending Yankee Conference champion and currently ranked fourth in the nation among Division II teams. Harvard plays Massachusetts, another Yankee power, which is ranked eighth in Division II. Joe Restic, Harvard's coach, said, There's no way these teams shouldn't be Division I teams.

title: $300 Million Development Plan Offered For Gateway National Recreation Area
Indonesia Reports a Plot To Overthrow Suharto
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 22 (AP)The Government has foiled a plot to overthrow President Suharto and install former Vice President Mohaad Hatta, one of the leaders of the Indonesian revolution against the Dutch, State Secretary Sudharmano announced today.

title: Market's Rally Halts as Orders Of Durables Fall
description: A strong market rally was stopped dead in its tracks yesterday after the Government reported that durablegoods orders fell in August. Capital equipment stocks sagged as the hardesthit sector.

title: Around the Nation
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 22 (AP)A threat of polio vaccine shortages in many states has apparently been eliminated by a contractural agreement between the vaccine supplier and the Federal agency that distributes the vaccine to most state health departments.

title: Confusion Arises Over Deadline in Plan for Rhodesia
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sept. 22Differing interpretations emerged here today of the understandings reached last weekend by the Rhodesian Prime Minister, Ian D. Smith, and Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger over black majority rule in Rhodesia.

title: Islanders Tie Blues, 22
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 22 (AP)Gary Howatt scored 3 minutes, 3 seconds into the final period to give the New York Islanders a 22 tie with the St. Louis Blues in a National Hockey League exhibition game last night.

title: Ford to Aim at New York, Jersey And 8 Other Key Industrial States
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22President Ford is planning to devote most of his election resources to a concentrated campaign effort in New York, New Jersey and eight other battleground states, his political strategists said today.

title: Another Shot At Never Land For Ellenbogen
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Sept 22A 6foot5inch, 250pound version of Peter Pan returned to the Giants today.

title: $300 Million Development Plan Disclosed for Gateway Park Area
description: The National Park Service yesterday disclosed a broadly based $300 million plan for the development over the next two decades of the 26,000acre Gateway National Recreation Area.

title: Carter's Comments on Sex Cause Concern
description: Jimmy Carter's earthy remarks to Playboy magazine on sexual morality and lust appear to be generating as much comment as anything else in the Presidential campaign so far.

title: Dixy Lee Ray Leads in Washington Governor Race
description: SEATTLE. Sept. 22 (AP)Dixy Lee Ray, former Atomic Energy Commission chairman, held a narrow lead today over Seattle Mayor Wes Uhlman in the race for the Democratic nomination for Governor of Washington State.

title: Disaster Area Is Declared
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (Reuters) President Ford declared California a major disaster area today after severe storms and flooding in the southern part of the state from tropical storm Kathleen two weeks ago. The President's action allows the use of Federal funds for relief and recovery efforts.

title: THE BLACK FAMILY RECONSIDERED: II
At Lord &
description: Lord & Taylor, the first big store to squirt perfume into the Fifth Avenue air, to support American designers and to name a woman (Dorothy Shaver) as its president, opened its 150th anniversary celebration last night with a party on its newly renovated main floor.

title: Notes on People
description: Moving his colleagues to tears, Senator John O. Pastore fought back tears himself yesterday at his formal farewell to the Senate after 26 years. The 69yearold Rhode Island Democrat, son of an immigrant tailor, was the first ItalianAmerican ever elected to the Senate or as Governor of his state.

title: G.O.P. FUND DRIVE FOR ASSEMBLY LAGS
Corporation Affairs
description: Special to The New York Times

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 23, 1976

title: Waiting for Ian Smith
description: Is it conceivable that Secretary of State Kissinger has persuaded Prime Minister Ian Smith that the game is up in Rhodesia; and that the white minority regime in Salisbury is about to accept the principle of black rule within two years?

title: City Found Losing In Toll Collections On Staten I. Ferry
description: The city has been losing as much as $60,000 a year in vehicle toll collections (some of it possibly stolen) on the Staten Island Ferry, a joint study the Investigaton Department and the Marine and Navigation Department showed yesterday.

title: Cunningham Is Fined For Speeding on L.I.
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Sept 22Patrick J. Cunningham, the Bronx Democratic leader and former state Democratic chairman, pleaded guilty today to a reduced charge of speeding and was fined $100 in First District Court.

title: Disease That Killed 29 Is Believed New To Medicine in U.S.
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 22After review of Federal research on a mysterious disease that struck an American Legion convention in Philadelphia, the Pennsylvania health secretary believes the malady is probably new to modern medicine.

title: Report of a Split Over Yugoslavia Denied by Envoy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22The State Department and Ambassador Laurence H. Silberman have issued denials of an article in The New York Times reporting that the envoy to Yugoslavia had provoked the reassignment of a Foreign Service officer and other problems for his superiors.

title: People and Business
Man Surrenders in Slaying
description: CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 22 (UPI)A Philadelphia man surrendered to Camden authorities today to face a murder charge. The man, Weldon Covington, 31 years old, had been sought since Saturday in the shooting of Miguel Cruz, 21, of Camden. The authorities said Mr. Cruz had been shot on a street in an argument over a woman.

title: Christie Furs: Colors, Trim and Combinations
Excerpts From Report
description: LONDON, Sept. 22Following are excerpts from a report by the Royal Commission on Nuclear Energy dealing with nuclear energy, as made public by the Government today:

title: Bronx Democratic Organization, Led by Cunningham, Has Setback
description: The Bronx Democratic organization, led by Patrick J. Cunningham, suffered a major political setback yesterday when two candidates it backed for nominations for the State Supreme Court were defeated by the antiorganization New Democratic Coalition at the party's judicial convention for the First District (Manhattan and the Bronx.)

title: French Plan a Brief Price Freeze And Rise in Wide Range of Taxes
description: PARIS, Sept. 22Prime Minister Raymond Barre today announced a temporary freeze on prices as well as an increase in taxes on personal and corporate income, cars, gasoline and alcohol. The two moves were part of an antiinflation program submitted to the French Parliament.

title: Bill for Setting Up a Federal Bank For Consumer Coops Abandoned
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22  Another piece of banking legislation that at one point had been expected to sail through Congress died today when the House Banking Committee decided not to press a bill to set up a $1 billion Federal bank to finance consumer cooperatives.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Pretrial Hearings Postponed to Oct. 27 In Mass Kidnapping
description: MADERA, Calif., Sept. 22Pretrial pleas and motions were postponed today in the Chowchilla kidnapping case in which three San Francisco area men are charged with the July 15 kidnapping of 26 young children and their school bus driver 19 miles northwest of here.

title: Mad Dog Aspires to Be More Than Just a Gory Film
NixonKennedy Great Debate Gave a Contrast in Appearance
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22On Sept. 26, 1960, Richard M. Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy met in a stark CBS television studio in Chicago for history's first nationally televisied debate between Presidential candidates.

title: Nujoma Welcomes a Meeting
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Sept. 22Governor Byrne will nominate tomorrow the Assembly majority leader, George H. Barbour, Democrat of Maple Shade, to fill the longstanding vacancy on the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners.

title: Foes of Amusement Park On S.I. Fail in Bid to Get Views Before a Hearing
description: Demonstrators protesting a proposal for an amusement park on Staten Island sought unsuccessfully yesterday to present their case at a public hearing on new communitydistrict boundaries in the borough, but their presence kept Mayor Beame from presiding at the hearing, as he had planned.

title: 8 Consumer Groups Charge Ford With Endangering Public Safety
FAIR GROWTH IS CITED FOR POORER LANDS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The world's less developed countries managed to maintain a reasonably high rate of economic growth during the global recession of 197475, the World Bank reported today.

title: LEONARD WARE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22Leonard Ware, former newspaperman, Foreign Service officer and veteran of two world wars, died on Sunday at Mary Hitchcock Hospital in Hanover, N. H. He was 76 years old.

title: King Unveils Fight Plan a Tournament
description: Do you remember Sugar Ray Robonsin against Jake LaMotta? Beau Jack against like Williams? Tony Zale against Marcel Cerdan?

title: Matron to Mrs. Warren
description: Mrs. Warren drew out in the stretch and beat Negotiator by 6 lengths in the $85,270 Matron Stakes for 2yearold fillies at Belmont Park yesterday. Eddie Maple, who rode Mrs. Warren, brought home his fourth winner of the day in the Matron. Mrs. Warren, the daughter of Hail to Reason, took the lead at the head of the stretch and steadily widened her margin in running the seven furlongs in 1:24 3/5. Negotiator, the longest shot in the field of seven at 291, finished second, 3 lengths ahead of Resolver.

title: Diane Ladd Savors Top of World
description: In Lu Ann Hampton Laverty Oberlander, first of A Texas Trilogy to be presented at the Broadhurst Theater, Lu Ann, played by Diane Ladd, tells her mother of a dream she had about a castle in Europe.

title: British Commission Urges a Delay In Widening Use of Nuclear Energy
description: LONDON, Sept. 22A British royal commission on environmental pollution urged today that further expansion of nuclear energy in Britain be postponed as long as possible.

title: Rhodesians Are Taking Diplomatic Activity Calmly
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 22As the diplomats move toward a possible acceptance by Rhodesia's whites of a negotiated peace settlement, there is a striking absence here of either anxiety or enthusiasm.

title: Bishops Offer Alternative to Conditional Ordination
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 22By a voice vote that sounded unanimous, the House of Bishops of the Episcopal Convention today reversed itself and offered an alternative to conditional ordination for the 15 women irregularly ordained to the priesthood,

title: Schorr's Job Status Uncertain Despite Gain Over Ethics Panel
description: Although the House ethics committee dropped its case yesterday against Daniel Schorr, the CBS News correspondent's status with the network remained uncertain.

title: Protesters Block Talk by Humphrey
description: A dozen demonstrators who said they were from a group called Save Our Israel prevented a speech in the American Hotel last night by Senator Hubert H. Humphrey at a Citizens for Carter/Mondale Committee rally aimed at Jewish voters.

title: At Least Two New York Municipal Hospitals Faced With Closing
description: Faced with a budget deficit of $21 million to $23 million, the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation may be forced to close two or more major municipal hospitals unless it receives additional aid from the state and the Federal Government, according to the corporation's president, Dr. John L. S. Holloman.

title: Jerseyan Guilty in Fatal Beating
description: NEWARK Sept. 22 (AP)A 19yearold defendant Joseph Fluker of Newark, was convicted yesterday in the karatekick slaying of his 82yearold neighbor. The young man was found guilty of firstdegree murder in the beating death last April of John Flath, and he was sentenced to life imprisonment bY Essex County Court Judge F. Michael Caruso. The defendant also was convicted of assault and battery on Mr. Flath's 61yearold commonlaw wife, Esther Irizarry, and of robbing the couple.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: The Standings
description: Thursday, September 23, 1976

title: Straub, on 71 for 144, Gains Lead By a Shot in Metropolitan P.G.A.
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept.. 22 Austin Straub, an alumnus of New York City publicschool athletics, took the lead today in the second round of the goldenanniversary championship of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association.

title: BISHOP ON TRIAL NOTES MORAL ISSUE IN RHODESIA
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 22The Roman Catholc of Umtali, on trial on charges of having failed to report the presence oof nationalist guerrillas, said today that missionaries faced a deep moral problem in deciding whether to act as informers.

title: Britain Averts a Maritime Strike, But Inflation Fight May Be Costly
description: LONDON, Sept 22Britain has averted a serious threat to its yearlong effort to reduce inflation through severe wage restraint. But the victory may still prove to be a costly one, politically as well as economically.

title: Channel 13 and Cavett Discuss Nightly Culture Show
description: WNET/13 Is negotiating with Dick Cavett, the former latenight talkshow host for ABC, for a nightly program with an accent on cultural affairs that would be produced for the Public Broadcasting Service. Since the cancellation of his program by ABC two years ago, Mr. Cavett has done occasional specials for NBC, CBS and PBS.

title: A First for Walnut Street Theater
DR. MORRIS GOLDSMITH
description: Dr. Morris Goldsmith, who retired in 1973 after 20 years on the staff of the department of anesthesiology at the Long Island JewishHillside Medical Center, New Hyde Park, L. I., died of heart attack Monday in Clearwater, Fla., where he lived. He was 66 years old.

title: Coast Bus Drivers in Accord
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 (UPI)Striking bus drivers have agreed to a contract but say they will not return to work until mechanics also negotiate a new contract with the Rapid Transit District. More than 760,000 riders in Los Angeles, Orange, San Bernardino and Riverside Counties have been without bus transportation since the drivers and mechanics walked off their jobs 31 days ago.

title: Slapstick
description: In his last novel, "Breakfast of Champions," Kurt Vonnegut not only bade farewell to all the literary characters who had served him over the years (Kilgore Trout, Eliot Rosewater, and others), he also happened to give up storytelling altogether. Well, of course one didn't believe him; he was just walking his despair around the block. But in his eighth and latest novel, "Slapstick, Or Lonesome No More," it looks as if Mr. Vonnegut was serious about renouncing fiction. The book begins with a Prologue, the first sentence of which announces, "This is the closest I will ever come to writing an autobiography," and the remaining pages of which give news of Mr. Vonnegut's background and family; and explain how he came to daydream the fantasy that follows.

title: Brooklyn Residents Decry Plans For MunicipalService Districting
description: Undercurrents of racial, religious and class politics were seldom far from the surface yesterday at a public hearing on proposed communityservice district lines in Brooklyn.

title: Miller Shoots Record 63, With HoleinOne
description: NAPA, Calif., Sept. 23 (AP)With his parents looking on from the front lawn of his home, Johnny Miller scored a holeinone and went on to a courserecord, nineunderpar 63 and the firstround lead in the $175,000 Kaiser International open golf tournament today.

title: Donald H. Bryan, 48, Dies
description: Donald H. Bryan, vice president of the Mobay Chemical Corporation and general manager of its polyurethane division, both in Pittsburgh, died Tuesday at his home in Sewickley, Pa. He was 48 years old.

title: Parents/Children
description: When affluent working parents set out to find someone to care for their children, often they're looking for somebody at least as wonderful as Mary Poppins.

title: Team Has Losing Streak To Thievery
description: While such famous graduates of George Washington High School as Henry Kissinger and Rod Carew pursue such goals as peace treaties and American League batting titles, Sam Rutherford (Class of 77) has a simpler aim: He Would like to have enough equipment to finish this football season. Last weekend the locker room at the upper Manhattan school was broken into andfor the second straight yearthe football equipment was carted away.

title: Bertie G. Schwartz Is Dead at 74
description: Bertie G. Schwartz, a writer and authority on books dealing with Jewish culture and institutions who had a long association with Jewish philanthropies in New York, died Wednesday at Columbus Hospital of a heart attack. She was 75 years old and lived at 146 Central Park West.

title: OffDuty New York Police to Begin Picketing Today
description: In a protest over new work schedules and deferred raises, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday ordered 18,000 police officers to begin offduty picketing today at New York City's 73 station houses.

title: It's Now or Never for Fall Bulbs
description: The flowers of spring are already formed inside the stored food tissue of bulbs. But unless the gardener earnestly begins to set his bulbs into the ground this weekend or soon after, he may never realize the fragrant promise of hyacinths, daffodils and tulips next March, April or May.

title: Willson H. Coates, a Professor At U. of Rochester, Is Dead at 77
description: Wilson H. Coates, professor emeritus of history at the University of Rochester, died yesterday at Genesee Hospital in that city. He was 77 years old.

title: Management
description: Some companies are trying to buy their shares back from small stockholders in order to save money. Page D2.

title: Dances for Folks Of All Kinds
description: Folk dancing, true to its small town, informal character, is not a highly publicized part of weekend city life. But once found and enjoyed, folk dancing seems to breed a race of dogged devotees with a common language and an internationalism they like to say rivals. the United Nations. And it costs very little to participate.

title: Article 7  No Title
Eugene Schmidt Jr. Dies
description: Eugene A. Schmidt Jr., who retired in 1969 as senior vice president and treasurer of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company died Tuesday in his home, 55 Grosvenor Road, Short Hills, N.J. He was 72 years old.

title: 8 Workmen Killed in Blaze Aboard Britain's Newest Missile Destroyer
description: NEWCASTLE  UPON TYNE, England, Sept. 23 (UPI)A fire aboard Britain's newest guided missile destroyer, the Glasgow, killed at least eight men and injured four today.

title: U.S. Ready to Back Proposal to Extend Jersey PATH Line
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23Secretary of Transportation William T. Coleman Jr, announced today conditional approval of a proposal for extension of the PATH transit line as part of a $400 million Federal commitment to three major rail projects in North Jersey over the next forty years.

title: FUND RULE TIGHTENED BY ELECTION PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23The Federal Election Commission moved today to halt a campaign practice for which Jimmy Carter has been criticized and decided to investigate the legality of another Carter plan for raising funds during the Primaries.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 24, 1976

title: Responding to the Call of the Firehouse
description: The firehouse at 104 Duane Street looks like most others in New York City, but the first thing that strikes the eye is an old open car, painted bright red, bearing a sign that identifies it as a 1920 Ford, a deputy chiefs car.

title: U.S. Steel Plans Outlay in Spain Of $225 Million
description: MADRID, Sept 23The United States Steel Corporation is contemplating a $225 million investment in Spain in what Edgar Speer, chairman ofthe board, termed a vote of confidence in the Spanish political and economic future.

title: Screen: A Perilous Country
description: LIVING in a city devastated by war can be as pernicious for the survivors as war was for the victims. The daily, weekly, monthly, yearly contact with civilization's debris changes expectations, dulls some senses and sharpens others. The smells are particularrot and kerosene and, eventually, newly poured concrete. In a place where nothing comes easily, nothing is freely given. Citizens may be seen in groups. They live together as before, but each is a clandestine??

title: A OneAct Comedy
description: GROSSINGER, N.Y., Sept. 23A oneact comedy called The Physical enjoyed a brief but hilarious run here today in The Playhouse at Grossinger's Hotel. It drew rave notices.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: Friday

title: Inauguration of Sarkis Is a Gain for the Objectives of Syria in Mideast
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 23After nearly four months of military occupation in more than half of Lebanon, Syria appears to be achieving some of the goals of the intervention. But many of Syria's objectives in Lebanon still pose serious problems for the rule of President Hafez alAssad.

title: LightsCameraCandidates!
description: The 1976 Presidential debates resemble the LincolnDouglas debates, to which they are inevitably compared, as much as a town meeting resembleswell, a television spectacular. In 1858, the debaters, equipped only with their wits and vocal cords, reached audiences of up to 20,000, including lusty hecklers, as they spent hours rebutting each other. In 1976, the debaters setting from which they were seen and heard last night by an estimated 90 million Americans was to the original Illinois version what a supersonic jet is to the Wright Brothers first flying machinethough the jet developed engine trouble that put the debate into a holding pattern for almost half an hour.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS, MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900:, WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300: NASSAU CO. (516) 7410500; SUFFOLK, CO.
