title: Asian Bank Admits Vietnam
description: MANILA, Sept. 23 (UPI)The Asian Development Bank announced today that Vietnam had been accepted as a member of the bank in place of South Vietnam. The newly unified Vietnam will assume the old Saigon Government's capital stockholding of 3,000 shares and its loan obligations.

title: 2 Raiders and 2 Steelers Draw Fines
description: Two of the Oakland Raiders hardhitting defensive backs, George Atkinson and Jack Tatum, have been fined by Commissioner Pete Rozelle for overzealous play against the Pittsburgh Steelers in the opening game of the National Football League season Sept. 12.

title: House Rejects Guaranteed Loans For Synthetic Fuel Development
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23The House today rejected by one vote a bill that would have given. $3.5 billion in Federal loan guarantees to developers of synthetic fuels over the next nine years.

title: Article 5  No Title
Yonkers Racing
description: RESULTS

title: Management
description: Communicating with stockholders can be expensive, especially for small companies. As a result, at least three companies recently have made offers to buy out their small stockholders, thereby reducing their shareowner list.

title: Restaurants
description: Mimi Sheraton

title: Official Swedish Vote Gives the Victors 180
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 23 (Reuters)Official results from the Swedish general election, released today, give the victorious nonSocialist bloc 180 seats in the new Parliament, with 169 for the outgoing Social Democrats and the Communists, their unofficial legislative partners.

title: About Real Estate
description: The cloud of incomplete apartment buildings seemingly abandoned in midconstruction has begun to lift in Manhattan.

title: Lost and Found: $25,000 Cash
description: James Thompson was making a delivery of hardware supplies yesterday morning to 937 Broadway in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, when he spotted a canvas bag on the sidewalk in front of the building.

title: 9 NAMED TO REVIEW PANEL ON THE CONDUCT OF JUDGES
description: Nine people were appointed yesterday to the State Commission on Judicial Conduct, the new agency to investigate complaints against judges.

title: CATHOLIC BISHOP IN BRAZIL IS KIDNAPPED AND BEATEN
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 23 (AP)A Roman Catholic Bishop was kidnapped, beaten and then released by persons believed to be members of an antiCommunist group, a church statement said today.

title: New York's Accumulated Deficit In Budget Found Nearly Doubled
description: The new, stringently conservative accounting standards applied to New York City's financial records show that the city's accumulated budget deficit is $5 billionalmost twice the $2.6 billion figure arrived at by fiscal experts last year.

title: Alfred Aman Jr., Lawyer, Weds Carol Greenhouse
description: Carol Jane Greenhouse, a research analyst at the Bureau of Social Science Research in Washington, was married last evening to Alfred C. Aman Jr., an associate in the Washington office of the Atlanta law firm of Sutherland, Asbill & Brennan.

title: Peru Will Pay $37 Million For Nationalizing Marcona
description: LIMA, Peru, Sept. 23United States and Peruvian Government negotiators reached agreement today on compensation payment for the nationalization of a major American mining company.

title: Article 6  No Title
Coming: Light at End Of the 63d St. Tunnel
description: Twelve stories under East 63rd Street they're having one dandy of a dig. It's an eerie setting in this noisy netherworld:

title: Front Page 1  No Title
U.S. Flu Program Run By Doctor Who Sprints
description: WASHINGTON  On most Monday and Wednesday nights, Dr. W. Delano Meriwether leaves his seventh floor office at 200 Independence Avenue at about 7:30, drives his 1968 Ford to a neighborhood high school athletic field and changes from a suit to a sweatsuit while still in his parked car.

title: Companies Report Their Earnings
Article 2  No Title
South Korea, With Stress on Middle East, Is Becoming Important Builder Overseas
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea, with its eye on vital foreign exchange earnings, is fast becoming one of the world's major overseas builders.

title: In Memoriam
description: KAYClara Blum. Seat. 24 1970. Six years since you left us have not dimmed the memory of a wonderful wife, a devoted mother and an adored Gradmother. Your husband, your son and your three grandchildren cherish Your memory.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Allied Chemical Sentencing Put Off
description: RICHMOND, Sept. 23 (UPI)Sentencing in the case of the Allied Chemical Corporation on charges relating to the contamination of Virginia waters with the pesticide Pepone has been postponed until Oct. 5. The chemical company, which was to have been sentenced Monday, faces up to $13 million in fines for 940 counts of violating Federal water pollution laws.

title: Stage: The Last Of Texas Trilogy
description: PRESTON JONES'S A Texas Trilogy reached its third and final part at the Broadhurst Theater last night with The Oldest Living Graduate. This, and the other two plays, The Last Meeting of the Knights of the White Magnolia and Lu Ann Hampton Laverty Oberlander, are to continue in repertory.

title: Article 3  No Title
Traces of PCB's in Mothers' Milk In U.S. Prompts Call for Study
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23Traces of the toxic industrial chemicals called PCB's have been found in 78 samples of American mothers milk, but the significance of this is not known, scientists said today.

title: Kallinger Attorney Calls Client Crazy At Time of Slaying
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 23Joseph Kallinger's attorney said today in his opening statement today that his client was totally crazy and that psychiatrists would testify that he did not know right from wrong on Jan. 8, 1975, when, according to the charge in the case, he killed Maria Fasching, a 21yearold nurse, in Leonia, N.J..

title: Broadway
description: A MUSICAL called Two of Everything will come quietly into the Marymount Manhattan Theater on Oct. 14, stay there for ten days, and then, if all things work properly, move on to somewhere else. It will be a little like a tryout in New Haven, and the interesting thing about it is the people who are involved. There is, for example, the author, Andrew Rosenthal, who is also the composer, lyricist and director. In 1940, Mr. Rosenthal wrote The Burning Deck for Broadway. Then he wrote three more plays for Broadway, the most recent of which, Third Person, was done in 1955. None of the plays were a great success. Subsequently, Mr. Rosenthal spent most of his time in London.

title: The Standings
description: Friday, September 24, 1976

title: Lineup at Princeton Opener Will Include Some OldTimers
description: PRINCETON, Sept. 23  Dominick German will be at the Princeton football team's home opener here Saturday against Rutgers. Dominick Germani, who will be 86 years old next month, says he has been at every Princeton home football game since the first one played at Palmer Stadium on Oct. 25, 1914.

title: East Germany's Economy Is Facing a Grain Drain
description: WEST BERLIN, Sept. 17At the Leipzig industrial fair early this month, Erich Honecker, East Germany's Communist Party leader, entered the booth of a West German shoe manufacturer and, in full view of television cameras, ordered one million pairs of shoes for cash.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was erroneously reported in The Times Sept. 18 that a grand jury said in 1972 that the ultimate responsibility for an irregular method of paying some provisional city employees lay with two mayoral aides, Richard R. Aurelio and Sid Davidoff. Actually, the jury's presentment said that while the two aides had approved salary commitments not covered by the regular budge et, there was testimony that they had no knowledge of unauthorized use of office cash to pay the employees.

title: Dow Declines by 3.25 to 1,010.80
description: The decline in new orders for factory and industrial equipment continued to weigh upon the stock market yesterday and sent prices lower across a broad front..

title: The U.N. Today
description: Sept. 24, 1976 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: Memorial Services
description: GLICKMANRabbi Jack Stanley, Memodal Day Is second day of Rosh Hashanah from 207579st. Brooklyn, N. Y. C.

title: U.S. Ready to Back Extension of PATH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23Secretary of Transportation William T, Coleman Jr. announced today conditional approval of a proposal for extension of the PATH transit line as part of a $400 million Federal commitment to three major rail projects in North Jersey over the next four years.

title: Art:
description: IT IS A GOOD SEASON in the galleries that begins with a show that would be worthy of one room in a major museum. Shows of this sort have a point to make, don't go on too long and touch in a worthwhile way on the nerve of the times.

title: Major League Scores
Mrs. Johnson Says She Was Perplexed By Carter Remarks
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 23 (AP) Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson said today that she was distressed, hurt and perplexed by Jimmy Carter's remarks about her late husband in a magazine interview. Mr. Carter has apologized for his comments about the former President.

title: Market Place
description: Investors in companies that own hospitals were recently disappointed when Congress decided not to sweeten a tax measure under which hospitals are built with the proceeds of taxexempt bonds.

title: The Pop Life
description: ROCK AND DISCO are supposed to be at the center of the popmusic scene these days. But now Andy Pratt and David Forman have arrived to prove that the supposedly dying genre of introspective singersongwriter isn't finished yet, and that Los Angeles hardly has a monopoly of those that do exist.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: MORE TELEVISION ADVERTISING ON PRECEDING PAGE

title: A.T.&T. ORDERED TO FILE SOME NEW RATE CHARTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)  The American Telephone and Telegraph Company was ordered by the Government today to file within eight months new rate schedules for some of its specialized services.

title: Ford's 17% Gain Paces Auto Sales In MidSeptember Despite Strike
description: DETROIT, Sept. 23The Ford Motor Company paced the auto industry with a 17 percent sales gain in the Sept. 1120 period despite the United Auto Workers strike against it. The industry overall reported midSeptember sales up 7.9 percent from last year.

title: Csonka: Knew It Wouldn't Be A Bed of Roses
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y. Sept. 23Larry Csonka, admitting he has been acting like a turtle, came out of his shell today and said:

title: Finns Offer Bicentennial Musical Gift
description: Twenty years ago. Jean Sibelius was a towering figure whose works were performed with great frequency all over the world. In recent years his reputation has declined somewhat, but now the Finnish Government seems determined to revive the stature of its nation's greatest composer.

title: U.S. Flu Program Run By Doctor Who Sprints
description: WASHINGTON  On most Monday and Wednesday nights, Dr. W. Delano Meriwether leaves his seventh floor office at 200 Independence Avenue at about 7:30, drives his 1968 Ford to a neighborhood high school athletic field and changes from a suit to a sweatsuit while still in his parked car.

title: Italian Financial Aide Among Dead In Crash of the Turkish Airliner
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 23Count Astorre OddiBaglioni, managing director of Istituto Mobiliare Italiano in Rome, a governmental credit institution, and his wife were among the passengers killed in Turkish Airlines plane that crashed on Sunday.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: NO single street can fully encapsulate Manhattan. But 57th Street comes as close as any to providing a range of different visual experiences that, taken together, offer startling insight into the way New York is put together. Here commerce and residence, art and shopping, concert halls and schools all join in linear procession across the width of the island.

title: Film: A Trip Along the Opium Trail
description: The Golden Triangle is a 52minute, nononsense, French made documentary arguing persuasively that the opium trade that produces 80 percent of the heroin from Southeast Asia is not a police problem, but a political problem.

title: City Admits ParkingTicket Agents Are Told to Meet Daily Minimums
description: A spokesman for the New York City's Department of Traffic said yesterday that parkingenforcement agents who did not issue a specific minimum number of tickets each day faced the possibility of fines.

title: Rebozo and Abplanalp Lose Plea For Key Biscayne Zoning Shift
description: MIAMI, Sept. 23 (UPI)A group of businessmen led by. Charles G. Rebozo and Robert Abplanalp, both confidants of former President Richard M. Nixon, have lost a legal battle to liberalize zoning on a portion of Key Biscayne.

title: FourColor Proof
description: Mathematics is central to every aspect of modern civilizationfrom space navigation to the formulation of business strategy in the corporate world. Yet so highly abstract is the nature of most modern mathematical research that only on rare occasions is some major advance achieved whose nature is comprehensible to nonmathematicians.

title: CEMETERIES
description: ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? 4 ?? each, choice location. King . Solomon Memorial Pack, Clifton, N.J. Call Mr. ?? 201846.9131 (wkdys only).

title: Connecticut Senate Race: More Still Life Than Action
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 23 Twentyone original portraits of a politicianwhich is more than most people can ordinarily bear to look at simultaneouslywent up on the walls of a gallery here this week.

title: City Honors Le Gallienne
description: Eva Le Gallienne received the Handel Medallion, the city's highest cultural tribute, in a ceremony last night in the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center.

title: Notes on People
description: In the Henry VII Chapel of Westminster Abbey, J. Carter Brown, director since 1969 of Washington's National Gallery of Art, and Pamela Braga Drexel, formerly of Alpine, N.J., were to be married today. It was a close contest yesterday whether spokesmen for the museum or for the abbey were being more closemouthed but there was confirmation from a more intimate source that such an event would take place within the next 24 hours.

title: 2d Player Demand
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Sept. 23The only doctor in attendance here today as the New York Nets prepared for the opening of their training camp was Dr. Allan Levy, the team physician.

title: People and Business
description: Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon broke with precedent yesterday and awarded the Treasury's highest honor, the Alexander Hamilton award, to Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: TV SHOWING OF MASADA IS PROTESTED BY JEWS
description: The Jewish Community Relations Council of New York protested yesterday the scheduled showing tonight, at 10 P.M. on WORTV, Channel 9, of a film entitled Masada because it allegedly seeks to convert Jews to Christianity.

title: SARKIS INAUGURATED AS LEBANON'S CHIEF
description: CHTAURA, Lebanon, Sept. 23Elias Sarkis, a 52yearold banker, was inaugurated today as the sixth President of Lebanon under the protection of the Syrian Army and some Lebanese soldiers. He called upon all sides to strive for peace in the Lebanese civil war, which began a year and a half ago.

title: DOCTOR TERMS DOLE IN EXCELLENT HEALTH
description: Senator Robert J. Dole, the Republican VicePresidential nominee, is in excellent health with only the residuals of extensive World War II injuries, the attending physician of Congress said on the basis of a physical examination conducted Tuesday.

title: Upstaters' TaxProtest Ordinations May Spur New Law on Exemptions
description: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Sept. 23The actions of hundreds of Catskill Mountain area residents who are becoming ordained ministers to protest vague, undefined taxexemption laws may prod state legislators into Correcting inequities in realproperty tax legislation, according to some state and county officials.

title: A Month of Mahlermania
description: GUSTAV MAHLER has been a lively figure at the center of our orchestral repertory for some 15 years now, thanks largely to the recordings by Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic.

title: Woman Is Found Guilty of Murder In Argument Over Parking Space
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 23 (UPI)A New Jersey hospital technician was convicted yesterday of seconddegree murder in the shooting of a neighbor during an argument over a parking space.

title: U. S IS REASSESSING STRATEGY IN EUROPE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23  Partly as a result of the prodding of Senator Sam Nunn, a relatively junior member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, the Army is reassessing its strategic assumptrons and contingency plans for warfare in central Europe.

title: New York Orders City Schools Study
description: ALBANY, Sept. 23After hearing the New York public school system assailed as a failure, the State Board of Regents today authorized a major study of the system's educational effectiveness, cost and governance.

title: At the Library
description: The New York Public Library at Lincoln Center is open on Friday and Saturday from noon to 6 P.M. It is closed on Sunday. The current exhibitions are:

title: Meadowlands Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Transcript of First Campaign Debate Between Ford and Carter
description: Following is a transcript of last night's debate between President Ford and Jimmy Carter in the Walnut Street Theater in Philadelphia, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News. The moderator was Edwin Newman of NBC News. The questioners were Frank Reynolds of ABC News, Elizabeth Drew of The New Yorker and James P. Gannon of The Wall Street Journal.

title: RECORDING EXECUTIVE IS FINED IN TAX CASE
description: A suspended sentence and a $10,000 fine were imposed yesterday on Clive J. Davis, former president of CBS Records, who pleaded guilty to tax evasion for failing to report $8,800 of income in 1972.

title: Thai Premier Resigns Under Fire, Then Says He Will Resume Post
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 23 (AP)Prior Minister Seni Pramoj, under fire for not taking a tough stand against the return from exile of former Prime Minister Thanom Kittikachorn, announced his resignation today.

title: HayakawaTunney Senate Race a Study in Contrasts
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23As accus tomed as California voters are to exotic choices at the polling place, the United States Senate campaigns this year have given them an unusually rich diet.

title: U.S. Freezes New York Payments In Children's FreeFood Program
description: The United States Department of Agriculture, responding to criticism of the New York State. Education Department's handling of the summer freefood program for needy children, has barred the state from making any further payments to participarrts without permission from the department.

title: Art People
description: IT'S A GREAT leap from the regal subjects of Velasquez, an artist whom Juan Downey has lovingly rejected to the naked (though painted) Guahido Indians on the banks of Venezuela's Orinoco. But, with the aid of a PortaPak video camera. Mr. Downey has made the jump. For the last three years the Chileanborn artist has been videotaping the Guahibos and other isolated Indian tribes of Central and South America, aiming to expand their sense of the greatness of their pastand present. The result is Video Trans America, a complex installation using video and film, on view at the Whitney Museum starting next Thursday.

title: THE BLACK FAMILY RECONSIDERED: III
description: Booker T. Washington described the emancipated AfroAmericans as a simple people . . . freed from slavery and with no past. He was wrong.

title: Sound of Debate Off Air Nearly Half Hour
description: The sound suddenly went out on last night's Presidential debate and for 27 minutes the two men who are running for President of the United States stood in silence, television screens across the nation showing them standing behind their sidebyside electerns.

title: U. S. STEEL REPORTS IT ENTERTAINED FORD
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23The. United States Steel Corporation reported today that it had given President Ford five golfing holidays during his last 10 years in the House of Representatives. The White House declined to comment on the report.

title: New Viking 2 Data Called Marginally Positive, But Scientists Are Still Unsure About Mars Life Tests
description: PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 23The results of another biology experiment on the Viking 2 lander have been radioed to earth, but they left scientists just as uncertain as ever on the question of whether there is life on Mars.

title: CERTIFICATE HELD UP FOR NEW HOSPITAL
description: The New York State Health Commissioner, Dr. Robert P. Whalen. announced yesterday that he had decided to hold up the issuance of an operating certificate for the city's new North Central Bronx Hospital until he had received assurances that its expenses would be met and that its patients would receive quality care. He also expressed doubt that the hospital was needed.

title: Geico's Prospectus Indicates Recovery
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23Estimates of loss reserves and other data disclosed by the financially troubled Government Employees Insurance Company confirmed today the belief of analysts that Geico probably is well down the path to recovery and that, in fact, it may now be earning money.

title: Wheat Futures Rise, but Corn Falls
description: Wheat futures rose while corn futures declined yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: SARKIS INAUGURATED AS LEBANON'S CHIEF
description: CHTAURA, Lebanon, Sept. 23Elias Sarkis, a 52yearold banker, was inaugurated today as the sixth President of Lebanon under the protection of the Syrian Army and some Lebanese soldiers. He called upon all sides to strive for peace in the Lebanese civil war, which began a year and a half ago.

title: Dacca Deports Convicted Dutchman
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Sept. 23The Bangladesh Government, in what it called a gesture of good will, today deported a Dutch social worker and freelance journalist who had been convicted earlier this week of antistate activities.

title: James Warner Bellah, 77, Author Of Novels, Stories and Scenarios
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 (UPI)James Warner Bellah, novelist, shortstory writer and author of western movie scenarios, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 77 years old and lived in nearby Pacific Palisades. Mr. Bellah was stricken while doing research in the chancery office of the Roman Catholic archdiocese of Los Angeles for a speech he was preparing to give.

title: Ford's Nominee to Nuclear Regulatory Commission Is Opposed by 4 Public Issues Groups
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23Representatives of four public issue groups testified today against President Ford's nomination of George F. Murphy, executive director of the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy, to a fiveyear term on the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: ROBBERYSLAYING SITE VISITED BY SAXE JURY
description: BOSTON, Sept. 23 (UPI)Susan Saxe and the jurors who will decide her fate on armed robbery and murder charges took a tour today of the bank she is accused of helping rob six years ago.

title: Edward Call, ExNewspaperman, Led FundRaising Consultants
description: Edward P. Call, a former newspaperman and president since 1973 of Will, Folsom & Smith, fundraising consultants, of 19 West 44th Street in Manhattan, died Wednesday at the White Plains Hospital Medical Center. He was 70 years old and had homes in White Plains and Bay Palm, Fla.

title: Sound of Debate Is Off Air for 27 Minutes
description: PHILADELPHIA, Friday, Sept. 24For the first time in a long time, the candidates stopped talking.

title: MANDEL TRIAL WITNESS DENIES MAKING A DEAL
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 23 (AP)A key prosecution witness acknowledged today that he was under pressure to testify against Gov. Marvin Mandel and four codefendants but insisted that he had made no deal to have prosecutors drop possible criminal charges against him.

title: Three Masters of the Camera
description: THE INTERNATIONAL Center of Photography, which opened a busy program of exhibitions, lectures and workshops only two seasons ago in the elegant old Audubon mansion at the corner of Fifth Avenue and 94th Street, inaugurates its third season today with three exhibitions honoring three venerable figures of 20thcentury photographic historyAndreas Feininger, Karl Struss and Theresa Bonney.

title: DAVID M. LEVITAN
description: David M. Levitan, a jeweler in Manhattan for more than 50 years, died of heart attack in the subway Wednesday. He was 88 years old and lived in Far Rockaway. Queens.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Women Learn to Reach for Success
description: Barbara Preminger, an actress who may currently be seem soaking her hands in Palmolive Dishwashing Liquid on the Madge the Manicurist television commercials, longs to get her feet wet on a Broadway stage.

title: Tumult Marked Life of Author Of the 1549 Book
description: The original Book of Common Prayer was produced in 1549 by Thomas Cranmer, Archbishop of Canterbury, who next to William Shakespeare, is probably the most quoted of English writers.

title: Music: Verdi Requiem With La Scala Soloists
description: THE TEATRO ALLA SCALA could not come to New York and stage opera. But at least it sent emissaries. Last night in Carnegie Hall the Scala Orchestra and Chorus, conducted by Claudio Abbado, with eminent soloists, performed the Verdi Requiem. Presidential debate or no Presidential debate, the hall was sold out.

title: Around the Nation
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Brezhnev Plans Visit to France
description: PARIS, Sept. 23 (Reuters)Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, will come to France soon to meet with President Vaiery Giscard d'Estaing, the Elysee presidential palace said today. Mr. Brezhnev previously announced plans to visit West Germany as well.

title: Judge Rules Statements By Bronfman Defendants Can Be Used at the Trial
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 23A State Supreme Court justice ruled today that statements taken from Dominic P. Byrne and Mel Patrick Lynch, alleged kidnappers of the Seagram heir Samuel Bronfman 2d, might be used by the prosecution in next month's trial.

title: U. S. STEEL REPORTS IT ENTERTAINED FORD
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23The United States Steel Corporation reported today that it had given President Ford five golfing holidays during his last 10 years in the House of Representatives. The White House declined to comment on the report.

title: Transit Authority To Drop Coverage By Social Security
description: The New York City Transit Authority has served notice of its intention to cancel Social Security coverage two years from now for 45,000 subway and bus employees. The action brought an immediate and angry denunciation from the Transport Workers Union.

title: Sandra F. Maidman Married To W. Stewart Cahn, Banker
description: Sandra F. Maidman, manager of tennis court sales and services with Global Sports Inc. in New York, was married last evening to W. Stewart Cahn, a vice president of Chemical Bank. Rabbi Israel Moscowitz performed the ceremony at the Hillcrest Jewish Center in Queens.

title: Dance Unit From Boston Debuts Here
description: Small new dance companies come and go. The dancers may surface again in slightly different combinations, familiar faces and bodies devoted to some new choreographerguru. This weekend dancegoers will have a chance to see the latest of the crop, but Concert Dance Company, which will appear in its New York debut tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3 P.M. at the American Theater Laboratory, may be an ensemble with a difference.

title: President of Miners Union Opens a Convention That He Did Not Want
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 23Arnold R. Miller, the former West Virginia coal miner who was elevated four years ago to the presidency of the United Mine Workers of America, opened here today a miner union convention that he did not want and that may adopt positions he will not like and perhaps cannot survive.

title: THE HARRISES ENTER A NOT GUILTY PLEA
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 23 (AP)William and Emily Harris, the radical couple who joined Patricia Hearst in a crosscountry fugitive flight, pleaded not guilty today to charges that they had kidnapped the young heiress.

title: Roman, a Strong Prospect of Sorts, Given Chance at Tackle by Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, LI., Sept. 23The list reads like a Who's That? of pro football.

title: Advertising
description: The big challenge for General Motors and its ad agencies this year is convincing the American consumer that smaller, lighter fullsized cars are worth more than the old fullsized, or standard. models.

title: Unguarded Moment on House Dais
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23Vice President Rockefeller and Speaker of the House Carl Albert were overheard today in unguarded conversation in the House chamber about Liberians that included a derogatory remark about Senator Edward W. Brooke by Mr. Albert.

title: Business Records BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: KISSINGER HAS TALKS WITH BRITISH LEADER
description: LONDON, Sept. 23Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger concluded a 10day African mission today and flew to London for a late evening strategy session with Prime Minister James Callaghan on how to proceed ifas Mr. Kissinger expectsRhodesia's white leaders accept tomorrow the principle of black majority rule.

title: Poland Preparing for New Policy To Overcome Economic Troubles
description: WARSAWPoland's leaders are preparing some basic economic decisions in the aftermath of the workers riots last June that forced the postponement of decreed prices rises.

title: Erroneous Listing of Death
description: The name of Dr. Lawrence Meyers was erroneously published in the death notices of yesterday's issue of The Times, Dr. Meyers is the president of the methcal staff at St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center in Manhattan.

title: Ragas for A Sunday Morning
description: Each of the ragas or basic melodic forms of Indian classical music is associated with a particular time of day, and according to tradition it is to be performed only at that time. But of all the Indian musicians who have performed widely in the metropolitan area, only one, the vocalist Pandit Pran Nath, has gone against the Western tradition of evening concerts by performing frequently in the morning and afternoon. The morning is Pandit Pran Nath's favorite time, and he is presenting another in his new series of morning raga concerts Sunday at 10 A.M. at Heiner Friedrich Inc., 141 Wooster Street, on the second floor.

title: U.S. Money Supply Soars By a Record $4.5 Billion
description: The nation's basic money supply, in a sudden upsurge that caught Wall Street by surprise, soared by a record $4.5 billion in the latest reporting week, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday.

title: Some Auto Workers Prepared to Stay Out With Private Strike Funds
description: DETROIT, Sept. 23The last time Jim Martin went on strike, it just about ruined him.

title: Rosh haShanah Begins at Sundown
description: Throughout the New York metropolitan area synagogues will hold solemn religious services at sundown today as Jews mark the beginning of the 10day period of Holy Days with the observance of Rosh haShanah, the Jewish New Year 5737.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 23, 1976

title: Dollar in Europe Shows Strength, but Pound, Lira And French Franc Drop
description: LONDON, Sept.23 (AP) The French franc, the Italian lira and the British pound weakened today, but the American dollar strengthened on European foreign exchanges.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON Sept. 23Stanley Van Ness. the State Public Advocate, announced today that his office would represent three New Jersey shore counties in their attempt to force the Federal. Government to impose environmental safeguards on any offshore oildrilling operation.

title: Maoism Without Mao
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 23With the repeated calls by Peking to carry on the cause left behind by Chairman Mao Tsetung, China's new leaders seem to be trying to assure the Chinese people that in all the uncertainty surrounding Mao's death, at least his policies will remain in force for the immediate future. Mao's cause was often challenged during his lifetime. How faithfully his successor or successors, whoever they may prove to be, will now hew to his legacy is a question few of China's 800 million people can answer.

title: U.S. ASSERTS SARKIS RULE CAN BRING LEBANON PEACE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)The State Department said today that the inauguration of Elias Sarkis as President of Lebanon presented an opportunity to end the civil war there and rebuild the country's shattered structure.

title: Jimmy Ryan's, a Shrine To the Same Old Jazz
description: Jimmy Ryan's, the oldest jazz club in New York, is starting its 37th year this month, still offering the same kind of jazz that was being played when it opened at 53 West 52d Street in 1940. The club is now at 154 West 54th Street, where it moved in 1962 to make way for the Columbia Broadcasting System building at the Avenue of the Americas and 52d Street, but the only significant change that has occurred is that an apostrophe has been inserted in the name, which was originally Jimmy Ryans.

title: TELEVISION TODAY
description: TOP WEEKEND FILMS

title: Lottery Chief Asserts Duplication of Tickets Has No Effect on Result
description: Many of the state's new instantlottery tickets, both winning and losing tickets, are duplicates, the lottery's director, John ??. Quinn, said last night. However, he said such duplication had no effect on the game and did not increase the likelihood of ticketcounterfeiting.

title: Short Interest on the Big Board Is Off 138,213 Shares in Month
description: The short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange declined less than 1 percent from Aug. 13 to Sept. 15, the exchange announced this week. The latest total was 22,671,494, down 138,213 shares.

title: Dole Comes Under Fire in Midwest For President's Embargo of Grain
description: TRUMBULL, Neb., Sept. 23More than a score of farmers shuffled about in the morning chill today outside the Harmon grain elevator in this hamlet southeast of Grand Island, alternately questioning and politically scolding Senator Robert J. Dole, the Republican VicePresidential candidate.

title: AMERICANS ARE ACCUSED OF WASTING FUEL ASSETS
description: PARIS, Sept. 23 (AP)The International Energy Agency accused Americans today of wasting valuable energy resources because of cheap fuel prices. It said prices must rise soon if conservation is to be taken seriously.

title: Swedish Socialist Leader Fears a New Kind of Conformity After His Defeat
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 23Prime Minister Olof Palme expressed fear today that the end of Social Democratic government in Sweden would cement the power of businessmen and result in a new kind of conformity.

title: Shipping/Mails
New York Detective Is Acquitted Of a Charge of Murder in Denver
description: DENVER, Sept. 23 (AP)A jury today acquitted a New York City police detective of murder and assault charges but convicted him of murder conspiracy in the ganglandstyle shooting death of a Denver businessman and gambler.

title: Publishing:
description: THE PARIS of the 1920's and the literary generation that sojourned there have acquired an almost legendary aura, like Camelot. And keeping the coals glowing have been the many memoirs of the sojourners, from Malcolm Cowley's classic Exile's Return to the recently published The Very Rich Hours of Adrienne Monnier by Richard McDougall.

title: A Conductor For Year of The Dragon
description: A woman conductor has a hard enough time of it in a field dominated by men but if she happens to be Chinese she has a double problem.

title: Parking Unlimited
description: The accusation that agents of the Parking Violations Bureau often place summonses on legally parked cars to achieve a daily productivity quotaand yesterday the Traffic Department did admit to setting quotasshould surprise any New Yorker who daily observes unticketed violationsand don't we all?

title: ABRAHAM L. LAZARUS
description: Abraham L. Lazarus, who had been a criminal lawyer in New York until his retirement 10 years ago, died Wednesday in St. Francis Hospital in Miami Beach, where he lived. He was 90 years old.

title: Violent Crimes Reported Down, With Serious Crimes 3% Higher
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23The number of violent crimes reported by the nation's police departments dropped somewhat during the first six months of 1976 as against the same period last year, but theft and other crimes against property were up, according to figures compiled by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and released today.

title: SOUTH AFRICA PLANS MULTIRACIAL SPORTS
description: JOHANNESBURG. Sept. 23  South Africa ended decades of segregation in sports today with an official announcement that the Government would sanction multiracial games at all levels and mixed racial teams in international competition.

title: Leis of W.T.T. Moving
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 23 (AP)The Hawaii Leis World Team Tennis franchise will move to the Pacific Northwest next season, Don Kelleher, the Leis majority owner said today. Kelleher said the Leis 1977 schedule of 22 home matches will be divided equally between Seattle and Portland. The team office will be in Seattle.

title: Fossils Support LandLink Theory
description: Fossil bones found on Canada's Arctic Ellesmere Island have led two American scientists to offer them as evidence to confirm the theory that North America and Europe were linked by a land bridge and shared the same animal species until 45 to 48 million years ago.

title: Home Demand: Torrid and Strong In Some Regions, Weak in Others
description: IRVINE, Calif., Sept. 23More than 2,000 families gathered in a parking lot near here Sunday, and a lot of them prayed for luck. Luck blessed 82 of the families: their names were drawn from a steel drum, and this meant they could buy one of 82 new townhouses that were for sale that day.

title: School Taxes in Nassau Up Again, but Increase Is Smaller Than Before
description: MINEOLA, LT., Sept. 23Schooltax rates in Nassau County for this year went up an average of 79 cents for each $100 of assessed valuationabout $58 for an average housethe Nassau County Board of Assessors said today.

title: Rangers Open Preseason By Defeating Bruins, 7 to 5
description: Maybe there really is something to this new look business with the New York Rangers.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN his last novel, Breakfast of Champions, Kurt Vonnegut not only bade farewell to all the literary characters who had served him over the years (Kilgore Trout, Eliot Rosewater, and others), he also threatened to give up storytelling altogether. Well, of course one didn't believe him; he was just walking his despair around the block. But in his eighth and latest novel, Slapstick, Or Lonesome No More, it looks as if Mr. Vonnegut was serious about renouncing fiction. The book begins with a Prologue, the first sentence of which announces, This is the closest I will ever come to writing an autobiography, and the remaining pages of which give news of Mr. Vonnegut's background and family, and explain how he came to daydream the fantasy that follows.

title: U.S. Freezes New York Payments In Children's FreeFood Program
description: The United States Department of Agriculture, responding to criticism of the New York State Education Department's handling of the summer freefood program for needy children, has barred the state from making any further payments to participants without permission from the department.

title: Commodity Price Index Declines 5.3 From Last Week's Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials declined to 200.2 from 205.5 last week.

title: Record Rise in U.S. Money Supply Causes Sharp Drop in Bond Prices
description: This week's record $4.5 billion rise in the nation's basic money supply, considerably larger than most bond traders expected, caused bond prices to drop sharply late yesterday afternoon. Prices had declined moderately in the morningand early atternoon on expectations of a goodsized increase in money, but the fixedincome market was not prepared for a $4.5 billion increase. Altogether, bond prices dropped from half a point to more than a full pointa substantial move for the credit markets. The actively traded 8 percent Treasury notes that mature in 1986, for example, declined from 103 just prior to the Federal Reserve's money supply report at 4 P.M. to 102 at 5 P.M.

title: Californian Named to U.S.O. Board
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)Alden G. Barber of Menlo Park, Calif., was lamed by President Ford today to be a member of the board of governors of the United Service Organization. Named as members of the voluntary civilian corporation were Daniel M. Galbreath, a Columbus, Ohio, businessman; Paula Unruh, chairman of the Oklahoma Republican Party; Cary Grant, the actor, and Bernard Ziegler, a West Bend, Wis., businessman.

title: Knicks Open Camp
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Sept. 23 Neal Walk still prefers an avocado to a steak, he is still the Knicks bearded vegetarian, but that's where the old Walk and his old let it be philosophy appear to end.

title: Slicing the Big Apple
description: Mayor Beame's proposals for dividing New York into 52 new community districts in accordance with charter changes adopted last November have, predictably, generated some vigorous protests at hearings in the five boroughs this week.

title: Debate Turns Manhattan Into a Ghost Town
description: All over town last night, eerie blue glares could be seen in the windows of apartment buildings, brownstones and bars  a good indication that New Yorkers were watching the CarterFord debate. Or, if not that, the YankeesOrioles baseball game.

title: Where to Do a Czardas
description: Following is a list of some longrange folkdance programs. Columbia University Folk Dance, Earl Hall, Broadway at West 117th Street: International folk dance Sunday evenings 712. $1 a session, 75 cents for students with Columbia identification cards. Telephone 2805113.

title: Britain Sets Support Operation To Help Burmah Oil Pay Debts
description: LONDON, Sept 23, (Reuters) The British Government today initiated a new support operation to help the Burmah Oil Company pay off dollar loans.

title: Music:
description: A pianist who could play Mozart and Schumann with equal conviction and stylistic authority would be something of a freak, a Jekyll and Hyde personality to be approached with caution. And yet there is this split within every artist, a split that Nietszchc recognized when he named the two dialectically opposed personalities Apollo and Dlonysius. On the evidence of his piano recital at Alice Tully Hail on Wednesday night, Edward Ayer lives most comfortably in the camp of Mozart and Apollo.

title: Chinese Term U.S. Confrontation With Soviet in Africa More Acute
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 23 (Reuters)The Chinese press agency Hsinhua said today that the contention between the Soviet Union and the United States over southern Africa was becoming more acute.

title: Wright Closes With Course Record And Takes Met. P.G.A. by 9 Shots
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 23 Jim Wright of Fenway, ignoring gusty and swirling winds, toured the Glen Oaks Club course today in a record 65, seven strokes under par, and won the $26,000 Izod Metropolitan P.G.A. championship by nine shots with a 211.

title: Bridge:
description: Almost every disaster at the bridge table, when analyzed in the postmortem, can be blamed on one member of the suffering side and perhaps on both. But there are some rare cases in which it is hard to assign any blame and condolences are in order.

title: Court Upholds Barring of Hall
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Mildred Dunnock Is Ordinary Only Until She Gets on Stage
description: It's been 44 years since Mildred Dunnock first appeared on Broadway, and she has been in so many productions since then that her Playbill biography reads like a catalogue of theater in our time.

title: Episcopal Bishops Call for Unity as Convention Ends
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 23After approving the ordination of women and a new Book of Common Prayer, the Episcopal Church ended today what its House of Bishops said might well prove to be the most crucial general convention of this century.

title: SOUTH AFRICA PLANS MULTIRACIAL SPORTS
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 23  South Africa ended decades of segregation in sports today with an official announcement that the Government would sanction multiracial games at all levels and mixed racial teams in international competition.

title: 2 Soviet Astronauts Land Safely
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 23After eight days in orbit, two Soviet astronauts returned safely to earth today in their Soyuz 22 space capsule. Both men, Col. Valery F. Bykovsky of the Air Force, the flight commander, and Vladimir V. Aksenov, a civilian engineer, were feeling well after the landing, according to ?ass, the Soviet press agency.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: BRONX

title: MONDALE CAMPAIGNS IN FORD HOME STATE
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 23This was a rare quiet evening for Senator Walter F. Mondale a stroll across the Yale campus, dinner at his hotel and, of course watching television in his rooms. His day began before 7 A.M. in Wisc??sin, but he spent most of it campaigning in President Ford's home state.

title: Excerpts From Prayer Books
description: Following are excerpts from the. texts from the old Book of Common Prayer and changes approved by the Episcopal Church:

title: ZAMBIA AND ANGOLA MOVE TO ESTABLISH RELATIONS
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 23 (Reuters)Zambia and Angola have brought their uneasy relations closer to normalization with an agreement to exchange ambassadors and to establish a joint commission to sort out their problems.

title: KALLINGER IS CRAZY, COUNSEL TELLS JURY
description: HACKENSACK, Sept. 23Joseph Kallinger's attorney said today in his opening statement today that his client was totally crazy and that psychiatrists would testify that he did not know right from wrong on Jan. 8, 1975, when, according to the charge in the case, he killed Maria Fasching, a 21yearold nurse in Leonia.

title: Assault Verdict Upheld for Man Who Gave Tests With Needles
description: TRENTON, Sept. 23 (AP)The state's second highest court has upheld the atrociousassault and battery conviction of a Newark man found guilty of inserting pins and needles into his victims under the pretense of giving them health tests.

title: Smith Pledges Unequivocal Reply To Kissinger's Proposals Today
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 23Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said tonight he would broadcast a clear, positive and unequivocal statement tomorrow giving his Government's response to the proposals for a transfer of power to the black majority presented to him five days ago by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.

title: For Jewish New Year, A Taste Of Honey
description: Cooking relaxes me, said Leon Hirschbaum, a lawyer whose trim physique belies both his passion for food and his 68 years. I love to shop for food and cook dinner after a day of legal problems, and when I have insomnia, I sometimes bake at 3 or 4 in the morning.

title: CUNNINGHAM STATUS CONSIDERED SECURE
description: Patrick J. Cunningham, the Bronx Democratic leader, and Frank G. Rossetti, his Manhattan counterpart, appeared yesterday to be safe in their leaderships for some time despite their defeat by the antiorganization New Democratic Coalition in contests for party Supreme Court nominations.

title: REPORTED KICKBACKS TO KINNEY'S BUYERS SPUR COMPANY STUDY
description: The Kinney Shoe Corporation, a subsidiary of the F. W. Woolworth Company, and one of the nation's largest retail shoe chains, is currently conducting an investigation into reported largescale kickbacks to its buyers from. producers of apparel or related items.

title: GULF BOARD APPROVES A RESTITUTION PLAN FOR 6 PAST OFFICERS
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 23The surrender of stock and stock options and some cash paymentsa package said to be worth more than $4 millionwill be required of six former executives of the Gulf Oil Corporation as part of the settlement of stockholder claims arising from Gulf's ilegal political slush fund.

title: Belmont Racing
description: RESULTS

title: RADIO
Jets and Giants Billed for Games On Road With Tough Foes Sunday
description: Four defeats in their first four games for the Giants and Jets mark the poorest combined start ever for New York's two pro football teams. So the national television game, Baltimore at Dallas (Channel 4, 4 P.M.), holds chief interest in Sunday's schedule. Bout local teams face formidable opposition on the road, the Jets at Miami (Channel 4, 1 P.M.), and the Giants at Los Angeles (Channel 2, 4 P.M.). The Monday night game matches Washington and Philadelphia (Channel 7, 9 P.M.). Here is a preview of all games with wonlosttied records in parentheses:

title: Women's Film Festival: Adrift in Brazil
description: Branded for Life is an attempt to make a critique of modern Brazilian society through a story of three young drifters. One is a smalltime thug, the second a prostitute and the third a street urchin, a girl just past puberty. They meet, move into the same apartment, take up a threeway sexual relationship, and undertake a series of amateurish stickups, with dismal results.

title: Soviet Seems to Expect Setbacks From Kissinger Trip
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 23The Soviet Union is showing considerable uneasiness over Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's shuttle diplomacy in southern Africa, evidently concerned that the American initiative may undermine Moscow's long investment in building influence with the black nationalist groups that are expected to come to power.

title: At the Movies
description: Not long ago, United Artists teased the public by placing ads in newspapers for a sneak preview of a film that will open in December to qualify for the Academy Awards. Moviegoers anticipating a starstudded extravaganza may have, been taken aback when the credits flashed on Rocky, a film starring and written by Sylvester Stallone.

title: Leslie, Commodity World's Doyen
description: CHICAGO  Some time within the next two weeks, about 3,000 postcards will be prepared with a few simple questions relating to the major crops and then mailed from a 17thfloor suite in the august Board of Trade building here to virtually all of the agricultural counties in 26 states. Thus will begin the next crop survey of the Leslie Analytical Organization, the country's leading private cropforecasting service. The answers will be requested early in the first week of next month to meet the Oct. 11 target date for the upcoming crop estimate of Conrad Leslie, the lone operator who issues and analyzes the returns awaited throughout the commodity world.

title: Pirates Beat Cubs, 54, On Rookie's Hit in 10th
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 23Pittsburgh Pirate fans could have been excused if they put their hands over their eyes today. For the fourth sucessive game it was the bottom of the ninth with the score tied. This time it was Wrigley Field, the Chicago Cubs were threatening and the fading Pirates looked as if they were going to lose the sixth of their last seven games.

title: Dance:
description: William Dunas has a love affair with the idea of ballet, if not its bravura execution. He quotes constantly from the balletic vocabulary of steps in his own personal shorthand of movement and then mixes in less format and more freely figured gestures to make dances. The latest in this series was called simply Solo Dance and it was given at the Ambrose Arts Foundation studio Wednesday evening.

title: Yankee Hopes Again Snagged As Orioles Complete Sweep; Flanagan Outpitches Hunter in 21 Game Lead Cut to 7; Orioles Sweep Series, Delay Yankees Bid
description: The days of the 1976 baseball season are dwindling and suddenly so is the Yankees lead.

title: Keystone Ore Captures Little Brown Jug in Runoff
description: DELAWARE. Ohio, Sept. 23 (AP)Keystone Ore kept alive the prospects of winning the triple crown of pacing today by taking the Little Brown Jug in a raceoff with Armbro Ranger. Stanley Dancer drove the Bye Bye Byrd colt to victory in the one mile race for 3yearolds in 1:57 2/5 over the Delaware County Fairground's halfmile track. The winner's purse was $56,903. Keystone Ore, who won the first leg of the triple crown, the Can Futurity, will try to become the first horse to sweep the three events in the Messenger at Roosevelt Raceway on Oct. 30.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An angry Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday ordered that the New York City Corporation Counsel pay $500 a day in court costs until his office produced a lawyer to defend the Board of Education in a suit brought by a dismissed elementary school teacher.

title: Unguarded Moment on House Dais
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23Vice President Rockefeller and Speaker of the House Carl Albert were overheard today in unguarded conversation in the House chamber about Liberians that included a derogatory remark about Senator Edward W. Brooke by Mr. Albert.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation has met with difficulties in manponents and expects lower earnings ufacturing and assembling watch coinin the fiscal first quarter ended Sept. 22. Charles E. Sporck, its president, said at the company's annual meeting yesterday in Santa Clara. Calif.

title: New Life for Old Bottles
description: THE GLORIOUS COLORS and curious shapes of 19thcentury American whisky, medicine, perfume and poison bottles are attracting thousands of collectors today, bottle buffs who have formed more than 500 clubs where they share their enthusiasm and their bottles, too.

title: Carter in Illinois
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 23Gov. Jimmy Carter's performance in the first debate tonight, while far from flawless, may well hive been forceful enough to give him the momentum he needed to redeem a Presidential campaign that has been hesitant, diffuse and dogged by Mr. Carter's slips into irrelevant controversies.

title: In Memoriam
description: CARVERWilliam R. Dearest Bill, beloved husband of Maria. Gone one year. Never to be forgotten. Rest Peacefully.

title: FORD AND CARTER, IN FIRST DEBATE, TRADE CHARGES ON ECONOMIC ISSUE
description: President Ford and Jimmy Carter met last night in a generally genteel debate in which the President sought to portray his Democratic rival as a fuzzythinking spendthrift and Mr. Carter accused Mr. Ford of economic mismanagement and weak leadership.

title: Weekend Gardening:
description: There are few pleasures in life more tranquilizing than spending a crisp fall evening in front of a roaring fire, a bowl of fragrant, freshly plucked apples near one hand and a basket of chestnuts to roast near the other. Nibbling on the fruits of Iabors past, one dreams of grander things for the future. And although the approaching winter solstice is a time of planning and contentment for the gardener, the falling leaves are also a call to action.

title: The Right to Food
description: Massive human problems are generally such a subliminal part of daily life that they lie uncomprehended just beyond the general consciousness. It was that way for years with the nuclear peril, with the human attacks on the earth's environment, with overpopulationand so it still is with the problem of hunger throughout the world. Mere consciousness seems to advance in tiny increments; but no matter how small, each step in any of these fields constitutes a major contribution to mankind's efforts to construct a civilized global order.

title: EXPOSTMASTER GENERAL FINED FOR AIDING HAMMER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI)Former Postmaster General W. Marvin Watson pleaded guilty today to helping Armand Hammer, the chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, cover up illegal campaign contributions.

title: Gain in Purchasing Power Found in 50Nation Study
description: Along with the ebbing of inflation the rate at which money is losing purchasing power has slowed perceptibly in a majority of 50 countries covered in a survey by the economics department of the Citibank.

title: State Senate, 31 0, Approves Rules on Motor Bikes
description: TRENTON, Sept. 23The State Senate unanimously approved today strict regulations on motorized bicycles by banning them on roads with posted speed limits of more than 40 miles an hour and by requiring operators to be over 17 years of age and have a valid driver's license.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The police in Englewood have been stripped of their power to write parking tickets following a summonsblitz job action in which one officer ticketed his own squad car.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Of Vietnam and U.S. Domestic Politics

title: Sarkis: A Quiet Man for Lebanon
description: Elias Sarkis, who was inaugurated yesterday as President of Lebanon, is a quiet man who leads a secluded life. Until he announced his candidacy last spring, he had never held a news conference.

title: Opera:
description: William Harness took the part of Alfredo in Verdi's La Traviata for the first time with the New York City Opera in the performance given at the New York State Theater Wednesday night. He appeared with Maralin Niska (Violetta), Richard Fredricks (the elder Germont) and Kathleen Hegierski (Flora), all familiar with their roles from previous performances. The only other newcomer to the cast was Margaret Goodman, who was Annina for the first time.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 24, 1976

title: Federal Reserve Statement
Army Lifts 2Year Dumping Ban For a Lobster Area in L.I. Sound
description: NORTHPORT, L. L, Sept. 23After twoyear ban on dumping at a Federal site in Long Island Sound off Eatons Neck, L. I., a popular area for lobster fishing, the Army Corps of Engineers has reopened the site for the deposit, of dredged materials.

title: Article 1  No Title
Miss Nomer On the Debate
description: After somebody pulled the plug on the FordCarter debate, the President and the Governor naturally asked for equal time to question the Average American Voter.

title: A Jewish Generation Gap
description: An Orphan's Tale is 37yearold Jay Neugeboren's fourth novel and sixth bookthere was a collection of short stories, Corky's Brother, and memoir, Parenthesesand he seems to be unlucky. If a writer with brains, passion, wit and craft can't have Iarge numbers of readers, at least he deserves attentive reviewers. Otherwise he will get the felling that he is dropping his books into a hole in the head of the world, and they fall through space.

title: Russian Wins in Parachuting
description: ROME, Sept. 23 (AP)Greg Surabko of the Soviet Union won the men's world parachuting championship today, topping the overall standings for style and accuracy at the military airport of Guidonia, east of Rome. Pierre Forand, a 24yearold Canadian from Montreal, was second with 3.4150 and Jean Dermine of France third with 3,5637, Jack Brake of Birmingham, Ala,, was fourth.

title: SouthWest African Goes to Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 23Sam Nujoma, the leader of the SouthWest African People's Organization, flew home to Africa today after insisting that his group would not soften its terms for negotiating with South Africa on independence for the territory.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was erroneously reported in The Tunes Sept. 18 that a grand jury said in 1972 that the ultimate responsibility for an irregular method of paying some provisional city employees lay with two mayoral aides, Richard R. Aurelio and Sid Davidoff. Actually, the ?? presentment said that while the two aides had approved salary commitments not covered by the regular budget, there was testimony that they had no knowledge of unauthorized use of office cash to pay the employees.

title: Lloyd Beats Tanner in Net Upset
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 (AP)John Lloyd of Britain upset eighthseeded Roscoe Tanner of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., 16, 62, 76, today in the second round of the $125,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis championship.

title: MSL Industries Acquires For Cash and Notes Stock Of Allied Structural Steel
description: MSL Industries, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Allegheny Corporation, announced yesterday it had acquired all of the stock of the Allied Structural Steel Company for cash and notes. MSL did not disclose terms of the transaction. Allied Structural Steel, based in Chicago Heights, Ill., is a maker of structural steel members for industrial, commercial and institutional buildings, bridges and other structures. Sales in 1975 totaled about $37 million, according to an MSL official.

title: Policy Unchanged at August Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee kept monetary policy essentially unchanged at its Aug. 27th meeting but narrowed the target range for the key rate on Federal funds, it was disclosed today.

title: Attendant at Park Zoo Injured by an Elephant
description: Harry Wurster, a Central Park Zoo keeper, was injured by a 6,000pound elephant yesterday morning. The 30 yearold Siamese elephant, named Julia, seized the 46yearold keeper with her trunk as he was cleaning an area between her pen and a spectator railing, a Parks Department spokesman said.

title: U.S. and West Germany Sign Pact Of Cooperation on Lockheed Sales
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI)West Germany signed an agreement of cooperation with the Justice Department today in investigations of alleged illegal sales efforts abroad by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: Rhodesia Announces 40 Rebels Have Been Killed in Past Week
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 24 (Reuters)Ten black nationalist guerrillas have been killed by Rhodesian troops in the last 24 hours, a security force communique said today.

title: John Covert's Few Pictures Win a Place in History of Art
description: WASHINGTONWe tend to forget how lonely it once was to be a modernist artist in America. Today, when almost anything claiming to be artno matter how inane or farfetchedfinds a ready audience, and whole platoons of critics, curators and collectors are on the lookout for what is new or unusual, it requires a certain leap of the imagination to understand the isolation, disappointment and suffering endured by an earlier generation of modernists who produced their work under very different circumstances.

title: Statements in Debate Conflicted With Facts in Several Instances
$15 MILLION PAY CUT AGREED TO BY UNION
description: The largest union of municipal employees yesterday fulfilled a promise to the city and agreed to $15 million in fringe and pay cuts, including a 10 percent salary reduction for new city workers.

title: Erica Anderson, 62, a Film Maker And Schweitzer Associate, Is Dead
description: Erica Anderson, a documentary film maker and an associate of the late Dr. Albert Schweitzer, died Thursday of heart attack at her home in Great Barrington. Mass. She was 62 years old.

title: SUPREME COURT VIEW SCORED BY BUCKLEY
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 24In a vigorous criticism of the United States Supreme Court, Senator James L. Buckley charged today that the Court's decisions barring most parochial school aid were in effect religious repression.

title: Murphy Blames Business For Regulatory Growth
description: DETROIT, Sept. 24Thomas A. Murphy, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, accused big business today of creating some of its own problems in the area of socalled overregulation by the Federal Government.

title: Books of the Times
description: SWAMI. By Doug Boyd. Random House. 330 pages. $10.

title: Tanzanians Cool to Rhodesian Plan
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sept. 24There was no immediate response tonight from President Julius K. Nyerere to the white Rhodesian Government's apparent capitulation, but officials close to him reacted unenthusiastically and with disappointment to the speech of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Sept. 24The State Department of Health will be authorized to close industrial plants that pose a threat to their employees by emitting cancercausing substances, under legislation proposed by a special state commission studying cancer in the state.

title: Hearing on Parking Tickets Is Halted by an Injunction
Faulty 25Cent Part Silenced the Debate
description: A faulty, 25cent electronic part about the size of a cigarette butt was identified by engineering sleuths yesterday as the gremlin that silenced the Presidential debates Thursday night before a national television audience.

title: RHODESIA MOVE STIRS EXCITEMENT AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Sept. 24Security Council delegates started hasty informal canvassing among themselves today, in anticipation of moves next week toward a possible lifting of United Nations sanctions against Rhodesia.

title: COCOA PRICES JUMP
description: Decemberdelivery cocoa jumped the daily trading limit of 4 cents a pound yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange to close at $1.14 a pound.

title: DEBATE IS REGARDED AS DRAW BY EXPERTS WITHIN BOTH PARTIES
GOING OUT Guide
A Man of Integrity
description: Paul Howard Douglas of Illinois was the kind of Senator you like to think about in the Bicentennial year. He went to the Senate for one purpose and one purpose only: to work as hard as he possibly could for the good of ire nation as he had cove to understand it. He was no body's notion of a lion on the cocktail circuit, but he was a tiger in subcommittee meetings on tax bills, housing policy, conservation issues or civil rights initiatives. His head was full of facts, economic theories and visions of a better, fairer and more decent America.

title: Death on the Street: Vehicle Homicide Unit Relies on Science and Sense to Solve Cases
description: When Sgt. Frank Ghiorsi arrived at the scene, all that was left was a pool of blood and a yellow chalk outline of a body on the street.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: ing on his plane asked if he had spoken the crucial words.

title: Behind School Success Is a Father Who Cares
description: LONDON, Sept. 24  Does it really make any difference if a father turns up at a P.T.A. meeting? If a father takes his children to the zoo or to the movies or just out for a walk, will the child learn how to read any faster?

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Britain Set to Play Key Role in Rhodesian Transition
description: LONDON, Sept. 24Britain's hopes for black rule in Rhodesia, its renegade former colony, have risen and then collapsed enough in the last decade to make any Briton skeptical of new initiatives. Even so, there was a sense here today that Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger may finally have pulled it off.

title: Kissinger Cautions That Decision By Rhodesia Is Only the Beginning Kissinger Cautions on Rhodesia
Patents
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The head of a nonprofit Washington institute who has invented various ways of helping the disabled to communicate and operate equipment has expanded his system to serve those subject to involuntary actions  sufferers from spastics. Haig Kafafian, president of the Cybernetics Research . Institute, was granted Patent 3,982,236 this week for cornmunicatiops; and control method and apparatut for persons who may have muscular incoordination andor spasticity.

title: Britain Keeping KohiNoor Gem
description: LONDON, Sept. 24 (Reuters)Britain has turned down a request from Pakistan for the return of Kohidoor diamond, richest of all the British crown jewels, official sources said today. The diamond, acknowledged, as one of the world's finest, came into British hands in 1849 following the annexation of the Punjab.

title: About New York
description: Gerald F. Doherty has been shuttling into New York from Boston every week, wearing a Don't Tread on Me necktie, standing souldeep in Kennedy connections and working very hard to win a state he does not know too well New Yorkfor a politician he does not know too wellJimmy Carter.

title: Liberal Party Split on Senate Race
description: Representative Bella S. Abzug and former Mayor John V. Lindsay, both of whom had considerable support within the Liberal Party for its nomination for United States Senator from New York, said yesterday that they would not accent the nomination if it was offered.

title: Rockefeller, Albert Apologize to Brooke
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24  Senator Edward W. Brooke, Republican of Massachusetts, said that Vice President Rockefeller and the Speaker of the House, Carl Albert, had apologized today for remarks they had made about him yesterday.

title: Scores on WQXR
description: Scores of leading football games will be given over WQXR, on the 6 P.M. news broadcast and in other news reports. Please do not telephone The New York Times for scores; the calls tie up lines and interfere with the work of the newspaper and radio station.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: SelfRegulating Agency Proposed For Commodities Industry Group
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The Commodities Futures Trading Commission has received a formal proposal from an industry group seeking to set up a selfregulatory body that would function much like the National Association of Securities Dealers in the securities business, William T. Bagley. commission chairman, disclosed today.

title: Carter, in Texas, Says He's Sorry About His Criticism of Johnson
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 24Jimmy Carter, seeking the 26 Electoral College votes of Texas, expressed regret today about his remarks that former President Lyndon B. Johnson had engaged in lying, cheating and distorting the truth.

title: Newark School Board Rejects Proposed Service Workers Pact
description: A strike by 2,500 cafeteria and maintenance workers in the Newark school system entre a new stage yesterday with the rejection of a tentative contract agreement. A proposed contract settlement, worked out Wednesday with the help of Judge Sherwin Lester of Superior Court, was rejected Thursday by the Board of Education.

title: GERALDINE T. FITCH DIES
description: Geraldine Townsend Fitch, who wrote about and did public relations work for Nationalist China, died Thursday in Pomona, Calif. She was 84 years old and lived there at the Mount San Antonio Gardens Retirement Home.

title: Jeanette Chappell Kalt, 79
description: Jeannette Chappell Kalt, a poet and tennis player who for many years had been chairman of the women's ranking committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, died yesterday at the Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I., at the age of 79. She lived in Locust Valley. L.I.

title: Relaxed Rockefeller Enjoys Campaigning for FordDole
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24Vice President Rockefelier is clearly enjoying himself in what appears to be his last hurrah as an active politician.

title: KALLINGER IDENTITY STIRS TRIAL PROBLEM
description: HACKENSACK, Sept. 24With Joseph Kallinger missing from his murder trial, a prosecution witness called to identify him today had nobody to point out.

title: Radio
Mexican Labor Movement, Accepting 23% Pay Rise, Calls Off National Strike
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 24Under strong pressure from the Government, Mexico's labor movement today called off a planned nationwide strike and accepted an emergency wage increase of 23 percent to compensate for inflation since the Mexican peso was devalued last month.

title: Many Blacks Held in Johannesburg
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 24 (UPI)Riot squads patrolled Johannesburg's white shopping district today and police searched and arrested scores of blacks to prevent further outbreaks of racial Violence in the city's downtown areas.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Problems of Health Care of the Black and Minority Aged is today's scheduled topic of a fourday conference of health experts and officials in Newark aimed at lowering the cost and upgrading the quality of innercity health services in New Jersey.

title: The Region: 3 Years of Changes
description: Southern Africa has been an area of rapid and unforeseen political change in the last three years. A summary follows.

title: Article 9  No Title
S.D.A. Asks a Study by State Of Chemical Bank's Stock Plan
description: The Securities Industry Association, a leading spokesman for the brokerage business, asked the New York State bank.. ing department yesterday to investigate plans of the Chemical Bank to offer custamers an opportunity to buy stock at discount commission rates.

title: Old Jazz Stars Brought to Mind By Dick Hyman
description: Scott Joplin, Jelly Roll Morton and even James P. Johnson have become such standard sources for contemporary jazz traditionalists that a program called Jelly Roll, Joplin and James P., which started the fifth year of Jack Kleinsinger's Highlight in Jazz! series on Wednesday evening at New York University's Loeb Center Auditorium, seems to suggest a pleasant but unadventurous concert.

title: Phillies, Pirates Split Twin Bills And East Gap Remains 6 Games
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 24 (AP)  Earl Williams's twoout double in the sixth inning drove in Ellis Valentine with the tiebreaking run, giving the Montreal Expos a 32 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight for a split of their doubleheader.

title: Judge in Hearst Sentencing
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24Last June 21, the initials of 12 Federal judges from the Northern District of California were put into envelopes and placed in a shallow filing cabinet tray for a drawing, held to reassign the criminal cases of Chief Judge Oliver J. Carter who had died one week earlier. When the process was complete, Judge William H. Orrick had been chosen for the difficult task of determining the punishment of perhaps the most celebrated convicted felon in recent memory, Patricia Hearst.

title: Rigney Starts an Old Guessing Game
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24When Bill Rigney declared he would not return as manager of the San Francisco Giants next year, at a crowded press conference in Candlestick Park Tuesday night, the assembled experts immediately began speculating about a successor to be Chosen from the established tool of managerialmusicalchairs occupants.

title: SENATE UNIT MOVES TO PROHIBIT MISSILES FOR SAUDI ARABIANS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, in an unexpected setback to the Administration's Middle East policy, voted 8 to 6 today to block the sale to Saudi Arabia of 650 airtosurface Maverick missiles.

title: Mrs. Isaac Stern Honored for Humanitarianism
description: It was the afternoon before a concert by her husband, and Mrs. Isaac Stern was at home, fielding crises at a dizzying pace. Unflappable, a quizzical glint hovering persistently about her eyes, she soothed longlost friends without tickets and dealt in several languages with maids and delivery men. She saw one teenage son off for the afternoon, chatted reassuringly with her violinist husband, who was rehearsing at Carnegie Hall, and reminisced about the life of Vera Stern.

title: The First Debate
ADM. IVO PURISIC
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 24 (UPI) Adm. No Purisic, commander of Yugoslavia's Adriatic military area, has died after a long illness, the Belgrade state radio said today. He was 56 years old.

title: Financial Intrigue, Mystery Shroud American Bank and Trust Collapse
description: A week ago, the American Bank and Trust Company collapsed in New York, an apparent victim of shoddy management, selfdealing and corruptionall set in an atmosphere of international intrigue.

title: E.P.A. Delays Reducing Gas Lead
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP)The Environmental Protection Agency today dropped its controversial plan to reduce the amount of lead in gasoline on a stepbystep basis over the next three years.

title: Fezler Shares A Stroke Lead With Miller
description: NAPA, Calif., Sept. 24 (AP) Forrest Fezler rallied from four strokes off the pace with a solid 68 today and tied Johnny Miller for the secondround lead in the $175,000 Kaiser international open golf tournament.

title: RICHARD LYON, 51, DIES
description: TROY, N. Y., Sept. 24 (AP)Richard Lyon, who returned to Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute after football coaching stints at Ithaca and West Point, died last night at the age of 51. The Elnora resident suffered a heart attack after jogging, according to an R.P.L spokesman.

title: Closter, Cresskill and Cornwallis: The Battle Lines (1976) Are Drawn
description: CLOSTER, Sept. 24The guns have fallen silent, but the war has just begun.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company, a leading producer of wood products, said yesterday that an internal investigation showed irregularities in some overseas subsidiaries concerning improper or questionable payments, as well as two minor possible violations of the law by company managers in this country.

title: Electionomics
description: The first debate between Mr. Ford and Mr. Carter was focused almost entirely on economic issues, especially unemployment, inflation and taxes. The continual throwing about of statistics (as in lies, damned lies, and statistics) must have left the vast majority of viewers baffled and bored. Only the most experienced and knowledgeable auditors could possibly have picked his or her way through the dense and often contradictory assertions made by each candidate.

title: He Was ManMultitude, ManOcean
description: LAUSANNE, SwitzerlandMao Tsetung is no more. Recognition of his giant stature and his historyshaking exploits have been ample and worldwide. Here I tell of my own search for Mao Tsetung, his thinking that changed China and the world.

title: For the Canadian Wheat Grower, Record Crop and Life of Comfort
Uruguay Relaxes Its Economic Protection As Military Leaders Promote Exporting
