description: Four decades ago, the first official world championship was played here in New York. The Four Aces team, which dominated all the major American tournaments of that period, scored a decisive victory against the French team that had won the European Championship.He led a low heart toward the dummy, and West had to duck. Now he was able to proceed on reverse dummy lines. He ruffed a diamond, entered dummy with a club lead to the ace and ruffed the last diamond.

title: Rhodesia Struggled to Stand Alone
description: Eleven years ago Rhodesia declared itself independent of Britain. Today it is almost wholly dependent upon South Africa.

title: U.S. Interference Charged in Summer Food Program
description: New York State education authorities said yesterday that their ability to prevent and curb abuses in the summer freefood program for needy children had been stymied by poor Federal regulations and political interference by members of Congress and their staffs.

title: France Raises Cost Of Fuel to Cut Use
description: PARIS, Sept. 24  France has now moved where the United States has not by raising fuel prices sharply to discourage energy use and save on petroleum imports.

title: Vorster Silent, but His Critics See New Pressures
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 24The South African Government maintained silence tonight on the Rhodesian constitutional settlement it had helped to engineer, but critics of Prime Minister John Vorster's administration predicted that a shift to majority rule in Rhodesia would increase pressures for farreaching racial reforms in South Africa itself.

title: HanoiPhnom Penh Air Link
description: HANOI, Vietnam, Sept. 24 (Agence FrancePresse)Regular air service between Hanoi and the Cambodian capital of Phnom Penh has begun, according to the Vietnamese news agency. The first flight was on Tuesday, and there will be one roundtrip flight every two weeks.

title: Lockheed Inquiry In Japan Is Stalled By Kodama Case
description: TOKYO, Sept. 24  Prime Minister Takeo Miki told Parliament today that his Government's investigation of the Lockheed bribery scandal would take longer than expected.

title: The Antitrust Bill
description: President Ford has declared himself in favor of a strict enforcement of the antitrust laws. Yet the most important antitrust measure in decades, passed by Congress over a week ago, is still awaiting his signature.

title: Pedestrian Fatalities: A Statistical Profile
description: New York is a walker's city, as evidenced by the fact that more pedestrians are killed here as a result of auto accidents than are drivers or passengers.

title: $24 A SHARE IS BID FOR WILLIAMS &
description: Williams & Company said yesterday that Williams Companies had made a tender offer for all the outstanding shares of Williams & Company common stock at $24 a share. On the basis of the 1,131,757 shares outstanding, the transaction wouldtotal about $27.2 million. The offer made by The Williams Companies, a manufacturer of fertilizer and metals, based in Tulsa, Okla., follows a tender offer made Sept. 16 by the Superior Tube Company for all outstanding Williams & Company shares at $22 apiece.

title: Ford, Carter Alma Maters Meet in Football Today
Tropical Storm, $69.80, Wins Rich Jersey Trot
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 24Tropical Storm, belonging to the famous old harnesshorse establishment now operating as the Arden Homestead Stable of Goshen, N.Y., created a stir at the Meadowlands tonight by capturing the $94,000 Beacon Course Trot, for 3yearolds. A crowd estimated at 19,000 thought so little of the chances of this son of Floris that it sent him to the post as a $69.80for$2 outsider. Finishing second, beaten to the wire by 2, lengths, was Steve Lobell, competing as an oddson favorite with Quick Pay, a stablemate. Quick Pay was third.

title: ESTEBAN FRANCES, ARTIST AND BALLET DESIGNER, 61
description: Esteban Francs, a Spanishborn artist and theatrical designer who was associated with the New York City Ballet, died Monday following a fall while on a visit to Barcelona. Mr. Francs, who lived in Malorca, was 61 years old.

title: Jackson Hurls 5Hit Shutout As Yanks and Tigers Divide
Penthouse Magazine Indicted
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 24 (UPI)Penthouse International of New York, publisher of. Penthouse magazine, and, three other concerns have been indicted for the sale of allegedly pbscene material in the magazine's July 12 issue. Also indicted were the Curtis Circulation Company of West Caldwell, N.J., distributor of the magazine in the United States; the Manchester News Company of Bedford local distributor of the magazine. and Luv Pharmacy, Inc., the parent orgatilza tion of Luv Pharmacy, where the magazine sale took place.

title: Article 2  No Title
Freelance Flight Instructors Say New Rule By the State Stifles Free Enterprise System
description: Members of the Pilots Association in New Jersey rejoiced last March 4 when, after a threeyearbattle, an appeals court overturned the conviction of a federally licensed flight instructor for teaching without a state license at Linden Airport.

description: As you are all aware, I have recently had a series of meetings in Pretoria, firstly with the South African Prime Minister, then with Dr. Kissinger and finally with Dr. Kissinger and Mr. Vorster together.

title: Nuclear Second Thoughts
description: Two European developments of the past few days should give pause to the proponents of nuclear power as the best possible answer to the world's insatiable demands for energy. Sweden's Prime Minister Olof Palme blamed the defeat of his government on its program for greatly expanding that country's production of atomic energy, and in London a Royal Commission recommended that further expansion of England's nuclear plant capacity be postponed as long as possible.

title: Argentine Leader Says Victory Over the Guerrillas Is Near
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 24President Jorge Rafael Videla of Argentina said tonight that victory by the armed forces over guerrilla insurgents was close at hand after six months of repressive operations.

title: Sitar Recital by Nikhil Banerjee Is an Evening of Rarest Pleasure
STOCKS DECLINE 1.49 AS TRADING DROPS
description: Concern that the Federal Reserve Board may be .temporarily forced to tighten its monetary policy sent stock prices down slightly yesterday in slower trading.

title: China Cancels National Holiday Because of the Death of Mao
description: PEKING, Sept. 24 (Reuters)China has called off next Friday's National Day celebrations because of the death of Chairman Mao Tsetung, officials said tonight,

description: KAISER OPEN

title: Nets Start Hard Training At Camp in Westchester
Record World Wheat Output Seen
description: LONDON, Sept. 24 (UPI)Total world wheat production in 1976 is likely to be a record 391 million tons, the International Wheat Council said today. The Council said this would be 6 percent above the previous record of 367.9 million tons in 1973. It said record crops were expected in both the United States and Canada

title: Citibank Prime Rate Is Reduced to 6% , But Some Keep 7%
description: Citibank, the largest commercial bank in New York, lowered its prime lending rate yesterday to 6 percent from 7 percent in the face of continuing sluggish loan demand for the banking industry.

title: Schools for Pregnant Girls to Close
description: The city's five Special Schools for Pregnant Girls have had their staffs cut in half, they are unable to accept new students and they will be shut down entirely by February.

title: Rap Brown Wins State Parole and a New U.S. Trial
description: H. Rap Brown, who spectacularly entered public view in 1967 as a spokesman for a new black militancy and disappeared from sight in 1973 after being convicted of robbery and assault in New York City, won parole yesterday from Greenhaven Prison and is expected to begin that parole on Oct. 21.

title: The Yankees' Invisible Left Fielder
description: He's a baseball player who has seemed invisible unless observed under ultraviolet lights available only to those who understand the small skills. Roy White is in his 12th season with the New York Yankees, but he's quiet, serious, unemotional and unimposing at 5 feet 10 inches and a 175 pounds. Perhaps someday he will be recognized as the best left fielder in Yankee history, better than Bob Meusel, better than Charlie Keller, better than Hank Bauerif he ever is recognized. But he should be. Only 32 years old, Roy White has already established credentials that will surprise casual Yankee historians who don't put him up there with the glorious names of the past. Roy White has accumulated more hits as a Yankee than Elston Howard, Red Rolfe, Hank Bauer, Tommy Henrich, Gil McDougald or Charlie Keller; more doubles than Phil Rizzuto; almost as many home runs as Bob Meusel; more runs batted in than Joe Gordon or George Selkirk; and more runs scored than Bauer, Meusel or Keller. And with the Yankees about to clinch first place in the American League East, he might even play in a World Series for the first time.

title: SENATE UNIT MOVES TO PROHIBIT MISSILES FOR SAUDI ARABIANS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, in an unexpected setback to the Administration's Middle East policy, voted 8 to 6 today to block the sale to Saudi Arabia of 650 airtosurface Maverick missiles.

title: Police in New York Protest Over Shifts S
description: Thousands of offduty police officers, protesting against new work schedules and deferred raises, picketed yesterday at nearly all of New York City's 73 station houses while representatives of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association sought unsuccessfully to persuade Mayor Beanie to agree to their demands.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mayor Beanie announced the resignation of Alphonse D'Ambrose as New York City Personnel Director, and immediately appointed in his place Thomas F. Roche, the Mayor's assistant in charge of dispensing patronage. Mr. D'Ambrose will become the $51,675ayear general counsel to the New York City Transit Authority. As Personnel Director, the 44yearold Mr. D'Ambrose received $47,093 a year. He was appointed by Mayor Beame in November 1974. As general counsel to the Transit Authority he succeeds John S. Riedel, who retired. Mr. Roche, a 25year career civil servant, started as a Health Department clerk in 1951.

title: Dollar Eases: Pound Hits a New Low
description: LONDON, Sept. 24 (AP)The dollar eased in relation to all major currencies today except the British pound, which closed at a new low. Gold moved up around $1 an ounce in bullion markets.

title: Brokers and Clients Paying Less for Loans
description: Investors who buy on marginthat is borrow from their stockbrokermay soon discover that interest rates are coming down a bit.

title: KnightRidder Is Reorganized
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 (UPI)Directors of KnightRidder Newspapers Inc. approved today a reorganization plan dividing the company into two operating groups. The changes represent the final step in the company's plan for full integration of Knight Newspapers Inc., and Ridder Publications Inc., according to Alvah H. Chapman Jr., president and chief executive officer. The two companies merged almost two years ago.

title: People in Sports
description: Muhammad Ali, the world heavyweight champion, and Ken Norton, the challenger broke camp yesterday and headed for New York City for the final preparation prior to their rubber match in Yankee Stadium on Tuesday night. Ali sparred nine brisk rounds at his Concord Hotel camp in Kiamesha Lake, N.Y., going three rounds with Rodney Bobick, Randy Stephens and Jimmy Ellis, and joked briefly with Jackie Tonawanda, a woman boxer, who also sparred with Ellis.

description: A portion of Step 2 in the recipe for golden cheesecake that appeared yesterday was inadvertently omitted. After buttering the baking pan, line the bottom and side of the pan with, the prepared macaroon or zweiback crumbs to form a crust.

description: No one wore a Saint Laurent but it could be argued that the party at Greek Island was in the height of fashion. Many of the guests wore peasant inspired clothing and had been wearing it far years.

title: Mayer Upsets Vilas, 63, 64, In Coast Tennis
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (AP)Sandy Mayer of Mendham, N.J., and John Lloyd of England pulled off major upsets today in the third round of the $125,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis tournament.

title: Floridian Appeals to Kidnappers: Take $200,000 and Return Wife
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 24 (UPI)A wealthy real estate developer held a cardboard box containing $200,000 in cash today and pleaded with the kidnappers of his wife to return her safely because I have the money and I've got two children who need their mother.

title: Ernest Simon Dies
description: Ernest P. Simon, columnist for The Port Washington, News, who was the oldest known working newspaperman on Long Island, died Thursday at St. Francis Hos. pital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 86 years old and lived in Roslyn Heights.

title: Reading Plan Aids Poor Pupils in Chicago
Private Mail Delivery V. the Letter of the Law
description: The United States Postal Service is rotten, do you know that? Patricia Brennan said yesterday. I think next year they're going to charge 17 cents to mail a letter. Do you think service will get any better? Of course not. But when it goes to 25 cents I hope they have the decency to issue a Jesse James commemorative.

title: BEAME OFFERS POST TO NEWSWEEK CHIEF
description: Mayor Beame has offered the demanding job of leading the city's changing economic development program to Osborn Elliott, the chairman and editorinchief of Newsweek magazine.

Faulty 25Cent Part Silenced the Debate
description: A faulty, 25cent electronic part about the size of a cigarette butt was identified by engineering sleuths yesterday as the gremlin that silenced the Presidential debates Thursday night before a national television audience.

description: The Jets discovered yesterday that the nagging pain in Carl Barzilauskas's side was a broken rib.

ARTHUR W. CROSBIE
description: WILLIMANTIC, Conn,, Sept. 24, (UPI) Arthur W. Crosbie, general manager of the Willimantic Chronicle and a business and civic leader, died yesterday at Windham Memorial Community Hospital. He was 56 years old.

description: GLICKMANRabbi Jack Stanley, Memorial Day is second day of Rosh Hashanah from 207579St. Brooklyn, N. Y. C.

title: Man Killed in Jersey Crash
description: BRICK TOWN, NJ., Sept. 24 (UPI)Thomas Burnett, 24 years old, of Brick Town was killed and a passenger in his car was injured critically today in a highway crash. The passenger, Mark Cividanes, 21, of Howell Township was admitted to Point Pleasant Hospital in critical condition. The police said the car had run off a road on a curve and struck a tree as the men headed home from a. tavern.

title: Presidential Debate Scored Low Rating in a Cleveland Bar
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 24From the start there was no shortage of clues as to what President Ford and Jimmy Carter were up against in trying to impress the patrons of Johnny's Bar, deep in Cleveland's Fifth Ward: an urban meltingpot of 22,000 people, where the local economy depends on the steel mills in the valley and the auto plants across town, where the mixture of ethnic cultures is rich and tangy, and the Roman Catholic Church strong, and the Democratic Party overwhelmingly dominant.

Republican Leader Is Indicted
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 (AP)  A Federal grand jury has indicted Theodore S.A. Rubino, chairman of the Chester County Republican Party, on an extortion charge, according to the United States Attorney's office. Mr. Rubino; 66 years old, was charged yesterday with extorting $6,400 from an architectural concern in connection with a renovation project at Memorial Hospital in West Chester.

title: Jazz Program
description: It has been a long time since a jazz band with as powerful and liftingly exuberant an attack as Ted Curson's Septet has been heard around town. The group first set back New Yorkers ears last Spring, doing a month at the Tin Palace as well as dominating one of the programs at the Newport Jazz Festival in July. Now that Mr. Curson is back from his customary summer European tour, the group is at Boomer's, 340 Bleecker Street, through tonight, playing with an even tighter ensemble feeling than beforeand that simply increases the jubilant power of its attack.

title: 11 Arrested, 7 Hurt In Racial Incidents At a Boston School

Dance: Painter Link Is Revived
description: The simultaneous artistic event was a feature of many avantgarde dance concerts of the 1960's. Actors would do a playlet side by side with dancers who were performing an independent dance work of their own. Occasionally, an artist such as Robert Rauschenberg would paint while Merce Cunningham's Company would dance. In a few instances, the collaboration was fruitful, but for the most part nothing of note was accomplished. The continuance of the painterdancer tradition into the mid70's by Barbara and Tom Gardner in their work Yes was somewhat of a surprise at the Construction Company Studio on Thursday evening.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A burglary suspect was seized yesterday when the halfton safe he allegedly was trying to rob fell on him and broke his pelvis, the police said. The suspect, Ezekio S. Figuera, 22 years old, of Woodbury, telephoned the police for help from the Woodbury City Hall after the safe fell on him. He was listed as in fair condition at Underwood Memorial Hospital. It took six men to lift the safe off him.

Representatives. of the teachers and the school board agreed yesterday on a new contyiet, but withheld details pending ratifidation. The dispute had centered on wages, fringe: benefits and teachers demands for binding arbitration to settle grievances.

Geiger scored on a keeper play and passed to Tom Hailey for an I8yard touchdown in the second quarter and to Steve Richards for a 27yard touchdown in the fourth.

title: Connecticut Mayor Hurt in Crash
description: ANSONIA, Conn., Sept. 24 (AP)Mayor Michael J. Adanti of Ansonia was hospitalized today after his car crashed into a utility pole here, the police said. A spokesman at Griffin Hospital in Derby said Mr. Adanti, who is the Democratic nominee for the Congress from the Fifth District. was in goodcondition and was admitted for observation.

title: Former Sen. Paul H. Douglas Dies
description: Former Democratic Senator Paul H. Douglas, a champion of liberal causes who represented Illinois for 18 years, died yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 84 years old.

title: Harry King Dies at 86
description: Harry O. King, a mining executive who served in 1933 as administrator of the National Recovery Administration and from 1950 to 1962 as special assistant to the chief of staff of the United States Air Force, died Tuesday in New York City He was 86 years old.

title: Maoists Run Struggling Commune In Suburbs of Big Mexican City
description: MONTERREY, MexicoAt a distance, the slum called Land and Liberty looks like any of a score of squatter settlements that surround this city. Its streets are unpaved, it has no running water, its dwellings are a patchwork of stone, wood and metal and its inhabitants are shabbily dressed. But Land and Liberty is a Maoist commune, and it stands on land occupied more than three years ago in this stronghold of conservatism. The inhabitants have been organized into work groups, the slum is governed by a popular assembly and the Monterrey authorities, including the police, dare not enter.

title: Article 4  No Title
Rival of Miller Suffers a Setback In Speech at Mine Union Parley
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 24Delegates to the convention of the dissensionridden United Mine Workers union began unexpectedly today to sort out the factions that have been on the attack against Arnold R. Miller, the union's president.

title: THREE IN A L.I. FAMILY ARE SLAIN AT HOME
description: WEST ISLIP, L.I., Sept. 24An elderly couple and their middleaged daughter were found murdered in their home here last night, and Suffolk County homicide detectives have begun a nationwide search for the family's son.

title: After Strain of Month of Fasting, People of Damascus Relax, Feast, Visit Friends and Forget Problems
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 25The peopleof Damascus are in the midst of a threeday weekend of trying to forget their troubles, including tension in neighboring Lebanon, rising inflation and the fasting and penance that faithful Moslem were supposed to be doing in the month of Ramadan, which has just ended.

title: MCIAL FIGHTS VEX SOUTH BOSTON HIGH
description: BOSTON, Sept. 25Throughout the school clay, the white pupils walk out the front door and down the steps of South Boston High School in one's and two's.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Chicago Cuba, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 2 P.M. (Tele. visionChannel 9, 2 P.M.)

title: CUSTOM BUT NOT COSTLY
description: Design  build firms have a strong financial advantage over architects and a strong design advantage over builders, and they are taking business away from both. RafterJohnston's work is not so subtle as Bohlin & Powell's because it is not architecture intended for a handful of rather sophisticated clients, but architecture designed to compete directly with the standardized output of builders in the New CanaanWilton, Conn., area. RafterJohnston is a designbuild firm, and it seeks clients who are either financially unable to afford an architect or a bit too conservative for most customdesigned houses, but who instinctively sense that they want something better than the standard Connecticut builder's 1976 colonial. And what they get is a great deal better than the massproduced hurricane lamps and Georgian doorways that each day seem to fill more and more of the Connecticut suburban landscape.

title: Deborah Stoddard is Married To Blair Fahnestock Baldwin
description: The marriage of Deborah Stoddard, daughter of Mrs. Fillmore Morgan of New York and Howland Bradford Stoddard of Ellsworth, Me., to Blair Fahnestock Baldwin took place yesterday afternoon in the chantry of St. Thomas Episcopal Church. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. John G. Winslow and W. Barton Baldwin Jr., both of New York. The Rev. John Andrew performed the ceremony.

title: Come Again In the Spring
description: What with all those books for children explaining the process andmeaning of death, it's good to fmd one book where death comes out second best, Death, dressed in a great bearskin coat and carrying a ledger, comes for Old Hark in midwinter as he is scattering seen tor the birds. But Hark's not ready; the birds have to be fed. I ain't going. Come again in the spring. he says. Death has a schedule to keep and thinks of having a tree fall on the old man's head but the ledger calls for his exit quiet, gentle peaceful. Three wagers ensue between Death and Hark. and it looks like it's curtains for the old codger, especially after the third wager. Death, however, didn't reckon on Harks love for the birds.

title: Italy Wins Cup Doubles; Leads Australia by 2 to 1
description: ROME, Sept. 25 (AP)Adriano Panetta and. Paolo Bertolucci crushed the experienced Australian team of John Newdombe and Tony Roche, 63, 64, 63, today and gave Italy a 21 lead in their threeoffive Davis Cup tennis semifinal series.

title: Miss Barnum And a Lawyer Are Married
description: Serena Sears Barnum and monies Butler Eastland 2d were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Carroll C. Barbour in St. Edmund's Episcopal Church in San Marino, Calif.

title: AUGUSTA G. LEEDS
description: Augusta Glose Leeds, a vaudeville actress at the turn of the century and until her retirement in 1919, died Friday in Roosevelt Hospital at the age of 99. She lived at 320 East 72d Street.

title: Memorial Seruiceo
description: GLICKMANRabbi Jack Stanley, Memorial Day is second day of Rosh Hashanah from 207579st. Brooklyn N. Y. C.

title: ART
description: THE former Baptist Church on Piermont Road here was more like a bustling Moslem marketplace last week than a sedate Christian residence. The nave, transept, chancel and other parts of the deconsecrated building have been exuberantly embellished with a resplendent assortment of folkart items and crafts from around the world.

title: Jenkins Again. Sparkles As Hackley Again Wins
description: Paul Jenkins is giving the Hackley School's football fans a lot to talk about these weekends. Last week the senior halfback scored twice in a rout of Horace Mann and yesterday he tallied twice more as the Tarrytown team defeated New York Military Academy. 136. Jenkins barely gave the Hackley fans a chance to sit as he ran the opening kickoff 85 yards for a touchdown. Then, after N.Y.M.A. tied the score at 66 later in the first period. Jenkins

title: Tobacco: Leaf to Cigarette
description: For the last 20 years I've been puffing away on two packs of Chesterfields a day. in Durham, N.C., a tobacco town if there ever was one, I decided to seek out the source of the stains on my fingers, the holes in my clothes and the perennial cough in my throat. In a couple of stops I was able to seefree of chargevirtually the entire process by which a fansize leaf of tobacco is converted into a cigarette and packaged for the consumer. Any visitor to Durham can do the same.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: IAM a garden moron. I say it without humility. it just happens to be true. Otherwise enough of a mental giant to cross a street on the red lightor is it the green?and to fill out an incometax blank with the help of an accountant, I can wander about a garden for hours without absorbing the most elementary knowledge.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Tokyo: Culture Shock Makes The Head Spin
description: Tar daisapew and close automatically, and if you are a bumpkin from America you may get bopped a few times before you remember it. A monorail brings passengers from the airport to the edge of the business district; it is a rapid, obstaclehopping minitrain that runs over waterways, swoops under bridges, sneaks between buildings and parallels (and mocks) jammed expressways.

title: Speedboat
description: Back in the days when Renata Adler was writing movie reviews for The New York Times, various filmbuffs I knew used to complain that her approach was too intellectualized, too sociological or even philosophicalthat as a critic she was insensitive to both the formal esthetics and the cruder emotional impact of the medium. I can imagine similar complaints being raised against her first novel, Speedboat, by those whowhether realists, surrealists, or French think they know what a real novel is or ought to be. Certainly Speedboat makes no concession to any cravingvulgar or sophisticatedfor an engrossing narrative. Furthermore, though concerned fleetingly with motivations, Speedboat avoids the sustained psychological rendering of character as rigorously as the novels of RobbeGrillet, but without attempting their quasimusical purity as linguistic constructs. The book does have an emotional impacta strong onebut one that derives more from a painfully exact transcription of the life many of us lead than from the creation of a powerfully imagined fictional world. From almost any approach one chooses to take, Speedboat is a nonnovel.

title: Hard Labor
description: Cesare Pavese is best known to American readers as the author of a series of evocative short novels that to an extent share the vocabulary and concerns of postwar realist Italian cinema. (His Selected Works, translated by R. W. Flint and available in paperback from Farrar, Straus & Giroux, includes three of the novels and a novella.) Pavese has been seen as a realist because his novels explore the irreparably rent social fabric of mid century Italian society from a clearsighted though impassioned socialist perspective. But the dynamic tension between the earthcentered peasant world of Pavese's native Piedmontese hills and the sophisticated, alienating city of Turin, where he worked as a translator, teacher and editor and where he took his own life in 1950 at the age of 42, assumes a role of mythic importance in his work, lending it a personal, poetic intensity that belies its objective surface.

title: Yale Downs UConn, 2110; Pagliaro Star
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn.. Sept. 25 (UPI)John Pagliaro broke lose for two secondhalf touchdowns today to enable Yale to post a 2110 victory over Connecticut.

title: Casey Stengel, Facts and Much Fiction
description: Casey Stengel has been dead for year. it is harsh to say, but everyone seems to agree that that's what he is. In itself, this is a kind of enlightened thinking. After all, not every legend has been allowed to die.

title: Glass Industry Faces Pollution Test
description: EIGHT months ago, the Byrne administration tried to relax New Jersey's airpollution standards in order to allow the state's $160millionayear glass industry more freedom. The Federal Environmental Protection Agency objected, saying that New Jersey had not followed established procedures for easing the standards, including not having held public hearings about the effect of such action.

title: In Search of Leadership
description: WASHINGTONThe basic choice confronting voters in this election is whether they want a pleasing personality or a leader in the White House.

title: South Africa is Silent On Rhodesia Proposals; Acclaims Vorster's Role
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 25The South African Government remained silent today on the settlement plan for Rhodesia, apart from an assertion by the Information Minister, Connie P. Mulder, that Prime Minister John Vorster deserved the Nobel Peace Prile for his contribution to the accord.

title: Postal Employees On Strike in Spain; 2 Leaders Seized
description: MADRID, Sept. 25Several thousand postal workers in Spain are tying up the mails for the third time this year to push wage demands in a major test of the Government's ability to keep down labor tensions while it proceeds with political reform.

title: PEOPLE
description: TWO 14yearold Northport boys are missing the opening of their juniorhighschool classes this month, but they'll be back soon. The boysJohn Hornick and York Johnsonhave been designated Peacetime Heroes for the rescue of John's twin sister, Jane, and two other girls from a fire last June in an old shed being used by the girls as a clubhouse. The honor was bestowed by Operation Plus Ultra, a 12yearold international effort by Iberia, the Spanish airline. John, York and 14 other youngsters from the United States, Europe, Africa and South America have been so designated. And as a result, the boys have gone off to see the King and Queen of Spain. They have also been to Disney World, had an audience with the Pope, and been to receptions with the United Nations SecretaryGeneral, Kurt Waldheim, and Mayor Beame.

title: Education
description: When the children of Benton Harbor, Mich., began the school year this month, 150 first graders in the city's Title I schools carried home a recipe for a Home Education Learning Project.

title: Response to a Police Appeal for Horses is Called Overwhelming
description: The public response to a New York City Police Department request for gift horses for its mounted units has been fantastic and overwhelming, the department said yesterday.

title: Yugoslavia and Rumania Are Believed to Have Problems With a Project for Joint Production of Jet Fighter
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 23Plans by Rumania and Yugoslavia for joint production of a Yugoslavdesigned fighter plane, intended to reduce dependence of both countries on foreign arms supplies, appear to have bogged down in technical complications.

title: roupees
description: In 1972, Neal Slavin, a successful commercial photographer whose artistic credentials include representation in the permanent collections of the Museum of Modern Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art, came across his brotherinlaw's Boy Scout troop picture. The more he examined it the more his initial stereotyped impression of the group dissolved and the inherent individualism of each member asserted itself.

title: ART VIEW
description: WASHINGTON The first thing to be said about the Morris Louis exhibition at the National Gallery of Art (through Jan. 9) is this it is a very beautiful show. The eye is ravished by an experience of color that, though subtle in design and carefully calculated in effect, is nonetheless simple, fresh and direct. There is nothing hidden or mysterious in these paintings, and nothing metaphysical in our experience of them. They canture the eve with an easy immediacy, and hold it by eliminating everything but a naked appeal to the kind of optical pleasure that color, and color alone, can offer. Color is what Louis's painting is essentially about, writes E. A. Carmean Jr., the curator at the National Gallery who organized this exhibition and wrote its catalogue  a judgment everywhere confirmed in the paintings on view.

title: AT ONCE A RUGGED CABIN AND A GLASS BOX
description: A new house is never cheap. There is simply too much that has to be done when a completely new building is erectedfrom laying a foundation to creating sewage linesto permit construction costs to be really minimal. unless a house is being built as part of a massproduced tract development  la Levittown and its builder take advantage of economies of scale. But there is little tract development going on right now, and, in any event, it is a kind of construction that by its very nature does little to satisfy the desire for a distinctive and expressive living environment. The kind of building that does satisfy that desirea house designed by an architectinevitably costs more.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: I plan to have the oak floors in my house refinished and want to know which is more durable and scratchresistantgym seal or urethane. Also, which would give me a dull finish?Mrs. J. P., Rockville Centre, N. Y.

title: The Monarchs
description: The season's last hatch of Monarch butterflies is on the wing, and the milkweed they fed on is turning to a rich golden yellow. The Monarchs soon will be swarming and starting south. Incredible as it seems, these big orange and black butterflies migrate, even as the birds. Those from our area go all the way to Florida for the winter.

title: John F. Cowans to Wed Miss WooddCahusac
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Anglin WooddCahusac of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Lee WooddCahusac, to John Frederick Cowans, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Cassils Cowans of St. Andrews, New Brunswick. The wedding is planned for Oct. 30 at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: Left and Right Have New Meaning in Europe
description: PARISThroughout Europe, especially in France, it is normal for many people to identify themselves by saying I'm a man of the left, sometimes even with hand an heart. it is rare to find people who will volunteer that they are on the right.

title: Haig Says NATO Drills Respond To Gain in Warsaw Pact Abilities
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 25The North Atlantic alliance has responded to changes in the EastWest strategic balance with a series of exercises intended to tighten the combat readiness of its military forces.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: CONSUMER PRICES rose in August by 0.5 percent, the Labor Department reported. This meant the inflation rate remained steady in August. The Consumer Price Index climbed to 171.9 with 1967 equal to 100  New orders for durable goods received by manufacturers in August declined 2.2 percent to an adjusted $47.66 billion, following a 2.4 percent decline in July, the Commerce Department said. it also adjusted upward the real gross national product increase for the second quarter to 4.5 percent from 4.3 percent, and adjusted upward aftertax corporate profits for the same period to an annual rate of $82.7 billion from $81.1 billion.

title: Coaches Call National Organization Part of Swim Irnprovement Answer
description: In the aftermath of what one women's coach called The Games to Forget, concern has replaced confidence as the mood in America's competitive swim program.a program of daily blood tests to help determine what type of workloads swimmer could handle without overstressing the body. Each athlete pays $4 a day for the test; Schubert, with the assistance of a local medical laboratory, receives the results the same day in time to discuss them with the team physician and adjust afternoon workouts.

title: Unde feated N. Carolina Squeaks By Army, 3432
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 25North Carolina, ranked 16th nationally by one poll and installed as a 16point favorite over Army today, managed to stretch its undefeated record to 40 with a 3432 victory over a stubborn Cadet team, but it was not easy. The closeness of the game had Bill Dooley, the Tarheels head coach, clutching for his worry beads again.

title: Yanks Win Division Title
description: The New York Yankees clinched the American League's Eastern Division title when the Baltimore Orioles lost to the Boston Red Sox. The Yankees had won earlier in Detroit. Section 5.

title: News Summary
description: Joshua Nkomo, a Rhodesian nationalist leader told a group of supporters in Salisbury that a turning point may have been reached in Rhodesia. Mr. Nkomo, who spent five months traveling abroad in search of backing for black majority rule, is thought to be playing a key role in the formation of the interim biracial government. in his remarks, he played down reports of splits among the nationalist groups. [Page 1, Col. 6.]

title: Avoiding. The Worst
description: Although it is likely to he the most important event in the Presidential campaign, the debate last week between Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter produced little that was either stimulating nr new about the candidates capacities, characters and intentions.

title: Are Art Exchanges a Game of Propaganda?
description: Are certain international loan exhibitions, such as the forthcoming Treasures of Tutankhamun from Egypt, actually attempts to exploit American museums for propaganda purposes? is the U. S. State Department sweetening its dealings with foreign governments by facilitating the Tut show and othersthe Chinese archeological exhibition of two years ago, and a spate of Russian extravaganzas?

title: Sculptor Expelled by Moscow Is in the U.S. Looking for Work
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  Ernst Neizvestny, the Russian sculptor who left the Soviet Union in March, stood in the center of his hotel room, sketches strewn under the window, blownup photographs piled on the bed, manuscripts sitting on the dresser.

title: Techniques for Hiding Plywood's End Grain
description: PLYWOOD is a versatile building material that is almost universally used nowadays for constructing wood shelves, furniture, cabinets and other builtins around the house. However, it does pose one problem that those who work with solid lumber don't have to facehow to cover up or otherwise treat the end grain which is normally exposed along edges and outside corners.

title: The Logic of Numbers and History in Southern Africa
description: JOHANNESBURGFor a man who had been squeezed into a surrender by his only ally, Rhodesian Prime Minister Ian Smith was remarkably restrained. What happens here will inevitably affect the entire subcontinent, he said, in the only passage of his speech that could have been construed as an admonition to South Africa. it was a sentiment to which all involved in last week's negotiations on a plan to bring majority rule in Rhodesia within twn years including Prime Minister John B. Vorster of South Africa, could assent. Where they differed was in their intepretations of how black rule in the former British colony would affect the territory's immediate neighbors, notably South Africa.

title: Boat Builder Follows Old Methods
description: OLD SAYBROOK, Conn., Sept. 25 (AP) Earle Brockway knocks out 250 wooden boats a year, mostly because he says he doesn't know how to do anything else.

title: YUGOSLAVIA SEES GAINS FROM A CARTER VICTORY
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 23There are growing signs that the Yugoslav Government hopes a victory by Jimmy Carter will result in a friendlier White House and a marked improvement in the currently strained relationsm between Belgrade and Washington.

title: Oehmig Regains Crown In Senior Golf. 4 and 3
description: DENVER, Sept. 25 (AP)Lewis Oehmig of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., played par golf today and defeated John Richardson, 4 and 3, in the United States Golf Association seniors championship at Cherry Hills Country Club. Oehmig, who won the title in 1972, defeated the petroleum engineer from Laguna Miguel, Calif., with better putting.

title: Kings Point 27, Gettysburg 10
description: KINGS POINT, L.I., Sept. 25Fred McDonough caught three touchdown passes in the first half as Kings Point registered a 2710 victory over Gettysburg today.

title: Rally by Brien McMahon Pays Off
description: Paul Daniello scored three touchdowns, two within a threeminute span in the third quarter, to lead Brien McMahon of Norwalk to an 1813 victory over Greenwich.

title: PhiHies Beat Expos, Gain Division Tie
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 25The Philadelphia Phillies clinched a tie for the National League East Division title today when Mike Schmidt clouted his 37th homer of the season and drove in three runs in a 65 victory over the Montreal Exnos.

title: Islanders Turn Back Sabres, 53
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Sept. 25Call it a case of preseason blahs, meaning you can't expect too much when the regulars are giving the rookies a chance to get ice time.

title: Home Style.
description: Praise be. Kathy and Mel Garfinkel are finally ready to paint the interior of their churchturnedhome in Hoboken, N. J. After just two and a half years of renovation work, too. Another year or so, they figure, and their house will be finished.

title: Week's Hearings Set By City Council Units
description: New York City Council committees will hold the following public hearings this week:

title: NATHANIEL L. BEDFORD
description: Nathaniel L. Bedford, who was for many years special assistant to the president of the Standard Register Company of Dayton, Ohio, manufacturer of business forms, died Friday at his home in Pelham, N. Y., at the age of 91. He retired in 1955, but afterward was a businessforms consultant with an office at 362 Madison Avenue in Manhattan until a few years ago. His first wife, the former Ethel Delanuslut, died 10 years ago. He is survived by his second wife, the former Thelma Smith; a son, Nathaniel F of Mountain takes, N. J.; four grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren.

title: Lady Oracle
description: Joan Foster has an identity crisis with a difference she knows who she is all right, but there are too many of her. As Joan, she is the colorless wife of Arthur, a pompous graduate student who spends most of his time flitting from one tiny leftist movement to another. As Louisa K. Delacourt, she is an enthusiastic writer of the sort of quickie Gothics that are sold in the dime stores she claims to work at when she's really at the library doing costume research. Joan chose her nom de plume in honor of her Aunt Lou, the only person who cared about her when she was a miserable, fat teenager, and this past is another secret: Arthur must never find out that her stories of highschool popularity and cheerieading are lies. It's a hard act to keep up. When Joan produces Lady Oracle, a book of automatic writing described by her publishers as halfway between Rod McKuen and Kahlil Gibran, her new status as the toast of Toronto brings her little pleasure. Now, for sure, her secrets will all come out the Gothics, the obesity, the rancorous, lonely childhood, and her new lover, who calls himself the Royal Porcupine and stages avantgarde exhibitions of freezers full of runover animals. Threatened with blackmail, Joan fakes her own death and runs off to Italy to sort her selves out.

title: The World
description: Arter 44 years of Socialist rule that gave Sweden one of the world's more advanced welfare states, the voters have apparently decided that while they like what they have, they do not want increased state involvement in their lives. in an election last week, Prime Minister Olof Palme's Social Democratic Party was defeated. Thorbjorn Falldin, leader of the Center Party, will form a new Government from his own and two other nonSocialist parties.

title: The bribe busters
description: A few years ago, after the Securities and Exchange Commission suspended trading in the stock of ParvinDohrmann Company, a gogo outfit with multiple Las Vegas and other interests, a group of lawyers from the company marched into the office of Stanley Sporkin, then deputy director of the Commission's Division of Enforcement. Sporkin's men were in the process of investigating ParvinDohrmann, looking for evidence of fraud, and that activity had prompted the halt in trading.

title: and little mac
description: MC DONALD'S, with its great hamburgers, is, of course, one of the most lucrative businesses in the nation, having an exceedingly low overhead because its personnel are youngsters.

title: Heriberto Kahn is Dead at 31; Was a Top Argentine Reporter
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 25Heriberto Kahn, an outstanding political reporter who exposed corruption and the existence of rightwing death squads during the rule of the Peronist Government, died carlv yesterday after a long illness.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Chicago Cubs conclude a threegame series against the Mets with a 2:05 P.M. game in Shea Stadium today. The Mets finish their home season with games against the Montreal Expos at 5:30 P.M. for a twilightnight doubleheader tomorrow and 8:05 P.M. Tuesday and 7:05 P.M. Wednesday. The Yankees end their regular season against the Cleveland Indians at Yankee Stadium at 8 P.M. Friday and 2 P.M. Saturday and Sunday.

title: The Golf Clinic
description: The prevalent opinion on the Professional Golfers Association tour is that if you were picking a man to attempt one putt that was worth everything you ownhouse, car, swizzle stick collectionyou would choose Jack Willam Nicklaus.

title: Buckley is Defying Decent Liberalism, Moynihan Charges
description: Daniel P. Moynihan accused Senator James L. Buckley yesterday of being a man who consistently and massively and only says no to the tradition of decent liberalism that New York State has always stcod for.

title: Beverly Norsworthy Rewed
description: Beverly Norsworthy, widow of Richard W. Norsworthy, and Alden C. Winchell were married yesterday by the Rev. Walter P. Hurley in Christ Episccipal Church in Harwich Port, Mass. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Allan Tubman of South Harwich, Mass. Mr. Winchell is a nephew of Mr. and Mrs. Parker Holmes of Barnstable, Mass. The couple Plan to live in Harwich.

title: In Iran, It's Alms to the Poor and the Rich
description: TEHERAN, IranThe Pahlavi Foundation gives artificial limbs to amputees. it hands out fuel to poor families. It cares for orphans.

title: Massone Named Coach
description: Mike Massone, who was graduated In June from St. Francis College in Brooklyn, has been named coach of the college's crosscountry team. He was a member of the crosscountry and track teams in 1975 and this year.

title: A Talk With Alex Haley
description: As I look at it now, says Alex Haley, it seems there was a meanttobe quality about Roots I first heard the story told by my grandmother as a child, that was the real beginning. Cynthia was her name but we all called her Miss Sis and, after the death of her husband, she lost her vitality, became numb. She would sit on the porch, with her reveries. Just sittin, she would say. Whenever we children came around, she would repeat the story of the man she called the African, how he was captured and what happened to him when he arrived in America. After a while we started acting out the incidents, playacting, recreating everything she told us, and it became an indelible memory for me.

title: The Region
description: The effort by Daniel P. Moynihan, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, to capture the center of New York State's political spectrum and push his opponent, incumbent Conservative  Republican James L. Buckley, into a deep hole on the far right, received unanticipated support last week from New York's other Senator, Republican Jacob K. Javits.

title: Living Apart, But Together
description: WHEN Gemma Philcox first suggested that she and her husband, George, live in separate apartments, he was adamant in his opposition. Now, after two years of living in his and her apartments, Mr. Philcox wonders why he ever worried.

title: Iowa Upsets Penn State, 76, On Quartaro's Conversion
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Sept. 25 (AP)  Tom Renn raced 2 yards for a firstperiod touchdown, and Nick Quartaro kicked the winning conversion today as Iowa upset Penn State, 76, in a college football game.

title: Alsocland Fresil
description: Alsocland Fresil

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The CocaCola Bottling Company of New York has bought a 226,000squarefoot structure in Paterson, N.J., for use as a softdrink warehouse. The seller was the Continental Group, Inc., which had used the eightyearold faas a can warehouse.

title: Letters
description: The Sept. 5 New York Times Magazine cover (You make me sick, Basics!) showing raw, stark hatred on the face of the man confronting the terrified young woman cadet, [below] and the accompanying article, Kill, hatemutilate! (by Grace Lichtenstein), made me sick. To what abyss of perversion have we sunk when the supposed elite of our youththe very leaders who one day are expected to be officers and gentlemen in our mighty armed forcesget their basic indoctrination (brainwashing) in killing, hating and mutilating? Can anyone now question how My Lai could have hapPENED?

title: The Guest Word
description: Not long ago a commercial for Inglenook wine that pretends to depict a joyous moment in a fiction writer's life was widely broadcast on network TV. Skillfully and expensively produced, may well succeed in selling Inglenook, but in its revelation of writers and what they are about, it is illogical and strangely troubling.

title: FISHING
description: THE next few weeks should be great for fishing off the Jersey coast, barring any drastic changes in the water temperaLire. The fall bluefish run is now under way, providing good to excellent action from the Cholera Banks south to the A ???alon Shoals. Bonito and albacore aiso are productive off shore, while fluke are along the jetties and beaches.

title: Discrimination in Hiring in Broadway Orchestras Charged by Mrs. Norton
description: The city's Commission on HumanRights has said that musicians from minority groups are being systematically excluded from orchestras for most Broadway musicals and that it will begin an investigation into the matter.

title: Carolyn H. Staniford, Editor, Engaged to Todd Sollis
description: Carolyn Houghton Staniford, an assistant editor of House and Garden magazine, and Todd Bryant Sollis, lawyer with the New York firm of White & Case, plan to be married on Oct. 30.

title: Showing at Los Angeles Has Morale Factor
description: LOS ANGELES, SEPT. 25It's pretty early in the football season for a team to face a makeorbreak situation, but the New York Giants will be perilously close to one when they face the Los Angeles Rams at the Coliseum tomorrow afternoon (4 P.M. New York time, televised on Channel 2).

title: Energizing Energy Conservation
description: EVERY morning Edwin F. Shelley gets up, drives to his Old Westbury office in an aircon??? car, Washes up in an airconditioned bathroom, turns on all the lights in his office sits down behind his deskand thinks up ways Americans could save energy.

title: In CloseUp:
description: Over the next couple of weeks there will be an impression around here that the normal order of forces in the movie world has been rearranged. American films, which usually dominate the scene in promotion and accessibility, if not m quality, will be temporarily submerged by a flood of foreign films.

title: Notre Dame 48, Northwestern 0
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Sept. 25 (UPI) Rick Slager, in setting a Notre Dame singlegame pass completion record, threw three touchdown passes today and AI Hunter ran for two touchdowns as the Fighting Irish defeated Northwestern, 480.

title: Little Though I Be
description: Big though I be, it is still possible to sympathize with the diminutive offspring trying to win the approval of an insensitive father in Little Though I Be. Timothy a dreamer. loves books, birds and beasts. His father admires his two tall sons brute strength, but scorns tiny Timothy for neglecting his chores. Sooner than food from.

title: BANQUETTES ARE THE BASIS
description: Pat and Steven Ross's hectic business careers make it imperative that their rented onebedroom apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan require very little maintenance. At 30, Pat, who uses her maiden name, Green, in business, runs her fouryearold wallpaper firm, Groundworks Inc.; Steven recruits executive personnel. Instead of purchasing furniture at a department store, they had banquettes built in their living room and shopped for accessories and nearantiques at small shops and outoftown flea markets.

title: The search for Carter
description: Plains was different from what one expected. Maybe it was the name, but anticipation had been of a dry and dusty town with barren vistas, ramshackle warehouses and timeless, flybuzzing, sunbaked afternoons. Instead, Plains was green. As one approached, the fields were green and the trees were tall. The heat of southern Georgia was as hot in summertime as it promised to be, but there was shade under the elms, the pecan trees and the oaks, and if the streets were wide, the foliage was rich enough to come together overhead. A surprising number of houses were big and white and wooden and looked to be 50 years old or more. Some were a hundred years old. They had porches and trees in the front yard, and lawns ran a good distance from the front door to the sidewalk while the grass to the rear of the house meandered leisurely into the back yard of the house on the street behind. Some homes might be newly painted, and some were shabby, but the town was pleasant and spread out for a population of 683 inhabitants. By comparison with meaner looking places with a gas station, barbecue shack, general store, junkyard, empty lots and spilled gasoline, a redneck redolence of dried ketchup and hamburger napkins splayed around thinshanked, dusty trees, Plains felt peaceful and prosperous. it had the sweet deep green of an oldfashioned town that America has all but lost to the Interstates and the ranch houses, the mobile homes and the condominiums, the neon strips of hottedup truck stops and the static pall of shopping centers. Plains had an antique store on the main street that must have been a hundred feet deep, and it was owned by Alton Carter, Jimmy Carter's uncle; Plains had a railroad running througn the middle of the main street and a depot that was not more than twice as long as a tinker's wagon: Plains had an arcade one block long (the length of the main street) and all the stores were in the shade under the arcade, including a brand new restaurant called The Back Porch with white tin ceilings 15 feet high, fourblade propeller fan turning overhead and chickensalad sandwiches with a touch of pineapple and a touch of peppertasty. Plains was that part of America which hitherto had been separate from the media, the part that offered a fundamental clue to the nature of establishment itself, One could pass through a hundred small towns in a state, and 20 or 30 might be part of a taproot for the establishment of its capitol 20 draw upon. A place like Plains could be modest by the measure of its income and yet offer an unmistakable wellordered patina, a promise that the mysterious gentility of American life was present, that there were still people interested in running things without showing the traces, that the smalltown establishment remained a factor to be taken account of among all the other factors like exhaust roar and sewage slick and those plastic toylands stretching to the American horizon.

title: MORE THAN JUST A FACADE
description: Dr. and Mrs. Baruch Boxer wanted to turn the twocar garage of their 1950's Cape Cod house in suburban New Jersey into a more usable family room. Because Baruch Boxer is a geographer at Rutgers and, therefore, universityoriented, they called the architecture department at Princeton for recommendations and so found their way to Peter Waldman, an architect who teaches there.

title: Shawnee Cramer is Betrothed to James R. Baldwin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Cramer of Christiansted, St. Croix, V. I., and Williamstown, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sharon Cramer, to James R. Baldwin. He is a son of Beverly B. Baldwin of Simsbury, Conn. and Robert A. Baldwin of Cromwell, Conn.

title: Mets Gain 83d Victory, 52, Tying Team Mark of Sorts
description: Although this season's version of the Mets has been largely a disappointment, it seems certain to roll up the secondhighest total of victories in the club's 15year history.

title: An Economic Opportunity
description: LONG ISLAND is geographically and legally in the middle of the East Coast offshore oil issue and at a critical time in the economic and ecology history of the Island. To date, our elected officials have translated their interpretation of public opinion into, policy and actions intended to prevent the exploration and development of oil resources north and south of Long Island. it may be in the best interest of the majority of our citizens to reverse this policy at this time.

title: The Kissinger Round
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  in the first Presidential debate, Jimmy Carter got bis wandering campaign back on course, but the second debate (San Francisco, Oct. 6) will be on foreign and defense policy and here the President should have a clear advantaee.

title: Cosmos Rally to Tie Stars
description: TOKYO, Sept. 25 (AP)The New York Cosmos of the North American Soccer League twice rallied to tie an all Japan team, 22, today before 50,000 fans. Giorgio Chinaglia scored the Cosmos second goal.

title: James Moore 3d Marries Miss Tully
description: Catharine Mary Tully, assistant manager of the men's division of Bloomingdale's in New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to James B. Moore 3d in Pelham Manor, N.Y. Msgr. Vincent Jeffers performed the ceremony in Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church.

title: A.S.P.C.A. is Moving to Restore Its Old Reputation
description: The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals has been a dominant force in the humane movement for more than a century. Founded by Henry Bergh, the son of a wealthy New York shipbuilder, it has included among its charter members James J. Roosevelt, John Jacob Astor Jr., August Belmont, Peter Cooper and Horace Greeley. of late, the 110yearold organization has been involved in lawsuits and has run into financial difficulties. There had been much criticism that the organization was a richman's club, with many of its members not actively engaged in the humane movement.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Unfortunately, your remarks on the transformation of New York's Five Points [5 Points Moral: in Time Place Transcends Its Past, Aug. 29] obscures our already dim understanding of Nineteenth century city life.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THIS is a detective story. it is about two young men and their lives over a twoweek period. It is an account of how we reconstructed their activities with a high degree of accuracy in a short time. Since we had been out to the Hamptons, where people speak in such terms, I would call it an example of how one life style emerges when, the other generation withdraws from the scene; nature abhors a gap and, believe me, it was filled to the brim.

title: Proud Delta Captures Beldame by 3 Lengths
description: About two hours before the 5108,200 Beldame was run at Belmont Park yesterday, Jorge Velasquez, who was to ride Montpelier's Proud Delta, looked at the past performances of the eight horses in the race and said he thought his filly would be the winner.

title: A Correction
description: The telephone number for information on the Oct. 3 house tour in Westbury, L.I. [House Tours Calendar, Sept. 191 was listed incorrectly. The number is (516) 3335675.

title: GARDENING
description: THE clematis is valued mostly for its flowers, which the majority of New Jersey gardeners seem to think are at their height in June. This is more or less true of the largeflowered forms, but one or another smallflowered species will be in flower from May until October.

title: Furniture On the Island Before 1776
description: GENUINE American antiques have never gone begging. The art, furnishings, clothing, work tools and utensils and whatnots used by our predecessors are sought and collected with zeal by both amateur and professional antiques buffs. And there's nothing like a Bicentennial to raise that interest to a fever witch.

title: Engagements
description: Mrs. Shirley Malick of Englewood. N. J. is plecsed to announce the engagement of her daughter. Madeline Renee (daughter of the late Charles Malicia to Lawrence Calked, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Do!kart of New Milford, N.J.

title: Toms River So. Defeats Brick; Hampton Stars
description: Toms River South avenged its only 1975 loss when it surprised Brick Township, 120, in a season opener in Toms River yesterday.

title: Timothy Carrington. Marries Merrill Ware, Arts Program Aide
description: Genevieve Merrill Ware, coordinator of historicpreservation grants for the architecture program at the National Endowment for the Arts in Washington, was married there yesterday afternoon to Jimmy reau ??? Washington correspondent for Securities Week, a McGrawHill publication. The Rev. Jo C. Tarrtt performed the ceremony in Grace Episcopal Church in Georgetown.

title: Two Polls Taken After FordCarter Debate Find Viewers Gave President Slight Edge
description: Two national polls taken after Thurcrlay night's debate between President Ford and Jimmy Carter give Mr. Ford a slight edge in the encounter. The results were made public yesterday by Newsweek magazine and ABC News, the sponsors of the separate surveys.

title: A Tight Race in Texas
description: DALLAS, Sept. 25  on July 25, an unknown Georgian named Jimmy Carter met in the Stoneleigh P (for pharmacy) Cafe here with about 10 Texas Democrats who were looking for a Presidential candidate. They found one.

title: PEOPLE
description: As more people live longer, thanks to medical science, a relatively new field, gerontology, is assuming an increasingly important role in the social studies. And now a leading gerontologist, Dr. Beth B. Hess, who teaches at the County College of Morris, has collected and edited a selection of essays on the subject of aging. The collection, which is available in book form, is called Growing Old in America. in it, Dr. Hess observes, in a note to tile young: Today's aged are in the process of working out solutions that will enhance the lives of future cohorts; it remains for the other age groups to provide the goods and services needed to make such adaptation possible. We, too, shall be growing old in America.

title: Carl Coerdt Weds Constance Parsons
description: Constance Parsons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Parsons 3d of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Carl DeWitt Coerdt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Coerdt of Shaker Heights, Ohio.

title: Author's Query
description: For a critical biography of Louise Bogan (18971970), information, reminiscences and anecdotes would be welcome.

title: GARDENING
description: IN a search for the most maj'estic of all garden flowers, it would be difficult to ignore the lily. Its delicate flowers have been used to symbolize purity and peace and have long been a religious symbol to many.

title: Barbara Lois Boyd is Bride Of Richard Guilmet, Engineer
description: Barbara Lois Boyd, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James L. Boyd of Locust Valley, L.I., was married there yesterday afternoon to Richard Philip Guilmet. son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Guilmet of North Andover. Mass. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony in St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church.

title: Johanna Meier is A MadeInAmerica Opera Star
description: WHEN, late in August, City Qpera soprano Johanna Meier was the subject of a newspaper story, it was for the wrong reason on her way to a rehearsal. via one of LineOln Center's underground passageways, a mugger had attacked her, violently. Summoning up all her South Dakota true grit, Miss Meier collected herself, hurried on to the theater, and went through with her rehearsal.

title: Izzy's Posters
description: Izzy Grove is drinking coffee in the Colony restaurant on Seventh Avenue near 34th Street where his AliNorton posters are in the window.

title: Some Prep Traditions Are Still Kicking But Others Are Buried in Coffin Corners
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Sept. 22Football tradition at the Lawrenceville School thrives mainly in the athletic director's office. For the players, only the recent past seems to matter as Lawrenceville enters its 100th year of varcitv football.

title: FISHING
description: BARRING any drastic weather changes, the next few weeks should be great for fishing. The fall bluefish run has begun, providing good to excellent action from Block Island and Montauk along the South Shore and up into New York Bay.

title: Calm Puts Off Yachting
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 25There was no wind on Long Island Sound off Belle Haven Club today and the regatta for Yacht Racing Association fleets based EastofRye had to be canceled without any boats being able to start. Only one was able to reach the starting area.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: The ancient and august firm of M. Knoedler & Co. has joined the ranks of the art galleries that are now showing photographs on equal terms with paintings. After a trial run last year with a wellselected show of 1930's photographs in their basement gallery, they have opened the season this year with a major retrospective of the works of Alfred Eisenstaedt that fills not only the basement but also the main groundfloor room.

title: Poor in U.S. Rose by 2.5 Million In 1975, Most in Recent Decades
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25The number of poor persons in the United States increased by 2.5 million in 1975, the largest rise in a single year since the Government began keeping poverty statistics in 1959.

title: Yanks Bubble in Toasting End to 12Year Dry Spell
description: DETROIT, Sept. 25The New York Yankees were in the middle of a dinner party given by George Steinbrenner, the team's general partner, when the score of the Boston Red SoxBaltimore Orioles game was announced tonight.

title: F. T. C. Studies the Cost of Dying
description: America's $2billionayear funeral industry has run into some vexing problems. First, the death rate has been declining, which means a weakening of demand. And now a threeyear investigation by the Federal Trade Commission seems to be heading toward Federal regulation of the industry.

title: To Sublet Or Leave Is a Right By Law
description: Most New York apartment dwellers have the right to sublet their apartmentor break their lease, at the landlord's optioneven if the lease specifically forbids subletting. But evidently they are taking little advantage of the right, in part because it is not widely known.

title: BRIDGE
description: One might suppose that at bridge tournaments nonplaying captains are immune from the ethical problems that often afflict the members of their teams at the table, but there was an unusual exception in the final crunch of the World Team Olympiad in Monte Carlo in May.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: How about a crop of 200 apples picked from 20 trees growing in an orchard that is five by six feet? Sounds impossible? it has happened in the second year of the miniorchard's existence. This unusual fruit harvest took place recently at Hamden, Conn. where scientists are experimenting with a new type of fruit growing.

title: Headliners
description: Clifford Irving, the writer imprisoned in connection with a phony hook he wrote about the life of Howard Hughes, has cleared himself of fraud charges filed by the Internal Revenue Service. The I.R.S. said that Mr. Irving had knowingly and fraudulently concealed income from a movie made from a book of his, when he filed for bankruptcy in 1973. But a civil court judge ruled there was no intention to deceive in the bankruptcy petition, in which Irving claimed $110million in liabilities and $770 in assets. Mr. Irving served as his own attorney in the case, and wrote a sevenpage rebuttal to the arguments made by Government attorneys. It was, he said, one of the most satisfying works I have ever written.

title: Letters: Passports Pose a Safety Risk
description: On a recent WNETTV documentary on Terrorism, a hijacker revealed that on one mission he was able to separate Jews from nonJews by the passports the passengers were holding.

title: TV VIEW
description: When an alarming proportion of this fall season's new series make most of the returning programs seem like beloved classics, commercial television could be suspected of playing the devilishly subtle game of making itself look good retrospect. in reality, however, no one has been quite that clever. Operations at ABC, CBS and NBC are varying states of disarray, belching forth enough plots to start another new series entitled Panic on Sixth Avenue.

title: Problems, urban and suburban
description: Neither of these two new urban volumes will provide immediate help for New York, Newark, Cleveland or Detroit's budget woes. it is also of little solace to those of us who struggle with our daily fiscal crisis that the quality of urban writing and analysis has improved.

title: U.S. Group Formed to Press for Black Rule in Africa
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Black members of Congress and representatives of more than 100 black organizations from around the nation formed a lobby here today to press for black rule in Africa. Its first item of business was harsh criticism of the plan for shifting power from white to black hands in Rhodesia.

title: Wife Phone Listing Rejected in Vermont
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 25 (AP)A request that the first name of both husband and wife be listed in telephone directories without additional charge has been rejected by the Vermont Public Service Board.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: In his review of The My Lai Massacre and Its Coverup (Aug. 1), R. R. Baxter criticizes as inadequate the remedies which the editors of that book propose, yet he is himself apparently unaware of the paradox, if not absurdity, inherent in his own position when he states that the best protection against the recurrence of My Lai is good training, good discipline and implanting firm respect for law and human life in the hearts and minds of all members of the armed forces.

title: Ford Workers Face Hard Times
description: THERE are more than 5,000 workers at Ford's Mahwah plant, the company's largest assembly line in the United States, and those of them with families are concerned about the future under the best circumstances. A strike means almost instant hardship.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: The title of the article on the Vanderbilt Museum, A Museum Exhibition of Politics, [Aug. 15] is very apt. We in the Suffolk County Archeological Association do not know of any other area of 1.5 million population, near a large metropolitan area, with a museum budget of such magnitude ($830,000) which is run by politicians and not by museum professionals.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: There were fireworks in Wall Street last Tuesday, when the stock market suddenly broke out of a narrowand boringtrading range that had persisted since February and soared in its best singleday performance for an entire year.

title: Title IX Progress: Little Has Changed
description: Once the University of Georgia didn't even have a women's golf team. Now the university supplies each of its women golfers with one golf ball, and it gives each of its male golfers as many as he needs. That about sizes up the situation on the Title IX home front.

title: A LOST DESIGNED AROUND LIGHT
description: Four years ago, Wallace F.rench, a Canadianborn artist, his wife, Patricia who works for the Board of Education, and their 9yearold daughter, Vanessa, moved into their new loft with a hot plate, sleeping bags and a few pieces of furniture. For the next six months they camped out, amid piles of lumber and swirls of plaster until the 3,000squarefoot space became the allwhite living and work environment that it is today. Throughout this chaotic and disruptive period, Wallace French was never happier. The loft not only answered his needs for a large work studio, but also his lifelong dream to live in a sculptured space of his own creation.

title: PROTEST IS EXTENDED BY NEW YORK POLICE
description: Offduty New York City police officers who are protesting against new work schedules and deferred raises by picketing at station houses, extended their demonstrations yesterday to the homes of Mayor Beame and Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd.

title: FILM VIEW
description: I custard maims and whipped cream kills, is mayhem less brutal or death less final? This is one of the questions posed to the adult by Alan Parker's very curious English film, Bugsy Malone, a musical parody, enacted by what department stores classify as young adults, of those American gangster films produced mostly in the thirties about bigcity crime in the twenties. When you first learn that Bugsy Malone acted by kids, your stomach has every right to turn over. The heart can miss a beat. The mind bends under the awful weight of memories of radio's old Horn & Harden Children's Hour, when fouryearold tots with oddly formed vocal chords did imitations of Sophie Tucker, Harry Lauder, Helen Kane, Al Jolson and Lillian Roth. Perhaps, like me; you can also remember being forced to sit through some dreadful nonsense, made, I suppose, for children, in which chimpanzees wearing little suits and dresses and sunbonnets waddled through an entire feature film that was supposed to be a comic Western. My friends and I gave that one a groupcringe. I suppose some kids liked it but at the age of nine or ten, the members of my group thought It was overcooked rhubarb. When we spent our money on a Western, we wanted Hopelong Cassidy or Buck Jones or even Ken Maynard, not midget apes. It's not that we objected to midget apes, only to the ones who attempted to act like people. We took our movie illusions seriously.

title: Future of Arab Lands Looming As ElectionYear Issue in Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 25Israel is at the beginning of an election year that is expected to bring a debate on the nation's precarious economic state and on the future of the occupied Arab territories.

title: Toledo: A Day Trip Misses The Best of It
description: I sat crammed in a chartered bus carrying a load of American tourists back to Madrid after a day trip to Toledo. in seven hours, the tour guide had hustled us from one landmark to anotherinto the great cathedral, down endless corridors of the Alcazar, through El Greco's homeall the while spouting a dizzying spiel of facts and dates, as well as admonishing us at each stop, Hurry, hurry up. You have only a few minutes.

title: Sunday Observer
description: I painted the cellar windows, and in the process also painted extensive areas of myself and the cellar floor. It was that oilbase paint which takes days to dry, and when I stepped on the floor spatters, the paint attached itself to the soles of my shoes and stayed there until I walked upstairs and painted the livingroom rug.

title: Oklahoma Eleven is Victor Over Florida State by 249
description: NORMAN, Okla., Sept. 25 (AP)Florace Ivory scored two longrange touchdowns and Zack Henderson came up with a couple of key defensive plays today as Oklahoma registered a 249 college football victory over inspired Florida State.

title: M. W. Sands Weds Elizabeth Dietel
description: Elizabeth L. Dietel and Michael Winthrop Sands, graduates of Hampshire College in Amherst, Mass., were married yesterday afternoon. The Rev. T. Gutherie Speers, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony in a meadow of Meadow Rise Farm, home of the bride's parents in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: SOVIET SEES FRAUD IN RHODESIAN PLAN
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 25The Soviet press agency Tass described the proposed Rhodesian settlement today as fraudulent, contending that it would create a proWestern government to deflect the African national liberation movement.

title: Gate of $3.5 Million Forecast at Stadium For AliNorton Bout
description: Before he fought Joe Frazier for the third time, Muhammad confessed that his personality had attracted the world.

title: Bronx Woman and Daughter Shot Through Window of Home
description: A 35yearold woman and her 10yearold daughter were both shot through a window last night as they sat in the living room of their ground floor apartment in the Bedford Park section of the Bronx.

title: A.H. Durfee Fiance Of Jessie A. Owens
description: Mr. and Mrs. William A. Owens of Nyack, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jessie Ann Owens, to Alan Hetherington Durfee, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Durfee of South Hadley, Mass., and New Ipswich, N.H.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: I ve been ransacking the house this morning, frantically and bitterly, looking for something I'd read within no more than the past two weeks. My memory being what it is, I can't recall in exactly what magazine or newspaper I came across it. And my wife being what she is, a compulsive tidier of other people's things, I should have known that anything so vital would have vanished immediately. of course I didn't know it was vital until saw Going Up.

title: Some Americans in Mexico Gain, Some Lose in Devaluation of Peso
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept 25The recent 37 percent devaluation of the Mexican peso has either gladdened or shocked thousands of elderly and disabled Americans who are living in retirement in Mexico.

title: Young Quinn Sets Marks in Meadowlands Victory
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.New Zealand pacer Young Quinn set a world record for an aged gelding and a trick record in winning the $40,000 George M. Patchen Pace (second leg) last night at The Meadowlands in 1:55. The clocking equaled the third fastest mile in harness history.

title: The Doctor's Wife
