description: Despite its great technical skill and air of timeliness this new novel by the IrishCanadian Brian Moore, about a woman tunneling her way out of an oppressive middleclass marriage with the trenching tool of an adulterous affair involving a lover 11 years younger than herself, is really quite oldfashioned in plot management and quite conventional in its, implications.

title: The Iceman
description: At 17, Henry Coonrod gets a summer job driving an ice truck in Red Hill, Okla. The pay is $1.50 a day, seven days a week  good money in 1938. Especially since Henry's father has been laid off at the railroad yard, where he drives steam locomotives. Besides the money, the ice truck is the key to the interesting parts of the city, including the bars and the lady bootlegger who sells moonshine by the dipper. Delivering ice is also a way to toughen muscles for football, the way Red Grange did, and it's an allround consciousness raiser.

title: Wendy Evans, T. L. Saltonstall Plan to Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Melvin T. Evans of Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Ellen Evans, to Thomas Lee Saltonstall, son of Margaret B. Saltonstall and Joint L. Saltonstall Jr. of Boston.

title: Rockefeller University Hit by Storm Over Tenure
description: At the Rockefeller University, hothouse for Nobel Prize winners, a summer storm over tenure has produced perhaps the greatest embarrassment in the institution's 75year history.

title: Gail Ann Wendell Engaged
description: The engagement of Gail Ann Wendell to Thomas Keller has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Roy E. Wendell of Melville, L.I., parents of the future bride. Mr. Keller is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Keller of West Isip, L.I. Miss Wendell is an alumna of the State University at Farmingdale, L.I. Her fiance, who ??? from St. John's University, is a ??? student at New york University.

title: Losing Streak Hits 50 As a Late Kick Fails
description: PROPST CROSSROADS, N.C., Sept. 25 (AP)The hopes of this Catawba County community fell short last night as a last minute, 22yard tield goal attempt went wide, sealing the 50th cobsecutive football loss for Fred T. Foard High School.

title: The Scandal in Dassault's Missing Dossier
description: PARISThe Marcel Dassault company, whose owner's wealth rivals that of any Persian Gulf Sheik, is trying to buck the headwinds of what French newspapers are calling de Vathaire gate, a word play on Watergate. The scandal involves payoffs in high places and other irregular practices in France's militaryindustrial complex.

title: What's Doing Along the SHENANDOAH
description: THE VALLEYBetween the ancient peaks of the Shenandoah Mountains to the west and the Blue Ridge to the east lies the fertile green valley nourished by the Shenandoah River. The river runs northeast for nearly 150 miles, separating into two forks to coil around the mighty Massanutten Mountain, then merging near Front Royal, Va., to form a rushing waterway that flows into the Potomac River at Harpers Ferry, W. Va. This is the rolling river nostalgically recalled in the old folk song, and its bountiful farmland is celebrated in the paintings of Grandma Moses. One of the first to be taken by the beauty of the valley (and its economic promise) was George Washington who, as a young surveyor's apprentice in 1748, noted in his diary that the land is exceeding Rich and Fertile all ye way and produces abundance of Grain, Hemp, Tobacco, etc. German and Scotch. Irish settlers moved into the valley from Pennsylvania in the 18th century along the Great Wagon Road. That thoroughfare, originally an old Indian trail, became the strategic Valley Pike, bitterly disputed between the North and South during the Civil War. Now, as U. S. 11, it is lined with. markers commemorating its long history. The landscape today is still one of rustic beauty, a patchwork quilt of apple orchards and cattle pastures, of towering limestone formations and unspoiled national parklands, of country inns and backroads stores. Its small cities  Winchester, New Market, Harrisonburg and Staunton, founded in the 18th century along the spine of the wagon roadhave grown into industrial centers, but their downtowns, with old stone churches and county courthouses, preserve a sense of continuity with a past.

title: Chinese Rugs: Painstakingly Done
description: It's because of TCNNP&ABPI&EC that there is now a large collection of Chinese rugs in New Jersey.

title: Five African Leader Are Gathering to Discuss Rhodesian Proposals
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 25A meeting of the socalled frontline African presidents was hastily convened here today amid increasing criticism from nationalists of the proposals outlined by Prime Minister Ian D. Smith for majority rule in Rhodesia.

title: QUEENS WILL OFFER OWN DISTRICT LINES
description: A new element of controversy was injected into the drawing of uniform district lines for delivery of municipal services in New York City yesterday when Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens announced that he would propose his own set of boundaries, which would be different from those recommended by Mayor Beame's Subcommittee on Coterminality.

title: Katherine Soffer Wed To Malcolm S. Hart, Rand McNally Artist
description: Katherine Barns Soffer, a trial lawyer with the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission in Chicago, and Malcolm Steven Hart, an artist in the design department of the Rand McNally Company in Skokie, Ill., were married yesterday afternoon.

title: Christina N. Bora Betrothed
description: The engagement of Christina Nan Borg to Alvin H. Broome, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Broome of New York, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Borg of Scarsdale, N. Y. An October wedding is planned.

title: Andy Pratt and David Forman Add Vitality to Eclectic Pop Mix
description: ROSLYN, L.I., Sept. 24It is always interesting to encounter an artist in live performance after hearing him or her on records. if the studio captures music with a technical perfection impossible to duplicate in real life, the live performance compensates with the vitality of the moment and whatever magnetism the performer may possess in person.

title: How Hearing Delays Affect the Innocent
description: Judges in Brooklyn cited two cases last week to illustrate how arraignment delays complicated the lives of suspects who might be quickly acquitted.

title: Talents of Handicapped Children Being Developed in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 25In Connecticut, a rather large new pool of undeveloped artistic talent has been discovered where it had scarcely been looked for beforeamong seriously handicapped children.

title: Sales Tax and Wage Freeze Critical Issues in Nassau
description: SUCH local issues in Nassau County as the sales tax, the wage freeze for county employees and disputes between the county and its Patrolmen's Benevolent Association are expected to play more important roles in November's election than national issues.there will he a very favorable response for Democrats from the public.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: ALL of a sudden, Saturday is important again. The rusty leaves began to drop off the trees last week, fall was here and the pace began to quicken. Saturdays in the summer are lazy days made for moping. on Saturdays in the summer, the kids aren't home. They're swimming, or off bikeriding, or with their friends, moping.

title: Catholic Bishops Neutrality Pledge Quiets Dissension
description: A crisis in the top ranks of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States that grew out of the highly publicized meetings between members of the hierarchy and the two major Presidential contenders has been at least temporarily resolved by the bishops recent declaration of political neutrality.

title: Rhonda S. Lustig Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Lustig of Edison, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rhonda Sharon Lustig, to Howard Stanton Fensterman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Fensterman of Highland Park, N. J. The couple are graduates of American University. The future bridegroom is a student at the Georgetown University Law Center.

title: Multihulls Lured to Race at Montauk
description: With all the aura of the Starship Enterprise, some of the most advanced sailing machines in the world have converged on Montauk to prepare for the first professional yacht race on a national scale.

title: ART
description: T HE exhibition of political cartoons at Hofstra University's Emily Lowe Gallery is a crazy quilt of biting humor. At one extreme it is dry, wry and pokerfaced and at the other it is slaphappy earthy vaudeville. in between there is witty, scathing satire in the form of direct pictorial expression.

title: Race Today to Honor Former Cycling Star
description: Because of Alfred Letourner's work with youngsters in Central Park, the Federation of New York Bicycle Clubs has dedicated today's 72mile race in the park to the former sixday cycling star.

title: Sonny Fortune's Quintet is Minus
description: Sonny Fortune's Quintet has been playing on fourandahalf wings during its engagement at the Village Vanguard that ends tonight. The group has just lost its regular trumpet player and, while Mr. Fortune decides on a replacement, various trumpeters have been sitting in.

title: Romney Brent, 74, Digs; Actor and Stage Director Had a 40Year Career
description: Romney Brent, who played on Broadway, in London and in Latin America in an acting career from the 1920's to the 1950's, died Friday in Mexico City. He was 74 years old.

title: School Board Members Find That Job is a Trying One
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 25Are you interested enough in the education of your domtnunity's children to give up 20 or more hours of your own time free each week? Are you willing to grapple with increasingly complex problems, some of which have little to do with education? And are you willing to risk abuse and hostility from your neighbors?

title: Doctors Found to Share Blame When Patients Err In Following Prescriptions
description: When patients make mistakes in following their doctors prescriptions, the fault may lie at least as often with the physician as with the patient, a new study suggests.

title: Voter Turnout Has Been Declining Steadily Since 1960
description: WASHINGTONIt is estimated that 85 million people witnessed the great debate between Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter on television last Thursday night. But by November 2, by many an informed and alarmed estimate, scarcely half the 147 million Americans old enough to vote will go to the polling booth to make a choice.

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABC: Message of Israel. Address by Rabbi Ely E. Pilchik of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, Short Hills, N.J.

title: Junior Pentathlon to Dobi
description: WARSAW, Sept. 24 (AP)Lajas Dobi of Hungary won the title in the junior world pentathlon championships today at Ziclona Gore, Western Poland, With 5,342 points. Jan Bartu of Czechoslovakia was second with 5,322, and Evgeni Lipeyev, of the Soviet Union third with 5,308.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Faults at Forest Hills The Noncoach
description: To the Sports Editor: Now that the hubbun of Forest Hills has quieted down until next year, a little reflection on many areas of annoyances at the United States Open tennis matches may bring needed relief to make attendance more enjoyable and more in keeping with the traditional decorum at Forest Hills.

title: Coverage Cradle to Grave
description: STOCKHOLMJust think about it. Our life's mapped out into little squaresevery day, every hour, every minute. And on every square it's written down what we're supposed to do. The squares are filled, one by one, and in good time. if there's suddenly an empty sauare we're dismayed

title: Correction
description: An item in the Review of Sept. 19 on the. Senate primary election in New York misstated a suggestion concerning black Americans made by Daniel P. Moynihan several years ago. The suggestion was for a period of benign neglect of racial rhetoric.

title: Beame Drafts Business Tax Breaks
description: A pew economic development plan whose keystone would be a program of tax concessions for business has been drafted by the Beanie administration.

title: Auburn Aerials Sink Tennessee, 38 to 28
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 25 (AP)Phil Gargis, equally effective as a passer and runner, directed a suddenly explosive Auburn team to a 3828 Southeastern Conference triumph over Tennessee to give Coach Doug Barfield his first victory.

title: The Female Muhammad Ali Meets Idol
description: Jackie Tonawanda, billed as the female Muhammad Ali, had an opportunity to work out in the gymnasium and spar with her hero last week at his training camp at the Concord Hotel Kiamesha Lake, N. Y. Ali's hands were faster than ever, the 5foot11inch, 175 pound light heavyweight boxer said. I'm glad they weren't Sports touching me. His combinations were beautifula jet plane would do second to him.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in the Arts and Leisure Section:

title: The Shah in New York
description: A new 36story office tower is rising at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and 52d Street, where the old DePinna building once stood. The story of how it came to be there is a tale of international intrigueof influence peddling greed bribery attempts and duplicity.

title: STAMPS
description: Today there is one telephone for every 10 persons on earth, so it is not surprising that just about every nation in the world has issued or will issue commemoratives to mark the 100th anniversary of its invention.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Angler Loses Optimism
description: MONTAUK, L.I.Capt. Al Urban was not bubbling with optimism as he, his wife, Mary, and I set forth for an afternoon of fishine from Montauk Harbor.

title: Burke, Literary Critic, is Feisty at 79
description: ANDOVER KENNETH BURKE, the 79yearold literary critic and philosopher of language, talked about his work. I've decided that I'm not going to do any more straight teaching, he said. I've got books to finish. His forehead furrowed as Mr. Burke explained his ideas. His white hair was combed back in long shocks, and his eyes danced with delight.

title: Music in Review
description: Eric Stumacher, a native of Philadelphia who has studied with Rosina Lhevinne and Beveridge Webster, among others, has appeared here in the past as pianist with the Apple Hill Chamber Players. Last Tuesday night, he gave a debut program as a soloist at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: His Inquiries Could Affect the Presidential Race
description: WASHINGTONThe oncepowerful Watergate special prosecutor's office is now a handful of caretaker lawyers tucked away in a shabby set of offices that used to house part of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's intelligence division. it was sent there to await its bureaucratic extinction next January and to handle leftover appeals of earlier cases or shards of investigations. Nobody really expected to hear from the prosecutor or his staff again.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Among the various functions that today's automated cameras perform in making a photograph, the newest models are required to calculate a relationship between lens openings and shutter speed in order to determine accurate exposure. These modern cameras have, in effect, become complex and highly sophisticated optical systems blended with miniaturized electronic calculators.

title: Backus Stars vs. Lafayette
description: Columbia played wideopen football yesterday at Baker Field to score a 3831 victory over Lafayette College.

title: R. Thomas Martell Jr. Planning to Marry Kelley Marie Macdonald, Nurse, Nov. 27
description: Kelley Marie Macdonald and R. Thomas Martell Jr., both of Oakland, Calif., plan to be married on Nov. 27 in Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson. N.J.

title: T. G. I. Fall
description: GREEN PORT

title: Lack of Offensive Punch Is Problem for Holtz
description: Somewhere in this country there is the Big Play, and if the Jets find it, just once, it might turn things around.

title: U.S Nine Beaten, 52
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 25 (AP)Japan beat the United States, 52; South Korea topped Nicaragua, 32, and Taiwan stopped the Philippines, 132, today in secondround games of an international baseball tournament. Joe Beckwith, the United States pitcher, allowed seven hits in taking the loss, the first for the United States atter three straight victories in secondround.

title: It couldn't happen to her, but it did
description: I could scarcely turn the pages of this book for feeling my chest for lumps. From the very first, the reader, especially the female, is drawn deeply into the drama of the author who appears to have everything finally coming together in her life only to discover that she has been walking around for a year with a malignant growth in her left breast. This simply could not be happening to a liberated, healthy, professionally successful and emotionally steady lady. No, not to her. But it did, and if it could strike Betty Rollin, then it could strike Barbara Howar. And for 206 pages, I agonized through her ordeal as if it were my own.

title: Author's Query
description: For a compendium on super; stitions, I would appreciate receiving remembered and current superstitions. Please include country or area of origin and other pertinent information.

title: Knights Triumph by 170
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 25The Rutgers fans waited until the game was over this time before leveling the goal posts at Palmer Stadium in celebration of a victory over Princeton. But after the 17.0 triumph today, the fans needed only 9 seconds to tear down the south posts and 11 seconds to demolish the north.

title: Vigorito's Runs Lift De Paul To a Second ShutoutVictory
description: Tom Vigorito, De Paul's outstanding runner, missed his usual blocker yesterday but still managed to carry the Wayne team to a 70 victory.over Lakeland in Wanaque.

title: A Future For the Past
description: HISTORIC preservation in Morris County has reached critical point. The means are evailable to assure a future for the past, but time is on the side of progress, growth, expansion. By 1980, it is estimated, our population will have increased by more than onethird from its 1970 level.

title: Private Manmade
description: PARSIPPANY LAKE PARSIPPANY is a body of water surrounded by progress and dissension. The township's proposed drainage improvements in the vicinity of the 155acre lake will either improve its quality or lead to its demise, depending on who is interpreting the experts data.

title: The Slouch is Out At Trade Shows
description: Momusrown INDUSTRIES across the country spend $7 billion.a year mounting and staffing exhibits at trade fairs and expositions around the world, and some of them aren't sure that they're getting their money's worth.

title: Baylor Stuns Illinois, 3419, On Franklin's 4 Touchdowns
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Sept. 25 (AP)Cleveland Franklin, staged a oneman show today, scoring four touchdowns as Baylor upset Illinois, 3419.

title: Ford Visits Superdome
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 25 (UPI)President Ford made a surprise visit to the Louisiana Superdome tonight, greeting crowd of about 30,000 persons at the Boston CollegeTulane football game.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: Joanne Fusco Wed To Peter B. Mackey
description: Joanne Eleanor Fusco, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Clifford Fusco of Glen Cove, L.I., was married yesterday to Peter Brendan Mackey of Arlington, Va., an economist with the Department of the Treasury in Washington.

title: Housing Construction in New York City Expected to Climbto the Lowest Level of the Great Depression
description: The pace of housing construction in New York City is expected by state officials to rise more than 50 percent this yearbut all the increase would do is to bring the pace up to the lowest level of the Great Depression of the 1930's.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Vote on motion to close debate on bill to allow a court to award lawyers fees to a prevailing party in suits brought to enforce certain civil rights acts, which required a threefifths vote of the Senate for passage. Motion passed, 63 to 26, Sept. 23.

title: Regional Theaters Spawning New Plays
description: If one wants to look ahead to what plays will come to New York this season as well as in future seasons, one should check the schedule at, among others, the Long. Wharf Theater in New Haven, the Arena Stage in Washington and the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles. It is from such regional theaters as these that so many significant new plays have come, such works as Streamers, The Changing Room, The Great White Hope, Moonchildren, In the Matter of J. Robert. Oppenheimer and A Texas Trilogy.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SLGALLOWAY (SeaLand), Bremerhaven Oct. 2 and Cofferdam 3; sails from Pt. Elizabeth, N.J.

title: Madison Boro Lengthens Its Undefeated Streak to
description: Chris Jilleba, younger brother of former allstate player, Pete Jilleba, teamed with Tony Evans yesterday to supply Madison Boro with a powerful ground attack as it opened its season with a 287 victory over Delbarton in Madison.

title: BUILDING WELL FOR LESS
description: For which of you, intending to build a tower, sitteth not down first and counteth the cost, whether he have sufficient to finish it? asked St. Luke, reminding us that since Biblical times construction costs have been a problem. And if you are building not a tower, but a room or a corner of a room, the problem still holds: Building is not cheap. Thus it has always been, and thus it will probably remain.

title: 3 Homers Help A's Triumph, Cut Lead to 5
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP)  Home runs by Ron Fairly, Claudell Washington and Gene Tenace, plus the relief pitching of Rollie Fingers, helped Oakland post a 74 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight, keeping alive the A's slim pennant hopes.

title: Roots
description: I cannot guess what Alex Haley's countrymen will make of his birthday present to us during this election and Bicentenniai year. One is tempted to say that it could scarcely have come at a more awkward timewhat with them conventions, the exhibition of candidates, the dubious state of this particular and perhaps increasingly dubious union, and the American attempt, hopelessly and predictably schizophrenic, of preventing total disaster, for white people and For the West, in South Africa. There is a carefully muffled pain and panic in the nation, which neither candidate, neither party, can coherently address, being, themselves, but vivid symptoms of it.

title: Jeanette Chappell Kait, 79; Poet and a Leader in Tennis
description: Jeannette Chappell Kalt, a poet and, tennis player who for many years had been chairman of the women's ranking committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, died yesterday at the Community Hospital in Glen Cove, LI., at the age of 79. She lived in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: GARDEN CITYLate 20th Century Graphics, presented by the Alumni Association of Adelphi University and Getter/ Pall Gallery; through Oct. 8; weekdays, 9 to 11:30 A.M. and 2:30 to 5 P.M. Alumni House, 154 Cambridge Ave.

title: Head of Crime Family Slain in L.I. By Gunmen Waiting Outside Home
description: Andimo (Tony Noto) Pappadio, a reputed leader of the Luchese crime family, was shot to death late Friday night outside his luxurious home in Lido Beach, L. I.

title: The Debates: A Marketplace In the Global Village
description: WASHINGTONPresidents sometimes rail at Congress, recriminate against critics or tonguelash bureaucrats. From time to time they govern. But they hardly ever debate.

title: Lobbyists Play Pass the Bill
description: TRENTON AT the height of a typical New Jersey legislative seasonthat is, when the Senate and Assembly are in a rare billpassing moodupward of 200 men and maybe a dozen women, all wearing hesitant smiles and an air of anxiousness, crowd the halls of the capitol.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Since I grew up in Middletown and worked for a while for McGrawHill, I feel particularly well placed to comment on the plight of the poor, misled Lefaivre family of St. Louis, who accepted relocation to New York because they thought that a 20 per cent salary increase would give them more luxuries and a better life (Aug. 1).

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MOST Long Island homeowners are painfully aware of the need for conserving energy these daysnot only because our political leaders have been telling us it is the patriotic thing to do, but also because householders are sharply reminded each time they receive a new increase from their local fueloil supplier, or a new Dill from Lilco.

title: A Certain Magic
description: Although the past few years have produced a number of fine novels about the young Anne Franks who survived the horrors of World War IIsuch as Johanna Reiss's The Upstairs Room, Judith Kerr's When Hitler Stole Pink Rabbit and Marilyn Sachs's A Pocket Full of SeedsDoris Orgel's new book approaches memories of this bitter era from a different angle. Here it is the contemporary, Americanborn niece of an Austrian Jewish refugee girl, Jenny Ehrentell, who uses an accidentally discovered (and secretly read) journal of 1938: to learn about the longago but still partially unresolved sufferings of her beloved Aunt Trudl.

title: E. P. Pazicky Jr. Weds Diana Loercher, Journalist
description: Diana Ellen Loercher and Edward Paul Pazicky Jr. were married yesterday morning in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Terence J. Finlay.

title: Adornment For Male Of the Species
description: Harry Platt, the wellgroomed president of Tiffany's, wears a wrist watch and cuff links, neither of which he considers jewelry.

title: Blyleven Stalls Royals
description: ARLINGTON, Texas, Sept. 25 (AP)Bert Blyleven pitched a four hitter and the Texas Rangers delayed Kansas City's march to the American League West title with a 1.0 victory tonight.

title: VIETNAM ORPHANS  FACE NEW BATTLE
description: BRIDGEPORT, Cann., Sept. 25  A crosscountry tugofwar that will decide the fate of two children flown out of Vietnam in Operation Babylift during the panicfilled closing days of the Vietnam War got under way this week as attorneys for both the children's natural mother and their foster father began legal proceedings.

title: En Garde With the Foil, the Epee or the Saber
description: THERE are more than half a million active fencers in the United States todayhalf of them women who have taken up the hobby in recent years. Some of these enthusiasts enjoy the activity because of the physical exercise it provides, and the fact that it helps to develop strong (but never bulging) muscles in almost every part or the body. Others feel that Marcel Marceau, the famed pantominist, best summed it up over 40 years ago, when he said: Fencing is a school of humility and develops speed, perfect control of the body, balance, beauty and strong grace. It should be recommended to all men wanting to master their feelings and actions during their lifetime.

title: Indian Regime Approves Ambitious FiveYear Plan After Delay of 2 Years
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 25Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government formally adopted today Indian's ambitious fifth fiveyear plan after a delay of nearly two and a half years.

title: Ellis Sparks Bethpage in Polo
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 25 Dave Ellis scored seven goals today to lead the Bethpage polo team to an 1110 victory over Westbury in a Long Island league game at Hickox Field. Russell Corey and Jeff Broderick shared scoring honors for Westbury with four goals each.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: ALTHOUGH New York is recognized as the numismatic hobby's number one city at any given time, its attraction for collectors this year has been and still is at an unprecedented peak. The excitement of last month's tremendous Anierican Numismatic Association convention is still fresh in the minds of thousands of metropolitan area collectors; now another major coin show is minima to town.

title: Criminals At Large
description: John Godey's The Taking of Pelham One Two Three, which came out in 1973, was a caper novel that attracted considerable attention and was made into a blockbuster of a movie. In that book a group of thugs hijacked a New York City subway train, holding it and its hostages for ransom. Could anybody top that? Godey tries. In his new book, THE TALISMAN (Putnam's, $8.95), there is an even more unusual caper.

title: RhodesiaSunrise at Last?
description: After nearly eleven years of going it alone in an increasingly hostile continent and world, Rhodesia's white minority Government has bowed to the inevitable. Prime Minister Ian Smith, who said as late as last March that not in a thousand years would be turn over power to Rhodesia's black majority, has agreed to do exactly that within two yearsthe maximum transfer period designated in the BritishAmerican proposals pressed on Mr. Smith in. South Africa last weekend by Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: Possible Covert Union Gifts to Ford From '64 to '74 Called Target of Inquiry by Watergate Prosecutor
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 25The Watergate special prosecutor's office is investigating whether funds from two large maritime unions were laundered through Republican committees here and covertly paid to Gerald R. Ford in the 10 years beginning in 1964, according to local politicians and Federal officials.

title: Dr. Fredric D. Young to Wed Laurie Gruberg in December
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Gruberg of Eastchester, N.Y. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Ann Gruberg to Dr. Fredric D. Young, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Young of Munster, Ind. A December wedding is planned.

title: From Indictments to Landslides, He Has Overcome
description: Politics in New Jersey, rarely simple or polite, becomes particularly lively and unfathomable in the Ninth Congressional District, for this is the arena of Representative Henry Helstoski, a controversial and unorthodox individual who practices survival techniques with astonishing success. The sixterm Congressman, despite a Federal extortion indictment and charges of voting fraud, came through again last week by decisively defeating Assemblyman Byron M. Baer in a rerun of their Democratic primary of last June.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor. The lowest voter turnout since 1948 has been forecast for the coming Presidential election, according to recent issues of The Times. The projected decline is attributed largely to the public's lack of interest in the candidates and in the political process, but there is also general agreement that our election procedures, particularly registration, discourage voting. Apathy is a systmle ill, hard to cure, but procedural defects can and should be corrected promptly.

title: Paperbacks
description: DRAGON, DRAGON, by John Gardner ($1.50). TUCK EVERLASTING, by Natalie Babbitt ($1.75). TOMFOOLERY, collected by Alvin Schwartz ($1.75). From the first flock of Bantam's Skylark Books, these three titles (respectively original fairy tales, a fantasy and a collection of puns and jokes) give an auspicious sendoff to this new children's paperback line in an attractive format and illustratedl were heir selected by this Review as best books of year. THE FIRST CASUALTY, by Phillip Knightley. (Harcourt/Harvest $5.95.) The war correspondent's role as hero, propagandist and myth maker, in wars from the Crimea to Vietnam; a narrative account that concludes it's the truth that always bites the dust first.

title: Janet Dockendorff Wed to Frederick Ballou 2d
description: Janet Cornell Dockendorff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Noyes Cornell Dockendorff of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to Frederick David Ballou 2d of Boston. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. David Sweet Ballou of Norwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Ballou.

title: The Many Roles of Guild Hall
description: GUILD HALL in East Hampton has not the oppressive majesty of its namesakes in Europe. A guild hall in France or Belgium or Germany A likely to be the most portentous building in town. And it has, almost always, the reek of an immemorial selfsatisfaction as one generation of prosperous burghers succeeds another. Even Geoffrey Chaucer knew that reek, and he died in 1400.

title: ADDING ARCHITECTURE AT MODEST COST
description: An addition to a house can provide the things that a family has been wanting for many a yearan extra bedroom, a family or game room, a new kitchen or any number of other practical necessities. Often, adding to a house can persuade a family to remain in familiar and congenial surroundings rather than move to someplace new and unknown. An addition can avoid uprooting the children, changing schools and friends, playgroups and car pools. Yet it can also provide a sense of changea fresh feeling about the old houseas well as new practicality.

title: The Magnetism of Mahler Three Views
description: What is it that attracts us about Mahler? is it merely the sentimental, bizarre or sarcastic reflexes of dwindling world at the turn of the century which a keenly perspicacious man knew how to catch? is this sufficient to hold our attention and enthrall us? The reason

title: No Winner, but a Start
description: That is the question the experts would like to be able to answer after the first of the Presidential debates. The pollsters will add up the percentages and publish their inconclusive conclusions. The politicians will claim victory for their side and assign defeat to the opposition.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Sept. 25 (UPI)The Cleveland Barons, with two quick goals in the third period, defeated the New York Rangers, 41, in a National Hockey League exhibition game last night.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: FEW people around here understand what he's talking about but Representative Jerome A. Ambro, Democrat of East Northport, spends a lot of time muttering about aquifers. Lately he has been muttering about aquifers and polyvinylchloride liners, which he doesn't like. He says they leak.

title: 5 Youths Die in Upstate Crash
description: BOICEVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 25 (AP)Five young men from Kingston, N. Y., were killed here early today when their car careered off the road and struck bridge abutment. The police said the apparent cause of the crash was speeding. The victims were identified as Robert Stevens, 22 years old, the driver; William Duffy, 19; John Aitken, 19; Thomas Arcadipane, 19. and Steven Feldmeth, 20.

title: GERMAN PROFESSOR CAMPAIGNS IN RUHR
description: BOCHUM, West Germany, Sept. 19A 46yearold Americaneducated professor is taking the conservative Christian Democrats election campaign to the coal miners and steelworkers of the Ruhr, making sharp inroads into a vital stronghold of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Social Democratic Party.

title: Nancy Marks, G. R. Rahmes, Lawyes, Wed
description: Nancy Anne Marks, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Antonio C. Marks of Tiverton, R.r., and Ocean Reef, Fla., was married sterday at noon to Gordon Roswell Rahmes Jr. son of Mr. Tard Mrs. Rahmes of St. Louis.

title: SHOP TALK
description: WICKER, cane and rattan can lend an interesting accent to any room, and The Wicker Shop in Bloomfield has furniture and accessories for every room in the house. A lot of people come in here to buy one thing, but end up getting so hooked on wicker that they do a whole room with it, Diane Hagen, a saleswoman, said the other day.

title: Handsome Houses in a Drab Area Inspire Renovators
description: OSSINING, N.Y.When Karen and Roger Pellaton started house hunting six years ago, they were looking for a nice, old, inexpensive place with a rentable apartment for extra income.

title: Notes: Controversy Sends RDT TheaterHopping
description: Anotsofunny thing happened to the Utah Repertory Dance Theater on its way to Manhattan. The moderndance company's first New York season in three years, which opens Tuesday at the Manhattan School of Music, almost fell through because of a lastminute controversy over a pas de deux with lesbian overtones in one of the works on the program.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Two weeks ago in this section, Richard Eder reviewed Victor Erica's The Spirit of the Beehive at the annual film festival in Telluride, Colo. The film, which focuses on the two daughters, aged 8 and 10, of an uppermiddleclass family in postCivil War Spain, was shown at the Museum of Modern Art a couple of years ago. Eder called it the best Spanish film ever made  one of the two or three most haunting films about children ever made  one of the two dozen best pictures made anywhere in the past halfdozen years, and lamented that it lacked a commercial distributor in the United States. Now that vacancy has been filled, and The Spirit of the Beehive has just open at the D. W. Griffith Theater, 235 E. 59th St. (7594630)

title: U.S. Roller Skating Pair Leads for World Title
description: ROME, Sept. 25 (AP)Jane Puracchlo and Kerry Cavazzi of the United States moved into the lead today over their teammates, Fleurette Arsenal and Don Little, after the compulsory events for the figure dancing title at the World roller skating championships.

title: Would Chekhov Accept This AngloSaxon Ivanov?
description: LONDON Ivanov was Chekhov's first produced play, and, partly because of an opening performance in which one actor was hopelessly drunk and most of the rest forgot their lines, it was widely misunderstood in its day. The main character, a landowner equally out of love with his wife and life, drifts into the arms of the daughter of his welltodo neighbors, galvanizing the local gossips.

title: Gregorek Captures Run By This Much
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Sept. 25John Gregorek of St. Anthony's High in Smithtown, L.I., who had clever won a crosscountry race until last week, defeated nationally ranked Dave O'Conor today in the Albertus Magnus Run at Bear Mountain State Park.

title: Margaret Wytrwal is Bride
description: Margaret Wytrwal, a teacher specializing in Braille, and Joseph Robert Polak 3d, assistant athletic director at New Hampshire College in Manchester, were married yesterday afternoon in Amsterdam, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph Cuilik performed the ceremony in the St. Stanislaus Roman Catholic Church. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore L. Wytrwal of Amsterdam, graduated from Manhattanville College and received a master's degree from the College of St. Rose in Albany. Mr. Polak, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Robert Polak of Flushing, Queens, is an alumnus of Fordham University.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: One of the best known problems in mathematics, the socalled fourcolor conjecture, has at last been solved. The problem has engaged both amateur and professional attention for many years because it is so easily stated: Prove that four colors are enough to color any conceivable map, such that no two adjacent areas will be colored the same.

title: Carter Recruiter Visits Jerusalem In Quest of Votes
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 25Besides their platoons of speech writers, coatholders and boosters, American political candidates are nurtured by the nameless legions of the party faithful who knock on doors from Southampton to Seattle urging the electorate to get out and vote. The Democratic National Committee has been widening its net, having gone international in its quest for votes.

title: Bodyguards for Connors?
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 (UPI)Hell no, I don't have any bodyguards, Jimmy Connors snapped. I'd like to see the guy that started that.

title: Danger to the Ozone
description: When scientists a few years ago put forward the theory that gases from aerosol spray cans might increase skin cancers and seriously affect the earth's climate, they triggered an expected degree of ridicule and the usual cries of hysteria. Now a panel of the National Academy of Sciences finds that these fluorocarbon gases are in fact weakening the planet's ozone layer, threatening precisely the consequences predicted.

title: Carroll MacGahan is Wed
description: Carroll Patricia MacGahan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John A. MacGahan of Twilight Park in Haines Falls, N.Y was married yesterday afternoon to David Michael Spitko, son of John Spitko of Ambler, Pa., and the late Mrs. Spitko. The Rev. McCrae Cobb, assisted by the Rev. Russel Landholt, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony in the Episcopal. Church of All Angels in Twilight Park. The couple graduated from Ursinus College. Mr. MacGahan received a master's degree on public administration from Syracuse University.

title: CEMETERIES
description: CEMETERY Pinta for ??? ???? graves each, choice location. Kind Solomon Memorial Park, Clifton, N.J. Call Mr. Geiger 2018469131 wkdays only.

title: Victor Shousha to Wed Susan Suaper on Nov. 27
description: Susan Dorothy Snaper, granddaughter of James L. Kilgallen of New York, a veteran reporter with the Hearst Headline Service, and Victor B. Shousha, a chartered accountant with the London firm of Randall & Payne, will be married Nov. 27.

title: The Bribe
description: Fort Lee, at the New Jersey end of the George Washington Bridge, has been notorious for decades as home and haven for some of the most lethal rulers of the underworld. The cozy relationship of crime and politics was one of New Jersey's worstkept secrets and enabled some distinguished officeholders to enjoy a naboblike life style. Against this background, it is not difficult to understana the incredulity that swept the United States Attorney's office in Newark in May 1974, when Burt Ross, the new 31yearold mayor of Fort Lee, reported he had been offered a $500,000 bribe by a Mafia emissary. Adding to the sense of unreality was the proposition that Ross made to Assistant U.S. Attorney Bruce Goldstein, Wire me for sound, he said in effect, and I'll help you catch these crooks.

title: CHESS
description: Diane Savereide, 21 years old of Culver City, Calif., won the 22d running of the United States Women's Championship in Teton Village, Wyo., with a score of 82.

title: West Plans Aid To Assure Ties With Rhodesia
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25The United States plans to work out with Britain and South Africa in coming weeks details of what will probably be a large international economic plan to help assure that in Rhodesia's transition to black majority rule over the next two years moderates and proWestern factions will prevail.

title: Party Balance in Senate Expected to Change Little; Forecasts Now Indicate Democratic Gain of 2 Seats
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 25Politicians and political observers around the country expect that neither party will gain significantly in this year's elections to the Senate.

title: Wife of South Korean Dissident Says That Imprisonment Appears to Damage the Health of Her Husband
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 25Every morning at about 9:30, Mrs. Kim Dae Jung, the wife of the former South Korean presidential candidate, drives to the Seoul Detention House in hopes of seeing her husband. Mr. Kim, who ran against President Park Chung Hee in 1971, has been detained there now for six months.

title: CALIFORNIA FLOODS CLOSE ROADS AND DAMAGE HOMES
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 (AP)More than 100 homes were damaged and a score of highways closed by flooding broueht on by three days of heavy rain.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Ordinarily this would be a time for cheer. The economy is not yet midway into its second year of economic recovery, and history shows that peacetime recoveries in the postwar era have lasted at least two full years. Also this is a Presidential election year, and the economy has usually done well during such periods.

title: LAYERS OF SPACE AND SYMBOL
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Claghorn and their family had outgrown the kitchen of their 1870's house in Princeton, N. J., and wanted something that would let them breathe. Michael Graves, a Princeton architect, gave them more than they budgeted for at $22,000  a little masterpiece of interrelated spaces, structure and architectural symbols  and they love it.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: TodayMamaroneck (N.Y.) Kiwanis Club antique car show and flea market at Harbor Island Park, Boston Post Road (Route 1) and Mamaroneck Avenue; judging at 12:15 P.M.

title: Both Parties Confident in Suffolk's Close Contests
description: WITH posters, debates, kaffceklatsches, buttons, bands and bumper stickers, the local political races are under way in Suffolk County. In many respects, they are miniature versions of the contest between President Ford and Jimmy Carter, but they also have issues and personalities that directly affect their voters.

title: St. Paul's Wins Opening Game Of New League
description: St. Paul's of Garden City accomplished something that had never been done on Long Island before when it defeated St. Agnes of Rockville Centre, 206, yesterday to register the first victory in the newly formed Island Football Conference.

title: A Cry for the Children
description: DUTY arises from our potential control over the course of events. Where attainable knowledge could have changed the Issue, ignorance has the guilt of vice. So said Alfred North Whitehead. So say I, regarding the way striking teachers conduct themselves.

title: FOOD
description: SECOND only to potatoes, cauliflower is one of the local crops that still reaches the area beyond Nassau and Suffolk. This year the firm white heads are beginning to appear at farm stands and markets for 69 cents, 59 cents and eventually three for a dollar along the roadsides around Riverhead.

title: Landlords in Westchester Agree to End Sex Discrimination in Rentals.
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 24Westchester apartmentbuilding owners agreed today to end sex discrimination in renting apartments, by counting the income of men and women equally when determining financial qualifications.

title: All About BIG MAC
description: ACOMMENTARY (Sept. 5) by Assemblyman Richard J. Codey was critical of several recent financings arranged by the state's Economic Development Authority for the McDonald's Corporation.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Television This Week
description: 1:00 P.M. (2) DANCE OF THE ATHLETES. An hour special focusing on the relationship of athletics and dance, with Edward Villella, principal dancer with the New York City Ballet; Tom ??? and Jerry Grote of the New York Mets; Bob Griese of the Miami Dolphins; Virginia Wade, former U.S. Open tennis champion; George McGinnis of the Philadelphia 76ers, and Muriel Grossfeld, former Olympic gymnast.

title: Szen is Publicity Aide For Seattle Baseball Club
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 25 (AP)David Szen, a former Boston Red Sox public relations man, has been named assistant public relations director of the Seattle Mariners, an American League expansion team.

title: History And Music Barge In
description: WINDING up its fourmonth, 2,400mile journey through the state, the New York Bicentennial Barge will finally make it to the Island. The 857ton, 250footby39foot twolevel vessel, a converted Reading Railroad harbor lighter packed with exhibits depicting life in the state before and after the Revolution, will tie up in Port Jefferson next Saturday and Sunday and then, pushed by two tugboats, will move on to Oyster Bay for a threeday stand starting Tuesday, Oct. 5.

title: Mrs. Young Raises Carlton Golf Lead to 5 Strokes
description: CALABASAS, Calif., Sept. 25Nothing will convince Donna Caponi Young that she is a shooin to win the $205,000 Carlton, richest tournament in women's golf. She had a fourstroke lead at the midpoint yesterday and was ahead by five strokes today wtm et 54hole total of 210 to 215 for Sandra Palmer, the tough, tiny Texan. Mrs. Young had a 72 today and Miss Palmer a 71.

title: ECONOMICS OF THE TIMES
description: WASHINGTONWhile political developments in the United States, Africa and Europe have recently dominated the interest the world and created some new tensions, the international economic picture has been sliding into the background. But in coming weeks it will be drawing the increased attention it gets every year at this time.

title: Twilley and Cappelletti Finally Regulars
description: What do Howard Twilley and John Cappelletti, who play today against the Jets and Giants, respectively, have in common? Not much, except both were late bloomers in pro football. Howard James Twilley Jr., the Dolphins 32yearold wide receiver, has been deposed many times as a regular, yet here is again, a key figure in the offense in his 11th season. John Raymond Cappelletti, the Los Angeles running back, is only in his third pro season, but may as well have spent the first two in a vault. He hardly ever played and at one point last season ranked sixth among six running backs on the roster. His status was fuel for those who maintained that Heisman Trophy winners hardly ever fulfilled their prospects in the National Football League.

title: Rules Code for Presidential and Congressional Campaign Efforts Proves Unenforceable for'76 Election
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25The long and complex code of rules that is controlling the Presidential and Congressional campaigns this fall is tentatively unenforceable and cannot become iegally effective, as things stand now, until about four months after the 1976 election.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: ACTOR'S CAFETHEATER, South Munn and Central Avenues, East OrangeButley. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through Oct. 9). $3.50$4.90; students and the elderly, $2.50$3.90; group rates. (201) 6751881.

title: The Watches Of the Night
description: Harry Caudill is a lawyer who lives in Whiteiburg, Ky., but who is best known as the author of a taunting description of the Appalachian plateau, Night Comes to the Cumberlands. That book came out in 1963, in the first period of the rediscovery of the American poor, and it told of America's most underdeveloped region. Yet Caudill was not simply a Jeremiah from the hills who denounced the indignifies which afflicted his people. He also understood and analyzed. An indigenous American radicalif that word is taken in its best meaninghe was as impassioned in his criticism of a welfare system which reduced so many of his neighbors to a helpless and even lifelong dependency as he was in his condemnation of the coal companies whose rape of the region made welfare a necessity.

title: CARTER VOWS A CURB ON NUCLEAR EXPORTS TO BAR ARMS SPREAD
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 25Jimmy Carter said today that, if elected President, he would halt further sales of nuclear power technology and nuclear reactor fuel to any nation that refused to forgo nuclear weapons development or insisted on building its own national plant for reprocessing reactor fuel.

title: Democrats on Panel Foresee Need to Spur Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  Majority Democrats on the Congressional Joint Economic Committee concluded today that Congress would probably have to act early next year to spur the pace of expansion of the economy and keep the unemployment rate heading downward.

title: Around the Nation
description: JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 25 (UPI)The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People began a legal counterattack yesterday to try to avoid the necessity of raising an estimated $1.5 million bond to appeal an adverse court ruling in Mississippi.

title: After Forcing a Decision on Smith
description: DAR ES SALAAM, TanzaniaWhat we're trying lo find out is whether the conditions exist for the major actors to sit down together, said Tanzanian President Julius K. Nyerere last week, summing up the mission by United States Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger to still the guns in southern Africa. Like many others close to the situation in the subcontinent, Mr. Nyerere has begun using metaphors of the theater to describe the present situation underlining the drama of it all perhaps, but also carrying the suggestion of an overlay of complicated plots, actions occurring offstage and a certain amount of role playing by principals whose motives may not be readily apparent.

title: Tony Komheiser
description: And he stands, as they cheer him glistening in the light of their admiration.

title: Andrew Milstein Fiance Of Carol Diane Mandel
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lenard H. Mandel of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Pike Trails Ranch in Guffey, Colo., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Diane Mandel, to Andrew R. Milstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Monroe G. Milstein of Long Beach, L.I., and Burlington, N.J.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Joanna Thompson Wed to Clifford Carver
description: Joanna Hasty Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Hasty Thompson of Portland, Me., was married yesterday afternoon in Scarborough, Me., to Clifford Harold Carver, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford M. Carver of Glen Cove. L.I. The Very Rev. Donald A. Webster. dean of the Cathedral Church of St. Luke in Portland, performed the ceremony in St. James Episcopal Chapel. A reception was held at the Prouts Neck Yacht Club.

title: TURNING POINT SEEN AHEAD FOR RHODESIA BY A BLACK LEADER
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 25Joshua Nkomo, the nationalist leader who already widely presumed to be playing a key role in the formation of a biracial interim government here, said today, From now on we may arrive at a turning point.

title: How it Was
description: In the aufumn of 1924 Ernest Hemingway published a poem in Der Querschnet, a German literary magazine, called The Soul of Spain [In the Manner of Gertrude Stein], part of which goes:

title: POLITICS
description: AT first blush, Nassau and Suffolk seem to be polir,ical Siamese twins largely white, middleclass Republican. Usually, as one goes, so goes the other statewide elections.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: AHOMEOWNER in North Jersey, upset over the size of his last few fuel and electric bills, feels that something should be done about it. I wish it were possible to get all homeowners together to picket, like other specialinterest groups do, he writes. Isn't there some way we can keep the costs of fuel and utilities from climbing still higher?

title: FollowUp on the News
description: It was the richest prize in any lottery in the nation's history$92,352 a year for lifeand Eric C. Leek, a 26yearold hair stylist of North Arlington, NJ., became the first to win it last Jan. 27.

title: Siamsa is the Gaelic Word For Folk Entertainment
description: DUBLIN Compared with the many world famous companies visiting the United States to celebrate the Bicentennial, Siamsa is an unknown pygmy among renowned giants. The group consists of little more than 20 performers and they are all amateurs who normally work on farms, in shops and offices. Yet in its own diminutive way Siamsa is as important as the more lustrous opera and theater companies from London, Paris and Moscow. in its mixture of innocence, simplicity, gaiety, warmth and spontaneity it certainly has an overall charm few others can equal.

title: Sarah L. Hall, L. C. Wood Jr. Wed in Jersey
description: The First Presbyterian Church of New Vernon, N.J., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Sarah Leighton Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren S. Hall Jr. of Morristown, N.J., to Leighton Christopher Wood Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wood of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. George E. Chorba performed the ceremony. A reception was held at the Hall home.

title: FORD TELLS SOUTH, I WANT YOUR VOTE
description: DESTREHAN, La., Sept. 25President Ford steamed down the Mississippi today to preach political conservatism to Jimmy Carter's native South.

title: Answers/Questions
description: A:ROSE BLACK SPOT (Sept. 5) T.H.C., from Ontario, Canada is tired of spraying his roses every week for control of black spot. He found one variety, Maria Stern, to be immune. He asked if readers knew of any other varieties. Mrs. Henry MacCallum, a Connecticut reader, has found in her garden, the following varieties showing resistance to black spot: Tampico, Cayenne and Peace. Beverly R. Dobson, a Westchester County reader, explains, when PernetDucher bred yellow coloration into hybrid teas by crossing with the species, Rosa foetida, the Austrian brier rose, he inadvertently bred low blackspot resistance in as well. Hybridizers have been working ever since to breed it out again. The American Rose Society notes disease resistance in its Proof of the Pudding reports published in the Rose Annual available for $9.35 from The American Rose Society, P.O. Box 30,000, Shreveport, La. 71130.

title: Panel Says U.S. Agency Ignored Signs of Danger In Building of Idaho Dam
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)The Federal Bureau of Reclamation ignored several warning signs that should have prompted it to halt construction of the illfated Teton Dam, according to a House panel.

title: POLL FINDS 34% SHARE BORN AGAIN FEELING
description: Jimmy Carter's bornagain religious experience has apparently been shared by 34 percent of adult Americans, according to a Gallup Poll released yesterday.

title: Belgian Wins Cycle Race
description: Sept. 24D (UPI)Belgium's Roger De Vlaeminck won the Montelupo grand prix cycling race today, edging 20 competitors in the final sprint. His time for 140 miles was 5 hours 45 minutes, an average speed of 24.626 miles per hour. Pierino Gavazzi and Enrico Paolini of Italy were second and third.

title: On the London Stage, King Comedy Reigns
description: LONDON  British comedy has range and variety that I don't think is usally found in the American variety. it runs the gamut from the courtliest comedy of manners to bedroom farce with apparently equal gusto.

title: Parent and Child
description: The hottest new item in postWatergate curriculums is moral education, an attempt by educators to instill moral values in youngsters by using newly designed teaching methods. With many believing that people in the United States do not live as moral and honest lives as they used to, according to Gallup, moral education is now favored by four out of every five Americans.

title: INVESTING
description: In May 1974, a scant month after the Consolidated Edison Company omitted its quarterly dividend on common stock, the lights appeared to dim for the various bond issues of the New Yorkbased utility. Moody's Investors Service suspended its ratings on these bonds, pending sufficient evidence that the company could finance its needs.

title: Miners, in AntiCommunist Move, Expel Some Reporters at Parley
description: CINCINNATI, Sept 25An emotional debate over alleged Communists in the union and among newsmen reporting on the United Mine Workers convention here interrupted the proceedings for hours today and led to the expulsion of half a dozen correspondents for leftwing publications.

title: Msgr. William T. Greene, 72; ExArchdiocese Music Director
description: Msgr. William T. Greene, pastor for the last 20 years of the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Perpetual Help in Ardsley. N. Y., died Friday at the Misericordia Hospital Medical Center in the Bronx at the age of 72.

title: Turner's 4 Touchdowns Spark Snyder
description: Anthony Turner, a senior halfback, scored four touchdowns and Snyder displayed predicted power as it moved to a 347 victory over Dickinson yesterday in Jersey City.

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 25 (Reuters) Prime Minister Seni Pramoj of Thailand, who resigned two days ago because of criticism of his handling of the return from exile of former military strongman Thanom Kittikachorn, was reappointed today by King Phumiphol Adulet.

title: For Kids: A Few Bright Spots in the Customary Sludge
description: My son, who is 11, Just reported to his 8yearold sister that Nancy Carter, who is a character in The Edge of Night, is having an affair. Strange ??? stalk the cartoon jungle, and the Public Broadcasting Service sports three debuts, but the real news, Judging by the new children's shows this season, is the realization that what glues kids most tightly to the tube are soaps, game shows And reruns of I Love Lucy. ABC, CBS and NBC, thus enlightened, have produced half a dozen juniorstyle sitcoms and game shows. PBS, being smarter, has discovered the soap.

title: Miss Hussey Bride of R. E. Frankovich
description: Deborah Hussey and Richard Edward Frankovich of New York were married yesterday afternoon in Wellesley, Mass. The Rev. James MacColl performed the ceremony in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

title: Princeton Seeks Tomorrow's Energy
description: PRINCETON FUSION power. it is called the most sophisticated scientific problem ever attacked by man. Since 1951, scientists here have been trying to find the keys to producing electrical energy from the fusion of hydrogen atomsthe principle behind the hydrogen bomb.

title: Farriers Face Evil Eye In Jersey Championship
description: They call it the evil eye, and if sounds macabre, you're correct.

title: Season Opens Saturday For Archery Deer Hunt
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 25 (AP)The archery deer season opens next Saturday for more than 200,000 archery hunters in Pennsylvania. The State Game Commission says More than 25.percent of the nation's archery hunters buy licenses in pennsylvania.

title: In Memoriam
description: BURGERJoseph, on the first ??? sary of his passing the employees of Art Steel Co., Inc., are saddened remember our past Vice Chairman And, President, September 26, 1975.

title: BOOKS
description: I have always hoped it is true that the Lord helps those who help themselves, but whether He does or not the publishing industry clearly intends to. A large number of new books are available on domestic arts, home repairs, crafts and architecturesome dreadful, some extremely good. At the top of the latter list is THE HOUSE BOOK by Terence Conran (Crown, $30). It is a brilliant, admirable, totally satisfying book (how many times lately have you been able to say that about anything?) filled with drawings and diagrams and, oh joy, over 1,000 color pictures of other people's houses illustrating imaginative solutions to every conceivable domestic design or decorating problem, from mail slots and window boxes to major floor plans. The book is packed with practical information, and the writing is clear, to the point and witty. A gift of a book.

title: Today's Events
description: Greenpoint Bicentennial Festival, in conjunction with viewing of Bicentennial Barge; 10 A.M., India Street pier, Brooklyn.

title: Salt Lake City: The Founder Is Palpably Present
description: No wonder Brigham Young, emerging with his intrepid party of 147 Mormon pioneers from the western exit of Emigration Canyon, said, This is the place. What he saw on the floor of the valley below was as beautiful a setting for a city as exists in America.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE EASTER PARADE, by Richard Yates. (Delacorte Press, $7.95.) A spare, unsparing tale of two sisters who choose equally futile paths.

title: A Riddle: Where is Your Home?
description: No one in his right mind would buy a new home without knowing its address.

title: Impresario Of the Arts Center
description: WHEN Robert J. Jablonski travels around the state in his Lincoln Continentalhe clocks 45,000 New Jersey miles a yearit is in his role as an investment banker dressed in the obligatory buttoneddown shirt and pinstripe suit.

title: Moynihan Aims To Get Million For Campaign
description: A latestarting senate contenaer, Daniel P. Moynihan, spent up to onethird of his time during the primary campaign on the telephone and at parties and luncheons rattling the cup for fund contributions. Now it starts all over again because the candidate came out of the primary at least $100,000 in the red. Mr. Moynihan's aides hope to raise $1 million in six weeks to get into the same ballpark, at least, with his Republican opponent, Senator James L. Buckley. The Senator has been fundraising for two years and had collected $1.2 million as of the end of August.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Fares on New Jersey's subsidized rail and bus lines will remain at their current levels until at least July 1977, according to State Transportation Department officials. The officials had threatened to raise the fares substantially later this year unless the Legislature appropriated $13 million to close a projected deficit in the state subsidy program.

title: Boston Dancers Prove a Group With Potential
description: The Concert Dance Company of Boston offers encouraging news that the outlying regions of the dance world are spawning higher standards. Appearing at the American Theater Lab on Friday night, the fouryearold modern dance troupe made a generally good impression.

title: For young readers
description: There's no denying that this book is aptly titled. it is decidedly about both ropes and jungles, particularly one long piece of the former stretching over four miles of the latter in southern Mexico in 1905.

title: A walking parody of American values
description: Is Tiny Tim for real? is he really a freak comic who believes his act? Well, according to this unauthorized show business biography, there'is no line between his performance and his personal weird trip. Like Tiny Tim of Charles Dickens's A Christmas. Carol, Herbert his personal, Wetra trip. LIM a cheery crippled kid. But the Tiny Tim we all watched marry his dear Miss Vicki on the Tonight Show in the late 1960's seems psychically crippledbe acts like a child in an adult's body.

title: Earl R. Bramlett is Dead at 65; Retired Labor Negotiator at G.M.
description: Earl R. Bramblett, a retired chief labor negotiator and vice president in charge of personnel for the General Motors Corporation, died of an apparent heart attack yesterday at St. Joseph Mercy Hospital in Pontiac, Mich. He was 65 years old and lived in Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

title: The Nation
description: Congress has posed a difficult political choice for President Ford by sending him two bills intended to create jobs. The President must either relax his opposition to using Federal funds to generate employment or risk a political charge of indifference to rising joblessness in the midst of the election campaign.

title: Miss Miller Has Nuptials
description: In the Swarthmore (Pa.) Presbyterian Church yesterday afternoon, Christina Suzanne Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Paul Miller Jr. of Swarthmore, was married to David Cutler Sargent, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Cutler Sargent of Aurora, Ohio. The Rev. J. Barrie Shepherd performed the ceremony.

title: Notes: Less Waiting At the White House
description: More than 1.2 million visitors have passed through the White House in the first eight months of this Bicentennial yearan increase of about 10 percent over the comparable period of 75, What's more, this year's visitors have been having an easier time of it than their predecessors, many of whom waited in line up to an hour and a half to get into the Executive Mansion.

title: Golf Lead To Gilbert On 65205
description: NAPA, Calif., Sept. 25 (AP)Gibby Gilbert dropped six putts in the 10to12foot range on the way to a 65 and had a onestroke lead after today's third round of the $175,000 Kaiser intarnatinnal anon golf tournament.

title: Big Apple's Banking Lure
description: In the battle to win more banking business, New York State is thinking about reaching into its legislative arsenal to brandish a controversial weapon. The financial olout of this weapon, a seldomused section of the State Banking Law called Article XII, could prove to be tremendous. (It's a license to steal, complains one officer of a New York commercial bank.)

title: A Merry Widow Hits the Jackpot
description: EVER since she was a very young girl, Mary Higgins Clark always said she wanted to have six children so they could sit even on a bus. Today. Mrs. Clark whose bestselling novel. Where Are the Children? (Dell: $1.95)is in its 13th printing and already has sold more than 1.6 million copiesin paperback,is the mother of five children and still regrets that she didn't have six.

title: Deborah C. Woodward is Married
description: Deborah Coolidge Woodward, daughter of Mrs. John D. Runyan of Dayton, Ohio, and the late Robert Woodward, was married yesterday afternoon to Harry Griffin Billings. The Rev. Robert Fenwick performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Dayton.

title: Ashe, Ramirez Gain Semifinals; Injury Forces Connors to Default
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 (AP)Arthur Ashe and Raul Ramirez of Mexico won their quarterfinal matches today and will meet tomorrow in a semifinal match of the $125,000 Pacific Southwest open tournament  at Pauley Pavilion.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONThere are not many people around who have been honored, in different ways, by George Meany, Richard M. Nixon and Valdry Giscard d'Estaing.

title: DINING OUT
description: LOOKS can he misleading. Don't be put off by the exterior of this restaurant, a couple of storefronts with neon Rhinegold signs in the windows. Inside are two pleasant rooms with white stucco walls and red checkered tablecloths. What counts is the food.

title: Army Engineers In Arabia: Why?
description: American contractors swarming to the Saudi Arabian peninsula in pursuit of a piece of the Arab nation's $144 billion development programthe largest construction effort in peacetime historyare finding a familiar face across the bargaining table the United States Army Corps of Engineers.

title: Literary criticism for the uncommon and the common reader
description: It is well known that the most advanced literary critics have become weary of the themes and purposes traditionally assigned to them. Many critics wbo regard Practical Criticism as a mechanical exercise are resorting to intellectual activities which are metaphysical rather than literary. Much of this work is best understood as proposing a secular version of metaphysics or a scheme of postChristian ethics. Leo Bersanfs new book is a case hi point it is literary in the sense that it is a commentary upon works of literature, mostly fiction and drama, but it is criticism only in a special sense. Professor Bersani is not interested in discriminating between works of literature good, bad, or indifferent. He is chiefly engaged in mounting an argument in favor of psychic mobility, a condition in which we release ourselves from the rigidity enforced by a psychology of the coherently structured and significantly expressive self. The works he chooses for discussion either support such a psychology or affront it; either way, they become texts for a commentary better understood as a rhetoric than a critique. Professor Bersani's art is offered as an interpretive fiction, a meditative structure provoked by works of literature but ready at any moment to act independently and to consult its own interests.

title: Food
description: With the zucchini running rampant, the tomatoes begging to be gathered and the basil turning into bushes, what better use of September produce than in recipes from the Italian kitchen. The combination of seasonal, properly ripe vegetables with fine, pure olive oil, fresh herbs and cheese is half the secret of the success of the recipes. The other half is the timing: Italians never overcook a vegetable. One of our favorite meals for early autumn consists of a first course, in which raw, ripe salad tomatoes make the sauce for pasta, and one of the three following second courses assorted hatterdipped fried vegetables baked, stuffed tomatoes; or a fragrant topofthestove casserole of peppers, potatoes, zucchini and herbs. Served with a glass of chilled, dry white wine and a piece of fresh Italian bread, these dishes salute September.

title: BLUECOLLAR WAGES HELP SWELL BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25When Senator A.S. (Mike) Monroney was running for reelection in 1968, he managed to get a provision written into the Federal compensation laws designed to benefit a group of Federal wage workers in his home state of Oklahoma.

title: Margaret Winters Married to John C. Everett
description: Margaret O'Brien Winters of Little Silver, N.J., widow of Dr. Daniel McCoy Winters, an orthopedic surgeon, was married yesterday to John Carroll Everett of Scituate, Mass., and Atlanta. The Rev. Ambrose Graham performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church in Cohasset. Mass.

title: POLITICS
description: THERE is some confusion over whether Joseph A. Hoffman quit or was dismissed as the state's Commissioner of Labor and Industry earlier this month. Mr. Hoffman explained that he was just getting ready to resign when Governor Byrne pushed him out the door.

title: Arraignment Lag In New YorkCity Hurting Innocent
description: Many of the 4,000 people arrested in New York City each week are being held in police detention cells for as long as three days without a court hearing because of a breakdown in the arraignment system.

title: Elizabeth Jones Has Wedding
description: Susan Elizabeth Jones, a legislative assistant to State Senator Roy M. Goodman, RepublicanLiberal of Manhattan, was married yesterday afternoon to Peter Wyckoff Mettler of New York, a trial lawyer with the Internal 1Revenue Service.

title: Divinity Schools Get Grant
description: The Kresge Foundation has awarded a $100,000 grant to Colgate Rochester Divinity SchoolBexley HallCrozer Theological Seminary, an ecumenical cluster of divinity schools in Rochester, N.Y. The grant will increase the shelving capacity of the schools Ambrose Swasey Library by about 14 percent. The library, with more than 180,000 volumes, is regarded as one of the foremost theological collections in the country.

title: Michigan Routs Navy By 70 to 14
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 25 (AP)Rick Leach, Michigan's sophomore quarterback, ran for two touchdowns and passed for two more today as the topranked Wolverines routed. Navy. 7014.

title: Adolf Hitler
description: There have been biographies of Adolf Hitler and histories of the Nazi era almost without number; the clue to John Toland's success in telling us more than we knew before about Hitler is the astonishing number of personal interviewsover 150 and most of them tapedthat he managed to obtain. Listed at the end of this book, they show that he managed to talk to many Germans who would not normally have granted an interview to an American or any other foreign writer, and to some who would not normally be interviewed at all.

title: Viking to Hunt Soil for a Life Test
description: PASADENA, Calif, Sept. 25The mechanical arm of the Viking 2 lander was commanded to reach out today and scoop up another sample of Martian soil for a chemical test that could be crucial to the search for life on Mars.

title: GEN. FRANK S. BOWEN; SERVED IN THE PACIFIC
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 25 (AP)Maj. Gen. Frank S. Bowen, one of the nation's most decorated soldiers and former commanding officer at Fort Jackson, S. C., died yesterday at Moncrief Army Hospital. He was 71 years old.

title: Larries Open on Sour Note
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25Penn Charter, which hadn't defeated Lawrenceville in several years, snapped back with a vengeance today as piled up points and yardage in a 3013 trouncing of the visitors. it was the home team's second victory while the loss opened Lawrenceville's 100th football season on the wrong foot.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Last week Hanae Mori, one of Japan's top fashion designers, opened a boutique in New York. Next January she plans to establish her own couture house on the fashionable Avenue Montaigne in Paris, thereby becoming one of the few women who have tried to succeed in the maledominated French fashion capital since World War II.

title: Cairo Garbage Gives Migrants A Good Living
description: CAIRO, Sept. 24Snarling dogs prowl an area still smoldering from a fire of two months ago. The stench of garbage fills the air, and dead rats litter the dirt streets of a city of black metal huts in the nearby Mukattem Hills.

title: A British Team Will Aid Transition
description: LONDON, Sept. 25Britain will assign an advisory team to Rhodesia, probably within the next few days, to oversee the proposed transition from white to black rule, the Foreign Office said today.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: So La Scala and the Paris Opera have come and gone. it was a pity that La Scala did not take any of its productions to New York after its Kennedy Center run. Washington was luckier than New York, for Paris repeated its three productions in Washington after leaving the Metropolitan Opera. The only taste that New York got of La Scala was a performance of the Verdi Requiem in Carnegie Hall.

title: The Horsey Set Is Going Public
description: MELVILLE IT was early Sunday morning and the parking lot at the Thomas School of Horsemanship was jammed with cars. Some of them had behind them the boxlike metal vans used for transporting horses.

title: Births
description: Susan and Steven Gold (nee Smith) joyfully announce the birth of Joshua Harris's brother, David Eric, on Sent. 20, 1976. Proud grandparents are Mr. and Mrs. Lee Gold and Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Smith.

title: Brown, the King of Ivy Soccer, Can Expect Challenge to Reign
description: Cliff Stevenson, the coach at Brown, obviously didn't have Yale in mind when he predicted before the season that the Ivy League is going to be ctronger than ever before. Stevenson's statement applies more to his team, which dominated the league the last three years and reached the National Collegiate semifinals twice. The Bruins opened defense of their threeyear title by trouncing Yale, 111, but the road will not be as rosy the rest of the way this leason. The strongest challenges will come from Penn, Harvard, Cornell and Columbia. Yes, the same Columbia that finished at the bottom last year.

title: Pear and Apple Trees Upstate Are Devastated by Fire Blight
description: ALBANY, Sept. 25An epidemic of fire blight, a bacterial disease that devastates pear and apple trees, has been spreading this year along the south shore of Lake Ontario, one of New York State's major fruitproducing areas.

title: DINING OUT
description: VISUALLY, Archers is striking, with its tintedglass facade, plantfilled cocktail lounge and marble and mirrorfilled dining rooms on two floors. Beyond that, unfortunately, this is a very routine Italian restaurant. Not bad, but certainly nothing special. Chicken alla Fiorentina (with spinach) was a boned, sauteed breast that came off well tender and not greasy.

title: Bayonne Seeking A New Rail Link
description: EARLY this fall, according to State Transportation Commissioner Alan Sagner, Hudson County residents will be asked to comment on and endorse a new BayonneJersey City railtransit plan now being studied by special consultants.

title: Deaths
description: ALDORPeter, of Bogota, Colombia, on September 20, 19/6. Beloved husband of Eva. His death is mourned deeply by his family.

title: QUEENS CLAIMANTS BAFFLED BY SYSTEM
