description: More than 40 percent of the claimants who won cases in the Queens County small claims court over the last three year were unable to collect on court judgments, according to a recent study.

title: Endpaper
description: In the months since our first commuter chronicle, men and women of the suburbs have continued to ride the rails through adversity to wrest their sustenance from a still heartless city. Here, then, are more of their tales, attested to by onthescene obseriers I believe to be completely credible, and enduringly courageous as well.

title: Louisville to Hold Race of Champions
description: Louisville (Ky.) Downs will be be the site of the Race of Champions of the American Motorcycle Association's Camel Pro Series for the third time on Sunday. Oct 17.

title: COLOR IT BRIGHT FOR KIDS
description: Design for children's rooms thrives on colorsthe bolder the betterin stenciling floors, papering walls or transforming closets.

title: Diane Indiveri is Bride Of Robert James Zingali
description: Diane Patricia Indiveri and Robert James Zingali were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of SS. John and Mary in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Ohio State Upset, 2221, By Missouri
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 25Pete Woods, a substitute quarterback, tossed a 2yard touchdown pass to Leo Lewis with 12 seconds left in the game and then ran for a 2point conversion today to give Missouri a 2221 victory, over powerful Ohio State.

title: New London Gets Flood Aid
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Sept. 25 (AP)The United States House Public Works Committee has approved $7.1 million for a New London flood control project. The expenditure is part of House and Senate bills concerning harbors and rivers.

title: State Education Commissioner Orders Rockville Centre to Integrate Racially Imbalanced School
description: ALBANY, Sept. 25The State Education Commissioner has ordered the Rockville Centre, L. I., Board of Education to devise a plan for achieving quality integrated education at its racially imbalanced Floyd B. Watson Elementary School.

title: How Ragtime Led to Discord
description: Los ANGELES It has been two years since the enterprising producer Dino De Laurentiis optioned Ragtime, E: L. Doctorow's critically acclaimed and popular blend of fact and fiction, which featured imaginative renderings of such reallife figures as Harry Houdini, Evelyn Nesbitt Thaw and J. Pierpont Morgan. However, a movie has yet to be made of Ragtime. Why? The answer lies in the interactionand squabblingof some of the best known and most admired talents ???n the entertainment industry.

title: INGENUITY COUNTS MOST
description: Recycled kitchen Four years ago, Paul Segal, an architect, renovated this kitchen, in an older apartment building, at a cost of $6,500. Both the counter and the backsplash are surfaced in butcher block, and the leftover wood was used to make the ceiling cove. Shelves are lighted from above and below.

title: The Dream Deferred
description: Three years after Richard Nixon declared the urban crisis ended, New York's fiscal plight, Boston's school agony and San Francisco's shootout with public employee unions have put the issue of urban America back on the front page, and I hope, the national agenda. Understandably, to date, the problems of the central city have captured the lion's share of public attention. Samuel Kaplans contribution is to remind us vividly of the other, larger part of our urban complexes where the majority of Americans now live; suburbia. His message is that there are problems there too.

title: On the Track of the Unwed Father
description: WE live in a society in which an unwed mother is often valued no more and treated no better than a stray dog, and often she has been conditioned to accept her lot as deserved.

title: The Action Offshore Is on the Shelf
description: THEY say it all really started in 1974 with the Arab oil embargo. There were lines inching through the streets and wrapping around blocks like thirsty boa constrictors in a daze. Today things have changed, but not necessarily for the better.

title: APOWER OPPOSITION GROWING IN EUROPE
description: LONDON, Sept. 25Public opposition to nuclear power in western Europe, long cerebral, apolitical and ineffective, is gathering the kind of force that has slowed reactor building in many parts of the United States.

title: Dee Lewis and John T. Zerbst to Marry Oct. 16
description: Judith Dee Lewis and John Thomas Zerbst plan to be married in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church on Oct. 16.

title: A No  Work Perennial Border For the Lazy Gardener
description: Can a lazy person have a beautiful perennial garden that blooms from June to Labor Day with one hour of work a week?

title: No Sound, No Fury
description: NEW HAVEN Thetwomart show that opened at the Walnut Street Theater in Philadelphia last Thursday night was performed behind two lecterns separated by a modern abstract form that vaguely resembled a bomb. Though it is cruel to judge a work that is obviously still in outoftown tryouts, this may well prove an approPriate symbol of the entire tour.

title: Doff Show Calendar
description: TodayWestbury K.C. allbreed and Nassau Dog Training Club trial, N.Y. Institute of Technolom Northern Boulevard (25A). Brookville, 2,151 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: Russo, Carty CoCaptains
description: Steven C. Russo and Derrick Carty, sophomores, have been named cocaptains of the crosscountry team at St. Francis College in Brooklyn. Russo is chemistry major from Bishop Loughlin High School in Brooklyn. Carty, from Gilbert High School in Brooklyn, is a.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Awhile ago, this department received a telegram that read simply: Flat Event. This was indeed conceptual dance at its most conceptual: The receipt of the telegram constituted the dance concert. Naturally, such phenomena bring mind the old question: What is dance? Dance esthetics, which wrestles with such problems, is not a new field, as readers of dance literature have long been aware. Lately, however, dance esthetics nas oecome an  area or IR terest not only to specialized dance magazines but also an increasing number of literary and philosophical journals.

title: SARKIS MOVING TO FORM NEW LEBANESE CABINET
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 25 (UPI)President Elias Sarkis accepted the resignation of Prime Minister Rashid Karami and his Cabinet today, the first step toward putting together a new government.

title: Catherine Seckel Bride of W. G. Thompson Jr.
description: Christ Episcopal Church in Sag Harbor, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Catherine Schmid Seckel, daughter of Mrs. Frederick C. Schmid of Sag Harbor and the late Mr. Schmid, to William Glasgow Thompson Jr. of Bridgehampton, L.I., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thompson of Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Correction
description: It was incorrectly stated in an article in lait Sunday's New York Times that Belscot Retailers, a Chicagobised retail chain, had been involved in a bankruptcy situation. Belscot has had a profit every year since its founding in 1968 and has strong credit and banking relationships.

title: Francois Truffaut  A Man for All Festivals
description: Someday, said Francois Truffaut, as he sat chainsmoking in his office off the ChampsElyses, I am going to direct a movie about my own childhood.

title: Onlyand lonelyin America
description: Six months ago, I went to the secondfloor banquet room of rundown West Side hotel to observe a welcoming session for batch of 30odd Russians. Each of them had paid the Soviet Government 500 rublesthe equivalent of five months salary for an average doctor or engineerfor the right to renounce Soviet citizenship. Twentyfour hours earlier, they had arrived as immigrants, at American expense, in New York City. Now, under the protective care of NYANA, the New York Association for New Americans, they were being briefed on the new life ahed of them.

title: It May Not Be Worth It
description: THERE is no dispute over whether the United States faces an energy problem. We are in worse shape today than we were two years ago, when the Arabs first turned off the oil spigot, because our dependence on Arab oil has more than doubled and because Congress has shown nn sign that it even comprehends the critical need for a national energy policy.

title: Yanks Win,Take Title as Orioles Lose
description: DETROIT, Sept. 25The power of positive thinking and the power of their bats led the New York Yankees to a 106 victory over the Detroit Tigers today and the knowledge that they can finish in no worse than a tie for the Eastern Division championship of the American League.

title: U.S.C. Crushes Purdue, 3113; Bell: 177 Yards
description: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind., Sept. 25 (AP)Ricky Bell, held to 89 yards against Purdue last year rushed for 177 yards and one touchdown today. and Vince Evans passed for 168 yards and another score to lead Southern California to a 3113 victory.

title: Cannot Be Neutral, On Abortion Issue, Cardinal Proclaims
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke told worshipers at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday that the Roman Catholic Church neither endorsed political candidates nor favored one political party over another but that it cannot be neutral on the abortion issue.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: A Natural History of Zebras, pictures by Ugo Mochi, text by Dorchas MacClintock (Scribner's, $7.95).

description: Horses listed in order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Social Security CheckDelivery On Saturdays Moved to Fridays
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI)  The 36 million Social Security recipients will receive their monthly benefit checks Friday instead of Saturday, the normal second of the month delivery date, because of an unpublicized Treasury Department policy change, groups of retirees have announced.

title: Everest Base Camp Established
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Sept. 26 (Reuters) Five Sherpas have established a camp for the American team climbing Mount Everest some 4,500 feet from the summit of the world's highest mountain, the Nepalese Foreign Ministry announced today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Some 700 maintenance personnel and guards at Columbia University are scheduled to strike at 6 A.M. today because of an impasse in their efforts to negotiate a new contract providing higher wages. The employees are members of Local 241 of the Transport Workers Union. A spokesman for the union said the workers, whose pay ranges from $3.85 an hour for cleaning personnel to $8.98 for power engineers, have sought a pay increase of about 5 percent a year in a twoyear contract.

title: Slovenes Accuse Austrians of Bias
description: GLOBASNITZ, Austria, Sept 26Slovenian activists accompanied by Yugoslav journalists held a rally in this southern Austrian mountain hamlet today to accuse this country of persecuting its siovene minority.

title: Angola President to Visit Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 26 (Reuters)President Agostinho Neto of Angola is to pay an official visit to the Soviet Union early next month, the Tess press agency reported today. The visit follows a friendship and cooperation agreement signed by the two countries last May.

title: Mayor's Neighbors Pelt Noisy Picketing Policemen
description: Nearly 1,000 offduty police officers, for the second day, noisily demonstrated early this morning in front of Gracie Mansion, angering neighborhood residents who pelted them with bottles and tomatoes.

title: Pole Succeeds in Meeting Reagan To Display G.O.P. Unity on Coast
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Sept. 26Senator Robert J. Dole has been tiptoeing gingerly for the last few days through the quicksands of California politics.

title: Robert B. Dresser, Lawyer And Conservative Spokesman
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 26 (AP)Robert B. Dresser, a lawyer, industrialist and outspoken political figure, died in his home yesterday. He was 95 years old.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Montreal Expos, twilightnight doubleheader, at Shea Stadium. Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens. 5:30 P.M.

title: Goldin Says Uncollected Fees At City U. Rose to $12.2 Million
description: Uncollected student fees at the City University rose from $3.3 million in 1973 to $12.2 million last June, according to an audit report released yesterday by City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin.

title: Editors Differ on Ethics of Using Political Candidates Paid Articles
description: Some weekly newspapers in Missouri and Tennessee have a longstanding practice of not reporting that candidates are running for political office unless the candidates pay for the article or take out paid political announcements.

title: A Correction
description: A typographical error distorted the meaning of a sentence in the Sept. 25 editorial Nuclear Second Thoughts. The sentence should have read: Obviously, neither he [Sir Brian Flowers] nor the [Royal] commission can be charged with the kind of illinformed prejudice and needless timidity that have been so unfairly imputed to critics here who have been warning against the danger of overreliance on the split atom as a source of power.

title: Consumers to Get Bigger Voice
description: MENDON, Vt., Sept. 26 (AP)Virginia H. Knauer, Pyesident Ford's special assistant for consumer affairs, says the President will announce a plan tomorrow that will require all major Federal agencies to appoint consumer, affairs assistants.

title: News Summary
description: Leaders of five African countries refused to accept the plan presented by the Rhodesian Prime Minister, Ian D. Smith, for the transfer to majority rule in Rhodesia. The presidents of Zambia, Tanzania, Botswana, Angola and Mozambique also called on Britain, as the colonial authority over Rhodesia, to convene a conference to work out new plan. The statement appeared to lessen chances for a quick settlement of the Rhodesian problem, but it did not close the door to further negotiations.

title: Film: The Rich, the Bored, 'The Sunday Woman'
description: A plot is the pretext for a good detective story, not its point. The characters and the setting are the point. The plot serves to display the characters in a conventional kind of motion, as a model's walk displays her clothes. It serves as a vehicle for making tours of the setting; the more rambling and full of holes it is, the better the view.The plot of the new Italian film, "Sunday Woman," is as full of holes as a plateful of macaroni. It creaks and rambles but it takes us through a dry and lovely comedy of manners, with Marcello Mastroianni, Jacqueline Bisset and Jean-Louis Trintignant all making the most of parts that allow them to show their gifts for stylishness and subtlety.It is set among the rich and boreda favorite predeliction of Italian filmsthis time, in Turin. It is a society of busy industrialists and wives who have plently of time and means for odd games and exotic relationships. For example, Ana Maria Dosio, wife of a rich businessman, spends a lot of time with Massimo Campi, the idle son of a rich family. The relationship is more or less platonicMassimo has a young man as a loverand is occupied mostly by a search for style. Massimo, for example, decides that it would be equally vulgar to own an expensive car and a cheap one, so he takes taxis. As the movie opens, the two of them are engaged in an interminably reasoned quarrel over whether pronouncing "Boston" with a Bostonian rather than an Italian intonation is the intelligent or the pretentious thing to do.Into this cobweb life two things erupt. Somebody smashes the head of Garrone, an unlikable crumb attached to Turin's upper crust. The weapon is one of the counterfeit ancient stone phalluses that he sells to foreigners. Quite a few members of Turinese high society, including Ana Maria and Massimo, had reason to dislike Garrone. So, with the greatest reluctance, the authorities put Inspector Santamaria on the case. Hiss assignment, in effect, is to solve the crime without catching anybody.Santamaria is the most winning and nuanced role that Mastrioanni has had for some time. He is a serious man of the middle class. He has aspirations to the good life, dresses in sport clothes that are a little too careful, and has an eye for women; but he is a moralist.He is sanely apprehensive about his mission. "Dsio. Dsio. Campi. Campi," he mutters, the emphasis acknowledging the trouble he will have with his glittering list of suspects. But he pursues it with tenacity.The encounters of this nave, sensitive but purposeful man with the sophisticated and purposeless Beautiful People of Turin are the film's heart. There is a marvelous first encounter with Massimo, played by Trintignant. Santamaria offers American cigarettes; Massimo insists on cheap local ones. Santamaria quotes an appropriate Latin tag: Massimo says he doesn't know Latin. Santamaria is after the good things; Massimo, who has them all, rejects them as vulgar.The comedy turns serious when Santamaria discovers Massimo's young lover. The two poses crack  Santamaria is deadly serious about the crime; Massimo is deadly serious about his lover  and the two are suddenly shouting at each other. Trintignant makes his jaded sophisticate both funny and affecting, man teetering on the edge of a crackup.Santamaria's encounters with Ana Maria are even better. Again, seriousness  this time in the form of mutual attractionbreaks through the comical and mannered fencing. Jacqueline Bisset, a beautiful and most skilled actress who is usually starved on silly parts, is a battleground of real feeling and decadent detachment, a tempest in a crystal wine glass.There is a whole gallery of minor characters, some of them trite but most with at least a few moments of comic inspiration. Aldo Reggiani is particularly good as Massimo's young lover; a mixture of dopiness and moonstruck passion.The ending of "The Sunday Woman," which opened yesterday at the Fine Arts Theater, is a surprise, but it is a distant surprise and irrelevant. A mystery villain should be under our noses all the time. It is the final creak in the plot, but I was too pleased by the scenery to mind the destination.

title: Youths Roaming Through Midtown Terrorize and Attack PassersBy
description: At least one band of youths roamed through midtown Manhattan for several hours Saturday night and Sunday morning in the wake of a Madison Square Garden rock concert, terrorizing, attacking ind robbing passersby before the group was broken up by police.

title: Edith L Sachs, 82, Board Member Of the Mt. Sinai Medical Center
description: Edith L. Sachs, a member of the board of trustees of the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan and founder of a rehabilitation workshop there for disabled patients, died Saturday at her home at 993 Fifth Avenue after a long illness. She was 82 years old.

title: King Cotton is Seeking Throne Lost to Polyester
description: RALEIGH, N. C.As a result of sophisticated New South marketing techniques and product research, King Cotton, dethroned a decade ago by pretender named polyester, is making a strong bid for a return to his former reign.

title: The Terms, as Stated by Smith
description: Following, as stated by Prime Minister Ian D. Smith are the proposals put forward by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and accepted by Mr. Smith for Rhodesia's move toward majority government:

title: Correction Officers Assail Judge
description: The union that represents the city's 2,800 correction officers announced yesterday that it had asked for a review of what it termed a toolenient sentence of an inmate who assaulted a guard at a Rikers Island prison earlier this year.

title: CAREY AND MOYNIHAN TO ADDRESS LIBERALS
description: Governor Carey will make an unusual appearance at a meeting of Liberal Party leaders today to try to snuff out the rebellion over the proposed endorsement of Daniel P. Moynihan for United States Senator from New York.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Sept. 26The State Assembly returns to work tomorrow, with a long squabble over state aid to education one of the unresolved questions likely to be taken up.

title: Rhodesia Aide: it is Up to West
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 26Pieter K, Van der Byl, Rhodesia's Foreign Minister, said today that in light of the five black African Presidents refusal to accept key aspects of the BritishAmerican proposals for a transition to black majority rule it was now up to the Western powers, America and South Africa in particular, to sort it out.

title: Canal Treaty in Peril
description: It would be an unspeakable tragedy if a new Panama Canal treatyan imperative for future United States relations with Latin Americashould become a casualty of the American Presidential campaign; but errors and excesses in both countries have made this an alarming possibility.

title: Dolphins Are Helped to Triumph by 5 Turnovers
description: For the second week in a row we didn't score a touchdown, said Lou Holtz, the Jets coach as he pondered his team's third straight defeat. We had five turnovers [four lost fumbles plus the interception] and three 15penalties. There's no way in the world you can win that way. it is difficult enough to play Miami without turnovers.

title: Vast Oil Revenues and Revolution Have Changed the Face of Libya
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Sept. 20Scarcely two decades ago Libya was called the poorest country in the world, but now new buildings are going up in every corner of this capital, the port is clogged with freighters from all over the world, the streets are lined with MercedesBenzes, Volkswagens and Peugeot pickup trucks, and the hotels are crowded with foreign consultants and contractors.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Citizens Group Suggests Savings For New York on Welfare Costs
description: A citizens group estimated yesterday that New York City would save $22.6 million a year  $10.1 million in local taxes, the rest in state and Federal sharingif it stopped exceeding state standards for special welfare grants and group daycare costs.

title: Ford's Son Sees Truth In Interview by Carter
description: SOUTH HAMILTON, Mass., Sept. 26 (AP)  Michael Ford, eldest son of the President, says that as a divinity student he thinks Jimmy Carter's comments on adultery were an honest expression.

title: Mrs. Young, Snead Win
description: The big figure in golf yesterday was $35,000. Mrs. Donna Caponi Young won that prize, the largest in women's golf, with a fivestroke victory in the Carlton tournament at Calabasas, Calif. In Napa Calif., J. C. Snead had a final round 68 and earned the same amount in the Kaiser International tourney. Page 45.

title: Mondale Terms U.S. Indifferent To Needs of Emerging Countries
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  Senator Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic VicePresidential candidate, assailed United States foreign policy today as one that is frequently indifferent to people seeking greater justice and that feels threatened by movements demanding greater equality.

title: JetsDolphins Scoring
Danbury High, Once Racially Split, is New School Today
description: DANBURY, Conn.A year ago Danbury High School was torn by fighting between black and white students. The trouble had stirred for days and finally, on Oct. 1, erupted into a huge brawl, with students swinging belts and chains and throwing stones and chairs and whatever else they could pick up or tear loose.

title: A Testament
description: WASHINGTON  on Sept. 10 the Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet issued Decree No. 588, which strips me of my nationality, for gravely threatening the essential interests of the state. This measure is just one more addition to the shameful history of the violation of human rights committed by the military junta.

title: Alaska Airlines Hit by Strike
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 26 (AP)Alaska Airlines flight attendants, who had worked without a contract for 18 months, went on strike last night when bargaining on wages and other issues broke down. The carrier said it would operate one flight daily between Seattle and Anchorage.

title: Look CloselyThe Cigarette Gives it Away
description: At first glance, the paintings look like the work of Holbein, Titian and AlmaTadema.

title: Yankees Biggest Fans Shouting Vamos!
description: With the New York Yankees officially in the American League playoff since Saturday night, yesterday was a day of exultation for those most avid of Yankee baseball fans, Puerto Ricans, who are rapidly becoming to the Bronx what the Dodger fans were to Brooklyn.

title: Hughes and Nets Agree; Center Will Report Today
description: Kim Hughes, the Nets center, agreed last night to report to preseason training camp after an agreement was reached on his contract.

title: Bangladesh Leader Accuses India Of Training and Arming Guerrillas
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Sept. 26The military ruler of the Government here has charged that India was systematically training Bangladeshi dissidents as guerrillas and was helping them to infiltrate into the country from several dozen special camps it had set up along the border.

title: Yanks Return to the Top: The Names Are changed But Results Are the Same
description: Back in the days when pennants flew over Yankee Stadium as routinely as dirty air hovered over New York, it was easy to understand why the Yankees reigned as perennial pennant winners. The reasons were Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig, Joe DiMaggio and Mickey Mantle, Bill Dickey and Yogi Berra, Red Ruffing and Whitey Ford.

title: Background Facts And Figures on Libyai
description: Area679,358 square miles. Population2,680,000.

title: A Young Socialist Assails but Fights for Schmidt
description: BONN, Sept. 24One of Helmut Schmidt's biggest handicaps in the national elections Oct. 3 is middleclass fear of the Young Socialists in his party.

title: Market Place
description: Exchange funds are like weeds. Congress chops them down, turns its back, and they come again.

title: Soviet Union Demands the Return Of Pilot Who Flew Plane to Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 26 (UPI)The Soviet Union has sent a protest to Iran demanding the return of a Soviet Air Force lieutenant who fled last week in a small, nonmilitary plane, a Soviet Embassy source said today.

title: China Tests Nuclear Device in a Show of Resolve After Mao's Death
description: PEKING, Sept. 26 (Reuters)China tonight announced it had conducted successfully a new nuclear test in an implicit demonstration that Mao Tsetung's death would not weaken its military resolve.

title: Fight Fans Fly in From All Corners
description: From the very beginning, Mike Burke knew that the $200 seats wouldn't be a problem. From the very beginning, he knew that the highrollers would go to the hip for the big bucks. A $200 seat to a fight, especially a fight with Muhammad Ali, is something special. And the highrollers make it a condition of membership to appear at something special.

title: Music: A Fascination for Mahler
description: The New York Philharmonic started its Mahler month last night in Carnegie Hall, and the audience filled every nook and cranny of the venerable auditorium. Mahler continues to exert his fascination as a contemporary culture hero and symbol.

title: Los Angeles Gains a 2410 Victory After Trailing
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26Atter promising first quarter in which they took a 10.0 lead, the Giants couldn't do much against the Los Angeles Rams at the Coliseum today and took their third straight defeat of the young football season, 2410.

title: BLASE VILIM DIES AT 67; CZECH SOCIAL DEMOCRAT
description: Blasej Vilim, who had been secretary general of the Czechoslovak Social Democratic Party before the Communist coup in 1948, died Thursday in London of heart attack. He was 67 years old.

title: About New York
description: On a recent Monday morning, as the city cleaned out its social catch basins after a routinely gamy weekend, the Brooklyn police ran out of jail space.

title: Brazil is Hopeful Oil Discovery In Iraq Will Turn Into Bonanza
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  With Brazil's economic development and consumption of oil rapidly increasing, a search has been under way to find major new petroleum sources. Now, Government officials believe they have found their bonanza6,000 miles away in Iraq.

title: VOTER POLL FINDS DEBATE AIDED FORD AND CUT CARTER LEAD
description: In the prevailing view of the American. electorate, President Ford won his crucial first debate with Jimmy Carter on Thursday night, a poll by The New York Times and CBS News indicates.

title: NEW RISE EXPECTED IN RATES THIS WEEK
description: Interest rates, which climbed sharply higher last Thursday afternoon and again on Friday, seem likely to continue to move higher this week, many investment bankers believe, in the wake of the Federal Reserve's disclosure of a weekly record increase in the nation's money supply. With the dedines late in the week, bond prices last week dropped for the first time since midAugust. Over the course of one week, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company remarked in its MoneyMarket Bulletin, the summer was gone and the debt market world had swung from virtual exuberance to a grimmer autumnal reality.

title: Machine Tool Orders in August Totaled $203.8 Million, 11.2% Higher Than July's
description: Machine tool orders in August totaled $203.8 million and were 11.2 percent ahead of the July total of $183.3 million and 98.3 percent above the $102.8 million ordered in 1975, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported over the weekend. As a result, total orders for the first eight months soared 75 percent ahead of the like 1975 period and totaled $1.29 billion.

title: Vast Oil Revenues and Revolution Have Changed the Face of Libya
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Sept. 20Scarcely two decades ago Libya was called the poorest country in the world, but now new buildings are going up in every corner of this capital, the port is clogged with freighters from all over the world, the streets are lined with MercedesBenzes, Volkswagens and Peugeot pickup trucks, and the hotels are crowded with foreign consultants and contractors.

title: State of the Arts
description: The cultural bubble of the 1960's has never really burst; contrary to rumor and recession, the arts are flourishing in America. it is a curious, perverse flowering, in which creativity and nihilism are often equated, but what both fine and performing arts lack in easy comprehensibility is made up in intellectual ferment, productive energy and very real achievement.

title: Bridge:

Carlo Mosca and Silvio Sbarigia, two highly talented young Italians who were members of the team that just failed to win the world Olympiad team title in Monte Carlo this year, employ a surprising extension of the canap concept.

title: Theater: Home Boy Goes North
description: Home Boy, which opened last night at the comfortable new Terry Street Theater, is the fifth play in Ed Bullins's projected 20play cycle about blacks in contemporary America. Later this season Mr. Bullins has promised to deliver Daddy, the sixth play in the series. Next week, a noncycle, independent work by the author, Joanne, scheduled to open at the Theater of the Riverside Church. One of the inevitable results of being so prolific and talented is that Mr. Bullins has to be compared with himself.

title: Kidnapped Woman Found Tied to a Tree in Florida; Friend's Brother is Held
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 26 (UPI)A 35yearold woman who was kidnapped from her home four days ago was found today tied to a tree in a wooded area of South Jacksonville. The Federal Bureau of Investigation charged the brother of her husband's finest friend with the crime.

title: Yankees Biggest Fans Shouting iVamos!
description: With the New York Yankees officially in the American League playoff since Saturday night, yesterday was a day of exultation for those most avid of Yankee baseball fans, Puerto Ricans, who are rapidly becoming to the Bronx what the Dodger fans were to Brooklyn.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: There is a certain nostalgia about candymaking in the home, a pastime that was popular before the advent of television and caloriecounting.

title: 1,167 Persons Queried In TimesCBS Survey
description: The New York Times/CBS News survey is based on telephone interviews conducted on Sept. 24 and Sept.25 with 1,167 adult men and women across the continental United States.

title: Beverly Somach Handles Violin With Brilliance, but Lacking Flair
description: Beverly Somach, a former child prodigy who retired to rear a family and then returned to the concert stage seven years ago, gave a recital at Alice Tully Hall yesterday that proved a consistent demonstration of highquality violin playing. Miss Somach, solidly and authoritatively partnered by the pianist Fritz Jahoda, performed a program full of technical and musical difficulties, negotiating its shoals and narrows expertly.

title: Guerrillas Hold 90 in Syrian Hotel, Are Overpowered in 7Hour Battle
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 26 Four guerrillas, believed to be Palestinians opposed to Syria's intervention in Lebanon, seized a hotel and 90 hostages in downtown Damascus at dawn today and fought a bloody battle with Syrian troops before being overpowered.

title: News Summary
description: Leaders of five African countries refused to accept the plan presented by the Rhodesian Prime Minister, Ian D. Smith, for the transfer to majority rule in Rhodesia. The presidents of Zambia, Tanzania, Botswana, Angola and Mozambique also called on Britain, as the colonial authority over Rhodesia, to convene a conference to work out new plan. The statement appeared to lessen chances for a quick settlement of the Rhodesian problem, but it did not close the door to further negotiations. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Events Today
description: SIAMSA, National Folk Theater of Ireland, Pat Ahern, artistic director; at the Palace Theater, Broadway and 47th Street, 7.

title: Soybean Plant Yields Increased 10% in Tests of More Efficient Bacteria
description: Researchers at Oregon State University have found that by changing the type of bacteria that colonize the roots of soybean plants, it may be possible to increase the plant's yield by as much as 10 percent.

title: J. C. Snead Shoots a 68 for 274 And Captures Kaiser Golf by
description: NAPA, Calif., Sept. 26 (AP)J.C. Snead shot a final round of fourunderpar 68 today and denied Johnny Miller a third consecutive victory in the Kaiser International open golf tournament.

title: New Management System Tightens Beame's Control
description: Mayor Beame has started using an extensive new management system that, for the first time, elicits monthly performance reports from 30 city agencies and marks a greater intrusion by City Hall into their operations.

title: Taxing the Economy
description: Municipal Assistance Corporation chairman Felix Rohatyn warned the other day that high and steeply rising realty taxes were undermining the rescue of New York City's economy. To avert this threat, he proposed a Federal loan guarantee program that would enable the city to stretch out its massive accumulation of debt and thus to reduce annual debt service charges which must be paid out of property tax revenues. Mayor Beame also is reported to be looking for ways to cut taxes in conjunction with a new economic development program.

title: Radio
Screen: Dutch 'Keetje Tippel':Sentiment Fairly Abounds at the 68th St. Playhouse
description: "Keetje Tippel" is doubtless one of the most gorgeous movies of the year, which is by no means to declare it one of the best. But giving this Dutch film its due is a little like making sport of "Cinderella.""Keetje Tippel," which opened yesterday at the 68th Street Playhouse, comes to us so coated with the sugar of its splendid costuming, its meticulously re-created late 19th-century Amsterdam atmosphere and the classicism of its improbable, happy ending that the temptation is not so much to advise prospective audiences to check their critical faculties at the door as to check their teeth for fresh cavities upon departing.There is little mitigation in the knowledge that the story told in "Keetje Tippel" is described as being based on factthe memoirs of a woman named Neel Doff. With her name changed in this film to Keetje (pronounced Kate-yuh), she is one of the children in an impoverished, oversized rural family that, like many others, migrated in 1881 to Amsterdam in search of food and work.A raw, coarse, nave and irrepressibly spirited girl, she fights against hazing by her fellow workers in a lethal wool factory, is subjected to rape at the hands of a milliner, submits to a doctor who names sex as his price for saving her from death from tuberculosis and becomes a whore under the chaperonage of her mother before her life takes a sudden turn for the better.The events of "Ketje Tippel" take place amid the terrible poverty of Keetje's family and others like it. One of her sisters is a prostitute. Her young brother takes money from a homosexual. People steal broad. Water floods their homes. Wooden shoes are used for firewood. Warmth and a little food represent dreams come true.Present in "Keetje Tippel" are the ingredients for powerful social commentary, but the collaboration of the director, Paul Verhoeven, and the cinematographer, Jan de Bont, has produced a movie that is romantic about adversity. From time to time, as though having pangs about the lavish patina they have imposed on such crushing poverty, the movie-makers inject a burst of revolutionary song, an artist who paints revolutionary pictures, though romantic ones; and a confrontation between workers and the police.As Keetje, Monique van de Ven has a field day, making the most of a role that enables her to undergo a transformation from hoyden to lady, playing by turns the coarse peasant, the innocent shop girl and the reluctant prostitute before blossoming into a radiant woman despite everybody and everything that might have destroyed her.By and large, her indestructible spirit is admirable. But it comes to us in a context that makes it seem like one more ingredient in a very well made commercial designed to make hideous social inequality appear appetizing and acceptable.

title: Mondale Terms U.S. Indifferent To Needs of Emerging Countries
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  Senator Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic VicePresidential candidate, assailed United States foreign policy today as one that is frequently indifferent to people seeking greater justice and that feels threatened by movements demanding greater equality.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 (AP)Bill Barber scored three goals and assisted on a fourth as he led the Philadelphia Flyers to a 75 National Hockey League preseason victory over the New York Rangers tonight.

description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 (AP) Brian Gottfried upset Me Nastase, 26, 64, 75, in the semifinals of the $125,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis tournament at Pauley Pavilion today.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)Some 2,500 persons walked in a memorial procession here today for Orlando Letelier, the former Ohilean Foreign and Defense Minister killed in a bomb explosion Tuesday, then attended a funeral mass at St. Matthew's Cathedral.

title: Another Warsaw Retreat
description: The Polish Government announced the other day that it is abandoning all plans to increase basic food prices until at least mid1978. This is the latest and in some ways most impressive retreat of the Warsaw regime before the anger of Polish workers so violently expressed last June during the shortlived effort to raise food prices.

description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Sept. 26Lieut Gov. Ralph Steinhauer of Alberta, the first Indian to head a Canadian province as the official representative of Queen Elizabeth it in provincial affairs, frequently breaks protocol on behalf of Indians with grievances against the white government.

At a signal, they crouched and began to jab and spar with the sticks, soon no more than blurs in the air, and scores of onlookers cheered.

title: BRITAIN IS PRESSING ITS ROLE IN RHODESIA
description: LONDON, Sept. 26Britain, anxious to salvage the twodayold plan for Rhodesia, said tonight that it would help organize an interim government leading to black majority rule in the rebel colony.

title: Francis L. Albert, Navy Chaplain In Western Pacific in World War
description: Capt. Francis L. Albert, a Protestant Navy chaplain from 1918 until his retirement in 1953 who was decorated several times for his service in World War II, died Friday at the Ormond Beach Hospital at Ormond Beach, Fla., where he lived. He was 82 years old.

title: Advertising

title: An Attractive Concert of Sibelius Is Finland's Gift to Bicentennial
description: Today, with the stirrings of a Sibelius revival all around us, it may seem odd that the Finnish composer fell so far out of fashion as he did in the 1950's and 60's. He never disappeared completely, to be sure there was too much character and craft in his music for that. But here was a composer of demonstrable individuality and ability to please symphony subscribers, and he wasn't being played. it seemed perverse.

title: Whether It's a Musical or an Opera, It's a FirstRate Porgy and Bess
description: The best musical on Broadway tonight is not a musical. it is an opera. it is Porgy and Bess and it opened at the Uris Theater on Saturday night, and I am almost embarrassed to tell you about it, because although I am an opera buff I am not an opera critic. The curtain had not been up for 10 minutes when I had a feeling that Harold C. Schonberg should be sitting in my seat. Then, despite a touch of guilt and a profound sense of inadequacy, I relaxed and enjoyed myself. And I enjoyed myself mightily. This production was a revelation.

description: In the prevailing view of the American electorate, President Ford won his crucial first debate with Jimmy Carter on Thursday night, a poll by The New York Times and CBS News indicates.

title: Beirut Peace Hopes Dampened as Syria Accuses the P.L.O.
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 26President Elias Sarkis's chances of leading Lebanon back to peace received a crippling blow today when Syrian Government reports said that Al Fatah, the mainstream Palestinian guerrilla organization, had been responsible for the attack on the Semiramis Hotel in Damascus this morning.

title: MexicaliTijuana Road Still Out
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 26 (AP)The road between Mexicali and Tijuana is still washed out as a result of a sbonn that swept northern Baja California earlier this month, the Public Works Secretariat reported today it said that travelers between Mexicali and Tijuana are being rerouted on the United States side of the border and to the route from Mexicali to Tijuana via San Felipe and Ensenada.

title: Ethiopia Transfers the Control Of Its Schools to Local Bodies
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 26 (Agence FrancePresse)Ethiopia's military government issued a proclamation today giving responsibility and control of the lower levels of public education to the Ethiopan people.

title: Going out Guide
description: STONE WALLS The Fortune Society is an organization of former offenders and others interested in the problems of prisons and correction. The society has been active in providing a forum for the problem, and now it is starting a Criminal Justice Forum, a panel discussion series to be held on the last Monday of each month.

title: 3 for Nystrom As Islanders Down Sabres
description: BUFFALO, Sept.26 (AP)60b Nys trom scored three times and Billy Smith turned in a strong performance in goal as they led the New York Islanders to a 42 victory over Buffalo in a National Hockey League exhibition game tonight.

title: Phils Win, Take Title In Division
description: MONTREAL. Sept. 26 (AP)The Philadelphia Phillies, led by Greg Luzinski's threerun homer, clinched the National League's East Division title today by beating the Montreal Expos, 41, in the first game of a doubleheader. The Phillies also won the second came. 21.

title: Books of The Times
description: There comes a point near the end of How it Was, Mary Welsh Hemingway's memoir of her life and times with and without her husband, Ernest, when the author suddenly begins to parody herself. In the winter months in New York [in 1966]  I followed orders scrawled or implied in my desk calendar: ScalperMan for All Seasons. Evelyn Duys; check to Leg. Def. Fund. 57 Architectural League; Ellisons, limierorder car; flowers to Mat Chase Brown; tickets, StarSpangled Girl; Brunch, Fran Koltun; check to World Wildlife; 8:30 Rubinstein, Carnegie; Call Jimmy Sheean; fly Miami, Dave, Tina Roberts; reserve La Caravelle; ducks here, Peter Schub  And so en.

title: Questions on Vaccine
description: The United States Government is about to begin an unprecedented campaign of mass immunizations by vaccine against swine influenza, a disease still conspicuous by its absence. Several recent news items strengthen our impression that on flu and other vaccines there is less certainty and knowledge than one would like to have prior to the initiation of a program whose goal is the vaccination of virtually every man, woman and child in this country.

title: Debate Contributes to Carter Decline in One Neighborhood
description: ROCKFORD, Ill., Sept. 26A campaign poster for the entire Democratic ticket in Illinois, topped by the name Carter in big letters, appeared on Anthony Guzzardo's front lawn last week, tacked to a stake.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: SMELLING LIKE ROSES:

title: Legionnaire Wounded in Corsica
description: CORTE, Corsica, Sept. 26 (UPI)A French Foreign Legion soldier was wounded in an ambush and a plastic bomb attack today on the home of the local Legion commander. The Legionnaire was hit by a burst of gunfire as he drove an army jeep past a roadblock formed by townspeople demanding the withdrawal of all Foreign Legion units from the Mediterranean island, which is part of France.

title: Steve Cady
description: While they waited for Muhammad Ali, some of the men at the gym watched a darkhaired fighter stalk an imaginary opponent.

title: Isley Brothers Produce Raw, Energetic Sounds In Concert at the Garden
description: The current edition of the Isley Brothers consists of Ronald, Rudolph and Kelly Isley, who sang gospel music as children and were making hit records as early as 1959, and Ernie and Chris Isley and brotherinlaw Chris Jasper, who were raised on hard rock and joined the family band in 19 69. With the addition of a cricumspect but solid drummer, the group makes a raw, energetic sound that is something like a cross between a sanctified church service and a superamplified rock show.

title: ATOM POWER CURBS ON 6 STATE BALLOTS
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25Proposals to restrict atomic power development will be on the ballots in six states in the November election: Washington, Oregon, Arizona, Colorado, Montana and Ohio.

title: California Begins Quake Broadcasts
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26The voice, unmistakably, that of Bugs Bunny, and it asks: What do I do when the shaking stops?

title: New Fad: Creative Phone Messages
description: Hello, John's been taken in front of the galactic council, and he wants you to leave your name, number and grid coordinates so he can return your call by hydrophone as soon as the quark storm has subsided.

title: New Fad: Creative Phone Messages
description: The above concoction, by John Avildsen, the film director, is an example of a new and sometimes creative fad  highly personalized I'vegottabeme type of messages that squawk from New Yorkers telephone answering machines.

title: Parents Fought To Be With Children in Hospital And Won
description: Last November, Laurie Adams found herself at loggerheads with the pediatrics department of the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center when her then 3yearold daughter, Alexa, was taken there with pneumonia.

title: Memorial Services
description: GLICKMANRabbl Jack Stanley, Memortal Day is second day of Rosh Hashanah from 207579St. Brooklyn, H. Y. C.

title: POLICE DENY THEY CAUSED FATAL BLAST IN HIJACKING
description: A police spokesman yesterday characterized as totally untrue an accusation by a lawyer for one of five Croatian hijackers that a fatal bomb they had left in the Grand Central subway station had been detonated by, faulty police equipment. One officer was killed and three wounded when they tried to deactivate the bomb.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Passaic County Freeholder, Joseph D'Arco, has been convicted of bribery and misconduct in office. The jury of seven men and five women deliberated for two days in Paterson before reaching a verdict. The 61yearold Democrat from Clifton was found guilty of soliciting a former Freeholder, Charles S. Dorman, to accept payoffs in return for voting favorably on certain county projects. He also was convicted on A charge of paying Mr. Dorman $100 to sell his votes on the projects and of accepting a bribe from former Riverdale Mayor, Albert Scaletti, and an architect, Neil S. Greydanus. The jury cleared the Freeholder of a charge of conspiring with two former freeholders, Edward Gola and Donald Farinella, to accept payoffs.

title: W. Frederic Colclough, 71, Headed American Bank Note Company
description: W. Frederic Coiclough, who was president and chairman of the American Bank Note Company, died Thursday in Kingston (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 71 years old and had lived in West Hurley, N.Y., since his retirement in 1970.

title: 2 States Ask to Cancel Leases Of Exploration for Oil and Gas
description: New York State, its two Long Island counties and three counties from New Jersey joined today in asking the United States Court of Appeals in New York to cancel $1.13 billion worth of Government leases for oil and gas exploration in the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Carter for Limited Crop Support But Not Return to Rigid Controls.
description: ATLANTA  While Jimmy Carter has harshly criticized President Ford's farm policy in recent days, his own position on agriculture is being formulated and submitted to its first public tests.

title: Rail Unit's Loan Ceiling Raised For Costs of Bankrupt Railroads
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)The House passed today a bill to increase the loan ceiling of the United States Railway Association to $300 million from $230 million to pay the operating expenses of railroads in reorzanization.

title: Superior Tube Expands Tender Offer to Williams
description: The Superior Tube Company said it would extend its $22 a share tender offer for all the outstanding shares of Williams & Company to 5 P.M. on Nov. 30. The previous expiration date of the tender offer by Superior was Sept. 30.

title: Bulgarian Fishing Vessel Seized
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 27 (AP)A Bulgarian fishing vessel was seized by the Coast Guard off the Oregon coast today and accused of violating the 12mile fishing limit of the United States. A Coast Guard spokesman said that the 274foot Ofelia, a combination stern trawlel and factory ship, was seized by the cutter Venturous and was being escorted into Coos Bay, Ore.

title: Belmont Racing
description: RESULTS

title: Disgrace to the City
description: For the second time in a matter of weeks a band of hoodlums spread out over midtown Manhattan Saturday night, robbing stores, terrorizing and assaulting people and vandalizing property. Harried police officers, two of whom were injured, arrested ten of the youths, reportedly half the gang. The police did a commendable job, with a minimum of violence.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: United States Attorney Jonathan L. Goldstein came out yesterday against a proposal to legalize casino gambling in Atlantic City, saying it would attract criminals and benefit only few people. Saying that his stand did not reflect that of the Justice Department, he declared that New Jersey had undergone a rebirth during recent years, exposing and convicting corrupt public officials, executives and members of organized crime. He said it had also led the country in combating serious crimes and had restored the sense of decency and honesty to its citizens.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Agreement is Reached on Merger Of Hamilton Petroleum Into Sabine
description: The Sabine Royalty Corporation and the Hamilton Brothers Petroleum Corporation surprised Wall Street yesterday in announcing that they had reached an understanding for a taxfree merger of Hamilton into Sabine. This marked a turnaround in relations between the two companies, which have been strained since Hamilton began a bid for Sabine last week with tender for 1.5 million shares at $60 each, or more than 10 points above Sabine's market price.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a caption in yesterday's Times. David Amram, the composer, was incorrectly identified as John Alvidsen, the film director.

title: ALLIED CHEMICAL TRIAL ON IN VIRGINIA KEPONE CASE
description: RICHMOND. Va., Sept. 27 (AP)The Allied Chemical Corporation went on trial today on charges of contributing to pollution of the James River with Kepone, a highly toxic insecticide ingredient.

title: Kidnapping Suspect is Arraigned As Federal Charges Are Dropped
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 27 (AP)The man accused of kidnapping the wife of a wealthy developer and leaving her tied to a post without food and water for four days and nights was formally charged by state officials today.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: The Task Of Implementing New Fisheries Act
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass.Marin biologists, other scientists and administrators were given a glimpse here recently of the problems faced by those whose responsibility it is to put the Fishery Conservation and Management Act of 1976 into operation.

title: Suit Seeks to Block Bid By ForemostMcKesson
description: The Justice Department filed a civil antitrust suit yesterday to prevent ForemostMcKesson Inc., the nation's largest liquor distributor, from acquiring two Las Vegas liquor distributors.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Talks between Westchester landlords and apartment workers broke off, with the union negotiator predicting a strike Thursday. If we don't get a firm answer by Wednesday afternoon, then Thursday morning I'm almost positive we'll be on the streets, said Joseph DiBucci, business representative for the 3,000member Local 32E of the Building Service Employees Union. He said the union planned to meet tomorrow night at Elmsford, N.Y.

title: Man Arrested in Threat on Ford
description: MIAMI, Sept. 27 (UPI)The Secret Service arrested today a man for threatening President Ford's life during his trip to Miami. The man was identified by the Secret Service in Washington as Sean Kevin O'Leary, 43 years old, of Cincinnati. The agency said Mr. O'Leary called the Miami Secret Service field office about 2.40 A.M. and threatened the President. He also told people where he was calling from, a spokesman said.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 27 (UPI)The Justice Department asked a Federal court today to levy more than $91 million in penalties against the Chrysler Corporation for allegedly selling 1976 Plymouths and Dodges without valid clean air certificates.

title: Monsanto Unit Raises Prices 8% On Lasso and Ramrod Herbicides
description: The Monsanto Agricultural Products Company, a subsidiary of the Monsanto Company, announced yesterday an 8 percent increase in prices for its Lasso and Ramrod brand herbicides used for corn, soybeans and other crops. The company also said that it was increasing Lasso production at its Muscatine, Iowa, plant with a new facility to begin operations there before yearend. This will raise Lasso capacity by 40 percent.

title: ABC Buying 2 Stations
description: American Broadcasting Companies announced it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire two Washington radio stations from Washington Star Communications for $16 million. The two stations are WMALAM and WMALFM.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The State Senate's Insurance Committee is trying to determine why, despite substantial rate increases, insurers are still reluctant to write new business in New York State. Automobile insurance is not now profitable for insurers in New York. Insurance rates must reflect the future cost of wages, medical services and repair costs, and these costs have been spiraling.

title: BEAME AUTHORIZES DISCIPLINARY STEPS FOR SOME OFFICERS
description: Mayor Beame authorized disciplinary action last night against some of the offduty police officers who had noisily demonstrated in residential neighborhoods during the last three days to protest new work schedules and deferred raises.

title: Finesse on Rhodesia
description: It is an accepted tactic in diplomacy to minimize or finesse differences between antagonists in the interest of getting a crucial negotiation off the ground. This is obviously the kind of maneuver in which Britain and the United States are engaged, in their strenuous joint effort to keep negotiations for a twoyear transition from white to black rule in Rhodesia from collapsing before they have even begun.

title: 2 British Experts Fly to Botswana to Try to Speed Up Plan for Rhodesia
description: LONDON, Sept. 27Britain's two top Africa specialists are flying to Botswana to quell dissension over the threedayold plan for majority black rule in Rhodesia and to try to accelerate the process of outtine it to worx.

title: Dollar Down, Gold Steady
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 27 (UPI)In European money markets dominated by a sharp drop in Britain's panel, the dollar hovered at its lowest levels in 14 months. In Frankfurt, it closed at 2.4690 marks, and in Amsterdam it went from 2.5873 guilders to 2.5785the lowest rates since midJuly. 1975.

title: Voters Indicate That They View Ford and Carter as the Rivals Portray Themselves
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27The problem with the economy is stagnation, said Sheldon Kreig, a senior dispatcher with New York City's Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Ford hasn't done a thing. There should be a landslide of new programs, even something like the old C.C.C. [Civilian Conservation Corps] camps. I work up in Harlem and I'll tell you thisas long as a guy's got a job, he's got a little selfrespect. Otherwise he's got nothing.

title: DEBATE CALLED HELP TO OTHER CANDIDATES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Lawyers challenging continuation of the debates between President Ford and Jimmy Carter believe that the first one strengthened their legal case.

title: Warwick Hotel in Philadelphia Up for Sale Because of Losses
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27Philadelphia's Warwick Hotel has been put up for sale because of mounting losses, a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the hotel's owner, Warwick Hotel Associates, disclosed today.

title: Gains Sparse for Debate Viewers
description: The dust from the first FordCarter debate half a week ago seems to be settling at last as the formal election campaign nears the halfway point, but the nation has not yet been treated to any starting or imaginative new ideas for dealing with the major economic issues for either Presidential candidate. If the American public was the real winner last Thursday night after the joint discussion by the two contendersas some of the political pundits on both sides were quick to proclaimit appears that the 85 million viewers of the televised performance came away with rather sparse winnings.

title: Preliminary Nielsen Data Show 38 Million Households Saw Debate
description: The preliminary national Nielsen ratings, published yesterday, indicated that Thursday night's debate between President Ford and Jimmy Carter was watched in an average of 38 million households, or approximately 53.5 percent of homes with television sets in the country.

title: An Issue of $75 Million Is Offered by Pan Am
description: Pan American World Airways, which is making a recovery in earnings after reporting deficits from 1969 through 1975, expects to sell $75 million of convertible debentures today. The airline's issue was increased in size yesterday from $50 million.

title: Nixon, Aides Named In a $22 Million Suit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)Jack Anderson, a newspaper columnist, filed a $22 million damage suit today in which he accused former President Nixon and 19 subordinates of conducting a fiveyear campaign to destroy Mr. Anderson's credibility and take away his First Amendment rights as a newsman.

title: Poetic, Moving Days in Trees Is a Duras Exploration of Love
description: There is something curiously insulting about the phrase woman novelist  perhaps because no one has ever suggested that there could be a man novelist  yet undoubtedly, in their approach to narrative arts, both novels and plays, men and women frequently do have different sensibilities, different perceptions and even different priorities of style.

title: A Flavor of Peasantry With a Feminine Flair
description: The peasants are from Guatemala or Peru, which gives them something other than European ancestry.

title: Gannett Plans Purchase Of 4 Louisiana Papers
description: The Gannett Company, a nationwide newspaper chain, announced it had agreed in principle to acquire four Louisiana newspapersThe Shreveport Times and The Sunday Times at Shreveport and The World and The Evening NewsStar at Monroe. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: News Summary
description: The statement by African leaders that they would not accept Ian D. Smith's plans for a temporary government in Rhodesia was not, in the State Department's view, meant as a rejection of the BritishAmerican proposals for black rule in Rhodesia. One of Secretary of State Kissinger's closest advisers on Africa said that several of the leaders had informed Washington that the negotiations to end whiteminority rule in Rhodesia were still on track. (Page 1, Column 6,]

title: Italy in Final On Panatta's Cup Victory
description: ROME, Sept. 27 (AP)  Adrian Panatta, winner of the Italian and French open titles earlier this year, sent Italy into the Davis Cup tennis final when he beat the Australian veteran, John Newcombe, in a delayed match today.

title: Plutonium Dangers
description: A highlevel study of national and international nuclear energy policy ordered by President Ford during the summer has evidently brought him divided counsel on the most critical problem whether to speed the United States and the world toward a plutonium economy. Nevertheless, a crash decision to move toward common use of plutonium as a fuel in nuclear power reactors seems to be in thm making, despite likely criticism from Jimmy Carter.

title: Anthony L. Conrad: Enigma After 30Year Rise to Top
description: Until his forced resignation as chairman and chief executive officer of RCA 12 days ago, Anthony L. Conrad appeared to be straight out of the corporate mold.

title: 2 ROB QUEENS BANK, ESCAPE IN SKOOTOUT
description: Two masked gunmen robbed a bank In Queens yesterday, then eluded the police, shot the driver of a car passing by and fled in the vehicle with the wounded man's wife and their infant twins.

title: RHODESIAN NATIONALISTS MAP ALLIANCE AT TALKS
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept, 27 (Reuters)Two major Rhodesian nationalist groups today began talks on forging a political and military alliance as black African leaders awaited British moves to end white rule in Rhodesia.

title: Financial Writers Follies on Nov. 12
description: The New York Financial Writers Association said yesterday that it would present its annual Financial Follies on Nov. 12 at the Americana Hotel. Tickets are available from the association at Post Office Box 4306, New York, N.Y.

title: 17 U.S. AGENCIES TOLD TO PLAN CONSUMER AID
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)President Ford ordered 17 executive departments and agencies today to develop consumer representation plans in an effort to make consumers a part of the decisionmaking process.

title: Jury in Case on Illegal Gun Sale Sees Videotape of Alleged Payoff
description: An unusual videotape was played in Federal court yesterday that allegedly showed Col. Manuel Alfonso Rodriguez, who was chief of staff of El Salvador's armed forces, receiving a $75,000 payoff from undercover agents posing as Mafiosi.

title: LLOYD WALSER CONDUCTS CITY OPERA'S PINAFORE
description: There's not a great deal a conductor can do to show his mettle leading Gilbert and Sullivan's H.M.S. Pinafore, but Lloyd Walser did all that was necessary to keep things shipshape in the City Opera's performance Sunday night. This was Mr. Waiser's official debut, although he has been an assistant conductor with the company and he has led productions at New York's Young Artists and Bel Canto Operas.

title: Atoms and Guns
description: As the nearfiasco of the first FordCarter debate rapidly recedes into oblivion, the two Presidential candidates are resuming their more normal campaign on the hustings.

title: Dole Says G.O.P. in Farm States Is Lacking Comfortable Margin
description: MOLINE, Ill., Sept. 27 (UPI)Senator Robert J. Dole of Kansas, the Republican said today that the Republican Party does not have the comfortable margin it needs in the farm belt.

title: Met Guarantees Egypt $2.6 Million For 3Year Tutankhamen Tour
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has met a demand by the Egyptian Government for a 32.6 million cash guarantee for the Treasures of Tutanlchamen show, which will begin its threeyear tour of the United States on Nov. 17.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS HAIL RHODESIA'S REVERSAL
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 27  Apart from farright extremists, all sectors of opinion in South Africa have hailed Rhodesia's acceptance of majority rule. But the implications for South Africa are being drawn in sharply divergent ways that illustrate how far apart the Government and its critics still stand on the issue of domestic racial reform.

title: Kallinger Returns to Courtroom. But Unruly Actions Are Repeated
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Sept. 27  Two weeks after the murder trial of Joseph Kallinger began, the jury saw the defendant today for the first time. As he sat at the defense table, the Philadelphia cobbler's head bobbed and jerked, then swung in clockwise arcs, perpetually in motion.

title: 56 Women Officers Are First To Patrol Philadelphia Streets.
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 (UPI)Women police officert are patrolling the streets of Philadelohia for the first time.

title: New Federal Tax Law Could Foster Growth Of Plans to Provide Prepaid Legal Services
description: Two hundred guests showed up for the wedding reception, but the caterer did not, and the bride, Jean Walker Williams, became so distraught that she could not go on her honeymoon.

title: Jets Roster Falls Six Below Limit
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 27None of the Jets walking wounded will come off the injury list this week and there is one addition, Carl Russ, the linebacker hurt in the Miami game yesterday. So the team will have 37 players rather than the usual squad complement of 43 for Sunday's game against the 49ers in San Francisco.

title: Market Place
description: The Dictaphone Corporation, which has been both hunter and hunted in unsuccessful takeover sorties hr the last two years is on safari again.

title: Israeli Sectirity Questioned After Landing by Arabs
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 27The ease with which an Egyptian speedboat carrying five Arabs landed on a beach in Tel Aviv over the weekend prompted several calls today for an investigation into the effectiveness of Israel's coastal surveillance.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Rise at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTION on Sept. 27Yields rose on Treasury bills today in the weekly sale in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 27 (Reuters)sJimmy Carter said today that he supported efforts for a peaceful transition to black majority rule in Rhodesia but he ??? Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger of waiting for an election year to get involved.

title: President, in Miami, Pledges a Crusade On Crime in Nation
description: MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 27President Ford said here today he would rally the nation in the first 100 days of a new Ford Administration to help tear away the shroud of fear caused by crime.

description: High Tides Around New York

title: Deaths
description: AVNETNan. Beloved inether of John. Dear sister of Reeve Freoricks, Dolly Sherridc and Etnar interment privaie.

title: JOSEPH BELSKY, 74, UNION LEADER, DEAD
description: Joseph Belsky, who retired last June as international president of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen of North America, which has 600,000 members in the United States and Canada, died Sunday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center at the age of 74. He lived in Atlantic Beach. L. I.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: Architectural Aim of New Court Building Is Admirable, but Falls Short in Execution
description: The new Family Court building on Lafayette Street at once looks backward and forward, back in time to an era when solid masonry boxes served as civic symbols and ahead to a progressive attitude that wishes to fill public rooms with color and light. The architects, to their credit, have understood the need for both traditional symbolism and for modern freedom from the dark and hostile interiors of so much older civic architecture.

title: Rozelle Speaks of Options in Light of Draft Ruling
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 27 (AP)Commissioner Pete Rozelle said today that the National Football League faced two options in adjusting to a recent ruling in Federal District Court declaring the professional football draft illegal. One option, he said, is a bargaining agreement, after several years without one, between the owners and the players.

title: Miss Hearst, Before Grand Jury, Tells About Her Kidnapping in 74
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 27 (AP)In her first appearance as a government witness, Patricia Hearst testified before grand jury today about her kidnapping by the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army, a terrorist group, and was followed into the closed chambers by her former fiance Steven Weed.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: 5 CROATIANS DENY GUILT IN HIJACKING AND DEATH
description: Five Croatian nationalists pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that they hijacked a Trans World Airlines jet Sept. 10, and also caused the deatk of Officer Brian Murray of the Police Department's bomb section.

title: Rajeff is Casting Victor
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 27 (AP)Steve Rajeff of San Francisco edged Ulf Janson of Sweden in a castoff yesterday and won the multiplier accuracy event in the world fly casting championships. The two finished in a 9595 tie, but in the extra casting, Rajeff won, 9585.

title: Article 3  No Title

title: Coffee and Cocoa Jump Daily Limit In Futures Trading
description: Coffey and cocoa contracts jumped the daily limit yesterday, spurred by buying by processors and speculators, respectively.

description: Yankees vs. Red Sox, at Boston. (RadioWMCA, 7:90 P.M.)

title: President, in Miami, Pledges a Crusade On Crime in Nation
description: MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 27President Ford said here today he would rally the nation in the first 100 days of a new Ford Administration to help tear away the shroud of fear caused by crime.

title: SCHOOLS IN PHILADELPHIA FACE DESEGREGATION ORDER
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 (AP)The Pennsylvania Human Relations Commission unanimously rejected today a plan by the Philadelphia School Board to desegregate the city's public schools by voluntary means.

title: DEMOCRATS FIGHTING M'CARTHY PETITIONS
description: A challenge of the nominating petitions of former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, filed yesterday with the State Board of Elections, alleged that 16,309 of his 28,236 petition signatures were invalid for a variety of reasons.

title: Arnsparger Gets a View Of a Winner the Ram's
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 27Bill Arnsparger was leaving the field at the Los Angeles Coliseum yesterday following the victorious Rams into the locker rooms, thinking how big they looked.

title: LITTLE CHANGE SEEN IN DISTRICTING PLAN
description: Mayor Beame's final proposal for new community district lines probably will not differ much from the preliminary boundaries that have been the subject of public hearings over the last eight days, Deputy Mayor Paul Gibson said yesterday.

title: Troy Will Plead Guilty Tomorrow
description: City Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr. will plead guilty when he appears in Federal Court in Brooklyn tomorrow to be sentenced for income tax violation following his decision to stand on the plea he entered July 2 before the late Judge Orrin G. Judd.
