title: Army Bomb Expert Dies in Explosion at Illinois Plant
description: QUINCY, Ill., Sept. 28 (AP)An Army bomb specialist was killed in the last of five dynamite explosions that rocked a plant on Quincy's north side today.

title: Congressional Conference Bars Export of Plutonium Equipment
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28House and Senate conferees, in one of three Congressional moves on nuclear policy, today informally approved an amendment that would prohibit by law the export of equipment to extract plutonium from used uranium. Plutonium is the raw material for nuclear weapons.

title: VaughnSquires Lawsuit Transferred to Virginia
description: A suit involving David Vaughn, former pro basketball player, and the nowdefunct Virginia Squires of the American Basketball Association was transferred to the Eastern District Virginia Federal Court yesterday.

title: SCHLESINGER IS RECEIVED BY PREMIER HUA OF CHINA
description: PEKING, Sept. 28 (Reuters)Former Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger today had nearly three hours of discussions with Prime Minister Hua Kuofeng.

title: National Public Radio to Broadcast Two of La Scala's U.S. Productions
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  National Public Radio has obtained exclusive United States broadcast rights to two performances by the Teatro alla Scala of Milan, which had its American debut at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts here earlier this month.

title: Giants Rookie Spaceman Enjoys Knocking Down Foes, Gets Rewafd
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 28Terry Metcalf doesn't do the kickoff and punt returns for the Cardinals anymore, so the chances are he won't meet the Spaceman in St. Louis Sunday.

title: Clamma Dale Sings Way to Top And Seeks Out New Challenges
description: Sitting in her upper West Side apartment, accepting congratulatory telephone calls and bouquets of roses testifying to her Broadway success as Bess in Porgy and Bess, Clamma Dale remembered a crucial day in the eighth grade in her allblack junior high school in Chester. Pa.

title: 7 in BaaderMeinhof Band Get Terms Ranging From 2 to 7 Years
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Sept. 29 (UPI)A West German court sentenced seven members of the BaaderMeinhof urban guerrilla band today to prison terms of two to seven years.

title: Drop in Leading Indicators Spurs Optimism on Bonds
description: A large drop in the Government's leading economic indicators announced yesterday morning wiped out the credit marKet's concern with rapid growth in the money supply and replaced it with more optimistic view of the outlook for bond prices. The fixedincome securities market recovered, and new bond issues sold more readily as traders and investors concludedfor the moment, at leastthat the demand for borrowed funds was not likely to pick up quickly.

title: Libyans Say, Our Land is Fertile, And Seek Food SelfSufficiency
description: ARYAN, LibyaThey are planting trees where trees shouldn't grow, growing wheat where nobody else would try and breeding sheep in the heart of the desert.

title: U.N. is Urged to Consider Penalty Against Pretoria Over SouthWest Africa
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28Zambia urged the Security Council today to consider mandatory sanctions against South Africa because of its refusal to yield control of SouthWest Africa, or Namibia.

title: SCHORR, IN DISCORD, QUITS CBS NEWS JOB
description: Daniel Schorr, who was frequently at the center of journalistic controversies in his 23 years as a CBS News correspondent, ended his latest episode of strife yesterday by resigning from the network.

title: A Health Center Opens in BedfordStuyvesant
description: A fourstory, 160bed health care and nursing facility has been opened at 270 Nostmnd Avenue in the BedfordStuy vetent section of Brooklyn. The 82,000 square foot unit was built at a cost off $5.46 million and will have a bilingual roster of 130, including licensed nurses and doctors covering a wide range of medical specialties, when fully staffed.

title: McDonald Answers Call In Big Way for Chargers
description: Three weeks ago Dwight McDonald, a wide receiver, was released by the San Diego Chargers, for whom he had been a regular last session, and no other team picked him up. The 25yearold McDonald, a San Diego native, refused to believe that this About was the end of a career, not an untypical reaction Pro of final cuts in the NaFootball tional Football League. So he played tennis every day and waited for the phone to ring. Some wait forever.

title: Viewing Childhood As it Is
description: It's popular in certain psychological circles these days to point out to someone, That's the child in you talking now.

title: Dow Off 18.20 on Fears Of a Setback for Recovery
description: The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 18.20 points yesterday as fears of an economic downturn rippled through Wall Street.

title: Auto Company's Backing Assures Firmer Footing for U.S. Ski Team
description: The lack of adequate financing, major annual concern of the United States national Alpine and Nordic ski squad, will not pose a problem for this winter's competitive and training programs.

title: ExGreen Beret, Trapped in a Car, Survives by Ingenuity for 2 Weeks
description: TROUT LAKE Wash Sept. 28A 27yearold former Green Beret from White Hall, Mich survived by his wits for two weeks in the forest near here while he chipped away at a log that entrapped him in his overturned car.

title: Canada Foresees Threats To Commonwealth Games
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Sept. 26Two months after the event, the political aroma of the summer Olympic Games in Montreal surround the preparations for the next big international sports event scheduled in Canada, the Commonwealth Games to be held here Aug. 312, 1978.

title: Japan Lists Balance of Payments Of $107 Million Surplus in August
description: TOKYO, Sept. 28 (UPI)Japan's overall balance of payments registered a $107 million surplus in August, the smallest since last February, the Finince Ministry and the Bank of Japan announced jointly today.

title: A Witness Identifies Kallinger as Leonia Intruder
description: HACKENSACK, Sept. 28Edwina Romaine Wiseman pointed out Joseph Kallinger at the defense table today as the armed intruder who forced his way into her parents house in Leonia last year on the day Maria Fasching was killed in the basement.

title: News Summary
description: The war in Lebanon stepped up with a tankled offensive by the Syrian army and local Christian militias against Palestinian units entrenched in mountain positions east of Beirut. Lebanon's new president, Elias Sarkis, was said to be saddened by this dashing of his hopes for a period of calm for a conciliation effort. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Books of The Times
description: Scientists Marx, Weber, Durldieim and Simmel were without question. But they were also artists, and had they not been artists, had they contented themselves with demonstrating solely what had been arrived at through aseptic problem design, through meticulous verification, and through constructions of theory which would pass muster in a graduate course in methodology of sociology today, the entire world of thought would be much poorer. What Robert Nisbet is pleading for in this passage, and in Socialogy as an Art Form in general, is a recognition by the sociologist of the artist in himself and of his reciprocal relation to the art of his time. Mr. Nisbet attempts to encourage the sociologist to cultivate his intuition, to give freer play to his imagination, by pointing out that this is precisely what the giants of 19th and early 20thcentury social thought have Cone.

title: Notes on People
description: The Public Broadcasting System station in Buffalo, WNED, has canceled its invitation to the cofounders of the Northern Ireland women's peace movement after receiving threatening phone clls. The cofounders, Betty Williams and Mairead Corrigan, had been scheduled to go to Buffalo early next month to tape an interview with Sandra Elkin for her television show Woman, which is carried by some 200 stations, according to Wheel Collins, president of WNED.

title: Demonstrators, Youths and Fans Make Up Mob Scene at Stadium
description: Elegantly dressed ringsiders stalled in a traffic jam of limousines, teenagers tried to crash the gates and 2,000 whistleblowing, offduty police officers turned the area around Yankee Stadium into a scene of mass confusion last night. The highspirited crowd outside the stadiumfans, policemen and teenagersall but upstaged the heavyweight title fight inside.

title: A Social Figure is Fined $5,000 For Not Declaring $3,800 Dresses
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 (UPI)Betty Newling Bloomingdale, a wealthy person prominent in fashionable society, was fined $3,000, given a oneyear suspended prison sentence and placed on a year's probation today for not declaring the full value of two Christian Dior dresses she brought to the United States from France.

title: The Cuddly Little Dolls Aren't Necessarily Toys
description: Little girls will probably flip over Colette, Magdalene, George, Pierrot and the other dolls offered in the needlework department on Altma.n's fifth floor Oct. 7. dress and undress.

title: Ali Outpoints Norton and Retains His Heavyweight Crown
description: With more votes then cheers, Muham mad Ali retained the world heavyweight championship last night with a contreversial but unanimous 15round victory over Ken Norton at Yankee Stadium before 30,298 spectators who created a gate of about $2.4 million.

title: OTIS BLACKWELL PERFORMS WITH BAND AT OTHER END
description: Otis Blackwell has come to the Other End, where he is appearing through tomorrow, with all the trappings of a legend. Unfortunately, he doesn't perform like one.

title: Yeo Says U.S. Will Resist Moves To Alter I.M.F.'s Gold Auctions
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28The United States will resist any effort by other countries at next week's annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund in Manila to alter the schedule or amount of the I.M.F.'s gold auctions.

title: The Plans for Gateway
description: It took vision, in Congress and out of it, to conceive of the Gateway National Recreation Area, that remarkable complex of parks and seashores projected as a unified whole stretching from Sandy Hook to Queens. Once legislated, it needed vision to make specific plans for this first Federal park in an urban settingthe most concentrated urban setting in the country.

title: Figueroa Fails In Bid for 20th As Yanks Bow
description: BOSTON, Sept. 28There must be something about being watched on television hack in Puerto Rico that turns off Ed Figueroa. There was something about the way he pitched tonight that could have prompted his Puerto Rican fans to turn off their sets.

title: SYRIANS, CHRISTIANS OPEN MAJOR ATTACK ON P.1.0. IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 28The Syrian Army and Lebanese Christian militia forces began a tankled offensive at dawn today to dislodge Palestinian units from their positions in a wide mountain area east of Beirut.

title: Buckley is Using 60% of Donations On Drive to Raise Campaign Fund
description: Reflecting the new restrictions on big money in political campaigns, Senator James L. Buckley has spent on fundraising nearly 60 percent of the $1.2 million he had raised as of last month and has had to reach out of New York State for about half the money he has collected.

title: The Hakkas of China Wasting Nothing At All
description: HONG KONGThe Hakkas are a distinctive Chinese people who traditionally raise what they eat, wasting nothing.

title: This Was for Auld Lang Syne
description: In the third round Ken Norton hit Muhammad All with a left and right to the head and the heavyweight champion of the world responded with a sneer: You ain't got nothing. He should have said it to his mirror. in his 17th defense of the title he has won twice(All had all his familiar tricks of theater last nighthis fancy dance steps, his gaudy flourishes, his penchant for mockery. He had the support of a large and noisy majority of the 30,298 who paid up to $200 a seat. And he got the votes of all three ring officialsArthur Mercante, the referee, and the judges, Barney Smith and Harold Lederman. But he had scarcely a vestige of the skills that once distinguished him, and it says here he had no right to the decision that saved his crown. In this hook Norton whipped him cleanly for the second time in their three fights. Though the judges gave him eight rounds to seven and Mercante made it eight to six with one round even, the score in this corner was 10 for Norton, five for the champion.

title: $5.1 Billion for Foreign Aid Voted, Over Half for Middle East Nations
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  Congress passed and sent to the White House today the fiscal year 1977 foreign aid appropriations bill containing $5.1 billion, more than half of which is earmarked for Middle Eastern nations as part of the Sinai accords drawn up by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.

title: . Israeli Pound Adjusted
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 28 (Reuters)The Israeli pound was adjusted tonight and from midnight will be worth 8.40 to the dollar compared with 8.25, a Government announcement said. it is the second small change in the Israeli currency since it was linked to a basket of foreign currencies after having previously been linked to the dollar. The adjustment effectively devalues the Israeli pound by 1.8 percent.

title: Nuclear Agency Aide Backed.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 28 (AP)The Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy approved today the nomination of George Murphy, director of the committee's staff, to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. The nomination now goes to the full Senate.

title: About Education
description: Flooded with more applicants than they can possibly accept, the nation's law, medical, dental and other professional schools are caught in the midst of a growing controversy over their admissions criteria.

title: Radio
SOUTH AFRICA RADIO SAYS ANGOLANS GAIN IN SOUTH
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 28 (Reuters)The South African radio said today that Cubanled Angolan troops had wiped out whole villages in southern Angola and that hundreds of refugees were fleeing for their lives.

title: Illinois Paper to Be Sold
description: FREEPORT, III., Sept. 28 (UPI)The Freeport JournalStandard Publishing Company will be sold Oct. 1 to Howard Publications of Oceanside, Calif., it was announced today by Donald L. Breed, editor of the JournalStandard, and Heinz K. Vaterlaus, copublisher with Mr. Breed.

title: The Standings
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Deaths
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 3.3900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 9.5300; NASSAU CO, (518) 747.0500; SUFFOLK CO. (516)6601800; CONNECTICUT ((203) 33487767.

title: Copper Exporters Propose Group To Stabilize World Market in Metal
description: GENEVA, Sept. 28 (Reuters)  Copper exporting countries proposed today that a working group be set up to consider ways of stabilizing the volatile world market for the metal, informed sources said.

title: West German Formula: Not Just Work, but Minimizing of industrial Strife
description: BONN, Sept. 28The West German industrial machine works, but it is not military colossus. it is, instead, a reflection of a political and social consensus that may be unique in Western Europe.

title: MOON SECT SCHOOL IN DIPLOMA DISPUTE
description: The Unification Theological Seminary, founded a year ago with funds provided by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church, has been promoting a program of study for a master's degree that it cannot legally confer.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: An attorney for Representative Henry Helstoski, Democrat of East Rutherford, pleaded guilty in Federal Court in Newark yesterday to charges he had helped to impede a grand jury investigation into alleged wrongdoing by the Congressman. The attorney, Vincent L. Verdiramo, 39 years old, who served as Mr. Helstoski's defense counsel during the investigation that led to the Congressman's indictment on a variety of changes, admitted he had endeavored to procure and influence Joel Urdang, a certified public accountant, to render false and misleading testimony to the grand jury.

title: City Opera. Struck by Musicians Seeking Extension of Work Year
description: Pickets marched outside the New York State Theater and a stalemate prevailed yesterday in the contract dispute between the New York City Opera Management and the musicians' union. The union, Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians which represents the opera company's orchestra, went on strike over the players' demand for a guarantee of 11 welts of work in addition to the regular opera season.

title: ForemostMcKesson to Purchase Mueller Stock
description: Foremost  McKesson Inc announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement to purchase all of the outstanding capital stock of the C.F. Mueller Company, the maker of spaghetti and other pasta products, for $115 million in cash from New York University.

title: Technology
description: Telephone customers in Utica and Syracuse, N.Y., hardly know it, but they are taking part in a significant step in automating the work of the Bell System's many thousands of operators.

title: U.N. GETS TWO PLANS TO CUT USE OF FORCE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28Two treaties to inhibit the use of force in international relations were submitted for General Assembly consideration today a sweeping ban on force as an instrument of diplomacy, proposed by the Soviet Union, and a proposal to confront terrorism, submitted by Wets Germany.

title: A Sweet Variation Of Acidophilus Mills Now in the N.Y. Area
description: Sweet acidophilus milk, a recent development that is a boon to those who cannot digest conventional milk but dislike the soured flavor of the previously available acidophilus milk, is now on sale at retail stores in New York, and New Jersey.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR

title: The Agency Route to Barickman
description: From McCannErickson to Benton & Bowles to J. Walter Thompson to Barickman Advertising. That has been the agency route of E. Wyatte Hicks, one of whose jobs now is somehow to deliver some of the size and reputation of the first three to the fourth. For the last six weeks he has been its chairman.

title: W. PARSONS TODD DIES; MINING EXECUTIVE, 98
description: W. Parsons Todd, perhaps the oldest active executive of a publicly held American company, died yesterday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 98 years old and a resident of Morristown.

title: Of Guarantees and the M.A.G
description: A year ago, Governor Carey and his highpowered financial advisers trooped to Washington seeking Federal guarantees for Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds, which were then having trouble in a marketplace wary of the security behind anything with the name New York attached to it. The Governor and his supplicants were dealt a blunt turndown by both President Ford and by the Democraticcontrolled Congress.

title: New Bond Issues
description: UTILITY BONDS

title: Sanitationmen to Spur Cleanup Of Broadway From 72d to 116th
description: Sanitation Commissioner Anthony T. Vaccarello said yesterday that he would assign extra workers to clean up Broadway between 72d and 116th Streetsa section that has come to be known by West Siders as one of the filthiest in the city.

title: Many Fans Are Unhappy About Decision in Fight
description: The big television screen in centerfield at. Yankee Stadium had Muhammad Ali's name on it, and the word winner flashing on and off above.

title: Issues in Police Officer Dispute
description: PARTICIPANTS: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association which represents 18,000 police officers, and the Beame administration, whose chief negotiator in the talks, which began almost five months ago, has been the First Deputy Mayor John E. Zuccotti.

title: Bronx Landlords Approve Pact
description: Landlords represented by the Bronx Realty Advisory Board ratified yesterday a threeyear contract with Local 32E of the Service Emlployees Union. The agreement calls for a $35aweek increase over three years.

title: Germany to the Polls
description: The recent ouster of Sweden's Social Democratic Party after 44 years in power has encouraged conservative forces all over Europe, particularly in West Germany. Helmut Kohl, leader of the opposition Christian Democratic Union, called the outcome in Sweden a signal for Europe not to deliver our continent over to the Socialist International.

title: F.B.I. Linked to East Side BreakIn Months Alter Kelley Took Office
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, searching for a fugitive member of the Weather Underground, burglarized a New York City residence several months after Clarence M. Kelley took over as the Bureau's Director, according to a wellplaced F.B.I. source.

title: A's Win a Stormy Game, Keep in Race
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 28  The Swingin A's, as they officially bill themselves, and their flingin fans, swung a lot of fists and cardboard beer containers as well as bats last night as they, kept alive baseball's lone remaining pennant race by beating the Kansas City Royals. 83.

title: About Real Estate
description: WOODBRIDGE, N.J.For the last few years James Wolosoff had his eye on a wooded hillock in Metropark, the corporate office park off the Garden State Parkway here.

title: British Pound at $1.64, New Low; Central Bank Acts to Halt Plunge
description: LONDON, Sept. 28The British pound, once the world's proudest and strongest currency, crashed 4 cents today to $1.64, its lowest point ever, after falling 2 cents yesterday. The losses are among the sharpest in history, and the Government is now beginning to look very much like one in crisis.

title: Mondale Declares That Crime Rate Has Climbed 60% in G.O.P Years
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 28 (UPI)The rate of serious crime in the nation has increased 60 percent since Republicans took over the White House eight years ago, Senator Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic VicePresidential candidate, said today.

title: Rhodesia Questioning a U.S. View That Aspects of the Peace Settlement Are Negotiable
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept 28The Rhodesian Government today challenged the reported comments of an American State Department official who suggested that aspects of the peace settlement outlined here last week by Prime Minister Ian D. Smith were less than hardandfast, takeitorleaveit propositions.

title: 16 PERSONS AND SIX LABS CITED IN MEDICAID FRAUD
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (UPI)A Federal grand jury has indicted 16 medical service providers and six laboratories in a Medicaid fraud scheme that ran well into the millions of dollars, United States Attorney Samuel K. Skinner said today.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Montreal Expos, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 7:05 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9, 7 P.M.) (Radio WNEW, 6:50 P.M.)

title: Shavers Knocks Out Clark in 2d
description: Earnie Shavers, who once retired briefly after a knockout by Jerry Quarry, returned to prominence among the heavyweight contenders last night by registering a secondround knockout of Henry Clark in the feature preliminary to the AliNorton title bout at Yankee Stadium.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: QUEEN ELIZABETH 2 (Cunard). Left Cherbours Sept. 22; arrives 8 A.M. at W. 55th St.

title: ZONING FOR ELDERLY IS UPHELD IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 28The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that special zoning districts specifically for housing for the elderly were constitutional.

title: Tokyo Title Bout Signed
description: TOKYO, Sept. 28 (AP)Rigoberto Riasco of Panama, the champion, and Royal Kobayashi of Japan today signed contracts for their World Boxing Council superbantamweight 15round title bout in Tokyo Oct. 9 at the Kuramae Kokugikan Hall.

title: The Pause That Depresses
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28Looking back over the first quarter of the election campaign since the conventions, Governor Carter must be aware not only of the rising opposition of the Republicans but of the puzzlement and disenchantment of his own Democratic supporters. For the Governor, this is the pause that depresses.

title: DISORDER THREATENS CABINET IN MADRID
description: MADRID, Sept. 28The Spanish Cabinet, which has set as its main goal the holding of peaceful elections for a democratic parliament, has become so beset by agitation and disorder that both the Cabinet and the goal seem imperiled.

title: Ford Hails Islamic Celebrants
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI)President Ford today extended his warmest greetings to Americans of Islamic faith on Id al Fitr, the special holiday ending the fasting month of Ramadan. Celebrating the reaffirmation of your faith, this feast is a particularly happy occasion for you and a reminder to the rest of us of the vitality and strength of your heritage in our national life, Mr. Ford said.

title: Hancock Tower to Be Dedicated Today; Some Problems Solved, but Others Linger
description: BOSTON No building in recent times has been more cursed. There was civic opposition to something so large going up at the edge of Copley Square. When construction started, the foundations caused trouble. Then the structure needed stabilizing. And then, of course, the glass fell out. But the John Hancock Tower has finally managed to reach completion with new glass installed. Already partly occupied, it will be dedicated today, even though for years to come, lawyers will be working their way through litigation brought about by the buildings problems.

title: Ali Outpoints Norton and Retains His Heavyweight Crown
description: With more votes then cheers, Muham mad All retained the world heavyweigth championship last night with a contreversial but unanimous 15round victory over Ken Norton at Yankee Stadium before 30,298 spectators who created a gate of about $2.4 million.

title: Events Today
description: THE PHILANDERER by George Bernard Shaw directed by Stephen Hollis; starring Donald Madden and Cara DuffMacCormick; at the Roundabout Stage One, 333 West 23d Street, 8.

title: A.S.P.C.A. SETTLES AN INTERNAL FIGHT
description: Dissident members of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals have dropped their suit against the agency in return for six seats on the society's board of managers.

title: TV: Lear's Factory Hums Along
description: The Norman Lear factory hums along with incredible efficiency. One of its new products, All's Fair, is already on display at CBS at 9:30 P.M. on Mondays. Another, The Nancy Walker Show, will be unveiled tomorrow at 9:30 on ABC. Meanwhile, the established series are being carefully monitored and adjusted to insure continuine freshness.

title: Turnabout on Rhodesia Proposal Is Denied by Tanzania's President
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sept. 28President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania strongly denied today that the frontline African presidents had agreed to detailed proposals for Rhodesian majority rule in talks with Secretary of State Henry A. Kissingerproposals they later rejected in public.

title: People and Business
description: The nation's third women's bank opened its doors yesterdaythis one in San Franciscowith a man, Robert L. Shearn, as its first president. Dorothy Kulvin, vice chairman of the Western Women's Bank, said that in getting started the new bank needed someone well known in San Francisco's financial community.

title: COLORADO TAX PROPOSAL IS RULED OFF THE BALLOT
description: DENVER, Sept. 28 (AP)An initiative that would have required voter approval of all future taxes was ordered off Colorado's Nov. 2 ballot yesterday by a retired State Supreme Court justice.

title: Guide Dog to Replace; One Killed by Police
description: An Inwood, L. I., man whose guide dog was shot to death Saturday by Nassau County policeman will get new one, it was announced yesterday by the Guide Dog Foundation for the Blind, the nonprofit organization that had supplied his first dog.

title: Nixon, in Memoirs, Blames Foes for Watergate Scandal
description: LONDON, Sept. 28In his forthcoming memoirs, Richard M. Nixon maintains his innocence and contends that Watergate was merely a partisan scandal used by his enemies to bring him down, according to publishing sources in the United States and Europe who have read part of the manuscript.

title: Youth, 14, Recovers From Coma After 70 Days of Family's Prayer
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L.I, Sept. 28Lewis Sadowsky walked out of the hospital today, five months after he was carried in.

title: Louisa Gross Horwitz Prize Won by 2 Research Biologists
description: Two research biologistsSeymour Benzer and Charles Yanofskyhave been awarded Columbia University's 1976 Louisa Gross Horwitz Prize for outstanding contributions to the study of genetic structure and function.

title: Yugoslavia Cracks Down on Slovenes Who Urge More Political Freedom
description: L.TUBLIANA, Yugoslavia, Sept. 25In a drive to purify the press and courts of the Slovenian Republic, the authorities Ore have sentenced a nonCommunist Jorunatist to two years imprisonment and ave charged a judge with treason.

title: Personal Finance
description: Bank depositors may be able to buy time certificate with an interest rate based on the money market rates at the time of purchase if an idea circulating in official circles in Washington successfully makes the long journey between concept and regulation. And if it does, time certificates based on the then current money rateknown in the industry as variablerate time certificatescould offer some important advantages to depositors.

title: Carter Tries Out A Rougher Style In His Campaign
description: PLAINS, Ga., Sept. 28Jimmy Carter has tried on and modeled a new political style, denouncing President Ford in the evangelistic tones of a Southern populist.

title: AUGUST B. HOOK
description: August B. Hook, a retired New York liquor industry sales executive, died Sunday at a nursing home in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 81 years old and a resident of Tampa.

title: Nixon, in Memoirs, Blames Foes for Watergate Scandal
description: LONDON, Sept. 28In his forthcoming memoirs, Richard M. Nixon maintains his innocence and contends that Watergate was merely a partisan scandal used by his enemies to bring him down, according to publishing sources in the United States and Europe who have read part of the manuscript.

title: POLICE FLOUT WRIT BY BLOCKING TRAFFIC AT ALINORTON FIGHT
description: Hundreds of offduty police officers, in direct violation of a court order, blew whistles and blocked traffic last night near Yankee Stadium and encouraged roving bands of youths in unsuccessful efforts to crash the gates to the Muhammad AliKen Norton heavyweight championship fight.

title: Suspect in Ford Threat Seized
description: MIAMI, Sept. 28 (UPI)A Cincinnati, Ohio, man accused of threatening President Ford's life during Mr. Ford's visit to Miami was being held at the Dade County Jail today, awaiting transfer by United States marshals. The Secret Service in Washington said that Sean Kevin O'Leary, 43 years old, called the Miami Secret Service office about 2:40 A.M. yesterday and threatened Mr. Ford's life. He also told people where he was calling from, a spokesman said, and was arrested a short time later.

title: Aid to Private Colleges Urged
description: HARTFORD (AP)Senator Lewis Rome has proposed legislation that would increase state aid to Connecticut students attending private colleges by $2.5 million. Mr. Rome, leader of he Republican minority in the State Senate said his plan was the cheapest way to educate increasing members of students. He said it would cost more to build state colleges or expand existing institutions.

title: Jobless Up in Common Market
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 28 (Reuters)Unemployment continues to rise in the European Common Market, with women affected most, according to data issued today. Seasonally adjusted figures show increases in Denmark, Ireland, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Britain and Northern Ireland.

title: Ruling Aids PartTime Farmers
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex. (UPI)An economist for the Texas Agricultural Extension Service says a recent Texas Supreme Court decision could save parttime farmers and ranchers tax money. The court ruled that farmers and ranchers qualified for agricultural tax exemptions on farm real estate even if they earned more than half their income from other sources.

title: To Avoid the Bifocal Look, 2 Controversial Answers
description: What? Bifocals? A fashion  conscious Westchester County career woman sat in her ophthalmologist's office recently and balked at the very idea.

title: Carter Tries Out A Rougher Style In His Campaign
description: PLAINS, Ga., Sept. 28Jimmy Carter has tried on and modeled a new political style, denouncing President Ford in the evangelistic tones of a Southern populist.

title: Kaufman & Broad Net Up Sharply From a Year Ago to $2.8 Million
description: Kaufman & Broad Inc., a leading bulkier of housing here and abroad, reporied yesterday a net income of $2.8 million, or 17 cents a share for the third itisr:al quarter ended Aug. 31, up from $265,000, or I cent a share earned in thesimilar three months last year. Revenues were $92 million, or 7 percent ahead of a year aeo.

title: How the Officials Scored 15Round Bout
Group Homes Offering Hope to Troubled TeenAgersi
description: RED BANK, Sept. 28  They are truants and runaways. They come from disrupted homes and unstable families. They have experimented with drugs and alcohol, and they have been in a series of foster homes. They have also appeared in juvenile court.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FLOWER PEOPLE Bryant Park, which has rather gone to seed in recent years, will blossom today with its eighth annual flower show. The big event, in which many, if not most, large New York botanical and flower groups participate, will fill a huge yellow and white tent, 240 by 60 feet, in the center of the park through Sunday.

title: Lynching
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is engaged in a desperate effort to raise $1.6 million to post as a bond in order to appeal a $1.2 million judgment entered against it by a court in Mississippi. it is a sad and undeserved plight for one of America's most distinguished institutions.

title: SYRIANS, CHRISTIANS OPEN MAJOR ATTACK ON P.L.O. IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 28The Syrian Army and Lebanese Christian militia forces began a tankled offensive at dawn today to dislodge Palestinian units from their positions in a wide mountain area east of Beirut.

title: Israeli Arabs Halt Work in a Call For Ouster of Top Galilee Official
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 28Israeli Arabs from the Galilee region quietly demonstrated today to back demands for the dismissal of an Israeli official who provoked a furor with his report recommending measures to curb the growth and influence of the country's Arab population.

title: Hancock Tower to Be Dedicated Today; Some Problems Solved, but Others Linger
description: BOSTONNo building in recent times has been more cursed. There was civic opposition to something so large going up at the edge of Copley Square. When construction started, the foundations caused trouble. Then the structure needed stabilizing. And then, of course, the glass fell out. But the John Hancock Tower has finally managed to reach completion with new glass installed. Already partly occupied, it will be dedicated today, even though for years to come, lawyers will be working their way through litigation brought about by the buildings problems. An Appraisal The John Hancock Life Insurance Company, which will occupy twothirds of the building, has already filled most of its space, and the first tenants in the remaining onethird will begin moving in this week. Some of them have been waiting since 1972 when so much glass fell out of the structure and was replaced by wooden panels that, for a while, it looked like a better advertisement for U. S. Plywood than for a glass company.

title: Television
The Hungry Heart
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28The heart has hungers that the real world cannot satisfy. They exist independent of politics, but politics cannot be fully comprehended without taking account of them.

title: How One Mother Makes Do, Or Doesn't Make Do, on Welf are
description: Elisa Fuentes is a welfare mother with three daughters. She benefits by Medicaid help every other week for her baby. She has been buying food stamps, but not right now because welfare records apparently got snarled when she moved from the Bronx to East Harlem.

title: Greece Modernizing Its Schools; Textbooks Lose Elitist Language
description: ATHENS, Sept. 23When Greek school children open their new books this month, they will be able to read themfor a change.

title: McCarthy Wins Spot on Ballot
description: BOSTON, Sept. 28 (AP)The State Supreme Court ruled today that former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota must have his name on the Nov. 2 Massachusetts ballot as an independent candidate for President. The court set aside an order barring Mr. McCarthy's name from appearing. The order was issued two weeks ago by Chief Justice Alan B. Hale of the Appeals Court.

title: Harvester Accord is Reached
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (UPI) Negotiators for the International Harvester Company and the United Automobile Workers union signed an agreement today to keep working on a daytoday basis even though their contract expires Sept. 30.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in yesterday's Times about the negotiations between the Metropolitan Museum and the Egyptian Government over the Treasures of Tutankhamen show reported that the museum had made a $2.6 million guarantee in return for the exhibition's tour here. Actually, the museum did not guarantee the money but told the Egyptians they could expect it from a private donor and sales of reproductions.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in yesterday's Times about the negotiations between the Metropolitan Museum and the Egyptian Goveminent over the Treasures of Tutankhamen show reported that the museum had made a $2.6 million guarantee in return for the exhibition's tour here. Actually, the museum did not guarantee the money but told the Egyptians they could expect it from a private donor and sales of reproductions.

title: Bergman Reported Subpoenaed By a Jersey Federal Grand Jury
description: Bernard Bergman, the nursinghome operator, has been subpoenaed to appear before a Federal grand jury in New Jersey that is believed to be investigating Medicaid fraud and abuses in that state's nursinghome industry, persons close to the investigation said yesterday.

title: News Summary
description: The war in Lebanon stepped up with a tankled offensive by the Syrian Army and local Christian militias against Palestinian units entrenched in mountain positions east of Beirut. Lebanon's new president, Elias Sarkis, was said to be saddened by this dashing of his hopes for a period of calm for a conciliation effort. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: There are a dozen size designations currently in use by the canners of ripe olives in the United States, a number that the Department of Agriculture finds unmanageable and confusing, that some growers find meaningless and that other growers find essential to the consumer.

title: All Finds NonBelievers in His Dressing Room
description: Muhammed Ali thought he won. But he wasn't that sure.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Connally Calls Carter Remarks on Johnson an Insult
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28Robert S. Strauss, the Democratic party chairman, says that John B. Connally will play Jimmy Carter's outburst against the late Lyndon B. Johnson (whom the Democratic Presidential nominee ac

title: Carter Campaign is Still Led By LittleKnown Democrats
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 28Though more than 600 persons from all 50 states have been added to Jimmy Carter's campaign payroll since the Democratic convention, the campaign remains basically an operation run by political outsiders and littleknown Democrats.

title: Food Day
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 28If you were to ask the average restaurant enthusiast in the United States where on the map he would situate a restaurant called Comme Chez Soi, he might hazard a guess that it was in the heart of Paris or the South of France. Actually, it is neither. it is one of Belgium's culinary treasures and it is in a small dormer private residence in a Atte plaza in the heart of Brussels.

title: Anderson Sues Nixon and Aides For $22 Million Over Wiretaps
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI)  Jack Anderson, the columnist, has sued an array of Nixon Administration officials for $22 million in damages for wiretaps and alleged planned retaliations, possibly including death, for his news reports that were unfavorable to the Administration.

title: URSULA DeVINE
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 28 (AP)  Ursula DeVine, wife of the chairman of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Corporation, Gregory S. DeVine, died at a hospital here yesterday, the Chessie System Inc. said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your lead editorial of Sept. 19 says that President Ford called for [housing] subsidies that would substantially reduce the required downpayment on homes. The editorial also suggests that the President's proposal contradicts his veto of the 1975 emergency housing act.

title: LEADING INDICATORS FELL 1.5% IN AUGUST
description: The Government index designed to predict the nation's future economic trends took a sharp drop in August after rising steadily for 17 consecutive months, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.

title: Defense Bails Out Redskins in Overtime
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 (AP)Billy Kilmer took it all in stride. The 37yearold Washington Redskin quarterback, a 15year veteran of the National Football League wars, completed just 11 of 33 passes for 96 yards and had three intercepted in last night's 2017 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Rockefeller Says He Won&t Take Any Post in Next Administration
description: PHILADELPHIA. Sept. 28 (AP)Vice President Rockefeller Said today that he would not accept any post in the next Administration because want to he with my family.

title: Asians and Arkansas Hill Folk Ease Mutual Misgivings
description: GRANNIS, Ark., Sept. 26Mrs. Floy Lane, the storekeeper, has learned to like Orientalstyle alimentary paste, which she cooks into a soup.

title: Technology Column
description: New techniques in automating the work of telephone operators paint toward multimilliondollar annual cost savings nationwide for the Bell Sys. tem. Page 65.

title: Capitols Rally to Win
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich., Sept. 28 (AP) The Detroit Red Wings lost a 20 lead as Mike Lempman scored two goals in the third period to lead the Washington Capitols to a 32 preseason hockey victory tonight.

title: Eagles Home Game. Oct. 10 Is Switched to St. Louis
description: ST. LOUIS. Sept. 28 (AP)The site of a scheduled. National Football League game between the St. Louis Cardinals and the Philadelphia Eagles on Oct. 10 was switched today to St. Louis.

title: Appeals Court Sustains Ban on U.S. Prosecutions Of SelfExiled Draftee
description: A former student who moved from New York to Israel in 1969 cannot be prosecuted for his failure to report for induction into the United States Army in 1971, according to a decision yesterday by an appeals court in Manhattan.

title: Maximilian's Quiet Approach to Furs: Styles Are the Essence of Simplicity
description: If Maximilian's lowkey approacha show with no music, no customers and not a beautiful person in sightmeans that the firm is sufficiently secure to garner its laurels only on its designs, the feeling is well placed.

title: Russian Stabs Herself on Refusal Of Visa to Join Husband in Sweden
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 28 (AP)A 37yearold woman stabbed herself in the chest at a Moscow passport office after she was refused permission to emigrate to Sweden, where her husband is living, relatives said today.

title: About New York A Commercial, if Not Critical, Success
description: His voice is all around us in 6,000 commercials. He has been the Beloved Herring Maven, Taylor Wines Answer Grape, Hostess Cakes Captain HoHothe separate voices of an entire Greek chorus as America goes to marketsnatching at our minds with resonant talk of hamburgers (Burger King), dog foods (Mint Bone, Cycle) and other stuff made vital.

title: Norton: First Shock, Then Tears
description: The shock had turned to tears by the time Ken Norton barreled his way through the ringside crush at Yankee Stadium last night to the saftey of the dressing room.

title: Kleindienst Reports $250,000 Fee Tied to Teamsters
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Richard G. Kleindienst, an Attorney General in the Nixon Administration, said he received a $250,000 fee last spring for about five hours work helping an insurance company obtain business from the Teamsters Union.

title: U.S. Cup Team Plans to Use Pecher, Bick
description: Steve Pecher, who was sent off during the World Cup game between the United States and Canada in Vancouver last Friday night, will not, according to his coach, be suspended from Sunday's World Cup game against Mexico in Los Angeles.

title: GOOD SAMARITAN AWARD WILL BE URGED BY GOLDIN
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday that he would recommend that the New York City Board of Estimate approve a Good Samaritan claim filed by Gloria Pirone, whose husband died last year after he intervened in a fight to rescue a 12yearold girl.

title: $5.1 Billion for Foreign Aid Voted, Over Hall for Middle East Nations
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  Congress passed and sent to the White House today the fiscal year 1977 foreign aid appropriations bill containing $5.1 billion, more than half of which is earmarked for Middle Eastern nations as part of the Sinai accords drawn up by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: NASA is Criticized On Deal With Writer
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI)Senator William Proxmire criticized the Federal space agency today for agreeing to spend up to $140,000 for a long article and a booklength history of the Viking Mars landing project.

title: Most New York Welfare Families Lifted Above the Poverty Level
description: New York City's welfare families actually, receive cash and services that lift most of them well above the poverty level, leaving only 10 to 20 percent below that standard, a Federally financed study by the Rand Corporation reported yesterday.

title: People in Sports
description: The Baltimore Orioles ended speculation about Manager Earl Weaver yesterday. Weaver was rehired for the 1977 American League baseball season. Hank Peters, the club's general manager made the announcement.

title: Manila Investigates Torture Charge
description: MANILA, Sept, 28 (AP)The Philippine Government has ordered a no holds hjirred military investigation of charges that members of the armed forces tortured prisoners, Defense Secretary Carmelo Z. Barbero said today, He said the inquiry was ordered after Amnesty International, a Londonbased civilrights organization, made public interviews with prisoners who alleged widespread torture in jails and prison camps.

title: Election Panel Bars Shirt FundRaising
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28The Federal Election Commission decided today that a state Democratic organization could not buy more than $1,000 worth of CarterMondale Tshirts and sell them at a profit, even though the proceeds went to finance state candidates.

title: Ford's Car Prices Up 5.7%, or $271, On its Base Models
description: DETROIT, Sept. 28The Ford Motor Company announced today that the average sticker price of its basemodel cars for 1977 would rise by 5.7 percent, or $271 a car. This compares with 5.8 percent, or $269, announced last month by the industry's pricing leader, the General Motors Corporation.

title: On the Gutman Thesis
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Herbert G. Gutman has performed an invaluable service with his meticulous research on the black family under slavery and in freedom, which formed three articles on this page last week. The black family, his research shows, was remarkably stable under slavery and after migration to the Northat least until 1925, when his detailed studies end.

title: Major. League Scores
description: Major. League Scores

title: Alex Webster's Libel Suit Against Bouton Dismissed
description: Deeming television news reporters as much entertainers as journalists, a judge dismissed a $3 million libel suit. against Jim Bouton, the television announcer and former Yankee pitcher. Yesterday.

title: Mary Worth on Teenage Pregnanc
description: Mary Worth, the pillar of morality whose grandmotherly counsel has solved marital crises, patched up spats between parent and child, and taught families to cope with alcoholism, infidelity and emotional trouble for. more than three decades, will be asked to handle a new type of problem: the first illegitimate pregnancy in newspaper comicstrip history.

title: ROLLINS INC. BANNING OVERSEAS PAYMENTS, REVERSING ITS POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29Rollins Inc., which last winter said in admitting 127,000 of questionable foreign payments, that it might be forced to continue to make them, has changed its course and adopted a policy that prohibits such payments, a company filing made available at the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today.

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29Some time in the next day or so, what is generally known as the autibribery bill will die with the final adjournment of the 94th Congress.

title: FINNS GET A GOVERNMENT OF NONLEFTIST MINORITY
description: HELSINKI, Finland. Sept. 29 (AP)Finland obtained today its 59th government in 58 years of independence as Prime Minister Martti Miettunen returned to office at the head of a nonSocialist minority government.

title: TV: Two Shows Tonight Aspire to Quality Drama
description: Tonight at 9, the normal television diet of sitcorns and actionadventures is supplemented with two projects aspiring to the category of quality drama: Captains and the Kings, super soap opera on NBC's new weekly series called Best Sellers, and George Kelly's The Fatal Weakness, a fluffy drawing room comedy on PBS's Hollywood Television Theater. Neither is a dazzling triumph but, given most of the competition, each is almost touching in its aspirations.

title: BRITAIN IS PROPOSING PARLEY ON RHODESIA
description: LONDON, Sept, 29Britain announced today its readiness to convene a conference in southern Africa to discuss formation of an interim government in Rhodesia that would lead to a peaceful transition to black majority rule.

title: Montefusco of Giants Hurls a NoHitter
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 29 (AP)John Montefusco of the San Francisco Giants came within one pitch of a perfect game tonight, hurling a 90 nohitter against the Atlanta Braves.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed in order of post positions.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FLIGHT OF FANCY The first Oscar ever awarded to a motion picture went to 'Wings in 1928. It was a real rouser of a movie full of flyboy derringdo in World War I. Strafing, aerial combat, histrionics. in the cast were Buddy Rogers, Clara Bow, Richard Arleneven Gary Cooper. William Wellman was the director. You may have missed this twopart (short intermission in the middle) film the first time around and it has not been back for too many encores in recent years. But today only, a new print of the old movie is being shown at Theater 80 St. Marks, at 80 St, Marks Place (2547400). You can see it at 2, 4:35, 7:10 or 9:45 P.M. Admission: $3. Contact.

title: Reserve Intervention Spurs Credit Markets Advances
description: The Federal Reserve intervened actively in the credit market yesterday, twice arranging repurchase agreements and then promising to do more today as well as purchasing longerterm Treasury securities outright. The effort appeared aimed at helping to offset what must have been a substantial contraction in bank reserves this week as a result of the flow of money to the Federal Government.

title: Chile Thwarted in Bid to Change Andean Pact Rules on Investment
description: LIMA, PeruAn attempt by Chile to change the rules on foreign investment of the Andean Pact has failed, and the other member countries, led by Venezuela, Colombia and Peru. are moving again toward building a common market.

title: After Long Years On Streets, Sally Is Out ofthe Cold
description: The chief thing about Sally, the former shopping bag lady, is that she has personality. What a loss to the world of theater when Sally decided to go on the bum.

title: The Mind of the South
description: PLAINS, Ga., Sept. 29A supporter of Jimmy Carter, talking the other day with a skeptical Northerner, put question that concentrated the Northern mind wonderfully.

title: Woman to Get Her Final Wish: To Be Buried Next to Her Dogs
description: Brigite Riffaterre will, as she requested, be buried with her pet dogs.

title: Garrett's Grand Slam Helps Expos Conquer Seaver, 72
description: The New York Mets closed out their 1976 home season on a sour note last night when Tom Seaver served up a grand slam to Wayne Garrett and a tworun homer to Ellis Valentine that enabled the Montreal Expos to roll to a 72 victory.

title: Group Seeks to Void Toll Rise On George Washington Bridge
description: HACKENSACK, Sept. 29A coalition of 33 government and civic leaders is invoking a 1906 Federal law in seeking a rollback of the fare increase in May 1975 across the George Washington Bridge.

title: Mrs. Court Advances To Semifinals in Japan
description: OSAKA, Japan, Sept. 29 (UPI)Margaret Court and Lesley Hunt of Australia scored easy victories over Americans and reached the semifinals of a $50,900 international women's tennis tournament today.

title: 7 Partners Relinquish Posts On Lehman Brothers Board
description: Peter G. Peterson, board chairman of Lehman Brothers, the investment banking house, said yesterday that seven prominent senior partners, including George W. Ball and Alexander Abraham, were steping down as board members to make way fulltime for younger men.

title: Progress in Reading
description: In its penchant for store keeping and selfanalysis, the American public tends to rush to alarming conclusions at the drop of a percentage point. Nothing is so constantly monitored, frequently by questionable instruments, as the progress of each generation of schoolchildren. Any fluctuation in that progress on any an infinite variety of curves and graphs sends critics into paroxysms of pedagogical and social gloom.

title: A Threat of Anarchy
description: Mayor Beame. and Police Commissioner Codd have begun an essential crackdown on city police officers whose riotous demonstrations in a labor dispute have approached a state of insurrection against the city by those who are charged with defending it.

title: Torrez Victory Stirs Owner Finley
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 29The telephone on Chuck Tanner's desk rang, a few minutes after Oakland's 10 victory over Kansas City had made it certain that the American League West race could not be settled before Friday night. There was no doubt who the caller was.

title: RealtyTax Exemptions Expected To Be Passed by City Council Unit
description: The chairman of a City Council committee said yesterday that, despite major flaws, a Beame administration bill to provide real estate tax exemptions for newly constructed or renovated commercial and industrial buildings would nonetheless be voted out of committee within two weeks.

title: Yanks Romp as Nettles Bats in 6 on 2 Homers
description: BOSTON, Sept. 29  Somebody forgot to include Graig Nettles in Billy Martin's resttheregularsnowthatthedivisiontitlehasbeenclinched program. Unlike many of the other frontline Yankees, who are working half a day or none in these meaningless games, Nettles played the entire game tonight and erupted in the team's most awesome batting display of the season.

title: and the Labor Party
description: Whatever the shortcomings of Britain's Labor Government, it is plain bad luck for Prime Minister Callaghan that the current sterling crisis coincided with the annual conference of the Labor Party. It is at the conference that the party's left wing invariably vents its spleen against any Labor Government trying, realistically and responsibly, to confront Britain's precarious economic situation. At best, the conference spectacle of a party savaging itself is an embarrassment; during a run on the pound it can be a disaster.

title: Knicks Drumming Into Haywood The Company Way to Do Things
description: Spencer Haywood speaks more like a team player now, and if his words turn to deeds on the basketball court, many of the Knicks' problems of the last two seasons may be solved.

title: Libya, Short of Skilled Labor, Seems in No Hurry to Take Over the Oil Industry From Foreign Companies
description: TRIPOLI, LibyaLibya's revolutionary regime appears to be in no hurry to take over the country's vital oil industry, which is expected to provide $8 billion this year, or mere than 80 percent of the Government's revenue.

title: Vietnamese Railway Reviving
description: TOKYO, Sept, 29 (Reuters)Only 127 miles of track remain to be laid to restore the 1,050mile rail link between Hanoi and Saigon, the Vietnam News Agency reported yesterday.

title: Letelier is Buried in Caracas
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 29 (Reuters)Former Foreign Minister Orlando Letelier of Chile, assassinated in Washington last week when a bomb tore his car apart, was buried here today. Before the burial ceremony, Venezuela's President, Carlos Andre Perez, and his Cabinet expressed their personal condolences to Mr. Letelier's widow and their solidarity for Chileans who believe in fivedom and democracy.

title: The Weirdness Factor
description: WASHINGTONThe strange way Jimmy Carter handled the adverse reaction to the interview that even Playboy magazine headlines as incredible tells us much about his character, and what sort of President he would be.

title: Union Leaders Ask State to Ease Pollution Rules for Glass Industry
description: TRENTON, Sept. 29Representatives of organized labor in the glass industry said today that proposed airpollution standards that would permit a 350 percent increase in particulates emitted from company smoke stacks did not go far enough, and should be relaxed even more.

title: In Memoriam
description: FEIGINDanny, September, 30, 1961, eight years since you left us. As always you are forever in our hearts.

title: Income Tax Faces First Test at Polls in 14th District
description: BAYONNE, Sept. 29The Congressional campaign in the 14th District, which includes most of Hudson County, is providing the first test of public reaction to the state income tax.

title: POLICE AIDE'S BODY IS FOUND IN DETROIT
description: DETROIT, Sept. 29 (AP) A Detroit deputy police chief who told a newspaper reporter three days ago that he would be ruined if he was linked to a Federal investigation of possible narcotics payoffs apparently killed himself today, according to investigators.

title: Music: Pianist
description: There has been a great deal of wordofmouth about Yefim Bronfman, the 18yearold Sovietborn pianist who has been in Israel the last three years or so. Last night in Carnegie Hall, he played a major work with the Israel Philharmonic Orchestrathe Third Piano Concerto by Rachmaninoff. And in some respects he lived up to advance billing.

title: 7 Governors to See Carter on Region
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 29  Democratic governors from seven Northeastern states have drawn up a list of topics they plan to discuss with Jimmy Carter in Hartford Friday in an effort to show the Democratic Presidential nominee how Federal policies might help the region avert a dismal economic future.

title: Leonard Silk
description: The seers of ancient Rome used to take apart and interpret the entrails of chickens, and the seers of contemporary Wall Street try to read the weekly fluctuations of the money supply. Since, as the accompanying chart shows, the money supply keeps jumping above and below the growth targets announced each quarter by the Fed, this creates excitement for Wall Street moneywatchers and erratic behavior in stock and bond prices.

title: Widener's Success Continues
description: Billy (White Shoes) Johnson set so many rushing records and won as many games for Widener College in 1971 through 1973 that his opponents were mighty happy to see him transfer his talents to the Houston Oilers in 1974. The feeling then was that College an era of success had ended at Widener, and Coach Sports Bill Manlove would have to Notes rebuild. But Widener just keeps on winning, even though the Pioneers from Chester, Pa., do not have anyone with all of the talents of the 5foot9inch Billy White Shoes.

title: Japanese Concerns Win Contract
description: TOKYO, Sept. 29 (UPI)Two Japanese companies announced today that they had won a $7.9 million contract from the Indonesian Government to lay an underground telephone cable in Jakarta. Toyo Menka and Furukawa electric companies said that they planned to start laying the cable in December this year for completion scheduled for June 1978.

title: STEPHEN B. MAHONEY, 82, A RETIRED AD EXECUTIVE
description: Stephen P. Mahoney, who retired in 1963 as president and treasurer of Burke, Kuipers & Mahoney Inc., a newspaper advertising representative in New York City, died yesterday in his home in Scarsdale. N.Y. His age was 82.

title: Egypt Calls for Arab Meeting
description: CAIRO, Sept. 29Egypt today called for a meeting of six Arab leaders within 48 hours to discuss the fighting in Lebanon.

title: Women Voters League is Lagging In Fund Raising for the Debates
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP)Despite a $14.000 newspaper advertising campaign the League of Women Voters Edution Fund has raised only about $53,000 of the $250,000 it will spend to sponsor the four Presidential and VicePresidential debates.

title: Investigation Discussed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)President Ford has heard nothing from tip Watergate special prosecutor about a reported investigation of his campaign finances, and does not plan to ask, Mr. Nessen said at the White House news briefing.

title: Record $3.25 Million Paid for a Rembrandt
description: The purchase of Juno, a Rembrandt painting of the goddess, for $3,250,000 was announced yesterday by Dr. Armand Hammer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum corporation.

title: Economics of Times
description: Leonard Silk discusses how Wall Street interprets the weekly fluctuations Mb the Federal Reserve Board's moneysupply statistics as an indicator of basic trends in the financial markets. Page 63.

title: Ali Scoffs at Rernatch, Urging Norton to Beat Foreman First
description: Calling George Foreman the rightful contender for his world heavyweight title, Muhammad Ali rejected a demand by Ken Norton yesterday for an immediate rematch.

title: BRITAIN TO ASK I.M.F. FOR $39 BILLION LOAN, ITS BORROWING LIMIT
description: LONDON, Sept. 29  The British Government said today that it would ask the International Monetary Fund for a standby loan of $3.9 billion, the limit of its borrowing rights with the fund.

title: Bearded Collie Qualifies at Last For Listing in A.K.C. Stud Book
description: The bearded collie has made it. Starting tomorrow, the mediumsized shaggy dog can be listed for registration in the American Kennel Club stud book. The beardie will be No. 122 in that volume, which is more exclusive Bearded Collie Qualifies at Last For Listing in A.K.C. Stud Book than the Social Register. On Feb. 1, the native from the Scottish Highlands becomes eligible to compete for breed, group and bestinshow honors. He will be classified as a working dog. The original stud book, published in 1878, had 10 breeds. The first dog recorded was an English setter, Adonis, owned and bred by George E. Delano, a Harvard student.

title: Notes on People
description: Possible bladder surgery awaits Senator Hubert H. Humphrey when he enters Bethesda Naval Medical Center Sunday. The 65yearold Minnesota Democrat is scheduled for extensive tests for recurring bladder tumors, described as a borderline form of cancer, that were discovered in a recent checkup to have undergone a change in character. Senator Humphrey is running for reelection.

title: PILOT SEES SOVIET AIDES, BUT DECLINES TO GO HOME
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP)The Soviet fighter pilot who defected to the United States met with Soviet diplomats at the State Department yesterday and told them that he did not wish to return home, State Department officials said today.

title: ALBERT KING PLAYS BLUES ON GUITAR AT BOTTOM LINE
description: At a time when blues has virtually fallen by the waysideeven the young white Hsteners who supported it during the 1960's are turning increasingly to jazzAlbert King is fighting the odds and winning. He has a successful album riding up the charts, a cleverly produced, discotinged album that is garnering airplay on both soul and progressive FM radio stations. But Mr. King, who used to perform frequently at the Fillmore auditoriums and was perhaps the principal influence on English guitarists such as Eric Clapton, has not tampered with his live show very much. It is still pure blues, and some of the best to be heard, as Mr. King demonstrated Tuesday at the Bottom Line.

title: Accountant Asserts Mandel Got Funds From CoDefendant
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 29 (AP)Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland received $6,065.47 in 1972 from a codefendant in his political corruption trial as the Governor's share of proceeds from an alleged secret corporate interest, an accountant testified today.

title: Richard G. Rettig is Dead at 66, Retired Advertising Executive
description: Richard G. Rettig, retired vice president in charge of advertising for the Whitehall Laboratories Division of the American Home Products Corporation, died yesterday at the Naples Community Hospital in Naples, Fla. He was 66 years old.

title: The Standings
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Palestinians Lose Areas in Lebanon To Syrian Force
description: BHMADUN, Lebanon, Sept. 29Tankled Syrian troops today drove Palestinian guerrilla forces out of most of the key mountain positions they had held east of Beirut.

title: The Battered Pound
description: The British pound hit an alltime low of $1.63 on Tuesday before rallying a few cents. Although it spent yesterday bouncing around, the sterling crisis has not ended. It cannot end until British inflation, now running at an annual rate of roughly 17 percent, double triple that of other industrial countries, is brought down to singledigit figures.

title: Ship Tonnage Loss of 995,261 In 75 is Second Largest Ever
description: LONDON, Sept. 29 (UPI)The world's merchant fleet lost 962 ships, representing almost 1 million tons last year, the second largest amount ever recorded, according to Lloyds Register of Shipping.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Federal judge Utica, N.Y., has lifted an order that delayed construction of Interstate 88 for almost three years. Judge Edmund Port issued the injunction after a challenge to the environmental impact statement filed by the state. On Tuesday, Judge Port accepted a revised statement and rescinded the injunction.

title: Rites Held for a Reputed Leader Of the Luchese Family in Nassau
description: Some mourners arrived early. Standing near the redbrick Notre Dame Roman Catholic Church, they scanned the street expectantly. Some were mere curiosity seekers, others probably detectives. But all looked like ordinary citizens waiting to pay their last respects to a prosperous member of their community.

title: Carter, in Comments on the Press, Asserts Accessibility is Key Issue
description: PLAINS, Ga., Sept. 29 (AP)limmy Carter the Democratic Presidential nominee, was questioned today about published reports that at an offtherecord session with reporters last week he complained about the coverage of his campaign.

title: BUCKLEY'S CAMPAIGN FERVENTLY LOW KEY
description: Senator James L. Buckley, still shy and almost diffident with prospective voters after five and a half years in public office, campaigned in Brooklyn and Nassau County this week in a lowkey, friendly manner, preaching the evils of Federal bureaucracy and inflation.

title: HOUSE UNIT FAILS TO FIND SUSPECT IN SCHORR CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP)The House ethics committee approved today a report concluding that its $150,000 investigation cannot name or even suggest who gave the secret House report on national intelligence agencies to Daniel Schorr, the CBS newsman.

title: Viking Experts Work in Sandbox In Test of Craft's Next Maneuvers
description: PASADENA, CALIF., Sept. 29For days some of the geologists and engineers of the Viking Project here have been as busy as children in a sandbox. Literally. They crawl around in a huge indoor sandbox, smooothing the sand here and arranging a clump of rocks there, making believe they are on Mars in the shadow of the Viking 2 Lander.

title: Palestinians Lose Areas in Lebanon To Syrian Force
description: BHMADUN, Lebanon, Sept. 29Tankled Syrian troops today drove Palestinian guerrilla forces out of most of the key mountain positions they had held east of Beirut.

title: AFRICANS WELCOME BRITAIN'S INITIATIVE
description: GABORONE, Botswana, Sept. 29Representatives of several of the parties involved in the Rhodesian dispute reacted positively today to the call in London for a conference on the issue.

title: Talks Settle Postal Strike in Spain
description: MADRID, Sept. 29A weeklong postal strike was ended tonight by negotiation, but leftist labor and political forces continued agitation with calls for a general strike and other action Friday in protest against the killing of a student, allegedly by extreme rightists.

title: Caucasus, Toro Riding, Wins Manhattan on Turf
description: Fernando Toro, who made a special trip from his California base to compete in yesterday's 75th running of Manhattan Handicap, made the journey worthwhile by riding Cardiff Stock Farms Caucasus to victory in the 1 mile turf event. The 4yearcolt, carrying 120 pounds, came from far back during the early running to beat Caesar P. Kimmel's Trumpeter Swan by half a length. Charles Hopmans Kamaraan II was third. The winning time was 2:14 2/5.

title: BRITAIN IS PROPOSING PARLEY ON RHODESIA
description: LONDON. Sept. 29Britain announced today its readiness to convene a conference in southern Africa to discuss formation of an interim government in Rhodesia that would lead to a peaceful transition to black majority rule.

title: MAN FACES DEATH PENALTY IN KILLING OF CITY GUARD
description: A 27yearold man who killed a Correctoins Officer and wounded two other persons in an escape from custody on Sept. 9, 1975, was convicted by a Supreme Court jury in Brooklyn yesterday of murder in the first degree, which carries an automatic death penalty.

title: People in Sports
description: Tommy LaSorda, who won five pennants in seven seasons as a manager in the Los Angeles farm system, yesterday was named manager of the Dodgers. The 49yearold LaSorda, a native of Morristown, Pa., succeeded Walton Alston, who announced his retirement Monday after managing the club for 23 seasonseach on a oneyear contract.

title: Search for Ford's Records
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 29  President Ford has ordered his staff to look for records of his past golf outings with corporate executives. Ron Nessen, the White House press secretary, announced today.

title: Trading is Approved by C.B.O.E. In Government Bonds and Notes
description: Options trading in Government bonds and notes has been approved by the Chicago Board Options Exchange, Joseph Sullivan, president, said yesterday.

title: As Private as a Party in a Store Can Be
description: Put together 140 of the most sophisticated men and women in New York, ask them to listen to a series of sentimental tributes, and watch what usually happens. Facelifts drop, dinner jackets twitch and eyes glaze with disbelief.

title: Advertising
description: You've heard a lot of things about the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, but have you heard that he's a good client?

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Yonkers Racing
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% State tax.)

title: Two Thai Businessmen Charged With Jersey Sale of Pure Heroin
description: NEWARK, Sept. 29 (UPI)Two Thai businessmen have been arrested on charges of selling two pounds of pure heroin to undercover agents as part of conspiracy to import large quantities of the drug into the United States.

title: BRITAIN TO ASK I.M.F. FOR $3.9 BILLION LOAN, ITS BORROWING LIMIT
description: LONDON, Sept. 29 The British Government said today that it would ask the International Monetary Fund for a standby loan of $3.9 billion, the limit of its borrowing rights with the fund.

title: Holtz Changes Signals; Namath to Pass More
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 29Again Lou Holtz has changed his mind in his rookie season as the. Jets coach, and again the change involves Joe Namath.

title: Royals Down A's, Clinch Tie for Title
description: OAKLAND, Sept.29 (AP)  Larry Gura, a Kansas City lefthander making only his second pitching start of the season, stopped the Oakland A's on a fourhitter tonight and the Royals won, 40, to clinch a tie for the American League's West Division title.

title: Johnson Daughter ProDemocratic
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)Lynda Bird Johnson Robb, without mentioning Jimmy Carter by name, said today she will vote for the Democratic ticket in November. 1 I always have, said the daughter of former President Johnson. She declined comment on Mr. Carter's criticism of her father in a Playboy magazine interview:

title: President Vetoes $56 Billion Bill For Manpower, H.E.W. Programs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29President Ford vetoed today as too expensive a $56 billion appropriation bill for manpower, health education and welfare programs, charging that Congress had passed legislation for patently clear partisan political purposes.

title: Christie's Will Open New York Galleries
description: Christie's International Ltd., the 200yearold Londonbased auction house, will make a major attack on the New York market by opening two auction galleries in the city in 1977.

title: News Summary
description: Syrian troops in Lebanon using tanks and artillery drove Palestinian guerrilla forces out of most of their key mountain positions east of Beirut. They were apparently acting to settle by force their demand, shared by rightwing Lebanese Christians and opposed by Lebanese Moslem leftists, that they abandon the entire salient considered vital to the guerrilla positions in west Beirut and the southern part of the country.[Page 1, Column 2.]

title: FIVE DAIMLERBENZ AIDES, 2 OTHERS DIE IN AIR CRASH
description: A corporate jet carrying five present or former officials of DaimlerBenz and a crew of two crashed in bad weather Sunday while trying to land at the international airport at Sao Paulo, Brazil. All seven were killed.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)George. Bush, director of Central Intelligence, said today his agency was not im potent, but would welcome clearer guidelines on what it could do about drug trafficking.

title: Contracts for New Construction Fell by 13% in August
description: Paced by a drop in commercial construction, total contracts for new building fell sharply in August, according to a survey by the F. W. Dodge division of McGrawHill Information Systems issued yesterday.

title: Deaths
description: ALBERTJames M. The Officers & Board of The Union of Americanl Hebrew Congregations record with profound sorrow the death of our friend & colleague, Jim Albert of Miami. Member of the Executive Committee. former Vice Chairman. He was a devoted & distinguished leader of reform Judaism. a gentle A compassionate human being. We mourn his loss & express heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Leona, & his family. Matthew H. Ross, Chmn of the Bd. Alexander M. Schindler, Pres. ARUMHelen (nee Roth). Beloved wife of David. Dear mother or Dr. Eugene, Susan and Robert Biener. Dear sister of Dr. Sidney Roth Sylvia Eliasoff Ruth Roth and Dr. Emanuel Roth. Funeral Thursday 11:15 A.M. at Riverside Chapel 250 Central Avenue Far Rockaway. Shiva at 539 East State Street, Long Beach. ROSENHenri J., on September 77, 1976, in Saranac Lake, N.Y. Beloved husband of Nan. Devoted father of Barbara of Chicago, Illinois. Brother of Irving, Sarasota, Fla., Saul. New York City; Hilda Jager, New York City; Mildred Mendelson, of Calilornia. For 40 years he was coowner of Saranac Lake News Company. Funeral services will be held at 11. A.M. Friday, at Fortune Funeral Home Saranac Lake. Cremation will follow. Those wishing may donate to their favorite charity in his memory.

title: Thousands in Bangladesh Begin Drive to Encourage Birth Control
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Sept. 28Under he direction of the stern military Government that has been in control for the ??? 10 months, Bangladesh has just rawn up its first comprehensive national population policy and is sending thouSands of workers into the marshy counryside to carry it out.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Memorial Services
description: GLICKMANRabbi Jack Stanley, Mcmorial Day is second day of Rosh Hashanah from 207579 St. Bronklyn, N. Y. C.

title: Open Interest
description: (In bushels. 000 omitted) Tues.

title: London Schools Symphony Plays
description: The London Schools Symphony Orchestra closed out an American tour on Tuesday night with an enthusiastically received concert at Carnegie Hall. The orchestra, drawn from schools maintained by the Inner London Education Authority, has served as a training ground for professional British musicians since its founding in 1951 by Sir Robert Mayer. Sir Robert, who is 97 years old, appeared onstage at intermission and gave a brief and witty talk in which he proposed a musical alliance between England and the United States and flattered the younger nation charmingly.

title: Kissinger Expects Geneva Meeting On a SouthWest African Solution
description: Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger yesterday welcomed Britain's call for a biracial meeting on Rhodesia in two weeks and said that the United States expected a conference to be held in Geneva to settle the other pressing issue in southern Africa  independence for SouthWest Africa.

title: Police vs. City: Issues Outlined
description: PARTICIPANTS: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. which represents 18,000 police officers, and the Beame administration, whose chief negotiator in the talks, which began almost five months ago, has been the First Deputy Mayor John E. Zuccotti.

title: McDonald's Goes to School in Arkansas
