description: At the senior high school in Benton, Ark., students arriving for lunch pass under a pair of golden arches that have become a familiar sight to millions of Americans who eat at McDonald's. in fabt, there's a double lifesized portrait of Ronald McDonald, the clown used in their advertising, on the cafeteria walls.

title: Canada Flies Troops to Prison Riot
description: NEW WESTMINSTER. British Columbia, Sept. 29 (UPI)More troops were flown to the battered penitentiary here today as a new uproar flared among convicts holding a hostage and a cellblock wrecked in a $1 million riot.

title: CHARLES VITTITOE
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 29 (UPI)Charles Vittitoe, longtime Lexington golf professional and former vice president of the Professional Golfers Association died yesterday at his home. He was 64 years old. Mr. Vittitoe was also a past president of the Kentucky Professional Golfers Association.

title: Mexico Orders Spending Curbs In Effort to Stabilize Economy
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 29 (UPI)President Luis Echeverria Alvarez, whose sixyear administration ends Dec. 1, imposed a drastic curb on all government spending today to stabilize Mexico's economy following the recent peso devaluation.

title: Carter Asserts Ford Should Discuss Golf Trips and Use of Contributions
description: PLAINS, Ga., Sept. 29Jimmy Carter said today that President Ford should discuss with the press the reports that the Watergate Special Prosecutor is investigating his use of political, campaign contributions and a White House statement that Mr. Ford had accepted hospitality I at golf courses from corporations.

title: Market Place
description: A generation ago, investors were accustomed to common stock dividend yields twice those offered by corporate bonds6 percent vs. 3 percent was a typical ratio for quality securities of the two types.

title: F.D.I.C. Charges C. Arnholt Smith
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 29 (AP) C. Arnholt Smith, the financier, and companies he controlled are being sued for $21.3 million by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which alleges conspiracy and fraud.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Although the debates between the Presidential candidates are helpful in educating the public, their format is unfortunate. To devote one debate to socalled domestic issues and another to socalled foreignpolicy issues perpetuates a serious blind spot in public thinking.

title: When Carter and Playboy Spoke in Plains
description: CHICAGOFor the last couple of weeks, in responding to the uproar over the Playboy interview with Jimmy Carter, I've triedas the editor in charge of that feature for the magazineto confine myself to saying that it speaks for itself. But because it's become a campaign issue, perhaps few words from one of the participants, minus the editorial we, would be in order.

title: The Mannerly Manager and Muhammad
description: On the morning after, Ken Norton was winning the early rounds again. Wearing rosecolored glasses and a powder blue leisure suit, he had strolled into the redcarpeted Elizabethan Room in Marriott's Essex House and now he was sitting next to Bob Biron, his manager. Bob Biron is a grayhaired San Diego businessman who seems too mannerly to be in boxing. Manners don't count in boxing, especially among managers. They think Emily Post is an American Legion hall. But in his anger over the unanimous 15round decision for Muhammad Ali in Tuesday night's world heavyweight controversy at Yankee Stadium, the mannerly manager couldn't even lose his temper. He spoke about a formal protest to the State Athletic Commission, but he added, It would be naive to expect the verdict will be overturned. It also would be naive to expect that Bob Biron was involved what he called a battle for principle. He was involved in a battle for a rematch and now Ken Norton was threatening to retire unless that rematch materialized.

title: After Long Years On Streets, Sally Is Out of the Cold
description: The chief thing about Sally, the former shopping bag lady, is that she has personality. What a loss to the world of theater when Sally decided to go on the bum.

title: CHIROPRACTOR GIVEN 4YEAR PRISON TERM
description: Dr. Max Kavaler, a chiropractor convicted of Medicaid fraud, was sentenced to four years in prison yesterday by a Federal judge who wanted that dishonest doctors were endangering the entire Medicaid program.

title: Challenges Ford on Economy
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 29 (AP)  Mr. Mondale said today that the Government's latest economic indicators contradicted President Ford's contention that the Administration had succeeded in turning the economy around.

title: After Eight Years on Streets, Sally Has Finally Come Out of the Cold
description: Continued From Page 43

title: Confusion Over Rhodesia: Who Promised What to Whom
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sept. 29  When Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger arrived here two weeks ago to start his mediation shuttle on a Rhodesian settlement, President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania said he hoped the trip would be at least a shuttle of clarity. The trip proved far more momentous than that, but since then it has turned into a shuttle of confusion. The rejection of some aspects of the Rhodesian plan by five black African presidents has opened up a controversy over who agreed to what with whom.

title: F.B.I., at State's Request, Erasing 67,000 Improper Youth Records
description: Acting at the request of New York State, the Federal Bureau of Investigation is expunging from its files the records of 67,000 youthfuloffender cases that the state improperly failed to seal and that, in one instance, the F.B.I. released to a bank.

title: Mondale Recalls Role in Cases on Defendants Rights
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29A little more than two weeks ago, Senator Walter F. Mondale said that there was a philosophic disagreement between himself and Jimmy Carter about the direction of the Supreme Court.

title: Soviet Launches 858th Cosmos
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 29 (UPI)  The Soviet Union launched the 858th artificial earth satellite in its Cosmos series today to continue space exploration, the Tass press agency said.

title: Record $3.25 Million Paid for a Rembrandt
description: The purchase of Juno, a Rembrandt painting of the goddess, for $3,250,000 was announced yesterday by Dr. Armand Hammer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum corporation.

title: CODD ORDERS POLICE TO ENFORCE THE LAW OR TURN IN BADGES
description: Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd, acknowledging a failure in the level of police performance during disturbances Tuesday night at Yankee Stadium, told the 26,000 members of the Police Department yesterday that they must either enforce the law or leave the force.

title: Trenton Topics.
description: TRENTON, Sept. 29Although New Jersey residents by a wide margin believe that gambling casinos in Atlantic City would attract gangsters and other undesirables, a majority may vote for the proposition on Nov. 2, according to a poll by the Eagleton Institute of Rutgers University.up a dozen or so appointments made by Governor Byrne, a Democrat.

title: REV. VINCENT T. SWORDS, EXHEAD OF NIAGARA U.
description: The Rev. Vincent T. Swords, former president of Niagara University, died Wednesday of a heart attack at his home at St. John's University where he was subassistant Superior of the Vincentian Community. He was 62 years old.

title: City Wins Request to See Files on State Inspection Of New Hospital in Bronx
description: A State Supreme Court justice granted a request yesterday by the Health and Hospitals Corporation to obtain all records relating to an inspection conducted by the State Health Department at the new North Central Bronx Hospital.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Chrysler UK, the British subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation of Detroit, reported yesterday that, in contrast to the bankruptcy it faced a year ago, it was having its best car sales in two years. The company said that it was two months ahead of sales targets set for it last December when the British Government pledged the equivalent of $300 million to rescue the company and keep it from closing.

title: Dow Declines 3.74 as Investors Continue to Worry Over Economy
description: Stock prices turned downward yesterday after a midsession rally failed to hold its momentum as investors continued to worry over a possible faltering in the pace of the economic recovery.

title: RUDOLF MODLEY DIES; INDUSTRY CONSULTANT
description: Rudolf Modley, a management consultant, author and conservationist, died Tuesday at the Illinois Masonic Medical Center in Chicago. He was 69 years old and lived in Kent, Conn.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Business Records
description: Business Records

title: Belmont Racing
description: RESULTS

title: Ruling Supports McCarthy
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 29 (AP)An order for Louisiana to put Eugene J. McCarthy on its Nov. 2 ballot as an independent candidate for President was upheld Wednesday by the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The state had appealed an order issued last Friday by Federal District Judge Charles Schwartz Jr. Mr. McCarthy is a former Democratic Senator of Minnesota.

title: Blunt Criticism of U.N. Now Voiced By Many at Session of the Assembly
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29The dissatisfaction with the United Nations so widespread in public discussion these days is finding uncharacteristically blunt expression from the rostrum of the General Assembly.

title: Troy Gets 2 Months In TaxFiling Case
description: City Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr., after pleading guilty to filing a false income tax return for 1972, was sentenced yesterday to two months in jail, to remain on probation for three years and to pay a $5,000 fine.

title: Three Putnam Officials Accused Of Waste and Conflict of Interest
description: The New York State Commission of Investigation issued a report yesterday charging that three Putnam County officials wasted money, acted incompetently and tried to hide financial conflicts of interest in an attempt to set up a county garbagerecycling operation in 1975.

title: GALLUP DOORTODOOR POLL FINDS FORD WON DEBATE
description: President Ford was the winner over Jimmy Carter in their first debate last week, according to the findings of 1,204 doortodoor interviews conducted by the the Gallup Poll.

title: Studebaker to Swap Stock to Lift 78% Stake in Masoneilan to 100%
description: StudebakerWorthington Inc. and its 78 percentowned subsidiary, Masoneilan International Inc.. said yesterday they had agreed in principle on a merger in which Masoneilan would become a wholly owned Studebaker subsidiary and Masoneilan's public snarenolders would receive shares of Stwiebakercommon stock in exchange for their Masoneilan stock. The exchange ratio will depend on the average selling price of Studebaker's common stock during the 20 trading days preceding approval of the merger by Masoneilan shareholders.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SENTENCES JOURNALIST TO 10 YEARS
description: CAPE TOWN, Sept. 29 (UPI)A supreme court judge today sentenced a British journalist, David Rabkin, to 10 years imprisonment for furthering the aims of banned organizations.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
Companies List Earnings Figures
description: For oerlcds ended Aug. 31 unless othcrwise Indicated. (N) indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (0) over the counter.

title: Bellin Says Flu Vaccine Allotment Is Insufficient to Check the Disease
description: Dr. Lowell E. Bellin, New York City's Health Commissioner, charged yesterday that because of a Federal reduction in the allocation of swine flu vaccine for the city, New York would be unable to inoculate enough people to prevent the spread of the disease.

title: Japan's Exports and Imports Fall
description: TOKYO, Sept. 29 (UPI)Export and import contracts concluded by Japan's 14 major trading concerns in August declined from the preceding month, their parent organization announced today. The Japan Foreign Trade Council said that export contracts totaled $2.52 billion, off 5.9 percent from July, while import contracts stood at $247.7 million, also down at 13.2 percent.

title: Assistant Treasurer Appointed by Times
description: Denise K. Fletcher was appointed assistant treasurer of The New York Times Company yesterday, according to an announcement by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and chairman of The Times Company and publisher of The New York Times.

title: Suffolk's Police Get a 6.1% Increase
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 29The Nassau County Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and the County Board of Supervisors remained today in the throes of working out a contract agreement in the midst of a legal tangle.

title: Two Holdout ExMariners Are Leaving Snug Harbor
description: Two retired seamen agreed yesterday to give up their rooms in the vacated Sailors Snug Harbor on Staten Island, but won their battle to keep from moving with other mariners to the newlybuilt retired seafarers home at Sea Level. N.C.

title: 'Burnt Offerings' Is an Outstanding Terror Movie
description: Enter Ben and Marian with their 12-year-old boy, checking out the advertisement for a summer rental home. The isolated house is magnificent but decrepit Victoriana, not beyond the power to attractespecially Marian. And the price is right. Nine hundred dollars. Not a month. But for the whole season.Ben thinks there must be a catch, and what about the housework? "The house takes care of itself," says the woman who, with her rather dotty brother, is offering it for rent. There is, of course, octogenarian mom at the top of the house. But she's no trouble. Just leave a tray outside her room at mealtimes. Marian agrees. She'll care for mom herself.And so begin the events of "Burnt Offerings," which opened yesterday at a number of theaters, an excursion into eeriness led with admirable though not perfect assurance by the director, Dan Curtis.Here is the house as vampirealluring, renewing itself on injury, violence and death; capable of menance, vengeance, outrage and murder.To it, in all innocence, come such solid actors as Karen Black as Marian; Lee Montgomery as her son, David; Bette Davis as Ben's old Aunt Elizabeth, and Oliver Reed, as Ben, who is subject to nightmares about a childhood funeral, one of those old-fashioned glass-sided hearses and a chauffeur (Anthony James) whose face is going to haunt a lot of dreams for months to come.Director Curtis times his audience immersions into the ice bath of terror with such skill that moviegoers will scarcely have the leisure to ask why some of the renters aren't a bit more observant and curious about their dwelling.Only at the end does Mr. Curtis falter. Part of the climax is predictable; and, in another part, he relinquishes his deftness in favor of violence and gore on a scale that clashes with his earlier restraint.Nevertheless, such is his ability that, at the approach of the denouement during a preview of "Burnt Offerings," members of the audience began murmuring and shouting nervous jokes in a vain effort to break the undeniable tension.Rental agents hereabouts should get down on their knees and give thanks that "Burnt Offerings" is opening now. It's the kind of movie that does for summer homes what "Jaws" did for a dip in the surf.The PG rating ("Parental Guidance Suggested") seems attributable to one long shot of Marian diving nude into a swimming pool; to a couple of scenes indicating the state of Ben's and Marian's sex life, and, perhaps, to the climactic gore.

title: Rhodes Scholars From a Playwright to a Soldier Sail for England
description: John Ausink of Wyoming Andrew Banks of Florida  James Basker of Oregon  Troyen Brennan of Missouri

title: DORSEY'S LOSSES PUT AT OVER $1.35 MILLION
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29  The value of stock options and bonuses forfeited by Bob R. Dorsey, ousted chairman of the Gulf Oil Corporation, in the settlement of shareholders suits stemming from Gulf's illegal slush fund could top $1.35 million, according to a copy of the settlement filed in United States District Court here today.

title: Drug Sale Admitted
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 29 (AP) The 21yearold son of a Vappingers Falls physician has pleaded guilty to the illegal sale of 15,000 amphetamine pills that the police said he had stolen from his father's office. The physician's son. Joseph Scafuri, also admitted to the judge yesterday that he had been involved in previous sales of 10,000 pi'ls each. He had not been charged with those sales. Mr. Scafuri pleaded guilty to sixthdegree criminal sale of a controlled substance, and faces up to seven years in prison.

title: Dimmes McDowell, a Book Editor, Dies at 51 After Auto Accident
description: Dimmes McDowell, a book editor, died Tuesday at a TroisRivieres, Quebec, hospital from injuries suffered in an automobile accident there two clays earlier. She was 51 years old and a resident of Head Tide. Me.

title: House Clears $4.9 Billion Public Works Authorization Bill, Inviting Another Confrontation With President
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29The House passed and sent to the White House today the $4.9 billion public works authorization bill, thus inviting yet another confrontation with President Ford over an election issue.

title: Soviet Artist Emigrates
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 29 (Reuters)Igor Sinyavin, a nonconformist artist from Leningrad, left today for Vienna on his way to settle in the United States. Like most emigrants, whether Jewish or not, he was given an exit visa listing his destination as Israel.

title: Political Action Panels Have Spent $ 10 Million on Congressional Races
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29Political action committees established by unions, corporations and other special interest groups gave more than $10 million in contributions to Senate and House candidates before Sept. 1, the nominal opening date of the fall campaign.

title: Italian Mayor Orders Quarantine After Explosion Spreads Arsenic
description: MANFREDONIA, Italy Sept. 29 (AP)The mayor of this Adriatic town has ordered nearly four square miles around a fertilizer plant quarantined after an explosion spread arsenic around the area.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Wednesday.

title: Venezuela is Increasing Price of Its Heavy Fuel Oil By 25 to 70 Cents a Barrel
description: Venezuela will increase the price of its heavy fuel oil, most of which goes to the East Coast of the United States for use in utility boilers, by between 25 cents and 70 cents a barrel, the Ministry of Mines and Hydrocarbons announced yesterday.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: President Vetoes $56 Billion Bill For Manpower, H.E.W. Programs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29President Ford vetoed today as too expensive a $56 billion appropriation bill for manpower, health, education and welfare programs, charging that Congress had passed legislation for patently clear partisan political purposes.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets at 3 P.M. on SouthWest Africa.

title: Police Capture Fugitive of Rikers Accused in Times Square Slaying
description: A man accused of slaying two armored car guards in a Times Square movie theater last April was seized by the police in a Bronx housing project last night, two days after he and four other prisoners escaped from the House of Detention for Men on Rikers Island.

title: NESTLE COFFEE COSTS UP; I.B.M. PRICES RISING JAN. 1
description: The Nestle Company announced yesterday wholesaie price increases of 3 to 6 cents an ounce for three of its instant coffee brands. The company said that freezedried coffee prices would not he raised at this time.

title: Dividends
description: Dividends

title: Italian Red Leaders Try to Assuage Doubts About Support for Cabinet
description: ROME, Sept. 29After weeks of relative quiet, Communist Party leaders have embraced a somewhat tougher line, designed in part to calm uneasiness in their ranks over the decision to provide the essential props for the governing Christian Democrats.

title: Ottinger Assails State Power Unit
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 29Representative Richard L. Ottinger asserted today that the New York State Power Authority not only had available the power it would take to replace the Consolidated Edison Company in Westchester County. but the authority was obligated by law to Supply it if the county asked for it.

title: New 3Year Contracts Ratified By Clothing and Textile Workers
description: Members of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union have ratified new threeyear contracts that give wage increases, costofliving adjustments and improved health, welfare and pension benefits to 90,000 workers in the cotton garment industry.

title: Events Today
description: THE FRONT, directed by Martin Ritt, starring Woody Allen, at the Coronet Theater.

title: Carter Asserts Ford Should Discuss Golf Trips and Use of Contributions
description: PLAINS, Ga., Sept. 29Jimmy Carter said today that President Ford should discuss with the press the reports that the Watergate Special Prosecutor is investigating his use of political campaign contributions and a White House statement that Mr. Ford had accepted hospitality at golf courses from corporations.

title: Harrises Are Indicted in the Kidnapping of Miss Hearst
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 29William and Emily Harris, onetime underground traveling companions of Patricia Hearst, were charged today in a 13count: indictment by an Alameda County Grand Jury with kidnapping Miss Hearst two and a half years ago.

title: 7COUNTY HOSPITAL SCORED AT MEETING
description: VALHALLA, Sept. 29A growing dispute between Westchester's 13 voluntary hospitals and a new county medical center over anticipated competition for physicians, patients and income flared into the open today at a meeting intended to allay such fears.

title: Flyers Beaten by Islanders, 52, After Trading Schultz to Los Angeles
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Sept. 29  The Philadelphia Flyers, who traded Dave Schultz this afternoon to Los Angeles for future considerations, were defeated by the New York Islanders tonight, 52, in an exhibition game.

title: Move to Void Order On Recall of Rizzo Is Weighed by Court
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29Lawyers for Mayor Frank L. Rizzo and the City of Philadelphia asked the Pennsylvania Supreme Court today to overturn a lower court's decision upholding the validity of a liberalinspired recall petition here that could drive the ConservativeDemocratic Mayor from office in November.

title: Smithsonian Seminar Takes Up Politics and Comic Strips
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29The Smithsonian, which can crowd more camels noses under one tent than any other institution, collected a rare menagerie here this week to discuss The United States in the World.

title: Senate Panel Links H.E.W. Aide To Kickbacks in Medicaid Contract
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29The Federal official who approves contracts for antifraud computersystenis for the Medicaid program was named by a Senate investigations committee today as the recipient of kickbacks from at least one company receiving those contracts.

title: ENERGY AGENCY DATA TERMED MISLEADING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29The General Accoanting Office has accused the Ford Adminitration's energy research agency of preparing an inaccurate pronuclear propaganda pamphlet that was used to defeat a California initiative proposal to ??? nuclear power.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the later editions of yesterday's Times, a caption reversed the Identic fications of Mayor Coleman A. Young of Detroit. and William L. Hart, Police chief.

title: Iselin Reported Fair.
description: DENVER, Sept. 29 (AP)Philip H. Iselin, president and part owner of the New York Jets, was reported in fair condition today in St. Anthony Hospital, where he was taken Sept. 19 after suffering a cardiac arrest. The 74yearold Iselin has been removed from the intensive care unit.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The unemployment rate in New Jersey rose last month for the first time since last spring and recorded the biggest onemonth increase in more than a year. But the August unemployment rate of 11.3 percent is still well below the recession high point of 13.6 percent registered a year ago, according to the State Department of Labor and Industry.

title: Voters in a Colorado Farm Town Lean Toward Ford
description: YUMA, Colo., Sept. 27In recent weeks, eastern Colorado farmers who sowed their winter wheat early have been forced by heavy rains to plow under those first seeds and replant. Likewise, many voters in Yuma who liked Ronald Reagan and Jimmy Carter earlier in the political season have been forced by recent events to reassess their views.

title: Jerseyan Convicted of Plot
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 (AP)Richard Keats, 39 years old, described by the authorities as the mastermind of an international plot to steal $3.5 million in checks from the Los Angeles city treasury, was sentenced today to state prison for three to 33 years. Mr. Keats, a pharmacist and businessman from Fort Lee, N.J., pleaded guilty June 1 to charges of conspiracy, forgery and attempted grand theft.

title: New Coach at St. Dominic's Upholds Winning Tradition
description: The Capozzolis are gone from St. Dominic's football this season, and Pat Conklin is the man on the spot. Tom Capozzoli, the Doms coach for 16 seasons, retired after last season when the Doms were unbeaten and won the Catholic Schools Football igh League title. For the last four seasons, Coach Torn School had his son Tony at quarSports tcrback, a position he played so well he was considered by many college scouts as the finest scholastic quarterback in the nation. Tony is a freshman at Penn State now, and Torn spends his weekends traveling to see his son play. Conklin, the defensive coach for 13 seasons, took over as the head man at the Oyster Bay, L.I., school this season.

title: Socialist Party Wins Equal Time on NBC
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP)NBCTV is required to provide equal time to the Socialist Workers Party Presidential candidate on its Tomorrow show, the Federal Communications Commission said today.

title: News Summary
description: Syrian troops, in Lebanon using tanks and artillery drove Palestinian guerrilla forces out of most of their key mountain positions east of Beirut. They were apparently acting to settle by force their demand, shared by rightwing Lebanese Christians and opposed by Lebanese Moslem leftists, that they abandon the entire salient considered vital to the guerrilla positions in west Beirut and the southern part of the country. [Page 1, Column 2.]

title: Troy Gets 2 Months In TaxFiling Case
description: City Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr., after pleading guilty to filing a false income tax return for 1972, was sentenced yesterday to two months in Jail, to remain on probation for three years and to pay a $5,000 fine.

title: Soviet ATest is Detected
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (Reuters)The Soviet Union detonated a nuclear device underground at a test site above the Arctic Circle; a spokesman for the Energy Research and Development Administration said today. Seismic signals were from the Novaya Zemlya test island, he said.

title: Treasury Aide Assails Moody's As Biased Against M.A.C. Bonds
description: The United States Treasury Department aide who oversees New York City's finances has suggested to Moody's Investors Service that it disqualify itself from, evaluating Municipal Assitance Corporation bonds because of the rating agency's political bias.

title: Screen: 'Norman ... Is That You?'
description: It is possible to imagine "Norman . . . Is That You?" on television some rainy afternoon, seen through the rising steam of a pile of ironing, and with the sound turned all the way down. Otherwiseunless customers sneak ironing-boards and tubs of wet-wash into the Criterion, Apollo and other theaters where it opened yesterday"Norman" is very hard to imagine, let alone see.As a stage play, which ran 12 performances on Broadway, "Norman" was about the antics of one owner of a dry-cleaning shop who discovers simultaneously that his wife has run off with his partner and that his son is a homosexual. It was a comedy, not a tragedy except, perhaps, for those who bought tickets.The movie version, produced and directed by George Schlatter, substitutes a black family for a Jewish family. It helps matters not at all. It is a series of bad jokes about homosexuality, strung upon trite situation comedy and collapsing into what is meant to be an uplifting message about people being allowed to do their own thing.Well, Redd Foxxhe plays the dry-cleaneris a capable performer and he isn't doing his own thing. Pearl Baileythe wifeis a splendid performer and she isn't doing her own thing. They are both doing Mr. Schlatter's thing, and a poor, small thing it is."Norman is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It is all talk and no action, but the film's message is that if your children grow up to be homosexuals, don't worry; and presumably this is what the guidance is suggested for.

title: Rhodes SCholars From a Playwright to a Soldier Sail for England
description: The Americans were screened from a final list of 240 candidates from eight regions for the coveted scholarships, which have been provided since the turn of the century by the will of Cecil Rhodes. one of Britain's greatest 19th cerrtury empire builders.

title: Manhattan Handicap
description: Manhattan Handicap

title: A Southern Town is Hopeful About Default
description: MONROE, La.The leaders of Monroe used to talk of a day when their little city would have no taxes. It would run itself on the bounty of the huge natural gas field at the edge of town.

title: Frieda Lorber, Who Led Women's Bar Association And Was Arbitrator, Dies
description: Frieda L. Lorber, president of the New York Women's Bar Association from 1949 to 1951, died Tuesday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. She lived at 220 Central Park South.

title: CODD ORDERS POLICE TO ENFORCE THE LAW OR TURN IN BADGES
description: Police Commissioner Michael S., Codd, acknowledging a failure in the level of police performance during disturbances Tuesday night at Yankee Stadium, told the 26,000 members of the Police Department yesterday that they must either enforce the law or get out.

title: JANE FLOYD BUCK
description: Mrs. Jane Floyd Buck of Manhattan, a former public relations executive for Carl Byoir & Associates Inc., died Saturday in the Community Hospital of Carmel, Calif. She was 87 years old.

title: Christie's Will Open New York Galleries
description: Christie's International Ltd., the 200yearold Londonbased auction house, will make a major attack on the New York market by opening two auction galleries in the city in 1977.

title: Trilling Case Sparks PublisherLoyalty Debate
description: Little Brown & Company's refusal to publish a book of essays by Diana Trilling, the critic, that contains passages critical of Lillian Hellman, one of the publishing company's most eminent authors, has raised questions among publishers and writers about just how much loyalty a publishing house owes to its authors.

title: Books of The Times
description: In his first book, Wisconsin Death Trip, published in 1973, Michael Lesy undertook an original experiment in historical investigation. Whether intended so or not, it was a wrinkle on the socalled Annales school of historiography (named after the French periodical Annales: Economies, Societes, Civilisations), a revolutionary intellectual development that places timeless elements of physical and biological nature above the narration of sequential events that has characterized modern historical writing. In Wisconsin Death Trip, Mr. Lesy created a montage out of photographs and news items in order to show us what life was actually like in Black River Falls, Wis. in the 1890s. And while it is not certain that he proved his thesis that a large portion of the citizens of Black River Falls had obsessivecompulsive personalities ideally suited to the life of striving demanded by the American Dream (which is why they came undonewent crazy, murdered their children, committed suicide when the dream turned sour), there is no doubt that he showed us a sinister underside of the socalled Gay Nineties.

title: Lockheed Holders Bach Debt Shift That Reduces Their Equity 13%
description: BURBANK, Calif., Sept. 29Shareholders of the scandalridden Lockheed Aircraft Corporation met for the first time in almost two and a half years today and authorized a debtrestructuring agreement that would reduce their equity in the company 13 percent.

title: Clever Utahans Dancing Better Than Ever
description: The Utah Repertory Dance Theater, which has gained fame as a democratically run collective, opened its fourth New York series Tuesday night at the Manhattan School of Music under unusual circumstances.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: Royals Clinch Tie for Title
description: The Kansas City Royals clinched a tie for the American League Western Division title last night by defeating the Oakland A's, 40. Details on page 56.

title: Interest Bought in Drilling Vessel
description: FORT WORTH, Sept. 29 (UPI)The Western Company of North America said that its drilling subsidiary, Western Oceanic Inc., had bought a half interest in the Alaskan Star, a new semisubmersible drilling vessel and would operate the vessel under a joint agreement with the Exxon Corporation. The drilling vessel is being built at the Mitsubishi yard in Hiroshima, Japan. Western Oceanic operates primarily in the Gulf of Mexico, the Persian Gulf and the Arabian Gulf.

title: Bridge
description: Women experts around the world who have written about the game can be numbered on the fingers of one hand.

title: Radio
description: 7:308:55 A.M., WNYCFM. Till Eulenspiegel's Merry Pranks, Strauss. Piano Concerto in C, Haydn; Flute Sonata in E, Bach; Buckaroo Holiday, Copland; Visions fugitives, ??? Suite No. 3 for Harpsichord and Orchestra, Handet.

title: People and Business
description: Gerrit A. Wagner, president of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company, told New York Security analysts yesterday that demand for oil had improved in the first half of 1976, but he noted that there had been indications in recent months of a flattening in the demand curve.

title: NyquistDyson Feud is Raising Questions and Eyebrows in Albany
description: An unusual public battle over state education policy has erupted between two top state officials, with Governor Carey openly siding with one of them and the rest of the Albany hierarchy wondering where personal feuding leaves off and policymaking begins.

title: Bonn Socialists Pressing Investigation Into Charges Linking Foes to Lockheed
description: BONN, Sept. 29The West German Government announced today, only four days before the general election, that it would appoint a highly qualified judge to chair a special investigation of charges that political opponents of the governing Social Democratic Party took bribes from Lockheed Aircraft in the late 1950's.

title: DR. GEORGE A. BELL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29Dr. George A. Bell, executive director of the National. Association of State Budget Officers, died yesterday after a heart attack at his home in Lexington, Ky. He was 62 years old.

title: Five Croatian Nationalists Charged by Grand Jury With 2dDegree Murder
description: A Manhattan grand jury charged five Croatian nationalists with seconddegree murder in the death of a police officer who was attempting to dismantle a bomb that the group had placed inside a locker at Grand Central Station.

title: ANN LACY
description: Mrs. Ann Lacy, former editor of the Garden Club of America Bulletin, died yesterday at her home in Cleveland. She was 61 years old.

title: SouthWest African Nationalist
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 29For 16 years Sam Nujoma has led a liberation movement, sometimes with weapons but more often these days with words to rally support for an independent Namibiaas the United Nations cals SouthWest Africathe territory that the movement is trying to wrest from South African control. Man in the News

title: Peru Extends Crisis Rule
description: LIMA, Peru, Sept. 29 (Reuters)Peru's military Government today extended a nationwide state of emergency and Lima's night curfew for 30 days. The emergency measures, which make strikes illegal and curtail social life in Lima, were imposed July 1 after serious street disurbanges.

title: Stockton, Richey Advance In $125,000 Coast Tennis
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 (AP)Five seeded players won secondround matches today in the $125,000 Fireman's Fund international tennis tournament at the Cow Palace, but only Dick Stockton of Dallas, seeded No.6, was able to do it in straight sets and without a tiebreaker.

title: Wheat Futures Off In Active Trading; Soybeans Also Fall
description: Wheat futures fell in brisk trading yesmoved below a key support level of $2.93 for December wheat. At that point, heavy selling by local Chicago professional traders took prices down to $2.92 a bushel at the close, off about 8 cents for the day.

title: President's Playmates
description: Republican leaders inevitably deplore current investigations of President Ford's campaign finances in the days when he was a Representative from Michigan. Just, as inevitably they denounce the activity of the investigators as election year politics. And unless Special Watergate Prosecutor Charles Ruff and the F.B.I. find any serious evidence of illicit gifts or irregular contributions to Ford campaigns of the past, it is not to be assumed that Mr. Ford has in any way violated the law. But that is a long way from sayingeven on the basis of White House admissionsthat he is not to be criticized for a glaring lack of sensitivity in the degree which he hobnobbed with the representatives of special interests and freely took their hospitality.

title: NEW YORK WELFARE: BILLION WASTE SEEN
description: Richard V. Horan, New York State's Welfare Inspector General, estimated yesterday that nearly $1 billion, or almost onesixth of welfarerelated costs in New York State, including Medicaid and other services, were being dissipated through recipient and vendor fraud, administrative error or unnecessary and overbilled services.

title: Lunchtime Break Saves Pupils
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 29 (AP)A lunchtime break probably saved many of the more than 1,000 pupils and teachers at Pittsfield High School from Injury today when a propane gas blast ripped through the building. Fire department officials said that the noon blast occurred a wing away from the cateteria, where the pupils were at the time. Four men were injured, three of them slightly.

title: General Accounting Office Reports That Progress of Equal Employment Commission is Limited
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, which for 11 years has worked against discriminatory employment practices, has made only limited progress in eliminating employment discrimination against women and members of minorities, the investigative arm of Congress said in a report issued today.

title: Police Cheers for the Commissioner Turn to Abuse
description: These are hard times for Police Commissioner Michael Joseph Codd. Policemen have picketed his home en masse in the early morning, chanting antiCodd slogans.

title: SPLIT IN CONGRESS OVER ARAB BOYCOTT STALLS I.M.F ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29Congress;onal ratification of the sweeping amendments to the charter of the International Monetary Fund, approved by the House and noncontroversial in the Senate, has been stalled in the waning hours of the session as a consequence of a separate dispute over the Arab boycott of Israel.

title: Chess
description: Two former Russian grandmasters, Leonid Shamkovich and Anatoly Lein, recent immigrants to the United States, won the United States Open Championship in Fairfax, Va., by scoring 10.2 in the Swisssystem tourney.

title: All but 9 Counts Dismissed In Virginia Kepone Case Involving Allied Chemical
description: RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 29 (AP)A Federal judge today dismissed all but nine counts of a 153count indictment that Charged the Allied Chemical Corporation With contributing to pollution of the James River with Kepone, a toxic chemical used in insecticides.

title: Study by H.E.W. Finds Refugees From Asia Adjust to Life in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP)Most of the 138,000 refugees from Indochina who fled to the United States after Communistled victories in Southeast Asia are adjusting to their new country but many suffer from mental depression, a new report to Congress says.

title: Witness Says He Heard Screams After Kallinger Led Victim Away
description: HACKENSACK, Sept. 29A young man who said he heard Maria Fasching's dying screams from the next room pointed out Joseph Kallinger today as the man who had taken him and the 21yearold woman to the basement in Leonia where the murder occurred on Jan. 8. 1975.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the later editions of yesterday's Times, a caption reversed the identifications of Mayor Coleman A. Young of Detroit, and William L. Hart, police chief.

title: Stage: Roundabout Gives Attractive Version of Tired Philanderer
description: The Roundabout Theater has started its latest season, and it is unquestionably the most ambitious yet. It includes Shaw, Ibsen, Anouilh, Beckett, Gorki, a dance series, a guest stint by West Germany's Berlin Schiller Theater and even Emlyn Williams playing Dylan Thomas.

title: Schmidt, Displaying a New Vigor, Predicts Victory in German Vote
description: MAINZ, West Germany, Sept. 28Chancellor Helmut Schmidt says he is now confident he will win the election on Sundaybut with a much thinner majority in Parliament than the 46seat edge he has now.

title: Police Officer on Picket Line, Tries to Give Views
description: Theo P. Vafakos ordinarily walks the city's streets in his blue police uniform. Yesterday, however, the 46yearold police officer was wearing a brown doubleknit suit that was partly cbscared by the huge redandblue picket sign on his chest.

title: American Motors Named in Suit
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 (AP)  The California Air Resources Board filed suit against the American Motors Corporation today to recover $4.3 million in civil penalties assessed for alleged violations of the state's standards for cars, Deputy State Attorney General Gary Wexler, who filed the Superior Court suit, said none of the money had been paid by American Motors, against which the civil penalty was assessed last January.

title: Television
description: 6:00 (5)Read Your Way Up

title: Roots of U.S. Abstract Painting
description: Until about 15 years ago, American abstract painting of the late 1940's and early 50's was thought to be to the history of American art what Niagara Falls is to the flatlands beside Lake Erie: invisible and unimaginable, that is to say, until you are right on top of it. It was a long dull walk to get there, but when you finally made it you were rewarded a thousand times over.

title: Blast Changes Color Of a Victim's Eyes
description: TRENTON, Sept. 29 (AP)John Papierowicz walked out of St. Francis Medical Center a new man today. His eyes changed color.

title: Syrians Report Breakthrough
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 29Syria today reported the defeat of antiSyrian forces and the capture of eight towns and villages in the Lebanese mountains, including the strategically situated town of Ain Tura.

title: Singles Expo Puts Accent on Togetherness
description: Joan Cunningham came to New York three months ago after friends back home in Chicago told her she could be a model. But she is only 5 feet, 6 inches tall, and there are lots of pretty girls in New York City. She hasn't found work yet, and she's lonely.

title: Union Pacific Plans 77 Spending
description: OMAHA, Sept. 29 (UPI)The Union Pacific Railroad said today that it planned to spend $160 million next year for new equipment, including 90 locomotives and 3,079 freight cars. J.C. Kenefick, president of Union Pacific, said that the expenditure represented an increase of $44.5 million over the railroad's 1976 equipment program of $115.8 million for 73 locomotives and 1,780 freight cars.
